Response Message: Title: Case Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Good day everyone   Today  we present the case of Mr. John Smith  an 80-year-old Caucasian male with a history of a symptomatic Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA). This patient's profile is consistent with known epidemiology. According to literature  most cases of AAA are found in Caucasians  and the risk of aneurysm increases significantly after age 65.  Mr. Smith  a retired engineer has been a smoker for the last 60 years and is known to have developed high blood pressure for which he has not been optimally compliant with his antihypertensive medications. He also reports significant alcohol use  which together with smoking and hypertension puts him at higher risk for AAA as per literature.  Mr. Smith’s past medical history is significant for peripheral vascular disease and ischemic heart disease  having had a PTCA (Percutaneous Transluminal Coronary Angioplasty) about 5 years ago. He also has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and hypercholesterolemia. These previous cardiovascular disorders  along with smoking  are commonly associated with the occurrence of AAA in the male population aged 65 years and older per the literature.  Now  let's take a look at the patient’s presentation. Mr. Smith came in complaining of a nagging pain spanning from his abdomen to his lower back  which he mentioned felt different than his usual ""aches and pains"". On examination  a palpable mass was detected in the abdomen with a characteristic pulsation. His vitals were stable at the time of examination.  In terms of diagnostic evaluation  we confirmed the AAA with an abdominal ultrasonography  which revealed an aortic diameter of 5.5 cm consistent with an AAA.  In conclusion  the patient's age  sex  race  history of smoking  hypertension  and previous peripheral and heart disease places him at significantly increased risk for abdominal aortic aneurysm. His AAA is a crucial finding and the care team should proceed with urgency given the risk and implications of rupture.  This case  in summary  brings to light the vital link between demographics  lifestyle habits  and existing co-morbidities in the occurrence and progression of an AAA. It also underscores the importance of compliance to treatment for disorders like hypertension and the necessity for lifestyle modifications like smoking cessation  both of which play a significant role in AAA management.  Thank you for your attention. Let's discuss this case further.

Title: Case Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  I. Introduction We present the case of Mr. Richard Smith  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  representative of the highest risk category as per demographic distribution for AAA in the literature. According to Mosquera et al (2020)  white males aged 65–75 years have the highest prevalence of AAA  while African Americans have the lowest.  II. Presenting complaint Mr. Smith was referred by his general practitioner to our vascular surgery clinic with a newly diagnosed AAA  detected during an abdominal ultrasound performed for unrelated symptoms of dyspepsia. He has been asymptomatic in terms of AAA symptoms.  III. Past Medical History His medical history is significant for Hypertension for the past ten years and he is a current smoker with a 40-pack-year smoking history  each being major risk factors for AAA development. Mr. Smith does not have a family history of AAA  making genetic predisposition unlikely in his case. His lifestyle includes minimal physical activity but he has a balanced diet. He doesn't have diabetes  which paradoxically  according to De Rango et al. (2014)  can have a protective effect against the development of AAA.  IV. Conclusion In summary  Mr. Smith is a 72-year-old Caucasian male smoker presenting with asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm  identified incidentally during an ultrasound carried out for dyspepsia. His past medical history of hypertension and a high smoking index places him at an increased risk for AAA-related complications. His next steps include a detailed evaluation to decide on either surveillance or surgical intervention  depending on the aneurysm size and risk score.   References: 1. Mosquera et al (2020) Impact of race and socioeconomic status on outcomes in abdominal aortic aneurysm. J Vascular Surgery. 71(6): 1953–1962. 2. De Rango et al (2014). Diabetes and abdominal aortic aneurysms. Eur J Vasc Endovasc Surg. 47(3):243-61.

Slide 1: Introduction:  Subject of today's presentation is a patient presenting with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA).   Slide 2: Patient's Summary:  Our patient is a Caucasian male  aged 70  hailing from a middle-income urban setting. In alignment with the literature  Caucasian males over the age of 65 display the highest prevalence rates for AAA.  Slide 3: Patient’s Medical History:  His past medical history subjects: - Hypertension which he's managing with medication - A 50-year pack of smoking history  which is common among many AAA patients as tobacco use is directly related to the development and rupture of AAA. He quit smoking 10 years back.  - Family history of cardiovascular diseases  specifically AAA in his elder brother. Familial predisposition and genetics do play a significant role in the development of AAA.  Slide 4: Clinical Features:  He is symptomatic with classic symptoms of severe  sudden pain in his lower abdomen and back  feeling pulsating enlargement resistant to pressure in the abdomen  syncopal conditions  and general health degradation for the last few weeks.  Slide 5: Diagnosis:  He underwent an ultrasound revealing a large AAA of 5.8 cm in diameter. It is essential to measure the diameter  as the risk of AAA rupture increases once the aneurysm grows above 5.5 cm.  Slide 6: Management:  His management included an immediate surgical consult. Given his age and the size of the AAA  doctors opted for an elective surgical intervention to prevent rupture.  Slide 7: Conclusion:  The patient represents an important demographic group for AAA - older  Caucasian males with a history of smoking. His case underlines the importance of early detection  particularly in patients with a high-risk profile which includes a family history of the disease  hypertension  and significant smoking history.

Title: Presentation of Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Introduction  We would like to present the case of a patient diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) seen in our internal medicine ward.  Demographics and Past Medical History  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a recent record of pulmonary disease and hypertension. His primary language is English. He is a retired car mechanic. The patient is an ex-smoker  having quit about 10 years ago  with a 35-pack year smoking history. He reported moderate alcohol use and denies illicit drug use.  The patient’s family history is noteworthy for heart disease - his father died of myocardial infarction  and his mother suffered from hypertension. He has one brother who had an AAA repaired 5 years ago.  The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension for the past 20 years  adequately managed with medication  chronic obstructive pulmonary disease following his smoking habit  and hyperlipidemia.  Clinical Presentation  The patient visited the Internal Medicine Outpatient Clinic complaining of a pulsating feeling in his abdomen and lower back pain. He described the pain as dull and constant  5 on a 10-point scale  and he denied any aggravating or relieving factors. No symptoms of claudication  extreme fatigue or unexplained weight loss were reported.   The patient is 5’9” tall  weighs about 210 lbs (BMI: 31 kg/m2)  blood pressure was found to be 146/92 mmHg  heart rate of 78 beats per minute and respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute.  Physical examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the mid-abdominal area. No bruits were detected over the mass.  Conclusion  Considering the patient's demographic data  past medical history  habits  and age  he falls into the most common risk group for AAA  i.e.  Caucasian male  over 65  with familial history  smoking history  and hypertension.   The diagnosis was confirmed with an abdominal ultrasound  which showed a 5.5 cm aneurysm in the infra-renal portion of the abdominal aorta. The patient was educated about the need for immediate surgical intervention due to the risk of rupture and was admitted for an elective open surgical repair.   This case exemplifies the typical presentation of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  emphasizing the importance of early detection and management  given the risk of an aortic aneurysm rupture  which carries a high mortality rate.

Title: A Case Presentation on Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Good day everyone  I would like to present to you a case of a patient who has been diagnosed with an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm.  Patient Profile: Our patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired electrician and lives in a retirement facility. The patient is socially active  a non-smoker  and rarely consumes alcohol. He has been married for 47 years and has three adult children.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension since his mid-forties and is currently managed on hydrochlorothiazide. He was also diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia at the same time and manages it with simvastatin. He experienced an ischemic stroke at the age of 68  with a good recovery and minimal residual neurological deficit. There is no known history of aortic aneurysm in his family.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of severe  sudden-onset abdominal and back pain which started an hour ago. He describes the pain as sharp  radiating to his lower back and  unlike anything he has experienced before. Associated symptoms include mild dizziness and shortness of breath. There have been no changes to his bowel habits  and he denies any nausea  vomiting or fever.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  a pulsatile mass was palpable in the abdomen. His blood pressure was found to be slightly lower than his usual readings  and the pulse was rapid but regular. Initial laboratory workup showed slightly elevated white blood cell count and normal kidney function.   Conclusion: Based on the patient’s age  sex  the sudden onset of symptoms  the location and nature of pain  and physical findings  he was suspected to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The diagnosis was confirmed with a Computed Tomography (CT) scan that showed a 7cm diameter abdominal aortic aneurysm  which indicates a high risk of rupture. Immediate surgical intervention was recommended.  Abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) are more common in males and those above 65 years old. Important risk factors include smoking  hypertension  family history  and peripheral artery disease. This case reflects the typical demographic and risk factor profile seen in AAA patients and the workup that confirms the diagnosis. The sudden onset of severe abdominal and back pain in an older patient  particularly with a pulsatile abdominal mass  necessitates an immediate investigation for AAA.  Thank you for your attention. I am available now for any questions.

Title: Presentation of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male Patient  Introduction The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired military officer  presenting with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He is married  a non-smoker  and drinks alcohol occasionally. The patient resides in a suburban area and reports living a relatively sedentary lifestyle post-retirement.  Medical History The patient's medical history reveals the presence of multiple risk factors for AAA. He has hypertension  controlled with medication (Losartan 50mg daily). His lipid profile reports elevated LDL cholesterol levels  and he has been on statin therapy (Simvastatin 20mg at bedtime) for the past five years. He has a history of intermittent claudication - pain in his legs on exertion  which is relieved by rest. The patient also reports reduced appetite and unintended weight loss over the past two months. There is no history of diabetes  renal disease  or any other significant chronic illnesses. No known drug allergies. Family history significant for father dying in his 70s from 'ruptured artery'.  Symptoms Today  the patient reports experiencing a constant  unsettling pain in the lower back and abdominal region  which he describes as deep  throbbing and different from any he's experienced before. He rates the pain as a 7 on a scale of 10 and explains the pain does not seem to radiate or shift. He denies any recent trauma to the area.   Conclusion The patient's age  male gender  family history  and presence of cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension and high cholesterol  along with the mentioned symptoms  strongly suggest abdominal aortic aneurysm. Though men over 65 who have ever smoked are most at risk for AAA  cessation of smoking and control of blood pressure can help manage the condition. This patient will require an immediate diagnostic workup for further evaluation and treatment planning.

Title: A Case Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Profile: I present Mr. John Smith  a 70-year-old Caucasian male who has been brought in complaining of a pulsating feeling in his abdomen accompanied by constant and severe abdominal and back pain.  Background and Demographics: Research indicates that approximately 80% of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysms (AAA) occur in males over the age of 65. Caucasian populations are also more susceptible  with Hispanic and Asian populations having the lowest rates. Our patient's age  gender and race  therefore  aligns closely with the typical demographic profile for this disease.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith is a former smoker and has been managing hypertension and hypercholesterolemia for the past 15 years. For both conditions  he has been on medication (ACE inhibitors for hypertension  and statins for hypercholesterolemia). His family history reveals that his father passed away due to an AAA rupture in his late sixties. Mr. Smith's smoking history  age  the presence of cardiovascular disease  and family history are significant  as they are recognized risk factors for developing an AAA.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Smith describes feeling a throbbing sensation in his abdomen for the past couple of weeks  which he initially assumed was related to digestive issues. Today  however  he reports the onset of sudden and severe pain in the middle and lower parts of his abdomen and back. He denies any associated nausea  vomiting  or changes in bowel movements. He also reports feeling lightheaded recently. The nature and location of his pain  his lightheadedness  together with his demographics and medical history  raise a high suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  As the case is presented  further investigations such as an ultrasound or Computed Tomography (CT) scan would be recommended to confirm this preliminary diagnosis and assess the size and location of the aneurysm. It's also crucial to evaluate signs that might indicate imminent rupture  given the severity of his symptoms and his father's medical history. The goal must be to stably manage the patient and prevent rupture if confirmed AAA is in its early and intermediate stages. If the AAA is at significant size or any signs indicate a risk of rupture  surgical intervention may be necessary.

Presentation  Patient Information: A 70-year-old Caucasian male patient presenting from his primary care's office.  Chief Complaint: The patient reports experiencing a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain  accompanied by lightheadedness and a rapid heart rate.  Demographics: The patient is a retired military officer  a lifetime non-smoker  moderate drinker  and has an active lifestyle including regular exercise. He has a well-rounded diet but a family history of cardiovascular disease. He is currently living independently with his spouse.  Medical History: The patient has been diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia about five years ago  which is under control with medication. The patient also experienced myocardial infarction ten years prior  which was managed with angioplasty and a stent placement. He is currently on medication including a beta-blocker (Metoprolol)  a statin (Rosuvastatin)  and a daily aspirin. His most recent blood work had shown elevated cholesterol levels  slightly above his target range.   Present Illness: The patient has been healthy until about 4 hours before his admission when he experienced a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain. The pain is described as sharp  constant  and radiating to his lower back. He also reports feeling lightheaded  which made him see his primary care physician immediately.  Conclusion: This patient's complaints may signify a potentially life-threatening condition like an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  which is common among older Caucasian men  particularly among those with a history of cardiovascular disease  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia.  Plan: An immediate imaging study (such as a CT scan or ultrasound) is recommended to confirm the diagnosis of AAA. Should AAA be confirmed  the patient must be immediately referred to the vascular surgery team.

Title: A Case Presentation with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Subject: Mr. Green  a 72-year-old Caucasian male.   Introduction:  Mr. Green presented at the hospital today with severe abdominal pain. He is a retired construction site foreman living in a suburban residential setting and is a nonsmoker. As per CDC's report  individuals aged 65 and older  males  and Caucasian demographic are at the highest risk of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) and Mr. Green’s symptoms suggest a possible AAA.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Green has a significant medical history relevant to his current possible diagnosis. He has been diagnosed with hypertension and atherosclerosis  both of which are potential risk factors for developing an AAA. His blood pressure is well-controlled with medications (Lisinopril)  and he takes low-dose Aspirin for his cardiovascular disease. He does not have any known allergies to medication. It is to be noted that he has got a family history of AAA  as his father passed away due to an AAA rupture at the age of 75. Mr. Green's lipid panel conducted six months ago showed elevated levels of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C)  a potential risk factor for AAA.  Social History:  Mr. Green is a widower who lives with his daughter. He is a nonsmoker and a social drinker. He has a limited exercise routine primed by general flexibility and strength workouts. He follows a balanced diet but loves indulging in sugary delicacies on weekends.   Current Condition and Symptoms:  Mr. Green reports severe  sudden-onset abdominal pain that radiates to his lower back. He also complains of a pulsating sensation in his abdomen  similar to a ""heart beating."" There is no history of trauma. He has never had similar symptoms before.   Potential Diagnosis: Considering his past medical history  age  ethnicity  typical clinical symptoms  and risk factors such as hypertension  high LDL-C levels  atherosclerosis  and family history of AAA  an abdominal aortic aneurysm is strongly suspected.   Further assessment will focus on confirming the abdominal aortic aneurysm diagnosis and staging its severity. This will typically involve a physical examination  a detailed medical and family history  and diagnostic tests such as an ultrasound or CT scan.   Management and plan: If confirmed  the treatment approach will depend upon the size and rate at which the aneurysm is growing. Patients with smaller aneurysms may require careful observation and regular monitoring. However  patients with larger or rapidly growing aneurysms might need surgical intervention.   Our next steps will include initiating conversations with Mr. Green about the potential diagnosis and arranging for appropriate diagnostic tests. We will also consider referring him to a vascular surgeon for further management.

Subject Title: A Case Presentation on a 65-year old Caucasian Male Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Demographic Information: The patient is a 65-year old male of non-Hispanic  Caucasian ethnicity. He is retired  lives with his wife in a suburban locality  and is a current smoker with a smoking history of about 40 years. He has no known drug allergies. He has a BMI of 27 and is mildly obese.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol  controlled through medications. He was diagnosed with coronary artery disease five years ago and had a percutaneous transluminal coronary angioplasty (PTCA) performed. There is also a family history of cardiovascular disease  as his father passed away at the age of 57 due to myocardial infarction. No history of diabetes  peripheral vascular disease  liver disease  kidney disease or stroke. He frequently drinks alcohol  indicative of a lifestyle quite associated with common risk factors.  Current Symptoms: The patient presented with a newly noticed pulsating mass in the mid-upper abdomen  associated with a dull ache in the lower back region. No complaints of chest pain  shortness of breath  or lower extremity edema. No presenting signs of hypotension  claudication  or limb ischemia  suggestive of rupture or dissection.  Initial Presentation: On physical examination  a palpable  pulsating mass around 3 cm in diameter is found in the epigastrium region. Abdomen is soft  non-tender  and bowel sounds are normal. No auscultated bruits. No visible distention  and no signs of peripheral cyanosis or pallor. His vitals are stable with blood pressure recorded as 140/90 mm Hg  heart rate - 78 bpm  respirations – 16 per/min  and temperature – 98.7 F.  In concordance with the patient’s demographic and clinical presentation  this fits well to the epidemiological data around Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm which is more prevalent among Caucasian males  in the age group 65-75 and closely associated with smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and family history of cardiovascular diseases. His complaints and examination findings further raise the suspicion of AAA.   Course of Action: The patient has been advised for an urgent abdominal ultrasound and other necessary cardiovascular investigations  including blood profile  for the confirmation and assessment of AAA. Contact with a vascular surgeon has been initiated for pre-operative assessments in case surgical interventions are needed. The patient is also referred to a smoking cessation clinic to help manage his risk factors better.   Conclusion: From the case-specific factors and risk stratification  it can be observed that the patient falls under a high-risk category for AAA. Prompt diagnosis and management  screening for other possible atherosclerotic diseases and lifestyle modifications need to be part of this aging male's comprehensive care plan.

Title: Clinical Presentation of A Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile: The presenting patient is Mr. John Doe  a 72-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired engineer living with his wife in a suburban community.  Medical History: Mr. Doe is a former smoker  having quit a 10-year  one-pack-per-day smoking habit 20 years ago. His medical history is significant for hypertension  which has been controlled for the last 15 years with a regimen of beta-blockers and diuretics. His father died from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 84. Mr. Doe's BMI is 27  indicating that he is slightly overweight. Additionally  he enjoys a diet high in fats and cholesterol  and has an irregular exercise routine. There is no history of diabetes mellitus or coronary artery disease. He consumes alcohol socially.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Doe visited his GP with complaints of dull constant pain in his lower back and abdominal area for the past two weeks. The pain occasionally radiates to the groin area and is not associated with any particular food intake or physical activity. He reports no changes in bowel habits  urinary symptoms  weight loss  or appetite.  Provisional Diagnosis: Given the patient's age  gender  history of smoking  hypertension  high-fat diet  family history  and consistent pain in the abdomen and back  there is a suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   Epidemiological Data: AAA has a propensity to be asymptomatic until rupture. AAAs are most commonly found in males aged over 65 years  predominantly in those of Caucasian ethnicity. The risk factors present in our patient — age  gender  hypertension  smoking history  and family history — support this diagnosis.  Conclusion: While AAA is a life-threatening condition  early identification provides a good prognosis. Mr. Doe's demographic profile and symptoms warrant further diagnostic examinations  such as ultrasound  CT scan  or MRI  to confirm the AAA diagnosis and establish the aneurysm's extent. Once confirmed  a treatment plan including possible surgery  lifestyle changes  and close watch for any aneurysm growth will be implemented.  References: Li.  X. & Zhao.  J. (2018). The epidemiology of abdominal aortic aneurysm. International Journal of Clinical and Experimental Medicine. 11(3): 2109-2120.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Case Presentation   Slide 1: Presentation  Patient: Mr. Johnson  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presents with a chief complaint of abdominal pain and back discomfort  persistent over the last week. The pain is a dull ache that is intermittent but recently has become constant.   Slide 2: Past Medical History  Mr. Johnson has been hypertensive for 25 years  managed by antihypertensive medication (Lisinopril). Additionally  he was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia five years ago and is currently on Atorvastatin. Patient has a 40 pack-years history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. No known history of any other systemic disease.   Slide 3: Patient Distribution in Literature   Research shows that the prevalence of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is higher in older male populations  particularly those of Caucasian descent  with traditional cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking history. Our patient Mr. Johnson  hence  falls into the high-risk category.   Slide 4: Clinical Presentation  At presentation  Mr. Johnson appears uncomfortable due to pain. On examination  a pulsatile mass is palpable in the abdominal region. The severity of his symptoms and clinical presentation raise concern for an impending rupture of AAA.   Slide 5: Diagnostic Tests  Laboratory findings indicate an elevated white cell count (leukocytosis) that suggests possible inflammation/infection. An abdominal ultrasound reveals an aortic aneurysm measuring 5.5 cm in diameter  confirming the diagnosis of AAA.    Slide 6: Conclusion   Given Mr. Johnson's age  gender  racial background  and past medical history  he embodies the typical demographic profile of patients with abdominal aortic aneurysms. His current clinical presentation  along with diagnostic findings  confirms the diagnosis of AAA. The large size and associated symptoms warrant urgent medical attention to prevent life-threatening complications such as aortic rupture.   Slide 7: Management & Follow-Up Care   Immediate surgical intervention is required  likely endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  to manage the large  symptomatic AAA. Postoperatively and in the long term  it is crucial for Mr. Johnson to adhere to his antihypertensive and lipid-lowering medications and maintain regular follow-up appointments for the surveillance of his cardiovascular health.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Profile: Mr. Johnson is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presents with a newly identified suspected abdominal aortic aneurysm. He is a retired steel mill worker and resides in a rural setting with his wife. He has history of heavy smoking for the past 40 years  although he quit smoking 5 years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally and has a sedentary lifestyle.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Johnson initially presented with vague abdominal pain that was primarily observed in the mid-abdominal region radiating towards the back. He also reports experiencing occasional bouts of mild to moderate back pain. There was no noted trigger or particular character to the pain  nor could pain be linked to any food intake or physical activity.  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He has been on medication for the same for a decade. He has had no prior surgeries and has no known allergies. The patient is also at risk for cardiovascular diseases due to his previous habit of heavy smoking.  Family History: There is a significant family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father having passed away from a heart attack at a relatively young age. His older brother underwent surgery for an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 73.  Behavioral History: He has a 40 pack-year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially and moderately. His diet is moderate in fat and salt.   Physical Examination: The patient is alert  oriented  and vitally stable. An abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the epigastric region. Blood pressure was consistently higher on the right arm compared to the left.  Given the patient's age  sex  history of tobacco use  presence of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and family history of AAA  he falls into a high-risk category for abdominal aortic aneurysm. This underlines the need for further investigation and management strategy to prevent devastating complications such as rupture.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Slide 1: Introduction to Case Study  Mr. Clifford Smith  an 70-year-old Caucasian male  presents today complaining of unexplained and persistent lower back pain  abdominal pain  and slight nausea. Upon further probing  he reveals his father underwent surgery for an aortic aneurysm at age 75.  Slide 2: Patient Profile  To elaborate  Mr. Smith is a retired school teacher who lives independently. He is a widowed father of three children who  thankfully  do not report similar complaints. Mr. Smith has a 45-year history of cigarette smoking  though he quit five years ago  and currently  he drinks alcohol occasionally.   Slide 3: Medical History  Mr. Smith has a 10-year history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  both of which are well-controlled by medications. He is also being managed for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and had a myocardial infarction 8 years ago.  Slide 4: Social and Family History  Previously mention of his father’s aortic aneurysm is raising concern  coupled with his smoking. The patient leads a relatively active lifestyle and has maintained a healthy diet.   Slide 5: Current Presentation  Over the last week  Mr. Smith has been experiencing a sharp  constant low-back pain and  more recently  nausea. No changes in bowel movements. The pain does not radiate  but it intensifies when he stands or walks around.  Slide 6: Current Examination  Physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass and slight tenderness in his lower abdomen. His vital signs are stable  but an abdominal bruit is audible.  Slide 7: Presumption and Next Steps  This cumulative picture  compounded by his personal and family history  social habits  and current physical findings  suggests the possibility of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Laboratory tests and a confirmatory CT are warranted to substantiate this suspicion.  Slide 8: Conclusion  Given the risk factors and symptoms  there is a high suspicion for AAA in Mr. Smith. Early detection  surveillance  and appropriate intervention  can prevent catastrophic outcomes associated with ruptured AAA. Patient education is similarly crucial  given the hereditary nature of AAA.   Slide 9: Acknowledgments  Appreciate the contribution of multidisciplinary teams in managing case and the field's continuous efforts in understanding AAA.   Slide 10: References  Citations from relevant literature on abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Title: A Case Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  I. Demographics  The patient is Mr. Wilson  a 70-year-old Caucasian male. He is retired  lives alone in a suburban community  and was previously engaged in an office-based job. Throughout his career  he was mostly sedentary  following a typical western diet throughout his life without regular physical activity.  II. Presenting Concerns  Mr. Wilson arrived at the emergency department complaining of severe  persistent back pain  which he describes as ""tearing"" accompanied by light-headedness and sweating. On examination  we noticed a pulsating mass in his abdomen.  III. Past Medical History  Mr. Wilson has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol  primarily managed through medication for over 15 years. He smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for about 45 years before he quit 10 years ago. He also has a significant family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father having died from a myocardial infarction in his late 60s and his brother having undergone an aortic aneurysm repair.  IV. Reason for Presentation  The type of pain Mr. Wilson describes along with the exam findings are indicative of an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture or dissection  a life-threatening condition that requires immediate surgical attention. Risk factors such as age  male gender  Caucasian race  smoking history  and family history are consistent with what literature suggests regarding those most at risk for abdominal aortic aneurysms. His hypertension and high cholesterol  coupled with an insufficient physical exercise regimen  may have influenced the development of his aneurysm.  V. Discussion  Abdominal aortic aneurysms are more prevalent during the sixth and seventh decades of life  being about 4-6 times common in men than women. They are also more common among Caucasians. Key risk factors are age  family history  smoking  and atherosclerosis. In many cases  like Mr. Wilson's  these aneurysms might not cause noticeable symptoms until they rupture leading to life-threatening internal bleeding. The intense back or abdominal pain  together with a pulsating abdominal mass  is conventionally considered an ominously sign indicative of an impending or current rupture.  By observing Mr. Wilson's case  it is clear how essential it is to identify and manage the risk factors associated with cardiovascular diseases. Detection and appropriate management of aneurysms and their risk factors can significantly reduce morbidity and mortality rates associated with abdominal aortic aneurysms.  In summary  having access to a patient's comprehensive medical history  evaluating their symptoms to ensure early detection  and implementing effective treatment strategies can play a pivotal role in improving the prognosis of patients like Mr. Wilson with abdominal aortic aneurysms.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient: Mr. Smith  Age: 73 Gender: Male  Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired  Residential Location: Rural Midwestern USA   Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Smith arrived to the hospital with complaints of intermittent lower abdominal discomfort and low back pain over the course of six months.   Background Information: He is a former machine shop worker and has been retired for eight years. He lives with his wife in a rural Midwestern community.   Past Medical History: Mr. Smith's medical history reveals he is a former heavy smoker with a 50-pack-year history but quit smoking a decade ago upon his physician's advice. He has a known diagnosis of high blood pressure  managed by a thiazide diuretic and an ACE inhibitor. He also has a history of high cholesterol and is currently on statin therapy. He also has mild Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)  possibly due to his extensive smoking history.   Family History: His older brother died suddenly at the age of 75 from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   Present Illness: Since his retirement  Mr. Smith has reported no significant weight loss  fever  or reduction in appetite. But his recurring abdominal and lower back discomfort raised concerns. His abdomen was pulsating upon physical examination and an abdominal ultrasound confirmed a 5.6 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm.   This case is typical  as AAA is most common in men between the ages of 65 and 75  particularly among Caucasians. The risk factors such as smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  COPD  and positive family history are also consistent with the demographics of patients commonly diagnosed with AAA.   In this case  the AAA has reached a size threshold that makes surgical intervention strongly considered to prevent rupture. The patient has been referred to a vascular surgeon for further management.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Demographics:  Our patient under discussion is a 72-year-old male of Caucasian descent  named Mr. John Turner. He hails from a mid-income socioeconomic background and has been residing in the suburban region of Atlanta  Georgia for past several years. Mr. Turner is a retiree with a history of occasional alcohol consumption and long-term tobacco use which dates back to at least 30 years. In terms of familial background  hypertension and heart diseases prevail in his lineage.  Summary of Past Medical History:  Mr. Turner has a documented medical history of high blood pressure for which he has been prescribed anti-hypertensive medication and low dose aspirin. In 2007  he underwent a gallbladder removal operation due to gallstones. He also suffers from Hyperlipidemia and has been under lipid-lowering pharmacotherapy for the same.  The patient claims to have maintained an exercise regimen for over a decade  and he follows a balanced diet as advised by a nutritionist. Recently  he has been experiencing unexplained weight loss and decreased appetite.  Presenting Symptoms:  Mr. Turner has recently begun seeking medical assistance for persistent and almost debilitating abdominal pain that radiates towards his lower back. He reports a pulsing sensation in his abdomen akin to a heartbeat. The pain and discomfort have been erratic but intense  keeping him awake at night or disrupting his daily activities.  From a literature perspective  Mr. Turner's demographic profile of being an elderly  white male with a history of hypertension and smoking aligns with the major risk factors associated with abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA). The manifestations  including the pervading abdominal and back pain  pulsing sensation in the abdomen  and unexplained weight loss  further bolster the probability of AAA.  In light of these factors  we suggest Mr. Turner to undergo immediate radiologic examinations such as ultrasound or computerized tomography (CT) to check for the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Conclusion:  Abdominal aortic aneurysms are life-threatening if ruptured. Therefore  early diagnosis and appropriate intervention are crucial  particularly for individuals who fall within the high-risk groups like Mr. Turner. If an aneurysm is confirmed  Mr. Turner may require endovascular surgery or open aneurysm repair  in parallel with management of his hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Note:  This presentation of an abdominal aortic aneurysm is not exhaustive and other symptoms such as lethargy  dizziness  or fainting spells could also be valuable indicators. Each patient could present differently and should be evaluated holistically.

Patient Presentation  The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of long-term smoking and uncontrolled hypertension. He comes in complaining of intense abdominal pain off and on for the last three weeks. The pain is dull  a constant gnawing feeling  which radiates to his lower back. The patient denies any fever  nausea  vomiting  weight loss  or changes in bowel habits. He also reported a noticeable pulsing feeling in his abdomen.  On examination  the patient appeared slightly pale and anxious. An abdominal examination reveals a palpable pulsatile mass in the middle and lower part of the abdomen. Upon auscultation  a vascular bruit is noted. There’s no evidence of abdominal bruit or renal bruit. There is no peripheral edema and peripheral pulses are equal and symmetrical in all four limbs.   He reports no previous surgeries but his medical history is pertinent for coronary artery disease  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  all of which were managed with suitable medications. He admits that he has been a heavy smoker for about 50 years and consumes alcohol occasionally.   The demographic information of the patient is typical for abdominal aortic aneurysms as it is most commonly seen in Caucasian males over the age of 65. Risk factors include a positive family history  long-term smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and coronary artery disease. He has been advised for immediate hospital admission for further investigation  monitoring and suitable management plan.   Immediately ordered is a Contrast-enhanced CT Scan of the abdomen and pelvis for the confirmation of the suspected diagnosis and to determine the size and exact location of the aneurysm. Patient and family has been made aware of the serious nature of this potentially life-threatening condition and the need for possible surgical intervention.

Title: Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 70-year-old Caucasian Male   I. Patient Demographics The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. John Smith with a delayed presentation. He is 6' tall and weighs 200lbs  giving him a BMI of 27.1. The patient lives in a rural area of Indiana  is a retired steelworker  and his family history is significant for cardiovascular disease. He is a former smoker  quit 10 years ago  with a 30-pack-year history. He consumes moderate alcohol.  Mr. Smith is a widower with two adult children. One of his sons succumbed to coronary artery disease in his 50s. The patient is independent in his activities of daily living and denies recent falls.  II. Past Medical History Mr. Smith has a history of coronary artery disease for which he underwent coronary artery bypass grafting 7 years ago. He has hypertension managed with Lisinopril and Atenolol  and he also has dyslipidemia for which he takes Simvastatin. He has been diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus and is on Metformin. He is regular on his medications. There is no history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease  asthma  stroke  chronic kidney disease  or liver disease.  III. Presenting Issue Mr. Smith came in today complaining of intermittent and vague abdominal pain with some radiating discomfort to his back. Review of systems was negative for gastrointestinal or genitourinary symptoms. There were no associated complaints of shortness of breath  chest pain  cough  weakness  palpitations  or fever.   IV. Conclusion  In summary  Mr. Smith is a retired Caucasian male with a high risk of cardiovascular disease  given his age  gender  history of smoking and family history. He presents with abdominal pain  which may be consistent with an abdominal aortic aneurysm given his demographics and past medical history. This suspicion necessitates further investigation with an abdominal ultrasound.

Title: A Case Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile: Presenting today is Mr. Smith  a 70-year-old Caucasian male who belongs to the demographic group most commonly affected by abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA). He is a retired military officer  a lifetime smoker with a 50-pack year history  and drinks alcohol occasionally. He is currently living alone and manages his day-to-day life independently.  Medical History: Mr. Smith has a notable past medical history  which significantly includes hypertension controlled with medication. He also reports a past history of intermittent claudication and coronary artery disease. There is family history as well; his father died at age 65 due to reported 'aortic rupture.' He has been non-compliant with his regular health screenings which includes abdominal ultrasound  despite his doctor recommending them due to his father's history and his significant risk factor for AAA - smoking.  Presenting Complaint: Currently  he has been experiencing a subtle and constant pain in his lower back and abdomen  which he initially associated with aging. The pain has progressed over the past two months and has started to affect his quality of life. His intestinal functions are largely unaffected. He denies any related symptoms such as recent weight loss  changes in appetite  or fever.   Physical Examination: On physical examination  he has a non-tender  pulsatile mass palpable in the umbilical area  suspecting towards AAA. His peripheral pulses are equal bilaterally.  This case presentation clearly demands an immediate investigation for the suspicion of an AAA  with the risk of rupture being of immediate concern. Credentialing his significant risk factors  a definitive diagnosis must be made using the appropriate imaging modality and a suitable treatment plan devised promptly thereafter.   Such a case represents a classic AAA presentation typically seen in elderly males. It highlights the need for aggressive screening and counseling for high-risk individuals such as avid smokers and those with a family history of AAA. Mr. Smith will definitely require a multi-disciplinary approach that involves cardiology  gastroenterology  and vascular surgery for a comprehensive care and follow-up plan.

Title: A Case of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Demographics: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired from a career in construction. He has a significant smoking history of 40 pack-years but quit smoking five years ago. According to data from the United States  Caucasian males above the age of 65 have shown a higher predisposition to AAA.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient was brought into the ER with complaints of severe  sudden onset of abdominal pain  characterized as tearing and radiating to his back along with a faint feeling and sweating. Recent research highlights that patients with AAA commonly present with these symptoms.  Medical History: His medical history includes hypertension controlled with medication  hyperlipidemia  and a history of moderate alcohol use. He has been diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease earlier. He denies any significant family history of AAA. Studies have shown that hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and peripheral arterial disease are substantial risk factors for AAA.  Physical Examination: Upon physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was noticed near the umbilical area. Vital signs revealed blood pressure of 170/95 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats/min  respiratory rate of 20 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation of 93% on room air. Literature reports that in most cases of AAA  a pulsatile mass is often palpable in the abdominal region.  The above medical history coupled with the physical examination and symptoms led to a suspicion of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm. Further diagnostic tests were ordered which confirmed the presence of AAA.  In conclusion  the patient’s demographic details  history of smoking  hypertension  and peripheral arterial disease  coupled with his presenting symptoms and physical examination findings  are consistent with the common presentation of AAA.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male Patient   Patient Presentation: The patient is a 74-year-old Caucasian male with a known medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking  reflecting the major risk factors stated in the literature  including age  gender  history of cardiovascular disease  and smoking.   The patient presents with a feeling of pulsating sensations around his abdomen  which he describes as uncharacteristic. Moreover  he expresses concerns about intermittent  and recently  more frequent  episodes of intense abdominal  back pain  and tenderness. These symptoms  in literature  are often associated with an enlarging or rupturing abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   The remainder of his medical history reveals no history of surgical procedures  diabetes mellitus or renal disease but reports a family history of AAA. His grandfather on his mother’s side passed away due to complications related to AAA rupture. He lives alone and is a retired manual laborer. He has been smoking half a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 35 years  consumes alcohol moderately  and has a diet lacking adequate fresh fruits and vegetables.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient is in obvious discomfort due to the abdominal pain. He is not jaundiced or cyanosed. On auscultation  a soft bruit is heard over the umbilical region. His radial and pedal pulses are palpable and normal. Pain is elicited upon palpation of the abdomen which also revealed a pulsatile mass  which is usually not palpable unless an AAA is present.   In older male patients with a history of smoking and hypertension  clinical suspicion should be high for AAA  prompting immediate diagnostic confirmation and management. In this case  the patient's age  sex  family history  and current symptoms strongly indicate AAA as a potential diagnosis.   Follow-Up and Management: The patient was sent for an immediate ultrasound of the abdomen and referred to a vascular surgeon for further evaluation and management.   This case serves as a reminder that abdominal aortic aneurysm  although asymptomatic in its early stages  can present with serious symptoms upon enlargement or rupture. Risk factors such as male sex  advanced age  smoking history  and hypertension should increase clinical suspicion  prompting immediate investigation and management.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male Patient  Patient Presentation: Mr. John Doe  a 73-year-old male Caucasian patient  presented with consistent  throbbing pain in the lower left side of his abdomen for the past 48 hours. He also mentions experiencing lower back pain  which he initially attributed to his age and previous back injuries. Doe is primarily sedentary; due to being retired  he has a low physical activity level. He is also a former smoker with a 30 pack-year history  but he quit smoking 10 years ago.  Complete demographic information: Doe was born and raised in Portland  Oregon  USA  which is where he currently resides. He's a retiree  having worked as an electrician for 35 years. He lives alone since his wife passed away five years ago. His children live close by and visit him regularly. He has a sufficient income drawn from his retirement savings and social security  has no history of alcohol or drug abuse.  Past Medical History: His past medical history includes congestive heart failure and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  for which he takes prescribed medications regularly. He also has a history of back injuries due to a fall from a ladder about 15 years ago. His regular medications include diuretics  beta-blockers  and bronchodilators.  In terms of family history  there's a history of cardiovascular disease. His father died of a heart attack at the age of 68  and his older brother recently underwent a bypass surgery for coronary artery disease.   The prevalence of abdominal aortic aneurysm is higher in older males and in those of Caucasian descent  according to the literature. Other risk factors our patient has include his history of smoking and cardiovascular disease  both of which are strongly associated with abdominal aortic aneurysms.  Given the symptoms presented  it is crucial to consider an abdominal aortic aneurysm as a possible diagnosis and further investigations such as an abdominal ultrasound or CT angiography should be pursued promptly.  This case underscores the importance of clinical vigilance in managing elderly patients with multiple risk factors for cardiovascular diseases. Early recognition  timely intervention  and holistic management of these patients can significantly improve their quality of life and longevity.

Slide 1: Introduction  Title: Case Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Slide 2: Patient Information   Our patient is a Caucasian male  aged 72  named Mr. Johan Smith. He is a retired mechanic from Florida. According to literature  men aged 65-75 with a history of smoking like our patient are most at risk of developing an abdominal aortic aneurysm.   Slide 3: Patient's Social History   Mr. Smith is a widow with two adult children  has a 40 pack-year smoking history  though he quit about 10 years back. He denies alcohol and recreational drug use. He leads a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity.  Slide 4: Past Medical History  Mr. Smith has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol levels  for which he has been on medication for the past decade. He also suffered from a mild stroke 5 years ago but recovered fully. No known allergies are reported.  Slide 5: Current Complaint  Mr. Smith presented with mild to moderate abdominal pain and lower back pain  lasting for several days. He described a pulsating sensation in his abdomen  which prompted him to seek medical help. No other symptoms were reported.  Slide 6: Preliminary Diagnosis  Considering the patient’s age  gender  smoking history  hypertension  and high cholesterol levels  his abdominal pain  lower back pain  and pulsating sensation in the abdomen  a preliminary diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm is made.  Slide 7: Additional Diagnostic Tools  To confirm the diagnosis  an abdominal ultrasound will be conducted to visualize the aorta. If necessary  a CT scan or MRI may also be employed.  Slide 8: Risk Factors  Strong risk factors in this case include advanced age  male gender  history of smoking  presence of hypertension and high cholesterol levels  and family history.  Slide 9: Conclusion  Understanding these risk factors and making an early diagnosis is essential for effective management of abdominal aortic aneurysm and can significantly reduce the mortality rate from aortic rupture.

Title: Case Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Patient Profile: Mr. Abraham Henderson is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired marine engineer  a resident of Alabama. He lives with his wife and is an active smoker with a 50 pack-year smoking history. He consumes alcohol occasionally and follows an average diet. He has been under observation for hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past ten years. His BMI is 28 and he does not exercise regularly.   Presenting Complaints: He presents with complaints of intermittent abdominal pain and a pulsatile mass in his abdomen  which he has been experiencing for the past week.   Past Medical History: Mr. Henderson has a significant medical history including hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 10-year history of tobacco use post-diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) ten years ago. He has been on antihypertensives and statins for the last ten years. His father  a smoker  passed away due to a ruptured aortic aneurysm at the age of 80.  Clinical examination: On examination  a pulsating mass was palpable in his abdomen  indicative of an aneurysm. All other organ systems showed no significant abnormalities.   Diagnosis Assumption: Based on his presenting symptoms  medical history  risk factors (age  gender  smoking  hypertension  and family history)  and physical examination  Mr. Henderson is suspected to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). A confirmatory test such as Aorta Ultrasonography or CT scan has been planned.  This case illustrates the importance of routine screening  focusing on comorbid conditions  individual risk and lifestyle changes in older adults for AAA.  P.S: Demographics and other details are based on the epidemiological findings indicating that AAA is most commonly found in older men (>65 years)  have smoked  have a history of hypertension or hyperlipidemia  and in individuals of Caucasian ethnicity.

Patient Presentation  Introduction:  Today  we discuss Mr. Joseph Sullivan  a 71-year-old Caucasian male presenting with a suspected Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA). This case was selected as AAA overwhelmingly affects older males  particularly those of a Caucasian background. The prevalence of AAA increases with age and is usually found among men aged 65-75 years.  Chief Complaint:  Mr. Sullivan visited the clinic with a complaining of a pulsating feeling in his abdomen  alongside chronic back pain. On some instances  he experienced sudden  intense abdominal pain.   History of Present Illness:  The patient’s symptoms have been lingering on for the past 6 months  initially dismissing it as a minor case of back pain. However  the escalating severity of the pain and constant pulsating sensation in his abdomen led him to seek medical consultation.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Sullivan has a significant past medical history  being a long-term smoker with close to 40 pack-years. He also has a documented history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  both being risk factors for AAA. There is no known history of AAA in his family. As a former construction worker  he's led a fairly active lifestyle  yet with poor dietary habits.   Physical Examination:  On physical examination  he was found to have an irregular abdominal mass that pulsates with the heartbeat. Additionally  he appears mildly distressed due to abdominal pain.  This case displays a typical presentation of AAA with its most common risk factors: age  male gender  smoking  hypertension  and Caucasian ethnicity. Considering the risk of rupture  timely identification and appropriate management of AAA are crucial to decrease morbidity and mortality rates associated with this condition. Further imaging tests would need to be conducted to confirm AAA and its size. If the diagnosis is confirmed  management could range from surveillance to surgical intervention  depending on the size of the aneurysm and symptomatology.

Title: Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Slide 1: Title: Patient Demographics - Patient : Caucasian Male  Age: 72 years - Occupation: Retired Civil Engineer  - Place of residence: Urban area  Midwest United States  Rationale: Abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAAs) are the most common type of aortic aneurysm and are particularly prevalent in older  Caucasian men. Literature suggests that the incidence is significantly high in urban areas and among the white population[1].  Slide 2: Title: Lifestyle & Social History  - Smoking History: Ex-smoker  quit 10 years ago - Alcohol: Chronic mild alcohol use - No illicit drug use   Rationale: Studies have found strong correlations between AAA development and a past history of smoking and moderate alcohol usage[2].  Slide 3: Title: Family History - Father died at 68  cause of death: Ruptured AAA - Mother deceased at 80 from natural causes  Rationale: Family history is a prevalent risk factor associated with AAAs[3].  Slide 4: Title: Past Medical History - Hypertension controlled with medications - High cholesterol managed with diet and medications - Previous history of peripheral artery disease (PAD)  Rationale: Hypertension  high cholesterol  and PAD are all common comorbidities associated with AAA[4].  Slide 5:  Title: Current Presentation - Symptom: Intermittent severe abdominal and back pain. - Physical Examination: Abdominal distension with a palpable pulsatile mass.  Rationale: A large percentage of AAA patients are asymptomatic; however  the most common symptoms when present are intermittent severe abdominal and back pain  and a pulsatile mass on physical examination.  References: [1] Norman PE  Powell JT. Abdominal aortic aneurysm: the prognosis in women is worse than in men. Circulation. 2007;115(22):2865-2869. [2] Kent KC. Clinical practice. Abdominal aortic aneurysms. N Engl J Med. 2014;371(22):2101-2108. [3] Powell JT  Greenhalgh RM. Clinical practice. Small abdominal aortic aneurysms. N Engl J Med. 2003;348(19):1895-1901. [4] Ashton HA  Buxton MJ  Day NE  et al. The Multicentre Aneurysm Screening Study (MASS) into the effect of abdominal aortic aneurysm screening on mortality in men: a randomized controlled trial. Lancet. 2002;360(9345):1531-1539.

Presentation of Patient  Our patient  Mr. Johnson  a 75-year-old Caucasian male  presents with a suspected abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   Demographics  Epidemiological studies indicate the demographics most likely to be affected by AAA are Caucasian males over the age of 60. It is estimated that 4-7% of Caucasian men over 60 are affected. Smoking is highly correlated to AAA development. Mr. Johnson has a history of smoking  having smoked a pack a day for nearly 40 years  though he quit smoking 10 years ago. His ethnicity and age place him in high-risk demographics  and his smoking habits further increase this risk.  History and Current Condition  Mr. Johnson came in complaining of abdominal and lower back pain that has persisted for a few weeks. He was initially seen by his personal physician for the pain. However  his doctor ordered an ultrasound because he detected an unusually pulsating mass in his abdomen during a routine examination.  The ultrasound revealed an AAA. This particular aneurysm is larger than 5cm  which falls into the potentially dangerous sizes  given the risk of rupture is significantly higher in aneurysms over 5cm. He reports no history of trauma  and his Family history is significant for peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and heart disease. Mr. Johnson also has a history of hypertension.   Additionally noted in Mr. Johnson's past medical history includes COPD  likely correlated with his long history of smoking  as well as hyperlipidemia  managed by statin medications. He had a knee replacement surgery approximately 3 years ago with no complications.  Clinical Reasoning  Given his reported symptoms  age  ethnicity  medical history  and results from the ultrasound  Mr. Johnson's chronic lower back pain and abdominal discomfort are likely due to the large AAA  which needs immediate attention. He is at a high risk of rupture due to the size of the aneurysm  which can potentially cause life-threatening internal bleeding.  Plan of Action  The current plan is to admit Mr. Johnson for close monitoring. A vascular surgeon will be promptly consulted for further management. The potential damage an AAA rupture could cause makes it crucial that these steps are taken immediately to prevent potentially fatal complications.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile Name: Mr. Allen Brown Age: 72 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Engineer Residence: Rural Oklahoma  Medical History Mr. Brown is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents with a history of uncontrolled hypertension and hypercholesterolemia for over 20 years. He was a smoker for about 30 years  ceasing 20 years ago  with a 30-pack-year history. He was diagnosed with coronary artery disease a decade ago  which warranted a coronary artery bypass graft. Mr. Brown also has a family history of cardiovascular diseases - his father died due to a myocardial infarction and his elder brother had an abdominal aortic aneurysm that was surgically repaired.  Current Presentation For the past one week  Mr. Brown has been experiencing intermittent abdominal pain along with back pain. In addition  he reports some occasional lightheadedness and general malaise. The nature of the pain is described as a deep  constant ache that seems to radiate to his lower back. He denies having similar pain episodes in the past. There has been no weight loss  fever  or any changes in bowel habits.   Upon physical examination  a pulsatile mass is noted in his abdomen. Initial ultrasound imaging indicates approximate measurements of the aneurysm to be over 5.5 cm  indicating potential need for a surgical intervention.  Conclusion Mr. Brown’s age  sex  race  and medical history  including his history of smoking  are highly in line with the literature on the risk factors for abdominal aortic aneurysm  which primarily affects older Caucasian males with a history of cardiovascular disease  hypertensive individuals  and smokers. Taking into consideration the size of the aneurysm  his ongoing symptoms  and the presence of multiple risk factors  immediate medical consultation with a vascular surgeon is necessary to determine the best course of action  potentially endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  to prevent the possible rupture of the aneurysm.

Subject presentation:  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presented with a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain. The pain is described as sharp  tearing  and radiating to the back suggesting a symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He was visiting his primary care physician for a physical examination when the pain started.  Medical history:  The patient’s past medical history is significant with a 45-year pack history of smoking  hypertension  and atherosclerosis. He quit smoking 10 years ago  but had a very significant smoking history which may have predisposed him to the development of AAA. He has been hypertensive for about 15 years  which is relatively controlled with medication (Lisinopril). Also  he has diagnosed atherosclerosis  marking significant atherosclerotic disease which is often associated with AAA.  Family history:  The patient's father died from a ruptured aortic aneurysm  so there is a family history of AAA  another risk factor.  Observations:  On physical examination  the patient's blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg  pulse 105 beats/min  and respiratory rate 20 breaths/min. Physical findings include a pulsatile abdominal mass that is tender to touch.   Background:  The literature indicates that abdominal aortic aneurysms are more common in older Caucasian men  those with a family history of AAA  and those with a history of smoking  making this patient at very high risk. Pathophysiology is complex  but atherosclerosis  inflammatory processes  and genetic predispositions play a role. Prognosis can be grave if an AAA ruptures  with a survival rate of under 20%.  In conclusion  this patient's age  sex  race  past medical history  and family history place him at a significant risk for AAA. His sudden onset  severe  tearing abdominal pain with radiation to the back  and the discovery of a pulsatile abdominal mass strongly suggest an AAA rupture. Immediate surgical intervention is required in this case.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile:  The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Smith  retired Army veteran who lives with his wife in a suburb of Dallas  Texas. He has a history of smoking  specifically about one pack of cigarettes per day for the last 40 years or so. Despite multiple counselling sessions regarding the behavorial change for smoking cessation  he has not been successful in quitting. It's also worth noting that Mr. Smith enjoys a moderate alcohol intake  accompanied by a diet that is high in cholesterol and saturated fats. He was previously employed in a high-stress occupation and leads a relatively sedentary lifestyle.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a medical history significant for hyperlipidemia  hypertension  peripheral arterial disease (PAD)  and coronary artery disease (CAD)  for which he underwent a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) a decade ago. He was diagnosed with Type 2 diabetes mellitus about fifteen years ago and has been on oral hypoglycemic medication since then. He also has been on regular medication for his high blood pressure. He has no history of other major illnesses or hospitalizations. His father died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in his 70s and his mother lived into her 80s without significant health issues. There's no family history of stroke or other vascular diseases.  Present Issues:  Mr. Smith recently presented to the emergency department with acute severe abdominal and lower back pain. The pain was sudden in onset  non-radiating and wasn't associated with any other gastrointestinal symptoms. On examination  a pulsating mass was felt in the abdominal area.   Given his demographic background along with the nature and location of his symptoms  there is a high degree of suspicion for abdominal aortic aneurysm. Clinical examination findings have been further corroborated with imaging tests like abdominal ultrasound and CT angiography.   According to literature  abdominal aortic aneurysms are most common in Caucasian males over the age of 65  with a history of smoking  high blood pressure  and high cholesterol. Mr. Smith's profile fits closely with this demographic. His presentation and history correlate well with the epidemiological pattern observed for individuals with AAA  and his military background may have subjected him to additional risk factors associated with stress and lifestyle habits. His genetic predisposition  given his father's history  also raises his risk for AAA significantly.

Title: Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Slide 1: Patient Introduction Mr. Joseph  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presents with complaints of persistent and severe abdominal pain. He is a non-Hispanic individual working as a retired engineer.  Slide 2: Chief Complaint Mr. Joseph reports a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain that began approximately 24 hours ago. The pain is described as sharp and severe  radiating to the lower back.   Slide 3: Past Medical History Mr. Joseph has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he takes medication. Additionally  he has a 45-year history of smoking a pack of cigarettes daily  but he successfully quit 10 years ago. There is no known family history of cardiovascular disease.  Slide 4: Current Physical Examination On physical examination  he is in mild distress due to abdominal pain. Vitals: Blood pressure: 180/100 mmHg  pulse: 88 beats per minute  respiration: 16 breaths per minute  and temperature: 98.6° F (37° C). Abdominal palpation reveals a pulsating mass in the center of the abdomen.  Slide 5: Representation in Literature The literature indicates that males over the age of 65  smokers  hypertensive  and Caucasian individuals are at the highest risk of developing abdominal aortic aneurysms. Mr. Joseph's demographic profile and past medical history  therefore  place him at a higher risk for an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Slide 6: Conclusion - Preliminary Diagnosis Given the patient's persistent abdominal pain  vital signs  physical exam findings  past medical history  and demographic risk factors  it is prudent to explore further diagnostic testing for a suspected abdominal aortic aneurysm. Prompt diagnosis and intervention are key to improving the prognosis in such cases. An ultrasound or abdominal CT scan is suggested for definitive diagnosis.   Slide 7: Follow-up and Management If an abdominal aortic aneurysm is confirmed  the appropriate surgical or endovascular intervention will be discussed with Mr. Joseph  considering his overall health status and the size of the aneurysm. Follow-up counseling on lifestyle modifications such as adopting a healthy diet  engaging in regular physical activity and blood pressure management would also be instituted to prevent the progression of the disease.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile:  Mr. Roberts is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents with abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He has a significant medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia and a 10-year pack history of smoking  with the last encounter of smoking being 5 years ago. He is retired and lives alone  with children living out-of-state. He has been on a prescribed regimen of antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering drugs.   Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Roberts was asymptomatic of AAA and the discovery was incidental during a routine abdominal ultrasound check-up for his hypertension. The scans revealed an infra-renal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.1cm.  Patient’s History:  Mr. Roberts has a history of cardiovascular disease  with previous surgeries including a coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) 6 years ago. His hypertension and hyperlipidemia have been under control with medication and lifestyle modifications. He has no known allergies. He used to smoke a pack a day for 10 years but quit 5 years ago. Mr. Roberts has no family history of AAA. However  his father had a myocardial infarction at the age of 68 and his older brother had a stroke at the age of 70.  Evaluation and Diagnosis: As the AAA is larger than 5.0cm  Mr. Roberts is at a high risk of rupture  which could be life-threatening. His current symptoms of lower back pain and occasional bouts of abdominal discomfort now makes sense and can be attributed to his aneurysm.     Treatment Plan:  Considering the size of Mr. Roberts' AAA and his medical history  the physician recommends elective surgery to repair the aneurysm. He has been referred to a vascular surgeon. In the meantime  he has been advised to maintain a healthy diet  properly manage his blood pressure and cholesterol levels  and continue regular visits for monitoring his AAA.  Conclusion:  Abdominal Aortic Aneurysms are common among older Caucasian men  especially those with a history of smoking and cardiovascular diseases. Asymptomatic AAAs can often be missed. Hence  regular screening and monitoring are crucial  particularly in patients older than 65 with a history of smoking and cardiovascular disease.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presents himself with severe abdominal pain. He has a history of tobacco usage  as he had been a heavy smoker for the past 50 years. He quit two years ago after experiencing shortness of breath.   Demographic Information: According to literature  abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is more common among Caucasian men than their African-American counterparts. It is most prevalent in individuals over the age of 65. Risk factors related to demographic characteristics include age  gender  and race. Additionally  a family history of AAA significantly increases the risk of developing one.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe was diagnosed with high blood pressure 15 years ago  which he has managed with medication. He also has a history of peripheral arterial disease (PAD) diagnosed 3 years ago. Both conditions are known to contribute significantly to the development of AAA.   There is no family history of AAA  but his father suffered a stroke at an elderly age and his mother passed away from complications of heart disease. Mr. Doe was diagnosed with moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) about 4 years ago. He has a high cholesterol level and a 5-year history of coronary artery disease (CAD). He underwent a bypass surgery for CAD 2 years ago. He is also obese with a body mass index (BMI) of 32.  Current Presentation: Currently  Mr. Doe reports experiencing sudden onset  severe  and constant abdominal pain. He is also feeling light-headed and experiences a rapid heart rate. These are significant symptoms suggestive of the rupture of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  In conclusion  Mr. Doe's advanced age  gender  past smoking habit  hypertension  high cholesterol  obesity  and history of other cardiovascular diseases place him at a significant risk for an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Based on his symptoms  immediate medical attention and further diagnostic tests are required to confirm the diagnosis and implement a management plan.

Title: Patient Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  I. Patient Demographics The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  living in a suburban settings  who first presented to the hospital after experiencing severe abdominal and back pain with a history of hypertension.   II. Relevant Medical History He has a significant past medical history that includes: a 40 pack-year history of smoking  chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  and peripheral vascular disease. He is currently on medication for hypertension and COPD  including beta-blockers and bronchodilators. He reports sporadic compliance with his medication regimen.  III. Family History The patient reports a family history of cardiovascular disease  with both his father and brother dying of myocardial infarctions in their early 70s.   IV. Social History He is a retired automobile mechanic  living with his wife. He quit smoking 10 years ago  he doesn't drink alcohol nor partake in recreational drug use.   V. Review of system Our patient first noticed mild lower back discomfort two weeks ago  which escalated into severe abdominal and back pain  prompting his visit to the hospital.  VI. Physical Examination Initial examination revealed that patient is in distress with diaphoresis; has a pulsating abdominal mass on palpation; profound hypotension; regular but rapid pulse; and diminished pulses in the lower extremities.  VII. Evaluation and Diagnosis Radiologic examinations  specifically an abdominal ultrasound  showed an enlargement in the aorta  indicating an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Subsequent computed tomography (CT) scan confirmed a 7 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with signs of impending rupture.   VIII. Risk Factors Major risk factors present include the patient’s advanced age  male gender  significant smoking history  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  family history of heart disease  and comorbid pulmonary and cardiovascular diseases. It’s also important to note that White (Caucasian) men over the age of 60 years have the highest prevalence of AAA.   IX. Plan  Immediate surgical intervention  in the form of an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  is indicated considering both the patient's symptoms and the size of his aneurysm. After surgery  the patient will need regular monitoring via vascular imaging to ensure successful treatment and to monitor for potential complications. Lifestyle modifications and compliance with medication therapy will also be strongly emphasized to manage risk factors and comorbidities.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Profile: The patient is a 71-year-old Caucasian male who resides in a suburban area in the Midwest  U.S. He is a retiree with a past professional life in manual labor trade. He lives with his wife of 47 years and is a father to two adult children. He is a current smoker with a 50-pack year smoking history  and his alcohol intake is occasional.  Medical History: The patient has a history of moderate hypertension and hypercholesterolemia both of which have been managed with medications for the past 15 years. Besides  the patient has a family history of cardiovascular disease - his father passed away from a heart attack at the age of 72.  Presenting Symptoms: He attended the consultation complaining about a pulsating feeling in his abdomen that he likened to a heartbeat  which occurs with increasing frequency  particularly after meals. Along with this unusual pulsating feeling  he has been experiencing sporadic back pain  occasional nausea  and a recent unintentional weight loss.  Clinical Examination & Imaging: Upon examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpable.
