Subsequent abdominal ultrasound demonstrated evidence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  with an aortic diameter of 5.3cm  higher than the normal range (usually under 3cm).  In conclusion  considering the patient's advanced age  active smoking habit  diagnosis of hypertension & hyperlipidemia  family history of cardiovascular disease  and detected aneurysm diameter beyond the normal threshold  there is a high risk of aneurysm rupture. Thus  rapid and active intervention is necessary. This case is representative of the typical demographic and risk factors associated with abdominal aortic aneurysms  as outlined in medical literature.

Title: Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male Patient.  Patient Profile:  James is a 76-year-old Caucasian male presenting with a sudden onset of severe  tearing abdominal pain that radiates to his lower back. He describes the pain as the worst he has ever experienced and states that it's intermitted with periods of relief.  He currently lives in an urban area with his wife and is retired. He worked as a truck driver for about 40 years. He is a lifetime non-smoker and has a history of moderate alcohol use.   Past Medical History:  His medical history reveals that James has been dealing with untreated hypertension for the last ten years and has a family history of cardiovascular disease  with both his father and elder brother dying from heart attacks in their early 70s. He has a history of hyperlipidemia but hasn’t been regular with his lipid-lowering medications.   James has been experiencing mild abdominal discomfort and unintentional weight loss over the past three weeks. He has peripheral vascular disease diagnosed five years ago. No history of renal disease  liver disorder  or diabetes.   On Inquiry  James mentioned having occasional claudication after long walks but was under the impression that it was due to his age. There is no history of any significant trauma  recent surgeries  or neoplasm. He takes a daily aspirin for heart disease prevention but has no known drug allergies.  Demographic Representation:  His profile matches epidemiological data  which indicates that abdominal aortic aneurysms are most commonly seen in Caucasian males aged 65 or older with a history of smoking and hypertension. However  it should be noted that James is a non-smoker  putting emphasis on the fact that while smoking is a significant risk factor  non-smokers can also develop an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Furthermore  the presence of peripheral vascular disease and family history of cardiac ailments further contributes to his risk profile for abdominal aortic aneurysm development.   In conclusion  James' severe abdominal and back pain  combined with his medical history and demographic profile  lead to a concern for a possible abdominal aortic aneurysm. Urgent diagnostic and potential surgical intervention is considered.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a Middle-aged Diabetic Man  Patient Information: Mr. James Powell is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  currently residing in Boston  Massachusetts. He is retired from a long career in civil service  living with his wife of 40 years. Mr. Powell was referred by his family physician to our vascular surgery clinic today.  Medical History: Upon reviewing Mr. Powell's medical history  we found that he has been a Type 2 diabetic for approximately 20 years  on Metformin. He is also known to be hypertensive  which has been managed through a combination of Lisinopril and Amlodipine for the past decade. He is a former smoker  having quit about 15 years ago after a 30-year pack history. There's a family history of cardiovascular disease  his father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 65. No surgical or significant family medical history was reported.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Powell presented with a one-week history of gradual onset  unrelenting  dull abdominal pain  localized in the mid to lower abdomen. Besides  the patient has been experiencing feelings of fullness and increased abdominal girth.   Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass consistent with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). His vitals were stable. Marginal tenderness was reported in the abdomen but no signs of inflammation or rebound tenderness. He had regular heart rhythm and lung fields were clear during auscultation.   Discussion: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm is predominantly a disease of older men  with a reported male-to-female ratio of 4:1. Several risk factors have been linked with AAA  including advanced age  smoking history  hypertension  and atherosclerosis.  Mr. Powell's demographic aligns with the representation of typical AAA patients as found in the literature. His diabetic and hypertensive history places him at an increased risk  as does his previous smoking habit and family heart disease history.   It is worth mentioning that despite the common notion that diabetes is a protective factor against AAA  some recent studies suggest that this relationship may not be as robust or consistent as it is initially thought. It is prudent to maintain our clinical suspicion in diabetics presenting with a compatible symptom profile.   Conclusion: Mr. Powell's case is a cautionary tale reminding us not to overlook the possibility of AAA in patients with a combination of risk factors such as advanced age  hypertension  smoking history  and positive familial history  even in patients with diabetes.   Next Steps: Further imaging like an abdominal ultrasound or a computed tomography (CT) scan will be the next step to determine the exact size  location  and severity of Mr. Powell's aneurysm. Subsequently  the treatment plan (survey  endovascular repair or open surgery) will be tailored according to the evaluation results and his general health status. He will also need tight control of his blood pressure and blood glucose  with medications and lifestyle modifications. Regular follow-ups and patient education are of utmost importance in such cases.

Title: A Case Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Introduction: We present a case of a 72-year-old Caucasian male patient with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). This case was chosen because of the high incident rate of AAA within this demographic. The patient was diagnosed with AAA via an ultrasound study during a routine check-up for his Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia.  Demographic Information: The patient is a retired teacher residing in NY city  with a 40 pack-year history of smoking. He is married with two adult children. He reports being relatively physically inactive and has poor dietary habits  with a predilection for high salt and cholesterol foods.  Past Medical History: This patient reports a history of Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia  Both well managed with medications. He quit smoking ten years ago. There has been no known hereditary genetic disease in his family. However  the patient's father had suffered from myocardial infarction and passed away at the age of 80.   Patient's Clinical Presentation: During a routine check-up visit with the general physician  an abdominal ultrasound detected mild enlargement in the patient's abdominal aorta. The finding was suspicious for AAA  and a subsequent computed tomography angiography (CTA) confirmed the diagnosis with an aortic diameter of 4.0 cm - indicative of a small AAA. As per guidelines  surgical treatments are reserved for aneurysms of larger dimensions (>5.5cm). Therefore  patient management at this time consists of regular follow-up screenings and healthy lifestyle modifications—smoking cessation  blood pressure control  appropriate diet  and physical activity.   Conclusion: Abdominal aortic aneurysms occur predominantly in elder males  especially those with a history of smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a family history of vascular diseases. Thus  routine screening and lifestyle modifications are vital for this at-risk population.   Note: This case summary outlines a typical presentation of abdominal aortic aneurysm to demonstrate the importance of early detection and the beneficial role of non-invasive imaging in managing this population.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Older Male Patient  Patient Presentation: Mr. James  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  presents with complaints of persistent lower back pain and occasional abdominal discomfort. He has a history of smoking and a sedentary lifestyle. His body mass index (BMI) is 30  with a history of bad eating habits.   Past Medical History: Mr. James is a known case of hypertension and high cholesterol for which he takes regular medications. He also has a strong family history of cardiac ailments with his father having died of a stroke at the age of 65.   Clinical Examination: On examination  there was abdominal tenderness and a palpable pulsatile mass in his abdomen. The patient also reported feeling lightheaded with episodes of syncope.  This case presentation is typical of the demographic most affected by Abdominal Aortic Aneurysms (AAAs)  as literature indicates a higher prevalence in older men  especially those of Caucasian ethnicity who have a history of smoking. The prevalence of AAA increases with age  particularly in those over 60 years.   Interestingly  the increased risk posed by demographic factors such as being Caucasian and male is reduced in populations over 80 years old where there is a tendency towards equal gender distribution. However  since Mr. James falls within the most at-risk demographic and presents with typical symptoms  a diagnosis of AAA is being considered and further diagnostic procedures including an ultrasound or CT angiogram will be performed to confirm this.  In relation to AAA and morbidity  studies have indicated that ruptured AAA is the 13th most common cause of death in the U.S.  and the 10th most common cause of death in men over the age of 55. This underlines the necessity of early diagnosis and appropriate management in patients like Mr. James.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Case Presentation  Demographics:  Mr. R is a 70-year-old Caucasian male patient.  Chief Complaint:  Intermittent abdominal pain and back pain that has progressed over the past few months.  History of Present Illness: The patient reports non-radiating moderate intensity  intermittent abdominal pain that seems unrelated to meals. His medical history also includes complaints of a pulsating sensation in the abdomen  a noticeable pulsating mass present in the abdominal area  and unexplained weight loss.  Medical  Family  and Social History:  His medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia  controlled with medications. Additionally  he is a former 30 pack-year smoker but quit 5 years ago. He does not consume alcohol. His father died of a myocardial infarction  and his mother had an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Physical Examination:  The physical examination reveals a slim man in no apparent distress. His blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg and heart rate is regular at 75 bpm. His abdomen is soft but reveals an easily palpable and pulsatile mass in the mid to lower abdomen.  Pertinent Labs & Imaging:  Abdominal ultrasound revealed a 7.3cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with possible mural thrombus.   Assessment:  Mr. R has an abdominal aortic aneurysm  which likely explains his abdominal pain and pulsating mass. These aneurysms are common in men over age 65  particularly in those with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking. It is especially concerning because of his family history of cardiovascular disease and abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Plan:  Given the large size of the aneurysm and Mr. R’s symptoms  surgical intervention is the likely next step. He needs a referral to vascular surgery for consultation regarding elective aortic aneurysm repair. The goals of treatment are to prevent the aneurysm from rupturing and treating any associated symptoms. Concurrently  his hypertension control should be optimized. He is also advised to avoid strenuous activity and heavy lifting till further notice to reduce the risk of rupture.   This case presents a typical demographic and medical history associated with abdominal aortic aneurysms  highlighting the importance of monitoring high-risk individuals to ensure early diagnosis and treatment.

Title: A Case Presentation on Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile: Mr. J. S. is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a history of heavy tobacco use  specifically an average of a pack a day for 40 years. He retired from his job as a construction worker 10 years ago. The patient lives with his wife in a suburban environment and has a family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father experiencing a fatal heart attack at the age of 78.   Presenting complaint: Mr. J. S. currently presents for a routine follow-up visit with non-specific complaints of episodic abdominal discomfort and lower back pain over the last month. He mentions the pain as a pulsating sensation in his abdomen  not correlating to meals or physical activity.  Past Medical History: In the past  Mr. J. S. has been diagnosed with hypertension for which he has been prescribed Lisinopril. He was also diagnosed with peripheral artery disease five years ago  and high cholesterol  managed with Atorvastatin. He has no known allergies.  Social History: Mr. J. S. admits to a history of heavy smoking  but reports quitting about two years ago. He denies alcohol or illicit drug use. He states that he stopped regular exercise a few years ago due to increasing shortness of breath.  Investigations: Due to the patient’s age  smoking history  related symptoms and family history of cardiovascular disease  further evaluation is warranted for a possible abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The recommended step would be to perform an abdominal ultrasound for further assessment.  This case is representative of the typical demographic profile of a patient with an AAA. The condition is most commonly found in Caucasian males over the age of 65 with a history of smoking. Other risk factors  such as hypertension  peripheral artery disease  high cholesterol  and a family history of cardiovascular disease  further increase the chances of developing an AAA. Therefore  it is important that these factors be properly managed and monitored in such patients to prevent further complications.   In summary  Mr. J. S.’s presenting symptoms along with his demographic profile and past medical history suggest the likelihood of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm. Further investigations are required to confirm the diagnosis and to determine the most suitable treatment approach.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 67-year-old Caucasian male who presents with complaints of constant and severe abdominal pain which he described as a throbbing sensation in the lower part of the abdomen that radiates to his back. He has also been experiencing occasional episodes of lightheadedness and sweating. Mr. Smith is a retired veteran and a long-term smoker with a smoking history of approximately 40 years.  Past Medical History:  He has a history of high blood pressure which is currently being managed with medication. In addition  he has Hyperlipidemia  a condition of high cholesterol that increases the likelihood of developing an aneurysm. There is no family history of abdominal aortic aneurysms. He also reports occasional alcohol intake. Mr. Smith has not had any previous surgeries or hospitalizations.   Demographic Information: Studies suggest that abdominal aortic aneurysms disproportionately affect the older population  particularly males around the age of 65-75 years  who comprise the majority of abdominal aortic aneurysm diagnoses. Smoking and hypertension significantly contribute to the development of these aneurysms. This  combined with his gender  Caucasian ethnicity  and age  puts Mr. Smith in the high-risk group for the development of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Epidemiology: Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) occurs most frequently in males over 65 years of age and the prevalence increases considerably with age. AAA is more common in Caucasians than in African Americans. Smoking  hyperlipidemia  and hypertension are well-established risk factors for AAA. The disorder also tends to run in families. This presentation fits the demographic typically found in literature.   Presentation based on his demographic and risk factors  combined with the described symptoms  has a high suspicion for Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  and requires immediate further investigation and treatment.

Title: A Case Presentation on Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile: The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  named John Doe  now residing in an urban community in Philadelphia. He is a retired veteran who experiences moderate socioeconomic status. His past occupational exposure includes several years in a shipyard with some asbestos exposure  indirectly indicating a lifestyle with potential for high cumulative tobacco use. The patient admits to a history of smoking tobacco for 50 years but quit 10 years ago. He reports consuming alcohol socially.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a significant medical history that includes hypertension controlled with lisinopril  hyperlipidemia treated with atorvastatin  and he experienced a transient ischemic attack (TIA) three years ago. He also exhibits mild COPD from his many years of smoking. There is no documentation of diabetes mellitus or renal pathology. Family history is relevant for cardiovascular disease  with his father having suffered from an aortic aneurysm.  Current Presentation: Mr. Doe visited the emergency service complaining of a sudden onset severe abdominal and back pain  which he describes as tearing and radiating to the back. He reported feeling lightheaded and had one episode of vomiting. His vitals include a blood pressure of 180/90 and an irregular heart rate of 100 beats per minute. An Abdominal examination showed a palpable pulsatile mass and moderate tenderness.  This case presentation delineates a typical patient demographic associated with abdominal aortic aneurysms  primarily an elderly Caucasian male with a substantial smoking history. Smoking has a direct linear relation with AAA  and the likelihood increases further when coupled with male gender and age.    The medical background of hyperlipidemia and hypertension—major cardiovascular factors—significantly contribute to the risk of developing aneurysms. Although the manifestation of symptoms such as severe abdominal or back pain and syncope indicate complicated AAAs  often these are asymptomatic and detected incidentally or during screening processes. Considering the potential lethal consequences of ruptured AAA  the initial diagnosis and timely intervention are pivotal.

Title: Case Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile: Mr. John Doe  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  with an address on Main street  small-town USA  has presented with complaints of constant abdominal and lower back pain. Mr. Doe  a retired manual worker  is a former smoker who quit 10 years ago after a 30-year history of tobacco use. He drinks about 10 standard alcoholic beverages weekly.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a significant past medical history of hypertension  which has been under control with Lisinopril. He has been diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia and is on Atorvastatin. He has no known allergies and is up-to-date with his recommended preventive care and immunizations.   Family History: His father passed away at the age of 65 due to complications of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. His mother has high blood pressure and is in her late 80s.   Review of Systems: Mr. Doe reports experiencing episodic persistent pain localized to the back and abdomen  not specific to any time of the day or night and not noticeably affected by food intake or body position. He also mentions intermittent feelings of lightheadedness but denies chest pain  palpitations  shortness of breath  lower extremity weakness  or any bowel or bladder dysfunctions.  Physical Examination: On examination  Mr. Doe has a blood pressure level of 140/85mmHg  a heart rate of 78 beats per minute  and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. He appears on closer inspection to have a pulsating mass in his abdomen. The lungs are clear to percussion and auscultation  and cardiac examination reveals normal S1 and S2 without any murmurs or gallop.   Investigation: Given the presentation and clinical findings  a suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is raised. An urgent ultrasound confirms a 5.6 cm infrarenal abdominal aorta. A CT angiogram is planned for further evaluation.     Plans: Mr. Doe is informed about the findings  implications  and potential risk of rupture and need for urgent intervention. Vascular surgery consultation is planned. Patient is advised immediate hospital admission for monitoring and management.   References:  1. Newman AB  Arnold AM  Naydeck BL  et al. ""Racial/Ethnic Differences in Risk Factors for Aneurysm Presence and Size"".  J Am Heart Assoc. 2012 Jun;1(3). 2. Society for Vascular Surgery. ""Patient Information: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)"" Retrieved from: https://vascular.org/patient-resources/vascular-conditions/abdominal-aortic-aneurysm 3. UpToDate. ""Clinical Features and Diagnosis of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm"". Retrieved from: https://www.uptodate.com/contents/clinical-features-and-diagnosis-of-abdominal-aortic-aneurysm

Title: Clinical Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  I. Demographics   The patient  Mr. Lopez  is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  as AAA is most prominently found in this racial group aged between 65 to 75 years old. He is a retired military officer currently living with his wife and has active involvement in his grandchildren's lives.  II. Medical History   The patient has a history of smoking  which is one of the biggest risk factors for AAA. He quit smoking 8 years ago but had a 30 pack-year smoking history before quitting. He has controlled hypertension  diagnosed 15 years ago  which is commonly associated with AAA. Furthermore  Mr. Lopez also has a family history of AAA  as his father had an aneurysm repair at the age of 75. The risk for AAA increases with a positive family history.  III. Presenting Symptoms  Mr. Lopez has been asymptomatic  which is characteristic of many patients with AAA. However  his primary care physician noted a pulsatile abdominal mass during a routine physical examination. In a small proportion of patients  an AAA might be incidentally noted in this manner.   IV. Recent Developments   Upon suspicion of an AAA  Mr. Lopez was referred for an ultrasound imaging study  which confirmed the presence of an AAA measuring 5.2cm. It's key to note that larger aneurysms (>5cm) like his are more likely to rupture  which is a life-threatening situation.    V. Conclusion  Now identified  Mr. Lopez will need careful follow-up and possibly surgical intervention depending on the progression of the aneurysm size and his symptomatology. He may be a candidate for either endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) or open surgical repair. Though asymptomatic now  his AAA status raises risks of rupture  arteriosclerotic vascular disease  and death if left untreated - emphasizing the importance of timely management.

Patient Presentation:  Good morning  everyone. Today we will be discussing Mr. John Hartwell  a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presented at our facility with symptoms consistent with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Mr. Hartwell is a retired construction worker who has a long-standing history of smoking  approximately one pack per day for the past 40 years. He also has an extensive medical history that includes hypertension which has been regulated by medication for the past 10 years.   Last week  Mr. Hartwell reported to his primary care physician about experiencing lower back pain which he described as a ""deep-seated  persistent throbbing "" especially after meals. Coupled with the fact that he also mentioned feeling a pulse in his abdomen  this raised suspicion of vascular involvement and he was referred for vascular consult to confirm a diagnosis of aortic aneurysm.  Demographically  Mr. Hartwell aligns with the common characteristics of patients who develop abdominal aortic aneurysms. This condition occurs most frequently in Caucasian males over the age of 65  with risk factors such as a history of smoking and hypertension contributing significantly to its development. Other risk factors he does not possess are a family history of AAA and hypercholesterolemia.  In summary  Mr. John Hartwell presents as a classic case of a patient with a suspected abdominal aortic aneurysm  based on his demographic  lifestyle habits and presenting symptoms. As the next step  we will now need to confirm this suspicion through appropriate radiological imaging in order to guide any further intervention.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnathon  a 73-year-old Caucasian male  presents with a notable pulsatile mass in the mid to lower abdomen and intermittent abdominal and back pain. He reports that the pain is not associated with eating or any specific activity. He notices that the pain tends to be more intense during episodes of exertion. He denies any weight loss  loss of appetite  stool changes  or urinary symptoms. He characterized the pain as “tearing” and radiating to his back.  Demographics:  Johnathon is a retired steelworker living with his wife in their own home. He has an extensive smoking history of 30 pack-years but quit 15 years ago. He consumes alcohol moderately and has a fairly sedentary lifestyle post-retirement.  Past Medical History:  Johnathon has a past medical history significant for hypertension  which has been controlled with Lisinopril for the past 10 years. He also has hyperlipidemia for which he's taking Atorvastatin. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease. His father experienced an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at the age of 70.  Physical Examination:  On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is appreciated just above the umbilicus. The upper and lower extremities are warm with the presence of distal pulses. His blood pressure is slightly elevated  and his body mass index falls within the overweight category.  Note:  The common risk factors for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  such as advanced age  male gender  history of smoking  and history of hypertension  are all present in Johnathon's profile. Furthermore  his father's history with AAA puts Johnathon at an increased risk. The description of the ""tearing"" pain radiating to his back is a concerning symptom often associated with aneurysm rupture  a life-threatening condition.    This case is reflective of the demographic most often affected by AAA: older  Caucasian males with a history of cardiovascular disease and/or smoking. As per data  men are much more likely to develop an AAA than women are  and whites have a higher risk than people of other races. The majority of cases also originate in individuals aged 65 and above.    Immediate diagnostic imaging for Johnathon would be prudent  given his risk factors and characteristic symptoms  to rule out a potential impending rupture.

Title: Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in Caucasian Male  Introduction:   The patient is a 66-year-old Caucasian male  named Mr. Brown  who presented to the emergency department with complaints of sudden extreme pain in his middle to lower back and abdominal region. The pain radiates to his groin and buttocks. He describes the pain as intense and constant. Mr. Brown has no history of any traumatic injury or lifting heavy weights.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Brown has a significant past medical history which includes hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and type II diabetes which are controlled with medications  and a 40 year history of smoking (1 pack per day)  although he quit 2 years ago. He has no history of surgeries or allergies.   Demographics in Context:  Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) is most commonly seen in Caucasian males over the age of 60  with the majority of patients being between 65–75 years old. Risk factors include hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  smoking history  and diabetes  which perfectly aligns with Mr. Brown's demographic and history  as mentioned above.   Discussion:  AAA is often asymptomatic and quite challenging to diagnose. However  in some cases  like Mr. Brown's  it presents with a sudden severe  tearing abdominal or back pain. Uncontrolled hypertension contributes to the expansion of an AAA and increased wall stress. In the presence of Mr. Brown's hypertension and history of heavy smoking  the likelihood of having an AAA increases significantly.   Conclusion:  Given Mr. Brown's sudden presentation of severe abdominal and back pain in combination with his demographic features and risk factors  it is crucial to assess the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm through immediate imaging studies. Consideration should be given to the high risk of rupture associated with his symptoms  and emergency surgical evaluation should be considered.

Title: Case Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: Mr. John Brown is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who seeks medical evaluation for the intermittent abdominal discomfort he has been feeling for the past few weeks. He is originally from the Midwest  and currently resides in the same region with his wife. He is a retired farming engineer and his primary language is English.  Medical History: Mr. Brown has a submitted extensive past medical history which includes high blood pressure for which he's been on medication (ACE inhibitors and diuretics) for the past twenty years. He has a long history of smoking which sums up to 40 pack years but he quit a decade ago. He also has documented high cholesterol levels managed with statins  along with a case of early-stage prostate cancer that was treated and has remained in remission for five years. His father passed away due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 76.   Presentation: Mr. Brown describes his symptoms as non-radiating dull ache in the center of his abdomen  sometimes extending to his back. He associates this discomfort with eating  initially dismissing it as gastric problems. He denies any recent weight loss  loss of appetite  changes in bowel or bladder movement patterns  chest pain  or any other discomfort in his extremities.   On general examination  he is 5’10'' tall  weighs approximately 195 lbs  and has a BMI of 28. On abdominal palpation  a pulsatile mass is identified in the peri-umbilical area which is indicative of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. His blood pressure is slightly elevated at 150/95  but he has clear lungs and a regular heart rate.  Given Mr. Brown’s age  sex  history of hypertension  positive family history  and smoking history  he fits demographically with the typical abdominal aortic aneurysm patient as seen in the literature. Previous epidemiological studies have shown that abdominal aortic aneurysms are most common amongst males aged 65 to 75  with these risk factors.   Imaging Studies/Clinical Findings: An immediate abdominal ultrasound was scheduled  given the physical finding of a pulsatile mass  and the high suspicion for an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Results confirmed the presence of an aneurysm  and further imaging with CT angiography showed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.5 cm in its largest diameter.  In Summary: This case presentation features Mr. John Brown  a 72-year-old Caucasian male who fits the demographic common to abdominal aortic aneurysm as noted in the majority of medical literature and presents with related signs and symptoms. Further imaging studies confirmed these suspicions.

Patient Presentation:  We present Mr. Johnson  a 73-year-old Caucasian male  who has presented with suspected abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The patient is a former smoker with a history of smoking two packs a day for 40 years  who quit 10 years ago. He has a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and coronary artery disease.  He came in complaining of sudden severe lower back pain of 7/10 intensity. He also reported shortness of breath  light-headedness  and abdominal discomfort. He lives independently. He has an active lifestyle and reports no issues with daily activities. However  he noted feeling a pulsating sensation in his abdomen which he had ignored until the back pain began today.  His family history includes a father who had an AAA that was repaired surgically  and a mother who died from stroke. He has two older brothers – both with a history of cardiovascular disease.  Mr. Johnson is retired and enjoys gardening  reading  and fishing in his leisure time. He lives with his wife  and he consumes alcohol moderately - about 2-3 drinks per week. His diet includes red meat  fried foods  and minimal vegetables.  His presenting symptoms alongside his history of smoking and family history of AAA point toward a possible diagnosis of AAA. Research has shown that factors such as age  smoking history  high blood pressure  and family history of AAA contribute to the incidence of AAA  and that it is more common among men and Caucasian individuals.  Further tests  including an abdominal ultrasound  will be conducted to confirm the diagnosis and establish the size of the aneurysm. If confirmed  treatment options will be discussed  depending on the size and stability of the aneurysm.  Ref: Howard DP  Banerjee A  Fairhead JF  et al. Age-specific trends in incidence of noncardioembolic stroke in 3 geographic areas. Annals of neurology. 2012;71(2):179-188.

Presentation Title: A Case Study on Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Slide 1:  Introduction  Good morning/afternoon  Our patient today is a 72-year-old Caucasian male - a demographic that statistically and substantially associates with a higher likelihood of developing abdominal aortic aneurysms.   Slide 2: Patient Demographic Information   Our patient hails from an urban residence and is a retired car mechanic by profession  hence with a possibility of exposure to environmental stressors. His BMI falls into the category of overweight  classified at 29  with a height of 5 feet 10 inches and weight of 200 pounds – an additional risk factor for aortic disease. He is an ex-smoker with a 30-pack year history  a known modifiable risk factor that increases the probability of developing aneurysms.  Slide 3:  Past Medical History   The patient was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago  which is managed with calcium channel blockers  thereby signifying another risk factor contributing to the disease state. He also has a known history of peripheral artery disease  which is an associated comorbidity of this condition. Previous medical records also indicate a familial history of abdominal aortic aneurysms  as his father passed away from a ruptured aneurysm at the age of 76  stressing genetics' role.  Slide 4: Conclusion  This case underscores the importance of recognizing our patient's specific demographic as a potential high-risk group for abdominal aortic aneurysm  given the confluence of age  race  familial history  and predisposing medical conditions.   Thank you for your attention  and I am ready to field questions now.   Slide 5:  Questions?  Please feel free to ask any queries or provide comments about the presentation.

Title: Clinical Presentation of Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Slide 1: Introduction  Today's case involves a patient presenting with a condition known as Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA). An AAA is a localized enlargement of the abdominal aorta that exceeds the normal diameter by more than 50 percent  and is a creating cause of death due to aortic rupture.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics  Our patient  Mr. Smith  is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  reflecting demographic data that suggests Caucasian males over the age of 65 have a higher prevalence of AAA. He is a retired construction worker and currently lives alone. He has been a smoker for over 50 years  a habit that significantly increases the risk of AAA.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  Mr. Smith has a relevant medical history for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which he has been managing with medication. He also underwent coronary artery bypass grafting 5 years ago. His father passed away due to a ruptured aneurysm  indicating a possible genetic predisposition for aneurysm development.  Slide 4: Current Symptoms  Mr. Smith presents with abdominal and lower back pain that he has been experiencing for the past week. He describes it as a pulsating feeling near his navel  consistent with AAA symptoms. However  he has had no recent weight loss  changes in appetite or gastrointestinal symptoms.  Slide 5: Diagnostic Findings  A physical examination revealed an abdominal mass that pulsated with heartbeats. An ultrasound confirmed the presence of an aneurysm in the abdominal aorta exceeding 3.4cm  classifying it as an AAA. No signs of rupture were detected.  Slide 6: Conclusion  In the case of Mr. Smith  the demographic profile  personal and family medical history  presenting symptoms  and diagnostic findings all lead to a diagnosis of AAA. Prompt surgical intervention as the appropriate treatment option will be planned  alongside lifestyle modification advice particularly for smoking cessation. Regular check-ups and monitoring will be essential to ensure optimal post-surgical recovery and prevent possible complications.

Slide 1: Introduction  Welcome to today's presentation where we will discuss a clinical case of an individual with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He has a history of smoking two packs a day since his late teens  though he quit five years ago. He also has a 10-year history of stable ischemic heart disease. There is no known family history of abdominal aortic aneurysms. He initially attributed this to ageing or potentially an old hernia acting up.   Slide 5: Recent Symptoms  Recently  the intensity and frequency of the pain significantly increased  causing him to seek medical attention. He also noticed a pulsating sensation in his abdomen  along with some unintentional weight loss.  Slide 6: Literature Review  Literature shows that males older than 65 years of age  particularly those of Caucasian ethnicity and with a history of smoking  hypertension  high cholesterol  or heart disease  are at a higher risk for abdominal aortic aneurysms.  Slide 7: Conclusion  In conclusion  this patient’s demographic profile  medical history  and presenting symptoms indicate a high suspicion for abdominal aortic aneurysm. This case emphasizes the importance of recognizing the risk factors  early signs  and symptoms of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  as timely detection and intervention can significantly improve patient outcomes. Title: Case Presentation on Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: We are presenting the case of Mr. Smith  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  who came in for a routine medical check-up in our outpatient clinic. He's a former smoker with a history of smoking for about 30 years  a habit he has quit for about 15 years. Mr. Smith's family history is notable for cardiovascular disease – his father died from a myocardial infarction in his late sixties.  Past Medical History: On the review of his past medical history  Mr. Smith has a documented diagnosis of hypertension  which has been managed for the past 15 years with a daily dose of Ramipril. Furthermore  he has been treated for hypercholesterolemia with Atorvastatin for the past 10 years. Smith is also diagnosed with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) and is on Tiotropium inhaler as required.   Presenting Problem: Mr. Smith has not reported any significant abdominal pain or back pain recently. However  a routine physical exam revealed a pulsating mass in his abdomen. An Ultrasound was requested which revealed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring around 5.5 cm. He has no history of syncope or lower limb claudication.  In conclusion: Mr. Smith's age  gender  smoking habit  and high blood pressure  coupled with his family's medical history  certainly increase his risk of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm. Despite being asymptomatic  the size of the aneurysm warrants immediate intervention to prevent serious complications such as rupture  leading to severe internal bleeding  a significant cause of mortality in such patients. Hence  he was referred to a vascular surgeon for further management of his AAA.  Note: According to the literature  AAA is more common in Caucasian males aged over 65 and is associated with modifiable risk factors such as smoking  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia. Family history of cardiovascular disease also increases the risk of AAA significantly. Therefore  Mr. Smith's case represents an accurate demographic representation.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Slide 1: Patient Introduction   Mr. James Smith  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presents with a complaint of intermittent abdominal and back pain for the past two months. He is a longtime resident of a small community town in North Carolina  where he lives with his wife and is retired from a career in construction. He was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia five years ago but is non-compliant with his prescribed statin. There have been no significant surgeries in his medical history  and he does not have any known allergies.  Slide 3: Family Medical History   In his family more specifically  his father died of a massive stroke at the age of 75. And one of his two older brothers underwent a surgical procedure to repair an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 72.   Slide 4: Current Presentation  Today  Mr. Smith describes sudden  intense abdominal and lower back pain that he rates as 8 out of 10 on the pain scale. The pain is not relieved by changes in position or over the counter pain medication. His wife also reports that he appears paler than usual and seems to fatigue easily.   Slide 5: Suspected Diagnosis and Reasoning  Given Mr. Smith's age  gender  and significant smoking history  as well as the familial occurrence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  we are concerned that his current symptoms may be indicative of an impending aortic rupture. A differential diagnosis will also consider gastrointestinal conditions such as diverticulitis or pancreatitis  but his familial history and symptomatology lean heavily towards an aortic aneurysm.  End of Slide.  (Note: Remember that an abdominal aortic aneurysm is a medical emergency and requires immediate diagnosis and treatment. Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Introduction: Today we will discuss the case of a male patient currently diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Patient Demographics: Patient 'X' is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a height of 5'10"" and a weight of approximately 220 lbs  living in a suburban neighborhood. He is a former smoker  having quit around ten years ago  but had a significant smoking history before then. He consumes alcohol in moderation.  Relevant Medical History: He has a significant past medical history  which includes: 1. Hypertension: Diagnosed around 15 years ago  under management with antihypertensive medication. 2. Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD): Likely linked to his long history of smoking. 3. Hyperlipidemia: He has elevated serum cholesterol levels  controlled through both diet and statins. 4. He underwent an appendectomy at age 44.  Present Symptoms: He came to the hospital complaining of mild to moderate abdominal pain  lasting a few days  constant but worsening recently. The pain is in the lower abdomen  primarily central  but radiates to the back in the form of a vague discomfort. He denies any fever  nausea  or recent changes in bowel or bladder habits. He mentions intermittent episodes of claudication.  Examination and Diagnosis: Physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass. The patient's blood pressure was slightly elevated. Given the history and examination  an immediate vascular surgery consult was sought and an abdominal ultrasound was ordered  which confirmed the presence of an AAA. CT angiography was subsequently recommended for better size assessment and planning possible repair.  Conclusion: Current management includes frequent monitoring  lifestyle alterations  medical control of comorbid conditions and assessing possible surgical intervention. Prompt identification and timely intervention are essential to prevent rupture  which has a high mortality rate.  References: The above presentation accurately represents the demographics commonly associated with AAA. According to the literature  AAAs are more common in males  significantly in older Caucasian males. Smoking  Hypertension  Hyperlipidemia  and COPD are also well-established risk factors for AAA (Sakalihasan et al.  2018).

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm: A Patient Case Presentation   PATIENT OVERVIEW   Mr. Robert Anderson is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presented with intermittent abdominal pain and discomfort for around six weeks. His symptoms include pain in the lower back and abdominal fullness  especially after meals. Mr. Anderson is a retired engineer  a lifelong smoker with a 45-pack-year history  and has a recorded BMI of 28.6. He has not been compliant with medical check-ups for the past 8 years.   DEMOGRAPHICS   Studies denote that the demographic most prone to abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAAs) include Caucasian men over the age of 65. Factors enhancing the risk of AAAs involve family history of the disease  smoking  and high blood pressure. Incidentally  these demographics and risk factors align with our patient's profile.  MEDICAL HISTORY   Mr. Anderson was diagnosed with hypertension 12 years ago. He has a history of hyperlipidemia for which he was prescribed statins. Mr. Anderson also reports his father died due to an aneurysm rupture  however  isn't sure of the location of the aneurysm. Despite his ailments  he has been rather noncompliant with the prescribed antihypertensive medications. The patient has no history of diabetes  cancer  or major surgeries.   PRESENT CONDITION   According to initial diagnostics such as a physical examination and ultrasound  there is a palpable and pulsating mass in his abdominal area  suggesting a possible abdominal aortic aneurysm. Immediate further investigations like Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) have been suggested to confirm the diagnosis as well as the severity of the aneurysm.   CONCLUSION   To summarize  Mr. Anderson's case exemplifies a high-risk patient for abdominal aortic aneurysms  given his advanced age  male gender  smoking history  hypertension  and family history of aneurysms. It underscores the need for rigorous preventive and screening strategies in individuals with such risk factors  in order to ensure early detection and management of AAAs.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient's Information: The patient  Mr. Smith  is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  living in a rural setting in the mid-western United States. He is a retired automobile mechanic and lives with his wife in a small town. He is an active smoker for the past 40 years with a significant pack-year history. He also reported feeling a palpable pulsating mass on his lower abdomen. However  he has no reported symptoms of fever  weight loss  or loss of appetite  and there was no recent trauma reported. This is a representation of an average patient who might present with an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  based on predominance in elderly males  Caucasians  smokers  and people with history of heart diseases as found in the literature. Title: A Clinical Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile  Name: Mr. David Layman Age: 74 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Factory Worker  Residence: Wichita  Kansas  Chief Complaint: Patient reports experiencing an intense and constant pain in his abdominal and lower back region for the last three days. He describes the pain as a ""deep gnawing sensation"" mostly localized to the middle of his abdomen.  Medical History: Mr. Layman has a significant history of peripheral arterial disease and high blood pressure. He is a former smoker  having quit the habit thirty years ago  after over twenty years of heavy smoking. He is also overweight with a BMI of 29. His diet is poor  high in processed foods and low in fruits and vegetables. He has had an irregular exercise habit  with long periods of sedentarism.   Family History:  Mr. Layman's father passed away at 62 due to a heart attack. His mother lived to 91 and had hypertension and osteoarthritis. He has two brothers  one of whom has a diagnosis of coronary artery disease.   Social History: Mr. Layman is a widower with three grown children. He lives alone and enjoys reading and watching television. He has a history of heavy alcohol consumption but has reduced his intake in recent years. He has declined overall since his wife's death five years ago.  Discussion: Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a condition that predominantly affects older males  especially those aged 65-75 years. Caucasians are reported to have a higher incidence than other races. Risk factors pertinent to Mr. Layman's case include his age  male sex  history of peripheral arterial disease  hypertension  smoking history  and family history of cardiovascular disease. It is worth noting that AAAs often remain silent until rupture  at which point they become a life-threatening emergency. Therefore  it's crucial to perform diagnostic tests  like ultrasound  once the suspicion is raised  for timely intervention.  This case presentation aligns with demographic data for AAA  as referenced in literature. Proactive treatment and lifestyle modifications can be lifesaving  emphasizing the role of primary health care providers in recognizing these risk factors early.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in Elderly Male Patient   Patient Presentation: Mr. Richardson  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presents to our clinic today with complaints of intermittent abdominal pain and lower back discomfort for the past few weeks. He denies fever  night sweats  or changes in bowel habits. His appetite has remained good. He lives with his wife and has a strong social support network.   Past Medical History: His medical history includes hypertension for which he has been on Atenolol for the last ten years. He has been relatively compliant with his medications. He was also diagnosed with hyperlipidemia five years ago which is managed with dietary modifications. He has no known drug allergies. He underwent appendectomy during his young adult years and has not had any significant illnesses since. His family history is pertinent for cardiovascular disease  with his father dying from a myocardial infarction at the age of 67.   Based on Mr. Richardson’s demographic profile  he corresponds to the typical patient diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). AAA predominantly affects older males  particularly those of Caucasian ethnicity. Risk factors include a history of smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia and a family history of cardiovascular disease  some of which Mr. Richardson possesses. The subtle  nonspecific nature of his presenting symptoms also indicates a potential AAA. Further investigation is warranted by complete physical examination and potentially an ultrasound or CT scan to confirm the diagnosis. We plan to conduct further diagnostic testing  while also educating him about the signs  symptoms  and risks associated with AAA.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Caucasian Male  Slide 1: Patient Introduction  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male presenting with abdominal pain and back pain that has been persistent for a week. He noticed a pulsating sensation in his abdomen and described the pain as entirely unusual to the minor discomforts he has experienced in the past.   Slide 2: Demographic Information and Prevalence  Abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAAs) are relatively common and can be life-threatening. They mostly occur in men over 65 years  with an estimated prevalence of 1.3% in men aged 45-54 years  jumping to 12.5% in those aged 75-84. They are more common in Caucasians while less common in Hispanic  African American  and Asian populations.   Slide 3: Medical History The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years  a significant risk factor for AAA. He has a past medical history of high blood pressure  hypercholesterolemia  and peripheral vascular disease  all of which exacerbate his risk. His father died from a ruptured AAA  indicating the patient's increased hereditary risk.   Slide 4: Current Medication The patient is currently on antihypertensives  a statin for cholesterol control  and aspirin for its antiplatelet effect. He is adherent with his medications and understands the necessity to manage his health conditions.   Slide 5: Pain Characteristic and Physical Examination The patient reports experiencing a sudden  severe pain in his lower back and abdomen. He has not felt any relief  regardless of his position or movement. Upon physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is palpable  and a bruit is heard through auscultation in the abdominal area.  Slide 6: Diagnostic Procedures Given the patient's presenting symptoms  past history  family history  and physical exam findings  an abdominal ultrasound is the immediate assessment for further evaluation on the suspicion of an AAA.  Slide 7: Management and Treatment The management will depend upon the size and growth rate of this AAA  as determined by ultrasound results. Small AAAs (less than 5.5 cm in men) are usually managed conservatively with surveillance and control of cardiovascular risk factors  such as smoking cessation and managing hypertension and cholesterol. However  larger AAAs or rapidly expanding those require surgical intervention.   Slide 8: Summary This presentation outlined the case of a 72-year-old Caucasian male presenting with symptoms suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Given his age  sex  family history  smoking habits  and medical history of high blood pressure  hypercholesterolemia  and peripheral vascular disease  this case is a representative example of an AAA patient to validate the need for a thorough evaluation.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm - Case Presentation  Slide 1: Introduction Mr. John Smith is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the Emergency Department at our hospital with complaints of severe  abrupt mid-abdominal pain.   Slide 2: Demographics As per literature  the demographic most affected by abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) are males over the age of 65  especially those of Caucasian descent.  Slide 3: Medical History The patient is a two packs per day smoker with a 50 year history  has moderate alcohol use  and a well-documented past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He had myocardial infarction 10 years ago and was treated successfully with a stent placement. Therefore  it depicts his risk factors associated with AAA  including long-term tobacco use  atherosclerosis  and advanced age.  Slide 4: Symptoms  Mr. Smith reported experiencing a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain that began approximately 3 hours prior to presentation. He stated the pain felt like a ripping sensation and was constant. He also felt some back pain  which he never had before.  Slide 5: Clinical findings and Diagnosis  On physical examination  his pulse was 110 beats per minute  blood pressure 150/95 mmHg  and an apparent non-tender abdominal mass. Further investigations (CT angiography) confirmed the presence of a 5.5 cm infrarenal AAA with evidence of rupture.   Slide 6: Treatment  The patient was immediately recommended for emergency endovascular aneurysm repair given his high risk for rupture and subsequent mortality. His postoperatory period was uneventful and was discharged after a week.  In this case  it is crucial to note that AAA is often asymptomatic until rupture  which emphasizes the importance of routine screening in older males with a history of smoking or atherosclerosis.   In conclusion  Mr. Smith's case is representative of a typical AAA patient  including age  gender  genetic risk factors  and lifestyle choices such as smoking and moderate alcohol use.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Our patient is Mr. James Anderson  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired police officer  presenting with an asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Mr. Anderson is a non-Hispanic  hailing from an urban setting  living with his wife of 40 years. James has a history of smoking  reporting a 30-pack year history  but successfully quit 10 years ago. He moderately consumes alcohol  with an intake of 2-3 standard drinks per week.   In terms of his medical history  Mr. Anderson has hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and peripheral artery disease. Mr. Anderson was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia 15 years ago and has been managing both conditions with medications. The peripheral artery disease was diagnosed five years ago  following changes in his exercise tolerance and walking distance. This patient presents an increased risk given these conditions  all of which could contribute to his current presentation of AAA.   He has  as well  a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father suffering a myocardial infarction at the age of 75  and his older brother also has an AAA.   Mr. Anderson does not have diabetes and has no known history of COPD or asthma.    His AAA was detected during a routine ultrasound screening; the aneurysm currently measures around 5.4 cm in size. Mr. Anderson has reported no symptoms related to the aneurysm  such as abdominal or back pain.  In terms of his psychosocial history  Mr. Anderson has been in a monogamous relationship for years and does not report any use of illicit drugs or practices of high-risk behaviors. He is currently under moderate stress due to his recent diagnosis.   This is a clear clinical presentation of an older adult man  representative of the typical demographic most commonly affected by AAA: older  male  with a past history of smoking  and pre-existing cardiovascular conditions. The literature consistently indicates these factors significantly contribute to the development and progression of AAA.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm: A Patient's Case Presentation   Introduction:  Our patient  Mr. Johnson  is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents with a diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Abdominal aortic aneurysms tend to be more prevalent amongst Caucasian men over the age of 60  aligning with Mr. Johnson's demographics.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a significant medical history that corresponds to the major risk factors associated with AAA. He was a long term smoker  having recently quit five years ago but he smoked a pack a day for nearly 50 years before that. He has a history of hypertension for which he takes Losartan 50 mg daily. His other relevant history includes high cholesterol  treated with Atorvastatin 20 mg  and a family history of cardiovascular disease  with both his father and elder brother having experienced myocardial infarctions. Mr. Johnson also had an episode of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) about 10 years ago  managed successfully with warfarin therapy.  Presenting Complaints: The presentation of an AAA can often be asymptomatic until rupture  making early detection conditions critical. Our patient reported mild to moderate abdominal and lower back pain consistent with AAA. He mentioned it felt different from his occasional flare-ups of chronic back pain. He also reported experiencing some episodes of brief dizziness over the past month.   Summary: In conclusion  Mr. Johnson is in the major risk demographic for abdominal aortic aneurysms  being a senior  Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidaemia  smoking  and familial predisposition. His presenting symptoms and history point towards AAA. Early detection and intervention are vital for such patients to avoid the catastrophic consequences of aortic rupture. The patient has been recommended for further diagnostic investigations and specialist referral.

Title: Presentation of Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Patient Information: The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. John Smith. He is retired military living in suburban Pennsylvania with his wife. He has been a smoker for more than 50 years and consumes alcohol moderately.  Medical Background: Mr. Smith has a medical history of hypertension and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  both chronic conditions commonly associated with the development of AAA. He had been prescribed antihypertensive medications and inhalers for the COPD  but his compliance with these therapies has been moderate at best. He does not report any family history of cardiovascular disease or aneurysms.  Present Complaint: Mr. Smith came for a scheduled regular checkup. While he does not have any persistent symptoms  he reports occasional mild abdominal and lower back pain  which he attributed to old age and physical strain. No weight loss  decreased appetite  or bowel irregularity reported.  Clinician’s Observations: On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was felt  which is a classic sign of AAA. Preliminary labs were carried out  and the patient’s blood pressure was found slightly elevated (150/90 mmHg). His BMI is 28.3 kg/m2  indicating overweight status which also increases the risk.  Diagnostic Procedure: Given the patient's age  gender  smoking history  hypertension  COPD  the presence of a suspicious pulsating mass in the abdomen  and a relevant risk factor BMI  a decision was made to further investigate the suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm with an abdominal ultrasound.  Discussion: AAA is more common in males  especially in their eighth (70-79 years old) decade of life  and Caucasian ethnicity. Risk factors to include tobacco use history  family history of AAA  COPD  and hypertension. Early detection leads to proper management hence prevention of fatal rupture.   Informed Consent: Mr. Smith was informed about the necessity of an ultrasound  and in case of confirmation  potential interventions ranging from careful monitoring to endovascular/surgical repair. As a retired military personnel  he understands the risks involved and agrees to proceed with further investigations.

Title: Case Presentation: An Elderly Male Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Introduction: The patient is a 73-year-old Caucasian male who presented with generalized abdominal pain  primarily located in the middle of the abdomen. The pain can be characterized as dull  continuous  and has been unrelieved in the past four days. He further reports that the pain seems to radiate to his lower back and is not associated with meals or bowel movements. According to the literature  AAA typically affects males over the age of 65 who have a history of smoking  which aligns with our patient's demographic.  Past Medical History: Mr. X has a history of long-standing hypertension and hyperlipidemia and was diagnosed with coronary artery disease seven years ago. He has successfully undergone coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). He also has Peripheral Artery Disease (PAD)  and underwent surgery for a similar aneurysm in his popliteal artery two years ago.   The patient is a long-term smoker and has consumed approximately 30 pack-years of cigarettes. Studies have shown that there is a strong correlation between heavy smoking and AAA. In August of 2015  his cardiologist had diagnosed him with a small infra-renal AAA measuring 3.0 cm in diameter discovered during a routine imaging study  which has been under surveillance.    Physical Examination: He appeared to be in discomfort and periods of restlessness. Blood pressure was 178/80 mmHg with a heart rate of 60 bpm. Examination of the abdomen revealed a palpable pulsatile mass in the epigastric region without overlying skin changes  bruit  or indications of inflammation. Additionally  there were no signs of peripheral vascular system abnormalities or other significant findings.   Conclusion: Given the patient’s advancing age  history of smoking  hyperlipidemia  and known diagnosis of infra-renal AAA  there is a high possibility that this increase in symptoms may be due to the progression of his AAA. Urgent imaging will be prioritized to assess the size and extent of the present AAA. Depending on the size of the aneurysm and the state of the patient  repair of the aneurysm would be considered promptly to prevent catastrophic consequences of rupture. It's critical to note that the most significant risk factors for AAA include age  male sex  smoking  and atherosclerosis  all of which coincide with the patient's health history.

Presentation:   Patient's Details:  Mr. Garcia  a 75-year-old Hispanic male  presents with complaints of persistent abdominal pain and discomfort. He has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50-pack year smoking history. He retired from a desk job 10 years ago and lives with his wife.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Garcia reports experiencing abdominal pain and discomfort  describing it as a deep  gnawing pain  which has been gradually increasing over the past several weeks. He had this on and off in the past but the severity and persistence caught his attention recently. He has tried OTC pain medications with slight relief.  Past Medical History: Mr. Garcia has been diagnosed with high blood pressure and hypercholesterolemia about 10 years ago for which he takes medication regularly. He has been a chronic heavy smoker for more than 50 years but has quit smoking a year ago. He underwent coronary angioplasty 8 years ago. There is no history of diabetes or renal disease. His surgical history is unremarkable.  Family History: There is a positive family history of cardiovascular disorders: his father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 68 and a brother who had a stroke at age 62.  Background: He worked as an accountant and carried out a relatively sedentary lifestyle. His diet was rich in saturated fats but has modified to a healthier one over the past decade due to his heart condition. He is married with three adult children and lives with his wife in suburban Chicago.  Explanation: This presentation reflects the demographic representation for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) as found in the literature. Men  particularly those over age 65  are significantly more likely to develop AAAs  as are smokers. High blood pressure  heart disease  and hyperlipidemia are identified as risk factors. The disease shows a racial bias  with reduced rates seen in Hispanic  African American and Asian populations compared to Caucasians. However  smoking  known to be a strong risk factor  levels the field leading to similar risks for Hispanics  overcoming the protective genetic factor.  This case attempts to demonstrate a typical example based on epidemiological studies  though it's important to bear in mind AAA can affect anyone  and presenting symptoms may vary. The chosen racial background  age  medical history  and lifestyle habits are in line with principal demographic information and disease occurrence frequency.

Title: Case Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Introduction:  Today we'll be discussing a case of a 72-year-old Caucasian male patient presenting with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm. The patient presents regularly for follow-ups  and on the last visit  severe abdominal pain paired with back pain and tenderness was observed.  Demographic Information: The patient is a retired engineer and a lifelong resident of Oklahoma  USA. He lives independently with his wife and reports that he continues to engage in social activities. He is a former smoker  who smoked a pack a day for approximately 50 years recollecting to have stopped smoking around his 62nd birthday. He is a social drinker and denies any illicit drug usage.   Medical History:  1. Hypertension: Diagnosed at age 55  and has been on a regular treatment regimen of ACE inhibitors and beta-blockers. 2. Hyperlipidemia: Diagnosed at age 58  and has been on statin therapy since. 3. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus: Diagnosed at age 60  well-controlled with oral hypoglycemics.  Family History:  The patient has a family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father having passed away at the age of 70 of a myocardial infarction and a paternal uncle who had an aneurysm (unknown location).  Physical Examination:  On physical examination  the patient appears in apparent distress due to abdominal and back pain. There's noted abdominal tenderness with an evident pulsatile mass in the central abdomen upon palpation. Blood pressure was slightly elevated at 156/90 mmHg.  Presentation Synopsis:  The patient's age  sex  longstanding hypertension  hyperlipidemia  smoking history  and positive family history put him at a significantly higher risk for AAA. Further investigations including abdominal ultrasonography or CT Aortogram will be needed to confirm the AAA  its size  location  and the need for intervention.  This case represents the typical demographic found in literature  as AAAs are seen more commonly in males  Caucasians  smokers  and individuals with a family history of aneurysm or cardiovascular disease. This condition is seen typically in the age group of 65-75 years old.  Importantly  this patient’s AAA symtoms  including the severe abdominal and back pain  may suggest rupture  which would warrant immediate medical attention. Our discussion to follow will plan out possible diagnostic and treatment pathways for this patient.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Profile: Mr. James Foster  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  with a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  presents with what he describes as a ""deep  gnawing pain"" in his lower abdomen and back. Mr. Foster is a retired construction worker and mentions being a smoker for 45 years.  History of Present Illness: Mr. Foster reports the pain started about a week ago  subtly  but has gradually become persistent. At first  he ascribed the discomfort to old age or possible gastric issues. However  the abrupt increase in its severity compelled him to seek medical attention. The pain isn't worsened or alleviated by food intake  posture  or using analgesics.   Past Medical History: Mr. Foster has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia managed on Lisinopril and Simvastatin  respectively. He has been adherent to the medications and maintains follow-ups with his primary healthcare physician. He was diagnosed with mild COPD approximately three years ago  secondary to his long history of smoking.   Family History: Mr. Foster’s father suffered from cardiovascular disease  dying from a heart attack in his late sixties  suggesting potential genetic predisposition to vascular diseases. No other significant family history was mentioned.  Social History: Mr. Foster lives with his wife in their suburban home. He quit smoking five years ago but admits a 45-year history of tobacco use. He drinks alcohol socially and denies illicit drug use.   Investigations & Diagnosis: Given the nature of his pain  patient’s advanced age  male sex  history of smoking  and having vascular risk factors such as hypertension and hyperlipidemia  an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was suspected. Physical examination demonstrated abdominal tenderness and a pulsatile abdominal mass. An urgent abdominal ultrasound was ordered  which confirmed the presence of a 5.5cm infrarenal aortic aneurysm in diameter. This diagnosis of AAA is consistent with literature indicating this condition is most prevalent in older Caucasian males with a history of smoking and other vascular risk factors.  Management: He was immediately referred to a vascular surgeon for evaluation for potential intervention  considering his symptoms and aneurysm size exceeding 5 cm. His primary care doctor was notified  and arrangements have been made for follow-up and further management.  Sources:   Upchurch  G. R.  Jr  & Schaub  T. A. (2006). Abdominal aortic aneurysm. American family physician  73(7)  1198-1204.

Title: Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a Case  Slide 1: Introduction   Patient Profile: - Mr. Davis  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer - Known smoker for 45 years  attempted to quit multiple times but unsuccessful - Suffers from moderate obesity – Current BMI stands at 30.5 - Family history significant for cardiovascular mortality (Father died at age 62 from a heart attack  mother suffered a stroke at age 70) - Is a moderate alcohol drinker  - Lives a sedentary lifestyle   Slide 2: Medical History   - Hypertensive for 15 years  currently on Lisinopril  - Diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus 10 years ago  on Metformin - Diagnosed and treated for high cholesterol  currently on Atorvastatin - Regular checkups indicated steadily progressive peripheral artery disease over the past 8 years  asymptomatic so far - Had a bout of transient ischemic attack 5 years ago  subsequently put on low-dose Aspirin regimen   Slide 3: Presenting Symptoms   - Leaking Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm suspected - Complains of continuous and severe abdominal and back pain  described as a dull throbbing sensation – pain score 8/10 - Reports that he often feels lightheaded and experienced fainting attack once recently - Loss of appetite and constipation noticed  Slide 4: Risk Factors   Consistent with the demographic data: - Age: Most AAAs occur in patients aged 65 and older - Sex: Males are 4-5 times more likely to develop an AAA - Smoking: A significant risk factor contributing to AAA development and growth - Upstream Diseases: Hypertension  Peripheral Artery Disease  and Atherosclerosis - Family History: Increase in the risk due to genetics   Slide 5: Conclusion   Mr. Davis has multiple risk factors making him a candidate for an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA). His symptoms  along with his medical history  point towards a leaking AAA that may require immediate attention to prevent rupture. It would be prudent to assess further using diagnostic tools like an abdominal ultrasound or CT angiogram to confirm diagnosis and plan for the necessary intervention.   Note: Confidentiality maintained by altering the name while presenting the case. It's essential to approach each patient with respect and provide the necessary care and support.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Introduction:  A 70-year-old Caucasian male patient  Mr. J.C.  presents today with significant abdominal pain  predominantly in the lower regions  which he describes as a pulsating feeling ""like a heartbeat"" in his abdomen. The patient is a former smoker  having quit the habit about seven years ago after a four-decade long history of smoking.  Background: Mr. J.C. has a past medical history including hypertension  high cholesterol  and heart disease  specifically coronary artery disease  for which he underwent angioplasty five years ago. He was also diagnosed with peripheral artery disease three years ago  a condition that has been controlled with medical management. He has been adherent to his medications and follows up regularly with his cardiologist. He lives independently at home with his wife and maintains an active lifestyle. He does not have any genetic disorders  nor any familial history of the aortic aneurysm. He is not a diabetic nor has he ever been diagnosed with a connective tissue disorder.   Medical Assessment and Plan:  Given his presenting symptoms and significant cardiovascular history  the possibility of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a substantial cause for concern. Mr. J.C.'s age  male gender  smoking history  hypertension  and peripheral artery disease are known risk factors for AAA  as documented in the literature.   To evaluate this prospect further  a physical examination involving a detailed cardiovascular and abdominal exam along with diagnostic studies  specifically an abdominal ultrasound  are recommended. Should an AAA be confirmed  the size will necessitate an immediate response. Small aneurysms may benefit from monitoring through medical management and lifestyle modifications  while larger or growing aneurysms may warrant surgical intervention. Further consultation with a vascular surgeon will be advised accordingly.   In summary  Mr. J.C.’s presentation and history reveal several risk factors for AAA. Further evaluation will help to confirm this diagnosis. His case emphasizes the importance of regular health surveillance in those with multiple risk factors for AAA to allow early identification and optimization of care.  References: 1. Sampson UK  Norman PE  Fowkes FG  Aboyans V  Song Y  Harrell FE Jr  Forouzanfar MH  Naghavi M  Denenberg JO  McDermott MM. Estimation of global and regional incidence and prevalence of abdominal aortic aneurysms 1990 to 2010. Glob Heart. 2014;9(1):159-170. 2. Golledge J  Norman PE. Current status of medical management for abdominal aortic aneurysm. Atherosclerosis. 2011;217(1):57-63.

Slide 1: Introduction Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Slide 2: Demographics  Today’s case involves a 72-year-old Caucasian male patient. The choice of this particular demographic is based on the prevalence of abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA)  which are most commonly found among older males and individuals of European descent.  Slide 3: Patient History Our patient  Mr. Thomas  is a retired construction worker who has a 45-year history of smoking  with a cessation 6 years ago. He presents with occasional abdominal and lower back pain  which is common in the setting of an AAA. He is also overweight with a body mass index (BMI) of 31  and has been diagnosed with hyperlipidemia years ago. All of these factors together represent the strong lifestyle and genetic risks associated with the development of an AAA.  Slide 4: Further Background & Investigations Former investigations were carried out when Mr. Thomas felt a ""pulse-like"" feeling in his stomach. Subsequent ultrasound images revealed an AAA of 5.3 cm  which had increased slightly from a 5.1 cm measurement a year ago.   Slide 5: Past Medical History Mr. Thomas's past medical history is significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  which are conditions that have been associated with AAA in several studies. He underwent a CABG procedure 10 years ago  indicating existing coronary artery disease.   Slide 6: Conclusion  Understanding our patient’s demographic information and past medical history  we can offer appropriate intervention including closer monitoring or surgical consultations. AAA can be effectively managed when such risks are identified and properly addressed.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male Patient  Patient Profile: Patient Name: Mr. X  Age: 72 years old Gender: Male Race/ Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired   Presenting Complaint: Mr. X  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presents with complaints of constant  intense pain in his lower back and abdominal region extending down to his pelvis.
