Past Medical History: Mr. X has a history of hypertension and atherosclerosis. He has been a lifelong smoker  although he reduced the frequency to just a few cigarettes per day after his diagnosis of hypertension 10 years ago. He has no known allergies to medications. Mr. X's family history reveals that his father died of an aortic aneurysm at the age of 78  and his elder brother had surgery for a similar condition when he was 67.   Current Medications:  Mr. X is currently on Lisinopril  a medication for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for the management of atherosclerosis. He also takes a daily aspirin as advised by his previous physician for coronary artery disease prevention.  Summary:  This case presentation highlights the typical demographic profile of a person diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm  which frequently occurs in Caucasian males above 65 years of age with a history of hypertension  atherosclerosis  smoking  and familial disposition. Key identifiers are severe pain in the lower back and abdominal area. The patient's past medical history and current medications illustrate the connection between cardiovascular disease and abdominal aortic aneurysms. His family history emphasizes the genetic component often seen in such cases.

Patient Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Demographics: Mr. Joseph Johnson is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired  originally from Ohio  currently residing in Florida. He is a widower  living with his son's family. His lifetime occupation involved managing a construction business. Mr. Johnson was a heavy smoker but quit about ten years ago. However  he continues to consume alcohol moderately.  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson has a multi-faceted medical history that includes controlled hypertension (on medication)  hyperlipidemia  and a previous cerebral sensorial episode about five years ago with no neurological sequelae. He has a reported history of 30-pack-years tobacco use. There are no known drug allergies. He is positive for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and signs of peripheral vascular disease  including intermittent claudication. Atherosclerosis  impacting the large and medium-sized arteries  was diagnosed earlier this year. His father passed away from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   Current Presentation: Mr. Johnson was referred to the hospital by his primary care physician following a routine physical exam that raised suspicions of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He reports a vague discomfort in his abdominal region  which he initially attributed to excess gas or indigestion  since it did not affect his appetite or bowel movements. He also mentioned an occasional feeble pulse in his abdomen when he laid flat on his back. On investigation  the mentioned discomfort was placed just above the umbilicus  lateralized on his right side. Mr. Johnson denies any back pain  unexplained weight loss  fever  or any other urgent symptoms.   Medical literature reflects that abdominal aortic aneurysms are more common in males over the age of 65  particularly  those with a history of smoking  hypertension  and a familial history of aneurysms  congruent with Mr. Johnson's demographics and history. Moreover  Caucasians are reported to have a higher risk of having AAA  thus making this a highly probable diagnosis. Most AAAs are asymptomatic and are often detected during routine physical exams  similar to the suspected case of the patient.

Title: Case Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile:  Mr. Alex Kowalski is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who has been active and has lived a relatively healthy lifestyle until recently when he began experiencing moderate  persistent pain in his lower abdomen and lower back. Mr. Kowalski is a retired electrician currently residing in the suburbs of New York with his wife. He has a 30-year history of tobacco use but quit smoking five years ago. He admits to moderate alcohol intake  namely  a few bottles of beer each week.  Relevant Medical history:  Mr. Kowalski has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been managed well with medications. He also had a mild heart attack at the age of 67. He has Type 2 diabetes mellitus  which has been managed through oral hypoglycemic medications and lifestyle changes.  Presenting Symptoms:  He presents consistent  dull  and severe ache in his lower abdomen and lower back  which has persisted for the last two weeks. The pain does not radiate and is not relieved by change in position or over-the-counter pain killers. He also expresses feeling unusually tired but has not experienced any drastic weight changes  fever or night sweats. He denies recent trauma or heavy lifting.  Reason for Consultation:  These symptoms brought him to his primary care physician  who upon suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  referred him to our Cardiovascular department for further workup.   High-risk factors to consider for this patient:  Given Mr. Kowalski's age  gender  history of smoking  and existing comorbid conditions such as hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and heart disease  he has several risk factors that increase the likelihood of developing an AAA.  Assessment Plan:  We plan to proceed with conducting an abdominal ultrasound  the primary diagnostic test for AAA. Depending on the results  a Computer Tomography (CT) scan or Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) may be necessary for a more detailed assessment of the aorta.   If Mr. Kowalski is indeed found to have an AAA  we'll develop a management plan that may involve surveillance  medication adjustment  and potentially even surgery  depending upon the size and growth rate of the aneurysm and the overall assessment of Mr. Kowalski's health status.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm: A Clinical Case Presentation   Patient Information:  Mr. J is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presents with a week-long history of persistent lower back pain and occasional abdominal pain. The patient also reports feelings of lightheadedness and rapid heartbeat  especially after physical activities.  Past Medical History:  Mr. J is  a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago after a 40-year habit  and has a history of hypertension  mildly elevated cholesterol levels  and had a myocardial infarction 7 years back. He currently controls his hypertension and cholesterol levels with medication.   Occupational History:  Mr. J is a retired civil engineer  and lives with his wife in a suburb. He has a history of moderate alcohol intake but denies use of any illicit drugs.  Family History:  His father passed away due to myocardial infarction at the age of 65. Mr. J is unaware of any other vascular diseases within his close relatives.  Reason for Current Presentation:  The patient first noticed his back pain a week ago. He initially thought it was due to physical strain from gardening but the pain persisted despite rest and over the counter pain medications. On presentation  the pain is described as dull aching. The abdomen is mildly tender to touch with no pulsations felt upon palpation. The patient also reports unintentional weight loss over the past six months.  Epidemiology:  Abdominal aortic aneurysm predominantly affects older adults  especially males over the age of 65. Risk factors include tobacco use  hypertension  family history  and white ancestry  all of which Mr. J possesses.  With his persistent lower back and abdominal pain  unintentional weight loss  the patient's presenting symptoms are consistent with an unruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA). The family history of cardiovascular disease and his personal history of hypertension and former smoker status are also significant risk factors. We recommend further imaging studies to confirm the presence and extent of his potential abdominal aortic aneurysm. In case confirmed  a referral to a vascular surgeon for possible surgery shall be considered.

Slide 1: Introduction  Today's case presentation is centered on a condition referred to as Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA). The aneurysm denotes an enlarged area in the lower facet of the aorta  the leading bloodstream channel within the human system. AAAs pose a serious risk as they can lead to severe and lethal bleeding if ruptured.   Slide 2: Patient Demographics and History  Mr. James  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presents to our clinic with symptoms indicative of AAA  which include: pain in his abdomen and back  vomits  and dizziness. He is a lifelong smoker with a 50-pack-year history  and has a concomitant medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is socially active  consumes alcohol moderately  and has never been diagnosed with any psychiatric disorders.  Slide 3: Statistical Overview  The demographics and health history align well with the literature on typical AAA patients. The prevalence of AAA varies across different areas but is particularly high amongst Caucasian males over the age of 65 years. Inferred from systematic review data  the age-standardized prevalence of AAA amongst men over 70 years old is approximately 3.9-7.2%. Known risk factors such as older age  male sex  and smoking are present.   Slide 4: Physical Examination and Investigations   On physical examination  a pulsating mass was felt in his abdomen. His blood pressure was elevated at 160/90  and his pulse was at 80/mi. A preliminary ultrasound confirmed a 5.2 cm abdominal aortic aneurysm.   Slide 5: Discussion and Plan   Given the size of the AAA and the symptoms presented  surgery is strongly recommended for Mr. James  since the aneurysm is at an increased risk of rupturing. Furthermore  it is necessary to manage his hypertension and hyperlipidemia with appropriate medication adjustments to prevent any additional cardiovascular complications. His smoking habit is a major concern  which should be addressed through counseling and cessation support.   Mr. James represents a unique opportunity to understand AAA's real-world impact considering his presentation aligns very well with typical AAA demographics.

Introduction: Today  we examine the case of a 69-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. X  who presents with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   Demographics: Mr. X is in line with a typical AAA patient demographic: predominantly found in males and those over 65 years old  specifically White/Caucasian  which accounts for 80% of AAA cases in the United States. He is a retired engineer living with his wife of 40 years. He has a history of smoking for over 30 years before successfully quitting 15 years ago. His BMI is within an overweight range  which aligns with epidemiological studies showing a high prevalence of AAA in overweight individuals.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. X visited his primary care doctor reporting a persistent abdominal and lower back pain for two weeks. His pain level ranged from moderate to severe and was often unprovoked  becoming more intense after his evening meals.   Past Medical History: Mr. X’s past medical history is significant for high blood pressure and high cholesterol levels for the last ten years  both controlled with medication. His father also had an abdominal aortic aneurysm  revealing a crucial familial tendency.   Physical examination and relevant tests:  On physical examination  Mr. X’s blood pressure was slightly elevated at 145/85 mmHg  despite regular use of antihypertensive medications. His abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the mid-epigastric region. An ensuing non-contrast CT scan confirmed an infrarenal AAA of about 5.5 cm diameter.  Conclusion: Mr. X's case bears classic AAA features including  being a former smoker  having a history of hypertension and dyslipidemia and a familial history of AAA. As his aneurysm is over 5.5 cm  the risk of rupture is significant  necessitating immediate surgical evaluation and likely intervention.   This case underscores how essential early detection and monitoring of AAA is  especially in high-risk individuals like Mr. X  to prevent possible rupture and associated morbidity and mortality.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: Our patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male by the name of Mr. Smith. He is a retired engineer with a long history of smoking and minimal physical activity. Mr. Smith has been residing with his wife in their suburban home in Houston  Texas.  Medical History: Mr. Smith has been managed for hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past 15 years  controlled through pharmacotherapy. He has also been diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  primarily caused by his habit of smoking approximately 2 packs of cigarettes per day for 50 years. His other specific medical conditions include peripheral arterial disease and a history of coronary angioplasty performed 7 years ago due to coronary artery disease. No known drug allergies have been reported.  Clinical Presentation: Over the last three weeks  Mr. Smith started experiencing episodic abdominal pain  typically after meals  which he initially attributed to gastric discomfort. However  the frequency and intensity of the pain progressively escalated. He describes it as a sharp  gnawing sensation located in the mid-abdominal region that sometimes radiates to his lower back. This was often accompanied by a sense of fullness or bloating.  Last evening  he had an episode of acute severe abdominal and back pain that alarmed him  prompting his visit to our emergency department. Upon initial physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpated. His vitals at presentation were: Blood pressure – 155/95 mmHg; Heart rate – 90 beats/min; Respiratory rate – 18 breaths/min; Temperature – 98.4°F; Oxygen saturation – 94% on room air.   This clinical presentation and history suggest the possibility of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Urgent imaging studies were ordered to confirm this diagnosis and ascertain if a surgical intervention is necessary.  Demographic Representation: The patient's profile matches demographic characteristics typically associated with abdominal aortic aneurysms. As per the literature  these are more frequently found in males  with increased incidence among the elderly  specifically those aged 65 to 75+. Smoking  hypertension  peripheral arterial disease  and atherosclerosis are known high-risk factors for the development of abdominal aortic aneurysms. Caucasians are also noted to have a significantly increased incidence than other racial groups. Mr. Smith's medical background and lifestyle align with these risk factors.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Patient Demographics: Mr. Jacobs is a 74-year-old Caucasian male  who is a retired military officer. He lives with his wife in the rural area of Arkansas and has two adult children living out of state. The relevance of his demographic information is based on the data from the literature which shows that Caucasian males  especially over the age of 65  show a higher prevalence of AAAs. Rural or semi-rural residents also have a higher incidence of AAA  likely due to access to healthcare.  Past Medical History: Mr. Jacobs has a significant past medical history. This includes a 45-year history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  as well as a diagnosis of peripheral arterial disease ten years ago. All three conditions have well-established links to AAA  due to the strain they put on the vascular system.   He has a smoking history of 30 pack-years  and although he quit smoking ten years ago  his past smoking status is a key risk factor for AAA. He does not consume alcohol excessively and he follows a balanced diet.   There is also a relevant family history; his father had a AAA  which increases his own risk of having the disease.   Mr. Jacobs has been relatively physically active throughout his life  which may have conferred some level of protection against the development or progression of AAA.  Current Presentation and Clinical Findings: Mr. Jacobs presented to the emergency department complaining of a severe  sharp  and persistent pain in his lower back and abdominal area that came on suddenly. He also reported feeling light-headed and having cold  sweaty skin. On examination  there was a palpable pulsating mass in his abdomen  which raised the suspicion of a ruptured AAA.  In conclusion  Mr. Jacobs  as an elderly Caucasian male  with a history of smoking  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  peripheral arterial disease  and a familial history of AAA  falls within the high-risk group for AAA. His current symptoms and clinical findings strongly suggest a life-threatening condition  possibly a ruptured AAA that requires immediate medical attention.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Introduction:  Mr. X is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presented with abdominal pain and back pain. These are the classic symptoms of an abdominal aortic aneurysm but they only occur in around 50% of cases.   Demographics: Currently residing in Florida  Mr. X is retired and lives with his wife of 40 years. He is a former smoker having quit 15 years ago  but has a long history of smoking 2 packs a day for 30 years. He was regularly exposed to secondhand smoke during his youth and early adulthood. From the data available  men  especially those of Caucasian ethnicity  aged 65-75 years with a history of smoking are more likely to have abdominal aortic aneurysms.  Medical History: Mr. X has a rather significant past medical history that includes hypertension and high cholesterol  for which he takes prescribed medication. He also has been treated for peripheral arterial disease and coronary artery disease. He reports having had a previous myocardial infarction (heart attack) several years ago. He was also diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) 10 years ago and has regular check-ups with a pulmonologist. He admits to his difficulty in maintaining a healthy eating and exercise regimen.  Recent Symptoms: Over the past week  he has been experiencing intermittent abdominal pain and a throbbing sensation in the abdomen. Occasionally  he has reported low back pain concentrated in the lower lumbar region. He also mentions experiencing brief spells of faintness and dizziness.  Conclusion: Given his age  sex  race  family history  and lifestyle  Mr. X has multiple risk factors synonymous with the possibility of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The aching  pulsation and tenderness he has been experiencing in his abdominal and lower back areas  coupled with spells of dizziness and faintness  indicates the need for immediate diagnosis and clinical intervention to prevent life-threatening conditions like rupture and hemorrhage.  Mr. X is demonstrating signs that warrant immediate attention and further diagnostic testing. Studies have shown that ruptured AAAs are often fatal  with about 80% not surviving until surgical repair  stressing the need for early diagnosis. It's crucial to push forth for an abdominal ultrasound  a non-invasive  accessible  and highly accurate test to detect an AAA.

Title: Presentation of Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Name: Mr. John Smith  Age: 75 Years Old  Sex: Male   Race: Caucasian  I'd like to present our latest case  a 75-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. John Smith who came to our care complaining of severe abdominal and lower back pain  intermittent and unprompted in nature. This symptom suggests the possible presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Mr. Smith is a retired construction worker  has a 30-year history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and had a 40 pack-year smoking history  however  he quit smoking 10 years ago. His family history is significant with his father and grandfather both having died due to an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture in their late seventies.   He does not have diabetes and neither any history of cardiovascular diseases  but he has been clinically obese for over 20 years. Despite having peripheral arterial disease diagnosed 7 years ago  the patient has been consistent with his medications and follow-ups.  It's important to note that Mr. Smith fits the predominant demographic pattern for AAA  as major clinical studies show men  particularly those of Caucasian descent above 65  being disproportionately affected by AAA. Key risk factors  as found in literature  like age  male sex  smoking history  family history of AAA  and presence of other atherosclerotic diseases align pretty well with Mr. Smith's profile.   Whilst abdominal and back pain might possibly indicate signs of AAA rupture in his condition  it is noteworthy to mention AAA is often asymptomatic until it ruptures  making screening and early detection critically important in patients with high risk.  It is imperative that we conduct further tests to confirm the diagnosis such as abdominal ultrasound or computed tomography angiogram (CTA)  considering his history and current symptoms  to rule out any possibilities of an impending AAA rupture and manage it accordingly. Immediate intervention  either surgical or endovascular  will be particularly crucial if diagnostic procedures confirm a large  symptomatic AAA.   Mr. Smith's case presentation emphasizes the importance of recognizing AAA's associated risk factors and taking them into account in the early detection and management of this condition.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Case Presentation  Patient's Details: The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. J. He is a retired construction worker and has been a smoker for more than 50 years  currently consuming a pack of cigarettes per day. He has a previous medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia and follows his medication regimen of statins and antihypertensive drugs diligently. On his paternal side  both his father and grandfather had aneurysms  which makes him genetically predisposed for the ailment.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. J visited the clinic complaining of persistent abdominal and lower back pain for the past two weeks which he says is not related to any injury. He also reported feeling unusually fatigued and experiencing slight weight loss without any significant change in his diet.  Examination Findings: The physical examination revealed a pulsating mass in the abdomen. More detailed investigations through ultrasound and CT scan confirmed the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The aneurysm measures 5.3 cm in diameter  positioning it in the high-risk category warranting surgery.  Risk Factors: Mr. J’s risk factors for AAA include his age  male sex  genetic predisposition  history of smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Caucasian ethnicity. As per the literature  Caucasians  especially those over 65 years of age  have a higher risk of AAA  and the male to female ratio is about 4:1. Smoking has been linked to about 75% of all cases of AAA.  Action Plan: Given the size of the aneurysm and the patient's symptoms  the immediate recommendation is for him to undergo corrective surgery. Meanwhile  Mr. J has been advised to quit smoking and maintain his control over hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Discussion and Prognosis: With careful perioperative management  the prognosis after surgery is optimistic. Regular follow-ups and monitoring of his hypertension and cholesterol levels are crucial to the long-term success of the treatment and to prevent the recurrence of another AAA. Counseling to promote smoking cessation will also play a significant part in improving Mr. J's overall health status.

Title: A Case of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Slide 1: Introduction  Patient: Mr. John Smith  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presents with sharp  severe pain in his lower back and abdominal region  accompanied by light-headedness and nausea.  Slide 2: Past Medical History   Mr. Smith is a retired construction worker with a medical history of smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for about 40 years. He has a history of hypertension  high cholesterol levels and atherosclerosis.   Slide 3: Demographics & Risk  Studies have shown that Caucasian males over 65 years  particularly those with a smoking history and cardiovascular diseases such as hypertension and atherosclerosis  face a higher risk of developing an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Slide 4: Presenting symptoms  Mr. Smith presents with symptoms typical of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  including severe pain in the abdomen or lower back that doesn't go away  feeling lightheaded  or nausea. These symptoms may indicate rupture of aneurysm which is a medical emergency and needs immediate attention.  Slide 5: Diagnosis   Preliminary physical examination showed a pulsating mass on palpation in the abdominal region. An abdominal ultrasound confirmed the presence of a large abdominal aortic aneurysm  measuring 5.5 cm in diameter.  Slide 6: Treatment options & Management  The treatment options are based on the size of the aneurysm. Since Mr. Smith's aneurysm is considered large (5.5 cm)  surgical repair  either via an open procedure or less invasive endovascular approach  is likely the preferable treatment approach.  Slide 7: Conclusion   Prompt recognition of the signs and symptoms of an abdominal aortic aneurysm is critical for emergency management and surgical intervention. In this case  Mr. Smith's risk factors (age  gender  race  smoking history  and cardiovascular diseases) should prompt healthcare providers to maintain a high level of suspicion for this potentially lethal condition. Regular screening and check-ups can help with early detection and management of this condition.   Slide 8: References  (List of references to support case study)

Title: A Case Presentation on Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Introduction:  Good morning/afternoon everyone  I would like to present a case on abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). AAA is a localized dilatation of the part of an aortic artery affecting the region below the kidneys. They usually occur silently  but when symptoms manifest or rupture occurs  it can lead to serious consequences.  Patient Information:  The patient is Mr. Smith  a 72-year-old Caucasian male residing in a suburban community. Literature indicates that AAA generally affects older men  particularly those of the white race  hence Mr. Smith's demographic is representative.  Presenting Complaint and History:  Mr. Smith was referred to our vascular clinic following an incidental finding of an abdominal aortic aneurysm on an ultrasound scan which was carried out for his recurrent urinary tract infection. Patient reports a history of vague discomfort in the belly but denies any chest pain  back pain or lower limb weakness.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a significant past medical history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and has been a smoker for 40 years  with an average of 20 cigarettes per day. He was treated for a myocardial infarction five years ago. His surgical history includes having undergone an appendectomy at 20 years of age. There is a known family history of cardiovascular diseases but no known genetic diseases.  Investigations:  The patient's AAA measured 3.8 cm on the ultrasound scan  which is less than the surgical threshold of 5.5 cm. However  Mr. Smith's significant risk factors make his case more precarious and necessitates careful surveillance.  Treatment and Management:  Given Mr. Smith's AAA is below surgical threshold and currently asymptomatic  we are managing his condition conservatively with strict blood pressure control  aggressive lipid management and smoking cessation. He is being closely followed up at our clinic every six months with ultrasound scans to monitor for any increase in the size of his AAA.  Summary:  In summary  Mr. Smith represents a high-risk profile for the potential development of AAA complications given his age  gender  ethnicity  smoking history  and cardiovascular condition. His case underscores the reason why vigilant monitoring and management of risk factors is of utmost importance in the conservative management of an AAA.  Thank you. I am open for any questions or discussion.

Subject: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Demographic Information: The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired elementary school teacher and is currently living with his wife of 45 years. The patient lives in a suburban neighborhood and has maintained a relatively active lifestyle  including regular walks and gardening.  Past Medical History: The patient has a complicated medical history including hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50-pack-year history of smoking. He quit smoking ten years ago after a minor stroke but never received any endovascular intervention to manage the high-risk factors.   The patient's father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 71  which was managed surgically  hence there's a family history of AAA. He has known allergies to penicillin and ibuprofen. His medications include atenolol and simvastatin prescribed for his existing conditions.  Presentation: The patient attended the clinic complaining of sudden  severe  and constant pain in his lower back and abdomen. He described a pulsating sensation near his navel and he reported unintentional weight loss of approximately 10 pounds over the past two months. He denied any changes in bowel or bladder habits but mentioned feelings of lightheadedness and dizziness.  Upon physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was detected through palpation. Blood pressure reading showed 145/90 mmHg  and his pulse was irregular. As his symptomatology and medical history (hypertension  hyperlipidemia  old age  male gender  family history  and smoking) are highly suggestive of possible AAA  he has been referred for further diagnostic testing including ultrasound and computer-assisted tomography (CT) scanning.   Unfortunately  AAA is a silent condition until a life-threatening rupture occurs. This case underscores the need for routine screening for high-risk individuals  especially older males with a history of smoking and hypertension. Early detection increases the treatment options and can drastically improve prognosis.   As demographic data suggests  Caucasian males above 65  particularly those with a family history  exhibit higher prevalence rates for AAA. Although smoking rates have decreased over time  current and former smokers remain at elevated risk for developing this disease. Other risk factors may include hyperlipidemia and hypertension. Individuals who match these demographic and clinical traits should be considered for regular screening to ensure prompt diagnosis and management of this potentially lethal condition.

Title: Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male Patient  Demographic Information: Our patient today is Mr. Smith  an 80-year-old Caucasian male. He lives independently and is a retired engineer. He is a non-smoker but has a history of moderate alcohol usage.   Medical History: Mr. Smith has a significant medical history which includes Hypertension  for which he takes an ACE inhibitor; Hyperlipidemia  managed through a statin therapy; and Type II Diabetes Mellitus  which is controlled using Metformin. He also has a history of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD).  Presenting Issue: Recently  Mr. Smith has been experiencing episodes of intermittent abdominal pain that sometimes radiates to his back. The pain has been non-continuous  episodic  and mild; however  the frequency has increased over the last two weeks. Due to this  he has experienced reduced appetite and resultant weight loss. No other significant clinical symptoms are associated including fever  nausea  vomiting  or change in bowel habits.  According to the literature  abdominal aortic aneurysms are most common in males over the age of 65  especially those with a history of smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and atherosclerosis  all of which Mr. Smith represents.   Upon physical examination  a palpable abdominal mass was detected in the peri-umbilical area. This mass was pulsatile and slightly tender  raising suspicion of the possible presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The rest of his examination was unremarkable.  Next steps include further investigations such as an Abdominal Ultrasound and possibly a CT Angiography to confirm the diagnosis and ascertain the severity of his condition. Upon confirmation  an appropriate treatment plan can be considered  including possible surgical intervention if warranted by the size and risk of rupture.   Implementation of lifestyle changes are also to be advised such as reduction in alcohol consumption  regular exercise and a healthy diet to keep his comorbid conditions under control and prevent the progression of the aneurysm.

Title: Clinical Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile: The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male living in the Midwest region of the United States. He is a retired industrial worker and lives with his wife  with weekly visits from his adult children.   History: The patient has a past medical history notable for high blood pressure  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-year pack history of cigarette smoking but quit 10 years ago. He also has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father dying from a stroke at the age of 76.  Presenting Issue: The patient arrived in the emergency room with sudden onset of severe abdominal and back pain  describing it as a tearing sensation  and the symptoms have drawn concern for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The patient also reports mild lightheadedness and feeling of ""impending doom "" but denies chest pain  shortness of breath  and loss of consciousness.  Physical Examination: The patient appeared uncomfortable due to pain but was otherwise alert and oriented. Vital signs revealed blood pressure of 180/90 mmHg  heart rate of 100 bpm  and respiratory rate of 16 bpm. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the midline of the abdomen. Laboratory test results are pending.  Demographic Background: Abdominal aortic aneurysms primarily affect older adults  particularly men over 65 years of age. According to epidemiological studies  abdominal aortic aneurysms are most prevalent in Caucasians  especially those of European descent. Men are four times more likely than women to develop AAA  and there is a strong correlation with a history of cigarette smoking and hypertension. It is also notable that 1 in 4 patients with AAA have a first-degree relative who has also had an AAA  indicating a potential genetic predisposition.  Close monitoring  early detection and timely intervention are crucial for patients with an AAA to prevent life-threatening rupture. The clinician team must collaborate to provide optimal medical management and surgical intervention if necessary.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Profile:  Mr. John Baker is a 72 years old Caucasian male  currently residing in the suburbs of Chicago  IL. He is a retired mechanical engineer and has a history of smoking  consuming about a pack of cigarettes a day for the past 40 years. He is also moderately overweight with a body mass index (BMI) of 29.  Medical History: Mr. Baker has an established past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are controlled with medication (Lisinopril 20 mg daily and Atorvastatin 40 mg daily). He reports compliance with these medications. He had a heart attack ten years ago  requiring a stenting procedure. He had also undergone a laparoscopic cholecystectomy approximately five years ago.   Presenting Complaint: Mr. Baker presented with an intermittent  vague abdominal pain  particularly post meals  associated with unexplained weight loss over the past three months. The pain has not been acutely severe  but persistent and out of character enough for him to seek medical attention. He has also noticed a ""pulsing sensation"" within his abdomen.  Family History: His family history is notable for cardiovascular disease. His father died from an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture in his late seventies and his elder brother  age 76  is currently living with an unruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Summary: Considering his age  medical history  lifestyle  and family history  Mr. Baker presents an archetypical profile of a patient with abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) as described in medical literature. AAA predominately affects elderly men over the age of 65 and is associated with a history of cardiovascular disease  smoking  and family history.    His periodic abdominal pain  the pulsing sensation he felt in his abdomen  and unexplained weight loss were indicative of a potential abdominal aortic aneurysm  and appropriate diagnostic investigations were proceeded with to confirm this suspicion. It is of utmost importance to promptly diagnose and manage AAA  given its potential to rupture leading to a life-threatening situation. The treatment also requires careful consideration of Mr. Baker's overall health and comorbid conditions.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Older Adult Male  Patient Profile: Mr. S.  a 70-year-old Caucasian male retired truck driver  presents with a chief complaint of severe  sudden-onset pain in the back and lower abdomen. He also reports faintness  and an increased heart rate. A resident of a small town in Texas  where he lives with his wife  he is a former smoker with a 20-year pack history until he quit 15 years ago. Mr. S. has a known history of uncontrolled hypertension which is managed with medication. He does not have a history of any other significant illnesses or surgeries.   Background: His lifestyle involves minimal physical activity and his diet includes high-cholesterol foods due to his long years on the road. Normally with a high pain threshold  he described a sudden strange sensation  'like a ripping feeling’  which made him seek immediate medical help.   Medical History: He was diagnosed 10 years ago with high blood pressure  for which he has been non-compliant with his medication. He has a family history of aneurysms (both parents died from ruptured aneurysms) making him a high-risk patient. There have been no previously documented or diagnosed abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA).  Current Presentation: On physical examination  he appears uncomfortable  and vital signs indicate a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  blood pressure 160/95mmHg  respiratory rate 22 per minute and oxygen saturation on room air is 98%. Physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass and minor tenderness to palpation in the lower abdomen. He was sent for an urgent CT which confirmed an AAA of 7 5cm diameter.  This presentation is a prototypical AAA case  given that it is most prominent among Caucasian males aged 65 to 75 who have a history of smoking and a history of aneurysms in the immediate family. It is notable that AAAs tend to be asymptomatic until rupture  at which point they have a very high fatality rate. Mr. S.'s immediate presentation was critical in his receiving potentially life-saving care.

Slide 1: Patient Information Name: Mr. John Doe Age: 72 Sex: Male Occupation: Retired Firefighter Residential Area: Manhattan  New York Ethnicity: Caucasian  Slide 2: Patient Presentation Chief Complain: Severe  sudden pain in the back and lower abdomen  persisting for several hours. Additional Symptoms: Nausea  cold feet with weak or absent pulses  clammy and pale skin.  Slide 3: Past Medical History Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension controlled with medication  moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) diagnosed around a decade ago  and a smoking history of 25 pack-years. No known allergies. History of occasional alcohol consumption.  Slide 4: Family Medical History The patient's father suffered from an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at the age of 75 and his mother died due to stroke at 80. His older brother has been diagnosed with peripheral artery disease.  Slide 5: AAA Prevalence and Risk Factors  Abdominal aortic aneurysm prevalently affects males above 65 years of age  particularly those from Caucasian descent. Risk factors include a family history of the disease  smoking  and hypertension. Chronic lung diseases like COPD and atherosclerosis are also considered contributing factors.  Slide 6: Demographic Representation According to National Institute of Health  the prevalence rate of AAA is higher among males and Caucasian individuals aged 65 and above.  Slide 7: Conclusion Given Mr. Doe's age  smoking history  family history of AAA  hypertension  and his COPD diagnosis  he fits the typical profile for an individual susceptible to an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Immediate medical attention and treatment are necessary to reduce the risks and manage his condition.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Caucasian Male  Demographics:  Patient Name: John Doe Age: 72 years  Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Businessman  Clinical History:  Mr. Doe is a 72-year old Caucasian male  living with his wife. He is moderately active for his age and enjoys gardening and daily walks. He is a non-smoker and reports occasional alcohol use. He has a history of high blood pressure and hyperlipidemia  both managed by medication. There is no significant family history of cardiovascular or aneurysmal disease.  He has been experiencing chronic lower back pain and abdominal discomfort for the past few months. Recently  the patient observed a pulsating sensation in his abdomen  primarily after meals. Using the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS)  he rated his pain as a 3 out of 10. There is no history of unexplained weight loss  fever  or night sweats.  Physical Examination:  On examination  a pulsatile  expansile abdominal mass was appreciated in the peri-umbilical region. There was mild tenderness on palpation around the mass  but no signs of peritonitis were found.  Additional Findings:  An abdominal ultrasound showed a localized  5.5 cm suprarenal dilation of the abdominal aorta  which is in line with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. No rupture was evident on the scan.  Comment:  Mr. Doe represents the typical patient demographic for abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA)  which is predominately seen in Caucasian men over the age of 65. The condition is associated with risk factors such as hypertension and hyperlipidemia that Mr. Doe has presented in his history.  The back pain and palpable abdominal mass experienced by Mr. Doe are classical AAA symptoms  but not always present. The pulsating feeling might be associated with expansion of the aneurysm  particularly after food intake increases abdominal pressure.  Conclusion:  Next steps for Mr. Doe are likely to include further investigations with CT angiography  to ascertain the exact size  location and potential involvement of other structures. Depending on these findings  he will likely be referred to a vascular surgeon for ongoing treatment and management.  As AAA carries a high risk of rupture leading to life-threatening hemorrhage  identifying and proactively managing this condition is of utmost importance. Since AAA is often asymptomatic until rupture  clinicians should maintain a high index of suspicion in older patients  especially those with risk factors such as hypertension and hyperlipidemia  as seen in Mr. Doe's case.

Title: Case Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Presentation: Mr. M  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department with a complain of acute onset of severe abdominal and back pain. The pain is sharp  persistent and radiates to his lower back. He states the pain as ""the worst pain he's ever experienced"". Mr. M appears distressed and diaphoretic.  Demographics: Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is more prevalent in older individuals  particularly men over the age of 65. In the United States  4-8% of older men and 1-2% of older women are affected and the demographic statistics reflect a higher prevalence among White populations compared to Black or Hispanic populations.   Past Medical History: Mr. M was a heavy smoker for 40 years  but quit 10 years ago. He has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a family history of aortic disease (his father died of a ruptured AAA at the age of 75). He took oral medication that was well-controlled with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin. Mr. M did not have a history of previous surgery or any allergies. His social history revealed that he consumed alcohol socially and had a diet of moderate fat intake.   Presenting Signs: Upon initial physical examination  Mr. M's heart rate was reported at 110 bpm and his blood pressure was noted to be 160/90 mm Hg. On auscultation  a bruit was heard on his mid-abdominal area. The abdominal examination revealed a palpable  pulsatile mass which was tender on deep palpation.   In the context of his medical and family history  as well as his presenting symptoms  an emergent ultrasound was ordered  demonstrating an abdominal aortic aneurysm of 6.5cm  supporting the suspicion of a rapidly expanding or ruptured AAA.   The comprehensive management approach for Mr. M incorporates multidisciplinary care that includes prompt surgical intervention coupled with management of his hypertension and hyperlipidemia in a postoperative phase. His demographic information and history significantly place him at a greater risk  necessitating urgent attention. Regular follow-ups intend to manage Mr. M's risk factors and monitor his recovery.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile: Our patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  married  and a retired engineer living in the urban areas. He is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago  with a smoking history of 50 pack years. He occasionally drinks alcohol and leads a sedentary lifestyle.  Presenting symptoms: The patient presented asymptomatic of any abdominal discomfort or back pain. However  he reported a slowly enlarging  pulsatile mass in his abdomen  which he started noticing about 2 months ago. His primary concern is the recent sudden increase in the size of this mass.  Past Medical History: In his past medical records  the patient has a known history of hypertension for the past 10 years  which he manages with oral anti-hypertensive medications. He also has borderline dyslipidemia. His father died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 73. He does not have any history of allergies  diabetes  or chronic kidney disease.  Surgical History: He underwent an appendectomy at the age of 25 and a right total hip replacement at the age of 65.  Family History: As mentioned earlier  there is a family history of aortic aneurysm (his father). His mother died in her late 80s due to Alzheimer's disease. He is the eldest of 3 siblings  none of whom have any known cardiovascular or aneurysmal disease.  Current Medications: The patient is currently on ramipril for hypertension and takes atorvastatin for dyslipidemia.  Clinical Findings: Upon initial examination  there is a noticeable pulsatile mass in his abdomen. His vitals are stable  with a blood pressure of 140/85 mmHg.  This fairly common presentation of an abdominal aortic aneurysm is aligned with the typical demographic and lifestyle factors outlined in various research studies: older age  male  Caucasian ethnicity  smoker  hypertensive  dyslipidemia  and a family history of the disease. The subsequent steps would include confirmatory diagnostic procedures like ultrasound or CT scan to determine the size of the aneurysm and potential need for surgical intervention.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Case Presentation  Patient Presentation: Mr. James Rodriguez  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  presents to the emergency department complaining of abrupt onset severe abdominal pain for approximately four hours. The pain  described as a tearing sensation  is centralized around his navel and radiates to his back.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of smoking one pack of cigarettes per day for about 40 years but has been smoke-free for the past four years. He has a longstanding history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  controlled by prescribed medication (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin).  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the patient is in distress. His vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 180/110 mmHg and a heart rate of 100 bpm. Abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass and severe tenderness around the navel.  Epidemiology: Male individuals aged between 65 to 75 years old who have a history of smoking are at higher risk of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Caucasian men are more likely to develop AAA compared to other ethnic and racial groups. In addition  patients with hypertension and hyperlipidemia are also at increased risk.  Conclusion: Given Mr. Rodriguez's age  gender  race  and history—especially his significant smoking history—along with his current symptoms and clinical findings  there is a crucial suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Urgent diagnostic and therapeutic management are essential.  References: The risk factors and patient presentation are gathered from the commonly seen demographics in the literature. For example  Smoking and Hypertension are agreed by most studies to be significant risk factors for AAA. The demographic information was found from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC)  which showed that Caucasian males over 60  particularly those with a history of smoking  are at a higher risk. The presentation and history align with guidance from the Mayo Clinic and other prominent medical reference sources.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: Mr. John Smith  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  has presented with symptoms indicative of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Chief Complaints: Mr. Smith primarily complains of occasional severe abdominal pain that tends to radiate to the back. He also reports a noticeable pulsating feeling near his navel.  Past Medical History: The patient has a significant history of uncontrolled hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is also a 40-pack-year smoker but quit smoking 5 years ago due to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). His father died from a ruptured AAA at the age of 75.  Physical Examination: On examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpated  more noticeable during expiration. There are no signs of limb ischemia. The patient continues to have a slightly elevated blood pressure at 145/95 mmHg.  Based on epidemiological research  men  particularly those of Caucasian descent  aged 65 and older who have a history of smoking and cardiovascular diseases have a high prevalence of AAA. Mr. Smith's demographics and medical history align well with these risk factors. Additionally  his symptomatology further suggests the presence of an AAA.  Due to the life-threating nature of ruptured AAA  it is imperative to further evaluate his condition. Mr. Smith should have an expedited referral for an ultrasound examination to confirm the diagnosis and to evaluate for any imminent risk of rupture.  References: • Fleming C  Whitlock EP  Beil TL  Lederle FA. Screening for abdominal aortic aneurysm: a best-evidence systematic review for the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force. Ann Intern Med. 2005;142(3):203-11. • Kent KC. Abdominal aortic aneurysms. N Engl J Med. 2014;371(22):2101-8.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  [Slide 1:] Title: Patient Background Information Mr. Jones is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). As per statistics  AAA is commonly seen in Caucasian males above the age of 65. Meanwhile  the condition's incidence is comparatively less frequent in non-Whites and women.   [Slide 2:] Title: Past Medical History Mr. Jones has had a history of smoking for the past 40 years – a significant risk factor for AAA. Furthermore  he has a family history of aneurysms  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and coronary artery disease. He underwent a stenting procedure for his blocked coronary arteries 5 years ago.   [Slide 3:] Title: Presenting Symptoms Lately  Mr. Jones visited the clinic with complaints of intermittent lower back pain and discomfort in the lower chest region. He also reported a noticeable pulsating feeling around his navel.  [Slide 4:] Title: Physical Examination During the physical examination  an enlarged  pulsatile mass in the peri-umbilical region was palpable. The vital signs showed a blood pressure reading of 150/95 mmHg  reflecting uncontrolled hypertension.   [Slide 5:] Title: Suspected Diagnosis and Further Tests The given history and physical examination findings amplify the suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. As such  the patient was referred for an abdominal ultrasound and possibly a CT angiogram to confirm the diagnosis and assess the size and extent of the aneurysm.  [Slide 6:] Title: Treatment Considerations Depending on the aneurysm's size and the patient's overall health  conservative monitoring or surgical intervention might be suggested. Lifestyle modifications  including smoking cessation and effective control of blood pressure and cholesterol  will be critical components of Mr. Jones' treatment plan.   This presentation allows for a comprehensive understanding of Mr. Jones's situation  enabling healthcare providers to make precise diagnoses and appropriate treatment decisions.

Title: Presentation of a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Introduction: Today  we are discussing Mr. Ramirez  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  who presents with abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Mr. Ramirez is a retired mechanical engineer  a passionate gardener  and enthusiastic in his community's local history club. He was recently divorced and lives alone.  Current Medical Presentation: Mr. Ramirez visited the Emergency Department  complaining of an intense  sudden-onset abdominal and lower back pain that he described as unlike anything he ever experienced. He also reported feeling an unusual pulsing sensation in his abdomen. He was pale and diaphoretic on arrival  and his vitals showed a blood pressure of 130/75 mmHg and pulse rate of 90 beats per minute.   Past Medical & Family History: Mr. Ramirez has a medical history of hypertension and Hyperlipidemia  both controlled by medication. He had a 40 pack-year smoking history  which he quit 10 years ago. He has a history of excessive alcohol consumption  though he hasn’t consumed any alcohol in the last five years. His father died from an AAA rupture at the age of 77.  Physical Examination: Physical examination revealed a slightly distended abdomen  and a palpable  pulsatile abdominal mass was also noted. His cardiovascular and respiratory systems were normal.  Investigation and Diagnosis: An urgent CT Abdomen was performed  confirming the presence of an AAA measuring 7.5cm in maximum diameter. No signs of leakage or rupture were identified.   Given the patient's age  gender  medical history  particularly his smoking and family history  he fits the most common demographic for an AAA. Mr. Ramirez was immediately referred to a vascular surgeon for further treatment.  Discussion: The AAA prevalence is highest in Caucasian males aged over 65. Risk factors include atherosclerosis  smoking history  hypertension  and a family history of AAA. AAA often remains asymptomatic until rupture  with only 25% of AAAs diagnosed before rupture. Severe  sudden-onset abdominal and back pain is often the first presentation  as in the case of Mr. Ramirez.  This case underscores the importance of considering AAA in older male patients with a history of smoking and sudden and severe abdominal pain  even if the pain had developed in a patient who lives alone and may delay seeking medical care. Swift diagnosis and referral for surgical management are essential to lower the high mortality rate associated with ruptured AAAs.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a Geriatric Male Patient  Mr. Joseph Dowling  a 72-year-old Caucasian man  presented to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain  which he described as severe  situated mostly in the middle and lower part of his stomach. The pain was sudden in onset  persisting for about three hours before presenting to the Emergency Department. He reports a sudden pain that started in his belly and radiates to his back.  Mr. Dowling  currently retired  is a former Marine Corps member. He has been a smoker for over 50 years  consuming an average of one pack per day. He occasionally consumes alcohol  mostly during social gatherings. His dietary history reveals a high-fat diet.  In terms of family history  his father died of a stroke while his mother passed away due to heart disease. His older brother had an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) repair at the age of 78. He is married with three grown children.  His medical history includes hypertension  which has been controlled with Lisinopril for over a decade. He also has hyperlipidemia  managed with Atorvastatin. Mr. Dowling denies any history of cancer  respiratory illness  liver disease  or surgery other than for an appendectomy during his youth.  Upon further investigation  a pulsating mass was palpable in his abdomen. His EKG showed a regular rhythm  and his vital signs were stable except for mild hypertension.  Mr. Dowling fits the typical demographic of an AAA patient. The literature suggests that the condition is most common in Caucasian men over 65 with a history of smoking  hypertension  and a family history of aneurysm. His high-fat diet also predisposes him to atherosclerosis  which can contribute to aneurysm formation.   The suddenness and severity of his pain indicate a possible rupture  which is a life-threatening condition requiring immediate surgical attention. His medical history  particularly controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia  signifies vascular health concerns that may have compounded over the years  creating a potential environment for AAA development and progression.  The inclusion of this case in clinical research would contribute to the nuanced understanding of AAA risk factors  progress  and outcomes in this demographic. Crucially  Mr. Dowling's case underscores the necessity for consistent monitoring  lifestyle modification  and preventive measures in at-risk individuals.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department (ED) with a sudden onset of severe lower back and abdominal pain that began a couple of hours ago. The pain is described as a ripping or tearing sensation and is constant  radiating to the back and lower abdomen. He also reports mild shortness of breath and is looking pale.   The patient has a history of hypertension for 20 years  and smoking one pack per day for over 35 years  but quit two years ago. He also has a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysms: his father died suddenly of a ruptured aorta. He admits that he hasn't been compliant with prescribed antihypertensive medications over the past few months because they made him feel lethargic.   He is retired and lives with his wife. He doesn’t drink alcohol. Patient has been previously healthy  but has not been under regular medical care or monitoring due to being generally healthy and having a fear of doctors.  Examination reveals that he is in distress with a blood pressure of 155/95 mmHg; pulse rate of 100 bpm  and respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. Abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile mass in the mid-abdominal area.   An abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is strongly suspected  and the patient is sent for ultrasound imaging for immediate investigation  followed by a CT scan for confirmation.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Anthony Jennings  a 74-year-old Caucasian male  presents with a gradual onset of constant  dull  gnawing abdominal pain and lower back pain that has been worsening over the last two weeks. He describes the pain as radiating to his lower back and not associated with meal intake. Additionally  he reports recent unexplained weight loss and occasional dizziness.  He has a pronounced pulsating mass in his abdomen that can be felt upon examination. The patient's pulse and blood pressure are within normative ranges. However  an abdominal ultrasound reveals the presence of an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.5 cm.  His past medical history includes hypertension  hyperlipidemia  chronic obstructive pulmonary disease  and a 50-pack-year history of smoking. Surgeries include a right inguinal hernia repair 7 years ago. His current medications include aspirin  a beta-blocker for hypertension  and a statin for high cholesterol.  The patient is a retired manual worker  widowed  lives alone and is independent in his daily activities. He quit smoking three years ago and drinks alcohol socially. Family history includes a brother who passed away from an aortic aneurysm at 62.    In general  the patient appears to be in discomfort but is alert and oriented.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  sudden onset abdominal and lower back pain  which he describes as a tearing sensation. The pain is not relieved by over-the-counter pain relievers. He has a 10-year history of hypertension and a 30-year pack history of smoking  both risk factors for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He has not had any previous imaging of his aorta. He also reports occasional feelings of lightheadedness and nausea. On examination  the patient appears uncomfortable and in distress. On palpation  a pulsatile abdominal mass is found. His blood pressure is 165/95 mmHg and his heart rate is 110 bpm.

Patient Presentation:  A 72-year-old Caucasian man presents to the emergency department with sudden onset  severe pain in his lower back and abdomen  radiating to his groin and buttocks. The patient initially describes the pain as a tearing sensation.   Over the last few months  he's noticed a pulsating feeling in his abdomen  which he dismissed due to his lack of other symptoms. He also reports a loss of appetite and unexplained weight loss.  Detailed History:  The patient is a retired engineer who has a 50-pack-year history of smoking. He is a moderate drinker and does not use elicit drugs. His family history is notable for vascular disease; his father suffered a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in his early 70s.   His medical history is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and peripheral vascular disease  all of which have been treated with medication for the past 10 years. He has not undergone any surgical procedures in the past. His medications are Amlodipine Olmesartan 5/40mg for hypertension  Atorvastatin 20mg for hyperlipidemia  and Aspirin 81mg for cardiovascular prophylaxis.  On Examination:  Vitals show a blood pressure of 160/95 mmHg and a heart rate of 110 bpm. Palpation of the abdomen reveals a pulsating mass that is tender to touch. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable.  Based on his age  family history of AAA  smoking history  the presence of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  the patient was considered to be of high risk for AAA. Therefore  radiological imaging was ordered to confirm the diagnosis  and emergency surgical consultation was sought due to the possibility of rupture.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male patient presented to the Emergency Department with deep  steady  persistent abdominal and back pain that he describes as ""tearing"" in nature  radiating to his lower back. The pain began suddenly  about two hours ago  while he was watching TV at home. His vital signs on arrival were: Blood pressure 170/95mmHg  Pulse rate 98 bpm  Respiratory rate 18 breaths/min  SpO2 97% on room air  and Temperature of 37.1°C.  The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past 20 years  managed with lisinopril and atorvastatin. He also has 60 pack-year smoking history  having smoked two packs a day for 30 years before quitting ten years ago. The patient has been non-compliant with his regular health check-ups and his last abdominal ultrasound was done five years ago which was normal. The patient lives alone  he stopped working 7 years ago  has a moderate alcohol consumption of two drinks per day  and no known drug allergies. He denies any family history of abdominal aortic aneurysms or any sudden cardiac deaths in his family.  Due to all these factors  concerning demographic data  and a high-risk medical history  the patient is suspected to have a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) which was later confirmed by CT angiography. Emergency vascular surgery review was called.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Smith is a 70-year-old Caucasian male presenting with sudden onset  severe abdominal and lower back pain that started roughly two hours ago. The pain is constant  non-radiating  and non-reliant on movement or position. It is described as a ""ripping"" sensation. He also reports feeling light-headed and having difficulty standing due to the pain. His past medical history includes hypertension  hyperlipidemia  a 40-pack-year history of smoking (ceased 10 years ago)  and a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysms with his father having died from aneurysm rupture.  On observation  Mr. Smith is a thin elderly man who appears older than his stated age  alert  in distress. He has an abdominal bruit present on auscultation and pulse exam demonstrated a pulsatile mass in the midline lower abdomen. The patient’s vitals are stable with a blood pressure of 160/95 mmHg  heart rate of 105 bpm  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  temperature of 98.6°F  and oxygen saturation of 95% on room air. His BMI is 24.2. Cardiovascular  respiratory  and other systemic examination findings are within normal limits.  Initial differential diagnosis would consider acute aortic syndromes such as an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) rupture or aortic dissection  given his risk factors of age  gender  prior smoking history  presence of hypertension  and family history. A stat CT scan is recommended for further investigation.

Patient Presentation:  A 70-year-old Caucasian male comes into the emergency room with severe  sudden onset of abdominal and lower-back pain  described as a tearing sensation. He rates it as a 9/10 on the pain scale. The pain is constant and he describes it as the worst pain he has ever experienced.  He has a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia and a 50 pack-year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. He also has a family history of cardiovascular disease and reports his older brother had an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  On examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is identified. The patient’s pulse rate is elevated at 105 beats per minute  blood pressure is slightly low at 115/60 mm Hg  and respiratory rate is slightly high at 20 breaths per minute possibly indicating the patient is in mild shock.  This presentation is most consistent with a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm  a medical emergency that requires immediate surgical intervention.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset  severe tearing pain from his abdomen radiating through to his back. The pain is constant in nature  not associated with food or exertion  and is the worst he has ever experienced. He looks pale and appears to be in a cold sweat. The patient admits to having taken non-prescribed nicotine for the last 50 years.   On physical examination  he is found to be hypertensive with a blood pressure of 176/98 mmHg. His pulse is regular but rapid at 110 beats per minute. Abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile mass in the midline area.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension  controlled with medication  hyperlipidemia  and a 20-pound unintentional weight loss over the past six months. He has never been diagnosed with diabetes mellitus. He has enjoyed good health up until now  despite his smoking habit  and has not visited the doctor in several years other than for a brief check-up due to his hypertension.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents with a history of acute onset of intense  centralized lower-abdominal pain that began about two hours ago at home. The pain is described as tearing and radiating to the back. The patient also reports associated symptoms of light-headedness and nausea. There are no complaints of chest pain  shortness of breath  or loss of consciousness. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-year pack history of smoking. He admits to poor compliance with his antihypertensive medications. He denies any previous surgeries or known allergies. On examination  his pulse is 98  blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg  and respiratory rate is 17. Upon palpation of the abdomen  you notice a pulsatile abdominal mass. Height and weight measurements produce a BMI of 28  indicating overweight. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. His family history is significant for an older brother who died from a ""ruptured artery in the stomach"" in his 70s.

Patient Presentation:  A 75-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic complaining of ongoing non-specific lower back pain  which he has been experiencing for the past two months. The pain is dull  persistent and he mentions that it is not relieved with over-the-counter analgesics. He also describes a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. He has lost his appetite and lost 5 kg in weight over the past month.   The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack-year history of smoking. His father experienced a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 72. His medication list includes Lisinopril and Simvastatin. He has no known drug allergies.  Upon physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is palpable. His blood pressure is 150/90 mm Hg and pulse rate is 88 beats/min. No other noticeable deformities or abnormalities are noted. The patient’s medical history  along with the presence of risk factors and physical examination findings  rise suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further diagnostic investigations such as an abdominal ultrasound are scheduled.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Thomas Livingston  a 69-year-old African-American male  presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden  severe back and abdominal pain that began about 3 hours ago. The pain is reportedly constant  sharp  and radiates to the lower back and left flank. He describes the pain as ""tearing"". His medical history is significant for hypertension  high cholesterol  and a 40-pack-year smoking history. He quit smoking about two years ago but has no history of regular exercise. He has not had any previous abdominal surgeries.  On examination  the patient appears highly distressed. His abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass  approximately 5 cm in diameter  just above the umbilicus. His vitals are: BP 170/90 mmHg  Heart Rate 110 bpm  Respiratory Rate 20  Temperature 98.5 °F  and Oxygen Saturation 96% on room air. Lower limb pulses are symmetrically present and no signs of limb ischemia.  Investigations reveal an abdominal ultrasound with a 5.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. Despite his hypertensive emergency and critical condition  the patient denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or loss of consciousness. Family history reveals that his father died of a ruptured aortic aneurysm.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson is a 73-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the emergency department with a complaint of severe and sudden onset abdominal pain that radiates to the middle and lower back. The pain  described as a pulse-like sensation  is consistent with a score of 8 on a scale of 10. He also reports feeling lightheaded and having shortness of breath. His skin appears pale and he seems distressed.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a history of hypertension which has been managed with medication for the past 15 years. He also has hyperlipidemia  for which he is taking statins. He has been a smoker for about 50 years but quit 2 years ago upon the doctor's strong recommendation. There is also a family history of cardiovascular disease. His father died from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm in his mid-seventies. He has no previous surgeries.   Social History:  He is a retired engineer  lives alone and is divorced. He has a son who lives out of state. His alcohol consumption is moderate and he is not involved in any regular physical activities.  This presentation is consistent with the typical demographic of an abdominal aortic aneurysm patient  as they are most commonly seen in Caucasian males over 65 years of age with a history of smoking  hypertension  and cardiovascular diseases.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Albert Green  a 73-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department complaining of severe pain in the middle and lower part of his abdomen extending to his lower back. He describes the pain as sharp and constant  which worsened upon lying flat.   He also reported feelings of fullness in his abdomen accompanied by episodic bouts of nausea but no vomiting. He denies any changes in bowel movements or any urinary symptoms. However  he has noticed unintentional weight loss in the past two months.   Patient's Medical History:  The patient is a retired firefighter and in his past medical history  Mr. Green has been hypertensive for the past 10 years controlled on Lisinopril. He also was a heavy smoker but quit smoking approximately 5 years ago. He lives alone after his wife passed away two years back  and acknowledges a history of alcohol use but stopped drinking after his wife's death. His family history is significant for an elder brother who had an aortic aneurysm repair.   No known allergies are reported by the patient  and he is not taking any other prescribed or over-the-counter medications apart from his blood pressure medicine.   According to published studies  the demographic group most at risk for abdominal aortic aneurysms is men aged 65-75 years  with Caucasian  smoker  and hypertensive individuals being disproportionately represented. The risk is further increased in those with a family history of the disease.

Patient Demographic Details: Mr. Robert Jones  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  a long-term smoker with a pack history of 20 years. He is a retired worker and lives with his wife. Mr. Jones has a BMI of 28 and is normotensive. He consumes alcohol occasionally and denies illicit drug use. His father had a heart disease and his mother suffered from high blood pressure.  Presenting History: Mr. Jones presents to the Emergency Department with a 48 hours history of severe  sharp pain in the lower abdomen and lower back that is constant and not relieved with over-the-counter medication. He describes it as a tearing sensation  rating it as 9/10 intensity. The pain slightly radiates to the right flank and groin region. He denies chest pain  but reports feeling a bit lightheaded and breaks out in a cold sweat occasionally.  Past Medical History: Further exploration of his medical history reveals hypertension for 20 years  controlled with Lisinopril. He has high cholesterol managed with atorvastatin. He had an appendectomy in his 30s and has been relatively healthy apart from that.  He has no known drug allergies. He is up-to-date on his vaccinations and sees his primary care physician regularly.  Social History: Mr. Jones is retired and loves to engage his time in gardening and walking his dog. Currently  he is a half-pack daily smoker and has attempted to quit multiple times in the past unsuccessfully.  Family History: His father had ischemic heart disease. His mother has a history of stroke and died due to complications related to hypertension. He has one brother who has no known health issues.  Considering his age  sex  significant smoking history along with pre-existing hypertension  and high cholesterol  an abdominal aortic aneurysm should be strongly considered.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department complaining of a severe  sudden onset of pain in his lower back  abdominal area  and groin. He describes it as the ""worst pain he's ever felt"". The patient profusely sweats and feels nauseous  but no vomiting. He has a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking about a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 50 years. The patient confirms both his father and brother were diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. His physical activity is limited due to the onset of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) from habitual smoking. Currently  he is taking antihypertensive medication  a lipid-lowering agent  and bronchodilators for his COPD. He denies any recent trauma to the abdominal or lower back area.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male reports to the emergency department with severe  sudden onset abdominal and back pain  which is tearing in nature and radiating to his lower back and legs. The pain started while he was having dinner after his afternoon walk and is not relieved by any over-the-counter medication. He describes the pain as the worst he's ever experienced. His wife  who brings him to the ER  mentions that he appeared pale  clammy  and was increasingly anxious over the past couple of hours.   The patient has a medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and smoking (40 pack/year). He has been on antihypertensive and lipid-lowering medications for a long duration. His family history reveals his father died at a young age from an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  and his two older brothers also had AAA. He regularly follows up with a cardiologist and primary care physician but has missed his appointments for the past year due to mobility issues.   His vital signs at presentation show a blood pressure of 170/95 mmHg  pulse rate of 110 beats/min  respiratory rate of 22 breaths/min  and oxygen saturation of 90% on room air. Physical examination reveals a pulsatile mass in the abdomen and a distended abdomen. Both femoral pulses are palpable but weak  and the patient's lower extremities are cold to touch. Increased heart rate  decreased blood pressure  and altered consciousness indicate hypovolemic shock. An abdominal ultrasound is suggested to confirm the diagnosis of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with complaints of intense  persistent lower abdominal and lower back pain for the last 4 hours. The pain radiates to the groin and legs occasionally. He describes the pain as a sharp  tearing sensation. The patient also reports feeling light-headed  but denies chest pain  shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  or altered bowel habits.   He has a past medical history of hypertension controlled with amlodipine  hyperlipidemia managed with atorvastatin  and a 20-pack year history of smoking  though he quit 10 years ago. He has no history of diabetes or coronary artery disease. His father had an aortic aneurysm rupture at the age of 75.   On physical exam  the patient appears distressed  pale  and diaphoretic. His pulse is 110 bpm  blood pressure is 90/55 mmHg. Abdominal examination identifies a pulsatile mass in the periumbilical area along with tenderness on deep palpation. There are no signs of peripheral arterial occlusion. The remainder of the physical exam is unremarkable.
