These signs  symptoms  past medical history  demographics  and physical examination findings raise the concern for the possibility of expanding or ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic with a complaint of abdominal pain and back pain that has been ongoing for the past week. The pain is centralized in his lower abdomen and does not radiate anywhere. It is described as a steady  gnawing pain which does not increase or decrease with food intake or defecation. The pain is sufficiently severe to disrupt his daily routines and occasionally causes him to wake from sleep.  The patient avidly smoked for almost 30 years and has quit 3 years ago. He has notable history of high blood pressure for which he takes Lisinopril  and also a family history of aneurysms with both of his parents suffering from cerebral aneurysms. The patient has had a generally poor diet throughout his life  with a preference for high-fat foods  and does not engage in regular exercise. He denies any recent significant weight loss  changes in appetite  nausea or vomiting  changes in stool or urine  chest pain or shortness of breath.  The patient lists no known allergies. He admits to being a regular drinker  with an intake of 1-2 alcoholic drinks per day. His physical examination reveals a pulsating mass in the periumbilical area of the abdomen  which is tender to the touch. His abdomen is soft  and bowel sound is normal. His BMI is 28.   The patient shows no signs of anxiety or depression. He is a retired engineer  lives with his wife  and has caregiver assistance due to mobility issues associated with arthritis.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency room with severe  sudden pain that began in his abdomen and radiated to his lower back. He describes the pain as sharp in nature. He also reports feeling faint and dizzy. He lives alone and says he had a loss in appetite the past couple of days. On questioning  the patient admits to have experienced mild  intermittent abdominal and back discomfort for the past several weeks  which he had ignored and attributed to age.   The patient's past medical history is significant for high blood pressure  40-pack year smoking history and peripheral artery disease. His father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm. On physical exam  there is a pulsatile abdominal mass palpable. An ultrasound confirms the presence of a large abdominal aortic aneurysm. Immediate surgical consultation is sought.

Patient  Mr. Fitzgerald  is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presents with a 2-week history of intermittent abdominal pain and occasional lower back pain. The pain is described as a dull ache that lasts anywhere from a few minutes to a few hours. He admits to feeling a pulsating sensation in his abdomen and has also noted recent unexplained weight loss. His back pain worsens during walking but relieves after some rest.   Further history reveals that he is a smoker  smoking two packs of cigarettes per day for the last 45 years. He has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol  both conditions are medically managed for the past 20 years. He admits to being non-compliant with his medications. His body mass index falls within the overweight category.  A year ago  he was diagnosed with peripheral arterial disease  managed with lifestyle modifications and medication. He reveals a family history of aneurysms; his father died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 72. His diet consists of high-fat foods and he admits to a sedentary lifestyle.  Upon physical examination  an abdominal bruit is noted  along with a palpable pulsatile mass in the upper middle region of the abdomen. His lower extremities show signs of reduced peripheral pulses. Mr. Fitzgerald is alert  oriented  and has normal motor and sensory functions. His vitals show slightly elevated blood pressure.   Given his history and examination findings  a clinical suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm is made  with potential risk for rupture due to his advanced age  genetic predisposition  smoking habit  and cardiovascular risk factors. Further diagnostic studies are warranted for definitive diagnosis.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with sudden and severe abdominal pain localized to his lower back and flanks. He rates the pain as an 8 out of 10  describing it as a throbbing sensation. He also reports feeling lightheaded  has experienced nausea  and noticeable weight loss over the last few months.   The patient has a past medical history notable for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 30-pack year smoking history  though he quit smoking 7 years ago. He has been on antihypertensive and lipid-lowering medications but is irregular in their intake. He underwent coronary artery bypass grafting 10 years ago due to ischemic heart disease. His father had a history of abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Upon examination  there is a palpable and pulsatile abdominal mass in the periumbilical area  indicative of a potential abdominal aortic aneurysm. The patient also has a moderate hypertensive crisis with his blood pressure being 180/100mmHg.  The patient lives alone  he is widowed  and he is a retired construction worker. He exercises occasionally but has a diet that's high in sodium and fats. He is otherwise independent with activities of daily living and reliant on his two adult children for emotional support and occasional visits.

A 72-year-old African American male patient presented to the Emergency Department  accompanied by his daughter. He complained of severe  sudden-onset back pain  described as sharp and radiating to the groin. He rates the pain as 10 out of 10. The patient has a notable past medical history of hypertension for which he has been prescribed hydrochlorothiazide for the past ten years  however  he admits to being inconsistent with his medication. He is also a former cigarette smoker with a 40-pack year history. He quit smoking ten years ago. Family history is significant with his brother passing away from an abdominal aortic aneurysm at 69 years old. The patient has no known drug allergies. Furthermore  he demonstrates signs of slight distress and is anxious and diaphoretic. He denies any history of previous similar incidents  recent traumas  or surgeries. He also denies any feelings of chest pain  shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  or any bowel or bladder changes.

Subjective:   Mr. John Doe is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the emergency department with intense  sudden-onset abdominal pain that began approximately two hours ago. He describes the pain as tearing and radiating to the lower back. Along with this pain  he reports a faint feeling and an increased heart rate. He denies any recent trauma  urinary or bowel changes  loss of consciousness  or chest pain.   Objective:  On physical examination  an abdominal aortic pulsatile mass is palpable and bruit over the aorta can be heard. His blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg on the right arm and slightly lower on the left arm. Heart rate is 108 bpm and respiratory rate 20 bpm. He also has a decreased femoral pulse.  Past Medical History:  John has a 45-year history of smoking (2 packs/day) and hypertension. He also has a documented history of peripheral arterial disease and coronary artery disease  for which he underwent angioplasty 6 years ago. He occasionally drinks alcohol but denies any use of illicit drugs. His father also had an abdominal aortic aneurysm. A CT scan confirmed a 7-cm abdominal aortic aneurysm.   Assessment:  Given the acute onset of severe abdominal pain  the presence of a pulsatile abdominal mass  and confirmed by CT scan  Mr. Doe has a likely ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Plan:   Urgent surgical consultation for possible repair of the ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. Pain control and hemodynamic stabilization will be initiated in the meantime. Transfer to the surgical ICU for close monitoring throughout management. Long term cessation of smoking will also be recommended.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Anderson is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents to the clinic with a complaint of intermittent abdominal and lower back pain over the past several months. The pain is described as a deep  gnawing ache  slightly relieved by leaning forward and exacerbated by lying on his back. He has also noted that he sometimes feels a pulsating mass in his abdomen on laying flat.  He has a 30-year history of hypertension  for which he takes Lisinopril. He quit smoking 2 years ago  after a 50-pack-year smoking history. He also has a history of high cholesterol levels and peripheral artery disease. There is no record of diabetes or obesity in Mr. Anderson's case. His father reportedly died of an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture in his late 70s.  On examination  an approximately 5 cm pulsatile mass could be palpated in the center of the abdomen. Auscultation revealed a bruit over the mass. Taking into account his age  gender  ethnicity  medical history of hypertension and high cholesterol  history of smoking  and his genetics  a medical imaging test is ordered to confirm a suspected abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic reporting recurring episodes of mid-to-low back pain over the past month. Over this period  the patient notes that the pain has gradually intensified. The pain  initially a dull ache which he associated with aging  has transitioned into sporadic episodes of sharp  severe pain. He describes a deep  gnawing sensation to his pain that sometimes radiates to his groin area. Lasting for a few minutes to hours each time  these episodes typically occur after having meals. He denies any change in bowel habits  urinary symptoms  fevers  or weight loss  although he mentions having a reduced appetite recently.  The patient  a retired engineer  lives with his wife  is a 50 pack-year smoker and has a history of moderate alcohol consumption. He has a documented history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been managed with medication over the past 15 years. There is no family history of any significant gastrointestinal conditions  but his older brother died of a myocardial infarction at age 76  and his mother also had a history of 'heart problems'.  Upon examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass could be palpated. The patient appears to be in discomfort although his vital signs are within normal limits. As the clinical picture is suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  an abdominal ultrasound is ordered promptly to confirm the diagnosis and evaluate the size of the aneurysm. The patient is also advised to quit smoking at the earliest to reduce further cardiovascular risk.

Patient Presentation: Mr. White  a 73-year-old Caucasian man  retired plumber  presents to the emergency room with a sudden onset of severe  ripping abdominal pain that radiates to his lower back. The pain has been continuous for the last 2 hours with no associated relieving factors and has not diminished over time. He also reports associated nausea and shortness of breath. He denies any recent trauma or injury.  His past medical history includes a 40-year history of tobacco use  quitting 10 years prior  controlled hypertension  and high cholesterol. He also mentions a previous diagnosis of peripheral artery disease about 3 years ago. He is currently taking antihypertensive medication and statins.  His family history is remarkable for his father who died of an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture at the age of 76. On physical examination  he appears pale  diaphoretic  and in distress. There is a palpable abdominal mass on his lower abdomen  and his blood pressure is noted to be low.  This presentation fits in line with literature which presents the greatest risk group for abdominal aortic aneurysms as males above the age of 65  who have some history of smoking  hyperlipidemia  hypertension  and a family history of aortic aneurysms.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Richard Davis  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department accompanied by his daughter. He reports a sudden onset of severe pain in the middle and lower part of his abdomen that began two hours ago while he was mowing the lawn. The pain is constant  10/10 in intensity  and radiates to his lower back. Mr. Davis also reports feelings of lightheadedness and nausea.  He has a past medical history of hypertension and high cholesterol  for which he takes Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively. He is a 50 pack-year smoker but quit ten years ago. He has no known drug allergies. On physical examination  a pulsatile mass in the mid-abdominal area can be palpated. The patient's blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg  heart rate is 90 beats per minute  respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute  and temperature is 98.6 F.  Family history is positive for cardiovascular diseases  his father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 78  and his brother has undergone coronary artery bypass grafting. He leads a sedentary lifestyle  chairs a local book club  and is a retired public service worker. He consumes alcohol moderately and has a healthy diet but has difficulty maintaining a regular exercise regimen due to arthritis.  Given his profile  a suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm is raised. An urgent ultrasound is ordered to assess the aorta.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Thomas is a 72-year-old African American male presenting to the emergency department with sudden onset  severe abdominal and back pain. He describes the pain as sharp  constant  and describes the severity as ""the worst he's ever experienced"". The pain radiates to his lower back and doesn't get better or worse with any movement or position changes.  Mr. Thomas has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol for which he has been inconsistent in taking prescribed medications due to financial restrictions. There's a 40-year history of smoking two packs per day  but he quit smoking five years ago. He has also previously undergone an ultrasound screening for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) several years ago due to a family history of AAA (his father died of a ruptured AAA)  but he has been noncompliant with follow-up screenings. He has no history of any surgical intervention.   His vitals on arrival are as follows: BP 150/90 mmHg  HR 110 bpm  respiratory rate 22 breaths/min  and SpO2 96%. He looks pale  is diaphoretic  and is distressed due to pain.  This patient fits into the risk group for AAA  with risk factors including advanced age  male sex  African American race  smoking history  history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and a family history of AAA. His sudden severe abdominal and back pain  along with his risk factors  suggest the possibility of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm  and therefore immediate medical attention including imaging is necessary.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the ER with severe lower back pain that started abruptly this morning. The pain is described as sharp and continuous  8/10 on the pain scale  and radiates towards the left side of his abdomen and pelvis. He complains of feeling a pulsatile mass around the navel. He reported he has not been experiencing fever  blood in the stool  or any other signs of infection.   Relevant Past Medical History: Patient has a 30-year history of smoking two packs a day until he quit five years ago. He has a known history of high blood pressure that is usually well controlled with losartan. Patient also suffers from hyperlipidemia and is on statin therapy  but control is precarious due to his non-compliance with diet and exercise regimen. He mentions he has been told before by his primary care doctor that he has a small aneurysm.   Physical examination showed a distended abdomen with a pulsatile mass slightly to the left of the midline  poor dentition  and peripheral vascular disease (including pedal pulses that are 2+ bilaterally). His BMI is 28 indicating overweight status. No other relevant findings were identified including a negative Murphy's sign and no renal angle tenderness.   Pertinent social history: Patient is retired and lives independently. He is a widower for the past 7 years and has two children who live out of state. He has quit smoking and uses alcohol sparingly. He reports being fairly active  walking daily but does not adhere to a particular exercise regimen. He does not have any known allergies.   In summary  the patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a history of smoking  controlled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  overweight and past medical history indicating a small aneurysm  presenting with severe lower back and abdominal pain and a palpable abdominal mass. The particular combination of these symptoms raise a high index of suspicion for a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith  a 73-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic complaining of severe  even  pulsating lower abdominal pain that radiates to his back and flank. He is also experiencing lightheadedness  nausea  and has vomited twice within the past 24 hours. His primary care physician referred him to this clinic because he suspected an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) based on John's complaint of abdominal pain out of proportion to his physical findings.  Mr. Smith’s vital signs upon arrival are as follows: blood pressure is 140/80 mmHg  heart rate is 98 bpm  and he is afebrile. On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass noticeable on palpation is found.   His medical history is notable for hypertension  high cholesterol  and he is a former smoker with a 25 pack-year history  but quit 15 years ago. Both his father and grandfather passed away in their 70s from AAA rupture  suggesting a strong family history. He is currently under medication for his hypertension and hyperlipidemia  but admits he has been noncompliant with his medications due to financial constraints.   Mr. Smith has a surgical history of cholecystectomy and tonsillectomy  and he leads a sedentary lifestyle with minimal exercise. His dietary habits include high salt and high fat foods. There is no known history of alcohol or substance abuse. He lives alone  retired as a mechanic.   Taken together  Mr. Smith’s age  gender  Caucasian race  family history of AAAs  his personal medical history with hypertension  high cholesterol  smoking  suboptimal control of hypertension  and poor dietary habits significantly elevates his risk for abdominal aortic aneurysm. As a result  further investigations through an ultrasound or CT scan are suggested for a conclusive diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. A is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents with a complaint of a pulsating feeling near the navel region  which he noticed around two weeks ago. He describes the pulsations as constant but not painful. He also reports symptoms of indigestion  bloating  and intermittent  dull lower abdominal discomfort that has escalated over the last few days. He denies any changes in bowel habits  hematochezia  recent weight loss or fever.  Mr. A is retired and a smoker  having smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the last 50 years. His past medical history is significant for high blood pressure and hyperlipidemia. He reports taking medications daily:  amlodipine for his blood pressure and simvastatin for his dyslipidemia.   His family history reveals that his father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He is married  denies alcohol use  and has no known drug allergies. His mother died at the age of 70 due to myocardial infarction.  He denies any significant surgical history.   Given his persistent  unclear abdominal symptoms  long history of smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  age  and relevant family history  an abdominal aortic aneurysm is suspected. An abdominal ultrasound or a CT scan would aid in confirming the diagnosis.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic with a complaint of intermittent lower abdominal pain which he describes as a “deep  pulsating pain” that has been worsening over the past few months. Pain tends to aggravate on exertion and sometimes radiates to his lower back. The patient also indicates episodes of lightheadedness and a feeling of faintness  but no frank syncope.   Mr. Thompson is a retired army officer  smoker with a 40 pack-year history  occasional alcohol drinker  leading a fairly sedentary lifestyle since retirement. His BMI is 28 showing his overweight status. He has a history of hypertension for which he is taking an anti-hypertensive medication. He also has hyperlipidemia managed adequately by Statin therapy.   He has a positive family history of vascular diseases; his father died of an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture at the age of 76 and his elder brother had a carotid artery stenosis. Mr. Thompson has not undergone any surgeries or procedures in the past.   His vitals are stable  blood pressure ranges on the higher side  pulse rate regular and peripheries warm. On examination  a pulsatile mass is palpable in the abdomen. There is no evidence of any lower limb ischemia.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with severe  sudden onset abdominal pain that began earlier in the morning. The pain has been consistent and is described as 'sharp' and 'pulsating' in nature  radiating to his back. The patient denies any aggravating or alleviating factors and any associated symptoms.  He has a past medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension for the past 20 years and a 25 pack years history of smoking until he quit 10 years ago. His family history is significant in terms of his late father  who passed from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 70. Regular medications include Lisinopril and Aspirin.   On examination  he appears distressed and diaphoretic. Abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile mass in the mid-abdomen. His blood pressure is noted to be 180/100 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats/min  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute and a oxygen saturation of 93% on room air.  This clinical picture is suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm in this high-risk individual due to age  male gender  Caucasian ethnicity  long term uncontrolled hypertension and strong family history of aortic aneurysm. The diagnosis can further be confirmed by ordering a CT scan of the abdomen to visualize the aorta in question.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Schultz  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  sudden onset lower back and abdominal pain that began roughly two hours ago. He describes the pain as constant  sharp  and says it rates an 8 on a scale of 10. He further reports a sensation of fullness or pulsation in his abdomen  as well as an increasing feeling of lightheadedness.   The patient's past medical history is significant for a 50 pack-year history of smoking  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and peripheral artery disease. He has been somewhat non-compliant with his antihypertensive and lipid-lowering medication as of late due to difficulty affording them. No known allergies are recorded.   His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  with his father passing away from a myocardial infarction at the age of 65  and a brother who suffered from a stroke at the age of 70. Despite his own personal history and family history  the patient maintains an inactive and sedentary lifestyle.   On physical examination  Mr. Schultz appeared in distress due to pain. He exhibited a noticeable abdominal pulsating mass on palpation of his abdominal area. His heart rate was 100 bpm; blood pressure 160/95 mmHg; respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute; and temperature of 98.6 F (37.0 ºC).  Based on his symptoms  medical and family history  and physical examination  Mr. Schultz was suspected to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm and was sent for an immediate CT scan for further evaluation.

Patient Presentation:  A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the ER with a sudden onset of severe  tearing pain localized at the middle to lower back region and radiating towards his groin area. He describes the pain as the worst pain he has ever experienced. The patient also mentions experiencing episodes of lightheadedness  nausea  and a feeling of rapid heart rate. He has a history of high blood pressure and hypercholesterolemia  for which he is currently on antihypertensives and statins. He has been a smoker for about 50 years.   He is also known to have peripheral artery disease and has a family history of aortic aneurysms. His BMI is 25  and he doesn't engage in much physical activities due to recurring claudication. His father passed away in his seventies due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. His ultrasound screening two years ago for the abdominal aortic aneurysm came back negative.  On physical examination  he appears pale and diaphoretic. Vitals reveal a blood pressure of 170/98 mmHg in the right arm and 158/95mmHg in the left  heart rate of 105 bpm  and respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. An abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass. An urgent CT scan of his abdomen and pelvis is ordered to further confirm the suspicion of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Thomas is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presenting to the Emergency Department with severe acute-onset abdominal pain radiating to his back. He rates the pain as 9 out of 10 and describes it as tear-like. He reports feeling light-headed and looks markedly pale. His vitals indicate hypotension with a blood pressure of 90/60 and a heart rate of 110 bpm.   Relevant Past Medical History:  Mr. Thomas has a significant history of smoking  with a 50-pack year history until he quit 10 years ago. He was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia 15 years ago  for which he takes Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively. His father passed away from a ""heart attack"" in his late 60s  but further specifics are unknown.   On examination:   Mr. Thomas's abdomen shows a pulsating mass in the periumbilical region  consistent with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   This presentation is consistent with the common demographics of AAA patients: predominantly seen in older age  male sex with a high prevalence in Caucasian populations. A history of tobacco use  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a family history of the disease is common  making Mr. Thomas representative of the standard AAA patient population.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the clinic with a complaint of consistent mid-abdominal pain for the past week. The patient reports the pain as a deep  pulsating sensation that is not affected by meals or movements. He also mentions a noticeable weight loss  noting a decrease of about 10 lbs in the last month  and an unexplained fatigue.   The patient has a past medical history of high blood pressure and hyperlipidemia  which have been managed with lisinopril and atorvastatin for more than 10 years. He is a former smoker with a 30-pack-year smoking history  having quit 15 years ago. His family history is significant for heart disease  his father having died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 68.   On examination  a palpable mass is felt in the middle and upper part of the abdomen that pulsates against the examining hand. Abdominal bruits are also noted on auscultation. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.  Given his advanced age  gender  smoking history  and presence of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  the suspicion for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is high. He is immediately referred for an urgent abdominal ultrasound to confirm the diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Thompson  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the clinic with complaints of a constant  severe pain in his lower back and abdomen that started a few hours ago. He describes the pain as sharp  non-radiating  and not associated with any food intake or bowel movements. The pain is not related to physical activity and is non-remitting. In addition  he reports experiencing a feeling of fullness in his abdomen. No urinary or bowel complaints are noted.  Mr. Thompson has a past medical history significant for high blood pressure and hyperlipidemia  both being managed with anti-hypertensives and statins respectively for the past 15 years. He has been a smoker for over 50 years  with a 30 pack-year history  and admits to occasional alcohol intake. He has no known allergies. His family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases  with his father suffering a fatal myocardial infarction at 60 years old.  On physical examination  a pulsatile mass is palpable in the abdomen slightly to the left of the midline. The patient appears to be in pain and the pain seems to escalate on palpation of this mass.  This patient presentation is suggestive of a possible ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).

A 70-year-old Caucasian male patient presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  sudden onset abdominal and lower back pain. The patient rates his pain as 8 on a scale of 10  with 10 being the most severe pain. His pain is constant and does not fluctify with meals or bowel movements. He describes it as a tearing sensation  unlike any pain he's ever experienced. He also notes feeling faint  but denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or paraplegia.   Patient's family history reveals his father passed away due to complications of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   His past medical history is significant for hypertension  for which he takes Lisinopril  and a 40-pack-year smoking history  although he quit 10 years ago. He does not consume alcohol and denies any illicit drug use.   On examination  there is a palpable pulsatile mass in the abdomen. His blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg  pulse rate is 99 beats per minute  respiratory rate is 22 breaths per minute  and with oxygen saturation at 96% on room air.  Due to its sudden onset nature  severe pain  and his family history  the primary working diagnosis is a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Presentation:  A 70-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. J  presents with a complaint of intermittent  mild to moderate lower back and abdominal pain for the last two weeks. He reports the pain is often dull and concentrated in the mid-abdominal and lower back region. He also complains of a faint pulse or throbbing near his navel.  His past medical history includes hypertension  high cholesterol (hypercholesterolemia)  and a 50-pack-year smoking history  although he quit smoking five years ago. There is no relevant family history  apart from his father  who had a stroke at age 75.  Physical examination reveals Mr. J is overweight with a BMI of 29. He has a visibly pulsating abdominal mass  and on auscultation  a bruit can be heard. He also shows slight tenderness in the abdomen.   Laboratory tests are generally unremarkable  though his lipid profile shows slightly elevated cholesterol levels.   An Abdominal ultrasound confirms the presence of a 5.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further investigation  including a CT angiography  is suggested for surgical planning and to rule out potential rupture.                                                                                 His social history is significant for alcohol consumption of 1-2 drinks per day but denies any recent illicit drug use. He lives alone  is widowed  and has two grown children who live nearby. He worked as a mechanic before retiring seven years ago. Despite the mild discomfort and anxiety about his condition  Mr. J appears clear and coherent in his communication. His primary concern is his ability to continue living independently.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male patient  Mr. Johnson  with a significant history of long-term smoking 1 pack/day for over 35 years  presents to the Emergency Department with sudden onset of severe  constant  and sharp pain in his lower abdominal and back that began approximately two hours earlier. He describes the pain as ""tearing"" or ""ripping."" He is a retired construction worker  overweight (BMI 27)  has low physical activity  and follows a high fat diet. Mr. Johnson has known  well-controlled hypertension managed with medication for the past ten years  but does not have any history of cardiac disease or diabetes mellitus.  His father died suddenly of an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture in his mid-70s and his older brother was recently diagnosed with an unruptured AAA. He mentions that he very rarely notices  a palpable  pulsating mass in his abdomen  but always wrote this off as a muscle spasm or digestive problem. However  he denies any associated symptoms such as nausea  vomiting  shortness of breath  dizziness  or fainting spells.   On physical examination  Mr. Johnson presents with a significant systolic blood pressure differential in the arms (right arm: 160mm Hg  left arm: 140mm Hg). He appears pale with cold and sweaty skin. His heart rate is 108 bpm with strong pulses in the upper and weak pulses in the lower extremities. His respiratory rate is 20 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. An approximately 6 cm pulsating mass is palpable in the epigastric area.   These symptoms along with his demographic details - old age  male sex  history of long-term smoking  family history of AAA  well-controlled hypertension  and Caucasian ethnicity  increase the risk and suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm as the potential cause of his symptoms.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John is a 70-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the clinic with a complaining of lower back and abdominal pain for the past couple of days. The pain is described as a dull  gnawing pain that seems to radiate to his groin area. The pain doesn't seem to improve or worsen with movement  nor does it have any association with food intake. He expresses a feeling of abdominal fullness but denies any changes in bowel movements or urinary habits. He denies any associated chest pain  shortness of breath  or lower limb swelling. He reports a recent unexplained weight loss but denies any fever  night sweats or loss of appetite.  In the past  he has been diagnosed with hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 20-year history of smoking  although he quit five years ago. He has no surgical history.   Mr. John's family history reveals that his father passed away from a ruptured aortic aneurysm. On physical examination  a pulsatile mass can be palpated centrally in the abdomen.   The combination of his age  male gender  history of smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia and a strong family history of aortic aneurysm  allied with the current abdominal and back pain  along with the pulsatile abdominal mass on examination - raises a strong suspicion for an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further investigations are required to confirm the diagnosis.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with severe pain in his lower back and flank region that began abruptly three hours ago. The pain is constant  7 out of 10 in severity  non-radiating and not associated with any aggravating or relieving factors. He mentions feeling faint and also notes a ""pulsing"" feeling in his abdomen. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting or change in bowel habits.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  a 40 pack-year history of smoking and a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm (his father). He has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive medications. He denies any previous surgery or known allergies. He has had no recent trauma or injury.  On examination  he is pale and diaphoretic  with a visible abdominal pulsation. His vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. His body mass index (BMI) is 27 indicating he is overweight.  His laboratory tests reveal a hemoglobin of 11 g/dL  slight leukocytosis  and normal kidney and liver function tests. An abdominal ultrasound reveals a 6 cm dilation of the abdominal aorta consistent with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He is immediately admitted to the surgical ward in preparation for emergent vascular surgery.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. K  presented to the emergency department complaining of a constant  severe pain in his abdomen and lower back  which started a few hours ago. The pain was described as throbbing and radiating to his groin. Additionally  the patient was lightheaded and had brief episodes of fainting.   Mr. K is a retired construction worker  lives with his wife  and has two adult children. His past medical history is notable for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 30-pack-year smoking history  but quit 10 years ago. He had been non-compliant with his antihypertensive medications due to financial difficulties. His father died at age 70 of a ""ruptured artery in the stomach.""  On the examination  his blood pressure was found to be 100/60 mmHg  heart rate 105 beats per minute  and he appeared pale and anxious. Examination of the abdomen revealed a pulsatile mass.  The above presentation is suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. His demographic details like older age  gender  being Caucasian  and his past medical history such as hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and prominent smoking history are considered common risk factors for abdominal aortic aneurysm per the literature. Furthermore  his family history also suggests a genetic predisposition.

Patient Presentation:   A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department due to a sudden and persistent severe pain in the lower back and abdomen. The pain is described as a tearing sensation that began abruptly. The patient further reports an associated feeling of lightheadedness and shortness of breath.   Patient Demographics:   Patient is a retired coal miner with a 45-year history of smoking two packs of cigarettes a day  although he quit 10 years ago. He has been diagnosed with hypertension and high cholesterol  both of which have remained relatively well-controlled with medication. Family history is positive for cardiovascular diseases; his father died at the age of 65 due to myocardial infarction  and his older brother had an abdominal aortic aneurysm.   Relevant Past Medical History:  The patient had CABG (Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting) about 5 years ago due to significant coronary artery disease. He also had an episode of transient ischemic attack around 2 years back. He is on aspirin  a beta-blocker  a statin  and an ACE inhibitor for his conditions. There was no recent trauma or heavy exertion at the time of presentation  and he denies any drug use. Physical examination reveals a pulsatile mass in the abdomen. No signs of peripheral embolization are present.   The above patient’s presentation is consistent with most common demographics found in literature for abdominal aortic aneurysms  including age over 65  Caucasian ethnicity  male gender  a significant smoking history  and a history of atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease. Significant family history further contributes to his risk profile for an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a notable history of smoking presents to the emergency department complaining of severe  sudden onset lower abdominal and back pain. The patient describes the pain as “tearing.” He denies any trauma  and notes that he's never experienced this type of pain before. He also reports feeling slightly lightheaded upon standing. He denies any changes in bowel or bladder function  leg weakness  or chest pain. However  he has been uneasy and sweating profusely.   His past medical history is significant for hypertension and high cholesterol  which he manages with hydrochlorothiazide and atorvastatin. He also had been a heavy smoker for many years but quit 5 years ago. His family history includes father and grandfather who both had aneurysms. No drug allergies are reported.   Initial vital signs are: blood pressure 140/90 mmHg  pulse 90 beats per minute  temperature 98.7°F  and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. Examination reveals a palpable abdominal mass pulsatiling. No neurologic deficits are found.   As males over 65  smokers  and people with a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) are at risk  the current patient falls into the high-risk category for AAA. His presentation of sudden intense back or abdominal pain and hypotension could indicate a rupturing AAA  which requires immediate surgical intervention.

A 73-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department complaining of acute severe lower back and abdominal pain. It started abruptly approximately 4 hours ago and has progressively worsened since. He describes the pain as a tearing sensation that radiates from his back towards the abdomen. He has no history of recent trauma. His past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which he controls with low-dose aspirin and a statin. He has a 30-pack year history of smoking but quit five years ago. He has no surgical history. He drinks alcohol on social occasions sparingly and denies illicit drug use. His family history is unknown as he was adopted. His father was lost to follow up and his mother died of natural causes in her early 80s. On physical examination  a palpable pulsatile mass is noted in his abdomen and his blood pressure is found to be 160/95 mmHg. Lab results show a significantly high white blood cell count and elevated creatinine levels.

Mr. Johnson  a 67-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department with a sudden and severe pain in his mid-abdomen and lower back. The pain is described as constant and sharp in nature that began about an hour ago  shortly after dinner. He reports a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both managed with medications. He is former smoker with smoking history of 20 pack-years but quit 10 years ago. Despite the sharp pains  Mr. Johnson is remarkably stable with vitals as follows: BP 150/92 mmHg  pulse 85 beats/min  respiratory rate 18 breaths/min  oxygen saturation 98% on room air.  On physical exam  a pulsatile mass is felt in the abdomen  slightly above the umbilicus. Upon pressing  the patient grimaces in pain. His lower extremities are cool to touch  but he refutes any weakness or numbness. No noteworthy changes are observed in his bowel sounds or in his gait. The remainder of his physical examination is unremarkable.  Mr. Johnson mentioned that his older brother underwent an operation for something similar  though he is unsure of the medical term. He shared that  in his family  cardiovascular diseases appear to be common  with his father and two uncles dying of heart attacks before they turned 70.  Based on his history of smoking  the family history of cardiovascular disease  and his presentation  there is a high suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Mr. Johnson is immediately sent for an urgent CT angiography which confirms the diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The surgical team is consulted for emergent intervention due to the fear of possible rupture given his severe pain.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a history of smoking for 50 years  hypertension  and moderate to severe atherosclerosis comes in complaining of intermittent severe abdominal pain for the last 3 days. The pain is characterized as a deep  gnawing pain that is localized to the middle or lower part of his abdomen and radiates to his back. He also reports episodes of lightheadedness and feeling his abdomen pulsating. He has a stable weight and denies any changes in bowel movements  urination  diet  or physical activity. The patient's father died of an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture in his early 70's. He has a prior history of taking antihypertensive medication  aspirin  and cholesterol-lowering medication. He denies any allergies or other chronic conditions.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the ED complaining of back and abdominal pain that started suddenly a few hours ago  describing it as sharp and constant. He reports no change in bowel or urinary habits. On examination  there is a prominent pulsatile mass palpated in the midline of his abdomen.  Previous medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been managed with medication for the past 10 years. He's a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago  but admits to a 30-pack year history. He has no known allergies to any medication. His father died at the age of 76 due to a ruptured aortic aneurysm. He retired as an engineer and lives with his wife. He denies any alcohol or illicit drug use. His medications include Lisinopril and Atorvastatin.    Vital signs show a blood pressure of 145/90mm Hg and a pulse rate of 78 beats per minute. Labs show a normal complete blood count  a slightly elevated cholesterol level  and normal renal function. An ultrasound of his abdomen confirms an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring approximately 5.5 cm in diameter.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presented to the Emergency Department with a complaint of severe and worsening abdominal pain radiated to the back  localized in the middle or lower abdomen. The patient described the pain as sudden and sharp  starting about two hours ago. He felt a pulsating sensation in his abdomen  associated with nausea and mild shortness of breath.  The patient has a significant past medical history including a 35-year pack history of smoking  hypertension managed with ACE inhibitors  and high cholesterol treated with statins. His hypertension was not well controlled with fluctuating readings reported at his GP’s office. His father had suffered from an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 78.  On examination  his blood pressure was 163/97 mmHg in his right arm and 159/96 mmHg in his left arm. His abdominal exam revealed a significant pulsatile mass in the abdominal periumbilical region which was tender to palpation. However  his distal pulses were +2 and equal bilaterally. The remainder of his physical exam was within normal limits.  Given the clinical suspicion for ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  the patient was promptly ordered a computed tomography angiography (CTA) which confirmed a 7.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with a nearby hematoma  likely representing a contained rupture.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 30-pack year smoking history. He presented with a chief complaint of intermittent lower back pain for approximately two months. The pain is described as a deep  gnawing  lower back pain unrelated to physical activity. It has been largely stable in character and intensity until recently when the intensity and frequency began to increase. There are no other associated symptoms such as nausea  vomiting  altered bowel habits  urinary complaints  or lower limb weakness.  On examination  the patient appears comfortable at rest. His vital signs are: blood pressure 160/90 mmHg  pulse rate 80/ min  respiratory rate 18/min  temperature 98.6 F  and saturation 94% on room air. Auscultation of the abdomen reveals a pulsatile mass of approximately 5 cm in the periumbilical area. The rest of the physical examination is normal.  On further questioning  he admits to sporadic follow up and uncontrolled hypertension likely due to non adherence to his antihypertensive medication. He quit smoking 10 years ago. His father died of a ""ruptured blood vessel in the abdomen"" in his 70s.    Given the history  physical examination and demographics  differential diagnoses include an enlarging atherosclerotic abdominal aortic aneurysm versus an aortic dissection. An urgent computed tomography (CT) scan is needed to confirm the diagnosis and guide further therapy.   (Demographic representation - men and those over 65 are more likely to develop an AAA. Others at high risk include smokers and those with a family history of AAA).

Patient Presentation:   Mr. James  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department complaining of sudden  severe pain in his lower back and abdomen. He describes the pain as tearing and radiating down to his legs  rating it as an 8/10 on the pain scale. He admits to feeling a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. Additionally  he reports feeling lightheaded with bouts of nausea.   Past Medical History:   Mr. James is a former smoker  having quit 20 years ago  but had a 30 pack-year history prior to quitting. He has a documented history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which are well-managed with prescribed medications. His father passed away at the age of 74 from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.   This presentation fits closely with epidemiological data which suggests that abdominal aortic aneurysms most commonly occur in older  Caucasian men. Further  risk factors for such aneurysms include being a smoker or former smoker  having a history of hypertension or hyperlipidemia  and having a family history of the condition.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents with unrelenting  severe abdominal and lower back pain for the last couple of hours. The pain is described as throbbing  approximately an 8 out of 10  and did not radiate anywhere. He reports a few episodes of vomiting and also feeling slightly lightheaded. The patient has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and 45 pack-year smoking  but quit smoking 10 years ago. The patient denies any history of trauma or injury. He also denies alcohol or drug abuse. There is a family history of aortic aneurysm; his father died at the age of 74 due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. His medications include Lisinopril 20mg daily and Simvastatin 20mg daily. On physical examination  the patient appears in acute pain. A palpable  pulsatile abdominal mass is noted in the midline of the abdomen  just above the umbilicus. The pain onset  intensity  vomiting and palpable pulsating abdominal mass arouse the suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The patient's high-risk factors  such as his sex  age  history of smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and family history of AAA  further increase this suspicion. Urgent medical attention and imaging are necessary to confirm the diagnosis and guide subsequent intervention.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents with intermittent  severe abdominal and back pain over the past few weeks. He describes the pain as a deep  pulsating sensation that seems not to relate to physical activity or meals. He also complains of unintentional weight loss and occasional nausea. He has a 50-pack-year smoking history. He reports his father died from 'a rupture in his belly ' but is unsure exactly what that means. His personal medical history is relevant for hypertension and hyperlipidaemia  both of which are controlled with medication. He is retired  lives with his wife  and they have four adult children who are all in good health. He does no regular exercise.  Physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass. No bruits are heard. His blood pressure is elevated (150/90 mmHg) with a heart rate of 80 beats per minute  rhythmic. He has no history of coronary artery disease or peripheral artery disease. His last lipid panel was 6 months ago  showing borderline-high cholesterol levels.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith is a 72-year-old Caucasian man presenting with a 3-day history of severe  constant abdominal pain associated with low back pain. The pain radiates to his back and groin. He also reports noticeable abdominal enlargement although denies recent changes in appetite  bowel habits or unexplained weight loss. He has a history of chronic high blood pressure and high cholesterol for over 20 years. He has been a smoker for 50 years with an approximate pack-year history of 50 pack-years. He does not consume alcohol regularly. He reports no history of injury or trauma.   Mr. Smith's medication regimen includes amlodipine and pravastatin for his hypertension and high cholesterol respectively. The patient has no known allergies and is independent with all activities of daily living. His surgical history includes an appendectomy in his 20s. His father died of a heart attack at the age of 72 and his mother had a stroke at the age of 80. His elder brother underwent surgery for abdominal aortic aneurysm in his late 60s.   On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is palpable in the umbilical region. Auscultation does not reveal any bruits. There is no sign of peripheral vascular disease and skin turgor and hydration status appear good. Neurologically  the patient is oriented to time  place and person.  Given his age  male sex  history of smoking  family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm and presence of hypertension  a diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm is suspected. Immediate non-contrast CT-scan of the abdomen and pelvis is arranged to further delineate the aneurysm and plan for potential endovascular repair.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Thomas is a 75-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the emergency department with a history of severe and sudden-onset abdominal pain that radiates to his lower back. Mr. Thomas describes the pain as the worst pain he has ever experienced  started suddenly  and is constant. He also mentions feeling a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. Thomas also reports feeling light-headed with associated nausea.  Medical History:  Mr. Thomas has a significant past medical history of high blood pressure  high cholesterol  and smoking one pack of cigarettes daily for approximately 50 years. He has received minimal health care and has never undergone surgery. Mr. Thomas worked in construction before retiring 10 years ago. He admits to not regularly taking his prescribed medications and has recently moved to the area from another state for retirement. He is not aware of any family history of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Demographic Details:  Marital status - Widowed Occupation - Retired construction worker Nationality - American Children - Two adult children living out of state Religion - Not religious Smoking status - Smokes one pack a day Alcohol use - Occasional mild drinker Living situation - Lives alone in a retirement community Travel history - Recently relocated for retirement Illicit drug use - None reported  The patient's presentation with sudden onset severe abdominal back pain  a pulsating sensation in his abdomen  the risk factors of long-term smoking  raised blood pressure  and a lipid disorder suggest an abdominal aortic aneurysm. A thorough examination and related investigations are direly needed for confirmation.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male patient presents to the emergency room complaining of sudden  severe pain in his lower back and abdomen that started a few hours ago. The pain is described as constant  sharp and ""tearing"". He also reports feeling lightheaded and nauseous. The patient does not mention any recent trauma or physical exertion.  He is a retired mechanic who has a 50-pack/year smoking history and admits to frequently consuming alcohol. His mother died of “an urgent stomach problem” around his age  but no further details are known. He has not undergone any past surgical interventions.   His past medical history includes 15 years of uncontrolled hypertension  moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disorder (COPD)  and hyperlipidemia. He takes medications for his hypertension and COPD  but admits to frequently missing doses.  On physical examination  the patient appears uncomfortable and diaphoretic. He is overweight with a BMI of 31 and his vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 150/95 mmHg  a pulse of 110 beats per minute  a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute  and an oxygen saturation level of 92% on room air. His cardiovascular exam is remarkable for a rapid and regular rhythm. A bruit is heard on abdominal auscultation and his abdomen is tender to palpation with a pulsatile abdominal mass noted.  This clinical presentation is highly suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  likely ruptured given the acute onset of symptoms and his risk factors such as age  being male  a strong smoking history  a family history of AAA  and uncontrolled hypertension.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a history of moderate to heavy tobacco use presents with a complaint of chronic lower back and abdominal pain. His past medical history includes moderate hypertension managed with medication  and hyperlipidemia. He also mentions that he has a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm. The pain he describes is particularly worrisome as it is severe  pressing  and constant. He also states he has been experiencing occasional feelings of faintness and dizziness for the past week. On physical examination  the patient appears anxious and slightly diaphoretic. An abdominal mass is palpable on deep palpation of the mid-abdomen  and a bruit is heard over the area with a stethoscope. No other significant physical findings are present.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. Brown  who presents to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe  tearing lower back and abdominal pain that began approximately 2 hours ago. The pain is described as constant and radiates to his left side and towards the groin. Mr. Brown also reports feeling lightheaded and has vomited twice since the pain started.   Mr. Brown is a retired construction worker  lives independently. He has a 40 pack-year history of smoking but quit 5 years ago. He has a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and peripheral artery disease. His current medications include a daily aspirin  lisinopril for his hypertension  and simvastatin for his hyperlipidemia. He is allergic to penicillin  which causes a rash.   His family history is significant  as his father also had an abdominal aortic aneurysm that ruptured when he was at a similar age  which resulted in emergency surgery. Furthermore  his deceased brother had been diagnosed with coronary artery disease.   On examination  his blood pressure is low (90/60 mmHg)  pulse is high (110 bpm)  and looks pale and sweaty. Upon palpation  a pulsatile mass is noted around his navel. An urgent CT angiography is ordered based on the suspicion of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm in this high-risk patient.

Patient Presentation:  A 69-year-old African American male presents to the office with a complaint of persistent abdominal pain and back pain for the past week. He describes the pain as a strong pulsating feeling in the middle of his abdomen. He also reports feeling unusually full quite quickly  even on eating minor amounts. The patient has a positive history of hypertension  high cholesterol levels  and is a smoker for nearly 40 years.   The patient mentions that his elder brother underwent a successful abdominal aortic aneurysm repair five years ago. He denies any loss of appetite or weight  fever  nausea or vomiting  changes in bowel or bladder habit  chest pain  or shortness of breath. His current medications include daily aspirin  atorvastatin  and lisinopril.  Relevant past medical history:  1. Hypertension - Diagnosed ten years ago. The patient has been on antihypertensive medication since then with good control of blood pressure. 2. Hypercholesterolemia - Diagnosed five years ago. The patient has been on statin therapy. 3. Tobacco use - The patient reports an average of one pack per day for the past 40 years. He has made several unsuccessful attempts to quit.   There is no history of diabetes  kidney disease  or chronic liver disease. His surgical and family history is significant for an abdominal aortic aneurysm in his elder brother. The patient is retired and lives with his wife.

A 69-year-old Caucasian male presents in the emergency room with a complaint of severe  sudden onset of lower back and abdominal pain that started a couple of hours ago. Pain is described as a ripping sensation  8 out of 10 in intensity  radiating to his back and groin area. The patient appears pale  diaphoretic  and distressful. Vitals include a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg and a pulse rate of 110 beats per minute. He has a known medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40 pack-year smoking history. The patient also underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) 10 years ago. There are no known allergies. He is currently taking Lisinopril  Atorvastatin  and Aspirin.  On physical examination  a pulsatile mass is palpable in the mid-abdominal region. Auscultation of the abdomen reveals a bruit over the aortic area. His femoral pulses are symmetrically diminished. The patient has difficulty ambulating due to pain and has mild abdominal distention.   Given his age  race  gender  and history of cardiovascular issues and smoking  this patient falls in a high-risk group for abdominal aortic aneurysm.  An emergent CT scan is warranted to confirm the diagnosis of a suspected ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.  If confirmed  this is a life-threatening condition requiring immediate surgical intervention.

A 65-year-old Caucasian male patient named Mr. Smith presents to the clinic complaining of a constant  severe pain in his middle and lower back that started about 10 hours ago. He also reports a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. He has history of smoking two packs of cigarettes per day for the past 40 years and has poorly controlled hypertension. Additionally  he has a past medical history significant for hyperlipidemia and peripheral arterial disease. Both his father and grandfather also suffered from aneurysms. He has no known drug allergies and currently takes Lisinopril for his hypertension and Atorvastatin for his hyperlipidemia. He has no history of previous surgeries and besides smoking  denies any alcohol or recreational drug use. On physical examination  an abdominal mass is visible with visible pulsations.

Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  a retired construction worker  presenting with complaints of constant abdominal and back pain for last 3 days. He reports the pain as severe and steady and located in the middle of his abdomen and through to his back  and described as a 'pulsating sensation'. He adds that he does not feel sick otherwise and has not experienced any fevers  chills  nausea  or vomiting.  His past medical history is relevant for hypertension and high cholesterol for the last 10 years  both of which have been managed with medication. He has a 45-pack-year history of smoking but quit smoking 5 years ago. The patient has reported no previous surgeries.  The patient's family history is significant  with his father having suffered from an aortic aneurysm which was fatal at the age of 80. During triage  the patient's vitals were normal except for a slightly elevated blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg. Upon physical examination  an abdominal mass is noticed  which is tender and pulsating. Given his past medical history  and family history  an abdominal ultrasound was ordered to further investigate the symptoms  which confirmed the suspected abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male patient with a past medical history of hypertension  coronary artery disease  and a forty-year history of tobacco use presents with a 2-day history of severe abdominal pain  which he describes as constant and sharp. The pain appears to be radiating towards the lower back. The patient admits to a decrease in appetite and an unintentional loss of weight in the past couple of months. He also complains of a pulsating feeling in his abdomen  especially when he lays down. He denies any changes in bowel habits  recent trauma  or known exposure to infectious disease. His current medications include aspirin  Lipitor  and Lisinopril.   His father died in his early 70s from what he was told was a rupture of an ""abdominal blood vessel."" He continues to smoke about a half pack of cigarettes a day despite multiple attempts to quit. His average alcohol intake is approximately 2-3 drinks per week. He lives alone but has a good neighbour network and has two children living in a neighbouring city. He expresses concern about his symptoms and appears anxious.   On examination  his vital signs are stable  heart sounds are normal with no murmur  lungs are clear  and peripheral pulses seem to be intact and symmetrical. On his abdominal examination  a pulsatile mass is palpable in the periumbilical area just above the navel  it is around 3 cm in diameter and appears non-tender. The pain seems to get worse on palpation. No bruits are auscultated over the mass  and all other systems are unremarkable. This presentation is suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further investigations including an ultrasound and CT scan are necessary to confirm the diagnosis and decide on further management.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe is a 67-year-old Caucasian male with significant past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and history of 40-pack-year smoking  who presents with vague  intermittent abdominal discomfort over the past few weeks. The discomfort is sometimes associated with a dull lower back pain. Mr. Doe reports that the pain is localized in his stomach area  is non-radiating  and has a ‘throbbing’ characteristic. There were no aggravating or relieving factors identified. He denies any significant changes in bowel habits  melena  hematemesis  unintentional weight loss  or fever. Of note  Mr. Doe hasn't been compliant with his prescribed antihypertensive medication  atenolol.  On physical examination  there is a palpable  pulsatile mass in the middle and upper part of his abdomen. Upon auscultation  bruit is heard over the mass. The rest of the examination is relatively unremarkable.  Mr. Doe has a family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father having died from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at the age of 72. His social history is significant for long term smoking (40 pack years) and occasional alcohol use. He is a retired construction worker  and currently lives alone since his wife passed away two years ago.  Considering the significant risk factors - advanced age  male  hyperlipidemia  hypertension  long-term smoking  and family history of AAA - an AAA is suspected in Mr. Doe’s case. Further investigations including Abdominal ultrasound or CT angiography are suggested for a definitive diagnosis.

Patient Presentation:  A 73-year-old Caucasian male presents in the Emergency Department (ED) with severe  sudden onset abdominal pain that radiates to his lower back. The pain is described as a 10 on a scale of 10  without alleviation or exacerbation by any maneuvers or movements. The patient reports associated faintness and mild nausea but denies chest pain or shortness of breath.  Past Medical History:  Upon review of his past medical history  it's learned that he has been managed for hypertension and high cholesterol in the past 10 years. His hypertension is treated with thiazide diuretics.   He is a former smoker  with a history of a 50-pack year smoking habit but quit 5 years ago. He also consumes alcohol occasionally. There is no history of any surgeries in the past.   The patient does not have any known allergies.   Family History:  Notable for father who passed away due to 'aortic problems.'  Physical Exam:  Physical examination reveals a moderately tender abdomen with a pulsatile mass palpable in the peri-umbilical region. Blood pressure is 90/60 mmHg  heart rate is 110 bpm  and he appears diaphoretic. An abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is suspected  and emergent imaging is ordered to confirm.   Representation in the literature:  According to literature  abdominal aortic aneurysm is more prevalent among elderly males  particularly those of Caucasian descent. Risk factors include hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a significant history of smoking. The presentation and history of this patient align well with current demographic and risk factor data seen in literature related to abdominal aortic aneurysm.

The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presenting with intermittent  severe abdominal and back pain over the last three weeks that radiates to the sides. He states moderate hypertension for 20 years  managed with beta blockers and diuretics. A former smoker  he quit 15 years ago  but had a history of 25 pack years. He also has high cholesterol levels and admits to a sedentary lifestyle. There's a family history of cardiovascular disease  specifically his father died from an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He denies prior surgical history or allergies and is not on any other medications. His physical health appears good with no evident weight loss or gain but reports decreased appetite. He is retired and lives with his wife of 45 years.   On examination  the patient exhibits tenderness in the central and lower abdomen and there is an abdominal pulsatile mass present on palpation. No bowel sounds are audible in the vicinity of the pulsatile mass.   This patient presentation fits with the commonly seen demographics of abdominal aortic aneurysms: they often occur in older (usually over 60)  white males with a history of smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  who often have a family history of vascular disease or aneurysms.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Samuel Wilson  a 73-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department with severe  sudden onset pain in the central and lower regions of his abdomen and his lower back. The pain has been constant and is not relieved by any positional changes. He further reports feeling lightheaded and nauseated but denies any recent trauma  fevers  change in bowel movements  chest pain or shortness of breath.  Mr. Wilson is a retired engineer  married with two adult children  and resides with his wife in the city. He is a former smoker with a 30-pack year history and quit 5 years ago. He admits to the occasional indulgence of alcohol  having 1-2 glasses of wine in a week. He walks for about 30 minutes daily for exercise and follows a healthy diet to manage his medical conditions.  From his past medical history  Mr. Wilson has been diagnosed with high blood pressure and high cholesterol for the past 20 years. He has a known history of peripheral arterial disease diagnosed 3 years ago. He is regularly taking a beta-blocker  ACE inhibitor  and a statin for these conditions. There is no reported history of diabetes mellitus  heart disease  or stroke. His father died of 'abdominal aortic rupture' in his late 70s.   On physical exam  a palpable mass was detected in his abdomen which is pulsatile. This  combined with his symptoms and significant personal and family history  point towards a possible abdominal aortic aneurysm. The suspicion would need to be confirmed by further diagnostic studies.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain that began approximately 2 hours ago. The pain radiates to his back and is described as constant and ripping. He has a history of hypertension  which has been controlled with medication for the past 15 years. He also has a 50 pack-year history of smoking and is retired from a job as a truck driver.  He rates the pain as a 10/10 and feels nauseous but denies vomiting. He is sweaty and looks pale. He does not have any known food or drug allergies. His father died from an abdominal aortic aneurysm in his late 70s. The patient is currently on a beta-blocker (Atenolol)  low-dose aspirin  and a statin (Rosuvastatin) for his cholesterol.  On examination  he has a pulsatile abdominal mass and is tender to the touch. His pulse is 110 bpm and his blood pressure is 190/95 mmHg. An urgent CT scan is arranged to confirm the diagnosis of a suspected abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a history of heavy smoking for 40 years and hypertension presents to the Emergency Department with a sudden onset of severe back and abdominal pain. He describes the pain as boring  radiating to his lower back and groin region and rates it as a 9 on a scale of 1 to 10. He also mentions he's been feeling faint and experiencing shortness of breath. He has an associated history of high cholesterol and had a myocardial infarction 3 years ago. His father had a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 80. On physical examination  his blood pressure is 142/92  heart rate is 110 bpm  and an abdominal palpation reveals a pulsatile mass in the middle and upper abdomen. He denies any chest pain or any lower extremity weakness or numbness.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male patient  Mr. Jackson  presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe  constant pain in the lower abdomen and back. The patient described the pain as ""tearing"" and rated it as a 10 on a scale from 1-10. Apart from intermittent episodes of mild to moderate abdominal discomfort  specifically around the navel in the past few weeks  Mr. Jackson reported having no recent health issues.   Mr. Jackson has a medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and a 45-year history of cigarette smoking. The patient has been taking antihypertensives  statins  and aspirin for over 10 years. He denied any family history of genetic disorders or any significant surgical history.   Given his age  history of hypertension  high cholesterol  chronic smoking and the sudden onset of severe abdominal and back pain  Mr. Jackson was suspected of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Further diagnostic investigations were subsequently initiated.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male patient presents with a three-day history of constant  severe pain in his lower back and abdomen. The pain is a 7/10 on the severity scale  described as sharp and radiating towards his lower back. He also reports recent unexplained weight loss and feeling abnormally full after eating only small meals. There have no changes to bowel or bladder habits. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath or lower limb swelling.  He has a history of smoking two packs a day for the past 50 years  is a regular moderate drinker and has a sedentary lifestyle. He does not have a known family history of cardiovascular disease.  His past medical history is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. His current medications include losartan for hypertension  atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia  and inhaled corticosteroids for COPD. He is compliant with medication but admits to not following the recommended low-sodium diet.  The patient has a history of non-compliance with regular clinic appointments and had missed his last two scheduled appointments. The patient was referred to the emergency department by his primary care physician due to concerns raised following a physical examination during a routine consultation.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with a complaint of sudden onset abdominal and lower back pain. The pain is described as severe  sharp  and constant  unlike anything he has experienced before. His medical history is significant for hypertension  atherosclerosis  and a 30-year history of smoking. The patient has no known allergies and his only current medication is 5mg Amlodipine daily for hypertension. He lives alone  is a retired engineer  and reports ongoing tobacco and alcohol use. He denies any recent changes in bowel movements  urinary symptoms  nausea  vomiting  fever  or chills. On physical examination  a palpable pulsatile mass was felt in the periumbilical area. The patient is stable  moderately distressed due to pain  and exhibits signs of mild confusion. The family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases  including an older brother who had an abdominal aortic aneurysm repair.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Garcia is a 72-year-old Hispanic male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 45-year smoking history  who presents with severe episodic lower back and abdominal pain for the last several weeks. The pain is described as sharp  radiating to the groin and exacerbated with movement or walking. He denies any trauma  fever  chills  urinary or bowel symptoms  but admits to unintentional weight loss of around 10 lbs over the past month. His last physical examination was over a year ago where his primary care physician briefly noted a pulsatile abdominal mass  but no further workup was completed at that time due to Mr. Garcia's hesitance towards medical intervention.  Upon physical examination  the patient is slightly obese with a BMI of 31. He exhibits pain upon palpation of the abdomen and a pulsatile mass can be palpated in the periumbilical area. His blood pressure is mildly elevated at 145/95mmHg with a heart rate of 87 beats per minute.  Mr. Garcia's family history is notable for cardiovascular disease  including a brother who passed away in his early sixties from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.  A bedside Ultrasonography is ordered immediately to confirm suspected abdominal aortic aneurysm given his history  family history  and presenting symptoms.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. David  a 71-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department with severe and sudden onset of abdominal pain radiating to his back. The pain started about 1 hour ago and has steadily worsened. The pain was described as generally diffuse  but he localized it more specifically to his back and lower abdomen. Mr. David is unable to find a position that alleviates the pain.   He also reports feeling lightheaded and has experienced two episodes of vomiting. On a scale of 1 to 10  he rates his pain as a 9. No bowel or bladder changes nor chest pain were reported.   The patient has a history of high blood pressure and hypercholesterolemia  which he manages with medication (Lisinopril and Atorvastatin). He used to smoke a pack of cigarettes a day for 35 years but quit 15 years ago. The family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases  with his father dying from a stroke at the age of 68  and his brother having a heart attack at 62.   On physical examination  the patient appears pale and diaphoretic. His abdomen is distended  and a pulsatile abdominal mass can be appreciated on palpation. Vital signs show a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg and a heart rate of 110 beats per minute.   Considering the triad of hypotension  abdominal/back pain  and a pulsatile abdominal mass in the context of his demographic characteristics and medical history  there is a high index of suspicion that Mr. David is experiencing a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm  a life-threatening condition that requires immediate intervention.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Katz is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who comes into the office complaining of a constant deep  gnawing ache in his mid to lower abdominal area that also radiates to his lower back. He says the pain is of moderate intensity but has gradually gotten worse over the last 24 hours. He also mentions feeling fullness in the abdominal area. Mr. Katz is a retired truck driver and admits to a history of smoking about a pack of cigarettes a day for more than 40 years. He is a known case of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been treated with antihypertensives and statins respectively. He has been comparatively compliant with the prescribed medications.
