Title: A Case Study on Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Slide 1: Introduction  Patient Identifier: Mr. B  Case No. 233  Pitch: Presenting a case study of a 72-year-old Caucasian male diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Slide 2: Demographics  According to medical literature  abdominal aortic aneurysms are more common in males above the age of 65  particularly Caucasians. Mr. B fits into this category being a 72-year-old Caucasian male.  Slide 3: Past Medical History   Mr. B has a significant history of hypertension and high cholesterol  conditions which have been linked to AAA. He is also a former smoker with a 30-year history of smoking; tobacco use is a known risk factor for AAA. He has had no surgeries in the past.  Slide 4: Current Presentation  Mr. B presented to the Emergency Department (ED) with a sudden onset of severe pain in the middle of his abdomen and back. The pain was described as a tearing sensation  and it was constant  10/10 in severity  and nonradiating with no alleviating factors.   Slide 5: Physical Examination   On examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpated  and the patient had tenderness upon palpation. Concurrently  Mr. B was hypotensive and showed signs of distress – he was cold  clammy  and had a heart rate of 110 bpm.  Slide 6: Investigations   A CT scan of the abdomen and ultrasound confirmed the presence of a 6.3 cm aneurysm  suggestive of AAA. Due to the size of the aneurysm  and the patient's presenting symptoms  this was classified as a ruptured AAA  a life-threatening emergency.  Slide 7: Management   The patient was immediately taken to the operating room for an open surgical repair. A graft was placed in the aorta to bypass the aneurysm and restore blood flow.  Slide 8: Outcome  Post-operative recovery was uneventful. Mr. B showed good recovery and was discharged 10 days post-operation with a advice to maintain regular follow-ups to monitor the graft.  Slide 9: Conclusion   This case emphasizes the importance of considering AAA in older patients with a history of smoking  hypertension  and high cholesterol who present with sudden  severe abdominal and/or back pain.

Title: A Case Study of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male Patient   Slide 1: Introduction The case is about a patient diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  a potentially life-threatening condition due to the risk of rupture.  Slide 2: Patient's Demographic Information  Our patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male. Research informs us that AAA most often affects white men over age 65. The patient lives alone  is retired  and has a history of smoking  a significant risk factor for AAA.   Slide 3: Past Medical History He has a history of high blood pressure  hyperlipidemia  and peripheral artery disease – all risk factors for AAA. There is also a family history of AAA. He had quit smoking ten years ago and has moderate alcohol consumption.   Slide 4: Presenting Symptoms The patient came to the hospital complaining of intense abdominal pain  described as a pulsating sensation in the mid-abdominal region. He also experienced episodes of lightheadedness and shortness of breath  but no syncope  vomiting  or gross hematuria was reported.  Slide 5: Physical Examination Notably  abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass  suggestive of AAA. No signs of lower limb ischemia were noted.  Slide 6: Diagnostic Findings Ultrasound confirmed the presence of a 6 cm infrarenal AAA. The patient was immediately referred to vascular surgery due to the risk of aneurysm rupture.  Slide 7: Treatment and Follow-up The patient underwent successful endovascular aortic repair. His post-operative recovery was uneventful. He was advised to regular follow-ups with imaging to monitor the integrity of the graft and the size of the aneurysm. The importance of good blood pressure control and a healthy lifestyle was emphasized at discharge.  Slide 8: Conclusion This presentation highlighted a typical case of AAA in a high-risk individual  with emphasis on early detection and management to reduce the risk of aneurysm rupture  the most frequent and catastrophic complication.    End of Presentation

Title: A Case Study of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Slide 1: Introduction Today we'll examine the case of a patient diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm - an enlarged area in the lower part of the aorta. Understanding the demographics  past medical history  and overall health contributes significantly to outcomes and management strategies.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics Our case concerns a 68-year-old Caucasian male  accurately representing a demographic often affected by the condition. According to literature  men aged over 65 are at the highest risk of abdominal aortic aneurysms  with Caucasians being five times more likely to develop this disease.  Slide 3: Other Demographic Factors The patient was a smoker for over 30 years and consumed alcohol moderately  heightening the risk factor. Socio-economically  the patient is retired and belongs to the middle-income class. Despite having quit smoking five years ago  he has accumulated potential cardiovascular risks due to his smoking history.  Slide 4: Past Medical History The patient has a notable history of peripheral artery disease (PAD) and hypertension. Both these conditions have significantly contributed to the risk of developing an abdominal aortic aneurysm due to the increased stress placed on the arterial walls. His family history also revealed that his father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm  underlining a potential genetic predisposition.  Slide 5: Previous Diagnostic Imaging and Surgical History This patient underwent a cholecystectomy fifteen years ago  but there were no diagnostic imaging suggestive of an aneurysm at that time. His PAD diagnosis  done three years back  would have prompted regular abdominal ultrasounds  which initially identified the aneurysm.  Slide 6: Clinical Presentation The patient initially presented with a vague discomfort in the lower abdomen. With aneurysm growth  the discomfort increased  radiating to the back  thus prompting a visit to the doctor. The physical exam revealed a palpable mass in the middle and upper part of the abdomen.  Slide 7: Conclusion Given the past medical history  demographic profile  and current symptoms  the medical team pursued further investigations to determine the severity of the abdominal aortic aneurysm. Early detection and surgical intervention are critical to avoid complications  such as rupture  emphasizing the importance of routine exams in high-risk populations.

Title: A Case Presentation on Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Slide 1: Introduction  Introducing John  a 75-year-old retired teacher  who visited a virtual primary care physician for recurring abdominal pain.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics and Social History John is a Caucasian male  reflecting the higher incidence of abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) among this demographic. He is a veteran smoker and used to be an avid drinker until 10 years ago. He lives independently  walks without assistance and maintains an active life with his wife of 50 years.  Slide 3: Medical History John has a history of hypertension  peripheral artery disease  and hyperlipidemia  conditions that have been associated with AAA in many medical literatures. His medications include a daily aspirin  lisinopril  atorvastatin  and intermittent nitroglycerin for chest discomfort. He has no known drug allergies.  Slide 4: Symptom Presentation John was experiencing abdominal pain  occasionally radiating to his back. He reported no fever  loss of weight or appetite. However  he has observed an alarming increase in the intensity of pain over the past two months.  Slide 5: Clinical Findings  On examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpable. Upon auscultation  a bruit was heard over the mass. The physical examination findings aligned with the typical presentation of an AAA - usually asymptomatic until rupture  at which point severe pain is most commonly experienced.  Slide 6: Diagnostic Tests  An abdominal ultrasound was carried out  which confirmed the presence of an AAA measuring 5.5 cm in diameter. He was immediately referred to the vascular surgery department.  Slide 7: Treatment and Follow-up  John was scheduled for an elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  a less invasive surgical procedure that decreases mortality and morbidity when compared to open surgical repair. He was also slated for pharmacotherapy to treat his other vascular conditions and modify risk factors to improve his overall prognosis.  Slide 8: Conclusion In conclusion  late diagnosis of AAA can lead to severe medical emergencies owing to its asymptomatic nature. Prompt diagnosis through regular checks for high-risk individuals could potentially reduce morbidity and mortality. John's case demonstrates the need for surveillance  appropriate referral  and treatment in patients with an AAA.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm: A Patient Case Presentation  Slide 1: Introduction ----------------------------- - Presentation context: An overview of a case involving Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  - Objective: Identify risk factors  clinical presentation  and appropriate management for AAA based on the patient’s history and demographic data.  Slide 2: Demographics ----------------------------- - Patient: 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker - Most AAA cases occur in this demographic (men aged 65-75  especially of Caucasian ethnicity) - Other demographic variables include lifestyle factors such as smoking history and occupational strain.  Slide 3: Past Medical History ------------------------------------- - Long-term smoker (40 pack years) - Hypertension - Hyperlipidemia - History of coronary artery disease - Family history of AAA - This patient's history is consistent with typical risk factors for AAA.  Slide 4: Presenting symptoms --------------------------------------------- - Back pain  feeling of pulsating in the abdomen  - Unintentional weight loss  - History of recent onset dyspnea  Slide 5: Diagnosis and Management ------------------------------------------- - Diagnosis was confirmed through abdominal ultrasound revealing aneurysm diameter of 5.5 cm - Due to the aneurysm's size and patient's symptomatology  surgical intervention was recommended - Post-surgery  long-term monitoring and lifestyle modifications (including smoking cessation  blood pressure management  and healthy diet) recommended.  Slide 6: Learning Points ------------------------------ - AAA commonly found in older Caucasian males with a history of smoking  hypertension  and cardiovascular disease. - Early detection is critical: Routine screening advised for at-risk individuals aged 65-75. - Management options include watchful waiting for smaller aneurysms. However  for large aneurysms (>5.5 cm) or symptomatic aneurysms  immediate surgery is often preferable. - Post-surgery management requires lifestyle modification and regular check-ups.  Slide 7: Conclusion ------------------------------ Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm is a life-threatening condition  needing prompt detection and appropriate intervention. Awareness among patients  especially in vulnerable demographics  can facilitate early diagnosis and successful management. Healthcare providers must remain vigilant for signs and symptoms of AAA in patients displaying classic risk factors  as timely intervention can greatly improve outcomes.  Slide 8: References ---------------------------- - Cite the latest literature and research data on Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm: A Case Study   Slide 1: Introduction Today we'll be discussing a hypothetical patient experiencing an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm. Slide 4: Current Complaint Mr. Jones reports a dull  heavy sensation in his lower abdomen that has persisted for several weeks. He has not seen any visible or palpable abnormality  but the discomfort has made him feel unease. He reports no acute pain  backache  or issues with urination or bowel movements.   Slide 5: Importance of Past Medical History Consider Mr. Jones's past medical history in line with known risk factors for AAA. Slide 6: Conclusion In light of Mr. Jones's demographic profile  past medical history  and current complaint  AAA should be a significant consideration. Title: Case Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Slide 1: Introduction - Age ≥ 65 years  white male as Abdominal Aortic Aneurysms (AAA) are most common in this demographic group. - Occupation: Retired Mechanical Engineer. - Location: Living in an urban city in the Midwest USA. Slide 3: Presenting Complaint  - Symptom-free: AAA was detected incidentally when the patient underwent an investigation for another non-related condition. Alternatively  it could be a health check-up as central and peripheral arterial diseases have asymptomatic periods. - Or atypical symptoms: FDA suggests older patients often produce important symptoms that are incorrectly dismissed as signs of aging.   Slide 4: Examination Findings -Presumably fit and asymptomatic  vital signs within a normal range as most AAAs are asymptomatic until rupture. - Palpable  pulsatile abdominal mass upon physical examination.  Slide 5: Investigations  - Abdominal ultrasound confirming a 5.6 cm infrarenal AAA. AAAs >5.5cm  especially in patients over 65  are typically considered for surgical evaluation  due to the increased risk of rupture.  Slide 6: Management - Refer to a vascular surgeon: A consensus assuming AAA >5.5cm in case of men and >5.2cm in case of women. - Risk factor modification: Continue anti-hypertensive management  lipid-lowering therapy. - Consider psychological support if needed.  Slide 7: Conclusion - Screening and early detection of AAA are critical  especially in high-risk populations. - Risk factor modification  and in suitable candidates  surgical intervention  can prevent the serious consequence of AAA rupture.  Slide 8: Reference - A long list of peer-reviewed articles  journals  and online websites that were referenced in making the presentation. (Note: This case is fictitious and is intended only for educational purposes)

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male: A Case Presentation  Slide 1: Introduction Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a degenerative condition typically occurring in a distal aortic segment  manifested as an aortic diameter that is at least 1.5 times the normal size. AAAs are most common in men over the age of 65 and those with a history of heart disease or smoking.  Slide 2: Patient Demographics Patient: Mr. J.K.  a 72-year-old Caucasian male who is a former heavy smoker.  Slide 3: Past Medical History Mr. J.K. has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidaemia  and coronary artery disease for which he underwent angioplasty five years ago. He quit smoking five years ago  but had 40 pack years history prior to quitting.   Slide 4: Presentation Mr. J.K. presents with mild to moderate lower back pain and vague abdominal discomfort. Given his demographic profile  medical history  and potential AAA symptoms  a high suspicion for AAA is warranted.  Slide 5: Screening and Diagnosis Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass. Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) confirmed an infrarenal AAA of 5.5 cm diameter.  Slide 6: Management  Considering the size and the presence of symptoms  surgical intervention is the appropriate next step  either through open repair or endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). The decision requires thorough discussion with Mr. J.K.  taking his general health status and personal preference into consideration.  Slide 7: Prevention and Monitoring Post-operatively  Mr. J.K. will require regular follow-up and imaging to monitor the surgical repair. Encouragement of continued smoking cessation  control of blood pressure and cholesterol  and maintaining a healthy lifestyle are pivotal to decreasing the risk of aneurysm growth and rupture.  Slide 8: Conclusions This case highlights the importance of a high index of suspicion for AAA in elderly males presenting with non-specific symptoms such as lower back pain  especially in patients with risk factors such as smoking  hypertension  and atherosclerosis  to enable timely intervention and prevention of complications.  Slide 9: Questions Open the floor for questions.  Slide 10: References List of references and sources of information used in the case presentation.

Slide 1: Introduction Title: Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm Subtitle: A Clinical Approach and Management  Slide 2: Patient Demographics Title: Patient Profile  - Gender: Male - Age: 70 years  - Ethnicity: Caucasian  - Occupation: Retired factory worker - Lifestyle: Non-smoker  moderate alcohol consumption  and low physical activity level   (NOTE: According to literature  abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAAs) are predominantly found in white men over the age of 65. Smoking  advanced age  male sex  and a family history of AAA are significant risk factors.)  Slide 3: Past Medical History Title: Medical Background  - Hypertension: Patient has been managing this condition for ten years - Hyperlipidemia: Under control with statin therapy - History of smoking: Quit 15 years ago but had a 30-pack year history  - Family history: Father had AAA at age 75  Slide 4: Clinical Presentation  Title: Manifestations and Complaints   The patient presents with vague and intermittent abdominal discomfort over the past weeks. Has also reported unexplained weight loss and occasional back pain. On physical examination  a pulsatile mass was palpated in the abdomen.   (NOTE: The classical triad: pain  pulsatile abdominal mass  and hypotension are often suggestive of a ruptured AAA. However  many cases like ours present atypically or are identified incidentally.)  Slide 5: Diagnostic Findings  Title: Diagnosis & Investigations  The patient underwent abdominal ultrasonography that revealed a 5.5 cm infrarenal aortic aneurysm. With proper lifestyle changes  medication management  and regular follow up  the patient is expected to have a favourable prognosis. Medical professionals should maintain a high index of suspicion  particularly in at-risk demographic populations.

Title: Case Presentation on Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Slide 1: Introduction Introduce the topic of the presentation  Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA). Title: A Case Presentation on Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Slide 1: Introduction Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  a degenerative condition  pertains to a localized enlargement of the lower section of the aorta. It primarily affects the elderly population and is more prevalent among males. The presentation focuses on a typical AAA patient  Mr. John  a 74-year-old Caucasian male.  Slide 2: Demographics  According to the literature  AAA predominantly affects males aged 65 and older. Additionally  it has been reported that AAA is more common among the Caucasian populace. Our patient  Mr. John  falls within this most affected demographic.  Slide 3: Lifestyle Factors  Mr. John has a history of smoking  a significant risk factor linked with AAA. He also has a moderate alcohol intake and has a inactive lifestyle  both of which also contribute towards AAA prevalence.  Slide 4: Past Medical History  Mr. John has a documented record of hypertension and high cholesterol levels  which have been under medication for the past ten years. Both these conditions could potentially contribute to the weakening of the arterial wall  thereby precipitating AAA. No significant family history of AAA has been recorded.  Slide 5: Presenting Complaints and Symptoms Mr. John presented with a palpable pulsating mass in his abdomen and occasional abdominal discomfort for the past six months. However  he does not show any signs of the most feared complication  i.e.  rupture  like severe back or abdominal pain  shock symptoms  and sudden decrease in hematocrit levels.  Slide 6: Diagnostic Investigation Upon physical examination and ultrasound imaging  a 5.5cm aneurysm was detected below the renal arteries. Computed Tomography Angiogram (CTA) confirmed the diagnosis  offering a more precise aneurysm measurement and its relation to renal arteries.  Slide 7: Management and Follow-up Due to the size of Mr. John's AAA  surgical intervention was recommended. The less invasive Endovascular Aneurysm Repair (EVAR) was performed successfully. Mr. John will be closely monitored through regular follow-up visits and ultrasound scans every six months.  Slide 8: Conclusion Early detection and vigilant management are key when dealing with AAA. Understanding risk factors  associated demographic profile  and educating patients about lifestyle changes can significantly contribute to AAA management.

Title: A Case Study of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA): Balancing Interplay between Demographics and Medical History  Slide 1: Introduction: Highlighted in this presentation is a hypothetical case study of Mr. Jack  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  recently diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Statistically  AAA is common among Caucasian men over the age of 65  due to factors such as genetics and lifestyle. He has a history of moderate alcohol intake but stated that he has made some efforts in limiting alcohol. The prevalence of AAA in populations is influenced by risk factors such as age  smoking  obesity  ethnicity  and a history of vascular disease. Most mentions are seen in Caucasians  smokers  and individuals between the ages of 65 and 75.  Slide 3: Past Medical History: Mr. Jack's medical history reveals he is hypertensive and has been undergoing treatment for the last 15 years. He has a history of Hyperlipidemia but has been managing it via statin medication for over a decade. There is also a history of coronary artery disease in his lineage  with both his father and grandfather dying from heart attacks in their 70s. In his mid-60s  he was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease but has managed to largely control it via drug therapy and lifestyle modifications. His hypertension and hyperlipidemia will continue to be managed with appropriate medications; lifestyle modifications to improve his BMI will be suggested  as will continued adherence to the smoking cessation. His case will be reviewed periodically to screen for any enlargement of the aneurysm.  Slide 6: Conclusion: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysms based on factors such as demographics and medical history are crucial in early detection  management  and would be an invaluable tool to prevent rupture. Health educators need to focus on the susceptible demographics in order to promote lifestyle modifications and appropriate screenings.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm: A Case Study  Slide 1: Introduction - Brief description of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysms (AAA): localized  abnormal  weak spots in the wall of the aorta causing an outward bulging or ballooning at a point below the kidneys.  - Highlight the potential for serious complications  including rupture that can lead to internal bleeding.  Slide 2: Demographics - Highlight that men are at a higher risk than women. - Discuss the prevalence of AAA in relation to age  showing the highest prevalence in individuals over 60. - Geographic and racial disparities—AAAs are more common in Caucasians than other races. - Family history of AAA also increases risk.  Slide 3: Case Presentation - Patient's Demographic: A 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker. - Chief Complaint: Unusual abdominal pain and back discomfort. - Past Medical History: Record of hypertension  high cholesterol  smoker with 50 pack years  no prior surgeries or diagnosed chronic diseases.  Slide 4: Clinical Manifestation  - Discuss the asymptomatic nature of many AAA cases. - Explain how some patients may experience abdominal  back  or flank pain.  Slide 5: Diagnosis - Discuss how the patient’s AAA was found incidentally during a routine check-up using Ultrasonography - Importance of Screening - especially in high risk patients (Male  65+  smoker)  to diagnose asymptomatic cases  Slide 6: Management and Treatment - Describe the non-surgical approach in managing small  stable AAA  including monitoring growth rate and risk factor management (quitting smoking  managing hypertension etc.) - Indication of surgery (open or endovascular repair) for larger aneurysms or rapidly growing ones  using guidelines relevant to current practice. - Describe the application of these strategies to this patient's individual case.  Slide 7: Prognosis - Describe typically good prognosis for individuals with small  stable AAA. - Raise awareness of life-threatening possibility of aortic rupture if unnoticed or left untreated. - Discuss prognosis in the context of the specific case.  Slide 8: Conclusion - Highlight the importance of risk factor management and screening in older male patients  particularly those with a smoking history. - Intervene early for patients with AAAs to prevent complications.  Slide 9: Questions - Allow time for questions from the audience.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm: A Case Study  Slide 1: Title: Patient Demographics - Age: 73 years - Sex: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired carpenter - Health habits: Smokes 1 pack of cigarettes a day for the past 40 years - Familial History: Father passed away from aortic aneurysm at 75     Slide 2: Title: Past Medical History - Hypertension  diagnosed 20 years ago - Hyperlipidemia  diagnosed 10 years ago - Type II diabetes  diagnosed 5 years ago - No history of peripheral vascular disease  - No previous surgeries - Medications: Atorvastatin  Lisinopril  Slide 3: Title: Presenting Complaints - Intermittent lower back pain over the last two months - Feeling of heartbeat in the abdomen - No loss of appetite  but mild unintentional weight loss observed   Slide 4: Title: Physical Examination - Abdomen: Noticeably pulsating mass in the central abdomen - Cardiovascular: Normal Rhythm  No Murmurs  - Pulmonary: Mild Rales at Lung bases  Likely due to Smoking  - Extremities: No edema  Pulses present   Slide 5: Title: Diagnostic Findings - Abdominal ultrasound reveals a 6 cm infra-renal aortic aneurysm.  - CT Angiography confirms presence of an infra-renal aortic aneurysm  5.8 cm in size. No sign of rupture  dissection or leak.  Slide 6: Title: Treatment Plan - Given the size of aneurysm (>5.5cm)  elective surgical repair is warranted. - Open repair vs endovascular approach to be decided upon after discussing risks and benefits with the patient   - Risk factor modification  including smoking cessation  strict BP control  and statin therapy - Regular monitoring post-surgery for complications and aneurysm recurrence   Slide 7: Title: Prognosis and Education - Patient educated about importance of lifestyle modifications and medication compliance - Prognosis generally favorable with successful surgery but depends on patient's overall condition and surgical risk  - Importance of familial screening discussed.   Slide 8: Title: Takeaway - Emphasize on timely detection and intervention  risk factor modification and vigilant monitoring in abdominal aortic aneurysm management.  Note: This case presentation includes common characteristics of patients with abdominal aortic aneurysms: older age  male sex  history of smoking  and presence of cardiovascular disease risk factors such as hypertension and hyperlipidaemia. These represent significant risk factors for development of abdominal aortic aneurysm found in literature.

Slide 1: Introduction Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA): A Case Study  Slide 2: Patient Demographics - Patient: 72-year-old Caucasian Male - Occupation: Retired Construction Worker  (Noteworthy: AAA is most common in males over 65 years old and Caucasian ethnicity tends to have an increased propensity towards the development of AAA.)  Slide 3: Past Medical History - Smoking: 50 pack years - High blood pressure: Diagnosed 15 years ago  occasionally irregular medication compliance - Atherosclerosis: Diagnosed 10 years ago  taking statins regularly  (The literature tells us that AAA has strong associations with smoking  hypertension  and atherosclerosis.)  Slide 4: Presenting Complaints - Recent history of mild abdominal and lower back pain  - Pulsating feeling in stomach   Slide 5: Examination and Diagnosis - Physical Examination: Palpable pulsating mass in the abdomen - Imaging (Routine screening with ultrasound): Identification of enlarged aorta  - Diagnosis: AAA of 5.5cm (AAA is generally diagnosed when the aorta enlarges to 1.5 times its normal size  typical at around 3cm)  Slide 6: Management & Prognosis - Due to size and symptomatic nature of AAA  patient referred for surgical intervention - Considering patient’s age and associated risk factors  endovascular aneurysm repair was recommended - Long term follow up to manage High BP  reduce atherosclerosis progression & close monitoring of AAA  Slide 7: Discussion Bottom-line - AAA’s incidence is high amongst individuals with the patient’s demographic profile and comorbidities. - Primary care professionals play a vital role in the timely identification  and management of risk factors that if left untreated  could lead to life-threatening medical complications.   Slide 8: Conclusion - This case emphasizes the importance of vigilant regular screening and management of high-risk population for AAA. - A holistic healthcare approach  including lifestyle modifications  medical management of comorbidities along with surgical interventions as needed  is key in preventing AAA-related mortality.   Slide 9: References  (List of references)

Title: Presentation of a Case of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Slide 1: Patient Introduction - Meet Mr. Smith  a 70-year-old Caucasian male from an urban setting - Occupation: Retired police officer - Lifestyle: Sedentary with moderate alcohol consumption and a 30-year history of smoking  Slide 2: Initial Philology and Presentation - Mr. Smith reports a 3-week history of intermittent  sharp  abdominal pain  - Noted weight loss over the last couple of months - No history of similar complaints - No changes in bowel or bladder habits  Slide 3: Past Medical History  - Diagnosed with Hypertension for ten years  currently under control with medication - Underwent a stent procedure for coronary artery disease five years ago - Having hyperlipidemia managed with statins  - A 30-pack year history of smoking  quit about ten years ago - No known history of connective tissue disorders  Slide 4: Family History  - Biological father died of a stroke at the age of 60 - Younger brother underwent surgery for an abdominal aortic aneurysm at 65  Slide 5: Physical Examination  - Vital signs stable. Abdomen tender in the periumbilical region.  - A pulsating mass palpable in the abdomen - No peripheral edema  distended veins  or bruits noted  Slide 6: Diagnostic Tests  - Ultrasound reveals dilatation of the aorta measuring 5.5 cm - Computed Tomography Angiogram (CTA) confirms abdominal aortic aneurysm - ECG and echo normal - Blood work: slight increase in creatinine level  rest within normal limits  Slide 7: Diagnosis  - Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm based on medical history  clinical examination  and imaging studies  Slide 8: Discussion  - Discuss the risk factors for abdominal aortic aneurysm present in Mr. Smith: Male gender  advanced age  hypertension  atherosclerotic disease  hyperlipidemia  smoking history  and a positive family history - Briefly touch on the associated risks with untreated aneurysms  such as rupture - Discuss the options for treatment  such as conservative management  endovascular repair  or open surgery  Slide 9: Treatment Plan and Follow-up  - Discuss the individualized treatment plan for Mr. Smith  potentially including a referral to a vascular surgeon for an elective procedure  given his age  symptomatic status  and the size of the aneurysm in the context of his overall health status. - Regular follow-ups and monitoring is crucial   Slide 10: Key Learning Points  - Summarize the importance of early detection  especially in high-risk patients - Emphasize the role of medical management in limiting the progression of AAA - Discuss the significance of lifestyle changes  such as smoking cessation and control of hypertension and hyperlipidemia.   Slide 11: References - Provide a list of credible references.

Title: Case Study - Understanding  Diagnosing  and Managing Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  I. Introduction   Patient Profile:  Mr. John Smith  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  with a height of 5'6"" and weight 82kg  retired construction worker living in urban Nevada  presents the case today.   Reason for visit:  The patient attended a routine health check-up  complaining of on-and-off abdominal discomfort accompanied by lower back pain.  II. Demographics and Past Medical History   Demographics:  By literature  AAA is more pervasive in males and individuals aged over 65 years  predominantly found in Caucasian ethnicity  which corresponds to our patient’s profile. It is more common in Western countries  accounting for approximately 1 in every 50 deaths in older men.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith is a former smoker with a 40-pack-year smoking history. He quit smoking 10 years ago. The patient has a medical history of essential hypertension managed with ACE inhibitors  hypercholesterolemia managed on statins  and peripheral arteriosclerosis. He also has a family history of AAA  as his father was diagnosed in his late sixties.   III. Clinical Presentation  The patient reported occasional abdominal discomfort and sporadic lower back pain lasting a couple of hours  usually relieved by rest. He denied any fever  chills  weight loss  or changes in bowel movements.   IV. Diagnosis   Physical Examination:  Upon initial examination  a pulsating abdominal mass was palpable.   Investigations:  Ultrasound of the abdomen was performed  revealing an aortic diameter of 5.5 cm  thus confirming the diagnosis of AAA.  V. Management and Prognosis   Since the aneurysm diameter is >5.5 cm  surgical intervention by endovascular aneurysm repair is indicated to prevent rupture.   Prognosis depends on the size of the aneurysm  speed of its growth  risk factors such as hypertension and smoking status  and age.   VI. Conclusion:   This case underscores the importance of maintaining a high index of suspicion for AAA in older  Caucasian males with a history of peripheral arteriosclerosis and familial history of AAA  to facilitate prompt detection and management and prevent fatal complications.   Educating patients  especially those at risk  about AAA will also assist in early diagnosis and potential life-saving interventions.   References:  (Global  regional  and national burden of mortality associated with non-optimal systolic blood pressure and non-optimal cholesterol from 1990 to 2015: A systematic analysis of the Global Burden of Disease Study. Lancet 2020.)

Title: A Case Presentation on Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Slide 1: Introduction  - Brief overview of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) - Explanation of the relevance to demographic representation  Slide 2: Case Identification  - Subject: Male  Caucasian  Age 70 - Reason for such demographics: According to the American Heart Association  AAAs are most common in white males and the risk increases with age. While AAAs can occur in women and other races as well  more than 60% of cases are reported in white males  especially over the age of 65.  Slide 3: Past Medical History  - Patient is a former smoker - Patient has a history of high blood pressure and high cholesterol - Family history of aneurysm (Research shows that smoking  hypertension  and family history significantly increase the risk of AAA)  Slide 4: Presentation - Patient presented with vague  uncomfortable feeling in the abdomen and lower back pain - No visible or palpable mass observed - No signs of rupture  such as intense abdominal pain  low blood pressure  rapid pulse  or loss of consciousness   Slide 5: Diagnosis  - AAA suspected based on age  medical history and symptoms  - Confirmed with ultrasound imaging showing enlarged aorta  (The Society for Vascular Surgery states that ultrasound has 95% sensitivity in diagnosing AAA)  Slide 6: Treatment  - Since the patient’s AAA is over 5.5cm  open surgical repair recommended to avoid rupture  (Note: If diagnosed early and the AAA is small  regular monitoring and lifestyle changes may be sufficient until the AAA is large enough to require surgery)  Slide 7: Conclusion  - Emphasize the importance of being aware of risk factors for AAA  particularly in older  white male patients with a history of smoking  hypertension  and family history of aneurysms.  - Highlight the potential for silent progression of AAA and thus the importance of screening in at-risk populations - Emphasize the effectiveness of surgical intervention in preventing life-threatening ruptures when diagnosed at later stages.
