A 72-year-old Caucasian male patient presents to the Emergency Department with a severe  sudden onset of lower back pain  explaining it as a tearing sensation that has been persisting for the last two hours. The pain radiates to the groin and abdomen. The patient also reports faintness and nausea. Personal medical history is positive for a 30 pack-year smoking history and 10-year history of hypertension  which has been inconsistively treated. The patient reports no previous diagnosis of any vascular disease.   On examination  the patient appears pale and diaphoretic. Palpating the abdomen in the midline just above the umbilicus  a pulsatile mass is appreciated. The patient's blood pressure is 90 over 60 with a heart rate of 110 bpm. This patient presents with signs and symptoms suggesting an acute rupture of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Information: A 70-year-old Caucasian male   Medical History:  The patient has a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  peripheral artery disease  and a ≥30 pack-year smoking history. He also has a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   Presenting Complaints/Symptoms:  The patient came in with occasional  uncharacteristic back pain and feeling of pulse in the abdominal region. The pain had been waxing and waning  but has become gradually more intense over the past few weeks. Recent worsening of his symptoms prompted him to seek medical attention. As part of his ongoing management for his hypertension  he undergoes regular blood pressure checks and it has typically been well controlled with medication. He also reported unintended weight loss and decreased appetite.  Given his age  history of smoking  family history  peripheral artery disease  and presenting symptoms  there is a high level of clinical suspicion for an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further diagnostic imaging is advised.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents with a sudden onset of a severe abdominal and back pain. The patient has a history of COPD  and a 45-year smoking history  although he quit 10 years ago. He has hypertension and high cholesterol for which he is taking medication (ACE inhibitor and statin therapy)  but he is non-diabetic. He has a familial history of vascular diseases. The patient has been feeling fatigued and has noticed unintentional weight loss over the past few months. He has no history of trauma or surgery. He denies presenting symptoms of fever  chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncopal episodes. Physical examination reveals a pulsating abdominal mass and tenderness over the abdominal region. The patient's discomfort is consistent with an acute abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).

Patient is a 72 year-old Caucasian male  retired blue-collar worker  heavy smoker with a 50 pack year history  and a record of uncontrolled hypertension. He presents with a sudden onset of severe  tearing pain in the middle and lower parts of his abdomen that is not relieved by any position or movement. The patient also reports constipation  some nausea but no vomiting  and a feeling of faintness. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease with his older brother having a myocardial infarction at age 65. No previous surgical interventions or known allergies. Physical examination reveals a pulsating mass in the abdomen and tenderness on palpation. Patient has a known history of coronary artery disease but denies any previous symptoms resembling his present situation. The patient looks pale with a BP of 105/60 mmHg  a pulse rate of 110 beats per minute  and a respiratory rate of 24 breaths per minute.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a known medical history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and 45-pack-year smoking status presents to the hospital with a sudden and persistent abdominal pain radiating to the lower back. He reports an associated sensation of pulsating in his abdomen. On physical examination  the patient appears pale and diaphoretic  with observation of a pulsatile abdominal mass. His vital signs show a blood pressure of 80/60 mmHg and a heart rate of 110 bpm. Past surgical history is unremarkable and he is currently on atorvastatin  aspirin  and lisinopril for his chronic conditions. Given his demographic  medical history  and current symptoms  there is a strong suspicion for a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male  current smoker with a significant 50 pack-year history  presents with sudden onset of severe lower back and abdominal pain. He reports a personal history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and coronary artery disease with a family history of aortic aneurysm. On examination  he is found to have a pulsatile abdominal mass and lumbar tenderness. His vital signs include blood pressure of 159/94 mmHg  heart rate of 92 bpm. Symptoms are exacerbated by physical activity and partially relieved by resting in a fetal position. The patient’s pain is rate 10/10  describing it as the “worst pain he has ever felt”. The sudden onset  severity of pain along with positive findings of pulsatile mass rises suspicion of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

An 72-year-old Caucasian male presents with sudden intense lower back pain and a pulsating sensation in the lower abdomen. His past medical history is significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50 pack-year smoking history. The patient also reveals a family history of aneurysms in his father and older brother. On physical examination  a palpable and pulsatile abdominal mass is identified. His vital signs are stable  but he reports feeling light-headed and clammy. Further evaluations including an abdominal ultrasound is suggested to confirm suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents with a sudden onset of severe  sharp pain in his lower back and abdomen  which is not associated with meals  bowel movements  or physical activity. The pain is 10/10  radiating to his lower extremities  unrelieved by position or over-the-counter pain medicine. He also reports feeling light-headed and nauseated. He has a medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and 50 pack-year smoking status. On physical examination  he has a pulsatile abdominal mass and mild tenderness on deep palpation. No apparent trauma or injury marks are noted. Vital signs reveal tachycardia and borderline hypotension. He has no known drug allergies  takes Lisinopril for hypertension  and Simvastatin for hyperlipidemia. He lives with his wife and has limited physical activities due to arthritis. His father died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at age 75.

Problem Representation:  An 82-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50 pack-year history of smoking presents with sudden severe back and abdominal pain. The pain is described as sharp  constant  and radiating to the groin on the right. The patient also reported feeling nauseous with one episode of vomiting at home. On examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is appreciated in the mid-epigastric area which was tender to touch. He has no significant surgical history. He currently takes amlodipine and atorvastatin. This presentation combined with his history suggests an abdominal aortic aneurysm that may have ruptured.

Mr. Johnson is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a known medical history of hypertension and high cholesterol. He does not have any known allergies but is a past smoker  having quit 20 years ago. He consumes alcohol rarely and has no family history of cardiac or vascular diseases.  He presents to the emergency department with sudden onset severe  constant lower abdominal and back pain that started earlier in the day. He reports feeling light-headed and has been vomiting. His last meal was breakfast this morning. The pain is not related to food  position  or activity. Associated symptoms include shortness of breath and an increased heart rate.  On examination  he looks anxious and pale  with a mildly distended abdomen. Palpation elicited tenderness in the periumbilical area. A pulsatile mass was also felt in the same area. His blood pressure is 112/64 mmHg  pulse 98 beats per minute  and oxygen saturation 91%.  This presentation is indicative of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Further evaluation through abdominal ultrasound and computed tomography (CT) scan is suggested to confirm the diagnosis and assess severity.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of high blood pressure and smoking presents with midline lower abdominal and back pain radiating to his groin. The pain is steady  severe and began suddenly. The patient also reports feeling lightheaded  but denies any diarrhea  melena  or recent changes in his bowel habits. On examination  his blood pressure is 150/85mmHg and there is an associated pulsatile abdominal mass in the umbilical area. His heart sounds are normal and distal pulses palpable. A comprehensive discussion of the patient's medical and surgical history reveals that the patient's father had a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. The patient has never had surgical treatment for aortic aneurysm. The patient is a retired truck driver  he is married and has had no history of alcohol or substance abuse.

Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male former smoker with a medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol and peripheral artery disease. He presents with sudden  severe pain in the middle lower abdomen radiating to the back that began a few hours ago. He also reports feelings of light-headedness and increasing shortness of breath. He has a frail build and a pulsatile abdominal mass is appreciated on physical examination. No history of previous surgeries. Blood pressure is found to be elevated with a value of 160/90 mmHg. No known drug allergies are reported. Family history reveals his father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Patient retired from truck driving 10 years ago. Denies drinking alcohol but smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. Tolerating diet without nausea  vomiting or changes in bowel habits. No history of trauma. No history of kidney disease or dialysis.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Williams is a 75-year-old Caucasian male with a 45-year history of hypertension and a 40-year history of smoking  who presents with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain that began 6 hours ago. The pain is described as constant  stabbing  and intense  radiating to his back and lower portions. The abdominal pain is not associated with nausea  vomiting  or any changes in bowel or bladder habits. He also reports feeling ""light-headed"" during these episodes. His vitals on presentation are stable  but his blood pressure readings fluctuate significantly between readings.  Upon physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass can be palpated. Labs reveal a raised white blood cell count and slightly decreased hemoglobin levels. A CT abdomen reveals a 5.6 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Given his advanced age  male gender  history of long-term smoking and hypertension  his clinical presentation and imaging results are suggestive of a symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm. This condition is in alignment with existing literature  where it is identified that males above 65 years  with history of smoking and hypertension accounts for a significant fraction of abdominal aortic aneurysm presentations.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and 40 years of smoking presents with chronic back pain and a pulsing sensation within the abdomen. The pain has been present for several weeks but has progressively worsened over the past few days. The patient also reports some light-headedness  although denies any fainting spells  recent trauma  or changes in bowel or urinary habits. On physical examination  a pulsatile mass can be palpated in the mid-abdominal region which increases suspicion for an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The patient's history of long-standing smoking and hypertensive disease puts him at higher risk for aortic aneurysm as well.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents with a sudden onset of severe pain in the lower back and abdomen that is unrelieved by lying down. He also reports feeling lightheaded and faint  and experiencing dry mouth or excessive thirst. His past medical history reveals hypertension  high cholesterol  chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (from a 40-year smoking history)  and familial history of AAA with his father having died of a ruptured aneurysm at the age of 75. He also consumes alcohol regularly but has no history of illicit drug use. He has been under medication for hypertension and high cholesterol. Examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass with a systolic bruit  and signs of shock including tachycardia and hypotension.

Mr. X is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a known medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 60-pack-year smoking history. He's been under treatment with antihypertensive medication and statins and is a recent ex-smoker. Today  Mr. X presents with a sudden severe impalpable abdominal pain that radiates to his back. He describes it as a 'tearing' pain and has associated it with nausea and clamminess. On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is palpable. His blood pressure measured in both arms shows significant discrepancy.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male smoker with a history of hypertension and atherosclerosis presents with sudden onset  severe abdominal pain that radiates to his lower back. He additionally describes a recent unexplained weight loss and has a palpable  pulsating abdominal mass. He has a known history of high cholesterol and claims paternal grandfather suffered an abdominal aortic aneurysm. His blood pressure is elevated and pulse is fast and irregular. Considering his age  sex  smoking history  family history  and hypertension  the presentation is highly suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and smoking presents with sudden onset of severe abdominal and back pain that started 2 hours ago. The pain is constant  and he rates it as 8 out of 10. He also reports feeling lightheaded and has vomited twice since the pain started. He denies any symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath  or trauma. His vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 110/70 mmHg  heart rate 110 bpm  respiratory rate 20 rpm  oxygen saturation 98% on room air  and temperature of 98.6˚F. Examination reveals a tender and pulsatile abdominal mass. He has a family history of cardiac diseases with his father dying of a heart attack at an early age. The patient is a retired engineer  who smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years but quit 10 years ago. He has no known drug allergies. He takes atorvastatin and lisinopril daily. His concern with the abrupt severe pain amid known risk factors  notably hypertension  smoking and elderly age  and his physical examination are suggestive of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack a year smoking history presents with abdominal pain of sudden onset. The pain is localized in the central-lower abdomen and radiates to the back. He describes this pain as being severe at onset and it is associated with nausea. In addition to this  he also reports feeling increasingly light-headed and clammy. His vital signs on presentation show a tachycardia and a blood pressure lower than the usual readings. His physical examination shows a pulsatile mass deep in the abdomen. There are no signs of lower limb ischemia. Given the sudden  severe nature of the pain  the physical findings  and his risk factors  the clinical concern is for a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Profile: We have an 72-year-old Caucasian male  with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50 pack-year smoking history  now quit for the past 7 years.  Presentation: The patient reported sharp  severe abdominal pain and back pain over the last 3 hours. He described the pain as constant and located in the mid and lower abdominal region  radiating to the back. He denied any bowel irregularities  hematochezia  hematuria  or trauma. However  patient reported mild shortness of breath and faintness. There was also a history of unintentional weight loss over the past few months.  Relevant Medical Examination: Physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass. Blood pressure readings were somewhat low at 100/60 mmHg  and patient appeared pale and mildly distressed.  In sum  considering the patient's demographic profile  past medical history  and current symptoms  the clinical scenario seems suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) with potential instability. Immediate hospital admission and further diagnostic imaging are required to confirm and plan the management of this potentially life-threatening condition.

A 73-year-old Caucasian male patient with a significant medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40 pack-year smoking habit  presents to the clinic with complaints of intense  sharp and stabbing pain in his lower back and abdomen  consistent with a symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He has noticed an increasing frequency of the pain over the last few days. He also reports feeling a pulsating sensation near his belly button. In addition to this  the patient has lost his appetite and is experiencing unintentional weight loss over the past few weeks. The patient has a family history of AAA in his father  who died suddenly from a ruptured AAA. He hasn't been screened for AAA yet. The patient does not have any known drug allergies. He consumes alcohol occasionally and has a sedentary lifestyle.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and heavy tobacco use presents with persistent back pain and vague abdominal discomfort for the past month. The patient notes the pain is non-radiating and does not seem to worsen with food intake or movement. There is no reported nausea  vomiting  or change in bowel habits. Recently  he has experienced unexplained weight loss and feels increasingly fatigued. His mother had a history of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. There is no history of surgery  trauma or infection. Physical exam reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass. There have been no previous investigations or management steps pertinent to his current presentation. The patient's reported symptoms and family history raise concern for potential abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 71-year-old Caucasian male presents with a sudden onset of severe pain in his lower back and abdomen  which he describes as a pulsating feeling. He reports no recent trauma or injury. He has a known history of large-aneurysm coronary artery disease (CAD) as well as hypertension  and a history of smoking (20 cigarettes per day) and occasional heavy alcohol use. He denies any fever  chills  nausea  vomiting  change in bowel or bladder habits  or weight loss. The patient appears pale and is noticeably diaphoretic (sweating). He is hemodynamically stable but complains of upper abdominal fullness. His family history reveals that his father had an aortic aneurysm. He is retired and lives alone. He has no known drug allergies. He is currently on Aspirin and Statins for his coronary artery disease.

Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male presenting to the emergency department with complaints of a sudden  severe pain in his lower abdomen and back  originating without any noticeable triggering event. His pain is consistent with a ""tearing"" sensation. The patient admits to feeling faint and having an increased heart rate. On examination  a tender  pulsating abdominal mass is palpable. In terms of medical history  the patient is an ex-smoker  with a 50 pack-year smoking history. He was diagnosed with hypertension seven years ago  which is managed with lisinopril. He also has a known history of atherosclerosis and peripheral artery disease. There is a family history of aortic aneurysm. He reports ongoing adherence to prescribed medications  though his blood pressure control has been challenging. Prior to presentation  the patient had no knowledge or diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. His recent lipid panels showed elevated low-density lipoprotein levels.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and a 30-year history of smoking  presents with a sudden severe pain in the middle and lower abdomen radiating to the back. The patient describes the pain as being constant with a rapid onset. He also reports associated nausea and faintness. Upon physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpated. It is to note that he has a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysms with his father undergoing surgery due to aneurysm rupture at age 72. There are no known allergies or previous surgeries reported. Currently  the patient is on Lipitor for high cholesterol and Lisinopril for hypertension.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents with sudden  severe back pain that radiates to his abdomen and hips. The patient describes the pain as gnawing and constant. He also reports light-headedness and feeling of a strong heartbeat in his abdomen. He has a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50-pack-year smoking history  though he quit 5 years ago. He underwent angioplasty for coronary artery disease 3 years ago. Family history is notable for an elder brother who died from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. On examination  a pulsatile mass is palpable in the mid-abdominal region. No other abnormalities were detected. The blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg in the right arm  and 138/92 mmHg in the left arm  while the pulse rate is 88 beats per minute. The rest of his vitals are within normal range.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe lower abdominal and back pain. Patient background includes a smoking history of 40 years  hypertension controlled with medication  a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysms  and moderate daily alcohol consumption.  Prior to presentation  he had been asymptomatic with no prior episodes of similar pain. On examination  he appears in distress with diaphoresis and a tender pulsatile mass palpable in the mid- to lower abdomen. Blood pressure is maintained slightly within normal range but the patient has tachycardia. All these are indicative of a possible ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired constructions worker  presents with a sudden onset of severe  sharp  tearing lower abdominal and back pain. He rates his pain as a 10 out of 10  stating this is the worst pain he has ever experienced. He also endorses a syncope episode at home prior to arrival. He has a known history of hypertension for 10 years which is poorly controlled  hyperlipidemia  40 pack-year history of smoking  and a family history of a brother who died due to a sudden heart attack. On physical examination  he appears distressed  diaphoretic  and his abdomen is pulsatile and tender to touch. There is no obvious abdominal distension  bowel sounds are present. His blood pressure measurement shows 99/65 mmHg with a heart rate of 92 beats per minute. On review of his systems  he reveals unintentional weight loss over the past 6 months  and occasional claudication.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presenting with severe constant abdominal pain that radiates to his back. The pain came on suddenly  and he mentions he has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has been a smoker for 50 years. His abdomen is tender to palpation and he has a pulsatile mass in his abdomen about 4 cm in diameter  above his umbilicus. His heart rate is 110 bpm  and BP is 150/90 mmHg. His pulse and BP are normal in his arms and legs  his neurologic exam is normal  he has clear lung sounds bilaterally  and regular heart sounds without a murmur. He seems in obvious discomfort. He has never had an abdominal ultrasound or CT scan. His FH is positive for cardiovascular diseases. His past medical history includes an MI five years ago.

A 72-year-old Caucasian man presents with sudden onset of severe  pulsating lower back pain and brief episodes of fainting. He has a history of 40 pack-years smoking and hypertension  for which he has been taking medication for 10 years. He also reports a family history of cardiovascular diseases  including his father who died from ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He denies prior knowledge of having AAA. On physical examination  there's a noticeable pulsating mass in his abdomen that is tender on palpation. He's hemodynamically stable but appears anxious and diaphoretic.

Patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  a former smoker with a history of high blood pressure  high cholesterol  and obesity. He presents with sudden  severe  and persistent abdominal and back pain  which is unusual for him. He describes the pain as a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. Other symptoms include nausea  clamminess  and dizziness. Family history is notable for a father who had an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He has not been regularly compliant with antihypertensive and antilipidemic medications. Physical exam reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass with bruit. The medical concern is a potentially rupturing abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 74-year-old Caucasian male  currently on medication for hypertension for the past 6 years  presents with sudden onset severe back and abdominal pain that is tearing in nature and has been gradually increasing in intensity over the past 2 hours. The patient mentions having a 32 pack-year smoking history and admits to having a sedentary lifestyle but denies any major surgeries or hospitalizations in the past. On examination  the patient is hypertensive with a blood pressure of 165/95 mm Hg and a pulsatile mass can be felt in the abdomen upon palpation. There is no peripheral edema  but peripheral pulses are faint. The patient also has mild signs of claudication and reports occasional mild discomfort in the lower extremities on exertion  which he attributes to old age. Family history reveals that his father died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 70. The patient has not undergone any imaging studies related to heart disease or vascular issues in the past.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a 50-pack-year smoking history has presented with a sudden  severe abdominal and lower back pain that doesn't fluctuate with movement. The patient also reports feelings of dizziness and lightheadedness. His medical history reveals hypertension which is managed with medication. He has lost around 8 pounds of weight without trying in the last two months. On preliminary examination  a pulsatile mass is palpable in the mid-abdominal area. The patient's symptoms  along with his age  gender  and smoking history  are highly suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Prior to this event  the patient didn't have any diagnosed cardiovascular conditions  however he acknowledges an overall lack of physical activity and unhealthy diet.

Patient Information: A 70-year-old Caucasian male   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of long-term smoking  peripheral arterial disease  and hypertension  and a familial history of aortic aneurysms.   Presenting Complaint: The patient presents to the emergency department with a sudden intense pain in the lower abdomen and back that has been ongoing for the last 3 hours. He also describes a feeling of fullness or a pulsing sensation in his abdomen. The patient reports feeling lightheaded and weak but denies chest pain or material dyspnea.  Clinical Findings: On examination  the patient seems anxious and looks pale. Vital signs reveal a heart rate of 110 bpm and a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg. An abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile mass in the mid to lower abdomen. The patient is tender to palpation in the same region.  Given the history of long-term smoking  hypertension  and familial history of aortic aneurysms  presence of peripheral arterial disease  plus the sudden onset of symptoms described  there is a high suspicion of ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. Immediate diagnostics and treatment options should be considered as this condition is potentially life-threatening.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  chronic kidney disease  and a 50 pack-year smoking history presents with constant  severe abdominal and back pain that started 2 hours ago. The pain is described as a tearing sensation  radiating to the lower back. He also reports a mild loss of appetite and unintentional weight loss over the past few weeks but denied dysuria  hematuria  or bowel changes. His regular medication includes amlodipine  simvastatin  and aspirin all of which he complies with regularly. On physical exam  he is found to be tachycardic and has a pulsatile  tender abdominal mass. His abdomen is otherwise soft  non-distended with normal bowel sounds. Given the patient's demographic  pertinent history and symptoms  there is a high index of suspicion for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).

A 67-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension and smoking presents with complaints of consistent pain in his lower back and abdomen. The pain is moderate in intensity and non-radiating in nature. He also reported feeling a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. There have been episodes of lightheadedness and unexplained weight loss over the last two months. He denies any symptoms of chest pain  shortness of breath  vomiting  or change in bowel habits. No known family history of aortic aneurysms. His vitals on presentation were stable. He is currently prescribed antihypertensives  but non-compliant occasionally. His smoking history is significant with 20-pack years.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male patient  with a history of heavy smoking (~1 pack/day for 40 years) and hypertension  presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain that radiates to the back. He reports the pain as a sharp  tearing sensation that started about 6 hours ago  maximal in intensity at onset  and persistently severe since then. He also expresses concern about feeling a pulsating mass in his abdomen  which he noticed a few months ago but ignored it  attributing it to his old age. Patient's over-the-counter antihypertensive medication compliance is irregular and he does not take any other medications  this might have increased the chance of him developing a chronic condition.   Family history reveals that his brother underwent successful abdominal aortic aneurysm repair a decade ago. The patient was active till the pain started and denies any recent weight loss  change in bowel movements  or urinary symptoms. No history of previous surgery or significant illnesses is reported. Upon physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is palpable and bruits can be heard over the mass. There is tenderness on deep palpation. He is in distress because of the pain but cognitively intact. His vitals are stable except for elevated blood pressure. Further diagnostic evaluations are needed to confirm the diagnosis and assess the extent of the abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient is a 74-year-old Caucasian male and ex-smoker presenting with constant and severe lower back pain lasting for a few hours  radiating to the abdomen and groin region. History of asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) diagnosed 3 years ago with an initial diameter of 4.5 cm on screening ultrasound. He has a significant past medical history of hypertension controlled with medication  hyperlipidemia managed with statin  and a 30-pack-year smoking history. He quit smoking five years ago. He does not have diabetes or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. His father had a diagnosed AAA and died due to rupture at the age of 78. On examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is palpable. His vitals are unstable with blood pressure presenting as 90/60 mmHg and heart rate as 110 beats per minute  signaling potential hypovolemic shock. There are no signs of lower limb ischemia. There is no history of weight loss  fever  or food symptoms.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a significant medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  obesity  and a 40-pack-year history of smoking  presents with a new-onset  severe  sharp and constant abdominal pain that radiates to his back. The pain does not change with movement or position and he feels it mainly in the upper  middle abdomen. He reports feeling light-headed when standing and has admitted to unintentional weight loss over the past couple of months. On examination  the patient appears diaphoretic  and palpation of the abdomen reveals a pulsatile mass. The patient denies any history of prior abdominal surgeries  known aneurysms  or family history of aneurysms. He lives alone and has noted intermittent difficulty with ambulation due to the pain. He also experiences mild dyspnea on exertion but no chest pain. He expresses concerns about his health status impacting his ability to live independently.

Patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  ex-smoker with a past medical history significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia  who presents with sudden onset  severe abdominal pain. The patient reports the pain as being tearing and radiating to his back  rated at 10/10 in severity  and ongoing for approximately 2 hours. No other relieving or exacerbating factors noted. He also mentions feeling light-headed when he attempts to stand  but denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or loss of consciousness. His vital signs are stable but on the lower side with blood pressure of 100/60 mmHg. On examination  a palpable pulsatile mass was noted in the midline of his abdomen. His lower extremities are warm with palpable peripheral pulses. His EKG shows normal sinus rhythm. This presentation is suggestive of a possibly ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Profile: 72-year-old Caucasian male   Medical History: Past medical history is significant for smoking (40 pack years)  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and peripheral artery disease. No prior history of aortic aneurysm. No family history of aortic aneurysm. Last physical examination was a year ago. Currently on medication for hypertension and hyperlipidemia.   Presenting Problem: Patient presents in the ER reporting sudden onset of severe abdominal and lower back pain that started a few hours ago. Symptoms are accompanied by an episode of syncope. On physical examination  a pulsatile mass was appreciated in the midline of the abdomen. The patient also reports feeling lightheaded with the pain.  Summary: This is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  with a significant history of smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and peripheral artery disease presenting with sudden severe abdominal and lower back pain  accompanied by an episode of syncope possibly indicative of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 73-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and previous smoking presents with sudden onset  severe mid to lower back pain. He describes his pain as sharp and continuous  rating it 8 out of 10 in severity  and adds that he feels it radiating to his flanks and lower abdomen. He also complains of weakness and light-headedness. He has a known family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm. He quit smoking 10 years ago  but has a 30-pack-year smoking history. Examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass and hypotension. The patient's reported symptoms  the presence of a pulsatile abdominal mass  the family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm  and relevant risk factors such as age  male sex  hypertension  hyperlipidemia and previous smoking suggest a possible ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a history of high blood pressure  smoking  and a family history of aneurysms presents with the sudden onset of severe abdominal pain radiating to his back. The patient also mentions occasional feelings of a pulsatile mass in his abdomen in the last few months  which is often accompanied by a mild discomfort. He has been controlling his hypertension for the last ten years but admits non-compliance with his medications. He has been smoking a pack of cigarettes per day for the last 50 years. His father passed away from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at age 70. His heart rate is 110 bpm  blood pressure is 150/95 mmHg  and on physical examination  a pulsatile mass can be palpated in the abdominal region.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male patient with a medical history significant for hypertension and smoking  presents with acute onset lower back pain and abdominal pain. The pain is characterized as constant  severe and radiating to groin region. The patient also reports feeling a pulsating mass in his abdomen and uneasiness. He denies experiencing chest pain  shortness of breath  or changes in his bowel habits. Physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass. The patient's blood pressure is slightly elevated on presentation and a bruit is heard over the abdominal mass. His lifestyle is sedentary and he has been a habitual smoker for the last 50 years. He reports no known allergies and is on antihypertensives. There is no known family history of aneurysms.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack year smoking history  presents with sudden  severe abdominal pain radiating to the back. The pain is described as tearing and was not associated with any activity  food intake  or changes in bowel habits. Additionally  the patient has noticed unintentional weight loss in the past few weeks. Physical examination reveals a pulsating abdominal mass. His family history is notable for an older brother who had an abdominal aortic aneurysm repair. The patient acknowledges poor compliance with his antihypertensive medication. He has no previous surgeries and does not use alcohol or illicit drugs. He's retired and lives with his wife.

Demographics: 75-year-old Caucasian male  retired truck driver  with a history of 30 pack-years smoking  moderate alcohol use  and a family history of cardiovascular disease.  Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He's been taking lisinopril 10mg daily for hypertension and atorvastatin 20mg daily for hyperlipidemia. He has no history of diabetes  but has mild COPD due to his smoking habits. His father died in his late-70s from a stroke  and his older brother had a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in his 70s.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient presents to the emergency department with severe  sudden-onset abdominal pain that radiates to his back. He describes the pain as tearing and reports feeling lightheaded. On physical examination  he has hypotension with a pulsatile abdominal mass palpable on deep inspiration. No other symptoms of peripheral vascular disease  such as intermittent claudication or rest pain  are present. Laboratory findings showed a slight decrease in hemoglobin  and urgent ultrasound confirmed a 6cm aortic abdominal aneurysm. No signs of rupture or dissection were detected on the imaging. The patient was in stable condition  but due to the size of the aneurysm  and his family history  the vascular surgeon was requested for an immediate review for possible surgery.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack year smoking history  presents with a sudden onset of severe  sharp  tearing pain in the lower back and abdominal area. He describes the pain as constant but worsening. Accompanying symptoms include cold  sweaty skin  rapid heart rate  and lightheadedness. Family history reveals his father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm.   The patient has been compliant with his antihypertensive and lipid-lowering medications. He does not have a history of surgeries. He quit smoking two years ago. The patient reports no allergies. He has been following a modified diet for hypertension but does not engage in regular physical activity. On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is palpable. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable  ensuring accurate information for differential diagnosis and subsequent treatment plan.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 30 pack-year smoking history  presents with an intermittent back and abdominal pain for the past 1 week. He describes the pain as dull and constant  with periods of sharp  intense pain which he rates as a 7 out of 10 on the pain scale. Associated symptoms include unintentional weight loss and fatigue. He denies any changes in bowel or bladder habits. On physical examination  a pulsatile mass is palpable in the midline of the abdomen. He doesn't exhibit signs of peripheral vascular disease. There is no relevant family history.  The patient's demographics and medical history place him at a higher risk for abdominal aortic aneurysm  an abnormal and potentially life-threatening dilatation of the abdominal aorta. Aneurysms can be asymptomatic until they rupture  causing severe  sharp  and constant pain. A pulsatile abdominal mass and unintentional weight loss may also be indicative of an unruptured aneurysm. Immediate vascular surgical consultation is warranted given the potential rupture risk and life-threatening consequences of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Smith is an 80-year-old Caucasian male  a retired truck driver  who presents with a sudden  intense  and constant pain in his middle and low back which started four hours ago. He states it feels ""like a pulsing sensation"" and he is very worried. His medical history includes high blood-pressure for the past 10 years  40 pack-year of smoking which he quit 5 years ago  and peripheral artery disease diagnosed two years ago. He also admits to having occasional claudication. He is currently taking antihypertensive medications and a statin. He has no known allergy to medications.  On physical examination  he appears pale and in distress. Blood pressure is found to be 135/85 mmHg in his right arm and 137/80 mmHg in his left arm. His pulse rate is 110 bpm  and respiratory rate is 24 per minute. Abdominal examination reveals a slightly tender  pulsatile mass in the middle and upper abdominal area. He also has diminished pulses in his bilateral lower extremities  with no visible or palpable signs of trauma or injury. The remainder of his physical examination is unremarkable.  Given his age  medical history  and physical exam findings  there is a high suspicion of abdominal aortic aneurysm with possible rupture.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male  previous history of smoking & hypertension  presents with an intense  sudden onset of abdominal pain that radiated to his lower back. He also reported a few episodes of syncope. He has a known history of high cholesterol and peripheral arterial disease for which he was prescribed a statin and anti-hypertensive medications respectively. The patient does not have diabetes or any known genetic diseases in his family. He has a noticeable pulsatile mass on his abdomen on physical exam  with tenderness and hypotension handled as suspected ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. His last recorded BP was at 90/60 mmHg with visible distress. He has no previous history of abdominal aortic aneurysm or surgery. He admits to a poor exercise tolerance  harsh & non-productive cough with constant fatigue over the past few weeks. He doesn't have gastrointestinal or urinary complaints or alterations. Previous X-ray imaging from a routine medical checkup a year ago didn't show any abnormalities. His BMI is 28 and shows no signs of malnutrition.

Problem Representation  The patient is a 75-year-old Caucasian male with 45-year history of heavy smoking and hypertension  presenting with sudden  sharp  and persistent pain in his lower back and abdomen. He also reports feeling a strange pulse near his bellybutton and a few episodes of fainting. On physical examination  you note an expansile abdominal mass. He has been compliant with his anti-hypertensive medications and has been regularly followed up by his primary care physician. However  he previously refused a screening ultrasound for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) due to his fear of diagnostic procedures. His family history is significant for AAA: his father died following a ruptured AAA at the age of 73.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male  prior smoker with a 30 pack year history  presents with mid-abdominal and lower back pain that can be described as a pulsing sensation. He has a medically relevant history of high cholesterol and hypertension  both of which he has managed with medication for 15 years. Family history includes a father who underwent emergency surgery for rupture of an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 67. The patient denies chest pain  shortness of breath  and lower extremity weakness or numbness  though he reports recently experiencing occasional light-headedness. He also reports unintentional weight loss and diminished appetite over the last couple of months. Physical examination reveals a palpable  pulsatile mass in the patient's mid-abdominal area. Bowel sounds are normal and the remainder of the examination  including the rectal and genitourinary systems  is unremarkable.

A 70-year-old African-American male with a medical history significant for chronic hypertension  smoking  hypercholesterolemia and known coronary artery disease reported experiencing sudden  severe and constant pain in the mid-abdominal region extending to his lower back for the past few hours. He also reports feeling slightly faint with associated mild shortness of breath. He has no history of any previous surgeries. He does not take his antihypertensive medications regularly. On examination  a pulsating mass just below the sternum is felt. The patient rates his pain at an 8 on a scale of 10. The patient’s symptoms  combined with his age and risk factors of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and smoking suggest a possible abdominal aortic aneurysm.

An 67-year-old Caucasian male  with a significant of smoking for 45 years  presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe  tearing lower back pain that radiates to his abdomen and flank and is not relieved by any position or motion. His medical history is significant for hypertension  high cholesterol  and a recent diagnosis of peripheral artery disease. On physical examination  the patient appeared diaphoretic  anxious and in noticeable distress. An abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the midline of the abdomen and the patient has a high blood pressure of 155/95 mm Hg.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male retiree presents with a sudden onset of severe abdominal and back pain  which he describes as tearing in nature and radiating to his back. He reports feeling lightheaded and having a vague sensation of his pulse beating in his abdomen which he had not noticed before. The patient has a past history of hypertension and high cholesterol  for which he is on medication  but he has a history of being relatively non-compliant. He also has a 50-pack-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. He has no known drug allergies. There is a history of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) in his family  with his father having the same. On physical examination  he is found to be diaphoretic and his pulse is weak and tachycardic. His blood pressure is slightly below the normal range. His abdomen is tender and a pulsatile mass is palpable in his mid-abdominal region. His femoral pulses are weak. The remainder of his examination is unremarkable.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack-year smoking history presents with sudden onset of severe  near constant  tearing abdominal pain and back pain. The pain was not accompanied by nausea  vomiting  diarrhoea  or urinary complaints. On examination  he has a palpable  pulsatile abdominal mass and his blood pressure is slightly elevated at 150/85 mmHg. His family history reveals that his father passed away after a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. He is currently not on any medication. Over the past few months  the patient has experienced unintentional weight loss and a decrease in appetite. Patient denies any previous similar episodes of abdominal or back pain.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50 pack-year smoking history comes to the ER with complaints of severe  sudden-onset abdominal pain that radiates to his back. The pain is not associated with food intake or activity. He further reports feeling lightheaded and sweaty. He has not had any changes in bowel habits or urinary symptoms. On examination  there is a notable pulsatile abdominal mass. There are no signs of bowel obstruction or tenderness. He has bruising on his flank sides. His blood pressure is slightly low and pulse rapid but regular. Family history is positive for aneurysmal disease. His last cholesterol and blood pressure were poorly controlled. He remains on regular medication for his hypertension and hyperlipidemia.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male patient with a history of heavy smoking and uncontrolled hypertension for 20 years presents with sudden onset of severe pain in the lower back and abdomen. On further probing  he describes the pain as tearing and radiating to his back. He has no history of any immediate past traumatic event. On examination  he is found to be hypotensive and has a palpable pulsatile mass in the abdomen. There is no history of earlier similar complaints  surgeries or known allergies. He self-reports poor compliance to his anti-hypertensive medications while his family history is notable for cardiovascular diseases. His lipid profile done 6 months back was within normal limits. Due to his age  medical history  and symptoms  there's an immediate concern for possible ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient is an 70-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia and a 40-pack year smoking history. He presents to the clinic with recent onset of mild to moderate  continuous  pulsating lower abdominal discomfort for the past week. He denies any nausea  vomiting  change in bowel habits  weight loss or any radiation of the discomfort. He mentions that the pain seems to worsen when he lies down or eats. On physical exam  a pulsatile abdominal mass is palpable in the mid to lower abdomen  with mild tenderness to palpation. No noted skin changes  hernia  or signs of infection. No peripheral edema or pedal pulses are palpable bilaterally. This presentation raises concern for an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Mr. Jackson  a 73-year-old Caucasian male with a history of high blood pressure  high cholesterol  and a 40-pack-year smoking history  presents with sudden onset of severe back pain that started 1 hour ago. He also reports a sensation of pulsation in his abdomen which he has never noticed before. He has been otherwise well  with no recent trauma or illnesses. His father passed away due to rupture of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. On physical examination  he appears distressed due to pain and is found to have a pulsatile mass palpable in his midline lower abdomen. His blood pressure is mildly elevated and his heart rate is in the normal range. This clinical scenario suggests a possible abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history notable for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and tobacco use presents with sudden  severe back pain. He is feeling faint and has vomited  although the vomit does not contain blood. On emailing his primary care physician  he mentioned he'd been feeling occasional unexplained abdominal pain in the past few days  similar to his current back pain but less severe. Reviewing his lifestyle  he reported a 30-pack year smoking history. There is no report of fever  recent trauma. His physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass and hypotension. His family history reveals his father died of a rupture aneurysm. His symptoms and history are concerning for a possible abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-year smoking habit  presents with sudden onset  severe pain in his lower back and abdomen. The pain is constant  tearing in quality and radiates to his back and groin. Associated symptoms include nausea  vomiting  lightheadedness  cold sweats and an increased heart rate. His vitals are stable but his pulse is slightly elevated. Relative on physical examination reveals a pulsatile mass in the midline of the abdomen. The patient has a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysms. He has no known drug allergies and is currently taking antihypertensive drugs and statins. He admits to occasional alcohol use but has quit smoking 2 years ago.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents with intermittent and severe abdominal and lower back pain that has been ongoing for the last two weeks. The patient describes the pain as a pulsating sensation that radiates to his groin and hips. He has a prior medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia and has been a chronic smoker for the past 50 years. He also reports a family history of cardiovascular disease - his father had a ruptured aortic aneurysm at age 68. He does not report any symptoms of bowel or bladder dysfunction or any changes in extremity sensation or strength. Clinical assessment notes a pulsatile abdominal mass.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male presents to the emergency department with sharp  radiating abdominal pain and lower back discomfort. He describes the pain as the worst he has ever experienced  rating it a 10/10 on the pain scale. Patient reports feeling nauseated and has vomited once. He also reports feelings of faintness and profuse sweating. Over the past week  he has observed some weight loss but did not think it serious. His past medical history is significant for hypertension  well-controlled on medication  and a 50-year pack-year smoking history. He reports a paternal family history of aneurysms. Physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass. His blood pressure is found to be unstable. No history of trauma or injury. He denies any history of drug or alcohol abuse. This presentation is suggestive of a leaking or ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Information: A 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired military officer  non-smoker  with a moderate alcohol intake.  Chief Complaint: Presents with a sudden onset of severe pain in the lower back and abdomen.  History of Present Illness: The patient describes the pain as 'ripping' and rates it an 8 on a 10-point scale. The pain first started 3 hours ago and has been gradually worsening. No known agitating or relieving factors. Patient also reports feeling dizzy and faint.  Relevant Medical History: Known hypertensive for 13 years  under irregular medication. A positive history of unstable angina that led to myocardial infarction 7 years ago  managed with percutaneous coronary intervention and is now under regular medication.   Family history: Father died due to myocardial infarction; mother died due to stroke. One older brother died because of aortic aneurysm rupture.  Relevant Findings on Physical Examination: The patient is in distress and his skin is pale. Vitals show a blood pressure of 162/98mmHg and a heart rate of 108 beats per minute. On abdominal examination  a pulsatile mass palpable in the midline of the abdomen. No signs of abdominal guard or rebound tenderness observed. Bowel sounds are normoactive.  Relevant Diagnostic Evaluation: EKG shows nonspecific T-wave changes. Laboratory evaluation shows an increase in WBC and increased serum lactate levels. The ultrasound reveals an abdominal aortic aneurysm of 7.3cm with periaortic fluid consistent with rupture.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and smoking presents to the emergency department with severe pain in his lower back and abdomen. The pain has been gradually increasing over the past few hours and is described as a pulsating feeling which is not alleviated by rest or changes in position. The patient also reports feeling lightheaded  sweaty  and an overall sense of unease. His blood pressure is 160/100 mmHg and his pulse is rapid and weak. He has a history of atherosclerosis and his only surgical history is an appendectomy when he was younger. Family history is unremarkable. No history of any previous similar episodes.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of hypertension and smoking presents to the emergency department with severe  sudden onset abdominal pain and back pain. He reports that the pain is a constant ""tearing"" sensation. He also mentions feeling lightheaded. There is no history of previous surgeries. On physical examination  there is a noted tender  pulsatile mass in the midline of the abdomen. His blood pressure is 150/100 mmHg on the right arm and 148/95 mmHg on the left arm. The combination of this patient's age  sex  smoking history  hypertension and symptoms strongly suggest the possibility of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA).

Patient Profile: A 73-year-old Caucasian man  former smoker  with a known history of aneurysms in the family.  Medical History: He has a long-standing history of hypertension and high serum cholesterol levels  managed by medication. He also has a documented family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm in his father and brother.  Presenting Symptoms: The patient has been experiencing intermittent  non-radiating lower back pain for the past three weeks  accompanied by unexplained weight loss. He reports feeling an unusual pulse or throbbing sensation in his abdomen. He denies other symptoms such as fever  changes in bowel or urinary habits  or cardiovascular symptoms like chest pain or palpitations. Physical examination reveals a pulsating mass in the central abdomen.  In light of his medical and familial history as well as the symptom narrative  the findings suggest abdominal aortic aneurysm.    Note: Abdominal aortic aneurysm is prevalent in older men  especially those with a genetic predisposition. It is also associated with smoking history  hypertension  and high cholesterol levels. The patient's demographic profile and presenting symptoms are consistent with much of the literature on abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male patient with a known medical history of hypertension  tobacco use  and hyperlipidemia presents to the emergency department with severe  sudden-onset pain in the lower back and abdomen that is not relieved by change in position or rest. He describes the pain as tearing and radiating to his lower back. On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is palpated below the umbilicus. The patient also reports feeling lightheaded and experiencing episodes of near fainting. His vital signs indicate tachycardia and hypotension  which are signs of hemodynamic instability. This points towards possible ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm  a life-threatening complication of an undiagnosed or untreated abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). This male patient falls within the typical demographic group for AAA  which occurs mostly in men over 65 years with cardiovascular risk factors.

Patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 45-year history of smoking  presenting in emergency with abrupt onset of severe abdominal pain that radiates to the back. The pain is associated with nausea  vomiting  and episodes of lightheadedness. He reports a feeling of a pulsating sensation in his lower abdomen since a few months. He is currently on daily doses of amlodipine and simvastatin and has inconsistent compliance to his medication. His family history includes a male sibling who had a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm in his seventies. A preliminary physical examination indicates a pronounced and palpable abdominal mass with a pulsatile character. He appears in distress  pale  and sweaty  and his vital signs are showing accelerated heart rate and borderline low blood pressure.

Patient Profile: A 72-year-old Caucasian male present.  Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and was a long-term smoker  having a smoking history of 40 pack-years before quitting 10 years ago. There is a known family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Presenting Problem: The patient came to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe  sudden-onset pain in the lower back and abdomen  described as feeling like tear or ripping sensation. Over the past several days  the patient has noted an unusual pulsing sensation in his mid-abdomen  which he initially thought to be the result of flatulence. However  this sensation began to be associated with a vague discomfort which escalated to debilitating pain in the past few hours. The patient is fatigued and lightheaded  but denies experiencing any trauma to the affected area.   Clinical Evaluation:  On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpated. The patient exhibited hypotension with blood pressure measuring 95/60 mmHg and had a tachycardic heart rate of 110 beats per minute. High suspicion of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was made considering the age  gender  background  and clinical presentation of the patient.   Immediately  arrangements were made for an emergency surgical intervention  analgesic was administered  and efforts were made to slow the heart rate and maintain optimal perioperative blood pressure.

Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a long-term smoking habit of 50 pack years  reporting non-specific symptoms of intermittent abdominal discomfort and back pain over the last several weeks. Recently  the patient also noticed unintentional weight loss and a sensation of abdominal pulsations. There is no any known history of heart disease  diabetes  or any malignancy. No prior family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Upon physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was identified. Test results revealed elevated blood pressure at 150/95 mm Hg. The patient's symptoms  long-term smoking history  and physical findings are highly suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male  long-term smoker with a significant medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and coronary artery disease  presents with severe  sudden onset lower back and abdominal pain. The pain is described as sharp and tearing  radiating to the groin. He also reports episodes of faintness and rapid heart rate. On physical examination  he exhibits signs of acute distress  with a pulsatile abdominal mass present and hypotension. The patient reports no history of similar pain  gastrointestinal disorders  or recent traumatic injury. The patient's father had a history of abdominal aortic aneurysm. These symptoms raise a high index of suspicion for a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male presents with a sudden onset of severe lower back and abdominal pain  accompanied by faintness and cold sweats. He has a significant past medical history of hypertension and a 45-year pack history of smoking. On physical examination  he has steady abdominal pain and is revealed to have a pulsatile abdominal mass upon palpation. Vital signs reveal tachycardia with a heart rate of 110bpm and blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg. No prior diagnosis or symptom of abdominal aortic aneurysm is documented. Familial history is significant with his father having died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 72.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male smoker with a medical history of high blood pressure and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with sudden  severe pain in his lower back and abdomen  which has persisted for a few hours. The pain is described as a tearing sensation  and is accompanied by nausea and clammy skin. He has no surgical history. His mother died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at age 70. On physical examination  his blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg  pulse is 110 beats per minute  he exhibits pallor  and there appears to be a pulsating mass in the central and upper part of the abdomen which is very tender to palpation. The rest of the examination is unremarkable. The clinical suspicion of abdominal aortic aneurysm is strong.

A 68-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40 pack-year smoking habit presents with a sudden onset of severe pain in his lower back and abdomen that began a few hours ago. He also reports some associated feelings of light-headedness. The patient describes the pain as constant  sharp  and radiating to his lower back. He denies any accompanying nausea  vomiting  or changes in bowel or bladder habits. On examination  his heart rate is noted to be 100 bpm and his blood pressure 145/90 mmHg. A pulsatile mass in the midline of the abdomen is palpable and he exhibits significant tenderness over the epigastrium. This clinical picture raises immediate suspicion for a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and 50-pack-year smoking history presents with severe  sudden onset lower back and abdominal pain. The pain is described as a constant  sharp pain that began suddenly about an hour ago. He also reports associated nausea. He denies chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncope but states he feels ""very unwell"". His vitals show elevated blood pressure and heart rate. Upon physical examination  there is a pulsatile mass found in the mid abdominal region. Given the combination of his age  high blood pressure  smoking history  and presentation  there is a high suspicion of ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. Immediate emergency surgical consultation is indicated.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and moderate tobacco use presents with sudden onset of severe back pain radiating to the lower abdomen. The patient also reports feeling a pulsing sensation within his abdomen along with increasing mild light-headedness. He denies any previous similar episodes  chest pain  or recent trauma. No bowel or bladder dysfunction. On physical examination  the patient is afebrile  hemodynamically stable  but appears distressed due to pain. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness over the mid and lower abdomen along with a palpable  pulsatile midline mass. These clinical findings are suggestive of a potential Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA).

Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired  with a history of high blood pressure  hyperlipidemia  and smoking 20 pack-years. He presents with sudden onset of severe  sharp pain in his lower abdomen and back. He rates the pain as 9 out of 10 in severity  describes it as 'tearing'  and says the pain began suddenly while he was having dinner. Patient also reports a sensation of fullness in his abdomen and states he's been feeling lightheaded  with a near fainting episode prior to arrival at the hospital.   On examination  he appears pale and diaphoretic. There is a visible pulsatile mass in his middle to lower abdomen. His blood pressure is low with a reading of 90/60 mmHg. There is no history of trauma or high-risk activities that would suggest a different cause for the symptoms. Personal medical history includes diagnosis and treatment of peripheral artery disease 5 years ago. He has been non-compliant with blood pressure and cholesterol medications.   The rapid onset of severe pain  the described character of the pain  and the location of it along with the hypotension and pulsatile abdominal mass suggest the possibility of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. His age  gender  history of smoking and hypertensive disease put him at elevated risk for this life-threatening condition. Immediate surgical consultation and intervention are warranted.

Problem Representation:  Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker with a history of hypertension  tobacco use (40 pack-years)  and hyperlipidemia. He presents to the emergency department with sudden onset severe back and abdominal pain  which he describes as tearing  lasting for the past couple of hours. He also reports feeling lightheaded and has been vomiting. Examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass  tachycardia  and hypotension. No previous history of any abdominal surgeries or traumas. He has had no recent medical screenings and his last physician's visit was due to a mild upper respiratory infection a year ago. His parents both died of heart disease in their eighties. He has a body mass index (BMI) of 27.3 and has been deficient in maintaining regular exercise. He has moderate alcohol consumption (around 10-12 drinks per week)  follows a diet high in saturated fats  and experiences regular bouts of stress.

A 67-year-old Caucasian male with a history of longstanding untreated hypertension and heavy smoking presenting with abrupt  severe pain in the lower part of his abdomen and back. He reports that the pain has persisted for the past few hours and is constant. He additionally notes feeling lightheaded and anxious. On physical exam  a palpable pulsatile abdominal mass is felt. He does not have a known family history of cardiovascular disease or aneurysm. His only medication is an over-the-counter painkiller he takes as needed for occasional backache.

A 70-year-old white male patient presents with intermittent and uncontrolled abdominal pain for the past 3 days. He has a 30-year history of uncontrolled hypertension and a 40-pack-year smoking history. He denies experiencing any fever  nausea  vomiting  hematuria  or changes in bowel and bladder habits but he mentions a noticeable 'heartbeat' sensation in his abdominal area. On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is palpable. Focused history revealed that the patient's older brother had an abdominal aortic aneurysm repaired at the age of 72. There are no known drug allergies and no recent or ongoing medication use. The pain does not seem to be relieved by any position or intake of antacids. Given the history of smoking  longstanding hypertension  age  and strong positive family history  among the various differential diagnoses to consider  one potential cause of the patient's symptomology is abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Demographic Information: A 68-year-old Caucasian male  Medical History: The patient has a significant history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has been a smoker for 30 years  but quit 5 years ago. The patient has no family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Presenting Symptoms: He presents with sudden  severe abdominal pain that radiates to the back  along with a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. On examination  an abdominal mass is noted. Additionally  the patient reports episodes of fainting.  Diagnosis: Findings are consistent with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further confirmation with medical imaging is necessary. Urgent surgical consultation is warranted considering the patient's symptoms.

Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a history of chronic hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and 40 pack-year smoking habit  presenting with severe  sudden onset abdominal and lower back pain. The pain is 8/10  constant  unrelieved by change of position or over-the-counter analgesics. He also reports a sensation of fullness in his abdomen and light-headedness. There are no associated symptoms of nausea  vomiting  or changes in bowel habit. He has no history of gastrointestinal disease or surgery. Physical exam reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass and hypotension. His family history is significant for his father dying suddenly in his 60s of a ""ruptured blood vessel"" and his older sibling undergoing surgery for an abdominal aortic aneurysm in his 70s.

Patient Profile: A 75-year-old Caucasian male  retired truck driver  presents with a sudden  severe abdominal pain and lower back pain.   Medical History: The patient has been a smoker for the last 50 years smoking approximately 15 cigarettes a day. He has a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia and coronary artery disease. He has a familial history of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA); his father died from a ruptured AAA.   Presenting Symptoms: He reports experiencing an onset of sharp  severe pain that began in the middle of his abdomen and radiated to his back  along with a sensation of pulsating in his abdomen. He also reports feeling lightheaded and short of breath. He denies any prior episode of similar symptoms.   Upon physical examination  a pulsatile mass was felt in the abdomen. Tenderness was observed in the midline of the abdomen below the xiphoid process. Hypotension is noted and peripheral pulses are reduced. His risk factors of smoking  aging  male sex  and the family history of AAA increase the probability of abdominal aortic aneurysm as a potential diagnosis.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with history of hypertension and smoking is presenting with intermittent lower back pain and abdominal pain over the past two days. Symptoms are more pronounced after meals. The patient reports unexplained weight loss over the past month and a decrease in appetite. He denies any changes in bowel habits or urinary symptoms. Upon physical examination  there is a palpable pulsatile mass in the mid-lower abdomen with no overlying skin changes. His BP is elevated at 155/95 mmHg in both arms. The patient's medical history includes a 40-pack-year smoking history and 15-year history of poorly controlled hypertension. There is also a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm with his father having died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Mr. Gomez  a 72-year-old Hispanic male with a history of smoking and high blood pressure  presents with sudden and severe lower back and abdominal pain  along with episodes of fainting. He also reports recent unexplained weight loss and feeling a prominent pulse in his abdomen. Consequently  his mobility has become limited due to discomfort. His family history reveals his father died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. Mr. Gomez's current medications include Losartan for hypertension. He retired as a construction worker  is married and lives with his wife  and has three grown children. He has been smoking approximately a pack of cigarettes a day for the past 50 years and occasionally drinks alcohol. Functionally  he's semi-independent  occasionally requiring assistance from his wife for physically demanding tasks.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and a 40-pack-year smoking history  presents with a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain  radiating to his back  lasting for three hours in duration. The pain is 8/10 in intensity  tearing in nature  not relieving by changing position and is associated with nausea and vomiting. On physical examination  a large  pulsatile  tender mass is felt in the middle and lower part of his abdomen. No signs of shock are present. His family history is positive for an abdominal aortic aneurysm in his father. He denies fever  night sweats  recent weight loss or any changes in bowel movements.

Patient is a 76-year-old Caucasian male  retired military officer  who presented with a sudden onset of severe  constant pain in the lower back and abdomen. He is visibly in acute distress. History reveals that he is a smoker with a 20-year pack history  has evidence of advanced peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and a long-standing controlled hypertension. Family history reveals that his father died due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. Patient admits to recent unexplained weight loss but denies any fever  chills  changes in bowel or bladder habits  or any previous similar episodes. Physical examination reveals a pulsating abdominal mass with bruit  pallor  and abdominal tenderness upon palpation. Vital signs are stable with a blood pressure reading on the higher side.

Problem Representation:  Mr. Smith is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol levels  and a 50-year pack of smoking  who presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe abdominal pain and back pain since last 3 hours. He describes the pain as “tearing” in nature which started in the mid-abdominal region and radiates to his back. He also reports feeling lightheaded and had one episode of fainting at home. On physical exam  a pulsathtaking mass in his abdomen is palpable and his blood pressure is noted to be on the lower side  90/60 mm of Hg. He also has diminished pulses in lower extremities. This may be indicative of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm requiring immediate surgical evaluation and intervention.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. S  with a known history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and a 40-pack year smoking history presents with sudden onset  severe abdominal pain that started 2 hours ago. He describes the pain as a ""ripping"" sensation that radiated to his back.
