Problem Representation:  Patient Profile: A 70-year-old Caucasian male patient comes to the clinic with abdominal pain and lower back pain. He reports his blood pressure is typically on the high side (hypertensive). He also has a history of smoking two packs of cigarettes a day (heavy smoker) for the past 45 years but quit smoking two years ago. The patient says he has been limiting his tobacco use but hadn't entirely quit until recently. He has been also having periodic episodes of rapid heartbeats (tachycardia). His family reports that he has progressively lost weight over the past few months  although he was not dieting or exercising to lose weight.  Past Medical History: In addition to hypertension and a history of heavy tobacco use  the patient has a history of hyperlipidemia (high cholesterol) and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He underwent coronary artery bypass graft surgery 10 years ago for triple vessel disease. A myocardial infarction (heart attack) was experienced 5 years ago. He has not had any peripheral vascular disease or cerebrovascular accidents. He has not undergone any abdominal or aortic surgeries in the past.  Family History: The patient has a family history of cardiovascular disease. His father died due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 60 and his oldest brother has a known abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Medications: He is on atorvastatin (statin medication for cholesterol control)  Aspirin (anti-platelet therapy) and Metoprolol (Beta-blocker for blood pressure control).  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient appears of stated age  mildly distressed due to abdominal and back pain. He has a body mass index (BMI) of 25 and blood pressure of 150/80 mmHg. An abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile mass in the mid-epigastric region. His neurological examination is normal.  Additional Data: Laboratory tests show increased inflammatory markers. An abdominal computed tomography (CT) scan shows a 5-cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm.  This profile represents a typical patient presenting with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The patient's characteristics and past medical history are in line with the typical demographic for this condition: older  male  Caucasian  smoking history  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and history of cardiovascular disease.

Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. George Thompson Age: 72 years Gender: Male Race: White Residence: Urban  Midwest USA  Problem Representation:  Chief Complaint: Mr. Thompson reports a sudden onset of severe pain in his middle and lower abdomen and back. The pain seems to be constant and is unchanged with movement/position.  Demographic Information: Mr. Thompson is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who lives alone in an urban area. He is a retired mechanical engineer and served in the military when he was younger. He smokes 1 pack of cigarettes a day for about 50 years.  Medical History: He has a history of cardiovascular disease  hypertension and COPD. For the cardiovascular disease  he has been prescribed beta-blockers  and for hypertension  he is on ACE inhibitors. He also takes bronchodilators for his COPD. He had undergone a coronary artery bypass graft surgery 4 years ago. He has a significant history of cholesterol for which he takes statins.  Family History: His father died due to a stroke at 78 years old. His mother is alive with Parkinson's disease. His younger brother died at 65 due to an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He has two children from his only marriage  both of whom are healthy.  Clinical Findings: During physical examination  the physician palpated a pulsatile mass in the abdomen. There is no traumatic injury noted. Lumbar spine is normal with no related pathology.  Social History: He has been widowed for 3 years now. He is relatively inactive with little exercise and has a high-fat diet. He has no history of drug use or alcoholism.  Summarizing the case  a 72-year-old white male presents with severe abdominal and back pain. He has a significant smoking history and suffers from cardiovascular disease  hypertension  COPD and hyperlipidemia. His family history includes a brother who died of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Current physical examination revealed a pulsatile mass in his abdomen.

Problem Representation:  A 70-year-old male patient presents with a sudden onset of severe and persistent pain in the lower back and abdominal region. The pain is knife-like and pulsating in nature. He also reported signs of experiencing lightheadedness and rapid heart rate.   Demographic Characterization:  The patient is a Caucasian male  keeping in line with demographic data indicating that abdominal aortic aneurysms are most common in this racial group. His age of 70 aligns with the significant presence of the condition in those aged 65 and older.  Patient History:  The patient has a history of heavy smoking  pharmacologically controlled hypertension  and high cholesterol levels. Both these conditions are risk factors for the development of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. There is also a family history of aortic aneurysms  which increases the patient's risk.  Upon physical examination  he appears distressed due to pain. His abdomen is noted to be rigid and slightly distended. A pulsating mass is felt upon palpation in the upper abdominal region  possibly indicating the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.   The patient's health has been stable for a good part of his life except for his managed hypertension and high cholesterol levels. He has a history of regularly following up at the clinic for his chronic medical conditions. He has been vaccinated for Influenza and Pneumonia. He is reasonably well-nourished and lives with his wife in their home.  Post-emergency surgical intervention for the abdominal aortic aneurysm  the patient's progress will need to be monitored. Long-term management of his hypertension and high cholesterol levels will need to be adjusted accordingly. Smoking cessation counseling will also need to be escalated to remove this risk factor. Yearly screening for aortic aneurysm will be mandated given his family history of aortic aneurysms.

Patient Profile:  **Patient Information** - Name: John Doe - Age: 73 years old - Sex: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired military officer - Marital Status: Widowed - Smoking History: 50 pack years  quit 5 years ago - Alcohol Consumption: Moderate  3-4 times a week - Recreational Drug Use: None  **Presenting Problem** John is complaining of uncharacteristic back pain and abdominal discomfort  which he initially believed might be related to old age or arthritis. He mentioned feeling a pulsating sensation around the navel area when laying flat on his back. The pain is continuous  dull and not associated with meals or physical activity.   **Past Medical History** - High blood pressure for 20 years  on medication - Diagnosed with high cholesterol 10 years ago  controlled with statins - History of peripheral arterial disease (PAD) diagnosed 7 years ago - Had a heart stroke 5 years ago  on aspirin for secondary prevention - Undergone coronary artery bypass surgery 6 years ago  **Family History** - Father passed away due to heart attack at age 70 - Mother  age 90 alive with dementia - Two elder sisters (76 and 79) both with high blood pressure  elder sister had a heart attack at age 70 - No siblings or parent with the history of aneurysm  **Physical examination** On examination  his blood pressure was slightly elevated at 145/90 mmHg  heart rate was regular at 78 beats per minute. An abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass around the navel.  **Assessment** Based on the patient's age  sex  risk factors (hypertension  high cholesterol  smoking history  PAD)  family history  and symptoms  there is a high suspicion for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  **Plan** Order a CT scan or ultrasound to confirm diagnosis  and depending on the size and patient's condition  discuss surgical or endovascular intervention options for the AAA.  This presentation depicts a common scenario for an abdominal aortic aneurysm. It is more prevalent in the elderly male population  and particularly in those with a history of cardiovascular disease  hypertension  high cholesterol  smoking  and Caucasian ethnicity. Family history of AAA slightly increases the risks. AAA is often asymptomatic but can manifest as unexplained abdominal or back pain  or a pulsatile abdominal mass.

Patient Problem Representation:  Patient: Mr. Gibbs  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  Presenting problem: The patient has been complaining of constant severe pain in his lower back and abdomen. He has also described experiencing a pulsing sensation in his abdomen.  Signs and Symptoms: Significant abdominal pain  pulsating abdominal mass  tenderness in abdomen  back pain  pulse distal to the aneurysm may be decreased.  Past Medical History: Longstanding history of hypertension  30-year-history of tobacco use (two packs of cigarettes daily)  was diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia 10 years ago and has been under medication since then. The patient has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  his father died from an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture. Mr. Gibbs was treated 5 years ago for a myocardial infarction. He denies any allergic reactions.  Examination Findings: Vital signs are BP 165/85  Pulse 95  Temp 98.6 F  RR 18  Oxygen Saturation 96% on room air. Examination reveals a pulsating abdominal mass  about 5 cm in diameter.   Investigations: Chest X-ray shows calcification of the aortic knob. Abdominal ultrasound reveals an aneurysm of the abdominal aorta measuring 5.5 cm. Complete blood count  renal function tests  and electrolyte studies are normal.   Demographics: Lives alone and is retired. He is not physically active and does not adhere to a healthy diet. He consumes alcohol socially. He denies use of illicit drugs.  In conclusion  these symptoms  along with the patient's age  race  long history of smoking  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia and a family history of cardiovascular diseases  particularly AAA  the presence of a pulsating abdominal mass and pertinent imaging findings suggest a strong possibility of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm.

Problem Representation:  Patient Characterization:  Mr. Thomas is a 71-year-old Caucasian male who has presented with complaints of constant  severe pain in the lower back and mid-abdominal area. Height is approximated to 6 feet  with a weight of 85 kg  bringing his BMI to 25.5  indicating he is slightly overweight. Consequently  he suffers from obesity. He also complains of occasional leg pains  which other doctors have attributed to peripheral artery disease over time. He is a retired banker  an active smoker since his mid-40s  and has a moderate drinking habit.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Thomas has a well-documented past medical history. He was diagnosed with hypertension and high cholesterol 15 years ago and has been under treatment since then. Both of these conditions have been fairly well controlled with medications. His medical records also reveal that he had undergone cardiac catheterization for coronary artery disease 10 years ago. He currently takes a daily aspirin  statins for high cholesterol  and antihypertensive medications.  Family History:  His father died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm  and his older brother was recently diagnosed with an unruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Relevant Literature:  According to literature  the typical patient suffering from an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is often an older male  aged around 65-75 years old. AAA is also found more commonly in Caucasians than in other racial or ethnic groups. The presence of other cardiovascular diseases  especially hypertension and high cholesterol  is common with AAA. Moreover  AAA has a strong genetic component  which is evidenced by the positive family history in this case.   Smoking  which is another significant risk factor for AAA  is also present in Mr. Thomas. As with most cases of AAA  he did not exhibit any noticeable symptoms until the aneurysm grew large; this aligns with the characteristic silent growth of AAA. The pain he now experiences may be indicative of the aneurysm being at the risk of rupture  which is a dangerous complication of this condition. The presence of peripheral artery disease further escalates the risk for cardiovascular events.   Since obesity can lead to hypertension and high cholesterol  Mr. Thomas’s weight can be considered as an additional risk factor contributing to AAA in his case. Alcohol consumption  although not a direct risk factor  can contribute indirectly to cardiovascular diseases  thereby affecting AAA.

Problem Representation:  Patient Demographics:  A 70-year-old male Caucasian patient  former smoker. Lives in a suburban area  has a history of moderate alcohol consumption  and is overweight (BMI 29). Additionally  he works as a retired engineer and is a veteran.   Chief Complaint: He presents with occasional mild-to-moderate abdominal discomfort. He has no history of diabetes or hypertension but does have a significant cardiovascular disease history  having  survived a heart attack six years ago.   Medical History: According to the patient records  he quit smoking five years ago but smoked for roughly 50 years. He underwent a cardiac angioplasty post-myocardial infarction. He has been on a statin (Lipitor) and a daily aspirin since his heart attack. No history of any respiratory diseases. The patient admits to a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activity and a diet high in fats and carbohydrates. He confirmed a family history of cardiovascular diseases; his father passed away due to a heart attack  and his elder brother had an abdominal aortic aneurysm.   Social and Psychosocial History: The patient lives with his wife. He is retired from a stressful job. He denies any illicit drug use. He enjoys playing cards with his friends usually once a week. The patient mentions that he often feels anxious about his health.   Observations: Upon physical examination  a pulsatile mass is palpable in the abdomen.   Investigations: Further studies including ultrasonography or CT scan can identify the abdominal aortic aneurysm size  location and risk of rupture. His lipid profile  renal function and other appropriate blood tests should be conducted as well to account for his underlying cardiovascular disease.   Note: This is a typical example of a patient with abdominal aortic aneurysm demographics. Males  especially Caucasians  aged over 65 years  having a history of smoking and/or cardiovascular diseases have the highest risk of developing an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Other risk factors include a family history  high cholesterol levels  and a history of heart or peripheral vascular diseases.

Problem Representative: Mr. David Thompson  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presented at the emergency department complaining of severe and persisting pain in the middle and lower part of his abdomen and back  with a feeling of pounding near his navel. He is a retired naval officer  married  with two adult children. He resides in the suburbs of Boston  Massachusetts.  His past medical history reveals that he was a smoker for 30 years  consuming a pack a day  but has quit 10 years ago. He has uncontrolled hypertension for the last 20 years and has type 2 diabetes for over 15 years  both of which he manages with medications. He also underwent a surgical procedure for peripheral artery disease around 5 years ago. He has a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysms as his paternal grandfather suffered from a ruptured AAA.   Mr. Thompson has been experiencing occasional chest pain and fatigue for a couple of months that he recently mentioned to his primary health service provider. His last physical examination which was about 6 months ago was satisfactory  at which time his body mass index was 28. His recent blood lipid profile showed slightly elevated triglycerides and LDLs  and he is currently following a low cholesterol diet plan.  He was found unconscious by his wife following the onset of symptoms and was rushed to the hospital. Triage was performed timely and he was resuscitated. Based on his clinical presentation and history  an emergency computed tomography angiogram (CTA) was ordered which confirmed an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Problem Representation:  Patient Demographics:  - Age: An elderly man  around 70 years old - Gender: Male  - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Retiree - Weight: Slightly overweight with the Body Mass Index (BMI) of 27 - Lifestyle: Former smoker who quit 10 years ago  drinks alcohol occasionally  Presenting Problem:  The patient has come to the clinic complaining of severe lower back pain that has been progressively getting worse over the past few days. The pain is not related to any movement or physical activity and it is constant. He has also been feeling increasingly fatigued and has somewhat reduced appetite. He hasn't noticed any changes in his urine or bowel movements  but occasionally felt heart palpitations.  Past Medical History:  Present illness:  - Previous history of hypertension for the past 15 years managed with antihypertensive medication - Dyslipidemia managed with statins. - Quit smoking 10 years ago  after 30 years of a pack-a-day habit - No previous surgeries or hospital admissions.  Family History:  - His father died at 75 from a stroke  mother died at 80 due to heart disease - His older brother had an abdominal aortic aneurysm repair at 72.  In addition to his presenting symptoms and notable family history  the patient’s age  gender  smoking history  hypertension  and dyslipidemia all make him a high-risk candidate for abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Problem Representation:  Demographic Characterization: Patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired  lifelong smoker with an average socioeconomic status. The patient lives alone and is fairly sedentary in his lifestyle.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presents with a recent history of intermittent  dull pain in the abdomen and lower back. He has also reported unintended weight loss over the past few months.   Past Medical History: The patient has a relevant past medical history of high blood pressure for which he takes medication. He has a 50-year history of smoking and quit 10 years ago. He has been diagnosed with hyperlipidemia and is currently on statin therapy. His father died due to a ruptured aortic aneurysm.  Literature Data: Demographic data from clinical research indicates that abdominal aortic aneurysms occur more frequently in men than in women  are most common in people aged 65 and older. They are more common in white people than in people of other races. A family history of aortic aneurysms often means an increased risk and the presence of other vascular aneurysms is usually an indication. Cigarette smoking significantly increases the risk  especially for men  and the risk diminishes after around 5-10 years of having quit smoking. Hypertension and hyperlipidemia are also key risk factors.   Problem: Given the patient’s demographic profile  his past medical history  and presenting symptoms  there is a potential indication of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The problem is further underscored by his advanced age  gender  long-term history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and his family history of aortic aneurysms. The pain in the abdomen and back  coupled with unexplained weight loss are common symptoms associated with abdominal aortic aneurysms. Immediate medical attention is necessary to confirm the diagnosis and decide upon the most suitable course of treatment.

Problem Representation:  Mr. John Smith is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents with some lower back pain and a pulsating feeling around his lower naval. He was a long-time smoker and quit 10 years ago but he continues to drink alcohol occasionally. He acknowledges an ongoing battle with obesity with his BMI remaining above 30 for the last 15 years. His medical history includes hypertension for which he has been taking medication for the past 7 years; however  his blood pressure has often been poorly controlled. He also has a history of high cholesterol and has been on statins for over a decade. He underwent angioplasty about 6 years ago due to coronary artery disease.   His family history is notable for his father  who passed away from an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) rupture in his late 70s. In terms of social history  he is a retired mechanical engineer who lives with his wife of 48 years. He has two adult children and four grandchildren. He admits to not getting as much exercise as he ought to and this has aggravated the discomfort in his back and abdomen.  This case presentation is typical as the incidence of AAA is more common in males over the age of 65 and in those of Caucasian descent. Multiple risk factors are present such as advanced age  a history of smoking  obesity  high blood pressure  high blood cholesterol  and a family history of AAA. Moreover  AAA is often asymptomatic and discovered incidentally during imaging for other indications  but in this case  patient is presenting with common symptoms associated with AAA such as lower back pain and pulsating feeling in the lower naval region.

Problem Representation:  Patient Demographic: The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a history of long-term smoking and high blood pressure. He is retired and lives with his wife in a suburban area. He has a BMI of 28  suggestive of being overweight but does not have any known food allergies. It is known that he drinks alcohol occasionally  maintaining a limit of 2 glasses of wine a day.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of hypertension for 20 years  controlled with Lisinopril. His lipid profile shows mildly raised cholesterol levels  being treated with Atorvastatin. He has no significant surgical history. The patient has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father having succumbed to a myocardial infarction  and his elder brother had surgical repair for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He is a former smoker with a 40 pack-year history but quit smoking 10 years ago.   Presenting Problem: The patient has recently started experiencing a constant  dull ache in the abdominal region  sometimes radiating to the lower back. The pain  initially mild  has gradually increased in intensity over the last couple of weeks. He has also complained of feeling unusually fatigued recently. He denies any recent trauma  fever  changes in bowel habits  or genitourinary symptoms. When seen in his primary care clinic  an abdominal mass is palpated and is noted as pulsatile.  Synthesis: Given the patient's age  sex  history of long-term smoking  hypertension  family history of AAA  and presenting symptoms of unexplained and persistent abdominal pain  the suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm is high. Further imaging tests such as an abdominal ultrasound or CT scan will be required for confirmation.  Literature Support: The demographic details and characteristics outlined here are consistent with existing literature which identifies older age  male gender  Caucasian race  smoking  and family history as the most significant risk factors for abdominal aortic aneurysm. The presentation of abdominal or back pain  coupled with a palpable abdominal mass  is also consistent with the typical presentation of advanced AAA cases.

Problem Representation:  Chief Complaint:  69-year-old male presented with a sudden onset of severe pain in the lower back area  radiating to the buttocks and thighs.   Demographic Information:  The patient is a 69-year-old Caucasian male  who is retired and lives with his wife. He is an ex-smoker  having quit 15 years ago  but smoked a pack of cigarettes every day for 30 years. He consumes alcohol occasionally. His BMI is 29  which puts him in the overweight category.   Previous Medical History:   The patient has been diagnosed with high blood pressure and hyperlipoproteinemia. He has been on anti-hypertensive medications and statins for the past 10 years. His father died of a heart attack in his mid-70s  and his mother died of stroke at age 80. His older brother had an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) repair at age 72.  Review of Systems: The patient has been feeling tired for the past few days. He reported constipation  poor appetite  and occasional dizziness. He denied chest pain  shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting  diarrhea  or changes in urinary frequency or volume.   Physical Examination:   On physical examination  the patient appeared in pain but not distressed. His vital signs were within normal limits except for a mildly elevated blood pressure at 140/90 mm Hg. His abdomen was soft and non-tender  but a pulsatile mass was palpable in the periumbilical area. Peripheral pulses were present and symmetrical in lower limbs.   Preliminary Diagnosis:  Given the patient's age  past smoking history  family history of AAA  and the presentation of sudden severe lower back pain with a palpable pulsatile mass in the abdomen  the preliminary diagnosis is an abdominal aortic aneurysm.   References: 1. Golledge J  Norman PE. Current status of medical management for abdominal aortic aneurysm. Atherosclerosis. 2011 Jul;217(1):57-63. doi: 10.1016/j.atherosclerosis.2011.03.043. Epub 2011 Mar 23. PMID: 21481865. 2. Schermerhorn ML  O'Malley AJ  Jhaveri A  Cotterill P  Pomposelli F  Landon BE. Endovascular vs. open repair of abdominal aortic aneurysms in the Medicare population. N Engl J Med. 2008 Jan 31;358(5):464-74. doi: 10.1056/NEJMoa0707348. PMID: 18234750.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an 80-year-old Male Non-smoker with Comorbidities: A Case Report  Case Presentation:   The patient is an 80-year-old male non-smoker with a past medical history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He is of Caucasian descent and retired military personnel who lives a predominantly sedentary lifestyle in a suburban setting.  His medications consist of metformin  lisinopril  and simvastatin. He is compliant with his medications and has good follow-up with his primary care physician and endocrinologist. He does not consume alcohol and has no known drug allergies. He doesn't have any known family history of aortic aneurysms.  The patient presented to the emergency department with severe  sudden-onset  tearing abdominal and back pain radiating to the lower extremities. In addition to the pain  the patient was experiencing concomitant symptoms of light-headedness  nausea  and profuse sweating. His vital signs on arrival were notably for tachycardia and hypotension.  Investigations:  A bedside abdominal ultrasound was done which revealed abdominal aortic dilatation measuring 6.5 cm. His blood work was remarkable for leukocytosis  elevated levels of serum creatinine  and lactic acid reflecting systemic inflammatory response and renal impairment.  Diagnosis:  Given the patient’s presentation and ultrasound findings  the diagnosis of ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm was made.  Treatment:  He was immediately taken to the operating room where a vascular surgeon performed an emergent open repair of the ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Outcome and Follow-up:  Postoperatively  the patient was managed in intensive care unit (ICU). His recovery was complicated by ongoing renal impairment and required temporary hemodialysis. He also developed pneumonia  but it was managed with antibiotics and respiratory support. After a total of 3 weeks in the ICU  he was transferred to the general vascular surgery ward. His recovery was slow but progressive  with improved kidney function that avoided long-term dialysis.  Discussion:  Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) is a condition that is more common in males  particularly those over the age of 65. The main risk factors include smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a family history of aneurysms. The patient's history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia put him at risk. Surprisingly  this case was found in a non-smoker patient  emphasizing the importance of bearing in mind the condition even in patients atypical of a classic AAA demographic.  Learning Points:  1. Early recognition and prompt intervention are critical for survival in ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysms. 2. Always consider AAA in the differential in patients over the age of 65 presenting with severe abdominal pain  even if they don't fit the typical profile (smoker). 3. Emphasize the significant importance of managing hypertension and hyperlipidemia in preventing AAA in at-risk populations. 4. Multi-disciplinary team approach involving primary care  endocrinology  intensive care unit and vascular surgery teams are crucial in the management of such complex patients.

Patient Initials: J.D. Gender: Male Age: 72 Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer Presenting Problem: Dull abdominal pain  Managerial History: J.D.  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  was brought to the emergency department presenting with dull  consistent lower abdominal pain that started approximately a day ago. The patient stated that the pain also radiates to the back. In his assessment  he rated his pain as a seven on a scale of zero to ten. J.D. was not experiencing any other symptoms such as fever  vomiting  diarrhea  or chest pain.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he is currently taking Hydrochlorothiazide 25 mg once daily and Atorvastatin 20 mg once daily. J.D. used to smoke a pack of cigarettes daily for 50 years but quit smoking 5 years ago. He admits to occasional alcohol use.  Family History: His father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 78  and his mother passed away from a stroke at 80. His younger brother is alive at 65 and has a diagnosis of coronary artery disease.  Physical Examination: Upon physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpated. J.D.'s blood pressure was 145/90 mmHg  and heart rate was 82 beats per minute. No renal bruits were heard on auscultation. The rest of the examination  including chest  cardiovascular  and neurological  was unremarkable.  Investigations: A computed tomography (CT) scan with contrast of the abdomen was ordered  which confirmed an infra-renal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) that was 5.5 cm in diameter. No signs of rupture or leak were present.   Management and Follow-up: The patient was admitted for surgical consult and then had an elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) due to the large size of the aneurysm. The patient’s postoperative course was uneventful. He was discharged 2 days after surgery and advised to quit alcohol entirely  continue his current medications  have regular follow-ups with the vascular surgeon  and get an ultrasound of the abdomen in 6 months.   Clinical Reasoning: The male gender  older age  history of smoking  the presence of cardiovascular risk factors (hypertension and hyperlipidemia) make J.D. more predisposed to developing AAA. The lack of symptoms  such as leg pain  decrease in pulses  or skin changes  excludes peripheral arterial disease. The normal and unremarkable chest and cardiovascular examination support the abdominal origin of the pain  narrowing down to a possible AAA. The pulsatile abdominal mass further supports the suspicion of AAA. The diagnostic imaging confirmed the presence of a large AAA  which required surgical intervention.   Discussion: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) is a potentially serious condition with a higher prevalence in men  especially those over 65 and with a history of smoking  hypertension and hyperlipidemia. AAA  unless ruptured  typically remains asymptomatic and may be discovered incidentally on physical examination or radiological studies performed for unrelated reasons. However  once the aneurysm ruptures  it may present with severe pain  frank shock  or death. Timely diagnosis and intervention are critical in managing this condition. The case highlights the importance of a thorough clinical examination  prompt diagnosis  and appropriate management.

Title: A Case of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-Year-Old Caucasian Male  INTRODUCTION:  We report a case of an asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) identified incidentally in a 68-year-old Caucasian male during a routine medical examination.   CASE PRESENTATION:  A 68-year-old Caucasian male presented for his annual check-up with no specific complaints. He is retired  previously worked in construction  is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally. His medical history included hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which had been controlled with medication (atenolol 50mg daily and atorvastatin 20mg nightly) for the last eight years. Family history was significant for a brother who had an AAA repair at age 70.  On physical examination  his vital signs were stable - blood pressure 130/80 mmHg  pulse rate 72 beats per minute  respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute  oxygen saturation 98% on room air  and temperature 98.6°F. Cardiopulmonary examination was overall unremarkable. On abdominal examination  a visible pulsatile mass with an expansile pattern was noted in the peri-umbilical region. No tenderness  distension  or signs of peritonitis were elicited.  On suspicion of AAA  the patient was referred for an abdominal ultrasound. The ultrasound revealed an infrarenal AAA with a maximal diameter of 5.5cm. No signs of rupture or dissection were observed.   DISCUSSION:  The patient was diagnosed with an asymptomatic AAA. Despite the normal blood pressure readings  it was decided to further lower the target blood pressure to reduce the pressure load on the aneurysm wall  and the dose of atenolol was increased to 75mg daily. Concurrently  the patient was referred to a vascular surgeon for further evaluation considering the aneurysm diameter of >5cm  advanced age  and family history of AAA.  In line with the current guidelines endorsed by the Society for Vascular Surgery  he was scheduled for an elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). The patient was informed about the risks and benefits of the procedure and he consented to it.  CONCLUSION:  In this case  the patient was asymptomatic and his AAA was found incidentally during a routine medical check-up. This underlines the importance of physical examination and raises awareness of AAA in older male patients with risk factors. Primary care physicians should be vigilant and consider referring such patients for screening abdominal ultrasound. This patient’s care was managed according to current guidelines  highlighting the importance of a multidisciplinary approach in the management of AAA.

Title: Symptomatic Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a Senior Hispanic Male: A Case Report   Introduction: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysms (AAA) are a common vascular disease in older adults and are often asymptomatic until rupture. It is prevalent in 5-10% of men over 65 years of age and is more common in Caucasians when compared to other racial/ethnic groups. This case report describes the unusual case of a symptomatic AAA in a senior Hispanic male.   Case Presentation: Patient Information: Mr. Q  a 73-year-old Hispanic male  presented to the emergency department with complaints of sharp  sudden-onset back  and abdominal pain along with nausea and vomiting for a duration of one day. The patient  a retired auto-mechnaic from New Mexico  lives with his wife. He is an ex-smoker with a 30-pack-year history and quit 5 years ago. He has a history of hypertension and peripheral arterial disease (PAD) and is on medication (lisinopril 20mg/day and clopidogrel 75mg/day  respectively). There is no known family history of AAA or vascular diseases.   Clinical Findings: On examination  his blood pressure was elevated at 170/90 mmHg  his heart rate was 96 beats per minute  and his respiratory rate was 18 breaths per minute. An abdominal examination showed a non-tender but pulsating mass in the midline of his abdomen. There was no distension or rigidity on palpation. There were no signs of peripheral embolization.  Diagnostic Assessment: The patient underwent a computed tomography angiography (CTA) scan which revealed a fusiform AAA with a maximum diameter of 6.8cm  with no sign of rupture. His complete blood count  coagulation profile and renal function were within normal limits. His urine analysis was also normal  excluding urinary tract infection as a source of his abdominal discomfort.  Therapeutic Intervention: Due to the size of the aneurysm and symptoms  the patient was referred for urgent endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). Written informed consent was obtained for EVAR  and the procedure was conducted successfully without complications.  Follow-up and outcome: The patient was discharged on post-procedure day 5 with prescriptions for antibiotics and analgesics. Follow-up post 6-weeks and 3-months showed reduction in AAA size  with no endoleak or complications. The patient reported no abdominal or back pain and was satisfied with the treatment.  Patient Perspective: Mr. Q expressed gratitude for the care provided by the hospital team and stressed the importance of regular follow-ups for preventing potential health issues.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of clinical suspicion and timely decision making in managing an infrequent case of symptomatic AAA in a senior Hispanic male  emphasizing the need for population-specific to enhance early detection and treatment of AAA.  Informed Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report and any accompanying images.  Keywords: Abdominal aortic aneurysm  Hispanic  male  symptomatic  endovascular aneurysm repair.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Aging Female Patient: A Case Report  Introduction: Abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) are commonly seen in males over the age of 65 and is highly associated with a history of smoking  high blood pressure  and atherosclerosis. Although it is less common in females  AAA can be fatal when undetected or untreated  often leading to rupture. We describe the case of a 75-year-old Caucasian female who presented with symptoms of a ruptured AAA.  Case Presentation: The patient  a 75-year-old Caucasian female with a medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  presented to the emergency department with severe abdominal and back pain. She is a non-smoker and leads a sedentary lifestyle. Her family history revealed that her father died of an aneurysm rupture at the age of 83.  An initial physical examination identified a pulsatile abdominal mass  with a reduced blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg. Laboratory test showed an elevated white blood cell count  hinting towards signs of infection or inflammation. A CT scan confirmed the diagnosis of an AAA with a diameter of 7.5 cm  indicating a high risk for rupture.   Treatment: Due to her critical presentation and the size of the aneurysm  an emergency open surgical repair was performed. The surgery was successful  and her aneurysm was repaired with a Dacron graft. Postoperative recovery was monitored in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) due to the significant risk of complications from the surgery.   Outcome and Follow-Up: The patient experienced a steady recovery for two weeks in ICU before being moved to a less intensive ward. Throughout the recovery  she had a constant check on vital signs  aneurysm graft patency  and signs of systemic complications. Six months after the surgery  the patient is doing well  with regular follow-ups highlighting no signs of graft complications.  Conclusion: This case demonstrates the presentation of AAA in an elderly female  a cohort typically underrepresented in AAA cases. Timely diagnosis and emergency surgical intervention were decisive in preventing a fatal rupture. Furthermore  this report emphasizes the importance of screening for AAA  especially in older patients with risk factors such as hypertension and hyperlipidemia  irrespective of gender. Further research is needed to understand AAA's gendered demographic disparities to improve screening and prevent complications.

Case Report: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information  A 74-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with acute-onset  severe abdominal pain. The patient reported the intensity of the pain as increasing rapidly within the span of several hours. The pain was centralized in the lower abdominal region and radiating to his back. Alongside  he also reported feeling lightheaded  with an episode of syncope just before arriving at the hospital.  Medical History  The patient's past medical history was significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a smoking history of 30 pack-years. He was on antihypertensive medicines (Lisinopril and Amlodipine) and a statin (Atorvastatin). However  he had been inconsistent on his medications and had poor compliance with follow-up medical appointments. He denied prior knowledge of the existence of an abdominal mass  decrease in appetite  or weight loss.  Family history was notable for cardiovascular diseases; both his father and older brother succceeded to a myocardial infarction in their late 60s. The patient  however  denied any previous surgical procedures or any known allergies.  Clinical Findings  Upon physical examination  the patient appeared in severe distress  was pale  diaphoretic  and had a fast but weak pulse. His blood pressure was 97/55 mmHg and his heart rate was 110 beats per minute.  Abdominal examination revealed a tender pulsatile mass in the midline of the abdomen that was not previously known. Urgent blood tests showed a hemoglobin level of 8.2 g/dL and a hematocrit of 24.8%  suggestive of potential internal bleeding.  Diagnosis  Intervention  and Outcome  Given the patient’s history  physical exam findings  and low hemoglobin  an emergent CT scan was carried out which confirmed the diagnosis of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA); 7.5 cm in diameter and involving the iliac arteries bilaterally.   The patient was immediately taken to the operating room where an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) was successfully performed. Post-operatively  he was managed in intensive care unit.   The immediate post-operative period was uneventful  and his condition improved steadily. He was subsequently transferred to a general ward and was discharged home one week later on adequate antihypertensives and statin therapy  with appointments scheduled for regular follow-up care.  Discussion  AAA is a common and catastrophic condition  with the incidence being particularly high among elderly males  smokers  and those with a history of cardiovascular disease  similar to this presented case. This case report illustrates prompt recognition and management of a ruptured AAA  even in patients with no prior diagnosis.  The risks associated with poor medical compliance are also highlighted  reminding of the pivotal role of medical follow-up and adherence to reduce complications related to chronic conditions such as hypertension and hyperlipidemia.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 70-Year-Old Caucasian Male: A Case Report  Case Presentation:  Mr. A.  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  was brought into the emergency department complaining of a sudden onset of severe pain in the middle of his abdomen that had started progressing towards his back. The patient’s vital signs included a blood pressure of 98/62 mmHg  heart rate of 110 bpm  respiratory rate of 22 breaths/minute  and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. He reported that the pain began after doing some heavy lifting in his garage earlier in the day.  Patient's History:  Mr. A. has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 30-pack year smoking history. He had quit smoking approximately 10 years prior to presentation. The patient's family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  as his father died of a stroke at the age of 74  and an elder brother had suffered from a heart attack at the age of 65. The patient was not on any regular medication except for occasional over-the-counter nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for arthritis pain.   Clinical Findings and Diagnostic Assessment:  On physical examination  a pulsatile mass was noted in the abdomen. Further investigation with a contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis showed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 7.5 cm in maximum diameter.   Treatment and Outcome:  Following the diagnosis  the patient was emergently transferred to the operating room for an open repair of the abdominal aortic aneurysm  bearing in mind his stable hemodynamic status. The patient tolerated the surgical procedure well. Post-operative recovery included vigilant monitoring in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) for two days before being transferred to a regular room. There was no record of post-surgical complications. After a week  he was discharged from the hospital with follow-up appointments scheduled with a vascular surgery specialist and advice to maintain his blood pressure and cholesterol levels.  Discussion:  This case illustrates the importance of considering large pulsatile abdominal masses with referred back pain as a potential sign of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  particularly in males over 65 years old with a history of smoking and hypertension. Early detection and prompt surgical repair can prevent the catastrophic consequence of arterial rupture and associated high mortality rates. This case also highlights the important preventative role of smoking cessation in such patients.  Bottom Line:  Abdominal aortic aneurysm is a severe condition largely prevalent in males over 65 years of age with a history of smoking  hypertension  and familial history of cardiovascular disease. A sudden-onset  severe abdominal pain should alert clinicians to this diagnosis as early detection and surgical intervention could be life-saving. The role of primary prevention  including targeting modifiable risk factors such as smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia and atherosclerosis  is crucial in preventing the development of this potentially fatal condition.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 72-Year-Old Male - Emphasizing the Diverse Manifestations and Diagnosis of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: A 72-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with complaints of a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain. The patient was 1.78 meters tall  weighed approximately 96 kg  and was generally physically active.  Clinical Findings: The pain originated in the lower central region of the abdomen and radiated towards the lower back. Physical examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the patient's abdomen  along with tachycardia  hypotension  and diaphoresis (profuse sweating).  Medical History: The patient has well-managed hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Additionally  the patient had a history of regular tobacco use  smoking 10-15 cigarettes daily for the past 30 years. He had a sedentary lifestyle and a diet rich in fats but has since put more effort into maintaining an active lifestyle and consumed a balanced diet. The patient's older sister also had a history of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Diagnostic Assessment: An urgent computed tomography (CT) scan was conducted revealing a large infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 6.2cm in diameter. An increase in size of the aneurysm was detected in comparison with the CT scan conducted for routine control  a year ago.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately transferred to the operating room  where open surgical repair of the abdominal aortic aneurysm was performed. The procedure was carried out without complications  a graft was inserted.   Follow-up and Outcomes: Postoperative follow-up was uneventful. The patient was discharged on the 7th postoperative day. At the follow-up visit  after 6 weeks  the patient reported being in good health and was readjusting to his routine life. Further surveillance will continue on a 6-month basis to monitor the graft and potential risk of endoleak.  Patient Perspective: Though initially apprehensive  the patient expressed relief upon successful surgery and was determined to amend his lifestyle further to prevent recurrence and enhance overall well-being.  Clinical Lessons: This case stresses the necessity of vigilance in patients presenting with sudden abdominal pain and a familial history of abdominal aortic aneurysms  even when they are displaying changes in their lifestyle and show general health improvements. Regular surveillance in patients with known abdominal aortic aneurysms is also crucial to detect any enlargement in the aneurysm in time. Furthermore  the role of cigarette smoking in the pathogenesis of abdominal aortic aneurysms must be addressed in the preventive strategies.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 65-year-old Caucasian Male: A Case Report  Introduction: The abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a potentially life-threatening condition  with a higher prevalence in men aged above 60  particularly in Caucasian ethnicities. This case report focuses on the diagnostics  treatment  and management of a 65-year-old Caucasian male diagnosed with AAA.  Case Presentation: A 65-year-old Caucasian male  a retired construction worker  presented to the emergency department with a complaint of progressive  severe lower abdominal and back pain of sudden onset. The patient described the severity of the pain as 8 on a scale of 1-10 with the pain spreading to his groin area. He stated his symptoms started unexpectedly while he was at rest at his home. The patient has smoked one pack of cigarettes per day for 35 years and has a history of hypertension  high cholesterol  coronary artery disease for which he had undergone angioplasty seven years back.   On physical examination  he was conscious  oriented  but exhibited signs of distress due to severe pain. His vitals were stable; pulse was 100 beats/min  blood pressure was 170/95 mm Hg  and breathing rate was 20 breaths/min. On inspection and palpation of the abdomen  a pulsatile mass was found in the periumbilical area that was tender on palpation. No bruit was heard on auscultation. Initial electrocardiogram (ECG) showed non-specific ST-T wave changes but no overt signs of ischemia or infarction.   Clinical Findings  Diagnostics  and Intervention: The initial suspicion of AAA was confirmed through Ultrasound which showed a large mass  approx. 7.5 cm in diameter at the level of the abdominal aorta. A subsequent computed tomography (CT) scan further confirmed the size and location of the aneurysm  suggesting that it was nearing rupture thus requiring immediate surgical intervention.  After receiving informed consent  the vascular surgical team performed an emergent endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). The postoperative period was uneventful  with the patient recovering steadily.   Follow-Up and prognosis: Post-surgery  the patient was enrolled in a smoking cessation program and advised to continue his medications for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. The patient will continue to have annual follow-up CT scans to monitor the graft and the size of the aneurysm. Long term prognosis in such cases largely depends on the patient's ability to quit smoking and manage his blood pressure and cholesterol levels.  Conclusion: This case emphasizes the importance of early recognition and treatment of AAA in high-risk individuals. The patient's history of smoking  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia combined with his age and ethnicity significantly increased his risk of AAA. Prompt diagnostic investigations and timely surgical intervention successfully manage this potentially life-threatening condition  providing the patient with a generally favorable prognosis.

Title: A Case Report on an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male with Hypertension and Diabetes Mellitus  Patient Presentation: Mr. C is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the emergency department with moderate to severe pain localized in the lower back and abdomen. The pain was previously tolerable but had intensified over the past six hours  prompting his visit to the emergency room. Mr. C described the pain as steady  with occasional sharp pains that seemed to radiate downwards to his left leg. He also complained of lightheadedness but no syncope  chest pain  or dyspnea. Mr. C is a former smoker with a 40 pack-year history  having quit 15 years prior to this presentation. He has a medical history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus  managed with lisinopril  hydrochlorothiazide  and metformin.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  Mr. C was awake  alert  and oriented but appeared in discomfort. He was afebrile with a blood pressure of 155/90 mmHg  a pulse rate of 96 beats per minute  and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. An abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the midline of the abdomen  and a bruit was audible over the area. There was no rebound tenderness or rigidity evident. Neurologic exam showed no focal deficits  and extremity examination revealed normal peripheral pulses.  Investigations: A computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis with intravenous contrast was ordered  which confirmed an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring approximately 6 cm. Lab results showed a slightly elevated white blood cell count  further raising suspicion for a leaking or rupturing AAA. Additional findings included an increased blood glucose level and moderate renal impairment likely secondary to his diagnosed hypertension and diabetes.  Treatment and Outcome: The cardiovascular surgery service was consulted  and Mr. C underwent emergency open repair of the AAA. Intraoperatively  a large infrarenal AAA was identified and successfully repaired with a prosthetic graft. The patient's postoperative course was complicated by a slow return of bowel function  but his recovery was eventually successful. Upon one-year follow-up  Mr. C’s graft repair remained intact without signs of endoleak or aneurysm growth.  Conclusion: This case underlines the importance of maintaining a high clinical suspicion for AAA in elderly males  particularly those with risk factors such as age  hypertension  and a history of smoking. Early detection and prompt intervention can significantly reduce the risk of rupture and associated mortality.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 70-Year-Old Male: Case Report and Review of the Literature  Patient Demographic: 70-year-old Caucasian male.  Presenting Complaint: The patient attended the Emergency Department with severe  sudden-onset  abdominal and lower back pain.  History of the presenting complaint: The patient described the pain as “tearing” and radiating to his back  beginning after he had lifted a heavy box at home. He hadn't experienced this type of pain before.  Background Medical History: The patient is a former smoker  quitting twenty years prior after 40-pack years. He has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  well-controlled with amlodipine and atorvastatin. The patient also had a previous history of coronary artery disease and had been managed with coronary artery bypass grafting 10 years ago. He is otherwise healthy  with no diagnoses of chronic lung disease  kidney disease  or diabetes.  Physical Examination: The patient was anxious  in pain  but conscious with stable vitals. His blood pressure was 132/88 mm Hg  heart rate 96 bpm  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation was 94% on room air. Abdomen was soft to touch  with the presence of a pulsating midline abdominal mass that was tender on palpation. Auscultation results were normal.   Investigations: Blood tests revealed slightly elevated inflammatory markers. Kidney function tests were within the normal range. A computed tomography (CT) angiogram of the abdomen revealed a large infra-renal aortic aneurysm measuring 8cm at its largest diameter with signs of rupture.  Management: The patient was immediately transferred to the vascular surgery department for an emergency open repair of the ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. The surgery was successful  with no major peri-operative issues.  Discussion: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm is relatively common in the elderly male population  particularly those with a history of smoking  hyperlipidemia  and hypertension. The typical presentation  as was evident in this case  is a classical triad of severe pain  hypotension  and a pulsatile abdominal mass. An early diagnosis and prompt surgical intervention can significantly increase survival rates  making it crucial for clinicians to have a high index of suspicion in high-risk patients presenting with abdominal or back pain.  Conclusion: This case underscores the importance of maintaining vigilance and swift action in the face of potential life-threatening conditions such as ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm  particularly in patients belonging to high-risk categories.

Title: Large Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 72-year-old Male  Introduction: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysms (AAA) are most frequently observed in white males aged 65-75 years old. This report describes a case of an elderly Hispanic male aged 72.  Demographic Information:  The patient is a 72-year-old Hispanic male  born and raised in Texas  USA. He is retired and lives with his wife. The patient has a history of smoking  with a 30 pack-year history. He quit smoking ten years prior.  Medical History: The patient has a past medical history of hypertension and Hypercholesterolemia. He had been taking Metoprolol and Atorvastatin respectively for these conditions. There is no significant family history of cardiovascular disease or aneurysms. He does not have any known drug allergies.  Presenting Complaints: The patient presented with a 2-week history of vague  intermittent abdominal pain which radiated to the back. He feels a throbbing sensation in his abdomen.  Clinical Findings: On abdominal examination  an expansile and pulsatile abdominal mass was palpable. Vitals were stable  and all systemic examinations were within normal limits.  Diagnostic Assessment: Abdominal Ultrasonography demonstrated the presence of an Abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring about 6 cm in diameter. Computed Tomography Angiogram (CTA) of the abdomen and pelvis was then conducted which confirmed the presence of an infra-renal AAA  with a diameter of 5.8 cm.  Therapeutic Intervention: Due to the size of aneurysm and the patient’s symptoms  endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) was advised and performed by a vascular surgery team successfully. Patient tolerated the procedure well  and was discharged a few days later on appropriate medications with advice to cease smoking as part of lifestyle modification.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Close follow-ups post-surgery were maintained. On a 2-month follow up visit  CTA showed successful exclusion of the aneurysm with no evidence of endoleak. Patient's symptoms had completely resolved. He was a part of smoking cessation program and reports no smoking since discharge.  Discussion: This case illustrates that despite the higher prevalence of AAA in white males  Hispanic males are also affected and doctors need to be aware of this demographic. Further  this case underlines the importance of vigilant detection of AAA in elderly males presenting with unexplained  vague abdominal or back pain. Early detection and treatment can help prevent complications  such as AAA rupture  which carries a high risk of mortality.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information:   Mr. John Doe is a 72-year-old Caucasian male from an urban community in Florida. He is a retired plumber and has lived a sedentary lifestyle for the last 14 years of his retirement. He is a former smoker  having quit smoking well over 20 years ago. His alcohol intake is minimal  approximately one glass of wine per week.   Medical History:   Mr. Doe has had a history of hypertension and high cholesterol for which he has been prescribed Lisinopril 20 mg and Atorvastatin 40 mg daily. He has been managing these conditions relatively well with the help of medication and annual check-ups. Apart from these  he has been treated for type 2 diabetes mellitus for the last ten years  managed with oral Metformin 1000 mg daily and dietary modifications. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died at age 80 due to a myocardial infarction.  Present Illness:  Mr. Doe initially visited his primary care physician complaining of a noticeable pulse in his abdomen along with lower back pain for the past few weeks. As these symptoms persisted with increasing severity  he was referred for an abdominal ultrasound.  Investigations:  The abdominal ultrasound showed a 5.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aorta with a mural thrombus. A subsequent computed tomography (CT) angiography declered the presence of an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring 5.6 cm in diameter with partial mural thrombus.  Impression and Plan:  A diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm was made  putting the patient at risk for rupture due to the diameter of the aneurysm. After a detailed discussion about the risks and benefits  he was referred to a vascular surgeon for possible repair. The patient agreed to undergo an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). Postoperative recovery was uneventful  and the graft was patent on a 1-month postoperative ultrasound.  Follow-up:  Mr. Doe will be followed over time with periodic ultrasound imaging to ensure that the graft remains patent and the aneurysm does not expand. He is also advised to maintain control of his diabetes  hypertension  and cholesterol as these are risk factors that could lead to the expansion of the aorta.  This report indicates that a high level of vigilance is required in patients with known risk factors such as hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  diabetes  advanced age  and family history of vascular disease to diagnose AAA and treat it accordingly to prevent catastrophic sequelae like aortic rupture.

Title: An Elderly Male with Asymptomatic Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm: A Case Report  Patient Presentation  Mr. J.C  72-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the outpatient department of our hospital for a routine health check-up. He lives independently and his only notable lifestyle behavior includes smoking for the past 50 years (20 cigarettes/day). He denied any symptoms such as back pain  abdominal pain  unintentional weight loss  gastrointestinal problems  or changes in bowel habits.  Past Medical History  The patient’s past medical history revealed no significant abnormalities. He was diagnosed with essential hypertension and hyperlipidemia about 10 years ago  for which he's on prescribed medication: Amlodipine (5mg/day) to manage blood pressure levels and Atorvastatin (20mg/day) to control cholesterol levels. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease – his father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 80.  Clinical Examination  On clinical examination  the patient appeared in good health. His vital signs were stable  and physical examination was unremarkable  except for a pulsatile abdominal mass felt on deep palpation of the abdomen. There was no tenderness  guarding  or rigidity noted.  Investigations  Given the patient’s clinical features and the finding of a pulsatile mass  an abdominal ultrasound was ordered. The ultrasound revealed a dilated abdominal aorta measuring 6.2 cm in maximum diameter  indicative of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   A computed tomography angiogram also confirmed the presence of an AAA with intraluminal thrombus and no signs of rupture. Peripheral pulses were present and comparable bilateral lower extremities. Complete blood counts  renal function tests  and serum electrolytes were within normal limits. The fasting lipid profile showed raised LDL cholesterol levels (180 mg/dL).  Management  Given the size of the aneurysm and the risk of rupture  referral to a vascular surgeon for possible elective repair of the aneurysm was made. The patient underwent elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) without any complications.   To optimize cardiovascular health  lifestyle counseling regarding smoking cessation and cardiac risk factor management was done. The Atorvastatin dose was increased to 40 mg/day  considering his raised LDL cholesterol level.  Follow-Up  At his 3-month follow-up visit  the patient reported no postoperative complications and expressed relief over having undergone the procedure. His LDL cholesterol level had dropped to 100 mg/dL  indicating good adherence to medication.  Conclusion  This case highlights the importance of routine health check-ups in elderly patients  especially those with cardiovascular risk factors  to timely diagnose and manage potentially fatal conditions like AAA.   It also emphasizes the crucial role of lifestyle modifications and control of cardiovascular risk factors in patients diagnosed with AAA.

Patient Information: The case presents a 73-year-old African-American male  with a past medical history significant for hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  a 45-pack-year history of smoking  although he quit 10 years ago  and a sedentary lifestyle. He has no known drug allergies  lives alone  is a retired engineer  and is a widower with two adult children. He has never been diagnosed or treated for any cardiovascular disease before.  Chief Complaint: The patient presented at the clinic with complaints of episodic abdominal pain and back pain that he has been experiencing for about two weeks. He described the pain intensity as mild to moderate  without radiation and slightly relieved when he bends forward. He denies any loss of consciousness  history of trauma  fever  night sweats  weight loss  lower limb weakness  or changes in bowel and bladder function. No gastrointestinal or genitourinary symptoms were reported.   Clinical Findings: Physical examination showed an obese man in no apparent distress  with stable vital signs: blood pressure of 132/84 mmHg  pulse rate 86 beats per minute  respiratory rate 18 breaths per minute  and temperature 98.2°F. He had a pulsating mass in the midline of his abdomen  just above the umbilicus. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable. His BMI calculation revealed a value of 31.4 kg/m^2.  Diagnosis: A deeper investigation into the patient’s symptoms was conducted  including lab samples for full blood count  renal function tests  and cardiac markers  all of which returned as normal within reference ranges. An abdominal ultrasound displayed a 5.3 cm infrarenal aortic aneurysm. A subsequent CT angiography confirmed the presence of a 5.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm  with no signs of rupture or dissection. The patient was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Therapeutic Intervention: Given the size of the aneurysm (5.5 cm) and the potential risk of rupture  the patient was referred to a vascular surgeon. After discussing the surgical and non-surgical options with the patient and his family  he elected to undergo an elective open aneurysm repair operation.  Follow-up and Outcome: The patient tolerated the procedure well and was discharged on the fifth postoperative day in stable condition. He was advised to quit smoking  engage in regular exercise  eat a heart-healthy diet  and maintain continuous control of his blood pressure and cholesterol levels. He was provided with a follow-up appointment with the vascular surgery team in one month to check his recovery and the status of the AAA repair. Long-term follow-up would involve monitoring with regular physical examinations and ultrasonographic check-ups to ensure there's no aneurysm recurrence.  Patient Perspective: The patient recognized he had been ignoring some signs of the disease for a while. However  having undergone successful intervention and been enlightened on the management and potential severe outcomes of his condition  he expressed appreciation for the treatment he received and regretted not seeking medical attention earlier.  Informed Consent: Informed consent was received from the patient for publication of the case details.

Title: Case Report - An Unusual Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Caucasian Female  Introduction:  Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) often presents silent until rupturing  making it a leading cause of death among the elderly population. It is most commonly seen in Caucasian males over 65 with a history of smoking  hypertension  and coronary artery disease. This report presents a rare case of AAA in an elderly Caucasian female with diabetes mellitus and a history of smoking.  Case Presentation: Ms. F  a 76-year-old Caucasian female  presented to the emergency room with severe lower abdominal and lumbar pain that had persisted for the past 48 hours. The patient described the pain as sharp  constant  and radiating to her lower back.  Ms. F has a significant history of diabetes mellitus type 2 controlled with Metformin  hypertension treated with Losartan  and a 30-pack year history of smoking that she quit 10 years ago. She has no family history of AAA. The patient claimed compliance with medications and denied any recent trauma  gastrointestinal complaints  chest pain  shortness of breath  or lower limb weakness. On physical examinations  the patient appeared anxious but was hemodynamically stable. Examination of her heart and lungs was unremarkable.  Abdominal examination revealed a palpable mass which was tender and pulsatile in the epigastric region. The remainder of the physical examination was normal.   Laboratory investigations were ordered  and while her hemoglobin was slightly reduced (11.5g/dl)  other standard blood tests  including markers for myocardial infarction (troponin I)  urea  creatinine  electrolytes  and liver function  were within normal limits.  An urgent computed tomography angiography (CTA) scan was ordered based on the presenting symptoms and physical examination findings. The CTA scan revealed a 7cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm  which was not ruptured but was in imminent risk of rupture.  The patient was promptly admitted in the ICU  given that the size of the AAA was above the threshold for intervention (5.5cm for males  unknown for females). She was medically optimized and then underwent successful endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). Postoperative recovery was uneventful  and the patient was discharged on the 8th postoperative day with timely follow-up appointments.  Conclusions: This case illustrates an unusual presentation of AAA in a female patient who is  based on epidemiological data  not in the typical demographic group. Although AAA is more common in males  clinicians should be vigilant and consider this diagnosis in females with suggestive symptoms and signs  especially with risk factors like smoking and hypertension. It also reinforces the value of physical examination  which prompted an urgent CTA that revealed the aneurysm. This report advocates for consideration of AAA in the differential diagnosis of abdominal and lumbar pain in the elderly population  irrespective of gender.

Title: A Case Report: An Elderly Male Diagnosed with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Demographic Information:  The patient is an 80-year-old Caucasian male who lives in an assisted living community in the United States. He is a retired mechanical engineer  a widower  with two adult children. He is an ex-smoker  having quit 10 years ago after a 40-year smoking history  and he drinks alcohol occasionally.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of ischemic heart disease  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  currently under medication. He underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) 12 years ago. The patient also had a hernia repair 6 years ago  and maintains a daily low-impact exercise regimen.  Presenting Complaint:  He had been experiencing progressive and intermittent abdominal discomfort and pain in the mid to lower abdomen for several weeks. More recently  his pain was accompanied by occasional lightheadedness and unease. He denied any present symptoms of fever  malaise  appetite changes  or weight loss. No previous episodes of similar symptoms were reported.  Clinical Assessment:  The patient was hemodynamically stable on presentation. Physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass upon palpation. No signs of peritoneal irritation were observed. Routine blood investigations were normal.  Radiological Findings:  A Computerized Tomography Angiography (CTA) of the abdomen was requested which demonstrated an infrarenal aortic aneurysm of 5.6 cm in the greatest transverse diameter. No evidence of rupture or dissection was detected.  Diagnosis:  Based on the clinical history  physical examination  and radiological findings  the patient was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Management and Outcome:  The patient was admitted for careful monitoring in a vascular surgery unit. Given the advanced age  comorbid conditions  and size of the aneurysm  the multidisciplinary team decided to proceed with an elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). The patient tolerated the procedure well and made an uneventful recovery. He was discharged on postoperative day three. At the one-month postoperative follow up  he was asymptomatic  and ultrasound demonstrated no endoleak.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of high suspicion and early detection of abdominal aortic aneurysm  especially in elderly patients with risk factors and vague abdominal symptoms. Prompt multidisciplinary management can significantly improve the prognosis in these patients.  Disclaimer: This case report is inspired by real clinical scenarios but contains fictional aspects for teaching purposes. It serves to emphasize important points in clinical diagnosis and management.

Title: Management of an Asymptomatic Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Patient  Patient Information:   The patient is a 75-year-old Caucasian male who had arrived at our healthcare facility for a routine post-prostatectomy follow-up. He is a non-smoker  normotensive  and does not have diabetes. His past medical record revealed a history of benign prostatic hyperplasia for which he underwent transurethral prostatectomy six months ago  along with controlled hypertension under medication for the past 10 years. He has no known drug allergies.  Clinical Findings:   At this visit  he had no complaints  but his abdominal examination was suspicious as a pulsatile mass was palpable in the periumbilical area. A subsequent ultrasound and computed tomography scan confirmed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 6.5 cm in maximum diameter. The patient had mild elevation in serum creatinine level (1.5 mg/dL)  suggesting slightly impaired renal function.  Timeline:   Post prostatectomy follow-up visit: Identification of pulsatile mass. 1 week later: Ultrasound and CT scan performed  confirming an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Diagnostic Assessment:   The diagnosis was established through a combination of physical examination and imaging studies  which included ultrasound and computed tomography scan. Further tests  including full blood count  electrolyte panel  and a coagulation panel  were all within normal limits  except for an elevation in serum creatinine level.  Treatment and Outcome:  Considering the patient's age  comorbid conditions  and size of aneurysm  he was recommended for an elective endovascular aortic repair (EVAR). The procedure was carried out without any complications. His postoperative recovery was uneventful. He was discharged 72 hours post-procedure. On subsequent follow-ups at 1 month  3 months  6 months and 1 year  ultrasound showed no signs of aneurysm expansion or endoleak. His renal function also remained stable.  Patient Perspective:  The patient initially had reservations regarding the surgery due to concerns related to his age and recovery. However  after understanding the potential risks of rupture and fatal hemorrhage  he consented to undergo EVAR.  Informed Consent:  An informed consent was obtained from the patient prior to EVAR.  Learning Points:  This case highlights the importance of regular physical examinations  even in asymptomatic patients. Abdominal aortic aneurysms are often silent until rupture  therefore early recognition is crucial. This case also underscores the utility of EVAR in elderly patients  showing satisfactory results and a stable postoperative course. Comprehensive post-procedure follow-up is crucial for early detection and management of potential complications.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 70-year-old Male  Patient Information  A 70-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with a complaint of sudden  severe abdominal pain that radiated to his lower back. The patient described the pain as a sharp  “tearing” sensation. He mentioned no recent trauma to the area. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension  a 30 pack-year smoking history  and a family history of cardiovascular disease. His medications include Lisinopril for high blood pressure and a daily aspirin.  Clinical Findings Physical examination revealed a pulse rate of 100 beats per minute  blood pressure of 160/90 mmHg  and respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. He was afebrile. The patient appeared anxious and uncomfortable. His abdomen was slightly distended with a palpable pulsatile mass in the mid-abdominal region. Neurological examination was normal. Auscultation revealed no positive findings.  Diagnostic Assessment A computed tomography (CT) angiogram was ordered and revealed a 5.5cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. Lab work including a complete blood count  biochemical profile  and coagulation profile were within normal limits. An electrocardiogram was done due to the risk of cardiovascular disease and did not show any signs of acute myocardial infarction.  Therapeutic Intervention Expecting rupture  the patient was immediately scheduled for an emergency endovascular aneurysm repair in consideration of his age and the size of the aneurysm according to the guidelines established by the Society for Vascular Surgery. The surgery was successful and the patient was prescribed antioxidants  statins and beta-blockers postoperatively to manage his blood pressure and risk factors.  Follow-Up and Outcome  The postoperative period was stable and the patient was discharged five days post-treatment with follow-up scheduled in one month. At the one-month follow-up  the patient reported a significant reduction in his abdominal pain. A CT scan showed successful sealing of the aneurysm with no endoleaks.  Patient Perspective The patient acknowledged his longtime smoking habit as a likely factor in developing an aneurysm and showed commitment to quit smoking. He was grateful for the early detection and treatment  which likely saved his life.  Teaching Points  This case illustrates the importance of considering an abdominal aortic aneurysm in elderly patients  particularly males with a history of smoking and hypertension  who present with sudden-onset severe abdominal pain. Early diagnosis and treatment can significantly reduce the risk of rupture  which carries a high mortality rate.  Authors: [Your Name]  MD Department of General Surgery [Your Institution's Name]
