Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male Patient – A Case Report  Introduction: Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) occurs predominantly in the older population  being more common in males above 65 years. Despite advancements in surgical strategies  the mortality rate in cases of ruptured AAA remains significantly high.  Case Presentation: We present a case of a 76-year-old Caucasian male who was diagnosed with a ruptured AAA. The patient lives in Beaufort  South Carolina  USA. He has a past medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50-pack-year smoking history  but no prior history of cardiovascular disease or any surgical interventions.  The patient presented to the emergency department with a 6-hour history of severe  sharp  constant pain in the center of the abdomen radiating to the back. He also reported associated symptoms of lightheadedness  nausea  and diaphoresis. He denied chest pain  shortness of breath  or bowel or urinary changes. He lives with his wife and was independent in activities of daily living prior to this event.  On physical examination  the patient was anxious and diaphoretic with a pulse rate of 110 beats per minute and blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg. An abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass with a diameter of approximately 6 cm in the peri-umbilical area. Lower extremities showed no signs of ischemia.  Laboratory investigations showed hemoglobin of 10.2 g/dL  a slightly elevated white blood cell count at 12 x 10^3/µL  and elevated serum creatinine at 1.8 mg/dl indicating kidney impairment. The patient was immediately taken for a CT scan which revealed a 6.5 cm infrarenal AAA with signs of rupture into the retroperitoneal space.  The patient was rushed to the operating room for an emergent open surgical repair of the ruptured AAA. Postoperatively  he was managed in the intensive care unit. Despite a period of hemodynamic instability and renal impairment  the patient showed gradual improvement in overall health and was discharged after 20 days of hospital stay.  Discussion: This case reiterates the severe consequences of an unrecognized AAA. It further highlights the crucial role of early diagnosis and prompt surgical intervention  which can dramatically affect the outcome. Therefore  the assessment of AAA should always be considered in older adults presenting with abdominal or back pain  particularly in those with a history of smoking or hypertension.  Conclusion: With the high risk of rupture and mortality associated with AAA  high-risk individuals must be offered surveillance and timely intervention. Dissemination of knowledge about the risk factors and symptoms associated with AAA to primary care providers can increase recognition and improve outcomes for this patient population.

Title: Emergency Repair of Symptomatic Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm: A Case Report  Introduction:  This report presents a clinical case of an 80-year-old Caucasian male diagnosed with a symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  a relatively common condition affecting up to 10% of males over 65 years. Though AAAs are often asymptomatic  they may lead to life-threatening scenarios when ruptured. This case demonstrates the importance of swift detection  diagnosis  and timely surgical intervention to manage this potentially fatal condition.  Case Presentation:  Mr. A  an 80-year-old Caucasian male  with a prior history of hypertension  presented to the emergency department with complaints of severe abdominal pain of sudden onset. The patient was a retired industrial worker  lived alone  and followed up regularly for hypertension for the past 20 years. He was a former smoker with a 30 pack-year smoking history. He had no known allergies  family history of AAA  or genitourinary problems.   On examination  Mr. A appeared in acute distress with a pallor and a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the umbilical area  with tenderness on deep palpation. Techniques like percussion and auscultation also led to a presumptive diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  The patient was quickly stabilized with intravenous fluids  after which a contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan confirmed the diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The AAA measured 8 cm at its largest diameter  providing an explanation for the patient's abdominal pain.   Management and Outcome:  In light of the symptomatic presentation  the patient underwent emergency open surgical repair of the aneurysm. The procedure involved replacing the diseased part of the aorta with a synthetic Dacron graft. Post-surgery  the patient’s recovery was uneventful.   The patient remained stable hemodynamically and was discharged on the 10th postoperative day. He was prescribed blood pressure medications and a statin for secondary prevention of cardiovascular events. At a 6-month follow-up visit in the clinic  Mr. A was doing well and had no further episodes of severe abdominal pain.    Discussion:  This case signifies the importance of prompt diagnosis and referral for AAAs  especially in older males with risk factors such as hypertension and a history of smoking. Given the large ratio of asymptomatic versus symptomatic patients  AAA often remains a silent killer. It further underscores the importance of AAA screening programs and prompt surgical intervention for large or symptomatic AAAs.  Patient Consent:  Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report and any accompanying images.    Conflicts of Interest:  The authors declare that they have no conflicts of interest.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 70-year-old Caucasian Male: A Case Report  Abstract:  This case report illustrates a 70-year-old Caucasian male with past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia who presented with a clinically significant  asymptomatic  infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Case Presentation:  Mr. A  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  who is a retired teacher  reported to his physician's office for a routine wellness check. He has been living in rural Kansas. He has a history of well-controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia managed with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin respectively. He is an ex-smoker  having quit 10 years ago  after a 40 pack-year history. His alcohol usage is occasional and his family history is notable for a brother who had an AAA repaired at age 75.   On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was evident upon palpation. Due to this  the physician ordered an abdominal ultrasound which revealed an infrarenal AAA measuring 5.6 cm. Despite the large size of the aneurysm  Mr. A reported no abdominal or back pain or any other symptoms indicative of AAA. Additionally  urinalysis  complete blood count  liver function test  serum electrolytes  chest X-ray  and EKG results were all within normal limits.   Due to the size of the AAA and his family history  Mr. A was referred to a vascular surgeon where an elective surgical repair was scheduled. The surgery was uncomplicated and performed through the use of an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  rather than open surgery  due to the patient's advanced age and overall health status. The patient was monitored in hospital for a week and discharged with outpatient follow-up scheduled with his vascular surgeon  as well as continued management of his hypertension and hyperlipidemia with his primary care doctor.   Discussion:  Abdominal aortic aneurysms are commonly found in older Caucasian males with a history of smoking  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia. Our patient falls into this high-risk demographic. Though the AAA was unexpectedly detected in an asymptomatic patient  the large size of the aneurysm required surgical intervention. Prompt detection and treatment most likely prevented the serious and often fatal complication of rupture. This case emphasizes the importance of routine physical examination and vigilant follow-up in high-risk patients such as Caucasian males aged 65-75 years with a history of smoking.   Conclusion:  Having taken into account the patient's age  comorbidities and the significant size of the aneurysm  an elective EVAR procedure was done successfully. This case underscores the importance of well-directed assessment and intervention in preventing life-threatening complications. It also emphasizes the effectiveness of EVAR in the management of AAA in the elderly.

Title: A Case of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-Year-Old Male with Comorbid Hypertension  Introduction:  This report describes a case of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in a 68-year-old Caucasian male who was diagnosed incidentally during imaging for an unrelated medical issue.   Case Description:  The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male presenting with a known case of hypertension and a history of smoking. He reports intermittent episodes of lower back pain  discomfort  and vague abdominal pain. The patient is not a known diabetic  and there has been no reported past history of any cardiovascular disease or stroke. He has been on hypertension therapy for the last 7 years. The patient is a non-drinker and has a 25-year history of smoking  recently quitting 3 years ago on his physician's advice. He has no known allergies.   Upon visiting a gastroenterologist for a routine check-up due to occasional dyspepsia  an upper abdominal ultrasound was performed which incidentally detected an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.3 cm in diameter. The incidental finding led to a referral to a vascular surgeon.  Physical Examination:  Overall  the patient appeared physically healthy  with normal vitals recorded at the time of examination. Auscultation of the abdomen revealed continuous bruit over the periumbilical region. There was no notable abdominal tenderness on palpation.   Diagnostic Assessment:  A Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) was subsequently done  substantiating the ultrasound findings and revealing an infrarenal AAA measuring 5.3 cm in diameter without any sign of rupture. The relationship between the aneurysm and the renal arteries was well defined  and no iliac artery aneurysms were detected.  Management and Outcome:  Due to the substantial size of the aneurysm  the patient was counseled for elective surgical repair to prevent fatal rupture. After shared decision making  the patient agreed to have an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR).   The postoperative period was uneventful  and the patient was discharged on postoperative day 5. At 3-month and 6-month follow-up visits  CT scans showed no endoleak or aneurysm expansion and the patient reported a significant reduction in his symptoms.  Conclusion:  This case illustrates the incidental detection of AAA in a patient with known modifiable risk factors such as hypertension and a history of smoking. Endovascular repair provided a good outcome in our patient  highlighting the importance of vigilant screening and management in at-risk populations.   Author's Notes:  This case report underscores the need for AAA screening amongst elderly Caucasian males  particularly in individuals with hypertension and a previous or current smoking habit. Early detection can lead to interventions that may prevent serious sequelae like aneurysm rupture.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male  Patient Information: The patient is a 74-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for essential hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago. His mother had a history of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Chief Complaint: The patient presented in the Emergency Department complaining of a sudden onset severe abdominal pain radiating to his back since a couple of hours ago. The pain was described as sharp  continuous  and worsening.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  an abdominal mass was palpable which was pulsatile in nature. His blood pressure was recorded as 160/90 mmHg and his heart rate as 80 beats per minute. The rest of the cardiovascular examination was unremarkable. His body temperature was 37.1 ˚C and oxygen saturation was 98% on room air.  Diagnostic Assessment: Initial laboratory findings showed mild leukocytosis. The electrocardiogram and chest X-ray did not show any significant abnormalities. Given the history and physical examination findings  an urgent abdominal ultrasonography was performed  revealing a 5.6 cm aneurysm in the abdominal aorta. A subsequent computed tomography angiogram confirmed a large AAA with evidence of imminent rupture but without active extravasation.  Therapeutic Intervention: An emergency laparotomy and open aneurysm repair was performed by the vascular surgery team. The patient received a Dacron tube graft. No complications were encountered during the surgery.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: Postoperatively  the patient recovered well  without any complications. He was discharged on postoperative day 6. On follow-up visits at 1 month and again at 6 months  a physical examination and ultrasonography found no evidence of graft complications or new aneurysm development. The patient is being monitored annually and is counseled regularly about the importance of blood pressure and cholesterol management.  Patient Perspective: The patient was initially shocked about his diagnosis but was relieved after successful surgery. He expressed gratitude for the effective management of his condition and committed to follow up and lifestyle modifications.   Discussion: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm is a pathologic dilatation of the aorta with a high risk of rupture that increases with the diameter. The risk factors include age above 60  male sex  smoking  hypertension  and family history. This case highlights the importance of a high degree of suspicion in elderly males with sudden onset severe abdominal pain  especially with a history of risk factors  for early diagnosis and effective treatment of this life-threatening condition.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in An Asian Female: A Case Report  Demographics: The patient  Ms. J  is a 75-year-old Asian woman from a suburban area. She lives alone  is a retired schoolteacher  and isn’t known to be taking any regular medication. She is a non-smoker and consumes alcohol moderately. Her BMI is 22.5 kg/m2.  Past Medical History: Up until the present complaint  Ms. J reported enjoying good health with no history of hypertension  diabetes mellitus  cardiovascular disease  or relevant family history. She has never smoked  drinks moderately  and did not have any surgical history.   Presenting Complaint: Ms. J was brought to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain extending to her back and was faint on arrival. She described the pain as sharp  constant  and the worst she has ever experienced in her life. The pain was not clustered around any particular meal. There were no associated symptoms like vomiting  constipation  urine abnormalities  fever  or weight loss.  Investigation and Diagnosis: A clinical examination demonstrated central abdominal tenderness and a palpable pulsatile mass. Her blood pressure was found to be 90/50 mmHg  heart rate 110bpm and a hemoglobin level of 9.0 g/dL suggestive of hypovolemia. An emergency CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis was conducted which revealed a 7 cm infrarenal AAA with signs of rupture and retroperitoneal hematoma. The diagnosis of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (rAAA) was made.  Management: She was promptly transferred to the operating theatre for an emergency open repair of the rAAA due to her instability. A tube graft repair was performed.  Outcome: Emergent surgery was successful with intraoperative transfusion of 4 units of packed red blood cells. Post-operative recovery was complicated by acute kidney injury  which required temporary dialysis but gradually resolved. She was discharged after 14-day post-operation once she regained her renal function.  Conclusion:  This case illustrates the importance of suspecting and diagnosing rAAA even in patients without typical demographic factors and risk elements of rAAA like smoking  male gender and Caucasian ethnicity. Ms. J  being an Asian woman  falls into a lower-risk category  suggesting the necessity for broadened vigilance to all patient demographics for early detection and management of this often-fatal condition.

Title: A case report of an abdominal aortic aneurysm in an elderly patient  Case Presentation:  A 72-year-old African American male patient presents to the emergency department with complaints of severe and persistent abdominal pain radiating to his back. He has a past medical history of moderate-to-severe hypertension  dyslipidemia  and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He’s a current smoker of 1 pack per day for the past 40 years and has a family history of cardiovascular disease. The patient denies any previous similar episodes or known abdominal pathology. He has no history of surgery  travel  and drug allergies. The patient leads a sedentary lifestyle and admits that his diet is high in fat and sodium. He also has an occasional binge drinking behavior.  Clinical Findings:  Physical examination reveals a distended abdomen with a palpable pulsatile mass in the mid-abdomen. The patient's vitals were stable  except for a slightly increased heart rate (tachycardia) of 110 beats per minute. Laboratory findings showed a slightly elevated complete blood count in reaction to stress  and normal kidney and liver function tests.   Diagnostic Assessment:  Abdominal ultrasonography was requested and showed a large  6.5 cm aneurysm with mural thrombus in the abdominal aorta. Further imaging  specifically a CT Angiogram  confirmed the diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  located 3cm below the renal arteries.   Therapeutic Intervention:  Due to the patient's age and the size of the aneurysm  surgical intervention was recommended. After administering required preoperative care  the patient underwent open surgical repair of the abdominal aortic aneurysm. A Dacron graft was used to replace the affected section of the aorta. The procedure was successful and without intraoperative complications.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  The patient’s postoperative period was uncomplicated  and he was discharged after a week. He was provided with education for lifestyle modification  medication regimen (antihypertensives  statins  and antiplatelets) and trained for the early identification of potential future complications. Follow-up at 1  3  and 6 months showed no signs of aneurysm recurrence or post-surgery complications  and the patient reported adherence to prescribed medications and lifestyle changes.  Patient Perspective:  The patient expressed relief from the constant pain he suffered and showed understanding of the necessity of lifestyle changes and regular monitoring.  Informed Consent:  Informed consent was obtained from the patient for writing this case report.  This case underlines the importance of regular primary healthcare check-ups in high-risk population groups  such as elderly African American males with a history of cardiovascular disease  smoking  and unhealthy lifestyle habits. Early detection of AAA is key to managing and preventing serious complications  reducing morbidity and mortality rates associated with this condition.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 67-year-old Male Patient: A Case Report  Patient Presentation:  Mr. X is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  retired car mechanic  resident of Sacramento  California who was referred to our vascular clinic for evaluation of persistent dull pain in the lower back and a pulsating feeling in his abdominal area  both symptoms gradually intensifying over 4 months. Mr. X reports limited physical activity due to occasional difficulty in walking. He denies any history of recent trauma or injury. The patient is smoker with a 40-year smoking history of approximately 20 cigarettes a day. He admits to occasional alcohol consumption. His diet is mainly composed of processed and fast foods with minimal intake of fruits and vegetables.  Past Medical History:  Mr. X has a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia and was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD) 5 years ago. He is currently on antihypertensive medications  beta blockers and statins. He does not have a personal or family history of aneurysms. Maternal grandfather died of myocardial infarction at the age of 72. Mr. X is presently living alone  divorced  with two grown-up children.  Clinical Findings:  On physical assessment  the patient presents with moderate obesity with body-mass index (BMI) of 30.8 kg/m2. Abdominal examination reveals a palpable mass in the mid-abdominal region with noticeable pulsations. Blood pressure is moderately high at 155/95 mmHg. Lab tests show mild anemia and elevated cholesterol levels.   Diagnosis  Suspicion for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) led to an Abdominal Ultrasound followed by CT Angiography. The results showed a dilation of the infrarenal aorta with the largest diameter measuring 5.4cm  confirming the AAA diagnosis.   Treatment:  Given Mr. X's age  medical history  size  and symptoms of the aneurysm  endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) is proposed as the treatment of choice. Mr. X was counselled about the surgery and the potential complications  which he understood and consented to.   Conclusion:  This case illustrates a typical instance of AAA in a patient with established cardiovascular risk factors  particularly smoking  hyperlipidemia  and hypertension. Early identification with appropriate imaging and timely-adopted interventional treatment are necessary for positive health outcomes considering the fatal consequences of a ruptured AAA. Tobacco cessation and better control of hypertension and cholesterol are also essential for reducing the risk of AAA progression.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 70-Year-old Male with a History of Hypertension.  Patient Profile: The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  residing in New York. He is married with two adult children. He presented with a history of smoking  weighing around 210 lb with a height of 6’2"". He is not a regular drinker and has no known allergies.   Medical History: His past medical history is significant for hypertension  diagnosed ten years ago  for which he is currently taking Lisinopril 20mg daily. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia  which is being managed with Atorvastatin 40mg daily. There is no history of diabetes  cardiac diseases  congenital disorders or kidney diseases. His father died at the age of 75 due to an ischemic stroke.  Presenting complaint and Examination: The patient presented with an initial complaint of episodic abdominal and back pain for a week  which had increased in intensity over the last 24 hours. On examination  the patient looked comfortable at rest  but was apprehensive due to the unrelenting pain. His blood pressure was 150/88 mmHg  heart rate 85 beats per minute  and respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute. On physical examination  palpable pulsating mass was noticed in the abdomen.  Investigations and Diagnosis: A full blood count  liver and kidney function tests  lipid profile  and clotting studies were conducted; the results fell within normal limits. An ultrasound of the abdominal aorta suggested an aneurysm  which was confirmed by an abdominal computed tomography (CT) angiogram. The CT showed an infrarenal aortic aneurysm of 6.5 cm.  Treatment & Follow up: The patient was admitted to the vascular surgery department and extirpation of the Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) with a grafting procedure was performed. The patient tolerated the procedure well  and the recovery was uneventful. He was discharged on the sixth day post operation. The patient was provided with lifestyle modification advice  including smoking cessation  balanced low-salt diet  regular physical activity  maintaining optimal body weight  and regularly taking prescribed medications to manage his hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has been requested to follow up with vascular surgery clinic every 3 months for the first year  then annually thereafter.  Conclusion: This case underscores the importance of taking the complete history and conducting a thorough examination in elderly patients with hypertension who present with complaints of abdominal and lower back pain. Early diagnosis and appropriate referral for management can significantly improve patient outcomes in cases of AAA.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-year-old Caucasian Male: A Case Report  Introduction: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) is a pathological condition characterized by localized dilatation of the abdominal aorta exceeding the normal diameter by more than 50%. It typically occurs in males over 65 years of age predominantly of Caucasian ethnicity.  Case Presentation: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and former tobacco usage. He has been being treated for these conditions with antihypertensives and statins for over 20 years. He has a 40-pack-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. He doesn't have a family history of AAA.  The patient presented to the emergency department with a complaint of severe  sudden-onset pain in the back and the abdominal region  which he described as 'tearing' in nature. He denied any related symptoms such as fever  weight loss  loss of appetite  nausea  vomiting  changes in bowel habits  or hematuria.  Physical examination revealed a pulsatile mass detectable in the abdominal area  but no signs of peripheral embolization. Blood pressure monitoring indicated hypertension with a reading of 170/90 mmHg.  Investigations: Following the suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  an ultrasound was promptly conducted  revealing a 7.2cm infrarenal AAA. Confirmative CT angiography demonstrated a saccular aneurysm of the abdominal aorta  with the largest diameter being 7.9 cm below the renal arteries  without signs of rupture.  Treatment: Given the extent of AAA revealed in diagnostic imaging and symptomatic presentation  the patient was offered an emergent open surgical repair to prevent rupture. During surgery  a tube graft was placed to replace the dilated segment of the aorta.  Post-Operative Course: Post-operative recovery was uneventful. The patient was closely monitored in the intensive care unit for two days then moved to the vascular surgery ward where he engaged in physical therapy. After a hospital stay of 12 days  the patient was discharged in a stable condition. He has regular follow-ups and continuing medical therapy for his hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Discussion: This case exemplifies the typical demographics and risk profile for AAA - an elderly  Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and significant tobacco use. It highlights the critical role of early recognition of this potentially life-threatening vascular condition and prompt surgical management. The patient's successful recovery underscores the benefits of immediate surgical intervention in symptomatic patients with AAA.

Case Report:  Title: A Rare Case of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Asian Female  Introduction: The patient is a 78-year-old Asian female  from urban background  who had presented to the emergency department with a complaint of sudden and severe lower abdominal and back pain.  Case Description: The patient is retired  lives with her husband and is generally active with housework and social activities. She does not have any known significant habits - she is a non-smoker  non-alcoholic and mainly enjoys a plant-based diet.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus  for which she has been taking antihypertensive and oral hypoglycemic agents for the past fifteen years. She also has osteoarthritis of the knee  for which she takes occasional analgesic medication. She has no known allergies. There is no significant family history related to any cardiac disease or genetic disorders.  Presenting Complaints:  The patient was admitted to the emergency department with severe abdominal and back pain which had started suddenly in the morning. The pain was constant  did not radiate  and was not related to meals or physical activities. No associated symptoms such as nausea  vomiting  diarrhea  or chest pain were reported. Her vital signs on arrival were: blood pressure of 140/90 mm Hg  heart rate of 90 beats/minute  respiration rate of 22 breaths/minute  and temperature of 36.6 degree Celsius.  Investigations: On examination  a pulsating mass was palpable in the middle and upper quadrant of the abdomen. No renal bruit was heard. An urgent abdominal ultrasound was performed which revealed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 7cm. These findings were further confirmed by a CT (Computerized Tomography) angiography. Lab investigations showed mild elevation of D-dimer levels. All other blood parameters  including kidney and liver function tests  were within normal limits.  Treatment & Follow-Up: The patient was immediately referred to the vascular surgery department. An emergency endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) was successfully performed. Post-operative recovery was uneventful  and she was discharged on post-op day 10. In her follow up visits  she had no abdominal or back pain. A repeat CT angiography done after three months showed no evidence of endoleak or aneurysm growth.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of a high index of suspicion for abdominal aortic aneurysm in elderly patients presenting with severe abdominal and back pain  even when there is no significant medical history of cardiac-related disorders.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male Patient: A Case Report  Patient Information: A 74-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension and long-term smoking was referred to our vascular surgery outpatient clinic due to persistent abdominal pain and back discomfort over the past month. The patient  a retired businessman  lives alone.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  he had a tender pulsatile abdominal mass. His blood pressure was 175/95 mmHg and his pulse was 88 beats per minute.  Diagnostic Assessment: An abdominal ultrasound and subsequent computed tomography angiogram (CTA) confirmed the presence of an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 7.2 cm in diameter with evidence of intraluminal thrombus. No signs of rupture or dissection were observed. Other blood work  including complete blood count  liver function  and kidney function tests  were within normal limits.  Therapeutic Intervention: Due to the patient's age and concurrent hypertension  we and the patient decided on an elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). He underwent successful EVAR using a bifurcated stent graft. The operation was completed without complications  and the patient was shifted to the postoperative intensive care for 24-hour monitoring.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Postoperative ultrasound showed no leak around the stent graft. The patient's abdominal and back pain resolved  and he was discharged home on the seventh postoperative day. He remains under regular follow-up every six months with ultrasounds to monitor the status of the aortic aneurysm. Till the last follow-up (18 months post procedure)  there is no evidence of aneurysm expansion or graft-related complications.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed relief over the resolution of his pain and was compliant with his follow-up schedule. He quit smoking post-procedure and has been managing his hypertension through prescribed medication and lifestyle modifications.  Conclusion: This case highlights the successful management of a large abdominal aortic aneurysm in an elderly male patient with hypertension. Regular follow-up and strict control of co-morbidities like hypertension are crucial for a successful long-term outcome.  *This case is in compliance with the widely accepted CARE guidelines for case report writing.*

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 70-year-old Caucasian Male  I. Patient Information The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who was admitted to the emergency department presenting with sudden intense abdominal pain and a rapid drop in blood pressure. He is a retired professional with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking. He lives with his wife and has three adult children. The patient has a body mass index (BMI) of 27 and is relatively inactive.  II. Clinical Findings On physical examination  the patient was found to be in acute distress with pale skin and cold sweats. He was hypotensive with a blood pressure of 80/60 mmHg and had tachycardia with a heart rate of 110 bpm. A pulsatile abdominal mass was appreciated on palpation with bruits audible on auscultation over the mass.   III. Timeline The patient experienced sudden onset of knife-like abdominal pain radiating to the back and associated with nausea in the early morning hours. He was brought to the emergency department approximately one hour after the initiation of symptoms.   IV. Diagnostic Assessment The initial suspicion of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was based on the patient's history  clinical presentation  and physical examination. Confirmatory diagnostic testing included a bedside ultrasound showing a large AAA and computed tomography angiography (CTA) revealing a ruptured AAA extending into the left iliac artery.   V. Therapeutic Intervention The patient was immediately taken to the operating room for an emergency endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). During surgery  the rupture site was identified  isolated  and a stent graft was placed successfully.  VI. Follow-up and Outcomes Post-surgery  the patient was monitored in the intensive care unit where he showed steady improvement with stable hemodynamics. He was transferred to the step-down unit on postoperative day 5 and was discharged home on day 10 with minimal pain and a resolution of symptoms. The patient was advised for smoking cessation  control of hypertension and hyperlipidemia to prevent future aneurysm growth.   VII. Discussion This case serves to highlight the typical presentation of a ruptured AAA  an important clinical entity associated with high mortality rates. Primary care providers should be mindful of risk factors for AAA  including age  male sex  smoking  and hypertension  and consider AAA in their differential for patients presenting with sudden severe abdominal or back pain. Expedient diagnosis and treatment are essential for survival.   Given the patient’s risk factors (age  sex  smoking  and hypertension) he was at high-risk for AAA development. His inactive lifestyle and BMI only served to exacerbate this risk. This case emphasizes the need for appropriate screening and preventive strategies in high-risk groups. Educational strategies aimed at lifestyle modifications can also reduce the incidence and improve mortality rates associated with AAA rupture.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in Elderly Male with Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia: A Case Report  Patient Information:   The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired  with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is a lifelong non-smoker and reports moderate weekly alcohol consumption. His BMI is 26 kg/m^2 and he reports moderate daily physical activity.  Clinical Findings:   The patient presented to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain  radiating to the back. His vitals showed a blood pressure reading of 140/90 mmHg  heart rate of 88 beats per minute  respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute  and a temperature of 98.6°F. Physical examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the abdomen.  Diagnostic Assessment:   An abdominal ultrasound was performed which revealed the presence of a 5.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The patient's hematologic and biochemical analysis were within normal ranges except for elevated cholesterol levels. His ECG showed signs of left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH)  likely a long-term consequence of his underlying hypertension.  Therapeutic Intervention:   Given the size of his AAA and history of hypertension  the patient was electively admitted for endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). His blood pressure was regulated using antihypertensive medications  and his lipid profile was managed using statins. His post-surgery recovery was event-less and was discharged on day 5 post-procedure. A regimen for the management of his hypertension and hyperlipidemia was provided  in addition to advice on maintaining a balanced diet  regular exercise  and moderation of alcohol intake.  Follow-Up and Outcomes:   30-day follow-up showed satisfactory wound healing and no signs of endoleak on the duplex ultrasound. Upon reevaluation at six months  the patient reported no abdominal discomfort and his blood pressure and cholesterol levels had improved significantly due to adhering strictly to prescribed medications and lifestyle changes. The size of his abdominal aorta remained stable at 3.0 cm.  Patient Perspective:   The patient expressed gratitude for his health restoration. He admitted at first to underestimating the importance of managing his hypertension and hyperlipidemia but is now committed to maintaining a healthier lifestyle.  Informed Consent:   The patient has given his consent for this case to be published.  Concluding Remarks:  This case underscores the importance of routine screening for AAA in elderly males with hypertension and hyperlipidemia. It highlights the crucial role lifestyle modifications and adhering to medical therapies play in the management of AAA and associated risk factors.

Title: A Case Report on Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male Patient  Introduction: We report an interesting case of an elderly male diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Abdominal aortic aneurysms represent a significant issue in vascular surgery  with an estimation of the prevalence in the aging population to be between 4-8%.  Patient Information: The patient  Mr. A  is an 82-year-old Caucasian male hailing from an urban locality. His vital signs upon arrival at the hospital were stable: pulse rate at 75 beats/min  blood pressure 152/88 mm Hg  respiratory rate 18 breaths/min  and temperature 97.3°F.  Clinical Findings: Mr. A presented to the emergency department with complaints of persistent  dull abdominal pain  and a pulsating sensation in the abdomen for the past two days. He also had accompanying lower back pain and episodes of light-headedness.  Diagnostic Assessment: Upon physical examination  a palpable abdominal mass was felt  which was pulsating in nature  leading to suspicions of an AAA. This was later confirmed via an abdominal ultrasound which revealed an aneurysm measuring approximately 5.3 cm in size. A CT scan further corroborated the diagnosis and estimated the extent of the aneurysm. Complete blood count  liver function test  kidney function test  lipid profile  and blood coagulation profile were within normal limits.  Past Medical History: The patient has a 40-year history of smoking  which he quit five years ago. He has been a hypertensive for the past 20 years and maintains blood pressure levels by adhering to prescribed medication. He was diagnosed with moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) four years ago and is currently on maintenance therapy. His familial history is significant  with his father dying from an untreated AAA rupture.  Therapeutic Intervention: Given the size of the aneurysm and potential risk of rupture as well as the acceptable operative risk despite his age and COPD  the patient underwent endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) using a stent graft. His postoperative course was uneventful with strong palpable peripheral pulses. He was discharged after a week. He is currently on regular follow-ups for observation and management of his hypertension and COPD.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of clinical suspicion and appropriate diagnostic measures in identifying AAAs  especially in elderly patients with long-term smoke exposure  hypertension  and a family history of aneurysms. Prompt surgical intervention may significantly reduce the risk of rupture and subsequent mortality.

Title: Unveiling an Incidental Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 70-Year-Old Male with Chronic Abdominal Discomfort: A Case Report  Abstract: This case report describes a 70-year-old Hispanic male with an incidental finding of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The epidemiology of the disorder suggests a slightly higher incidence in Caucasian males  making this case a demographic outlier. The goal of this report is to evoke consideration in the differential diagnosis and preventive counseling of older Hispanic males who may be perceived as low-risk due to underrepresentation in research populations.   Case Presentation:  Mr. P. is a 70-year-old Hispanic male who presented with a chronic history of mild lower abdominal discomfort and had recently noticed an increase in symptom severity over the past month. He denied any history of trauma  flank or back pain  or other pertinent symptoms and had a nonsignificant past medical history. His lifestyle factors included smoking (20-pack year history) and moderate alcohol consumption. There was no documented family history of AAA.  After initial examination suggested potential abdominal distention  radiological imaging was ordered revealing a 7 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. Considering the size of the aneurysm and the associated potential for rupture  Mr. P was immediately referred for a surgical evaluation. He successfully underwent endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) and is currently in a cardiovascular rehabilitation program mitigating his risk factors.  Conclusion: The demographic data suggest a slightly higher incidence of AAA in Caucasian elderly males  perhaps leading to unintentional neglect of minority populations in diagnosis and screening. This case underlines the importance of considering AAA in a differential diagnosis regardless of ethnicity  considering shared risk factors  particularly in older  male smokers with chronic abdominal discomfort. Further research should consider ethnically diverse population studies  maximizing the opportunities for early detection  and better prevention efforts.   Learning Points:  1. An abdominal aortic aneurysm can present as chronic mild lower abdominal discomfort  with increases in symptom severity potentially signifying enlargement or impending rupture. 2. Risk factors such as age  gender  smoking  and history of vascular disease contribute to AAA  regardless of ethnic background. 3. Abdominal examination and medical imaging can aid in the diagnosis of AAA  and large aneurysms should prompt immediate surgical referral. 4. It is crucial to exercise an inclusive approach in preventive and diagnostic measures  considering demographic factors  ensuring underserved populations are not overlooked.   Keywords: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Hispanic  Elderly  Smoking  Abdominal Discomfort  Case Report.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 75-Year-Old Male Patient: A Case Report  Introduction:  A 75-year-old Caucasian male patient presented with persistent lower back pain  mild abdominal discomfort  and a noticeable pulsating mass in his lower abdomen.   Case Description:  The patient in question was a retired tradesman with a history of heavy tobacco use lasting over 30 years. His medical history was remarkable for hypertension  high cholesterol but no diabetes  and no prior abdominal surgeries. This patient had a family history of cardiovascular diseases with his mother suffering a fatal myocardial infarction at age 70 and his father having undergone successful elective surgery for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at a similar age as he is currently.  On physical examination  the patient appeared comfortable; vital signs were stable  with a blood pressure reading of 150/90 mmHg. The heart sounds were normal without any murmur  the lung fields were clear  and the abdomen was soft with a palpable pulsatile mass in the periumbilical region. The rest of his examination was unremarkable.  He underwent abdominal ultrasonography  which confirmed the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.2 cm in diameter. The diagnosis was later confirmed by a CT angiogram  identifying a fusiform AAA just below the renal arteries without any signs of rupture.   Discussion:  AAA is a relatively common condition that is linked to high mortality rates when ruptured. Risk factors include advanced age  tobacco use  male gender  hypertension  and a family history of the condition. This patient had multiple risk factors  including age  heavy smoking history  a family history of AAA  and a known diagnosis of hypertension. His symptoms  along with these risk factors  made the diagnosis likely.   The fusiform shape  which was found in this case  is the most common type of aneurysm. In general  the larger an aneurysm is  the greater the risk of rupture  with aneurysms over 5 cm in diameter having an annual risk of rupture of about 10%. Therefore  election of surgery for AAA is generally indicated for the aneurysm of a size greater than 5.5 cm  or in patients with symptomatic or rapidly enlarging AAAs. In this case  the patient’s aneurysm  at 5.2 cm  approached the threshold for surgical intervention.  Conclusion:  This case exemplifies the importance of early recognition and timely intervention in the management of AAA  thus improving the outcomes and reducing the risk of rupture with the consequent high mortality rate. In hindsight  screening ultrasonography may have been offered to this patient given his age  smoking history  and family history of AAA.    This case also emphasizes the need for clinicians to maintain a high index of suspicion for AAA  especially in elderly males with a history of smoking  hypertension  and a family history of AAA. Ultimately  the clinician's mindfulness about this potentially life-threatening condition helped in the early detection and timely intervention.

Title: A Case Report on A Large Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male Patient  Patient Information: An 80-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  active smoker with a history of consuming 20 cigarettes per day for the past 60 years.   Presenting complaint: The patient reported to the emergency room with a sudden onset of severe  sharp  and tearing abdominal pain radiating to the back  along with a feeling of abdominal fullness. He rated the pain as 8 on the scale of 1-10. His pain was disproportionate to his physical findings.  Medical history: The patient has been previously diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and he has been irregular with his medications. He denied history of diabetes or any cardiovascular disease but had a family history of atherosclerosis.  Physical Examination: On examination  he was hypertensive with a blood pressure of 165/85mmHg and showed an elevated pulse rate of 105 beats per minute. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the mid and lower abdomen coupled with moderate tenderness.  Diagnostic Assessment: An urgent Computed Tomography Angiogram (CTA) was ordered  which confirmed the diagnosis of a large 6.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) with surrounding hematoma indicating rupture.  Treatment: Given his diagnosis and serious condition  an immediate endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) was performed. His post-operative period was uneventful. Anti-hypertensive and lipid-lowering therapies were aggressively optimized. Smoking cessation was strongly advised.  Follow-up visit: The patient was closely monitored. He was asymptomatic during a 3-month follow-up visit. However  continued surveillance was recommended due to the risk of EVAR failure as well as the need to manage his hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking habit.  Conclusion: This case report concludes that in the elderly population  particularly in those with a history of smoking  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  a high index of suspicion should be maintained for AAA  especially in those presenting with abdominal pain or abdominal mass. Early diagnosis  immediate surgical intervention  and effective management of risk factors play crucial roles in improving the prognosis of such patients. Any delay could result in life-threatening complications due to rupture. The role of lifestyle modification  particularly smoking cessation  and regular medications cannot be overstated.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in Elderly Male: A Case Report  Patient Description:  The patient is an 80-year-old Caucasian male  residing in an urban area  with a documented history of prolonged smoking. He is retired and lives with his wife. His family history is notable for cardiovascular disease  with his father having passed away from a myocardial infraction at the age of 67.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a 20-year history of moderate to high blood pressure levels  managed with anti-hypertensive medication. He was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia and prescribed statin therapy 10 years ago. He also has a 15-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus  controlled with metformin.   Presenting Complaint: He presented to the outpatient clinic with unexplained but persistent  dull lower back pain lasting for the past three weeks. No palpable abdominal mass was detected during the physical examination. He had no other symptoms like leg pain  dizziness  syncope  or shortness of breath.  Investigations: The ECG was essentially normal. No abnormalities were identified in his full blood count  liver function test  renal profile  and blood glucose levels. A urine test was also normal. However  given the patient's age  sex  history of hypertension and smoking  an ultrasound was done to rule out an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The ultrasound confirmed the presence of an AAA measuring 5.6 cm in diameter.   Discussion: The incidence of AAA is significantly higher in males and those over 65 years of age. It is uncommon in individuals below 60 years of age. The patient's prolonged smoking history  male gender  advancing age  diagnosis of hypertension  and hyperlipidemia fall in line with the risk factors identified in the literature. Though the genetic aspect cannot be disregarded  familial AAA was unlikely as the patient had no family history of AAA.  Management and Outcome:  The patient was referred immediately to the vascular surgery department given the size (>5.5cm) and risk of rupture of the aneurysm. He underwent successful elective infrarenal endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). He has regular post-operative reviews and is doing well so far  with an excellent recovery and no complications. The AAA remains stable in size on the six-month follow-up ultrasound.  This case study underscores the importance of finding and treating AAA in its early stages  particularly in high-risk populations. It is vital to maintain a high index of suspicion based on risk factors and not solely on symptomatology  as the disease could be asymptomatic until rupture. Prompt diagnosis can lead to effective preventive care  thus substantially decreasing morbidity and mortality.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 72-Year-Old Caucasian Male: A Case Report  Introduction: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) is a potentially life-threatening condition predominantly seen in the geriatric population  where the aortic wall weakens exhibiting a dilated feature. This report discusses a case of AAA in a 72-year-old male patient who presented to the emergency with severe abdominal pain.  Case Description:  The patient  Mr. X  is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and ischemic heart disease. He is a retired engineer who has a 50 pack-year smoking history and drinks alcohol occasionally. He has been on anti-hypertensives  anti-diabetic medications  and statins. He lives with his wife and leads a relatively sedentary lifestyle  being physically inactive for over a decade.  On presentation  the patient complained of sudden onset of severe  tearing abdominal pain radiating to the back. He reported feeling dizzy but denied any loss of consciousness. On physical examination  he appeared pale and sweating profusely. His blood pressure was 90/60 mmHg coupled with a pulse rate of 110 bpm. His abdomen was distended  tender in the periumbilical region with a palpable pulsatile mass.  Laboratory investigations revealed anemia and increased inflammatory markers. EKG showed nonspecific ST-T wave changes. Given the clinical index of suspicion for AAA and hemodynamic instability  an urgent computed tomography angiogram (CTA) was conducted  which confirmed a 7.4cm infrarenal AAA with evidence of rupture.  The patient was promptly taken to the operating room for emergency open repair of the ruptured AAA. He underwent a successful surgical intervention  with placement of a synthetic graft. His postoperative course was uneventful and was discharged on postoperative day 10  with scheduled follow-ups.   Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the crucial role of a prompt diagnosis and intervention in a ruptured AAA. Despite its rarity  it emphasizes the importance of considering AAA in older  male patients with multiple risk factors including Caucasian ethnicity  hypertension  smoking  and sedentary lifestyle  who present with a sudden onset of abdominal pain.   Informed consent to publish the details of their case was obtained from the patient.   Patient's Follow-Up: Mr. X is currently being monitored closely in the outpatient department with regular ultrasound screenings for a potential graft-related complication. Lifestyle modifications have been advised to the patient  including smoking cessation and engaging in moderate physical activity. His hypertension and diabetes are controlled adequately with medication  and his overall prognosis remains good.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Patient with History of Hypertension: A Case Report  Introduction:  Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) is a life-threatening condition prevalent in elderly males  often associated with a history of hypertension and atherosclerosis. This case study focuses on an elderly male patient who presented with ruptured AAA.  Case Presentation:  Patient Information: A 72-year-old African-American male presented to the emergency department with persistent severe abdominal pain  back pain  and transient syncope. The patient resides in Albany  New York  and is a retired office clerk. He is a former smoker with a 15-pack year history but quit 20 years prior to this presentation. He reports moderate alcohol consumption and has a diet high in fatty foods.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the patient appeared pale and diaphoretic with a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg  a heart rate of 110 bpm  and a respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsating mass in the periumbilical region with generalized tenderness. No other significant abnormalities were noted.  Diagnostic Assessment: Past medical history was significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and peripheral artery disease  managed with lisinopril  atorvastatin  and clopidogrel respectively. No history of surgery or any allergies was reported. Family history revealed his father died of an aneurysm rupture  but no other significant anamnestic data was reported. A computed tomography angiograph (CTA) revealed a 9 cm infrarenal AAA with surrounding retroperitoneal hematoma  suggestive of rupture.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately managed with intravenous fluids and scheduled for emergent open AAA repair. Intra-operatively  a large infra-renal AAA with a posterior rupture site was noted. Aortic cross-clamping was performed  and an aorto-aortic Dacron graft was subsequently placed. The operative course was uneventful.  Follow Up and Outcomes: The patient’s postoperative period was complicated by transient renal failure  managed with supportive treatment. He was discharged after 12 days in stable condition  with follow-up scheduled at the vascular surgery department. At a 6-month follow-up  the patient was asymptomatic  and no complications associated with the surgery were noted.  Patient’s Perspective: The patient expressed gratitude for the successful management of this life-threatening condition and vowed to continue with regular follow-ups to monitor his health status.  Conclusion: This case report reinforces the importance of maintaining a high index of suspicion for AAA in elderly males presenting with abdominal pain  especially with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and peripheral artery disease. Early recognition and immediate surgical intervention can significantly lower the mortality associated with ruptured AAAs.

Title: A Case of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-Year-Old Caucasian Male  Case Presentation:  Mr. H  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  was presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain. The pain was described as sharp  constant  and radiating to his lower back. He mentioned noticing a pulsating sensation in his abdomen recently  although he had not sought medical attention for it. The patient also reported a history of hypertension for which he had been taking antihypertensive medications inconsistently  blaming forgetfulness and lack of discipline. He was former smoker with a smoking history of 30 pack years and had quit 10 years ago. The patient had no known allergies. He led a sedentary lifestyle and drank alcohol moderately. Family history revealed his father had died of a 'ruptured aorta' at the age of 74.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  the patient appeared in moderate distress. Physical examination revealed a pulsating abdominal mass in the periumbilical region  and the patient was tender on deep palpation of the abdomen. His heart rate was 100 beats per minute and blood pressure was mildly elevated at 150/90 mmHg. Peripheral pulses were palpable and symmetric. Rest of the examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Findings:  Due to the clinical suspicion raised from the patient's history and physical exam  an urgent abdominal ultrasound was ordered  which resulted in the identification of a 5.6cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. A computed tomography angiogram (CTA) confirmed the presence of an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm  without signs of rupture or dissection.  Treatment  Outcome  and Follow-Up:  The patient was urgently referred to a vascular surgeon. Open surgical repair of the aneurysm was the decided route of management given the size of the aneurysm and the significant risk of rupture. He underwent a successful open infra-renal AAA repair with Dacron graft. He was discharged after one week of hospital stay without any complications. The patient was enrolled in a follow-up program at our vascular surgery clinic  with planned regular abdominal ultrasounds to monitor the status of the repaired aneurysm. The importance of adhering to his antihypertensive therapy was emphasized during the post-discharge meeting with the patient.   Discussion:  The patient's age  ethnicity  gender  history of hypertension  and smoking along with the familial propensity hold classic demographic and risk factor association with the abdominal aortic aneurysm as dictated in medical literature. The case underscores the need for increased awareness of the clinical presentation of abdominal aortic aneurysms  especially among at-risk populations  to ensure timely detection and management.   Patient Consent:   The patient provided written informed consent for the publication of the case details.

Case Report: Elderly Male with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information:  The patient is a 78-year-old Caucasian male  living in rural Midwest USA. The occupation of the patient was farming until his retirement 13 years ago. The patient lives with his wife with regular visits from their children and grandchildren. He has been a smoker for around 30 years but quit approximately 15 years ago.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a past medical history of hypertension which was diagnosed 20 years ago and has been kept under control with medication. Other medical information includes hyperlipidemia and osteoarthritis. He also underwent a cholecystectomy 10 years ago. The patient has a family history of cardiovascular disease  his father having died from a heart attack and mother from a stroke.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient presented to the hospital with a complaint of intermittent yet persistent abdominal discomfort and back pain for the past few weeks. The pain  according to the patient  does not radiate and is not precipitated by eating  but is exacerbated by exertion. In the last three days  the pain has intensified  becoming constant and the patient added that he felt unusually tired and has been experiencing a loss of appetite.  Examination Findings:  On physical examination  the patient is alert and oriented but seems anxious. His vital signs are BP 160/90 mmHg  Pulse 70/min  respiratory rate 18/min  temperature 37.0 degrees Celsius. Abdominal examination reveals a palpable  pulsatile mass in the mid-abdominal region which is tender on deep palpation. No bruits are auscultated. Lower extremities are warm  with 2+ pulses in bilateral distal posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis arteries.  Investigations:  An urgent abdominal ultrasound was performed revealing a 5.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. A CT-scan further confirmed the presence of abdominal aortic aneurysm without any signs of rupture or dissection.  Diagnosis:  Given the above information  a diagnosis of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) was made.  Management:  Given the size of the aneurysm and the increasing severity of the patient's symptoms  an open surgical repair (OSR) was decided upon. Post-surgery  the patient was kept under observation in the ICU for 24 hours and then shifted to the ward.  Follow Up:  The patient’s postoperative recovery was uneventful and he was discharged 6 days later. Follow-ups have been planned within 2 weeks  1 month  and then every 6 months to monitor the patient’s condition and any signs of aneurysm recurrence.  Conclusion:  This case emphasizes the potential silent nature of AAA that can even go unnoticed until becoming symptomatic or rupturing. Hence  more routine screening protocols  particularly in older males with a history of smoking and cardiovascular disease  should be implemented for early detection and management.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-Year-Old Caucasian Male: A Case Report  Patient Information: A 68-year-old Caucasian male patient  retired engineer  living in suburban Ohio  presented to the hospital with a chief complaint of abrupt onset intense abdominal and lower back pain.  Clinical History: The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension  chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to a long smoking history (40 pack-years)  and high cholesterol. His surgical history includes a cholecystectomy 15 years ago. His family history is notable for cardiovascular disease; his mother had a stroke at the age of 70  and his father died from a heart attack at the age of 65. The patient is on Hydrochlorothiazide  Atorvastatin  and Salbutamol inhaler.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the patient appeared uncomfortable and sweaty. Vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 170/95 mmHg  heart rate 98 beats per minute  temperature 37.0°C  and respiratory rate of 23 breaths per minute. Acute tenderness was noted to palpation in the periumbilical area  and a palpable pulsatile mass was felt. The abdomen was slightly distended with mild guarding. No other abnormalities were found on cardiovascular  chest  or neurological exam.   Diagnostic Assessment: A contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen was immediately ordered  which revealed a large infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring 7.0 cm in diameter. There was evidence of contained rupture with surrounding retroperitoneal hematoma. Initial blood tests showed mildly elevated white blood cells (12 500/μL)  normal hemoglobin  and slightly raised creatinine (1.5 mg/dl). His lipids were found to be in controlled range.  Therapeutic Intervention: Following the CT scan  the patient was immediately rushed to the operating room for an emergency open surgical repair of the ruptured AAA. Intraoperatively  a large infrarenal AAA with a posterior wall rupture was confirmed  and an aorto-bi-iliac Dacron graft was successfully placed.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Despite a challenging postoperative course which included acute renal insufficiency and a prolonged stay in the intensive care unit  the patient made a satisfactory recovery and was discharged home after a total of 15 days. On his postoperative follow-up visit  he was found recovering well and his renal function tests were improving gradually.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed his relief and gratitude post-surgery and pledged to adhere strictly to lifestyle modifications including smoking cessation.  Informed Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.   Teaching Points: This case highlights the important consideration of AAA in older patients  especially men who have cardiovascular risk factors. The case emphasizes the role of rapid diagnosis and management in improving survival outcomes in potentially catastrophic conditions like AAA ruptures.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-Year-Old Asian Male: A Case Report  Abstract: This case report details the presentation  diagnosis  and management of a rupture in an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in a 68-year-old Asian male patient. With a high mortality rate and subtle presentation  ruptured AAA poses a serious diagnostic challenge for physicians.  Case Report:  Patient Information:  Mr. X is a 68-year-old Asian male with a past medical history notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia controlled with moderate doses of Amlodipine and Atorvastatin respectively. His family history is significant for an AAA in his father. Mr. X has been a smoker for 40 years and admits occasional heavy alcohol intake but no drug use. He was referred from his primary care physician to the hospital due to the sudden onset of severe abdominal and low back pain.  Clinical Findings:  On arrival  the patient was pale and restless with a heart rate of 112 beats per minute  a blood pressure of 88/58 mm Hg  respirations of 22 breaths per minute  and an oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. Physical examination revealed a distended abdomen with severe tenderness in the mid to lower quadrants and a palpable pulsatile mass. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment:  Due to the patient's history  physical findings  and hypotension  a ruptured AAA was suspected. The patient underwent a CT angiogram  which confirmed a 7.3 cm infrarenal AAA with an adjacent retroperitoneal hematoma indicative of rupture.  Therapeutic Intervention:  Given the diagnosis  the patient was immediately transferred to the operating room. He underwent an emergent open surgical repair of the AAA by means of an aortic bifurcated graft and ligation of the ruptured aneurysm. His postoperative course was managed in the surgical intensive care unit where he required vasopressor support for 48 hours.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  On the fourth postoperative day  vasopressors were discontinued. By the seventh postoperative day  he was transferred to the general floor. He was discharged home with home health services on postoperative day ten. Robust post-discharge follow-up was implemented due to the significant mortality and morbidity associated with ruptured AAA. A follow-up CT scan six months later revealed no evidence of aneurysm or leak.  Conclusions:  This case highlights the importance of having a high index of suspicion for ruptured AAA given non-specific symptoms and known risk factors such as male gender  advanced age  family history  and smoking. Prompt diagnosis and surgical management are crucial to reduce morbidity and mortality.  Clinical Implications:  Physicians should maintain a high index of suspicion for AAA in older patients presenting with abdominal or back pain. Timely diagnosis can improve patient outcomes by allowing prompt surgical intervention. Postoperative vigilance in the acute care setting is essential due to possible hemodynamic instability. Regular follow-up with imaging after discharge can ensure graft patency and monitor for complications.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Patient Presenting with Unexplained Abdominal Pain  Introduction: This is a case of a 70-year-old Caucasian male presenting with severe lower abdominal pain  who was subsequently diagnosed with a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Case Presentation:  Mr. A is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50-pack year smoking history  who presented to the hospital with a four-hour history of sudden onset sharp  lower abdominal pain which was radiating to his back. He also revealed he has been experiencing episodes of lightheadedness and cold sweats. He denied any history of trauma. He reported no previous diagnosis of any kind of cardiac or vascular disease. His family history was positive for cardiovascular disease  with his father having died from a heart attack in his early 70s.  Upon examination  the patient was pale and sweaty. His pulse was 110 beats per minute  blood pressure was 90/60 mmHg  and his respiration rate was 24 breaths per minute. Abdominal examination revealed a palpable pulsatile mass along with tenderness in the lower abdomen.  The patient's CBC showed a hematocrit of 27% (norm: 45-52%). His kidney and liver functions were slightly deranged as reflected by elevated urea and creatinine  and moderately elevated liver enzymes. Electrocardiogram showed a sinus tachycardia with no other abnormalities.  Differential diagnoses for lower abdominal pain including acute mesenteric ischemia  perforated peptic ulcer  renal colic and ruptured AAA were considered. Given the patient's signs  symptoms and risk factors  the suspicion of a ruptured AAA was high. An urgent contrast-enhanced CT scan was arranged that revealed a large intra-abdominal hematoma along with an 8.5 cm dilated abdominal aorta confirming the diagnosis of ruptured AAA.  Despite the high operative risk given his clinical status  emergency open repair of the ruptured AAA was performed due to the life-threatening nature of the condition. The procedure went successfully without any intraoperative complications. Surveillance of postoperative care was done in intensive care unit with the administration of regular blood products to manage his anemia. His postoperative recovery  while slow due to his advanced age and comorbidities  was uneventful.  Conclusion:  This case highlights the importance of considering a ruptured AAA in the differential diagnosis of severe abdominal pain  particularly in older patients with risk factors like hypertension  hyperlipidemia and a significant smoking history. Early diagnosis and prompt surgical management greatly improves the prognosis in such cases. This case reiterates the significant role of vigilant history taking  physical examination and appropriate investigations in achieving a lifesaving diagnosis in emergency management. Also  it underscores the need for robust smoking cessation  and hypertension and lipid control programs aimed at this high-risk group.

CASE REPORT  Patient Information:  Mr. A is a 68-year-old Caucasian male living in an urban setting in New York City. He is a retired mechanical engineer and has a history of moderate  consistent tobacco use for 40 years but quit smoking around five years ago. He actively participates in light recreational activities and lives with his wife.  Chief Complaint:  The patient visited the clinic with a complain of persistent abdominal and lower back pain.  Relevant Medical History:  The patient has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he has been on treatment for the past 10 years. He also has a familial history of cardiovascular diseases with his father having died from myocardial infarction at 72 and his elder brother having undergone surgery for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Examination and Diagnostic Assessment:  A thorough physical examination was performed which was unremarkable except for a tender pulsating mass in the abdomen. A subsequent ultrasound confirmed the presence of AAA with an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 7.0 cm in the maximum diameter. No evidence of rupture was detected. A computed tomography angiogram (CTA) was performed afterward for better assessment and planning of potential intervention which further confirmed the diagnosis.  Interventions:  Given the size of the aneurysm and the familial history  endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) was decided as the course of action after detailing out the procedural benefits and risks. Mr. A gave informed consent for the procedure.  Progress and Outcome:  The endovascular procedure was successful without perioperative complications. The patient was monitored in the hospital for two days and was then discharged. Follow-up sessions and periodical imaging have been advised for routine surveillance. At his first-month follow-up  Mr. A reported significant improvement and cessation of his abdominal and lower back pain.  Learning points:  The case of Mr. A underscores the significance of considering familial history while evaluating pulmonary symptoms in people over the age of 60  particularly those with a history of smoking  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. Early detection and appropriate intervention of AAA can be life-saving  and hence should be highly considered in populations with high-risk factors for the development of AAA.

Title: Emergent Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 72-year old Caucasian Male with a History of Hypertension  Abstract: We present a case of a 72-year old Caucasian male diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  who was successfully managed with endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR).  Case Presentation: The patient  a retired professor  non-smoker  and moderate alcohol drinker  reported to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset of intense  tearing lower abdominal and back pain. The patient admitted haematuria since last two days. His past medical history was unremarkable  except for well-controlled hypertension for the past 8 years.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  vital signs were generally stable  but a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpable. His body mass index was 26.3 kg/m2. Lab tests revealed no signs of infection or anemia but showed a slight elevation in white blood counts and creatinine levels. Electrocardiogram represented no abnormal results.  Diagnosis: Urgent computed tomography (CT) scanning of abdomen and pelvis displayed a 7.2 cm infrarenal AAA with signs of impending rupture  and mild hydronephrosis. Based on clinical and imaging findings  the patient was diagnosed with an emergent AAA.  Intervention: The patient underwent emergent endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) within 4 hours of diagnosis. The procedure proceeded without complications  and a post-op CT scan confirmed a successful EVAR with no leak.  Outcome: The patient showed remarkable recovery post-surgery. His postoperative course was uncomplicated  except for transient acute kidney injury likely related to the preoperative hydronephrosis. His symptoms improved considerably  and he was discharged after eight days post-operation.  Conclusion: This case exemplifies the typical demographic pattern of AAA occurring in older  Caucasian males with hypertension history. Prompt diagnosis and swift surgical intervention via EVAR can significantly improve patient outcomes and decrease mortality risk. It reinforces the necessity of maintaining a high index of suspicion in older males with hypertension presenting with unexplained abdominal or back pain and emphasizes the appropriateness of EVAR as an effective treatment solution for AAA.  Keywords: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Hypertension  Endovascular Aneurysm Repair  Case Report.

Title: Symptomatic Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Female  Patient Information:  The patient is a 78-year-old African-American female with a known history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). She lives alone and was previously independent in all activities of daily living.  Clinical Findings:  The patient presented to the emergency department (ED) complaining of sudden severe abdominal and lower back pain radiating to her lower extremities. She also reported the pain was pulsatile  unrelenting and unlike any she had experienced before. The patient denied any recent trauma  fever  or history of abdominal surgeries. Her initial vital signs on arrival were blood pressure 158/90mmHg  pulse rate 90 beats per minute  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  SpO2 94% on room air  and temperature 98.8°F. Physical inspection revealed a palpable  pulsatile mass in the peri-umbilical region of her abdomen.   Diagnostic Assessment:  A computed tomography angiogram (CTA) of the abdomen and pelvis was promptly performed  which confirmed the diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.5cm in greatest diameter. No signs of rupture or dissection were observed. Laboratory tests including a full blood count  renal function test  and coagulation profile were within normal limits. Electrocardiogram showed signs of left ventricular hypertrophy  likely related to her history of hypertension.  Therapeutic Intervention:  After discussion with the vascular surgical team  an expedited endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) was planned. The patient was admitted into the intensive care unit for close monitoring until surgery. The procedure was performed successfully without complications  and the patient reported a significant reduction in abdominal pain post-operation.  Follow-up and Outcomes: The patient's recovery was uneventful  with the improvement of her symptoms and stabilization of her vital signs post-operation. Follow up CT scan showed successful exclusion of the aneurysm. She was scheduled for regular surveillance at the vascular clinic and her primary care physician for her comorbid conditions.  Lessons Learned: This case underscores the importance of maintaining high clinical suspicion for an abdominal aortic aneurysm in patients  especially elderly females with risk factors like hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Early diagnosis and intervention can result in excellent outcomes even in those with complex comorbidity profiles.    Patient Perspective: Reflecting on her experience  the patient expressed gratitude for the swift diagnosis and treatment  understanding the potentially life-threatening complication that was averted. She urged other seniors to maintain their routine medical check-ups  to catch diseases early  just like in her case.
