Case Report:  Patient Information:  Mr. Smith  a Caucasian male  aged 72  was brought to the emergency department of our facility. He lives in a suburban region of Pennsylvania and is a retired teacher. Mr Smith has a documented history of 40 pack-years of smoking but quit smoking 10 years ago. There is a familial history of cardiovascular disorders  with both his father and older brother having suffered from myocardial infarction in their late 60s.  Past Medical History: The patient has been diagnosed with hypertension for the past 10 years and had been on regular antihypertensive treatment (Lisinopril). He is also suffering from hyperlipidemia and is compliant to a statin drug (atorvastatin). In addition  he has well-controlled type II Diabetes Mellitus treated with Metformin. There is no history of any known allergies.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Smith presented with complaints of intermittent  mild lower abdominal pain that had been troubling him for the past week. The discomfort was described as a pulsating sensation located around the navel area. The pain did not radiate and was not associated with any complaint of chest pain  shortness of breath  or lower limb weakness. There was no associated loss of consciousness  vomiting  chest pain  or dizziness.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  the patient appeared conscious  coherent  and oriented. The patient's vitals were: blood pressure 150/90 mm Hg  pulse rate 86/min  respiratory rate 18/min  and temperature 98.6 °F. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass that was palpable in the periumbilical area.  Investigations: Laboratory investigations  including complete blood count  liver and renal function tests were within normal limits. The fasting blood glucose level was slightly elevated. An ultrasound of abdomen confirmed the suspicion of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  and the diagnosis was later confirmed by a CT scan which showed a 7 cm infrarenal aneurysm with no signs of rupture.  Treatment and Outcome: Given the size and potential risk for rupture of the AAA  the patient underwent an elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). Postoperatively  he remained stable and was discharged on the fourth postoperative day. The patient has since been regular to his follow-up visits. As of his most recent visit three months postoperatively  he reported resolution of the initial abdominal symptoms and expressed overall satisfaction with the treatment outcome.   This case depicts the presentation of a potentially lethal condition  an abdominal aortic aneurysm  in a fairly typical patient demographic. Given the risk factors of age  gender  long-term smoking history  hypertension  and a family history of cardiovascular disease  it underscores the importance of clinical vigilance and prompt intervention in managing this condition.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male Patient: A Case Report  Introduction: Abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) are life-threatening conditions that primarily affect older  male population. This report presents a case of a 70-year-old male with a progressively enlarging AAA  detailing the clinical presentation  management  and prognosis of the condition.  Case Presentation: The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  a former smoker with a past medical history significant for uncontrolled hypertension and peripheral arterial disease. He presented to the Emergency Department with complaints of acute onset severe lower back and abdominal pain. The patient has not had any prior surgical interventions.  Upon initial examination  the patient was in apparent distress  with a heart rate of 110 beats per minute  blood pressure 150/90 mmHg  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 94% on room air. He was afebrile. Abdominal examination revealed a palpable  pulsatile mass in the mid-epigastric segment  with mild tenderness elicited on deep palpation. No other major clinical signs were detected during the physical examination.  Diagnosis: A Triple-phase contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen and pelvis was performed which showed a 5.6 cm infrarenal AAA with evidence of impending rupture. Routine laboratory findings were unremarkable except for a mild elevation of white blood cells and a moderate increase in the D-dimer levels  suggestive of an ongoing inflammatory process.   Management: Given the size of the aneurysm and the risk of rupture  an open surgical repair was immediately planned over endovascular repair due to the patient's anatomical considerations and the surgeon's expertise. The patient was transfused with packed red blood cells preoperatively due to anemia. Intraoperative findings confirmed the CT findings  and a Dacron graft was inserted. The patient had an uneventful recovery after the surgery.   Outcome and Follow-Up: Postoperative recovery was smooth without any complications. The patient was discharged home on the 7th postoperative day with a plan for close follow-up in outpatient clinics. Six months postoperatively  a follow-up CT angiogram showed no evidence of graft leak or aneurysmal enlargement. The patient is also being managed for his hypertension and peripheral arterial disease in a multidisciplinary approach involving a cardiologist  vascular surgeon  and primary care physician.   Discussion: This case delineates the vitality of recognizing AAA symptoms and risk factors promptly  directing towards the appropriate imaging study and ultimately interventional management. Although the mortality rate connected to AAAs remains high  particularly in ruptured cases  improved surveillance and advanced surgical techniques have progressively improved patient outcomes.   Conclusion: An optimized multi-disciplinary approach with timely intervention significantly improves the prognosis for AAA patients and contributes to their quality of life. Clinicians should focus on the importance of early detection especially in high-risk individuals such as elderly males with a history of smoking or hypertension to prevent catastrophic outcomes associated with late presentations.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male: A Case Report  Introduction:  Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by localized enlargement of the abdominal aorta. If undiagnosed  complications can include rupture leading to a true medical emergency with a high mortality rate.  Patient Information: A 78-year-old Caucasian male  non-smoker with a previous history of moderate drinking  was presented at the emergency department with acute onset of severe abdominal and back pain. Past medical history revealed controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus  mild hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia. The patient was retired and lived alone. He had a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his older brother experiencing fatal myocardial infarction at the age of 82.   Clinical Findings:  Vital signs on arrival demonstrated hypertension (BP=170/90mmHg)  normal heart rate (HR=78 bpm) and slightly elevated respiratory rate (RR=22 per minute). Despite being in apparent distress  the patient was alert and coherent. Physical examination revealed a prominent pulsatile abdominal mass that was tender on deep palpation. No other significant pathological findings were detected during the examination.  Timeline:  On arrival  immediate laboratory investigations were done  which demonstrated mild leukocytosis and a slightly elevated serum creatinine level. Urgent CT-angiography revealed an infrarenal AAA measuring 7.5 cm in maximal diameter with evidence of contained rupture.   Diagnostic Assessment: Based on the CT-angiography findings and patient clinical presentation  a diagnosis of ruptured AAA was made confirming the necessity for urgent surgical intervention. While waiting for surgery  the patient was closely monitored and managed with intravenous fluids and BP control with β-blockers.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient underwent successful open emergency AAA repair with a prosthetic aortic graft. Intraoperatively  a large hematoma was found in the retroperitoneum confirming contained rupture status.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Postoperatively  the patient showed good recovery and was eventually discharged after 10 days. Over a follow-up period of 6 months  he remained asymptomatic without complications.  Conclusion: Diagnosis of AAA can often be challenging due to its silent profile until rupture occurs. When ruptured AAA is suspected  emergent imaging and surgical intervention are vital for favorable outcomes. Furthermore  this case underlines the importance of AAA screening in high-risk populations  such as elderly men with a family history of cardiovascular diseases  to ensure early detection and intervention.

Title: A Case Report of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 70-year-old Male with a History of Hypertension and Smoking  Introduction:  This is the case of Mr. A  a 70-year-old African American male  who presented with an incidental finding of an abdominal aortic aneurysm during a routine health check-up.  Case Presentation:  The patient is an African American male  aged 70 years  with a past medical history of hypertension and a 45-year smoking history. He had no known allergies  was a non-drinker  and not on any significant medication apart from antihypertensives. He was asymptomatic and denied any recent significant pain  change in bowel habits  or urinary changes. Based on ethnic and age representation in literature  this patient's demographic is reported to be among the highest risk category for incidentally diagnosed abdominal aortic aneurysms.  He had no personal or family history of vascular diseases or aneurysms. On physical examination  he appeared relatively well  with a body mass index of 29.5 kg/m2  blood pressure of 145/85 mm Hg  and pulse of 72 beats per minute. His cardiovascular system examination was unremarkable except for a faint pulsatile abdominal mass was reported on the patient's routine physical examination.  Further Investigation:  An abdominal ultrasound was ordered  which revealed a saccular aneurysm  measuring around 5.6 cm in diameter located in his infrarenal aorta with no obvious signs of rupture. This prompted a computed tomography of the abdomen which confirmed the aneurysm with similar measures and also ruled out signs of rupture or leak complications.  Management and Follow-up:  Following American Heart Association guidelines  our patient was promptly referred to vascular surgery for consultation and potential intervention. The surgical team opted for an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) due to the patient's age and co-morbidities. The procedure was uneventful  and the patient was discharged in stable condition on postoperative day five  with close follow-up instructions.  Discussion:  Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) poses a significant health risk especially in elderly males  that too of African-American heritage. In this case  the patient was asymptomatic  which made the case more challenging to diagnose without the routine physical examination. Early diagnosis and intervention are of the utmost importance as AAA is known for its potential to rupture  leading to significant morbidity and mortality. This case reiterates the importance of considering AAA in the differential in men over 65 years with a history of hypertension and smoking.  Conclusion: Raising physician awareness towards asymptomatic patients with common risk factors is crucial to detecting and managing cases of AAA efficiently  hence significantly reducing the risk of rupture and improving patient outcomes.

Title: Emergency Repair of a Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-year-old Male  Abstract: This case study examines the management and successful emergency surgical repair of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in a 68-year-old male patient  presenting unique challenges due to the patient's history of co-morbidities.  Introduction: An abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a dilated aorta in the abdomen  with a diameter in excess of 3 centimeters  or more than 50% of its normal size. Risk factors include age (typically over 60)  male gender  smoking history  hypertension  high cholesterol  a family history of AAA  and Caucasian ethnicity.  Case Report: Mr. Jones  a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack year smoking history  was brought to the emergency department with a chief complaint of sudden onset severe abdominal pain that radiated to his lower back. His pain was described as a sharp  tearing sensation  which was not relieved or exacerbated by movement. He denied any associated symptoms such as chest pain  bowel or bladder disturbances  fever  or lower limb weakness.  On examination  Mr. Jones was pale  clammy  and in obvious distress due to pain. His blood pressure was 80/50 mm Hg  and heart rate 110 bpm  indicating shock. Abdominal examination revealed a tender  pulsatile mass in the middle and lower part of the abdomen.  An urgent abdominal ultrasound showed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 7.5 cm in diameter  suggestive of imminent rupture. A Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) confirmed these findings.   With a diagnosis of a ruptured AAA  he was immediately transferred to the operating room for an emergency endovascular aortic repair (EVAR). The surgery was uneventful  with successful placement of an aortic stent graft. Post-operative recovery was complicated by acute renal failure due to hypotension  but improved with aggressive fluid resuscitation. Mr. Jones was discharged home on post-op day 7.  Discussion: Mr. Jones' case highlights the importance of rapid diagnosis and treatment in patients presenting with a suspected ruptured AAA. His risk factors of age  male gender  smoking history  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia aligned with the typically described risk factors for AAA.  Conclusion: Emergent diagnosis and intervention are crucial in managing ruptured AAA; a condition carrying a high mortality rate. Assessment of risk factors and prompt  targeted management can facilitate good outcomes. Comprehensive post-operative care is important  especially for complications such as renal failure secondary to prolonged perioperative hypotension. Despite notable risk factors and serious complications  Mr. Jones' case demonstrated successful AAA rupture management.

Case Report: An Uncommon Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-Year-Old Female Patient  Abstract: We report an atypical case of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) presented in a 68-year-old woman  primarily asymptomatic  before identifying the condition during a routine medical check-up. Given the prevalence of AAAs in older men  this case seizes attention due to the patient's gender and unusual symptomatology.   Patient Information: The patient  a 68-year-old Caucasian female  retired schoolteacher  presented during a routine medical check-up. She had no immediate significant complaints. Her body mass index was within the healthy range and she was nonsmoking. She was not a known case of hypertension  diabetes  or any other cardiovascular disease.   Clinical Findings: On physical examination  a slight pulsatile mass was felt in the epigastric area. No pain  discomfort  or other signs of compression symptoms were reported. There was no history of known familial AAA cases.   Diagnostic Assessments: A routine abdominal ultrasound for the unidentified mass led to the suggestion an AAA suspicion. A subsequent computed tomography (CT) angiogram confirmed the diagnosis  revealing a 5.5 cm infrarenal AAA. The aneurysm did not appear to have any signs of rupture or leak.  Therapeutic Interventions: After discussing the risks and benefits with the patient  she elected for surgical repair. Open AAA repair was done successfully without any complications  and the patient was found to be stable post-operatively.  Follow Up and Outcomes: Post-surgical healing was uneventful. The patient was followed up at 1  3  and 6 months with CT scans that showed no aneurysmal change or post-operative complications. She was additionally educated about the importance of regular follow-up consults and monitoring of her cardiovascular health status.  Lessons Learnt: Though AAA is typically symptomatic in most cases  the asymptomatic nature of this patient’s condition  along with her female gender  underpins the importance of routine checks in older individuals to detect the disorder  preventing potential life-threatening complications. It also highlights the crucial role of physicians in physical exam skills and the value of a structured primary care follow-up.  Conclusion: AAAs are more common in older men  but this report underlines that females can also manifest the disease. Clinicians should be aware of this possibility and engage in thorough physical examinations in all patients  irrespective of age and gender  particularly in the primary care setting. Additionally  AAA screening may be beneficial in asymptomatic individuals over the age of 65  especially if they possess other risk factors.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Female Patient: A Case Report  Introduction:  This case report pertains to an elderly female patient with a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) which is typically a disease of older adults with a median age of occurrence of 76.4 years and predominantly affects males (McCaul et al.  2017). Nevertheless  cases in females do occur  as this report will elucidate.  Patient Presentation:  Mrs. J.  a 78-year-old Caucasian female  presented in the emergency department with severe pain in the lower back and abdominal area  along with nausea  vomiting  and light-headedness. She reported that the pain was sudden in onset  sharp  and radiating to her left leg. The patient had a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia and was a former smoker  having quit 15 years earlier. There was no known family history of aortic disease.  Clinical Findings:  On examination  her blood pressure was 80/50 mmHg  heart rate of 110 beats per minute  and she had a tender and pulsatile abdomen. An urgent abdominal ultrasonography revealed a 7.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. Subsequent computed tomography angiography confirmed a ruptured AAA.  Treatment and Outcome:  Due to the forthcoming risk of imminent rupture  Mrs. J. was immediately taken to the operating theater where she underwent endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) as an urgent procedure. Postoperative recovery was uneventful  and the patient was discharged from the hospital on the tenth post-operative day.  Discussion:  AAA rupture is a life-threatening condition with high mortality and morbidity rates. Risk factors for AAA include advanced age  male sex  smoking  Caucasians  and a family history of AAA. This case emphasizes the importance of considering and promptly diagnosing AAA in elderly patients  irrespective of gender  presenting with abdominal or back pain and unstable hemodynamics  as timely intervention with surgery or EVAR can be lifesaving.  Learning Points:  - AAA should be included in the differential diagnosis in any older patient who presents with acute abdominal or back pain. - Risk factors such as hypertension  hyperlipidemia  former smoking  and Caucasian ethnicity  although less common  can predispose females to AAA. - Timely surgical intervention is paramount in achieving a favorable prognosis in ruptured AAA cases.  References:  McCaul  K. A.  Lawrence-Brown  M. M.  Dickinson  J. A.  & Norman  P. E. (2017). Long term outcomes of abdominal aortic aneurysm in the elderly and octogenarians: a systematic review and meta-analysis. BMC Cardiovascular Disorders  17(1)  156.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information:   A 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired  and a current resident of Boston  Massachusetts was admitted at the Emergency Department of our hospital for reporting of sudden  severe abdominal and lower back pain.  History of Present Illness:  The patient reported that he began experiencing a sharp  intense pain that started from his abdomen and travelled down to his lower back two hours before arriving at the hospital. He also noted occasional lightheadedness  nausea  and an increase in heart rate upon the onset of the symptoms.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a medical history of stage 2 hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and 30 pack-years of smoking  having quit ten years ago. He stated that he has been compliant with his blood pressure and cholesterol medications. There is no history of any kidney diseases  diabetes mellitus  lung diseases  or any kind of cancer. His family history includes a paternal uncle who had an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Physical Examination and Diagnostic Tests:  On physical examination  the patient appeared to be in moderate distress  pale  and diaphoretic. His blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg  pulse rate 110 beats per minute  and respiratory rate was 20 breaths per minute. On palpation  a pulsatile mass was detected in the midline of the abdomen.  Ultrasound was immediately performed  confirming the presence of a large abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring at least 5.6cm in diameter. CT angiography demonstrated an infrarenal aortic aneurysm with minimal mural thrombosis and no evidence of rupture.  Management:  The severity of the patient's symptoms along with the size of the aneurysm warranted immediate surgical intervention. An emergency endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) was performed successfully without any major complications.  Conclusion:  This case illustrates an elderly Caucasian male with significant risk factors - hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a past of prolific smoking  presenting with an AAA. It highlights the importance of early recognition and immediate surgical intervention in a large  symptomatic AAA in preventing catastrophic outcomes like rupture and death. Furthermore  it emphasizes the significance of screening and monitoring for AAA in populations enriched with risk factors to halt the progression of the disease with early intervention.  DISCLAIMER: This case report is purely fictional and created for constructive discussion only. It does not replace or represent any form of professional medical advice. Any resemblance to actual persons  living or dead  is purely coincidental.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information Name: Patient X Age: 67 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer  Presenting Complaints Chief complaints included occasional abdominal discomfort and intermittent lower back pain for the past two weeks.  Medical History Patient has a documented history of hypertension and high cholesterol levels for the past ten years. He has been a smoker for the last 35 years and reported heavy alcohol consumption in his younger years. The patient is also known to be positive for peripheral artery disease but is not diabetic. There is no family history of AAA (Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm).  Physical Examination On physical examination  the patient was generally well-looking  not in acute distress  and was afebrile. Pulse felt rapid  and blood pressure was elevated at 178/90 mmHg. The abdomen was soft  non-distended with an audible bruit on auscultation and a pulsatile mass palpated in the periumbilical area.  Investigations Abdominal ultrasound revealed an infrarenal aortic aneurysm  measuring approximately 5.3 cm in diameter. Further verification through a computed tomography angiogram (CTA) showed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with no evidence of rupture.  Diagnosis Patient X was clinically diagnosed to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Management The case's surgical nature was discussed with the patient and consent was obtained. The patient was successfully managed via endovascular repair (EVAR) of the abdominal aortic aneurysm. He was prescribed antihypertensive medication to control his blood pressure postoperatively and advised on lifestyle changes such as smoking cessation  healthy diet  and regular exercise.  Conclusion This case report illustrates a patient who had risk factors such as old age  male sex  hypertension  smoking  and a history of peripheral artery disease which are associated with AAA. The regular monitoring  early diagnosis  and management of AAA are crucial in preventing rupture and reducing mortality.  Informed Consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient for the case report and any accompanying images. A copy of the written consent is available for review by the Editor-in-Chief of this journal on request.  Data Availability Statement: All data generated or analyzed during this case report are included in the published article.

Title: A Case of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-Year-Old Male with a History of Hypertension   Introduction:  This case report presents a 68-year-old Caucasian male diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) after presenting with persistent abdominal and back pain.   Patient Information:  The patient is a retired construction worker living in the Midwest region of the United States and a father of two adult children. He has a known history of hypertension  and his family history is significant for cardiovascular disease (CVD)  with his father succumbing to a myocardial infarction in his early 60s. He has been an active smoker for over 40 years and consumes minimal alcohol. The patient's BMI is slightly high  pegged at 28 kg/m2  which is within the overweight range.   Clinical Findings:  For the past two weeks  the patient complained of a constant dull ache in the middle of his abdomen  which occasionally radiates to his back. The pain intensified when he changed his body position. He reported no changes in his bowel habits  no weight loss  and no symptoms of ischemia.  On examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpated. Auscultation revealed bruit in the peri-umbilical region. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable  with no signs of peripheral arterial disease.  Diagnostic Assessment:  An abdominal ultrasound revealed a 7cm infrarenal abdominal aorta aneurysm with no sign of rupture. His lipid profile showed borderline high low-density lipoprotein (LDL) levels. The renal function test results were normal.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The patient was referred for repair of the detected AAA as the diameter was >5.5cm  thus falling under the guideline-recommended threshold for surgical intervention. Given his reasonable physiological status  an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) was the chosen form of intervention. Antihypertensives were prescribed to manage his blood pressure  and lifestyle modifications were recommended  including smoking cessation  a heart-healthy diet  and regular exercise.  Follow-up and Outcome:  The patient did well post-operatively  with no complications during hospitalization. Regular follow-ups are scheduled to monitor blood pressure control and aneurysm repair. The patient and his family have initiated changes related to lifestyle modifications.  Patient Perspective:  The patient expressed relief with the management of his condition and was grateful for early detection of his aneurysm before any severe consequences could occur due to rupture. He acknowledged the need for lifestyle change and was determined to quit smoking.   Conclusion:  This case highlights the significance of timely AAA detection in patients  especially with associated risk factors like older age  male gender  hypertension  smoking  CVD family history  and being overweight. With successful surgical intervention and lifestyle modifications  the prognosis for AAA can be significantly improved.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a High-Risk  Elderly Patient  Patient Profile: Demographic information includes an 82-year-old Caucasian male who has a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  a 40-year history of smoking  and a family history of cardiovascular disease. He is a retired industrial worker  widowed  living alone  and does not consume alcohol. He adheres to his prescribed medication regimen to control his hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Presenting Complaints: The patient presented to the Emergency Department experiencing severe  sudden onset of back pain radiating to the lower abdomen. He reported associated symptoms of nausea  vomiting  feeling faint  and shortness of breath.  Clinical Findings: Physical examination revealed a moderately distressed elderly man with a blood pressure of 80/60 mmHg and a heart rate of 102 beats per minute. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the periumbilical area  which was tender on palpation. Distal pulses were weak. The patient's overall medical assessment revealed a frail individual with limitations in activities of daily living  living in social isolation  minimal instrumental support  mood disorders  and cognitive impairment.  Diagnostic Assessment: Primary investigations included a complete blood profile  renal function test  and urinalysis  which were mostly within normal limits aside from modest kidney function impairment. An urgent abdominal ultrasound confirmed the presence of a 7.5cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. Computed tomography angiogram evidenced the rupture of the aneurysm with a retroperitoneal hematoma.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately started on intravenous fluid resuscitation and underwent emergency endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). Post-procedural recovery was uneventful  with the patient being shifted to Intensive Care Unit (ICU) for close monitoring.  Follow-up: The patient was discharged two weeks post-surgery with instructions for home care and a follow-up appointment with the vascular outpatient clinic. He was also referred to the smoking cessation clinic and directed towards the community elder care program. The patient was advised on the implementation of a heart-healthy diet and medication compliance.  Conclusion: This case demonstrates the typical representation of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  especially among the elderly male smoker population with hypertension. It underscores the importance of timely diagnosis  immediate treatment  and post-treatment care. AAA case detection can be implemented through routine physical examination and ultrasound screening  especially in high-risk populations. Interventions such as smoking cessation  dietary changes  and blood pressure management are pivotal for the prognosis of AAA.

Title: Case Report: An Incidentally Found Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 70-Year-Old African American Male  Patient Description:  The patient is a 70-year-old African American male  retired construction worker  who visited the clinic for a routine checkup. He has a history of hypertension and was a former smoker  having quit smoking about 18 years ago.   Chief Complaint: The patient complained of mild intermittent leg cramps which he associated with aging and his job's physical demand. He denied recent changes in symptoms  specially any abdominal pain or back pain. He didn't mention any recent weight loss  fever  chills  or any other constitutional symptoms.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a 35-year history of hypertension  which is currently managed with Lisinopril 20mg daily. He quit smoking 18 years ago but has a 30-pack-year smoking history before that. The patient doesn’t have diabetes or hypercholesterolemia  and he had no known personal or family history of cardiovascular disease or aneurysm. He also has a laboratory-confirmed history of persistent low-level lipid elevation.  Interim Clinical Examination:  A physical exam revealed a blood pressure of 145/95 mm Hg  a pulse of 78 bpm  and a body mass index of 28 kg/m2. The patient's abdomen was soft and non-tender without any visible pulsatile mass; however  auscultation revealed a subtle bruit over his lower abdomen  which prompted an abdominal ultrasound.  Investigations: The abdominal ultrasound demonstrated a dilated abdominal aorta of 4 cm in diameter  indicative of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The findings were later confirmed by a contrast-enhanced CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis  which better delineated the extent of the aneurysm.  Diagnosis: The patient was diagnosed with an asymptomatic Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm.   Treatment: Given the size of the aneurysm and the patient's age  elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) was recommended over open surgical repair. The patient was referred to a vascular surgeon and received proper preoperative evaluation and counseling.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of careful physical examination in an asymptomatic patient and underlines the significance of regularly monitoring high-risk individuals like African American men  with a history of hypertension and smoking  in early detection and management of abdominal aortic aneurysm. The case also suggests the valuable role of a multidisciplinary approach in managing complex patients for elective procedures like EVAR.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a Seventy-year-old Caucasian Male   Patient Overview:  Mr. X is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  living in an urban area. He is a retired engineer  and he lives with his wife. His BMI is within normal limits (24.9)  and he maintains regular physical activity. He smokes a pack of cigarettes a day and drinks an occasional beer. He has a personal history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  treated with Hydrochlorothiazide 25mg daily and Atorvastatin 20mg daily  respectively.  Clinical Presentation:  Mr. X presented to the emergency department complaining of a sudden  severe abdominal pain radiating to the back. He also reported feeling lightheaded with increased pain on walking  but no syncope. He had no past record of any abdominal pain  and there was no significant reported trauma. He denied any changes in appetite  weight  or bowel habits.  Clinical Examination and Diagnosis:  On examination  Mr. X's blood pressure was 150/85mmHg  heart rate 110 beats per minute  temperature 98.6°F  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. Upon palpation  an abdominal mass with a pulsativity was noticed. A bruit was also heard on auscultation over the mass. The remainder of the abdominal examination and other system examination findings were unremarkable.  An ultrasound examination of the abdomen demonstrated a large abdominal aortic aneurysm sized approximately 7.5 cm. A contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen confirmed the ultrasound findings and ruled out rupture of the aneurysm.  Given the size and the ongoing pain  Mr. X was diagnosed with a symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Management:  Mr. X was immediately referred to vascular surgery. The surgeons performed an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). Postoperatively  he was transferred to the intensive care unit for close monitoring.  Outcome and Follow-up:  His postoperative period was uneventful  and he was discharged home on the fifth postoperative day with prescriptions for antihypertensives and statins. He was advised to quit smoking and limit alcohol intake. He was scheduled for regular follow-up visits. His latest repeat ultrasound  three months post-discharge  shows no abnormalities.  Discussion:  This case highlights the need for high clinical suspicion in diagnosing AAA  especially in elderly males with relevant risk factors such as smoking  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. The sudden onset of severe abdominal pain radiating to the back should raise the suspicion of AAA  even in the absence of hypotension or shock. Early diagnosis and prompt management of AAA is crucial to prevent life-threatening complications such as rupture of the aneurysm. The follow-up is also vital to monitor any recurrence or other complications.  Conclusion:  Close attention to the clinical symptoms  examining the past medical history  and accurate diagnostic tools conduce towards the early and successful management of abdominal aortic aneurysm  which can be life-saving for patients like Mr. X.

Title: A Case Report of a Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Hispanic Male  Patient Information: The patient is a 75-year-old previously healthy Hispanic male  retired  and living independently. He is a non-smoker  drinks alcohol occasionally  and has no known drug allergies. He does not have any family history of cardiovascular disease or abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Presenting Concerns: The patient presented at the emergency room with sudden onset of severe  tearing  and constant lower abdominal and back pain. He was sweating excessively  and complained of light-headedness and nausea.  Clinical Findings: On examination  the patient was pale and in distress. His blood pressure was 90/60 mmHg and pulse rate was 110 beats per minute. Abdominal examination revealed marked tenderness  especially in the mid and lower abdomen which was also distended. A bruit was ausculated in the abdomen  and pulsatile abdominal mass was palpable.  Diagnostic Assessment: Urgent bedside ultrasound showed an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring approximately 6 cm  with signs indicating rupture. Computed tomography angiography (CTA) confirmed the diagnosis by revealing a large infrarenal AAA  and a large hematoma suggesting a ruptured aneurysm.  Therapeutic Intervention: Immediate surgical consultation was done and the patient underwent emergency open repair of the ruptured AAA  with implantation of a Dacron aortic graft.  Follow-Up and Outcomes: His postoperative course was complicated by wound infection which was managed by regular dressing and antibiotic therapy. The patient demonstrated a gradual recovery over a period of six weeks. He was discharged with advice to follow up at the vascular clinic.  Patient Perspective: Although the patient initially felt quite shaken and overwhelmed by the sudden onset of severe symptoms and quick escalation to surgery  he was grateful for the immediate medical care which saved his life. He expressed commitment to adhere to all follow-up appointments and lifestyle modifications guided by his physicians.  Discussion: This case represents a typical presentation of a ruptured AAA  a condition with a high rate of morbidity and mortality. AAA is characterized by a lack of symptoms until rupture  emphasizing the importance of early screening  especially in high-risk groups  including males aged over 65 years and those with a family history. Creating awareness of the risk factors and symptoms associated with AAA in primary care can lead to early identification and surgical repair  potentially reducing the mortality and morbidity associated with this life-threatening condition.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Demographics  Patient's Name: [Redacted for confidentiality]  Gender: Male  Age: 72 years  Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired  Presenting Issue  The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of severe abdominal pain  which had been ongoing for several hours before his arrival. He described the pain as a sharp  tearing sensation in his mid-abdominal area and radiating to his lower back.  Medical History  The patient's medical history includes hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 45-year history of smoking (two packs a day  although he quit smoking ten years prior). The patient has been treated for both hypertension and hyperlipidemia with regular medications  including a beta-blocker and a statin  respectively.   He underwent a surgical operation five years ago for a right inguinal hernia and was diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) three years ago. The patient has no known allergies and no familial history of aneurysms.   Examination Findings  On physical examination  the patient appeared uncomfortable due to the pain. He was normotensive  but tachycardic with a pulse rate of 110 beats per minute. A pulsatile abdominal mass was palpable on examination  and his pain intensified with palpation.  Upon lab investigation  his renal and liver function tests were normal  with slightly elevated white blood cell count indicating possible infection. The electrocardiogram demonstrated no signs of ischemia  and chest radiography showed mild and consistent signs with COPD.  Diagnosis and Management  The clinical examination findings along with the patient's long history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking strongly indicated an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). A subsequent computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen confirmed an infrarenal AAA measuring 8 cm in diameter with signs of impending rupture.  Given the size and the symptoms of the AAA  emergency surgery was coordinated. The patient underwent successful open surgical repair of the AAA with a Dacron graft.  Conclusion  This case underscores the importance of considering AAA in the differential diagnosis  particularly in elderly male patients with a long history of smoking  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  presenting with acute abdominal pain radiating to the back. Early recognition and intervention significantly improve outcomes for patients with AAA.  Trends in the demographic data in literature have demonstrated that AAA is more common in males  Caucasians  those over 65  and those with a history of smoking  which are all applicable to this case.

Title: A Case of Asymptomatic Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 74-year-old Male  Introduction:  This is a case report on a 74-year-old Caucasian male presenting with an asymptomatic infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The patient had no history of AAA or other aortic diseases and was referred to our clinic as part of a routine medical examination after the AAA was discovered.  Case Presentation: The patient  an active man of European descent  is a retired teacher with past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is an ex-smoker  having quit smoking 20 years ago but his cumulative smoking pack years is calculated at 40 pack-years. He consumes alcohol occasionally  with a frequency of about once per fortnight. He had no family history of AAA or any other connective tissue disorders.  Clinically  he did not exhibit any signs or symptoms suggestive of AAA such as abdominal  back or groin pain  pulsating feeling in the abdomen  or unexplained weight loss. Physical examination revealed a normotensive  non-diabetic man with no palpable abdominal mass or bruit.   A routine abdominal ultrasound screening showed an infrarenal AAA measuring 4.5cm in maximal diameter. No signs of rupture  leaking  or dissection were noted. The discomfort-free status of the patient with the absence of urgent symptoms prompted a non-emergency approach to management.  Management: The patient was informed about the diagnosis and was educated about the risk factors and potential complications of AAA. Given the size of the aneurysm  in conjunction with current literature recommending repair for AAA sized 5.5 cm or larger  the patient was kept under active surveillance with repetitive ultrasound screening every six months. He was advised to monitor any sudden onset of abdominal pain. Aggressive management of his hypertension and hyperlipidemia was stressed  and he was advised to maintain a well-balanced diet  regular physical exercise  and good lifestyle.  Conclusion: This case points highlight the prevalence of AAA among elderly male patients with a history of smoking  even if it was in the distant past. It emphasizes the utility of abdominal ultrasound screening in asymptomatic elderly men for the early detection of AAA  allowing non-emergency management of such patients.  A collaborative approach involving the patient  primary care physician  and vascular surgeon is crucial in managing asymptomatic AAA cases. This includes maintaining a healthy lifestyle  monitoring signs of AAA progression  and timely follow-up assessments.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) in Elderly Male Patient: A Case Report  Patient Profile:  The patient  a 75-year-old African American male  was presented to the emergency department with a complaint of severe  sudden onset of abdominal and back pain. His past medical history included hypertension  hyperlipidemia  tobacco use  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. Prior to the presenting symptoms  the patient had no known history of aneurysm in the family.  Clinical Presentation: On physical examination  he was found to be in distress with a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg and a heart rate of 110 bpm. He complained of severe abdominal pain centralized around the umbilical area radiating to the back coupled with dizziness and an episode of fainting. A pulsatile abdominal mass was recognized upon palpation.  Diagnostic Approach: An emergency ultrasound was performed  which indicated a large abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). A Computed Tomography Angiogram (CTA) was performed next  revealing a 7.4 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with findings suggestive of imminent rupture  thereby validating the initial AAA suspicion.  Treatment: Emergency surgery was conducted under the consideration of patient's age  overall health status  and the size of the aneurysm. The surgical team decided on an endovascular aortic repair (EVAR). A stent graft was placed within the aneurysm to isolate the aneurysm from blood flow and reduce the risk of rupture.  Follow-up: Post-surgery  he was admitted to the ICU where he was closely monitored for indicative signs of postoperative complications. After a two-week follow-up  the patient reported an improvement in overall health symptoms and well-being and was discharged with prescribed blood pressure medication and a follow-up appointment with the vascular surgery team.  Conclusion: This case underlines the need for vigilance in older patients  particularly those with risk factors such as tobacco use  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  as well as the necessity for timely diagnosis and emergency surgical intervention in cases of AAA. Existing literature suggests the prevalence of AAA is higher in older  Caucasian males; however  this case report contributes to the diversity of demographic knowledge of the disease by showcasing an African American male patient.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile: A 73-year-old Caucasian male reported to the emergency department on June 1  2023  with recurrent  acute  and severe abdominal pain accompanied by occasional lower back pain. The patient also reported persistent lethargy and minor weight loss over the past three months. He is a smoker  with a 50-pack-year smoking history  and also has a reported heavy consumption of alcohol over the last twelve years. The patient had no known allergies.   Relevant Past Medical History: The patient's past medical history included hypertension diagnosed 15 years ago and managed with antihypertensives. He was diagnosed and treated for high cholesterol ten years ago. He was also diagnosed with peripheral artery disease two years prior to the current presentation. There was a family history of cardiovascular diseases - the patient's father suffered from a myocardial infarction  and his elder brother had an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) five years back.  Clinical Presentation: Upon examination  he was alert and orientated. The blood pressure on admission was 160/100 mmHg. During the physical examination  a pulsatile midline mass was felt in the abdomen. Lab testing showed anemia and slightly elevated levels of creatinine and blood urea.  Imaging and Diagnosis: Abdominal ultrasound demonstrated an infrarenal AAA with a maximum diameter of 5.2 cm. The subsequent CT angiogram confirmed the AAA extending from just below the renal arteries to the beginning of the aortic bifurcation  along with evidence of an impending rupture with a small amount of peri-aortic stranding.  Treatment and Follow-Up: The patient was immediately submitted for emergency open repair of his abdominal aortic aneurysm  given the size and signs of potential rupture. The aneurysm was successfully repaired with a polyester  bifurcated aortic graft. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was transferred to the ICU for further management.   Postoperative course was uneventful  and he was discharged 10 days after the operation with prescribed medication for his hypertension  high cholesterol along with smoking and alcohol cessation counselling. The patient has been scheduled for a surveillance CT scan after six months and subsequent annual follow-ups.  This case highlights the potential significance of family history in screening for abdominal aortic aneurysms  particularly in patients with peripheral arterial disease and lifestyle risk factors such as smoking and alcohol use. Though the patient arrived due to non-specific symptoms  the physical exam and past medical history directed the clinical suspicion towards the abdominal aortic aneurysm  which was subsequently confirmed by imaging.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a History of Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia: A Case Report  Introduction:  Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) refers to a localized enlargement of the abdominal aorta exceeding its normal diameter by more than 50 percent. The AAA poses a significant risk to the patient's life if ruptured due to severe sudden internal bleeding  warranting early diagnosis and appropriate management.   Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. S is a 67-year-old Caucasian male who is a retired engineer. He was residing in the urban areas of the Midwest region of the United States with a regular follow-up for chronic health problems. He is a former smoker with a 15-pack-year smoking history  a moderate alcohol consumer  not known to have any drug addiction  and has no known allergies.  Clinical Findings: Mr. S presented to the emergency room with symptoms of moderate  dull-constant abdominal and back pain exacerbated over the past two days. During the examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpated.  Past Medical History: He has high blood pressure and hyperlipidemia controlled with amlodipine 10 mg daily and atorvastatin 40 mg daily  respectively. There is no family history of any aneurysm.  Diagnostic Assessment: A high-index suspicion of AAA prompted an urgent abdominal ultrasound which revealed an infrarenal abdominal aorta with a maximal transverse diameter of 6.5 cm  suggesting an AAA. This was later confirmed with contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) of the abdomen  reported as an infrarenal AAA with no sign of rupture.  Therapeutic Intervention: Due to the size of the aneurysm and the patient's presenting symptoms  urgent surgical repair was advised to prevent rupture risk. The patient underwent open surgical repair (OSR) of the AAA. Intraoperatively  the AAA was confirmed and replaced with a Dacron graft.  Follow-Up and Outcome: Postoperatively  the patient recovered well without any complications. On six months follow-up  a surveillance ultrasound demonstrated that the graft was patent and there was no sign of an aneurysm.  Conclusions:   This case underscores the importance of considering AAA in the differential diagnosis in elderly male patients presenting with abdominal and/or back pain  especially those with risk factors including a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking. Early recognition and timely intervention can effectively reduce morbidity and mortality related to AAA.   Patient Perspective:  Mr. S appreciated the care provided by the team and the successful surgery outcome. He was relieved and motivated to adhere to regular follow-ups and a healthier lifestyle  including a low-fat diet  moderating alcohol consumption  and completely avoiding tobacco.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Caucasian Male: A Case Report  Introduction: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) is a significant health concern  especially in elderly Caucasian males where the prevalence is significantly higher. This case report describes an interesting scenario of a late-presenting AAA in this high-risk demographic.  Patient Information: Mr. X  a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a BMI of 26.8  presented at our hospital. He lives in a nursing home and is a former smoker (30 pack-years) who quit approximately 15 years ago. He was moderately active prior to presentation. His family history is notable for cardiovascular diseases (his father had a myocardial infarction in his late 50s). His past medical history includes controlled hypertension and a history of mild hyperlipidemia.  Clinical Findings: The patient was initially seen for complaints of episodic abdominal discomfort and early satiety over the past few months  not associated with any specific type of food or activity. Over the past few days prior to presentation  he experienced an exacerbation in the severity of the pain  along with the sensation of a throbbing mass in his abdomen. There were no secondary signs or symptoms indicative of rupture such as back pain or hemodynamic instability.  Diagnostic Assessment: A complete blood count and comprehensive metabolic panel were normal. However  due to the clinical suspicion of AAA  an urgent ultrasound was ordered. The ultrasound images demonstrated a fusiform aneurysmal dilation of the infrarenal aorta measuring 5.2 cm in maximal diameter. A subsequent CT angiography confirmed the presence of an AAA with a maximal diameter of 5.5 cm extending from the renal arteries to the aortic bifurcation without evidence of rupture or leak.  Intervention and Outcome: Following a discussion of risks  benefits  and options  the patient underwent endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). The intra-operative period was uneventful  and the AAA was successfully excluded. Postoperatively  he had an uncomplicated course and was discharged home on postoperative day 6. On follow-up in the vascular surgery clinic one month after discharge  he was doing well with resolution of his abdominal pain.  Conclusion: This case report highlights the importance of considering AAA within the differential diagnosis in elderly men presenting with non-specific abdominal symptoms  especially in the presence of risk factors like advanced age  smoking history  and underlying hypertension. Timely interventions like EVAR can potentially prevent catastrophic events such as rupture and subsequently improve the patient outcomes.   Confidentiality: The identity of the patient has been thoroughly anonymized to protect their confidentiality.  Patient Consent: Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.

Patient Profile  Name: [Not specified] Gender: Male Age: 71 years  Race: Caucasian Residential Location: Urban  Case Presentation:  A 71-year-old Caucasian male presented himself to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain  constant  described as tearing and radiating to the back. He also reported sweating and palpitations. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  maintained on medications. There was no family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  the patient appeared in distress  pale  and diaphoretic. Vital records showed a blood pressure of 190/100 mmHg and a heart rate of 110 beats per minute. An abdominal examination revealed a pulsating mass in the abdominal midline. The peripheral pulses were symmetrically present.  Diagnostic Focus and Assessment:  A Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) of the abdomen and pelvis was requested  which demonstrated an AAA measuring 8 cm in maximal diameter with signs of rupture. There were also atherosclerotic changes seen in the iliac vessels.  Therapeutic Focus and Assessment:  Emergency surgery was planned to repair the ruptured AAA. A vascular surgeon immediately conducted an endovascular stent-graft repair. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was shifted to the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) for post-operative care.  Follow-Up and Outcome:  Postoperatively  the patient's recovery was uneventful. His vital signs normalized  and the abdominal pain subsided in the next few days. The patient was discharged from the hospital on the 10th postoperative day  with instructions on lifestyle modifications  including a low cholesterol diet and regular physical activity. Regular follow-up was scheduled for the patient at one month  three months  and six months to monitor the efficacy of the stent-graft and his overall health status.  Patient Perspective:  The patient was initially anxious and concerned about the severity of his condition. After having been given a thorough explanation of his condition and surgical procedure's necessity  he felt reassured. He approved of the management plan and thanked the medical team for their rapid response  which he believed saved his life.  To ensure an accurate demographic representation  it is worth mentioning that most AAA cases have been reported in Caucasian males over 65 years old  especially those with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia and a known lifestyle of smoking. These patients typically present with a similar clinical picture of severe abdominal pain and a pulsating mass in the abdominal midline upon palpation.   Informed Consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient for the publication of this case report and any accompanying images. A copy of the written consent is available for review by the Editor of this journal.

Case Report: Management of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a Seventy-year-old Male  I. Patient Demographic Information:   The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male residing in a rural area in the U.S Midwest. He is married  has two children  and is a retiree from a construction company. He has limited physical internet access and healthcare facilities. His primary language is English  and he has an income below the national average.  II. Medical History:  The patient has been managing hypertension for 15 years and was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus five years ago. He is also a former smoker with a quitting history spanning 10 years. He has hyperlipidemia and a family history of cardiovascular disease - his father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 66. Despite these conditions  the patient has been making steady improvements in managing his conditions through changes to his diet  increased physical activity  and medication adherence.  III. Presenting Complaint and Examination:  The patient presented with episodes of abdominal back pain over the past three weeks. He reports that pain usually lasts several minutes and subsides without any intervention. On examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was detected slightly towards the left of the midline. He denied chest pain  shortness of breath  or loss of consciousness.  IV. Investigations:  Considering the age  medical history  and physical exam findings of the patient  an abdominal ultrasound was conducted. This revealed an infra-renal abdominal aortic aneurysm with a maximal diameter of 5.5cm. His blood pressure was elevated at 155/95 mmHg  and his glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) was 7.2%  indicating a modestly controlled diabetes condition. His lipid profile showed raised Low-Density Lipoprotein Cholesterol (LDL-C) at 145 mg/dL.  V. Management:  Given the size of the aneurysm and the patient’s symptomatic status  the decision was made to perform elective surgery to prevent rupture. The procedure carried out was an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) due to his age and comorbidities. His hypertension and hyperlipidemia were also further managed via adequate control of blood pressure and statin therapy  respectively.  VI. Outcome:  The surgery was successful  and the patient remained stable throughout the post-operative period. He was advised to continue his blood pressure and cholesterol-lowering medications and achieve better control of his diabetes. Lifelong surveillance of his aneurysm via regular ultrasound monitoring every 6 months was also planned. The patient was advised about the symptomatic warning signs (sudden abdominal or back pain) that should prompt immediate medical attention.  This case emphasizes the crucial challenge of managing an abdominal aortic aneurysm in a patient with multiple comorbid conditions  in a remote geographical location  with socioeconomic restrictions. It also underscores the essential role of personalized care and remote monitoring in managing such complicated scenarios.

Title: Asymptomatic Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male: A Case Report  1. Patient Information:  A 72-year-old Caucasian male patient was presented to the outpatient department of our hospital. The patient doesn’t have any known case of allergy. He is married with three adult children and is a retired engineer. The patient has an active lifestyle and does not smoke or consume alcohol. He does not have a family history of cardiovascular diseases.  2. Clinical Findings:  The patient visited the hospital for a routine health check-up. He had no presenting symptoms or complaints related to cardiovascular or respiratory function. However  he reported occasional episodes of mild abdominal discomfort.  3. Timeline:  The mild stomach discomfort has been ongoing for the past six months. He generally noticed it post meals and didn't associate with any specific food or activity. The patient didn't lay emphasis on these symptoms due to their mild nature and infrequent occurrence.  4. Diagnostic Assessment:  The physical examination of the lungs and heart was normal; the abdomen was soft with a palpable pulsatile mass in the center. Initial suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was suggested. Therefore  an abdominal ultrasound was performed  revealing a 6.5cm diameter AAA. No other abnormalities or health concerns were detected during the body examination.  An electrocardiogram (ECG) was also performed  which demonstrated normal sinus rhythm  and routine blood tests were all within normal limits. The patient was then referred for a CT angiography to better visualize the extent of the aneurysm.  5. Therapeutic Interventions:  Considering the aneurysm size and the patient's overall health  an elective open aneurysm repair surgery  a standard procedure for AAA of diameter larger than 5.5cm  was recommended by the vascular surgeon. The patient concurred with the recommendation after discussing the complication risks associated with the condition and its surgical repair.  6. Follow-up and Outcomes:  The AAA repair was performed successfully without any complications. The patient was discharged on the seventh postoperative day. He has been under observation with regular follow-ups at three  six  and twelve months intervals. So far  there have been no signs of AAA recurrence or surgical complications. The patient continues to report improvement and is satisfied with the course of treatment.  7. Patient Perspectives:  The patient expressed satisfaction regarding his overall treatment and gratefulness for the detection of an otherwise asymptomatic AAA through routine health checkups.  8. Teaching Points:  This case highlights the importance of routine health check-up  especially for the elderly  and how asymptomatic illnesses can be detected timely and managed effectively. An asymptomatic AAA  if undetected  could have led to a significant health event in the patient. However  due to early detection  the patient received the necessary surgical correction and is doing well.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 72-Year Old Male: A Case Report  Introduction: Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a common condition among older adults  especially males over the age of 65. It is characterized by localized enlargement of the abdominal aorta. Though common  AAA is a fatal condition if ruptured due to high mortality rates. Here  we present a case of a 72-year-old male who was diagnosed with an AAA.   Patient Information: The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male from the suburbs  retired  and living with his wife. His body weight is 68 kg and a height of 173 cm. He is a former smoker and has quit smoking for about 15 years.   Health History: The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are controlled with medications. No significant family history was elicited related to cardiovascular diseases. He was physically active and his diet was relatively healthy although he occasionally enjoyed a high cholesterol diet.  Presenting Complaints: The patient visited his primary care physician for a routine check-up. He complained of a subtle  nagging abdominal pain and mild lower back pain for the past two weeks. He described the pain as dull and constant but tolerable. No other symptoms like rapid heart rate  shortness of breath  or noticeable weight loss were reported.  Diagnosis and Treatment: Based on the patient’s age  history  and symptoms  an abdominal ultrasound scan was recommended  and the results revealed a 6cm aneurysm in the abdominal aorta. A computed tomography angiogram (CTA) was also performed to confirm the diagnosis and revealed a fusiform infrarenal AAA measuring 6.2 cm with relatively intact and healthy-looking arterial walls.   Given the measure of the aneurysm and the symptomatic presentation  our vascular surgery team decided to operate. The patient underwent successful endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR).   Follow-Up and Outcome: The patient was monitored post-operation in the hospital for 48 hours  during which his recovery went well without complications. On a 3-month follow-up visit  a reassessment abdominal ultrasound indicated no expansion of the aneurysm  no endoleaks and the patient was symptom-free. The patient was advised to continue managing his hypertension and hyperlipidemia  quit a high cholesterol diet fully and to continue staying physically active.  Informed Consent: Written and informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.   Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of recognizing potential symptoms of AAA  especially in older male patients. Regular monitoring and timely intervention are crucial to prevent the fatal consequences of a ruptured aneurysm. Furthermore  it underscores the relation of AAA with hypertension and hyperlipidemia  emphasizing the need for proper management of these conditions in older adults.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male: A Case Report   Introduction: This report highlights the case of a 76-year-old Caucasian male with a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Patient Information: Mr. A  a 76-year-old Caucasian man  a retired steelworker from Ohio presented to the emergency department complaining of severe  sudden onset pain in his lower back and abdomen along with generalized weakness.  Clinical Findings: Mr. A appeared pale and sweaty  with a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg  and a pulse rate of 110 bpm. On physical examination  he had a tender pulsatile mass in his abdomen with referred pain radiating to his back.   Medical History: His past medical history revealed that he was a smoker for about 50 years  had hypertension controlled with medication  and had a known diagnosis of AAA for last 5 years which was being monitored regularly. He also had a family history of AAA. However  due to low patient compliance  the regular check-ups pertaining to his AAA were sporadic.   Diagnostic Assessment: An urgent abdominal ultrasound and subsequent computed tomography (CT) scan confirmed the rupture of an 8 cm abdominal aortic aneurysm with a surrounding hematoma.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was introduced to emergency open repair surgery. The aneurysm was replaced with a synthetic graft  and the hematoma was evacuated.  Follow-Up and Outcome: Mr. A’s postoperative recovery was complicated by pneumonia and acute renal failure. However  with a multiple disciplinary team approach involving cardiologists  nephrologists  pulmonologists  and physical therapists  he was able to make a slow recovery over the course of three months in the hospital. At his six months follow-up  the graft was intact and he was back to his usual health.  Conclusion: This case emphasizes the importance of regular monitoring of known abdominal aortic aneurysms in high-risk patients  especially those over the age of 65  with a history of smoking and cardiovascular diseases. Punctual health surveillance can prevent catastrophic events like rupture  which significantly increases mortality rates  despite successful surgical interventions.   Keywords: abdominal aortic aneurysm  rupture  elderly patient  surgery  hypertension  smoking.

Title: An Incidentally Discovered Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an 80-year-old African-American Male  Introduction: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) is a common vascular ailment affecting around 3-10% of older adults globally. However  there's noticeably limited literature documenting cases among the African-American population which makes this unique case particularly worth discussing. This report presents an intriguing case of an asymptomatic 80-year-old African-American male with an incidentally discovered abdominal aortic aneurysm.   Case Presentation: The patient is an 80-year-old African-American male  non-smoker  with a past medical history that includes well-controlled hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and benign prostatic hyperplasia. He is a retired teacher  living independently  with a history of former social drinking and no drug abuse. He reported to the outpatient department for a routine check-up as part of his follow-up care for hypertension and diabetes. He exhibited no complaints of abdominal pain  back pain or recent weight loss.   On physical examination  the patient appeared comfortable with a BMI of 28. Vital signs were all within normal limits. No abdominal pulsatile masses were palpated during the routine abdominal examinations. The cardiovascular review was also unremarkable.  Due to his history of hypertension  and as part of a comprehensive geriatric assessment  the physician ordered an abdominal ultrasonography. The ultrasound incidentally revealed an infra-renal AAA  measuring 5.5 cm in largest diameter. The patient was immediately referred to a vascular surgeon for further management.  The patient underwent a successful elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). After a hospital stay of 5 days  he was discharged to home with appropriate pain control  with instructions to return in 6 weeks for a follow-up CT angiogram to assess the durability of the repair.  Conclusion: This case illustrates the essential role of routine physical examination and a comprehensive geriatric assessment for the early detection of vascular conditions such as AAA in elderly patients  even in the absence of risk factors such as smoking or Caucasian race. The unexpected diagnosis in this asymptomatic 80-year-old African-American male underscores the necessity for an index of suspicion for AAA in the elderly population regardless of race and typical risk factors. Moreover  it emphasizes the effectiveness of EVAR as a less invasive modality in the successful treatment of AAA.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-year-old Male Patient  Patient Information: A 68-year-old Caucasian male was admitted to the Emergency Department (ED) with symptoms of intense abdominal pain  back pain and general malaise. The patient has a known past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia and 30 years of smoking  with an estimated cumulative exposure of 45 pack-years. He had successfully quit the habit approximately five years earlier. He also reported a familial history of aneurysms  with his father having died from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at the age of 72. The patient lives independently and admits to a sedentary lifestyle with minimal physical activities.  Clinical Findings: The patient looks pale and is in considerable distress  reporting constant  severe  and pulsatile abdominal and back pain. Initial vital signs reveal a blood pressure of 110/64 mmHg  pulse 112 beats per minute  and a respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute. On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass is palpable.  Diagnostic Assessment: Given his symptoms and family history  an immediate abdominal ultrasound was conducted in the ED  and it revealed an AAA with a maximum diameter of 8.5 cm  with signs of rupture. Full blood count showed normocytic normochromic anemia with hemoglobin levels at 9.7 g/dL. Renal function tests and liver function tests were within normal range.  Therapeutic Intervention: After immediate consultation with the vascular surgery team  an emergency repair was performed through Endovascular Aneurysm Repair (EVAR). The procedure was successful  and no immediate postoperative complications were observed.  Follow-up and Outcomes: The patient's hemodynamic status remained stable post-surgery  and he was transferred out of intensive care on day 3 post-op. He was discharged on the 8th postoperative day. Received routine follow-ups at outpatient clinic showed no signs of endoleak or AAA recurrence. The patient was also counseled on the importance of lifestyle alterations including diet modification and incorporation of regular physical activities to keep his hypertension and hyperlipidemia under control.  Patient's Perspective: The patient expressed relief at having survived a life-threatening condition his father succumbed to. He was grateful for the speedy diagnosis and effective treatment. He mentioned his intention to follow medical advice on lifestyle modifications and attend regular check-ups with diligence.  Final Note: This case demonstrates the need for heightened vigilance in patients with significant risk factors such as advanced age  hypertension  smoking history and family history of AAAs. Quick diagnosis and appropriate management in such rapidly progressing  life-threatening situations can substantially improve patient outcomes.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a Caucasian Male  Introduction: The abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  an enlargement or bulge that develops in the wall of the aorta  remains one of the most potentially life-threatening vascular diseases due to the risk of rupture. In most cases  it is asymptomatic until rupture leading to high mortality rates. Studies consistently show that males  particularly those of the Caucasian race  older than 65 and those with a history of smoking  are at most risk.  Case Description:  A 71-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department complaining of sudden onset of intense pain in his lower back and abdomen  along with dizziness and increasing fatigue. He reported a history of hypertension  moderate renal impairment  and had been a smoker for about 35 years but had quit 10 years earlier.  His vital signs showed blood pressure slightly high at 140/92 mmHg in the right arm and 138/91 mmHg in the left arm. His heart rate was 83 beats per minute and respiratory rate was 19 breaths per minute. BMI was recorded as 26 kg/m2. Upon physical examination  a pulsatile mass was palpable in the abdomen.  The patient was sent immediately for computed tomography angiography which revealed a 7.3 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with evidence of a contained rupture. No other aneurysms were present. His laboratory findings showed a hemoglobin of 13.9 g/dL  a white blood cell count of 12.9 x109/L  platelet count of 178 x109/L  serum creatinine of 1.4 mg/dL  and increased levels of D-dimer (1.3 μg/mL).  He was urgently referred to a vascular surgeon who performed an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  considering the patient's symptomatic status and the size of the aneurysm. The postoperative period was uneventful  with recovery and close monitoring of his renal function.  Discussion:  Prompt recognition of AAA symptoms and appropriate investigations probably saved this patient's life. His risk factors (age  gender  race  smoking history  hypertension) should have raised clinical suspicion of an AAA earlier  during routine examinations. AAA screening  aimed primarily at males aged 65-75 years who have ever smoked  may have enabled pre-emptive elective repair  avoiding the significant morbidity and mortality associated with rupture.  Conclusion:  This case report shows the importance of risk factor recognition for AAA and the value of early detection and treatment. Increased awareness and adherence to screening guidelines could contribute to lower AAA mortality rates in the at-risk population. Regular follow-up of patients with moderate renal impairment  especially in those with risk factors for developing AAA  is prudent.

Title: Sudden Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male: A Case Report  Patient Information: An 81-year-old Caucasian male  retired wooden furniture artist  presented to the emergency department (ED) with sudden severe abdominal pain accompanied by back pain. The patient is a resident of a small agricultural town in Iowa  living with his wife.  Clinical Findings: The patient described his pain as sharp and concentrated mainly in the mid-abdominal area with a consistency that radiates to the lower back. The pain intensity was gradually increasing throughout the day. On arrival  his vital signs were stable with a slightly elevated blood pressure of 150/90 mmHg. Physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass.  Patient’s Past Medical and Surgical History: The patient's medical history is significant for hypertension managed with amlodipine for the past 10 years. He also has early-stage chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to a history of long-term smoking but quit about 15 years ago. He has no history of surgeries. The patient denied any family history of cardiovascular diseases; however  he mentioned diabetes on his mother’s side.  Diagnostic Assessment: Given the symptoms and physical findings  suspicion for an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was raised. An urgent abdominal ultrasound was ordered and revealed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 7.5 cm in diameter. Further confirmation was obtained by a Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) scan.  Therapeutic Intervention: Due to the larger size of the AAA and risk of rupture  the patient was immediately scheduled for an emergency open AAA surgical repair. The surgery was successful without post-operative complications.  Follow-up and Outcomes: The patient’s post-operative hospital stay was uneventful. His pain was managed effectively  and vital signs remained stable. A CT scan on post-operative day 3 showed successful repair of the AAA with no signs of leakage or dissection. He was discharged home on post-operative day 5 with optimal recovery. Regular outpatient follow up was arranged for blood pressure control and monitoring of the surgical site via ultrasound imaging.  Patient Perspective: The sudden severe pain worried the patient  yet the immediate care he received and the successful resolution of his situation left him relieved and grateful. He became more aware of AAA and resolved to comply with the prescribed medication regimen and follow-up plans.  Informed Consent: Informed consent was obtained from the patient for the publication of this case report.  Conclusions: This case highlights the crucial need for early detection and intervention in patients presenting with characteristic symptoms of AAA.
