Elderly males with a history of hypertension and smoking  even those living in rural settings  may have a higher risk of AAA and should be counseled and screened appropriately.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Introduction: We present a case of a 66-year-old  Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and heavy smoking  who was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Demographics: The patient is originally from the mid-western region in the United States  with no significant family history of disease apart from his father who had myocardial infarction at the age of 70. He is a retired mechanical engineer  married with two grown-up daughters. He has a 40 pack-year history of smoking but quit six years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally and denies any use of illicit drugs.  Medical History: The patient had been diagnosed with hypertension 12 years ago and hyperlipidemia 15 years ago. His other relevant history included obesity; BMI: 31. Both conditions were managed with medication  namely Amlodipine 10mg for hypertension and Atorvastatin 20mg for hyperlipidemia. There is no history of diabetes  stroke  or other cardiovascular diseases.  Presenting Complaint: The patient attended a routine health check-up in the local health center in March. An abdominal ultrasonography for prostate screening accidentally showed a 4.5 cm infrarenal AAA. The patient was asymptomatic  and there were no notable changes in his weight  appetite  or bowel movements.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient appeared well preserved for his age. His vital signs were within normal range  but blood pressure was slightly higher (150/90 mmHg). Cardiovascular examination revealed normal heart sounds  no murmurs. The abdomen was soft  non-tender  and a pulsatile mass was palpable centrally. No peripheral arterial disease signs were noted.  Investigation: A subsequent CT angiogram confirmed the presence of a 4.5 cm AAA without any sign of rupture or dissection. Lipid panel showed elevated LDL cholesterol of 180 mg/dl. Other laboratory tests including blood count  kidney function  and coagulation were normal.  Management: The patient was referred to a vascular surgeon who recommended conservative management with surveillance because the aneurysm was smaller than 5 cm. He was advised to have an ultrasound examination every 6 months to monitor any aneurysm growth. Also  the patient was encouraged to optimize his hypertension control  continue his statin therapy  adopt a heart-healthy diet  regular exercise  and maintain a healthy weight.  Conclusion: This case exemplifies the importance of routine health screenings  in which an asymptomatic AAA was detected in this high-risk patient due to his age  sex  race  smoking history  and presence of vascular comorbid conditions. The patient is following the recommended surveillance strategy and lifestyle modifications which he embraced fully since the discovery of the aneurysm.

Case Report  Patient Information  We present a case of a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a chief complaint of persistent and sudden-onset abdominal pain of 6 hours duration. The pain was described as severe and radiating to the lower back. The patient also reported a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. No history of trauma or injury was reported. The patient has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 50-pack-year history of tobacco use but quit smoking 10 years ago. A family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was noted  with a brother who died due to ruptured AAA.  Clinical Findings  The physical examination showed a distended abdomen with a palpable pulsatile mass noted in the periumbilical area. There was no sign of peritoneal irritation  and bowel sounds were normoactive. The remainder of the cardiovascular examination was unremarkable  with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops detected. His blood pressure was recorded as 158/95 mmHg and he had a regular pulse with a rate of 72 beats per minute. His respiratory rate was 18 breaths per minute  and his pulse oximetry reading was 96% on room air. The patient appeared anxious and diaphoretic.  Diagnostic Assessment  Due to the clinical suspicion of an AAA  an emergency abdominal ultrasound was performed  which revealed a 6.8 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. Computed tomography (CT) angiography confirmed the presence of an infrarenal AAA with no sign of rupture.  Therapeutic Intervention  Instant consultation with vascular surgery was made. Due to the large size of the AAA along with the presence of symptoms  urgent open surgical repair was planned. Informed consent was obtained from the patient. The procedure was successful and the patient tolerated the procedure well.   Follow-up and Outcome  The patient’s post-operative course was uneventful. He was managed in the Intensive Care Unit for 24 hours post-operatively for close monitoring. He was then transferred to the general ward once he was hemodynamically stable. The patient was discharged 6 days post-operation with advice for regular follow-up. At his 1-month follow-up consultation  he reported significant improvement  with no pain or discomfort.   Informed Consent  The patient included in this study gave written informed consent.   Notes   This case report highlights the need for high index of suspicion for AAA in patients presenting with non-specific abdominal symptoms  especially older male patients  those with a positive family history of AAA  those with known risk factors like smoking  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. Early diagnosis and timely intervention prove vital in preventing fatal outcomes from a ruptured AAA.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm: A Case Study  Case Presentation:  Patient Information: The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department with an acute onset of severe low back and abdominal pain. He has a history of heavy smoking  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He reported significant weight loss over the past couple of months accompanying with poor appetite and fatigue. The patient admits to a previous diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  but does not remember the dimensions or any details about it. The patient is retired and lives alone  limiting his accessibility to support and health care.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  the patient is pale  slightly diaphoretic and agitated. His pulse is rapid and thready  his blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. The abdominal examination revealed a significant pulsatile mass. His hemoglobin level was noted to be low (8.5 g/dL) and white cell count was elevated (14 000/mm3)  indicating possible hemorrhage and infection.  Diagnostic Assessment: A computed tomography (CT) scan of the abdomen and pelvis showed a large infrarenal AAA measuring 8 cm in maximum diameter with a contained rupture into retroperitoneum. No other significant findings were observed.  Therapeutic Intervention:  The situation was explained to the patient  his family was contacted  and informed consent for emergency surgery was obtained. The patient was taken to the operating room where he underwent open aortic aneurysm repair with a Dacron graft. Approximately 2000 ml of blood was lost during the operation  this blood loss was replaced with intravenous fluid and blood transfusion.   Follow-Up and Outcomes: Post-operative recovery was complicated by pneumonia and transient renal insufficiency. However  with appropriate treatment  the patient was stable and transferred to the ward on postoperative day 5. The patient was discharged from the hospital on postoperative day 14 with normal renal function and stable vital signs. At the 3-month follow-up visit  the patient was recovering well  although complaining of decreased energy levels.  Patient Perspective: While afraid initially  the patient was grateful for the care provided and understood the severity of his condition. He expressed determination to improve his lifestyle habits (reducing smoking  healthy eating) to prevent such medical emergencies in the future.  Discussion: This case emphasizes the importance of regular medical check-ups in individuals at risk for AAA  especially those with a prior diagnosis. Awareness and knowledge about AAA  its symptoms  and recommended follow-ups are vital to prevent life-threatening situations.  Learning Points: AAA is frequently asymptomatic until it ruptures  leading to a high mortality rate. Regular monitoring and early intervention in at-risk patients  such as elderly males with a history of smoking and hypertension  is crucial to lower fatality rates. This case emphasizes the importance of comprehensive patient education and establishing strong health worker-patient communication.

Title: Case Report on a Patient with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Introduction:  This case study details a 72-year-old Caucasian male  who presented with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  a condition in which there is enlargement of the lower part of the aorta. Notably  he had no known history of AAA and this report discusses the course of his diagnosis  treatment  and management.  Case Report:  The patient  a retired construction worker from Boston  Massachusetts  presented himself in the emergency department complaining about a 3-day history of growing pain in his abdomen and back. This was associated with feelings of fullness and episodes of nausea. He denied experiencing any fever  chills  shortness of breath  or change in bowel movements. The patient had a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and long-standing history of smoking 1-2 packs a day for 50 years  but no known malignancies. His family history revealed his father died due to AAA rupture at the age of 60  and his mother died due to heart failure.  On physical examination  the patient was in mild distress due to pain. A palpable  pulsatile abdominal mass was found upon palpation. His pulse rate was 90 beats/minute  and blood pressure was 150/90 mmHg. CBC  biochemical profile  stool guaiac test were all within normal limits  but the patient’s urinalysis showed microscopic hematuria.  Given the clinical findings and the family history  an abdominal ultrasonography was ordered showing a 7 cm infrarenal AAA. A subsequent computed tomography (CT) scan confirmed the infrarenal AAA  slightly tortuous  with no signs of rupture but with high risk given the diameter. These findings raised the suspicion for a symptomatic  non-ruptured AAA.  Considering the patient's AAA size  the patient was consulted for emergency surgical repair to minimize the risk of AAA rupture. In light of this  an open surgical repair (OSR) was performed by a vascular surgeon in which a graft was placed  and the aneurysmal part of the aorta was replaced.   Discussion:  The patient’s history of smoking  hyperlipidemia  as well as his age and genetics  form a typical demographic for AAAs. AAA is commonly seen in individuals over the age of 65 with Caucasian males having the highest prevalence. Furthermore  his family history and the presence of microscopic hematuria increased his risk.  Conclusion:  Post-operative recovery was uneventful with improvement of his symptoms. The patient was discharged home after 6 days of hospitalization with a follow-up appointment in vascular surgery and advice to cease smoking. This case emphasizes the need for early detection and awareness of AAA  given the increased risk in certain populations. A more systematic AAA screening protocol in male smokers  especially with a positive family history  might be beneficial to prevent life-threatening AAA rupture.

Patient Description:  A 73-year-old Caucasian male presented to the Emergency department with a chief complaint of acute onset abdominal and lower back pain  together with nausea.   Past Medical History:  The patient had a history of smoking for about 40 years (2 packs of cigarettes per day)  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia. He also reported a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) with his father having died suddenly of a presumed (due to presenting symptoms) ruptured AAA at the age of 68.  Demographic Information:  The patient is a retiree  living by himself in his household  and is dependent on a state pension to get by. He is of medium build with being 1.75m tall and weighing 78 kg. He is widowed and has two kids who live out of state. In terms of alcohol use  he reports minimal alcohol usage - one beer per night. He stopped smoking a year ago following advice from his primary care physician. He has not been part of any substance abuse treatment previously.  Presenting Complaint and Clinical Findings:  The patient described his current symptoms as a sudden onset of severe  sharp  and persistent abdominal and back pain which started approximately 12 hours prior to admission. He also complained of associated nausea  which he rated as severe. There was no vomiting  change in bowel or bladder habits  hematuria  or melena.  On examination  he appeared pale and sweaty. His pulse was weak and his blood pressure was difficult to read due to the severity of pain. His pulses were symmetric in his extremities. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile and tender mass in the suprapubic region indicating a possible AAA.  Diagnostic Planning and Findings:  Considering the symptoms  the physical examination  and the patient’s risk factors (age  male gender  smoking history  hypertension  and a family history of AAA) an immediate decision was taken to get an abdominal CT scan  which confirmed the diagnosis of a 6.8 cm infra-renal AAA. Unfortunately  findings indicated that the AAA was leaking blood into the retroperitoneal space  also known as an impending AAA rupture.   Treatment and Outcome:  The patient was admitted to the vascular surgery department where an emergency endovascular stent graft repair of the AAA was conducted. His postoperative course was uneventful and he was discharged home on the sixth postoperative day with a follow-up appointment scheduled with his vascular surgeon in a week.  Conclusion:  This case underscores the importance of a high clinical suspicion for abdominal aortic aneurysm in patients who are male  over 65  smokers or former smokers  have a family history of AAA  and present with sudden abdominal or lower back pain. Timely recognition and referral for emergency surgical intervention can be life-saving. This case also demonstrates the successful application of endovascular stent graft repair as a less invasive treatment option for AAA.

Title: Management of Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 71-year-old Male Patient  Introduction:  An abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) represents a serious health risk with a high mortality rate  particularly due to the complications of rupture. This case report discusses the management of a patient with a ruptured AAA.  Case Presentation:  A 71-year-old Caucasian male patient presented to the emergency department with acute severe abdominal and back pain. The patient had no other symptoms such as fever  night sweats  or weight loss.   Patient demographics:  The patient is retired with a history of smoking for the past 50 years  albeit had quit smoking five years ago. He consumes alcohol in moderation and is physically active in his daily routine. He is married with two adult children and lives in a suburban setting. His occupation was in construction  working as a builder for most of his life.  Clinical Findings:  On physical examination  the patient was hypertensive with blood pressure of 170/100mmHg  yet remained hemodynamically stable. There was diffuse tenderness in his abdomen  particularly in the periumbilical region  but no sign of peritonitis or any palpable pulsatile mass. He is obese  with a body mass index (BMI) of 31kg/m2.  Medical History: The patient has a medical history of hypertension for which he takes antihypertensive medication. He also suffers from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to his history of smoking. No history of any AAA  neither in patient nor in his family  was reported. There was no history of trauma or recent surgery.  Diagnostic assessment:  A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis revealed a 7.5cm infrarenal AAA with evidence of rupture into retroperitoneal space. His labs showed mild anemia and elevated white blood cells  but kidney and liver function tests were within normal limits.  Therapeutic intervention:  Emergency surgery was planned properly after stabilizing the patient. An open surgical repair was performed with an aortic tube graft.   Follow-up:  The postoperative course was complicated by a minor wound infection which was treated appropriately.  He was discharged home after 2 weeks postoperatively.  He remains well at his 6-month follow-up visit with successful management of his AAA.  Conclusion:  This case emphasizes that an immediate and effective multidisciplinary approach is crucial for the management of a ruptured AAA. This case also highlights the importance of considering an AAA in the list of differential diagnoses for any elderly patient presenting with severe abdominal pain.

Title: Emergency Management of A Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a Senior Patient: A Case Report  Abstract:  This case report demonstrates the detection  emergency management  and successful treatment of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) in an 80-year-old Caucasian male with a history of smoking and cardiovascular disease.  Case Description:  The 80-year-old male patient presented to the emergency department with a sudden onset of severe  tearful pain at his lower back extending towards his lower abdomen on the left side. His medical history includes hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and a 60-pack-year history of smoking. The patient's prior surgical history was unremarkable. Family history revealed that his older brother died earlier from a ruptured AAA.  Examination on objective assessment revealed a diaphoretic  pale  and dyspneic patient with a pulse rate of 110 per minute and blood pressure of 96/70 mmHg. Palpation revealed a pulsatile mass. Laboratory tests displayed evidence of plasma lactate elevation  consistent with generalized ischemia. The initial impression was a ruptured AAA which was confirmed by an urgent CT-angiography  revealing an extensive retroperitoneal hematoma along with an infrarenal AAA measuring 8.5 cm.  Management and Outcome:  The patient was taken emergently to the operating room for the repair of the AAA. A successful open repair was performed with an infrarenal aortic graft. Postoperatively  the patient was admitted to the intensive care unit where he had healing and recovery complications related to advanced age and cardiovascular morbidity. After the postoperative recovery period  the patient's abdominal and back pain resolved. The patient was evaluated in the vascular surgery clinic on regular follow-ups showing a significant improvement in his health.  Discussion:  Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) rupture carries high morbidity and mortality rates. Risk factors for AAA include age over 65 years  male sex  a history of smoking  and the presence of familial risk. This case underscored the importance of prompt recognition  decisive management  and the necessary interdisciplinary collaboration in managing the acute presentation of a ruptured AAA.  Conclusions:  This case report highlights both the complexity and urgency in diagnosing and managing AAA rupture. Furthermore  it stresses upon the importance of follow-up care in the postoperative period  especially in dealing with potential complications among aging patients with a complex history of comorbidities.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-year-old Male - A Case Report   Patient Presentation: The patient  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  with a reported history of hypertension and smoking  presented at the emergency department with severe abdominal pain radiating to the back  signs of hypovolemic shock  palpable abdominal mass and tenderness  suggestive of a potential ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   Background Information: The patient lived in a suburb and was a retired engineer  with a strong history of smoking for about 30 years although he had quit about 12 years ago. His medical records indicated that he had been diagnosed with non-insulin-dependent type 2 diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia. Further  he had a family history of cardiovascular diseases  including a brother who died of a heart attack at the age of 55.   Clinical Findings: The patient was in severe distress  experiencing dizziness  and shortness of breath. His blood pressure was 100/60 mmHg  and heart rate was 110 bpm. Physical examination showed a pulsatile abdominal mass. The patient’s skin was cold and clammy  indicating signs of shock.   Diagnostic Assessment: A rapid bedside ultrasound was performed  revealing an AAA measuring approximately 7 cm in diameter. Given the patient's symptomatology and ultrasound findings  a presumptive diagnosis of ruptured AAA was made. A computed tomography angiogram (CTA) confirmed the diagnosis  illustrating a large infrarenal aortic aneurysm with evidence of rupture into the retroperitoneal space.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately transferred to the operating room for an emergency open surgical repair due to the instability of his condition. After an extensive preparation  a transperitoneal approach was used to repair the rupture.   Follow-up and Outcome: Post-operative period was uneventful  and he was transferred to the intensive care unit for close monitoring. After 3 days in ICU and 1 week in the surgical ward  he showed significant improvement and was subsequently discharged from the hospital.   Conclusion: This case emphasizes the deleterious effects of multiple risk factors such as hypertension  long-term smoking  diabetes mellitus  hyperlipidemia  and positive family history on the development and rupture of AAA. This case also highlights the importance of early recognition and treatment of AAA to prevent fatal outcomes.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 70-Year-Old Male: A Case Report  Abstract: This case report discusses the clinical presentation  diagnosis  intervention  and follow-up of a 70-year-old male patient who presented with a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   Case Presentation: Patient Description: A 70-year-old Caucasian male patient  resident of a suburban middle-class neighborhood  presented to the emergency department with acute onset of severe lower abdominal and back pain of 3-hours duration  which he described as the worst pain he has ever experienced. He was a retired engineer  married with two children and a non-smoker  with moderate alcohol consumption.   Medical History: His past medical history was significant for hypertension  which was treated with a calcium channel blocker and an ACE inhibitor. He also had early-stage chronic kidney disease and hyperlipidemia. His familial history was positive for cardiovascular diseases  with his father passing away due to AAA rupture at the age of 67 years old.  On examination  he was in considerable distress  appeared pale and sweaty  with pulse rate 98 beats/min  blood pressure 90/50 mmHg. Abdominal examination revealed a palpable mass in the midline of the abdomen which was tender on palpation. The rest of the clinical examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Assessment: An urgent computed tomography angiography (CTA) showed a 7.0 cm AAA with evidence of rupture into the retroperitoneal space.   Therapeutic Intervention: The patient received immediate resuscitation and was taken directly to the operating theatre. He underwent successful open surgical repair of the ruptured AAA with a Dacron aortic graft  under general anesthesia. The patient also required four units of red blood cells due to significant intraoperative blood loss.  Follow up and Outcome: Post-surgery  the patient had an uncomplicated recovery. He was transferred to the ward after two days in the intensive care unit and was discharged home ten days later. The patient was scheduled for regular follow-ups with vascular surgery outpatient services.   Conclusion: This case underlines the critical importance of early detection and intervention in patients with AAA  especially those who are at high risk due to familial history or other predisposing factors such as hypertension and atherosclerotic disease.  Key words: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Rupture  Hypertension  Atherosclerosis  Case report

CASE REPORT  Patient Information:   Name: Mr. Robinson Age: 74 Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Geography: West Texas  USA  Presenting Complaint:   Mr. Robinson presented with acute  severe and persistent abdominal and back pain for the past 24 hours. He experienced a sudden  sharp  tearing sensation that initiated at the navel and radiated towards his back.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Robinson has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  chronic pain due to osteoarthritis  and moderate tobacco usage. He has been treated with antihypertensives and statins for the last ten years. He also had a 38 pack-year smoking history  though he had quit 8 years ago. Mr. Robinson had no known drug allergies.  Clinical Findings:   Upon physical examination  Mr. Robinson was in obvious distress due to the intense pain. His blood pressure was 180/90 mmHg  pulse rate was 90 beats per minute  temperature 98.6 F  and breaths per minute at 18. An abdominal examination revealed a palpable  pulsating mass in his belly  approximately 5 cm in diameter. The peripheral pulses in the lower extremities were detected and normal.   Diagnostic Assessment:   An abdominal ultrasound confirmed the presence of an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring about 7.4 cm in diameter. The aneurysm was not ruptured but was associated with a moderate amount of free fluid  potentially indicating a contained rupture or imminent rupture.  Therapeutic Intervention:   Given the large size and symptomatic nature of the aneurysm  the patient was transferred immediately to the operating suite for emergency open aneurysm repair. A Dacron graft was used to replace the diseased section of the aorta.  Follow-Up and Outcomes:   Postoperatively  Mr. Robinson's hospital course was uncomplicated. He remained in the hospital for an additional 7 days for acute pain control and to monitor for potential postoperative complications. Upon discharge  he was prescribed analgesics  antihypertensives  and was advised to continue his treatment for hyperlipidemia.  Patient Perspective:   Mr. Robinson was grateful for the immediate diagnosis and treatment. He recognized the need for smoking cessation as a crucial element for vascular health and decided to continue his efforts in maintaining a smoke-free lifestyle.  Informed Consent:  Mr. Robinson gave written informed consent for his case to be presented for academic and educational purposes.  Case Summary:  This case illustrates the presentation and management of a large  symptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm in an elderly Caucasian male with strong cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and  importantly  smoking. It reinforces the need for thorough assessment and prompt intervention in managing this life-threatening condition. It also highlights the continued public health importance of smoking-cessation programs.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male: A Case Report  Patient Information: Mr. J  an 80-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department (ED) with a complaint of acute-onset severe lower back pain. He is a retired businessman with no history of allergies. His right flank appeared mildly distended with evident discomfort on palpation. Mr. J is a longtime resident of Florida  living with his wife in a suburban locality.  Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  with irregular use of prescribed medications and a 40-year-pack history of smoking. He was diagnosed with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) ten years earlier and has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father having died due to myocardial infarction.  Clinical Findings: On examination  he was tachycardia with a pulse rate of 120 beats per minute and blood pressure reading of 170/90 mmHg. His oxygen saturation was 88% on room air. He also exhibited classic signs of hypovolemic shock  including decreased urination  cold and sweaty skin  and an altered mental state. His abdomen was distended with a palpable pulsatile mass.  Timeline: His severe lower back pain started 12-hours before his ED arrival. The patient's wife reported that he had not reported any health-related concerns before this incident  except some symptoms related to his COPD  such as shortness of breath and chronic cough  for which he was regularly taking his medications.  Diagnostic Assessment: The clinical presentation along with medical and family history raised the suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). An abdominal CT angiogram confirmed the diagnosis  revealing an infrarenal AAA with a diameter of 8 cm and signs of rupture into the retroperitoneal space.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately administered IV fluids and was prepped for emergent open surgical repair. Vascular surgeons performed an aorto-biiliac prosthetic graft implant  and the aneurysmal wall was closed over the graft. The surgery was successful  and no postoperative complications were noted.  Follow-up and Outcomes: Regular follow-ups showed the patient's good recovery process. He was strictly advised to keep his blood pressure under control and quit smoking. Services for smoking cessation were provided  as well as strict instructions to monitor any suspicious symptoms to prevent further health-related issues.  Patient Perspective: The patient expressed his appreciation for the prompt action of the healthcare team that saved his life. He affirmed his commitment to leading a healthier lifestyle  including abstaining from smoking  better managing his hypertension  and attending all follow-up appointments.  Lessons Learned: The case reiterates the importance of maintaining high suspicion in elderly patients presenting with unexplained abdominal or back pain and hypertension  particularly those with a history of smoking and COPD  for a possible AAA. Early recognition and prompt management can result in positive treatment outcomes.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 67-Year-Old Caucasian Male  Patient Information: The patient is a 67-year-old Caucasian male  a retired engineer living in a suburban area. He has a past medical history of hypertension and hypercholesteremia  which are currently controlled using atenolol and atorvastatin  respectively. He is also a former smoker  having quit 15 years ago. He is living with his wife and is relatively active  engaging in light to moderate physical activities such as walking and gardening.  Clinical Findings: The patient presented to the emergency department complaining of severe and sudden-onset lower back pain and abdominal pain. The pain was described as a sharp  tearing sensation that started approximately 3 hours prior to his hospital visit. The patient also reported feeling dizzy and lightheadedness.  Diagnostic Assessment: Upon physical examination  a palpable pulsatile abdominal mass was noted. Considering the patient’s age  past medical history  and clinical presentation  a suspected diagnosis of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was made. An urgent abdominal ultrasound confirmed the presence of a large aneurysm  measuring 7.5 cm at its widest point. Lab tests revealed significantly decreased hemoglobin levels  highlighting the critical nature of the patient’s condition.  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was promptly taken to the operating room for emergency open repair of the ruptured AAA. The operation was successful  and the integrity of the aorta was restored.  Outcome and Follow-up: Post-operatively  he was admitted to the intensive care unit for close monitoring and stabilization. Ten days after surgery  he was discharged from the hospital in a stable condition  with appropriate postoperative follow-up and home care instructions. He was also counseled to undergo regular screening for any future aneurysmal development.  The follow-up period was regular for six months  with no complications noted post-discharge. The patient reported significant improvement in his overall well-being and is currently adhering to physician's instructions regarding medication and lifestyle changes.  Conclusion: This case report of a 67-year-old with a ruptured AAA underlines the importance of early detection  prompt surgical intervention  and comprehensive post-surgical management in ensuring a positive outcome for patients with this potentially life-threatening condition. Further  it emphasizes the importance of vigilant follow-up and monitoring in those at risk  such as older adults with a history of cardiovascular disease or smoking.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a Smoker with Hypertension: A Case Report   I. INTRODUCTION  The abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a potentially lethal condition  characterized by a dilated aorta  frequently presenting no signs until rupture occurs. Men aged 60 and above with history of smoking and hypertension are mostly affected. We present the case of a 67-year-old Caucasian male smoker  diagnosed with a ruptured AAA and successfully managed with endovascular aortic repair.  II. CASE PRESENTATION  A 67-year-old Caucasian male presented at our emergency department with severe abdominal pain that radiated to his back and slight syncope. The patient was a past active smoker  having quit five years ago after smoking approximately 30-pack years. He has a ten-year history of well-controlled hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managing these with Losartan 50mg and Atorvastatin 20mg daily. His family history includes his father  who died of an aortic aneurysm at the age of 72. He is a retired electrical engineer  a widower  lives alone  and maintains an active lifestyle.  III. CLINICAL FINDINGS AND DIAGNOSTIC ASSESSMENT  On physical examination  he was pale  sweaty and had a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg. His heart rate was 108 beats per minute. On abdominal examination  there was a pulsatile mass in the middle and lower abdomen. A bruit could also be heard over this area. Blood tests revealed a hemoglobin level of 8.5 g/dL  slightly below the normal range.   Computed Tomography angiography (CTA) of the abdomen showed a 7.5 cm infrarenal AAA  with evidence of retroperitoneal hematoma  suggestive of an admission diagnosis of ruptured AAA. The patient was informed of the seriousness of his condition and consented to emergency endovascular repair.   IV. TREATMENT AND OUTCOME  The patient was urgently transferred to the hybrid operating room and underwent successful endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) under general anesthesia. The procedure was uneventful and a follow-up CTA demonstrated successful exclusion of the aneurysm without endoleak. Blood transfusion was given postoperatively and his haemoglobin levels were monitored. The patient remained stable and made a gradual recovery. He was discharged on the tenth postoperative day after satisfactory clinical progress.  V. DISCUSSION  This case reflects the silent yet potentially fatal nature of AAAs. It also highlights the importance of patient risk factors such as smoking  hypertension  and a positive family history. The use of EVAR was both life-saving and effective in our patient  demonstrating its value in managing such critical conditions.  VI. CONCLUSION  Regular screening in high-risk populations  particularly males over 60 with a history of smoking or hypertension  is crucial to detect AAA early and prevent fatal outcomes. As demonstrated in this case  prompt recognition and management of AAA can lead to satisfying patient outcomes.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 70-year-old Caucasian Male: A Case Report  Case Information Patient ID: MRN-5888 Age: 70 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired civil engineer   Presenting complaint: The patient presented to the emergency department (ED) with severe  sudden-onset abdominal pain radiating to his back  lasting for 4 hours.  Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  type 2 diabetes mellitus  and hyperlipidemia. He also has a 50-pack-year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. He has no known allergies. Patient denied any family history of cardiovascular diseases or aortic aneurysms.  Physical Examination: On examination  the patient was in distress with blood pressure 160/80mmHg  heart rate 106bpm  respiratory rate 24/min  and an oxygen saturation of 96% on room air. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the epigastric region  slightly tender on palpation.  Investigations:  - Laboratory investigations revealed elevated D-dimer levels. Lipid profile was abnormal with elevated low-density lipoprotein (LDL)cholesterol. Hemoglobin and hematocrit levels were low. Blood glucose and HbA1c levels were uncontrolled. - Abdominal ultrasound revealed a low echogenic mass approximately 7 cm in diameter  suggestive of an aortic aneurysm. - A subsequent CT angiogram confirmed a 7.3 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Treatment and Outcome: Given the large size of the aneurysm and the acute presentation  the patient was recommended for an urgent surgical repair. He underwent a successful endovascular aortic repair (EVAR). The immediate postoperative period was uneventful. He was discharged on the 5th postoperative day on blood pressure maintenance  blood glucose control  and lipid-lowering medications. On a 1-month follow-up visit  CT angiogram showed no leak  and the graft was patent.  Discussion: This case emphasizes the importance of early recognition of AAA  particularly in those with risk factors such as advanced age  male sex  smoking history  and diseases like hypertension  diabetes  and hyperlipidemia. Despite having major conventional risk factors  the patient did not have any previous ultrasonographic surveillance for AAA. Strict blood pressure control  glycemic control  lipid-lowering therapies  and quit smoking can be beneficial in limiting the growth of small AAAs.  Conclusion: Early diagnosis and proactive management of AAA in high-risk individuals can significantly reduce the risk of dreadful complications such as rupture and death.

Title: An Unusual Presentation of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male Patient: A Case Report  Introduction: Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  categorically a disease of the aging population  poses a grave health concern among males older than 65 years. The disease has a strong predilection for males  with a male-to-female ratio averaging approximately 4:1. We document here a remarkable case involving a 78-year-old male with an asymptomatic AAA discovered during a routine physical examination.  Case Presentation: The patient  Mr. W  is a 78-year-old Caucasian male with a history of controlled hypertension  moderate hyperlipidaemia  and type 2 diabetes  all of which had been well managed with medication. He was an ex-smoker  with a smoking history of 20 pack-years  but had quit around two decades ago. There was no family history of vascular disease.  Mr. W visited the hospital for an annual checkup. The patient had no complaints and specifically denied any abdominal pain  back pain  limb weakness  urinary or bowel incontinence  or unexplained weight loss. His body mass index was 26.8. Vital signs were normal  and a routine physical examination noted a vague pulsatile mass in the abdomen.  An abdominal ultrasonography was ordered  revealing a dilated infrarenal aortic diameter of 5.2 cm consistent with an AAA. Confirmatory computed tomographic angiography of the abdomen showed a 5.2 cm infrarenal AAA without any signs of rupture or leak.  Due to the size of the AAA  the patient was immediately referred to vascular surgery for further evaluation and management. Open repair surgery was deemed suitable based on the patient's overall low surgical risk and aneurysm morphology.  The patient experienced no postoperative complications  and the aneurysm was successfully repaired. Management of his hypertension  hyperlipidaemia  diabetes  and secondary prevention efforts were also addressed by the general practitioners following the operation.  Discussion: This case is characteristic of the 'silent' nature of AAAs  often asymptomatic until rupture. It emphasises the importance of routine physical examination  particularly among older males and those with risk factors like hypertension  hyperlipidaemia  and smoking history. In the older demographic  family physicians play a pivotal role in early detection and timely referrals to vascular surgery. This case also underscores the critical nature of managing comorbidities that may contribute to the pathogenesis of AAA and its complications.  Conclusion: Given the silent course and potential lethal outcome of ruptured AAA  primary care providers need to maintain a high index of suspicion in patients like Mr. W who carry significant risk factors. Appropriate imaging modalities  risk assessment  surgical evaluations  and close follow-up care are essential aspects of managing patients with AAA  and may influence the overall prognosis positively.

Title: Management of Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 76-Year-Old Asian Female: A Single Case Report  Introduction:  Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) is a vascular condition characterized by a localized enlargement of the abdominal aorta  potentially leading to life-threatening complications such as rupture if left untreated.  CASE REPORT  Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 76-year-old Asian female who presented to the Emergency Room (ER) with a one-day history of severe abdominal pain. The pain started suddenly  was constant  and radiated to her lower back. The patient also reported feelings of light-headedness but denied any associated chest pain  shortness of breath  nausea  or vomiting. The patient also had a previous history of hypertension and high cholesterol levels.  Physical Examination:  On examination  the patient appeared in pain and distress. Her vital signs revealed a blood pressure of 90/60 mmHg  a pulse rate of 105 beats per minute  and 21 respirations per minute. An abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the mid-epigastric region  and the patient was tender on deep palpation along the abdominal aorta.   relevant investigations:  Emergency Hematology and Biochemistry labs were within reasonable limits except for raised white cell count and C-reactive protein suggesting an inflammatory process. An urgent Abdominal CT angiogram revealed a 6.8 cm aneurysm in the abdominal aorta with signs of rupture.  Management:  The patient was immediately admitted to intensive care and treated for shock. Following resuscitation  she underwent an emergency endovascular stent grafting operation. The operation was successful  and the patient was kept in the ICU for monitoring.  Outcome:  Post-operatively  the patient’s vitals stabilized  and the abdominal pain resolved. The patient was discharged on post-operative day 10  with outpatient follow-ups planned with the vascular surgery team.  Discussion:  AAA is more commonly observed in older white men. However  this case highlights the occurrence of ruptured AAA in an elderly Asian female  for whom AAA is reported at a lower prevalence. The traditional risk factors  such as hypertension and high cholesterol levels  were present in this case. This case underscores the importance of considering AAA in elderly patients with risk factors presenting with abdominal pain  backed up with a focused history and physical examination to reduce morbidity and mortality.   Consent:  Written informed consent was obtained from the patient for publication of this case report.  Conclusion:  This case underscores that though AAA is less common in women and the Asian population  it can occur and clinician vigilance is required  particularly in the presence of risk factors and presenting symptoms suggestive of AAA.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an 80-year-old Male with Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia: A Case Report  Introduction:   Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a localized dilation of the aorta in the abdomen  which carries a high risk of rupture with grave medical prognosis. This case report describes an 80-year-old Caucasian male diagnosed with an AAA.  Patient Profile:  The patient is an 80-year-old Caucasian male residing in a suburban setting. He is a retired mechanical engineer with a smoking history of 40-pack years  but quit 10 years ago. His family history is noted for myocardial infarction in his father and grandfather. The patient lives independently  remains physically active and consumes low-to-moderate amounts of alcohol. He has been previously diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medication.  Medical History:   The patient’s medical history includes Stage 2 hypertension diagnosed 15 years ago  for which he is prescribed lisinopril  and hyperlipidemia diagnosed 10 years ago  managed with atorvastatin. The patient has not previously been diagnosed with any form of aneurysm or cardiac condition. He has no known allergies and his last physical examination  conducted a month prior  was unremarkable barring the hypertensive range BP readings.  Presenting Problem:   The patient presented at the outpatient department with a complaint of persistent abdominal discomfort  mild back pain  and loss of weight over the past three months. These symptoms had progressively worsened over the past week.  Clinical Findings:  Upon examination  a pulsatile mass was noted in the periumbilical area. Percussion confirmed dullness over the same area. Detailed vascular and abdominal examinations did not report any other abnormal findings. Routine labs were within normal limits  except for marginally elevated LDL and triglycerides.  Investigations:  The ultrasound of the abdomen revealed an aneurysmal aortic dilation measuring 5.8 cm in maximum diameter. This finding was further confirmed by a CT scan with contrast. It displayed an AAA with an infrarenal location with no signs of rupture or dissection.  Conclusion:  The patient’s age  Caucasian ethnicity  and history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  along with his extensive smoking history  are all significant risk factors making him susceptible to AAA.  Following the diagnosis of the AAA  the patient was counseled regarding the risks and complications of the aneurysm and potential therapeutic options. Since the diameter of the aneurysm was >5.5 cm  surgical intervention was recommended to prevent a possible rupture.  This report underscores the importance of considering a diagnosis of AAA even in elderly patients presenting with vague symptoms such as persistent abdominal discomfort and unexplained weight loss. Early detection can facilitate necessary surgical intervention and prevent life-threatening complications.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  A. Patient Information The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who works as a retired marine biologist. He lives with his wife and they have two adult children. The patient is a former smoker  having quit approximately 30 years ago. He is average in height and slightly overweight with a BMI of 28. The patient maintains a fairly sedentary lifestyle due to his retirement  and he self-reported a diet high in animal fat and processed foods. His alcohol consumption is minimal.   B. Past Medical History The patient has a history of Hypertension for which he has been taking antihypertensive medication. The patient’s historical health records also reveal Hyperlipidemia that appears reasonably well-controlled under statin therapy. Further  patient’s father died of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) in his late 70s.   C. Presenting Symptoms The patient presented to the hospital with sudden and severe lower back and abdominal pain. He describes it as “sharp” and “tearing ” rating it 10/10 on the pain scale. He denied experiencing prior symptoms leading up to this event  including changes in bowel or bladder function or loss of consciousness. The pain was not associated with food intake or any specific activity and was not relieved with rest.  D. Physical Examination On physical examination  the patient appeared in visible distress due to pain. His vital signs were stable  and his cardiopulmonary examination was within normal limits. An abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the central and upper part of the abdomen. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  E. Diagnostic Findings Laboratory examination did not show any significant abnormalities. However  the abdominal ultrasound identified a saccular aneurysm measuring 7.5 cm in the abdominal aorta. A subsequent contrast-enhanced computed tomographic scan confirmed a large AAA with signs suggestive of impending rupture.   F. Diagnosis Based on the patient's history  physical examination  and diagnostic results  an emergency diagnosis was made of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) with impending rupture.  G. Treatment and Outcome The patient was immediately scheduled for elective open surgery under general anesthesia. A prosthetic graft was successfully placed. The patient tolerated the procedure well. His postoperative period was uneventful  and he was discharged 10 days after the surgery. He was advised to maintain a low-fat diet  exercise regularly  and continue his medication for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has scheduled regular follow-ups at the vascular surgery clinic to monitor aneurysm recurrence.  This clinical case emphasizes the importance of considering AAA in older  male patients presenting with sudden and intense abdominal or back pain  especially those with risk factors such as a family history and personal history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia.

Title: Ruptured Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 70-year-old Male: A Case Report  Demographic Information: Patient A is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a height of 5'10"" and weight of 198lbs from upstate New York. He is retired  lives with his wife  and has a history of active smoking.  Presenting Complaint: The patient presented to the emergency department (ED) with a 2-day history of severe  unrelenting abdominal pain that was radiating to his back. There were no other associated syndromes such as nausea  vomiting  or change in bowel movements.  Past Medical History: The patient has had a history of hypertension (HTN) and hyperlipidemia  which have been under consistent management with Lisinopril and Atorvastatin  respectively. He had been a chronic smoker (40 pack-years) but he quit smoking 15 years ago.  Family History: Patient A's family history is significant for cardiovascular disease  with his father dying from stroke at the age of 65  and his elder brother being diagnosed with coronary artery disease (CAD).  Clinical Findings: Initial examination revealed a patient in acute distress due to pain with a blood pressure of 145/85 mmHg and heart rate of 105 bpm. Abdominal examination showed a pulsatile and tender mass in the midline of the abdomen slightly above the umbilicus. Other systemic examinations were within normal limits.  Investigations: A CT scan of the abdomen was obtained  which confirmed the presence of an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm of approximately 6.8cm diameter with evidence of rupture into the retroperitoneal space.  Hospital Course and Management: The patient was promptly taken to the operating room for an emergent exploratory laparotomy. A ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm was identified  and immediate repair was performed. His post-operative course was uncomplicated  and he was discharged home in stable condition on post-operative day 10.  Conclusion: This case underscores the importance of high clinical suspicion for AAA in older individuals  specifically male  presenting with acute abdominal or back pain. It also highlights the significance of chronic smoking as a risk factor for developing AAA. Early detection and management of AAA are critical to prevent life-threatening complications such as rupture and subsequent mortality. Regular screening and follow-up are also essential  particularly in patients with risk factors for AAA.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 72-Year-Old Male: A Case Report  Case Description:  Patient Information: Mr. X  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presented himself to the emergency department of our institution. He is a retired plumber with a history of smoking two packs of cigarettes daily for the last 50 years. The patient lives with his wife in the rural Midwest. They have two adult children.  Medical History: The patient has known hypertension for the last ten years  intermittently compliant with anti-hypertensive medications due to perceived side effects. He was diagnosed with moderate COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease) three years ago. He is currently maintained on short-acting bronchodilators  inhaled corticosteroids but is highly dependent on oxygen. His lipid profile is normal  but he has a history of being overweight with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of around 28.  Presenting Concerns: The patient was rushed to the emergency department complaining of severe  steady  and tearing abdominal pain  radiating to his lower back for the last six hours. The pain started suddenly early morning while he was having coffee. He also reported having experienced occasional milder episodes of similar pain in the past few months  which he attributed to 'indigestion'.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  he was alert but anxious. He was afebrile with a blood pressure of 164/98 mmHg  a heart rate of 100 bpm  respiratory rate of 16 per minute and oxygen saturation of 94% on room air. His abdomen was soft with slight distention and a palpable mass in the lower midline region.   Diagnostic Assessment: Emergent computed tomography angiography was performed suspecting aortic pathologies given the patient's classical pain description  revealing an infrarenal aortic aneurysm measuring 8 cm confirming the suspicion of a ruptured AAA (Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm).  Therapeutic Intervention: The patient was immediately taken for an emergency open repair of the abdominal aortic aneurysm. The procedure was successful  and postoperative recovery was uneventful.  Follow-up and Outcomes:  The patient was discharged on postoperative day 7. At the one month follow-up  the surgical site was healed well  the patient's blood pressure was controlled  and his chest symptoms were well-managed.  Teaching Points: This case highlights the importance of having a high degree of suspicion for the diagnosis of AAA with classic symptoms. Early diagnosis and urgent referral for repair can significantly improve the patient's chance of survival.

**Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)**  **Patient Information**  Mr. A. McCarthy is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired heavy equipment operator  with a medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking. Lives alone  has a daughter living out of state  and no reported family history of cardiovascular disease.  **Clinical Findings**  The patient initially presented at a primary healthcare center complaining of persistent lower abdominal and back pain  discomfort  bloating  and vague nausea for two weeks  but no vomiting  loss of appetite  or weight loss. He mentioned progressive intensification of his pain over the last two days.  **Diagnostic Assessment**  Physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass. Further diagnostic testing with abdominal ultrasound and computed tomography angiography (CTA) confirmed the diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The aneurysm  primarily infrarenal  measured 5.5 cm with a mural thrombus. No sign of imminent rupture was reported.  Complete blood count  renal function tests  and liver function tests were all within normal limits. Urinalysis also did not show any significant abnormalities. ECG showed no sign of ischemic heart disease.  **Therapeutic Intervention**  Given the presence of a large aneurysm  surgical intervention was deemed necessary and an attempt was made to regulate the hypertension. Immediate blood pressure management was initiated with IV labetalol  and he was shifted to a high dependency unit for close monitoring.  The patient underwent elective endovascular aortic repair (EVAR). Preoperative workup ensured that the patient had adequate renal function and was optimized from a cardiovascular perspective. The surgery was uneventful  and immediate post-procedure CTA confirmed successful graft placement with no endoleak.  **Follow-Up and Outcomes**  Mr. McCarthy remained in the hospital for 72 hours under close observation and was discharged on the fourth day  when his pain was under control and his blood pressure was stable. His anti-hypertensive medication was reviewed and titrated before discharge. He was advised to quit smoking and was provided with smoking cessation resources and lifestyle modification education.  During his one-month follow-up visit  the patient reported a significant reduction in his symptoms. An outpatient CTA was repeated three months post-operatively and showed patent graft with no endoleak. He was followed up regularly at the vascular surgery clinic for further evaluation and monitoring.  **Patient Perspective**  The patient expressed his gratitude for the successful intervention  stating that his quality of life had improved greatly since the procedure. He shared that he'd successfully quit smoking and was adapting a healthier lifestyle.  **Informed Consent**  Informed consent was obtained from the patient for this case report.   This 68-year-old man’s case underscores the importance of considering AAA in older patients with risk factors (hypertension  hyperlipidemia  smoking) who present with non-specific abdominal symptoms. Early diagnosis and prompt intervention can potentially prevent catastrophic consequences  significantly improving patient outcomes.

Title: A Case of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-Year-Old Caucasian Male  Introduction:  Abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) are a potentially fatal condition that predominantly affects males over the age of 60. Herein  we present an interesting case of AAA managing the condition non-surgically due to patient choice.  Patient Information: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male retired construction worker from a semi-urban area. He is a smoker with a history of 30 pack-years. Utility working exposed him to prolonged periods of standing and heavy lifting. His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. The patient lives with his wife and has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father passing from an aortic aneurysm. He reported moderate alcohol consumption and follows an inconsistent exercise regimen.  Clinical findings: He presented to the outpatient clinic complaining of persistent lower back pain for about three weeks that radiates to the legs and dull aching abdominal pain. There were no gastrointestinal or urinary symptoms. Physical examination revealed a pulsatile and tender mass in the lower abdomen.  Diagnostic assessment: An abdominal ultrasound was performed which showed a fusiform aneurysm of the abdominal aorta measuring 6.2 cm in diameter  indicative of an AAA. A complete blood count  metabolic panel  and coagulation functions were within normal ranges.  Therapeutic intervention: The patient was immediately registered under vascular surgery upon diagnosis. However  upon discussion of risks and benefits  the patient declined surgical intervention. A conservative management plan was initiated including smoking cessation counseling  blood pressure optimization with beta-blockers  and tight glycemic control. The patient was also encouraged to modify lifestyle choices  reduce alcohol intake  follow a balanced diet  and engage in light physical activities.  Follow-up and outcomes: He was scheduled for close follow-up appointments including regular ultrasound examinations. Over six months  the aneurysm remained stable without any further enlargement. However  the patient continues to experience intermittent abdominal pain and lower back discomfort.  Patient perspective: The patient expressed concern about his diagnosis but chose non-operative management out of fear of surgical complications. He shared his commitment to lifestyle modification and compliance with medications to control his blood pressure and diabetes.  Discussion: For AAA  early detection and prompt management are crucial. Although surgical intervention is usually preferred for AAAs greater than 5.5 cm  patient choice plays a significant role in management. This case underlines the significance of conservative management when surgical intervention is refused or contraindicated.  Conclusion: Despite the standard management for AAA being surgical intervention  this case underscores the potential role and necessity of yet vigilant conservative management in the setting of patient refusal for surgery. Physicians must be prepared to discuss all potential options and respect patient autonomy in treatment decisions.

Title: Rapid Growth of An Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 70-Year-Old Caucasian Male: A Case Report  I. Patient Information  The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. X  weighing approximately 75 kg  and measuring 175 cm in height. He is retired and lives with his wife in a small town. He is a non-smoker and has a history of moderate alcohol consumption. He has no known drug allergies.  II. Chief Complaint  The patient complained of persistent lower back pain extending down towards the abdomen  with the frequency and intensity increasing over the past two weeks.  III. Past medical history  Mr. X was diagnosed with hypertension 15 years ago and type 2 diabetes 10 years ago  both of which have been managed with medication. Additionally  he had been treated for hyperlipidemia for the past 12 years. There is no history of previous surgeries. He underwent coronary angioplasty 5 years ago following a minor myocardial infarction. His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease: his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 60  and his older brother underwent surgery for a cerebral aneurysm.  IV. Clinical Findings  On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was noted  and a bruit was heard over the mass. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable. The patient appeared in no acute distress  with normal vital signs.  V. Diagnostic Assessment  Abdominal ultrasound suggested the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The diagnosis was confirmed by a CT scan  which revealed a large AAA measuring approximately 5.5 cm in diameter.  VI. Therapeutic Intervention  Due to the large size and continued growth of the aneurysm  the patient was admitted for emergency surgery. An endovascular stent graft was inserted successfully with no complications.  VII. Follow-up and Disposition  Post-operative recovery was uneventful. He was discharged from the hospital after one week. Medications for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes were adjusted. Mr. X was advised to quit alcohol consumption  and he was referred to a physiotherapist for physical rehabilitation. A CT scan after six months revealed the absence of an endoleak  and the stent graft was in the correct position.   This case illustrates the importance of periodic abdominal examinations in high-risk patients  even in the absence of symptoms  for early diagnosis and management of abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 65-year-old Caucasian female patient with a past medical history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and current 30-pack year smoking habit  presents with acute mid-abdominal pain radiating to the back  indicative of a possible ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 72-year-old  Caucasian male  former smoker with a history of high blood pressure and coronary artery disease  presents with sudden severe abdominal and back pain suggestive of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.
A 72-year-old Caucasian male  former smoker with a history of hypertension and high cholesterol  presents with intermittent lower back Pain suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with past medical history of hypertension  smoking  and high cholesterol presents with sudden onset severe lower abdominal and back pain indicative of possible abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 74-year-old Caucasian male  smoker with a long-term history of uncontrolled hypertension and hyperlipidemia  presents with back pain and pulsating abdominal mass  suspected abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male  with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia and a 50-pack-year smoking history  presents with a sudden onset of severe lower back pain  suggestive of a rupturing abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 72-year-old African-American male  smoker and hypertensive  with a history of peripheral vascular disease  presenting with sudden severe lower back pain suggestive of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male  with a history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and tobacco use  presents with sudden-onset severe abdominal and back pain suggestive of a potential abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture.

A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and 40 pack-year smoking  now presenting with sudden-onset severe abdominal and back pain  consistent with a potential ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.
A 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and smoking habit presents with abdominal and back pain  suspicious for abdominal aortic aneurysm.
A 70-year-old African-American man with a history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and smoking  presents with sudden severe lower back pain suggestive of abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture.

A 70-year-old Caucasian male with a history of long-term smoking  hypertension  and peripheral artery disease  presents with sudden and severe back pain  demonstrating a pulsating sensation in the abdomen  suggestive of a possible ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Profile: The patient  a 69-year-old Caucasian male  was presented with a diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He is a retired engineer living with his wife in San Francisco  California. He has a history of high blood pressure and coronary artery disease for which he is on medication. He is a former smoker  quitting 15 years ago  and does not have a history of alcohol or drug abuse.   Medical History: The patient has been managing hypertension and coronary artery disease for over a decade  which were controlled through medication. He has a surgical history including appendectomy and coronary bypass grafting done almost 15 years ago.   Approximately 11 years ago  he was diagnosed as Borderline Diabetic but was well-managed through dietary adjustments  and does not require insulin currently. His other past medical history is significant for hyperlipidemia. There is no history of any renal  hepatic or other systemic disease.  Family History: His father had a myocardial infarction at an age of 74 and his mother died from complications of diabetes. Besides that  no other significant family history of aneurysms mentioned.  Presenting Condition: He visited for a routine check-up where he complained of a dull  gnawing feeling of discomfort in his lower back and abdomen. During examination  a pulsatile mass was palpable in the abdomen. He reported no other symptoms such as weight loss  loss of appetite  or changes in bowel habits.  Investigations: The physician ordered an abdominal ultrasound to investigate this mass further. The ultrasound revealed an AAA measuring approximately 5.5cms in diameter.   Discussion: AAA is more common in men than women and the risk increases with age  especially in those over 65. AAA is more common among Caucasians than it is among African-Americans  Latinos  and Asians. Screening examinations for AAA is recommended for men between 65-75 who have ever smoked.  There are strong associations with AAA and coronary artery disease  hypertension  high cholesterol and smoking. Our patient had all these risk factors.   Plan: As the patient's AAA was greater than 5.5cm  multidisciplinary team decided surgical intervention was needed. They planned an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) procedure which is less invasive and has a quicker recovery time compared to traditional open surgery. Alongside the surgery  managing other risk factors such as hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and monitoring sugar levels was agreed upon.   Post-EVAR  regular follow-ups with ultrasound or CT scans will be done to ensure the aneurysm has been successfully repaired and to continually monitor the patient's overall health status.   This case highlights the importance of regular health checkups in early detection and management of life-threatening conditions such as an AAA  especially in patients with multiple risk factors.

Patient Profile:  Patient's Name: Mr. James Waters Age: 70 years old Ethnicity: Caucasian Gender: Male Occupation: Retired Engineer  Medical Case Presentation:  Mr. James Waters  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presented himself to the outpatient department with a complaint of persistent abdominal pain for the past two weeks. The pain was described as a dull ache  concentrated in the central and lower part of the abdomen. On further inquiry  the patient also reported occasional back pain  but no change in bowel or bladder habits.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Waters has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia which are controlled on medication for the past 10 years. He had a myocardial infarction 5 years ago  for which he underwent angioplasty and is on regular follow-up. He continues to take the prescribed medication regularly  including antiplatelets  beta-blockers  ACE inhibitors  and statins. He has no known drug allergies. He has never been hospitalized outside of his myocardial infarction.   Lifestyle and Family History:  He is a former smoker  having quit 25 years ago. He occasionally drinks alcohol but does not engage in any recreational drug use. He is moderately active and follows a relatively healthy diet.   His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease. His father died at the age of 65 from a stroke  and his older brother underwent surgery for an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 68.  Physical Examination and Diagnosis:  Upon physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpated. His blood pressure was found to be elevated  inconsistent with his regular medication. Due to the suspicious abdominal findings and his significant family history  an ultrasound was carried out which confirmed the presence of an infra-renal abdominal aortic aneurysm.  This finding was subsequently verified by a computed tomographic angiogram (CTA)  showing a 5.5 cm infra-renal abdominal aortic aneurysm.  With the establishment of his diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  a treatment plan concerning surgical intervention is under discussion  however  the risks associated with his previous cardiac issues need careful consideration.  In summary  Mr. Waters presents a potentially complex case due to his previous cardiac history. Given the significant size of the aneurysm and the potential for rupture  immediate steps to arrange surgical intervention need to be undertaken  with careful preoperative cardiac evaluation. Multidisciplinary collaboration between cardiology  radiology  and vascular surgery teams will play a vital role in the successful management of Mr. Waters' condition.

Subject: 65-year-old African-American Male with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Presenting Patient Profile: Our patient is a 65-year-old African-American male  recently diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He weighs about 79 kg and his height is approximately 178 cm. He comes from an urban socioeconomic background and is a retired construction worker. His main concern was progressive abdominal discomfort with intermittent lower back pain over the last couple of months.  Past Medical History: The patient has been a hypertensive for the past 10 years and his BP has been fairly controlled on ACE inhibitors. He has a documented history of hyperlipidemia and has been on statins for the same. In addition  he has a 20-year history of smoking  although he quit 5 years ago. He does not drink alcohol or use illicit drugs. He denied other known cardiovascular or metabolic disease.  Family History: The patient's father died at 70 due to a stroke. His mother  85  is alive and suffers from type 2 diabetes and hypertension. He also reported an uncle who underwent surgery for an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 68.  Clinical Findings: On physical examination  the patient was found to have a noticeable pulsating mass in the abdomen. His blood pressure was slightly elevated 145/90 mmHg. His routine laboratory studies showed dyslipidemia with LDL cholesterol being quite high.  Radiological Evaluation: A contrast-enhanced abdominal CT scan confirmed the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. It reveals a 5.5 cm infrarenal aortic aneurysm without signs of rupture or dissection.  Treatment and Follow-up: Since his aortic aneurysm is about 5.5 cm in diameter and he is symptomatic  he will be considered for surgical repair to reduce the risk of rupture. He will continue his antihypertensive and lipid-lowering medications to manage the risk factors for AAA growth. The team will schedule him for annual surveillance with abdominal ultrasonography.  Risk Factors:   Epidemiological data suggest that the risk factors for the development of AAA in this patient could have been his age  male sex  Caucasian race  smoking history  chronic hypertension  and genetic predisposition.  General Demographics: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysms (AAA) are most commonly diagnosed in elderly men  with the prevalence increasing with age. AAAs are more common among Caucasians compared to African Americans. However  the outcome post AAA rupture is worse in African Americans  making this case quite noteworthy. Risk factors include smoking  hypertension  and a family history of the condition.

Patient Information:  Mr. R is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who has visited the Outpatient Department due to worsening abdominal pain over the last week. He resides in rural Tennessee  lives alone  and is a retired teacher.   Presenting Issue:   Mr. R informed us that he has been experiencing dull  constant abdominal pain for over a week  which seemed to be intensifying. He also mentioned feeling a pulsating sensation around his navel.  Past Medical History:  Mr. R’s medical history reveals controlled hypertension and a 10-year smoking history  which he quit approximately five years ago. He has a history of a mild heart attack 5 years ago and is on aspirin 75mg/OD for the same.  Family History:   Both his father and older brother had abdominal aortic aneurysms diagnosed in their later life. His father passed away at the age of 79 from aneurysm-related complications.  Clinical Examination:  On examination  he was alert and fully grounded in reality. His blood pressure was 135/85 mm Hg with pulse rate 70 bpm. Abdomen was soft  non-tender but a palpable pulsatile mass is noted in the infra-umbilical region.  Preliminary Diagnosis:  His symptoms  family history  and the presence of a pulsatile abdominal mass  Mr. R seemed to have an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Investigations:  An abdominal ultrasound confirmed a 5.2cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. CT angiogram also supports the same diagnosis; it showed a saccular infrarenal aneurysm with no signs of rupture.  Treatment:  Considering his age  previous medical history  symptomatology  and size of the aneurysm  Mr. R has been referred for repair of the aneurysm. Given the scenario  an endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) would be planned.  Conclusion:  Given Mr. R's demographics  history  and current presentation  it was essential to diagnose and treat his condition promptly to prevent life-threatening complications. The patient's age  gender  hypertension  smoking history  and familial history align with the current literature concerning risk factors associated with the occurrence of AAA. Early detection and timely intervention can potentially improve the prognosis for patients like Mr. R.

Patient Case Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: Mr. Johnson Brown  a 67-year-old African American male  was brought into the emergency room after complaining of severe lower back and abdominal pain for the past week.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Brown experienced sharp and radiating pain in his lower abdomen and back which he initially attributed to muscle strain. However  the extreme intensity and steady increase of the pain over time prompted him to seek medical attention.  Past Medical History: Significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He was diagnosed with these conditions 15 years ago and has been on regular medication (ACE inhibitors  statins  and bronchodilators respectively). Mr. Brown was a smoker and consumed nearly a pack daily for about 40 years. He quit smoking 10 years ago.  Family History: His father died from stroke at 72 and his older brother had undergone a successful operation for the same condition—abdominal aortic aneurysm— three years prior. His mother has a history of hypertension and died of heart disease in her eighties.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  a pulsating mass was recorded in the abdomen. His blood pressure was slightly elevated at 150/90 mm Hg. Other vital signs were stable.  Investigations: An ultrasound confirmed an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.5 cm in the infrarenal aorta region. A CT angiography was done as a follow-up to map the detailed anatomy of the aneurysm.  Disease Prevalence: The prevalence of abdominal aortic aneurysm is higher in males and increases with age. It is more common in the white population but is found to be more severe with poorer outcomes in African Americans. As validated by Khashram  Williman  and Jones (2016)  contributing factors include smoking  familial history  and heart disease.  Management: The patient's aneurysm falls into the category that needs surgical repair due to its size and risk of rupture. After consulting with the vascular department  an elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) was scheduled.  Conclusion: The presence of multiple risk factors such as age  history of smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and family history made Mr. Brown prone to developing an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Monitoring his vital signs for stability and controlling the blood pressure are crucial steps while arranging for the surgery. He would also benefit from lifestyle modifications such as a balanced diet  regular exercise  and regular monitoring of his lipid profile and blood pressure after the surgery.  References: Khashram  M.  Williman  J. A.  & Jones  G. T. (2016). Management of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing.
