Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Williams is a 70-year-old African-American male with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack year smoking history until he stopped five years ago. He was referred to the vascular surgery clinic for an incidental finding of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) on a recent abdominal ultrasound  which was carried out because he had complained of chronic  dull abdominal pain. His family history is significant for his father and older brother both succumbing to AAA ruptures. He takes losartan for hypertension and atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia. He has no known drug allergies.  Clinical Findings:  Mr. Williams is slightly overweight (BMI: 26)  with stable vital signs. His abdominal examination showed a pulsatile mass near the umbilicus  with no overlying erythema or tenderness. He also has no sign of lower extremity edema or peripheral arterial disease. The rest of his physical examination was unremarkable.   Diagnostic Assessment and Outcome:  A computed tomography angiogram (CTA) confirmed a 5.5cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with no signs of impending rupture. Given the size of the aneurysm and the family history  Mr. Williams was counseled for elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) which he agreed to. The procedure was carried out successfully with no immediate post-operative complications. Mr. Williams was discharged three days after the procedure  with orders to continue taking his antihypertensive and antihyperlipidemic medications. He was also advised for regular follow-up and imaging to monitor for potential aneurysm expansion or other complications.  Discussion:  Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a life-threatening disease that often has no symptoms until rupture  at which point the survival rate is low. The risk factors include advanced age  male gender  smoking history  hypertension  chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  family history of AAA  and Caucasian race - although recent research suggests that African-Americans may also be significantly affected. Intervention is generally recommended when the aneurysm reaches exceed 5.5cm  presents with rapid enlargement  or is symptomatic  as in this case. EVAR has greatly reduced perioperative mortality rates  but long-term surveillance is critical due to the risk of endoleaks and aneurysm expansion.

Patient Presentation:  Introduction: Mr. Alvarez is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presented with acute onset of severe lower abdomen and back pain. His pain was not associated with any triggering factors and was constant  which is unlike any previous experiences.  Past Medical History: He has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack-year smoking history. Previous surgeries include appendectomy and bilateral hernia repairs in his 50s. Mr. Alvarez's medications include Enalapril and Atorvastatin. He has no known drug allergies.  Family History: His father died at 72 from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  and his mother died from breast cancer in her 60s.  Symptoms: Mr. Alvarez admits he has felt a pulsating sensation in his abdomen in recent months  often associated with a slight discomfort  which he ignored. He does not report any weight loss  loss of appetite  or change in bowel habits.   Physical Examination: On physical examination  he appears chronically ill and stated that he has severe pain. His BP was 140/90 mmHg  pulse rate 100/min  and respiratory rate 18/min. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsating mass in the periumbilical region.  Radiology: A CT scan revealed a 7.2-cm infrarenal AAA with no sign of rupture but evidence of impending rupture.   Diagnosis: Considering his symptomatology  physical examination findings  and radiological evidence  he was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm with an impending rupture.  Plan: An anticipated plan consists of immediate surgical repair  either via open repair or endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  depending on further assessment by the vascular surgical team.   The patient has several risk factors associated with AAA  such as older age  male sex  a strong family history of AAA  smoking history  and concomitant disease like hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  In conclusion  the patient has an identified AAA  which was discovered due to acute onset of severe pain. Given the patient's significant family history and his smoking habit  extra vigilance  and regular check-ups have been recommended for quick detection and early intervention of AAA.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 65-Year-Old Male  Patient Information:   Mr. T  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presented with complaints of intermittent unrelenting abdominal pain and episodes of lightheadedness.  Clinical History:   Our patient  Mr. T  has a past medical history significant for smoking a pack per day for 30 years (quit 10 years ago)  diabetes mellitus type II and hypertension under treatment. The patient lives alone and has been maintaining his lifestyle with moderate exercise and balanced diet.  Family Medical History:   Mr. T has a family history of cardiovascular disease. His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 70  and his younger brother was detected with abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at age 60.  Presenting Complaints:   The patient complains of an unusual pulsating sensation in the abdomen corresponding to his heartbeat  accompanied by throbbing lower back pain.  Physical Examination:   On examination  his vital signs were stable but he had a palpable abdominal mass that pulsed with the heartbeat. Blood pressure was slightly elevated on the higher side - 150/95 mmHg  with a heart rate of 82 beats/minute.  Investigation findings:  Abdominal ultrasounds demonstrated an infrarenal AAA of 5.5 cm. CT angiography revealed a saccular aneurysm arising from the infrarenal aorta.  Management system:  Given the size of the aneurysm and symptoms  surgical intervention was advised. Elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) was carried out  which was successful.   Discussion:  AAA is predominantly observed in older adults  especially men over 60  Caucasian ethnicity  smokers  and individuals with a family history of the condition  which matches our patient's demographic profile. Hypertension and smoking history are major risk factors. The importance of proactive screening and timely interventions in patients at risk of AAA is emphasized by this case. The case also highlights the usage of EVAR for treatment  with less invasiveness and a quicker recovery time than open surgery.   References:  No specific references are included as this based on a hypothetical case. However  for a real case  related peer-reviewed papers and textbooks would be cited.

Patient Presentation:  Name: John C. Doe Age: 67 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Police Officer  History of Present Illness: Mr. Doe presented to the emergency department with acute onset severe abdominal pain which he described as constant  gnawing  and radiating to the back. The patient reports that his discomfort has been progressive over the last four hours. He denies any other associated symptoms like nausea  vomiting  or diarrhea; however  he mentioned a recent unexplained weight loss and mild fatigue over the past month. History of previous surgical interventions is insignificant.  Medical History: The past medical history revealed he had high blood pressure and high cholesterol levels for the past 15 years  managed with medication. The patient is also a 20-pack year smoker and has been quitting and starting smoking throughout his lifetime. He also has a 10-year history of Type II Diabetes Mellitus under control with Metformin.  Family History: He had a paternal uncle who died of a stroke in his early 70s  and his father had congestive heart failure in his late seventies. His mother and two siblings are alive and well  with no known hereditary illnesses.   Psychosocial History: Mr. Doe resides with his wife and they are both retired. He enjoyed a moderate alcohol intake  with approximately 2 beers a night  but he quit drinking six months ago on his physician's advice.  Physical Examination: Vital signs demonstrate a blood pressure of 147/88 mmhg and a pulse rate of 86 bpm. His cardiovascular examination showed normal heart sounds without any murmurs. However  palpation revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass. Bowel sounds were present  and the remainder of his physical examination was normal.  Assessment: Based on the clinical signs  symptoms and medical history  he was suspected of having an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). An aorta ultrasound confirmed a 7cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. The patient was immediately referred to vascular surgery for further management given the size of his AAA and his symptoms  which suggested potential imminent rupture.  Plan: A plan was made to admit the patient and arrange an elective repair of his aneurysm. His management will also include optimization of his blood pressure and lipid levels and smoking cessation counseling to potentially limit the expansion of his aneurysm.  This case serves as a potent reminder that high clinical suspicion for AAA is needed  especially in patients over 65 years of age with smoking history  hypertension  high cholesterol levels  and family history of aneurysm or strokes. Early diagnosis and management can prevent a fatal rupture event.

Patient Case Presentation:  Patient Information: Mr. Jack Martin is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired  residing in Norfolk  Virginia  USA. He is a lifelong non-smoker with a moderate history of alcohol use but has been sober for the last 5 years.  Chief Complaint: The patient presented with a consistent  severe pain in the stomach  radiating to the back.   History of Present Illness: The patient reported that the pain started abruptly about one day ago  has been steadily worsening  and is not relieved by any over-the-counter medications. No accompanying symptoms such as loss of consciousness  nausea  vomiting  or alteration in bowel habits were reported.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Martin has a known diagnosis of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for which he has been under treatment for the past 15 years. He also has a history of myocardial infarction 5 years ago and has been on aspirin and beta-blockers since then.   Family History: His father died of heart disease at age 67  and his mother died at age 78 from complications related to hypertension. He has one brother who is healthy and two sisters  one of whom was treated for breast cancer at age 50.  Physical Examination: Blood pressure: 160/90 mmHg  Pulse rate: 82 bpm  Temperature: 98.6°F  Respiratory rate: 18 breaths per minute. Abdominal examination revealed a palpable  pulsatile mass in the epigastric region.  Investigations: Ultrasound of the abdomen confirmed an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring 5.5 cm in diameter with no sign of rupture. Blood tests include: Complete Blood Count (CBC)  Liver Function Test (LFT)  Kidney Function Test (KFT)  Lipid profile. All within normal range except for elevated cholesterol and triglyceride levels. EKG and echocardiogram showed no abnormalities.  Management: Mr. Martin was admitted to the hospital and cardiothoracic surgery was consulted. He underwent successful endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) without any complications. His hypertension and hyperlipidemia medications were also reviewed and updated accordingly.  Follow Up: Mr. Martin was advised to follow up within two weeks after discharge  and regular follow-ups were scheduled every 6 months to monitor the aneurysm and to manage his blood pressure and cholesterol levels. He was advised to restrict his sodium and fat intake.  Conclusion: This case highlights the importance of a comprehensive medical history  clinical suspicion  and appropriate investigations in diagnosing AAA. With his family history of cardiovascular disease  Mr. Martin represents a typical AAA patient as described in the literature. Timely diagnosis and appropriate management can significantly improve patient outcome.

Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 70-year-old African-American male  has been diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Presenting Concerns: The client came in complaining of consistent and pulsatile abdominal pain. He rated it at a level of 8 out of 10 on the pain scale.  Medical History: Mr. Doe had a history of smoking  having stopped 15 years ago. He currently takes medications for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Type 2 diabetes. Past medical history also includes a minor myocardial infarction five years ago.  Family History: His father died from complications of an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 75. His mother lived to 80 and passed away due to breast cancer. His younger brother (age 67) has been diagnosed with a small abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Physical Examination: Upon physical review  an abdominal bruit was noted  along with a pulsatile abdominal mass.  Investigations & Results: A CT scan confirmed the presence of an aneurysm measuring 5.6 cm. Given his history and the results  he is currently classified as a higher risk patient.  Management Plan: He has been referred for an endovascular aneurysm repair. He was advised to quit drinking  follow a healthy diet  maintain a healthy weight  and perform regular exercise  alongside ongoing management for his chronic diseases.  Given Mr. Doe's personal medical history  the loftiness of the aneurysm  and his brother's diagnosis  he falls into a demographic highly susceptible to abdominal aortic aneurysms according to research. Such demographic includes mainly males over the age of 65  especially African-American  with a family history and related conditions  like atherosclerosis  hypertension  and a degree of genetic predisposition.  (Please note: This presentation should be validated with actual patient information to ensure an accurate and effective plan of care. Always respect the patient's privacy and confidentiality rights.)

Title: Elderly Hypertensive Male with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  living in rural Midwestern America. He has been a lifetime non-smoker and has moderate alcohol consumption habits. The patient has a known history of hypertension  for which he is on medication (Lisinopril 10mg daily). He has no history of diabetes or dyslipidemia and lives a moderately active lifestyle.   Medical History:  In addition to hypertension  the patient has a history of prostate cancer treated by radiation therapy eight years ago. He reports being in remission following therapy. His father had a history of coronary artery disease and died of a myocardial infarction in his late sixties. The patient’s mother lived into her late eighties and had a history of stroke. There is no familial history of any kind of aneurysm. The patient has two elder brothers both in their late seventies  with no major health concerns.   Presenting Problem:  The patient was referred for a routine screening ultrasound of the abdomen owing to his advancing age and history of hypertension. The radiologist identified an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring approximately 4.5cm in diameter and referred the patient back to his primary care physician  who ordered a CT scan to further examine the aneurysm.   Additional Findings:  This test confirmed the presence of the aneurysm. Furthermore  it demonstrated that the aneurysm was situated infra-renally  with no sign of rupture or leakage. Physical examination of the patient revealed no abdominal pain or discomfort  no back pain  and no pulsatile abdominal mass. The patient had a healthy BMI of 24 and appeared to be in good general health.  Recommendations:  Given the size of the aneurysm  the patient does not currently meet criteria for surgical repair (>5.5cm). Instead  the patient should have regular surveillance via ultrasound every 6-12 months to monitor the aneurysm's size. He should continue his hypertensive medicine and encourage an active lifestyle. Counseling may be advisable for the associated psychological distress.  In Summary:  An infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm was detected in a 72-year-old hypertensive man during a routine ultrasound screening. The aneurysm is currently 4.5cm in diameter and shows no signs of rupture. Non-surgical treatment  aimed primarily at monitoring  is recommended at this time.

Patient Case Presentation  Patient Profile: Mr. Diaz  a 70-year-old Hispanic male  retired mechanic from Texas  presented to the clinic with pain in his lower back and abdomen. He is a smoker with a history of high blood pressure and carries a BMI of 28. He consumes alcohol only socially and denies any use of illicit substances. He lives with his wife of 45 years and has two grown-up children. There is a family history of cardiovascular disorders; his father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 76 and one of his brothers was recently diagnosed with a peripheral artery disease.  Clinical Presentation: Mr. Diaz reports a consistent dull pain in his lower back for the last three weeks. The pain has gradually increased and occasionally radiates towards his abdomen. He also describes feeling generally malaise and has a noticeable decrease in appetite. There have been instances of light-headedness  though no instances of fainting. There have been no changes to his bowel or bladder habits.  Physical Examination: The patient has a blood pressure of 150/90 mm Hg and a resting pulse of 85 bpm. Abdominal examination revealed a palpable pulsatile mass and slight lower abdominal tenderness.  Investigations: The patient was then sent to have an abdominal ultrasound  which reported a 5.6 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. Blood tests show normal renal function but slightly elevated high-sensitivity C-reactive protein levels  indicative of systemic inflammation.  Working Diagnosis: Based on his clinical symptoms  family history  physical examination  and ultrasound scan  Mr. Diaz was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Management: A surgical consultation was arranged considering the size of the aneurysm and patient's symptoms. The surgeon explained that treatment options include open surgical repair or an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) - a less invasive procedure. Lifestyle changes were also emphasized  such as smoking cessation and blood pressure control.  Patient's Progress: Mr. Diaz elected to proceed with EVAR  which was successful without any complications. The patient is scheduled for follow-up visits with vascular surgery every six months to monitor his aneurysm via ultrasound. He has enrolled in smoking cessation and diet and exercise programs offered by the clinic and has been prescribed medication for improved control of his blood pressure. Presently  Mr. Diaz reports no issues of abdominal pain and is pursuing a healthier lifestyle.  Conclusion: Mr. Diaz's case has been crucial in understanding the early detection importance and accurate management of abdominal aortic aneurysms  considering the risk factors such as family history  advanced age  and smoking. The entire healthcare team will continue to work closely with him  ensuring constant monitoring and lifestyle changes to prevent recurrence in the future.

Patient Presentation  Patient Information:  Patient X is a 72-year-old Caucasian male who presents with a diagnosis of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA).   Demographics:  He is living in a rural community of Oklahoma  USA  and is a retired mechanical engineer. He has been a smoker for the past 50 years but is trying to quit currently.  Past Medical History:  Patient X had been diagnosed with hypertension for the past 15 years for which he takes regular antihypertensive medication. He has a history of hypercholesterolemia but refuses the use of statins due to previous experiences of side effects. His medical history also reveals diabetic mellitus (Type 2) which he manages with oral hypoglycemics. Other past medical events include a femoral hernia repair done 8 years ago.   Family History:  His father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 66  and his mother is currently alive at the age of 98 with no known cardiac disease but suffers from old age-related dementia. His paternal uncle had passed away from an untreated AAA rupture.   Present Health Status: The patient confirms he has been experiencing intermittent mild abdominal discomfort and lower back pain. These symptoms have alarmed him due to his family history of AAA. He denies trauma  bowel changes  gastroenteritis symptoms  urinary changes  or any other systemic symptoms.   Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass can be felt. However  examination findings might not be accurate due to his high BMI causing difficulty feeling the AAA. As such  an ultrasound was conducted  which confirmed the presence of an AAA of approximately 5.6 cm in diameter. Lab results indicate borderline glycemic control and slightly elevated lipid profile.   Management and Conclusion: The size of the aneurysm suggests an impending risk of rupture that calls for surgical intervention. Considering his age  family history  smoking status  the presence of other cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension  diabetes  and hypercholesterolemia  Patient X should be referred to vascular surgery for evaluation for potential repair. His management will also involve discussions about smoking cessation  improved control of his blood glucose levels  his blood pressure  and a reluctance to use statins.

Patient Identification: Mr. John  67-year-old male  Presenting Conditions: He arrived at the clinic complaining of consistent  dull abdominal pain and occasional lower back pain. These symptoms have been ongoing for a few weeks.  Past Medical History: Mr. John has been hypertensive for six years  actively managed through a regimen of antihypertensives. His additional medical history involves hyperlipidemia and mild renal impairment 5 years ago. The patient is an ex-smoker with a 30 pack-year history  having stopped smoking about ten years ago.  Family History: His father passed away from heart disease in his early 70s. His mother is alive and in her early 90s  suffering from dementia.  Physical Exam: On examination  the patient appeared comfortable but slightly anxious. Abdominal palpation revealed a large  pulsating mass consistent with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He was afebrile  his blood pressure was slightly elevated at 145/80 mmHg  and his heart rate at rest was 80 bpm. No peripheral edema was noticed  and both pulses in the lower extremities were felt equally and strongly.  Inferences: Given the clinical findings and the patient's medical history  the possible diagnosis was an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  which was inherent with a high possibility of rupture due to the patient's history of hypertension and smoking. The consistent abdominal pain experienced by Mr. John may be due to the increased pressure on neighboring organs caused by the aneurysm. Also  his age and gender correlate with demographic trends of AAA  which is more commonly found in men over the age of 65.  Management and Follow-up: Immediate intervention was deemed necessary due to the high risk of rupture. Therefore  an urgent CT scan was ordered to confirm the diagnosis and ascertain the size of the aneurysm. Thereafter  surgical intervention (either open surgical repair or endovascular aneurysm repair) would be performed according to the characteristics of the aneurysm and the patient's overall health status.  The risk of rupture for AAAs increases significantly when their size exceeds 5.5 cm or if there is rapid expansion over a short period of time (more than 1 cm per year). In the patient's subsequent care  lifestyle adjustments like healthy diet  exercise  and stress management are crucial  considering his history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  With Mr. John's consent  his case was discussed with the surgery team and plans were made to proceed with the optimal treatment plan based on his scan results.

Patient Profile:  Mr. John  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department in our facility with complaints of abdominal pain and discomfort.  Relevant Demographics: - Age: 72   - Sex: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired teacher  Living Environment: He lives alone in his home since his wife passed away. His closest kin is his daughter who lives in another city.  Past Medical History: Mr. John has a 20-year history of hypertension and a documented 15-year history of hyperlipidemia. He's been fairly compliant with his anti-hypertensive and lipid-lowering medications. However  his lifestyle includes a lack of adequate physical activity and a diet high in saturated fats. He also has a significant history of smoking  about 30 pack-years (1 pack of cigarettes a day for 30 years). He has no known drug allergies.   Family History: His father had a stroke at 70 and his mother had an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture quite late in her life. There’s no other significant family history of any cardiac disease.   Observational findings: During physical examination  he was found to have a pulsatile mass in his abdomen. The abdominal pain was determined to be non-radiating but was located in the central lower region of the abdomen. There were no signs of inflammation or infection in the region. His blood pressure was elevated at 150/90 mmHg  and his BMI was 29  indicating obesity.  Investigations: After an Ultrasound confirmed a sizable aneurysm in the abdominal aorta  a CT angiogram was carried out showing an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring about 5.5 cm in maximum diameter. The aneurysm showed no signs of rupture or leak.  Treatment: Based on his symptomatic presentation and the size of the aneurysm  surgical intervention was suggested  alongside conservative management of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He quit smoking with regular follow-ups and counseling.  In summary  Mr. John's case is typical for an abdominal aortic aneurysm patient: elderly  male  with a history of heart-related conditions and smoking. His lifestyle choices and family history also put him at increased risk.  Discussion: Mr. John’s case a classic example of demographics implicated in Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA). Studies show a strong correlation between AAA and males over 65 years  particularly those who are Caucasian  with a smoking history or a familial disposition. Other risk factors like hyperlipidemia  hypertension  atherosclerosis  and obesity also contribute to his chances of having an AAA. Given his current status  comprehensive care is important to prolong his life and improve its quality. His family history makes it integral to educate immediate family members about AAA risks and preventive measures.

Case Presentation:  Patient Profile: The patient is a 69-year-old Caucasian male  retired military officer  recently diagnosed with abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both managed with medication. He is a moderate smoker  with 25 pack-years of smoking history. He does not consume alcohol or engage in any physical activity. Family history reveals that his father and elder brother also had AAA  presenting similarly in their late 60s.   Presentation: Post retirement  the patient presented to the clinic with complaints of a dull  constant  and severe abdominal pain that had been consistent for the past week. Added to these symptoms were episodes of intermittent claudication and recent unexplained weight loss. Central to his concerns was that the symptoms were similar to those experienced by his father and brother.   Clinical Examination and Investigations: On examination  he was found to have a pulsatile abdominal mass. Subsequent abdominal ultrasonography revealed a well-defined aneurysm of 5.5cm in the infra-renal portion of his abdominal aorta. Further duplex scanning confirmed the site and size of the aneurysm. Laboratory investigations showed a mildly elevated white cell count and lipid profile  other parameters were within normal limits.   Diagnosis: With a positive family history  clinical and imaging results  a diagnosis of familial AAA was made.   Patient Management: Given his age  existing comorbid conditions  malignancy of the AAA  the risk factor of smoking  and familial tendency  endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) was considered as the most suitable treatment option. However  the patient has been briefed on the benefits and risks associated with EVAR vs. open repair. As he was a moderate smoker  nicotine replacement therapy was also recommended to help him stop smoking.  Prognosis and follow-up: Given his general health and the success rate of EVAR  the prognosis is good. However  he has been advised that close surveillance is necessary post-EVAR because of the risk of endoleak or aneurysm expansion. He will also need to make lifestyle modifications  including maintaining a heart-healthy diet  controlling hypertension and hyperlipidemia  and discontinuing smoking.  This case highlights the interplay of genetic predisposition  lifestyle factors  and aging in the manifestation of AAA. It exhibits the importance of early detection  proper diagnostic measures  and patient-centered management strategies that contribute to improved patient outcomes. It also underlines the importance of lifestyle modifications and systemic disease control in managing AAA.

Case Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile:  Mr. D is a 70-year-old African American man with a past medical history of hypertension  type II diabetes mellitus  and a 30-pack year smoking history. He lives in suburban America and is a retired mechanic.  Presenting Issue:  He presented to his primary care physician with complaints of intermittent  non-radiating  dull abdominal pain for the past two weeks. The pain seemed unrelated to food intake and was not accompanied by any other symptoms.  Past Medical History:  Mr. D’s hypertension and diabetes have been relatively well-controlled over the last decade. He has no known heart disease  stroke  or peripheral arterial disease.   Social History:  He is a retired mechanic and has a history of heavy smoking (30-pack years) but quit 10 years ago. He consumes alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use. He lives with his wife  has two adult children  and is physically active.  Family History:  His father had a history of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) and passed away due to its rupture. His brother had coronary artery disease and underwent coronary artery bypass grafting at age 65.  Physical Exam:  His vital signs are stable. On abdominal examination  a pulsatile mass is palpable. The rest of the physical exam findings are within normal limits.   Diagnostic Investigations and Results:  Considering his symptoms  family history  and physical exam findings  a computed tomography (CT) scan is ordered. The CT scan confirms an infrarenal AAA measuring 5.5 cm in diameter.   Treatment Plan:  Due to the size of the aneurysm and his father's aneurysmal rupture  Mr. D is referred to a vascular surgeon for further management.   Summary:  In consideration of his demographic profile  Mr. D has several risk factors for AAA  including age  male gender  African American ethnicity  smoking history  and family history. The early detection of his AAA creates an opportunity for successful surgical intervention  which may significantly improve his prognosis. His case underlines the importance of risk stratification  physical examination  and timely investigation in patients with risk factors for AAA. This strategy may facilitate early diagnosis and reduction in morbidity and mortality associated with AAA rupture.

Case Presentation:  Patient Overview:  Mr. J  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the emergency department complaining of intense abdominal and back pain radiating to his lower back. He has a medical history consistent with hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack-year smoking history  but has quit smoking for the last 10 years. The patient's body mass index (BMI) lands him in the overweight category  at 27.   Demographics:  Historically  abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is most commonly found in Caucasian males over the age of 65 (Wanhainen  2019). Hence  Mr. J falls within the high-risk demographic. The patient currently lives with his wife in a suburban setting  retired from his occupation as a mechanic. He leads a somewhat sedentary lifestyle with a history of moderate alcohol consumption.  Family History:  Mr. J's father died from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 73  thus indicating a strong family history. His elder brother (age 72) was diagnosed with an unruptured AAA two years ago  which further heightens Mr. J's risk of developing an AAA. Although his mother lived until 85 without cardiovascular complications  she had controlled hypertension and lived with type 2 diabetes.  Clinical Presentation:  Upon physical examination  Mr. J was found to have a palpable pulsating mass in the middle and upper part of his abdomen. He reported sudden severe pain in his abdominal area persisting for a few hours. There was no report of syncopal episodes  shortness of breath  or chest pain. However  he communicated a feeling of ""general unwellness"".   Diagnostic Tests and Results:  According to The Society for Vascular Surgery (SVS)  patients like Mr. J with a high suspicion of AAA should have immediate diagnostic imaging (Chaikof et al.  2018). An emergency abdominal ultrasound revealed an aortic aneurysm of 5.5cm. His electrocardiogram did not show any signs of myocardial infarction  and routine laboratory tests  including kidney function and complete blood cell count  came back normal except for elevated levels of D-dimer.  Conclusion: The diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm in Mr. J correlates with prior research indicating AAA diagnoses are more frequent in males with aging  history of smoking  hypertension  and strong family history of AAA. An emergency surgical consultation was made for the probable ruptured AAA  given the patient's severe pain and large aneurysm size. Meanwhile  he was stabilized with analgesia  intravenous fluids  and blood pressure management.  References: Chaikof EL  Dalman RL  Eskandari MK  et al. The Society for Vascular Surgery practice guidelines on the care of patients with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. J Vasc Surg. 2018;67(1):2–77.e2.  Wanhainen A. How to define an abdominal aortic aneurysm--influence on epidemiology and clinical practice. Scand J Surg. 2008;97(2):105-9; discussion 109.

Patient Profile  Mr. John Smith  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  is a retired mechanical engineer living in Upstate New York. He is a non-smoker and moderate occasional drinker. He has been obese for most of his adult life  with a body mass index (BMI) of 33. He's previously been diagnosed with hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  which are managed with medication. He is also compliant with his medication regime.   Family History and Current Health  Patient's father died in his early 70s due to complications from an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). His mother lived to her late 80s and had a history of hypertension and stroke. He is father to three children  all of whom are healthy.  The patient lives an active lifestyle and frequently partakes in morning walks. However  he has recently been complaining of a persistent  mild abdominal pain accompanied by back discomfort  noticeable after his morning walk  and subsides during the day while at rest. There have been no other new symptoms or significant changes in his health status.  Diagnosis and Treatment Plan  A CT Scan was conducted showing an abdominal aortic aneurysm of 5.5 cm. Due to the size and the patient's symptoms  surgical intervention is indicated. A meeting with the vascular surgery team is planned for reviewing the surgical options - open repair or endovascular aneurysm repair.  Management and Follow-up  The patient is on follow-up appointment schedules  and regular blood pressure checks have been strongly advised to manage systemic hypertension  which can influence the progression of the aneurysm. The patient understands the importance of vigilance regarding symptoms like sudden severe abdominal or back pain  altered state of consciousness  and feeling faint - which may indicate rupture and be life-threatening.  Conclusion  The patient's timescale to treatment and management is being expedited due to the presentation of symptoms and confirmed diagnosis. The nuclear family will need counseling  and risk determination screening may be recommended given the familial AAA incidental history. Lifestyle modifications such as weight management have also been advised to the patient as it can impact overall vascular health.   The medical team looks forward to monitoring this gentleman's progress  taking every measure to ensure his optimal recovery and long-term health.

Patient Case Presentation  I. Patient Introduction Patient X is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  currently residing in New York. He is retired and lives with his wife of 50 years. He has two children  both healthy and in their forties. The patient does not have a history of smoking  nor does he consume alcohol.   II. Education and Occupation Patient X is a retired engineer who had an active lifestyle prior to experiencing health issues. In the last decade  he had been dealing with hypertension and high cholesterol  for which he has been regularly taking prescribed medications.   III. Family and Social History  The patient’s father died of a heart attack at the age of 75 and his mother died at 90 due to old age. He has a younger sister who was diagnosed with breast cancer a few years ago  but there are no known genetic diseases within the family.   IV. Medical History Patient X was diagnosed with hypertension and hypercholesterolemia 10 years ago. He was diagnosed by his primary care physician  and since then  he’s been on antihypertensive and statin therapy. He has shown adequate compliance with medication but has inconsistent control of his blood pressure. He has no known allergies to medications.   V. Presenting Complaint Patient X visited the emergency department with complaints of an abrupt onset of severe pain in the lower abdomen and lower-back that began earlier in the week. The pain was described as constant and sharp  rating it as 8 out of 10 in intensity.   VI. Examination and Investigation Findings Upon physical examination  a noticeable pulsatile abdominal mass was present which raised the suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). A subsequent CT scan confirmed an AAA  measuring approximately 5.5 cm in diameter.   VII. Assessment and Plan  Given the size of the aneurysm  Patient X was recommended for immediate surgical intervention. Currently  endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) is being considered instead of traditional open surgery due to its minimally invasive nature and relatively lower risk.   In addition to surgery  Patient X’s current antihypertensive program will be reassessed to ensure optimal post-operative outcomes. A long-term plan including medical follow-up and lifestyle modifications including low salt  low cholesterol diet and an appropriate exercise regime will be considered.   VIII. Relevant Past Medical History  Patient X's hypertension and hypercholesterolemia are significant risk factors for AAA. The age  gender  and family history of cardiovascular disease make him more susceptible to the condition. Also  the large size of the aneurysm increases the risk of rupture  which is a life-threatening emergency.   Prepared by:  [Your Name] [Your Title or Position]   Date: [Presentation Date]

Patient Profile: Patient X is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  currently retired. His past medical history includes hypertension  hyperlipidemia (both managed with medications)  and a 40-pack year smoking history but quit 10 years ago. He has no known allergies. His family history includes his father dying of a myocardial infarction at an age of 65.   Presenting Problem: Patient X first consulted due to a dull  persistent pain in the lower back and abdomen  symptoms that he noticed increasing in frequency over the previous few weeks. He also complained of feelings of fullness. He denied experiencing any episodes of chest pain  palpitations  shortness of breath  syncope  or early satiety. He admitted to an unintentional weight loss of about 10 pounds over the past year  attributing it to reduced appetite and possible 'ageing'.   Clinical Findings and Diagnosis: Physical examination showed a moderately built man  with a blood pressure of 140/90 mmHg. On abdominal examination  a pulsatile mass was palpable in the midline just above the umbilicus. No bruits were heard over this mass. The rest of the examination was unremarkable.   Given the clinical suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  an abdominal ultrasound was performed which confirmed a 5.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. A CT angiogram was ordered to clearly delineate the extent of the aneurysm which also confirmed the diagnosis and further showed no evidence of rupture or leak.   Management Plan: Post-diagnosis  a consult with Vascular Surgery was sought which leaned towards an endovascular repair given the diameter and infra-renal location of the AAA. The patient underwent successful endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) and stayed for 2 days post-procedure for monitoring. His post-procedure recovery was uneventful  and follow-ups were scheduled.   Noteworthy Details: About 75% of AAA occur in men  with the highest prevalence in Caucasian men over 65. The most significant risk factors for AAAs include age  male sex  a history of ever smoking  and a first-degree family history of AAA. Most AAAs are asymptomatic until they rupture.   This case emphasizes the importance of observing subtle symptoms and vigilant physical examination  leading to early diagnosis and management in high-risk populations  thereby potentially avoiding devastating complications. A multidisciplinary approach involving a vascular surgeon was beneficial in this case.

Patient Identification:  Mr. Smith is a 72-year-old white male  retired military officer  presenting with complaints of persistent back and abdominal pain. He hails from Charleston  South Carolina and lives with his wife. His medical records indicate he is a chronic smoker for over 50 years and consumes alcohol occasionally. He does not have any known allergies.  Medical History:  The patient has a long-standing history of hypertension and high cholesterol  for which he is taking medication. His chart shows he has been non-compliant with his antihypertensive and lipid-lowering therapy. In the past  he has undergone surgery for a hernia and has been treated for peptic ulcer disease.   Family History:  Mr. Smith's mother passed away in her late 60s due to stroke  and his father died in his early 70s from a myocardial infarction. His older brother underwent surgery for the same condition  abdominal aortic aneurysm when he was 68 years old.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Smith reports a 2-week history of unrelenting lower back pain and occasional stomach pain. He describes the pain as a deep  throbbing feeling that becomes more intense with movements. Although he experiences mild relief with over the counter painkillers  it doesn't totally disappear.   Physical Examination & Diagnostic Tests:  Upon examination  a palpable pulsating mass in the abdomen was felt. Abdominal ultrasonography and a CT scan confirmed an infrarenal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.5 cm. Laboratory tests reveal elevated total cholesterol and LDL levels.  Plan:  Given the family history  smoking habit  and the size of the aneurysm  surgical intervention is discussed for Mr. Smith. He is now under the medical supervision of a vascular specialist. Given his notable risk of rupture  an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) procedure has been planned. His dietary habits and medication compliance are also being addressed.  Mr. Smith’s case underscores the importance of genetic predisposition  lifestyle choices  and adherence to treatment protocols in managing chronic vascular diseases like abdominal aortic aneurysm. It also highlights the necessity of periodic screening in high-risk individuals to prevent possible complications.

Patient Presentation:  Demographics: The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  referred for further checkup after a routine medical examination. He a retired engineer  lives with his wife  and has no history of smoking or illicit drug use. The patient drinks alcohol socially. His background shows a sedentary lifestyle since retirement.  Past Medical History: The patient’s medical history includes hypertension  which has been controlled by medication for the past 15 years. He has a history of high cholesterol levels and peripheral artery disease. He also had a coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG) 8 years ago. He was diagnosed with Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus three years ago and maintains his blood glucose levels well with medication and diet.  Family History: The family history is significant with the patient's father having died of myocardial infarction at the age of 70  and his mother passing away from stroke at the age of 75. His elder brother has peripheral artery disease  and a younger sister is living without any reported arterial or heart disease.  Presenting Complaint: The patient reported persistent abdominal pain and a sense of fullness. He had noticeably lost weight in the past few months.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  a pulsatile mass was palpated in the mid-abdominal area. The patient showed no signs of distress or altered mental status; his extremities were warm & well perfused.  Investigations: An ultrasound and subsequent CT scan confirmed a 6cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Management Approach: Initially  conservative management was started. However  given the patient's rapid aneurysm growth  significant size and the associated risks  an endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) was recommended after discussing the surgery risks and benefits with the patient.  Discussion: The patient represents the classic case of AAA  considering his demographic (white older male)  personal (hypertension  high cholesterol  smoking) and family history (cardiovascular diseases). AAA prevalence increases with age and is more common among males  with a male to female ratio of 6:1. Smoking  hypertension  age over 60 years and history of heart disease in the family are common risk factors seen  with approximately 20% AAA cases been reported to be genetically linked.  Therefore  early detection through routine clinical examination and screening of at-risk individuals is crucial as the majority of AAA  if ruptured  could be fatal. Most AAAs are asymptomatic until rupture  hence screenings and careful intervention planning as seen in this case presentation is highly vital. Overall  in relation to the risk factors  demographic details and family history this case presentation properly represents a typical case of abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Demographic Information  Patient Profile: Male  Caucasian  Age: 72  Presenting Problem: The patient complained of persistent abdominal pain and discomfort  with occasional back pain.  Past Medical History: History of Hypertension  High cholesterol  history of smoking  and Type II Diabetes.   Family History: Family history reveals there was a father and an uncle with cardiovascular ailments  specifically heart attacks in their 70s. Mother has a history of Hypertension and Hypercholesterolemia.   Physical Findings and Symptoms: The patient has been experiencing persistent  cramp-like abdominal pain which tends to radiate to the back. He reports occasional waves of severe  sudden stomach pain that lasts for more than a few hours. The patient also complains of bloating. He also reported unintentional weight loss over the past few months and weakness. No signs of fever. Physical examination reveals a palpable  pulsating abdominal mass that is tender to touch.  Diagnostic Findings: Ultrasound of the abdomen revealed a 5.2 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. No signs of rupture or leak were detected on the ultrasound.  Impression and Plan: The clinical findings in combination with the imaging results confirmed the diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Given the size of the AAA and the patient’s persisting symptoms  surgical repair was deemed necessary. As the patient has a significant risk for cardiovascular disease based on his medical and family history  he will be referred to a cardiologist for evaluation before surgery. Strict control of hypertension and diabetes is advised. Lifestyle modifications including cessation of tobacco use  dietary changes for cholesterol control and regulating blood sugar levels are advised.   Status Post Presentation: The patient is scheduled for an Endovascular Aneurysm Repair (EVAR). Prior to surgery  patient will also be on surveillance and medications to manage his hypertension  diabetes and hyperlipidemia.   Future Follow-up Plan: Post-operatively  he will be closely monitored in the intensive care unit. Discharge planning will involve teaching the patient about the signs of possible complications such as infection  aneurysm rupture  or graft problems. Follow-up appointments are set-up to monitor his recovery  wound healing and symptoms. Regular ultrasounds will be performed to track the stability of the aneurysm after repair. Long-term management of high cholesterol  hypertension  and type II diabetes is planned. Lifestyle modifications including tobacco cessation and diet changes will continue to be emphasized.

Patient Overview:  Mr. X is a 72-year-old African American male who presented himself at the hospital with complaints of continuous abdominal pain radiating towards his lower back. The ache has been worsening over the past few hours  with no relief from over-the-counter pain medications.   Demographics:  Epidemiological studies indicate that certain demographic categories  like older male patients of African American heritage  are at an increased risk of abdominal aortic aneurysms. Given the patient's age  race  and sex  he falls within this high-risk demographic.  Past Medical History:  Mr. X is a retired construction worker with a history of high blood pressure and high cholesterol levels for which he's been on medication for the past ten years. However  his compliance with taking the medication regularly has been questionable. He possesses a 50-pack smoking history and quit smoking five years ago. However  he reports no known allergic reactions to drugs.   Family History and other Risk Factors:  The patient's father passed away from an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture during his late 70s. Given Mr. X's familial predisposition and smoking history  the danger of an aortic aneurysm rises significantly. Studies indicate strong associations between family history  longtime tobacco use  and the prevalence of abdominal aortic aneurysms.  Diagnosis:  Upon initial examination  a pulsating mass could be detected in the abdominal region. The subsequent Ultrasonography and CT scan confirmed the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  approximately 5.5 cm in diameter  which is a significant size  calling for immediate intervention.  Treatment Plan:  Considering age  overall health status  and size of the aneurysm  a surgical approach is recommended for Mr. X. As his vital signs are currently stable  endovascular repair (EVAR) may be considered. Additionally  lifestyle modifications have been recommended  in line with control of blood pressure  lipid profile  and maintaining a cardio-healthy diet. He has also been advised to refrain from heavy lifting and strenuous activities.  Prognosis & Discussion:  The prognosis of untreated large AAAs is generally poor due to the high risk of rupture. However  with successful intervention  most individuals can continue to live a normal life. The surgical repair  while not without risks  significantly improves the prognosis. Regular follow-up care including surveillance imaging is essential.  Teaching points:  1. High-risk demographics for AAA include older age  male sex  African American ethnicity  and family history. 2. Lifestyle factors (hypertension  smoking  high cholesterol) contribute to AAA's 3. AAA often presents as a pulsating abdominal mass with or without pain radiating to the back 4. The risk of rupture is substantial for aneurysms over 5cm  needing surgical repair. 5. Post-surgical patients require regular follow-up and imaging surveillance.

Case Presentation:  Patient Profile:  Mr. J is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presenting with diagnosed abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The patient is a retired construction worker  married  with two grown children. He has a 45 pack-year smoking history but quit about 5 years ago. He drinks alcohol socially  and his BMI is 28  which categorizes him as overweight.  Past Medical History: Mr. J has a medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He was treated with an Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme inhibitor  amlodipine and a statin for these conditions respectively with average blood pressure within the normal range for the past year. He had his last cardiology check-up six months ago which did not pose any significant issues.  Symptoms Presentation: He came to the hospital complaining of a constant  severe pain in his abdomen and lower back  which started about three days ago. Mr. J also reports infrequent irregular heartbeat episodes over the past few months. There are no associated symptoms of gastrointestinal disorders  loss of consciousness  chest pain or shortness of breath.   Family History: His father died of an AAA rupture at the age of 72. In light of his family history and smoking history  Mr. J had been getting regular ultrasounds to monitor for an AAA and it was through this protocol  an expanding 5.4 cm infrarenal AAA was discovered two years ago. His mother had type 2 diabetes and died at the age of 78 due to myocardial infarction. His two siblings are alive and well; the older brother has hypertension  and a younger sister is healthy.  Physical Examination: The patient is afebrile. His vitals on presentation were BP 145/90 mm Hg  heart rate 75 bpm  respiratory rate 16/min and oxygen saturation 97% on room air. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the epigastrium.   Investigation: His complete blood count  urinalysis and kidney function tests were within normal limits. An ultrasound confirmed the presence of an AAA measuring 5.6 cm  which indicates moderate risk but considering his symptoms  it raises concern for imminent rupture.  Management Plan: Given his significant pain and the size increase of the aneurysm despite medical therapy  our team  after discussing with Mr. J  decided to proceed with open surgical repair. Risks and benefits were discussed with the patient  and he gave informed consent for the procedure.  Note: This case is a representation of the typical age group (65-75 year old)  gender (male)  ethnicity (Caucasian) and risk factors (smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  family history) associated with AAAs based on the literature. This demographic and risk factor profile corresponds with the general AAA patient population. The AAA growth rate has been estimated at 2-3mm/year. Larger AAAs (>5 cm) are associated with higher risk of rupture  especially if rapidly expanding or symptomatic.

Patient Profile: Mr. John Doe is a 70-year-old retired African American man  living independently with his wife in New Jersey. He was brought into the emergency department experiencing extreme back pain. Mr. Doe's BMI is 28 and he is a former smoker  having a 45 pack-year history. He quit smoking 15-years ago. He does not drink alcohol. According to the literature  it has been noted that African American men are at a higher risk of developing an abdominal aortic aneurysm  with the incidence further increasing with age  high BMI and smoking history.  Past Medical History: The patient has a sedentary lifestyle and is often subjected to unhealthy eating habits. He was diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago. Hypertension significantly increases the risk for developing an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Furthermore  he has type 2 diabetes controlled by Metformin for about 3 years and a history of moderate COPD diagnosed 7 years ago.  Family History: Mr. Doe's father passed away suddenly at the age of 55 due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. The presence of AAA in a first degree relative significantly increases the risk in patients  especially in males.  Presenting Condition: The patient presents with severe  sudden onset of pain at the back. Other complaints include dizziness  shortness of breath  and a rapid pulse. He denies chest pain  paleness  and clamminess. Differential diagnosis may include kidney stones  appendicitis  diverticulitis  or aortic dissection. However  his risk factors and symptoms led to the consideration of abdominal aortic aneurysm.   Investigations: Imaging studies were immediately requested – an abdominal ultrasound and CT aortogram. Results confirmed a 5.4 cm abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Management Planning: Clearly  the risk of rupture is high (AAA diameter >5.5 cm) and the patient's history highly suggesting the same. This patient will be referred to a cardiovascular surgeon for a possible surgical intervention. Lifestyle modifications are needed – reducing cardiovascular risks  managing his diabetes  COPD  and hypertension  and helping him to maintain a healthy diet.  Mr. Doe  his wife  and his children should be advised to get screened for AAA due to the strong family history. Further  cessation  or avoidance  of smoking should be emphasised as it is recognized as a significant risk factor for the development of AAA.   Outcome and Follow-Up: The patient will be closely monitored post-surgery with regular follow-ups  monitoring for potential complications and to ensure overall well-being and health status.  Mr. Doe's case emphasizes the importance of adequate screening measures  especially in high-risk populations  for timely diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  and can perhaps serve as a reminder for the same.

Patient's Profile: The patient under discussion is Mr. Smith  a 76-year-old Caucasian male with a history of smoking and hypertension.  Presenting Information: Mr. Smith presented to the clinic complaining of sudden  severe pain in his lower back and abdomen that started a couple of days ago. He also mentioned some mild-but-noticeable fatigue and slight dizziness over the past week.   Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has been hypertensive for the past 20 years  which is managed by a combination of beta blockers and ACE inhibitors. He is also a former heavy smoker  but he quit smoking around ten years ago after being diagnosed with mild Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD). No history of diabetes  dyslipidemia  coronary artery disease  or aneurysms is recorded in his medical chart.  Family History: There is a remarkable history of aneurysms in Mr. Smith's family: both his father and grandfather succumbed to complications due to aortic aneurysms.   Physical Examination and Findings: On physical examination  Mr. Smith's blood pressure was found to be slightly elevated (148/92 mmHg). Abdominal palpation revealed a pulsating mass. Subsequent ultrasound examination confirmed the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring approximately 5.5 cm in diameter. No other abnormalities were noticed.  Lab Results  Diagnosis and Treatment Course: Bloodwork  including full blood count  kidney function tests  and electrolytes  was generally within normal parameters. EKG showed no abnormalities. The final diagnosis indicated an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Due to the size of the aneurysm  and Mr. Smith's family history  an open surgical repair was recommended to the patient and his family. He is currently awaiting surgery and is under strict monitoring for any changes in his condition.  Social History: Mr. Smith lives with his wife in a suburban neighborhood. He is a retired engineer who leads a sedentary lifestyle. He quit smoking ten years ago. He doesn't consume alcohol or take illicit drugs. The couple has two adult children who live nearby.  Conclusion: Mr. Smith's presenting symptoms  physical examination  and subsequent ultrasound led to his diagnosis of the abdominal aortic aneurysm. His past medical history  family history of aneurysms  and lifestyle choices  such as smoking and having a sedentary lifestyle  have likely contributed to his current condition. Owing to the significant size of the aneurysm and his family history  an open surgical approach is recommended.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnston is a 71-year-old  Hispanic  retired mechanical engineer with a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and tobacco use. He was born in Texas and has lived there his entire life. He has no known drug allergies. He is currently living with his wife and is a father of three grown-up children. His mother passed away due to colorectal cancer and his father died of a stroke at the age of 78. He does not report any exercise or diet regimen.  Presenting Complaint:   Mr. Johnston presented to the clinic with complaints of a pulsatile abdominal mass that he noticed while taking a shower  coupled with a dull  constant abdominal pain for the past two weeks. He also mentioned that he occasionally feels a similar pain radiating to his lower back.  Physical Examination:  On examination  a pulsatile mass approximately 4 cm in size is palpable in the abdomen in the midline. His blood pressure is 145/90 mmHg  heart rate 85 bpm  and BMI 30.1. His chest and cardiac exams are unremarkable.   Investigation and Diagnosis:  Abdominal ultrasound revealed a 5.1 cm infrarenal aortic aneurysm. A CT angiography further confirmed a saccular aneurysm in the abdominal aorta. Given his symptoms and the size of the aneurysm  he was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   Management Plan:  Considering the size and symptoms of Mr. Johnston's aneurysm and taking into account his current overall health  the team decided to proceed with an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). Preoperative cardiac assessment showed no significant cardiac diseases that would prevent him from having the surgery.  In addition to treating the AAA  he was advised to continue his antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering medication  and a smoking cessation program was instituted. He was also encouraged to engage in a regular exercise routine and healthy diet to help control his other comorbidities.  Conclusion:   Mr. Johnston's case represents a common scenario in older male patients who smoke and have a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which are all strong risk factors for AAA. His demographic features and social determinants of health  such as his Hispanic background and resident of Texas  similarly fit the typical profile associated with increased risk of AAA as found in literature.

Patient Profile:   Mr. James  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  is brought to the emergency department with complaints of severe  tearing abdominal and back pain of sudden onset. Accompanying symptoms include lightheadedness  fainting  and profuse sweating. He has no known food allergies; but is allergic to penicillin. Mr. James is a retired coal miner  married with three adult children  and lives with his wife in the rural community.   Past Medical History:  Mr. James has a history of smoking and heavy alcohol use (1-2 packs/day for around 40 years and 3-4 drinks per day). He reports hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medications: Amlodipine 5mg and Atorvastatin 10mg respectively. He has no past diagnoses of cardiovascular diseases. In the past two years  he has complained intermittently about vague abdominal and back pain  assumed to be related to his previous hernia operation and advancing age  but never as severe as his current presentation.   Family History:  His mother died at the age of 75 due to a stroke and his father passed away at 68 from a sudden heart attack. One of his uncles had an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  suggesting possible genetic predisposition.  Physical Examination:  On examination  he appears distressed and diaphoretic. His temperature is slightly elevated  his blood pressure is 150/90 mm of Hg in his right arm and 145/85 mm of Hg in his left arm while his heart rate is tachycardic – 108 bpm. He has a pulsatile mass in his abdomen that is tender to palpation.   Investigations:  Subsequent CT scan revealed an AAA of 8 cm in diameter below the renal arteries with signs of rupture; Hemoglobin is slightly decreased  creatinine is elevated.  Diagnosis:  Given the history  abdominal and back pain  and confirmed by CT scan  the patient was diagnosed with a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  The commonly reported demographics of AAA  such as old age  male sex  Caucasian race  family history and smoking habit  as well as the clinical presentation and examinations were all concurrent with Mr. James’s case. This case highlights the importance of considering AAA in differential diagnosis for any elderly male presenting with severe abdominal or back pain  especially with a history of smoking and family history of AAA.    Reference:  Devaraj S  Dodds SR. Abdominal aortic aneurysm. BMJ. 2014;348(feb12 1):f615–f621.   Sakalihasan N  Limet R  Defawe OD. Abdominal aortic aneurysm. Lancet. 2005 May 7;365(9470):1577-89.

Patient Presentation: Mr. Jones is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who presents with consistent vague abdominal pain and occasional lower back pain for the past couple of weeks. He noticed an increase in the frequency and severity of pain during the last several days. The patient leads a sedentary life and has been smoking about 15-20 cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. He admits to being moderately overweight. He denies any recent changes in bowel habits  weight loss  or any other sickness.   Medical History: Mr. Jones has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He also has mild renal impairment  which has been stable over the past couple of years. His medications include hydrochlorothiazide  atorvastatin  and tiotropium inhaler. He has been on low-dose aspirin therapy since his diagnosis of hypertension.  Family History:  His father died at the age of 80 from complications related to COPD  and his mother died at the age of 82 from a stroke. He has two older brothers; one alive and healthy at the age of 74  and the other passed away from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at the age of 78.  Physical Examination: Physical examination reveals a hard  pulsatile mass in his abdomen  and high blood pressure. The rest of the physical examination is unremarkable  with no peripheral edema or signs of ischemia.  Clinical Investigations: In line with the patient's symptoms  family history  and examination findings  an ultrasound was performed  revealing an AAA of approximately 5.5 cm in diameter.  Treatment Plan:  Given the size of the aneurysm and risks associated  surgical intervention is pending. The patient is being evaluated for fitness for open repair or endovascular aneurysm repair. In the meantime  he is advised to quit smoking  maintain control of his hypertension and cholesterol  and monitor any increase in the severity of his abdominal pain  which could suggest an impending rupture.   Discussion: AAA is not uncommon in older adults  particularly in men over the age of 65 with a history of smoking and hypertension. Mr. Jones's family history of AAA and long-term smoking habit has increased his risk significantly. AAA often presents without symptoms until rupture  which carries a high mortality rate. Early detection and management play a crucial role in the patient's prognosis.

Title: A Case of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Caucasian Female   Patient Information:   Mrs. A  a 73-year-old Caucasian female  presented with a recent history of abdominal pain and general malaise. She has been living alone since she was widowed ten years ago and has two grown children who live within an hour's drive. She retired from her job as a primary school teacher six years ago and since then has been leading an active lifestyle  engaging in activities such as gardening  attending book clubs and traveling.   Past Medical History:  She has a history of hypertension  which is well-controlled with medication (lisinopril 20mg daily). She does not have diabetes and her cholesterol levels are within normal limits. She is a former smoker  having quit 30 years ago. She drinks alcohol sparingly  only on social occasions. She had no past surgical history and has not had any major illnesses in the past ten years except for minor ailments like colds and flu.   Family History:  According to the patient  her father died from a stroke in his 70s and her mother lived until her late 80s and died of natural causes. She has a brother who has a history of heart disease  and a sister who is healthy. She reported no family history of aneurysms.   Recent Illeness:  Over the past two weeks  she complained of a persistent abdominal pain and a feeling of fullness. She also experienced occasional feelings of light-headedness and discomfort in the back. She initially thought it might be due to indigestion and tried resolving it with over-the-counter medications  but the pain persisted.   Physical Examination:  Her vital signs on presentation were stable. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the center of the abdomen. The rest of the examination was unremarkable.  Investigation & Diagnosis:  A computed tomography angiogram (CTA) of the abdomen and pelvis was ordered which revealed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm  measuring about 5.7 cm in diameter.  Treatment and Follow-Up:  Considering her overall health and the size of the aneurysm  the patient was deemed suitable for a minimally invasive endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) procedure. She was counseled thoroughly about the risks and benefits of the procedure and consent was obtained.  Mrs A successfully underwent the EVAR procedure and her postoperative recovery was uncomplicated. She was discharged home on the fifth postoperative day with instructions to continue her antihypertensive medication and to maintain a heart-healthy lifestyle. A follow-up appointment and a duplex ultrasound scan were scheduled for six weeks post-discharge to observe the status of the abdominal aortic aneurysm repair.

Patient Presentation  Mr. Henry Thompson  a 68-year-old African American male  presented at the outpatient department of ABC hospital complaining of sudden and severe pain in his lower back and abdomen. He also reported having experienced episodes of feeling faint  along with unexpected weight loss in recent months. Mr. Thompson is a retired truck driver with a 35-year history of smoking two packs of cigarettes each day  though he quit 5 years ago. He has been struggling with poorly controlled hypertension for 15 years  and has type 2 diabetes.   Mr. Thompson lives alone and has two adult children. His father suffered a heart attack in his early 60s  and his mother had a stroke at the age of 70. According to literature  Black men aged 65–84  like Mr. Thompson  have the highest incidence of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) (Howard  Banerjee  Fairley  and Handa  2013). The patient's strong risk factors of age  genetic predispresentation  and smoking history further enhance his risk for an AAA (Buck et al.  2014).   On physical examination  a pulsating mass was felt in the abdomen  coupled with tenderness on palpation. The physician ordered an abdominal ultrasound  which confirmed the presence of an AAA. The aneurysm measured 5.5 cm in diameter  indicating a high risk for rupture.   Management and Follow-up   Given the size of the aneurysm and the patient's symptoms  the doctor recommended immediate surgical intervention and the patient was urgently referred for endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). In light of his hypertension and diabetes  our team will further help him manage these conditions post-repair to mitigate the risk of AAA recurrence and other serious cardiovascular problems (Chaikof et al.  2018).   Patient education about lifestyle modifications such as regular exercise and a low-salt diet will also be emphasized to manage hypertension and prevent episode recurrence. Psychosocial support will be offered given the patient’s living situation and the potentially traumatic experience of an emergency medical condition.

Patient Presentation:  Patient details: Mr. George Hernandez  Hispanic male  65-years-old. Occupation: Retired construction worker  Chief complaint: Sudden onset severe abdominal pain  Past medical history: High blood pressure  high cholesterol  type 2 diabetes (all controlled with medication)  20-year history of smoking  quit 5 years ago.  Family history: Father died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 73.  Present Status:   The patient presented to the emergency room with severe  unrelenting abdominal and lower back pain that began abruptly while he was doing his morning workout. He rates the pain as an 8 on a 10-point scale and describes it as ""tearing"". He shows signs of restlessness due to the discomfort. The patient also reported feeling slightly dizzy but did not lose consciousness. No history of recent trauma  fever  or changes in bowel or bladder habits.  Physical examination:  Mr. Hernandez is in apparent distress due to pain. His vitals at admission were: BP 160/90 mmHg  Pulse 98 bpm  Temp 98.6°F  Resp rate 20/min  and oxygen saturation 98% on room air. On examination  he has a pulsatile abdominal mass and tenderness to palpation. No signs of external injury or hernias. Bowel sounds are present. Peripheral pulses are palpable in all four extremities.  Radiological findings:  An emergency abdominal ultrasound followed by a CT scan confirmed an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring 5.5 cm in diameter  indicative of imminent risk of rupture  given the rapidity of onset of symptoms.  Treatment and Management:  The patient was admitted to the vascular surgery service for emergency repair. His hypertension was managed with IV medications. Endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) surgery  a less invasive procedure  was suggested for the patient's AAA given its size and his severe pain. After surgery  his postoperative course was notable for transient renal insufficiency  likely secondary to contrast exposure  which resolved with appropriate fluid management.  Education and Counseling:  The patient was thoroughly educated about his condition and the inherent risks of surgery prior to obtaining consent. After recovery  he was counseled to continue managing his risk factors  including hypertension  high cholesterol  and diabetes  with medications and a healthy lifestyle. His family members have been suggested to undergo AAA screening  considering their family history.    Follow-up:  The patient is scheduled for a 1 month post-operative evaluation and subsequent regular follow-ups. He was also suggested to take up a cardiac rehabilitation program or physical therapy sessions for recovery.    Prognosis:  Older age  larger aneurysm size  and history of smoking contribute to poorer outcomes for AAA. However  the patient's aneurysm was promptly diagnosed and successfully repaired  which greatly improves his prognosis. He is anticipated to recover with regular follow-ups and diligent management of his pre-existing conditions.

Patient Case Details:  Mr. Robert Jones  a 65-year-old Caucasian male  presented himself to the ER with complaints of intermittent severe abdominal pain that had escalated over the last 3-4 days. The pain was described as a constant and focused around the umbilical area radiating to his back. His body mass index is 27  suggesting that he is overweight. His past medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia  treated with amlodipine and atorvastatin respectively. There is no history of surgical interventions or allergies. He has been a heavy smoker for the past 25 years  with a history of alcohol consumption  but quit drinking 4 years ago.  According to Mr. Jones  his father had died at the age of 72 due to complications related to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Apart from this significant family history  Mr. Jones's mother is alive  free from cardiac diseases with only a history of diabetes type II. His sister was treated for breast cancer  but is otherwise healthy  and he has no children.  On his initial physical examination  a pulsating mass was felt in the abdomen. His blood pressure was 160/85 mmHg  heart rate 82 bpm  and body temperature 37.2 degrees Celsius. There was no tenderness or organomegaly. Laboratory investigations including complete blood count  liver function tests  and kidney function tests were within reference ranges. The lipid profile was slightly abnormal  with elevated levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol.  Considering his symptoms  family history  and physical exam findings  an ultrasound of the abdomen was requested  revealing an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) of 5.5 cm. A subsequent CT scan with contrast confirmed the diagnosis.  Treatment options were discussed with Mr. Jones  including observation  endovascular repair  and open aneurysm repair. Given his age and personal aggravating factors of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and smoking history  as well as his family history  a less invasive endovascular repair was considered the optimal course of action.  Patient was admitted and subsequently underwent successful endovascular repair of his AAA. He was discharged home on post-operative day four to follow up with Vascular Surgery in 14 days.  Clearly  Mr. Jones' case demonstrates the importance of considering AAA in patients with a family history  particularly with associated risk factors such as smoking  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. Successful management of this case was dependent on early recognition  appropriate diagnostic testing  and operative management. Efforts to control modifiable risk factors should be stressed upon in such patients to prevent recurrence or other vascular diseases in future.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. John Smith is a 75-year-old African American male  retired military personnel  who was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm during a routine physical check-up. Mr. Smith is a resident of Washington  DC  where he lives with his wife in their family home.  Demographics:  Mr. Smith falls into the age category at highest risk for abdominal aortic aneurysms  as over 80% of cases occur in individuals aged 65 or older. Additionally  African American men like Mr. Smith carry a significantly higher risk of developing this condition.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a medical history of hypertension and coronary artery disease  both of which are common comorbidities in cases of abdominal aortic aneurysms. Additionally  he has been a smoker for over 40 years  which substantially increases his risk for vascular disease formation. He also has a history of high cholesterol levels  which have been controlled with medication for 5 years. He has had no surgeries in the past.
