Family History:  His father died from a ruptured aortic aneurysm at the age of 78  adding the element of genetic predisposition to Mr. Smith's risk factors. His older brother has also been diagnosed with a (non-ruptured) abdominal aortic aneurysm at 73. There is no history of Marfan's syndrome or any genetic disorders in the family that might increase susceptibility to aortic disease.  Presentation of aneurysm:  Mr. Smith's aneurysm is infrarenal with a diameter of 5.1 cm. At the moment  he is asymptomatic  but considering the size of the aneurysm and his risk factors (smoking and hypertension)  immediate intervention is necessary to prevent rupture.  Treatment Plan:  Given Mr. Smith’s age  medical history  the size of the aneurysm  and his risk factors  his surgical team recommends an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  which is less invasive and has a shorter recovery period than traditional surgery. Mr. Smith will need to continue managing his hypertension and hyperlipidemia and be counselled on smoking cessation to optimize his long-term health and minimize further risk of aneurysm growth or rupture.  Prognosis and Follow-Up:  With successful surgery and ongoing management of his medical conditions  Mr. Smith's prognosis is favorable. He will need regular follow-up appointments initially every 6 months to monitor his recovery and check for aneurysm growth. His primary care physician will also manage his high blood pressure  heart disease  and smoking cessation progress.

Patient Profile: Ms. A is a 72-year-old Caucasian female patient  living in a suburban area of Boston  Massachusetts. She is retired and lives alone with no identified family support. She has been a smoker for fifty years but quit about five years ago.  Presenting Complaint: Complained of intermittent lower abdominal pain and lower back pain for around five months  which increased in severity over the last few days.  Past Medical History: Ms. A has a known medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. She has not had any surgical interventions before.  Family History: In terms of family history  her father had a history of peripheral artery disease and her mother died of a stroke. She has no siblings and her only child lives abroad.  Examinations and Diagnoses: On physical examination  she appeared pale and anxious but was hemodynamically stable. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass. An abdominal ultrasound showed an aortic diameter of 5.5 cm. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) confirmed the diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Management: The patient was referred for endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) because of her age and presence of comorbidities. She was also initiated on beta-blockers to control her hypertension and reduce stress on the aneurysm.  Discussion: Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a common condition  especially among older adults. Epidemiologic studies have shown higher prevalence among men  Caucasians  smokers  hypertensive and hyperlipidemic patients. There is also a strong genetic component. The condition can be asymptomatic; however  symptoms such as abdominal  back or groin pain may be present. Urgent intervention is required as ruptured AAA carries a high mortality rate. Endovascular repair has proven to be a less invasive approach with lower peri-operative mortality rates in high-risk patients.  Conclusion: This case illustrates the importance of considering AAA in elderly patients with a history of smoking  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia that present with abdominal or back pain. Early detection can significantly reduce the risk of rupture and subsequent mortality.  Reference: U.S Department of Health and Human Services  Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Aortic Aneurysm Fact Sheet. https://www.cdc.gov/dhdsp/data_statistics/fact_sheets/fs_aortic_aneurysm.htm

Patient Case Presentation on Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile The patient is a 72-year-old African American male who has been experiencing occasional abdominal and lower back pain over the past several months. He served in the military and is a retired school teacher. He is a widower with two adult children. He is a non-smoker and doesn't consume alcohol. He lives alone since the death of his wife two years ago.  Medical History The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has been on medical management for these conditions for the last 10 years. He also has a history of type II diabetes. In addition  the patient reported a significant weight loss of 20 lbs over the last year without trying.  Family History The patient’s father died of a heart attack at 60  while his mother lived until 85 but had a history of peripheral arterial disease. The patient's sister had an ischemic stroke at the age of 70. There is no known family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Presenting Symptoms The patient has been experiencing sporadic abdominal and lower back pain. The pain is usually mild but sometimes becomes severe and colicky. The patient also reported a feeling of fullness in his abdomen. The patient has not experienced any fainting spells  rapid heart rate  or sudden intense abdominal pain which could indicate a rupture.  Physical Examination Physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass. The patient exhibits a body mass index (BMI) of 27.8 which is classified as overweight. Blood pressure readings were 160/95 mmHg and the pulse was regular at 82 beats per minute.  Investigations The ultrasound revealed a 5.5 cm abdominal aortic aneurysm  confirming the diagnosis. Laboratory tests show slightly elevated blood sugar and cholesterol levels.  Management Plan The approach will involve monitoring and management of risk factors for growth and rupture of the aneurysm including managing hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes. An early surgical consultation is needed due to the size of the aneurysm and the intense pain episodes. The patient will be scheduled for an elective endovascular repair of the aneurysm.  Review Currently  the patient is on a therapeutic regime for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. His diabetes is managed by oral hypolipidemic agents. He is scheduled for regular follow-ups every 3-6 months to monitor the size of aneurysm and control of his other conditions.  Psychosocial The patient is a very independent individual but struggles with emotional loneliness after the death of his wife. This may affect his compliance with his management plan  so it would be beneficial to engage his children in his treatment plan to ensure he has the necessary support.  Concluding Statement Managing this patient will require both a mix of surgical intervention for the aneurysm and pharmacologic management of his other conditions. Additionally  consideration of his emotional health and support system is also necessary.

Case Presentation:  Patient Profile: The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male residing in a suburban location. He reports being a non-smoker but admits to a history of alcohol use  specifically moderate consumption of red wine daily for the past 50 years. His BMI falls under the overweight category  with no history of drug use. He is retired but previously worked in the construction industry  which involved manual labor. He lives with his wife and has two adult children.  Medical History:  The patient’s past medical history indicates well-controlled hypertension (for which he has been on Amlodipine for 10 years) and a mild case of obstructive pulmonary disease from past occupational exposure. Recently diagnosed with hyperlipidemia  he was put on Atorvastatin. No autoimmune diseases  diabetes  renal insufficiency  or peripheral vascular disease reported. He has no history of surgeries and no known allergies. His most recent blood work was a year ago and revealed no abnormality.  Family History:  His family history reveals a paternal side with cardiovascular disease; his father died from an unknown heart condition. No reported history of abdominal aortic aneurysm or other aneurysms in the family. His mother passed away at old age with no serious medical condition. He has one sibling who has type 2 diabetes and hypertension.  Presenting Complaint: The patient came to the emergency department complaining of severe back and abdominal pain that began suddenly and had been worsening over the past few hours. The pain was described as sharp and constant  radiating to his lower back  unresponsive to over-the-counter analgesics. He also reported feeling dizzy.  Physical Examination: On examination  a pulsating mass in the abdomen was palpable. Blood pressure was elevated (170/90 mmHg)  and the pulse was fast but regular. No signs of shock were evident.  Diagnosis: Given the patient's description of his pain  his uncontrolled hypertension  and the pulsating mass  a presumptive diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was made. An emergent abdominal ultrasound was performed  which confirmed the presence of a large infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (5.6 cm in diameter).  Conclusion: Considering the presenting complaint  vital signs  physical examination  familial risk factors  and diagnostic imaging results  the patient was diagnosed with a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. This instance call for the immediate involvement of a vascular surgeon for a potential surgical intervention  which is often required for such a critical AAA. The case highlights the urgency and importance of recognizing AAA symptoms to avoid serious consequences  including potential mortality.

Patient Summary: Mr. John 'Doe'  a 72-year-old African American resident of a suburban community  was presented to our medical facility. His height is 5’8'' tall  weighs approximately 220 lbs.  and has a body mass index (BMI) of 33.5  signifying obesity. Retired and living with his wife  Mr. Doe has 2 adult children and 4 grandchildren.   Medical History & Lifestyle: Mr. Doe has been a smoker for 45 years  admittedly smoking an average of a pack a day. He consumes alcohol occasionally and maintains a fairly sedentary lifestyle. He has a known medical history of essential hypertension and high cholesterol levels. Regular follow-ups with his primary care physician and routine medications have been helping to keep these conditions under control. He has no known food or drug allergies. In addition to this  he's on a diet high in fats and has a stressful lifestyle that could contribute to his overall medical condition.  Family History: There's a significant family history of cardiovascular diseases. His father died in his early 60s due to a heart attack  and his mother suffered from chronic hypertension.   Current Presentation: Recently  Mr. Doe has been complaining of unexplained lower back pain and a vague dull ache in his abdomen. Additionally  he described experiencing a faint pulse near his belly button. No change in bowel habits  hematochezia or melena was noticed. He also mentions occasional heart palpitations.   Physical Examination & Diagnostic Test: On physical examination  a pulsatile mass was palpated in the lower abdomen. Subsequently  an ultrasound revealed an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 6 cm in diameter  confirming our suspicion. He was also diagnosed with peripheral artery disease. No immediate alarming symptoms of rupture like severe abdominal pain  low blood pressure  rapid pulse  or loss of consciousness were observed.  Treatment Plan: Considering Mr. Doe’s age  the size of the aneurysm  associated symptoms  and co-morbidities  immediate surgical intervention was recommended despite potential risks. Mr. Doe was apprised of the urgency of the condition and the need for timely intervention to prevent possible fatal complications.   Follow-ups: Regular post-surgical monitoring has been advised to ensure appropriate healing and to minimize complications. Counseling was also provided to manage modifiable risk factors such as tobacco usage  diet  and exercise. The patient appeared understanding and committed to making necessary lifestyle changes.   Conclusion: Mr. Doe  an African-American male in his seventies diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm  faces compounded risk due to his family history along with lifestyle factors. Such cases highlight the necessity of addressing modifiable risk factors to prevent onset and worsening of life-threatening conditions like abdominal aortic aneurysms.

Patient Presentation:  A 70-year-old Caucasian male presents to the hospital complaining of a pulsating feeling in his stomach coupled with lower back pain. The patient lives in a rural part of Idaho  U.S.  and is a retired farmer. He reports a history of smoking about a packet of cigarettes a day for 40 years  although he quit 10 years ago. There has been no previous history of any significant illnesses to date except for mild hypertension.  His body mass index is calculated at 24.9 kg/m2  and his vitals upon admission are as follows: blood pressure: 140/90mm Hg  pulse rate: 80 beats/min regular  respirations: 14 breaths/min regular and non-labored  temperature: 37.2°C  and SpO2: 98% in room air. Physical examination showed a pulsatile mass in the abdomen.  The patient's family history includes his father  who died at the age of 75 years due to heart disease  while his mother died at the age of 78  also from cardiovascular issues. He has a brother who's currently 72 years old with no known health problems.  Investigations:  An abdominal ultrasound was conducted  which revealed a 5.2 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. No other abnormalities were detected within the abdominal cavity.   Discussion:  Abdominal aortic aneurysm is common in older adults  particularly in males over the age of 65. Risk factors include smoking  male gender  and a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm. Patients are usually asymptomatic and diagnosis often comes incidentally during examinations for other reasons or after complications have arisen. The case patient’s history of prolonged smoking  male gender  elderly age  and family history of cardiovascular issues increases his risk for abdominal aortic aneurysm.   Management:  The patient was referred to vascular surgery for consultation and for managing the aneurysm. The patient was also advised to continue with his antihypertensive medications and given additional education regarding the signs and symptoms of a ruptured aneurysm such as intense back or abdominal pain  rapid pulse  nausea  excessive perspiration  and loss of consciousness.  Further  the patient was educated about the importance of regular follow-ups and routine screening given his demographics and family history.  Conclusion:  Abdominal aortic aneurysm is a potentially life-threatening condition. This case emphasizes the importance of considering an abdominal aortic aneurysm diagnosis in older  male patients who have a history of smoking. Regular follow-ups and screenings are vital for managing the condition before complications occur. Patient education about the disease is also important  particularly regarding symptoms of a potentially fatal rupture.

Patient Case Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information:  Age: 72 Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian (Demographically  abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is more common in Caucasian males aged 65+)  Presenting Problem:   Mr. Smith  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  was referred to the vascular surgery department after an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring 5.5 cm  was incidentally discovered during a routine ultrasound. He complains of a continuous  deep pain in his lower back and abdomen which started a few days ago. He hasn’t experienced any symptoms of rupture  such as severe pain  shock  or loss of consciousness.   Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a 30-year-long history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both risk factors for the development of an AAA. He also has a 40 pack-year history of smoking. He has been on medication for controlling his hypertension and lipid levels  including a calcium channel blocker and a statin  respectively.   Other Significant Family History:  Mr. Smith's father had an AAA diagnosed at the age of 65 and his older brother  age 75  was confirmed with AAA two years ago. With such a strong familial history  Mr. Smith is also at a higher risk of developing an AAA.  Lifestyle:  As a retired engineer  his activity level is sedentary. He is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago but revealing a heavy history of smoking. His dietary habits are comprised mainly of red meat  sugary drinks  and processed foods.  Physical Examination:  On examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpably identified. His vital signs were stable  including blood pressure and pulse rate.  Laboratory and Diagnostic Results:  The abdominal ultrasound revealed an infrarenal AAA of 5.5 cm in diameter. A subsequent CT angiogram confirmed the size and location of the AAA and demonstrated no signs of rupture or leakage.   Impression and Plan:  Due to the size of Mr. Smith’s aneurysm (greater than 5.5 cm)  his age  overall health status  and significant family history  strong consideration should be given to surgical repair to reduce the risk of rupture. The approach to surgery  whether open repair or endovascular stenting  would depend on further assessment of the patient’s anatomic suitability and overall medical condition.   Other recommendations would include lifestyle modifications  such as adopting a heart-healthy diet  regular exercise  and regular monitoring of lipid levels and blood pressure. Genetic counseling and screening of first-degree relatives for AAA should also be considered  given the family history of disease.   A multidisciplinary approach involving a vascular surgeon  cardiologist  and an anesthesiologist should be utilized to effectively manage Mr. Smith's AAA. His case illustrates the importance of early detection and intervention in patients at risk  especially those with a family history of AAA and significant risk factors like hypertension  hyperlipidemia and a history of smoking.

Case Presentation:  Patient Profile: Our patient is Mr. T  a 74-year-old African American male  who presented with back pain radiating to his flank and moderate dyspnea. He has a long-standing history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been managed well with Amlodipine and Atorvastatin  respectively. He denies a personal history of coronary artery disease and peripheral artery disease  and he does not report any known family history of cardiovascular disease or aneurysmal conditions. Mr. T is a retired industrial worker  never smoked  and lives with his wife in a suburban community.  Presentation: Upon physical examination  Mr. T appeared distressed and diaphoretic  with significant discomfort. His vital signs on presentation were: Blood pressure 160/100mmHg  heart rate 100 beats per minute  respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute  and SpO2 of 95% on room air. On palpation  a pulsatile abdominal mass was detected.  Investigation and Diagnosis: Given his uncontrolled hypertension  age  race  and the finding of an abdominal mass  an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) was immediately suspected. Further investigations were conducted  included a fast  focused ultrasound examination that showed an aortic diameter of 6.2 cm. A later computed tomography angiography (CTA) confirmed the presence of an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm about 6.5.cm in diameter. No rupture was evident but the size of the aneurysm placed Mr. T in a critical condition requiring immediate medical attention.   Treatment Plan: Considering Mr. T's age  comorbidities  and the size of the aneurysm  he was deemed a candidate for endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). This was discussed with him and his wife  and they both agreed to proceed.  Discussion: Abdominal aortic aneurysms pose a significant risk for rupture once they reach a diameter of 5.5 cm or greater  with risk increasing as diameter increases. This can be life-threatening  with 80% mortality when rupture occurs. Such aneurysms are more prevalent in males  the elderly  smokers  and those with a family history of the disease. A higher prevalence in African American and Hispanic populations has also been noted. With a high-risk abdominal aortic aneurysm  endovascular or open surgical repair are the recommended treatment options.   In Mr. T's case  the AAA was detected early due to his presentation of symptomatic pain. His case should serve as a reminder to consider AAA in at-risk patients presenting with back or flank pain  especially if a pulsatile abdominal mass is detected on examination.

Patient Presentation  Mr. A is a 70-year-old  Caucasian male presenting with pain in his lower back and abdomen for the last three months. His pain has been gradually intensifying and is non-radiating in nature. He also reports occasional constipation. There weren't any noticeable precipitating factors for the pain.  His medical history is significant for high blood pressure (12 years)  Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (8 years)  and high cholesterol levels. He has a 30 pack-year smoking history. He has been compliant with his medications: Lisinopril  Metformin  and Atorvastatin. Mr. A denies any known allergies.  The patient's family history reveals that his father had a 'ruptured aneurysm ' causing a sudden death at 72. His mother lived to 80 with Hypertension (HTN) and Diabetes Mellitus (DM). One of his two elder brothers has HTN and the other is healthy.  On physical examination  the patient was slightly overweight with a BMI of 27. A palpable  pulsatile mass was detected in his abdomen just above the navel. His blood pressure was slightly elevated at 145/90 mmHg. There was no audible bruit on auscultation.  Lab results indicate slightly elevated glucose and lipid levels. A CT scan shows an infra-renal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.5cm in maximum diameter but no signs of rupture.   Considering Mr. A's significant risk factors (age  gender  smoking history  and family history)  symptoms  and examination findings  he was diagnosed with an unruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.  The patient was counseled regarding the disease's gravity  and the need for intervention is discussed. His options are open surgery or endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  with the final decision based on further assessment of his fitness and personal preference. He is also advised to stop smoking  maintain better glycemic and BP control  and regular follow-ups.  This case emphasizes the importance of considering abdominal aortic aneurysm in the differential diagnosis in the elderly presenting with abdominal or back pain  particularly in the context of certain risk factors. Early diagnosis and intervention can significantly reduce morbidity and mortality associated with the condition.

Patient Case Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information A 70-year-old Caucasian male patient  Mr. J.K  resides in Boston  Massachusetts. He is a retired carpenter  married with three adult children. He reports being a moderate smoker for 50 years; however  he quit 10 years ago.  Past Medical History He has a history of high blood pressure which was diagnosed 15 years ago and has been under control with medication. He also has been managing his hypercholesterolemia with statins since he was 65. Mr. J.K had an episode of myocardial infarction 7 years ago which was successfully managed conservatively. He is obese (BMI: 32) and continues to struggle with weight loss.  Family History The patient disclosed that his late father had a history of hypertension and died at the age of 75 from a stroke. Moreover  his maternal uncle underwent an operative procedure for an abdominal aortic aneurysm in his 60s.   Current Condition Mr. J.K presented to the emergency department due to a severe  sharp  persistent pain in his abdomen that radiated to his back  which started a couple of hours prior to admission. The pain is described as ""tearing"". Physical examination revealed pulsating abdomen and a tender mass. He has lost his appetite but has no nausea or vomiting. No bowel or bladder dysfunction were noted. Review of systems revealed increasing fatigue but the patient denied any chest pain  shortness of breath or syncope.  Investigations The patient's blood pressure was found to be elevated at 160/90 mmHg. Lab tests showed slight renal impairment (Creatinine 1.5 mg/dl). Given his symptoms and family history  a computed tomographic angiography (CTA) was ordered. The CTA revealed an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 7 cm in diameter  confirming the diagnosis.  Plan The size and symptoms of the aneurysm warrant immediate surgical intervention. Vascular surgery was consulted and the patient was scheduled for open repair surgery. The patient was admitted to the intensive care unit  in the interim  for close monitoring and blood pressure control.  Discussion As in our patient  most individuals with abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) are asymptomatic until the aneurysm ruptures. AAA is more common in older adults  particularly men  and in those who are or have been smokers. Patients with high blood pressure and a family history of AAA are also at risk. Rapid diagnosis and management of AAA is critical to avoid rupture  which has a high mortality rate.  This case underscores the importance of early recognition and urgent management of a suspected AAA  the management of modifiable risk factors such as hypertension and hyperlipidemia  as well as the importance of considering AAA in older patients with abdominal or back pain.

Patient Information: Mr. Thompson  a 70-year-old African American male  presented to the Emergency Room with sudden and severe lower back and abdominal pain.  Past Medical History: Mr. Thompson was previously diagnosed with long-standing hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has a 50-pack per year smoking history  which he stopped around five years ago. He also has a history of alcohol dependency  which he has abstained from for the past couple of years. The patient does not have any history of diabetes mellitus  but has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) in his medical history due to his previous smoking habits.  Family History:  His father died of a heart attack at age 68 and his mother at 72 after a massive stroke. His elder brother had been diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm that was successfully repaired.  Current Symptoms: Mr. Thompson described his pain as a tearing sensation in the lower abdomen and back area. He also reported feeling lightheaded and dizzy  with a sensation of his 'heart pounding in his chest'. The patient denied any chest pain  shortness of breath  or loss of consciousness.  Physical Examination: Mr. Thompson appeared in considerable distress due to pain. Vital signs were significant for a blood pressure of 180/120 mmHg  heart rate was fast at 115 bpm  respirations were 22/min and labored  and oxygen saturation was 92% on room air. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the umbilical area  along with moderate lower abdominal tenderness. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Evaluation: Laboratory results were significant for elevated white cell count and an increase in serum creatinine level. Fast-track Ultrasound confirmed the diagnosis of a large abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). A computed tomography (CT) scan further determined a rupture of an AAA into the retroperitoneal space.  Treatment Plan: On confirmation of the diagnosis  cardiothoracic surgery was immediately consulted for emergency endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) of the ruptured AAA.  Follow Up: Post operatively  Mr. Thompson was transferred to the intensive care unit for monitoring and was discharged after complete recovery. He was advised to attend regular follow up checks to monitor the graft and his blood pressure. He was also provided with resources for a healthier lifestyle  and nutritional counsel to manage his hypertension and hyperlipidemia.  Conclusion: Mr. Thompson’s case accentuates the severe life-threatening potential of AAA  especially in patients with risk factors such as age  ethnicity  smoking history  hypertension  and a family history of AAA. Early detection of an AAA is crucial for effective management and prevention of deadly complications  such as rupture.

Patient Profile: Initials: J.S. Gender: Male Age: 68 Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Civil Servant  Residence: Lived in Boston  Massachusetts  Presenting Complaint: J.S. reports experiencing intermittent severe pain in his abdominal region  alongside unexplained weight loss and occasional back pain for the past two months.  Past Medical History: J.S. has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Also  the patient records a 45-year history of heavy smoking  although he quit five years ago. He has been on antihypertensive medication and statins for controlling his blood pressure and cholesterol levels  respectively.   Family History: J.S.’s father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm and underwent surgery in his 70s. He also has a younger brother undergoing treatment for coronary artery disease. Both his parents were suffered from hypertension.   Current Medications: 1. Lisinopril (for hypertension) 2. Atorvastatin (for hyperlipidemia)  Examination and Tests: Physical examination revealed a slight pulsating mass in the abdomen. Ultrasonography confirmed the diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm with a diameter of 5.4cm. Other lab results were within normal values except for slightly elevated cholesterol levels.  Treatment Plan Overview: The size of J.S.'s aneurysm qualifies for surgical intervention  considering his age and associated risk factors. An endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) is recommended  whereby a stent-graft will be placed at the site of the aneurysm to prevent rupture. J.S. should continue with his currently prescribed medication to manage his hypertension and hyperlipidemia  with regular follow-ups to monitor his cholesterol levels  blood pressure  and the status of the aneurysm post-surgery.  Discussion: Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is more common among the male population aged over 65 years  with risk factors such as smoking  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia contributing to its development. Family history is also a significant risk factor as seen in J.S.'s case. Regular monitoring and appropriate intervention can prevent rupture and subsequent complications.   REFERENCE: 1. LeFevre ML; U.S. Preventive Services Task Force. (2014). Screening for abdominal aortic aneurysm: U.S. Preventive Services Task Force recommendation statement. Ann Intern Med  161(4)  281–290. doi:10.7326/M14-1204

Patient Information:   Mr. X is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who presented to the outpatient clinic with a chief complaint of vague and intermittent abdominal pain  which he has been experiencing for the last 5 months. He also complained of unintentional weight loss and fatigue in the past few months. He has a past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia and is a former smoker with a 40 pack-year history.   Family and Social History:  He is married  retired  and lives with his spouse in a suburban environment. He reported that his father passed away due to a 'heart problem' at the age of 72  but he was unsure of the specific details. His mother died at 79 from complications of diabetes. He denies any illicit drug use but admits to consuming alcohol moderately.  Physical Examination:  Vital signs were stable. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile and tender mass in the midline of the abdomen. No bruits were detected. The remainder of the examination was unremarkable.   Investigations:  Given his symptoms and the physical examination findings  an ultrasound of the abdomen was ordered  which revealed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 4.5 cm in diameter. Subsequent CT angiography of the aorta confirmed the presence and size of the aneurysm. Other lab findings  including renal function and complete blood count  were within normal limits.  Diagnosis:  Considering the findings and his clinical presentation  the patient was diagnosed with an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Management and Follow Up:  The patient was educated about the disease and its possible complications. Given that the aneurysm is currently below the threshold size for surgical intervention (5.5 cm)  the patient was advised surveillance with ultrasound every six months. Optimization of cardiovascular risk with antihypertensive and lipid-lowering therapy was conducted. He was also advised to quit smoking and limit alcohol consumption.   Given the family history of cardiovascular disease  family members were recommended to undergo screening for aortic aneurysms. The patient would be immediately referred for surgery if his aneurysm grows to 5.5 cm or larger  or if he develops symptoms indicative of rapid growth or impending rupture.  In accordance with the literature  it is known that Caucasian males over the age of 65  especially those with a smoking history like in this case  have a higher risk of abdominal aortic aneurysm. Hence the detection and management in this patient are in line with epidemiological findings.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 65-year-old Caucasian Male  Introduction: The patient is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who complained of abdominal pain. He described the pain as a constant  gnawing ache  which he had been experiencing for the past couple of months. He has a history of smoking for the past 30 years and heavy alcohol use.   Past Medical History: The patient was previously diagnosed with hyperlipidemia and hypertension  both of which had been managed with medication (lipid-lowering agents and ACE inhibitors  respectively). He has no known allergies. Previous surgeries included a knee replacement 5 years ago.  Family History: A family history revealed an elder brother who had died at the age of 67 from an aortic aneurysm. The patient's father died of a heart attack at 72  and his mother is still alive at 91 with no significant medical conditions.  Present Complaint and Examination: The recent complaint was an acute exacerbation of this chronic abdominal pain  along with increased fatigue over the past few days. Physical examination showed a pulsatile mass in his abdomen. Further tests  including X-ray of the stomach and an ultrasound  led to the diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Investigations: Blood tests showed normal renal function but elevated levels of cholesterol. An ultrasound confirmed the presence of a 5.5cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. No signs of rupture were reported.  Management Plan: Given the size and risk of rupture  an elective surgical repair was suggested. Due to his smoking history and hypertension  he remains at a substantially higher risk for perioperative cardiovascular complications  so he was referred to cardiology for perioperative risk evaluation and treatment. Smoking cessation was strongly advised.   Discussion: Our patient falls into a high-risk category for the development of an AAA due to his demographic (older  Caucasian male)  familial aortic aneurysm history  a history of smoking  and the presence of cardiovascular disease (hypertension and hyperlipidemia) - all well-established risk factors for AAA as per literature.   The patient's age and the size of the aneurysm present a risk of rupture if left untreated  hence the suggestion for surgical intervention. Although the potential for perioperative complications is high  studies showed that the risks associated with an untreated large abdominal aortic aneurysm far outweigh the operative risks.  Remember  the patient's well-being and consent are the most important factors when proceeding with the management plan for AAA. The patient should be fully informed about the potential benefits and risks of the procedure  and consideration of the patient's overall health status is important when deciding on the next steps.

Patient Presentation  Patient Details:  Name: Mr. James Montgomery Age: 73 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer Residence: Urban  Chief Complaint:  The patient came in reporting severe and persistent abdominal pain  which was consistent with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Clinical History:  The patient has been a smoker for the past 40 years and has been treated for hypertension for 5 years. He had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) 2 years ago but made a good recovery. There is a known history of hyperlipidemia  angina  and early-onset type 2 diabetes. He has been following up regularly for his medical issues and is compliant with medication.  Due to a family history of cardiovascular disease (father died of a heart attack at 67) he has been proactive in maintaining a balanced diet and doing regular moderate intensity exercises  but his past smoking history and current hypertension are significant risk factors for AAA.  Physical Examination:  Vitals stable  BMI within the overweight range  and carotid arteries are soft with no bruits. Pulsatile mass is felt on abdominal examination. There is no sign of renal disease from the physical examination.  Tests and Diagnosis:  Suspecting AAA  an immediate ultrasound was ordered that showed a large aneurysm of the abdominal aorta  size4.5cm. A subsequent CT angiogram confirmed the presence of AAA.  Patient Education and Management:  The patient was well informed about his diagnosis  the associated risks  and the options for management. Given his age and the size of the aneurysm  the risk of rupture was high. Following the discussion  the patient opted for an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  which was successful. He is now under regular follow-up and monitoring.  This case represents a typical case of AAA - being more common in males and those of aged over 65. Significant risk factor observed include smoking history  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  family history of cardiovascular disease and Caucasian race. The decision for surgical intervention and choice of EVAR over open repair were based on patient's specific risk profile and current guidelines.

PATIENT CASE PRESENTATION:  Demographics: Patient Information: Mr. X is a 69-year-old African American man who lives in a suburban community with his wife.  Chief Complaint: Mr. X was brought to the emergency department due to sudden  severe pain in his lower back and abdomen.  Present Illness: The patient has a history of progressive  intermittent lower back and abdominal pain over the past 6 months. He self-managed his symptoms with over-the-counter analgesics and rest due to his general aversion to hospitals and doctors based on previous experiences. However  the pain’s intensity had significantly increased during the last 24 hours  leading him to seek immediate medical assistance. He denies any trauma  recent activity strain  fever  or significant weight loss. He confirms episodes of nausea and mild constipation.  Past Medical History: Mr. X has been diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia  which he manages with lisinopril and statins  respectively. He is obese with a BMI of 32. He is an ex-smoker (quit 10 years ago) but used to smoke heavily (around 30 cigarettes per day) for almost 30 years. He reports occasional alcohol consumption.  Family History: His father underwent surgery at 74 for an abdominal aortic aneurysm and died at age 79 due to heart failure. His mother died from complications of diabetes. He has one brother who is alive and well.  Physical Examination: On examination  he appeared in distress due to pain. His blood pressure was 160/90 mmHg  heart rate 100 beats per minute  and respiratory rate 20 breaths per minute. An abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the middle and upper part of the abdomen. His lower limbs were warm  and there was no loss of sensation or motor function. Bowel sounds were present.  Investigations: An urgent CT scan confirmed the diagnosis of a 7 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm. His full blood count  liver function tests  and renal function tests were within normal limits except for a slightly elevated white cell count.  Problems Identified: 1. Abdominal aortic aneurysm – likely causing the severe lower back and abdominal pain. 2. Hypertension - poorly controlled. 3. Hyperlipidemia - well managed. 4. Obesity. 5. Ex-smoker - potential contributor to cardiovascular disease risk and aneurysm progression.  Management Plan: Mr. X was urgently referred to vascular surgery and will likely require an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) procedure. His hypertension and pain must be managed appropriately in the pre-operative period. Lifestyle modification  including weight loss  should be incorporated as an important part of the long-term management plan.  Patient Education: Emphasis will be placed on the importance of routine screening checks  regular exercise  healthy diet  weight loss  and strict blood pressure control. The patient will also be advised to schedule regular follow-ups to monitor the condition and adjust treatment  if needed.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Smith  a 74-year-old Caucasian male  presented with a complaint of abdominal discomfort and lower back pain that has been persistent for two weeks.  Medical History:   Mr. Smith is a former smoker  having smoked one pack per day for 40 years before quitting 3 years ago. He is also a diagnosed hypertensive  currently taking angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors  and was recently diagnosed with hyperlipidemia. He has obesity  with a BMI of 35  and a sedentary lifestyle.  Demographics:  According to available literature  elderly males  particularly Caucasians aged 65-75  who have a history of smoking  are most at risk for abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA).  Family History:   Mr. Smith's father had an AAA which ultimately led to his death due to aortic rupture at the age of 70. His older brother  who is now 77  had an elective AAA repair at 72 years old.  Investigations and Diagnosis:  Owing to his familial predisposition and suggestive symptoms  Mr. Smith underwent an abdominal ultrasound  which confirmed a 5.2cm infrarenal aortic aneurysm. This  taken in context with his age  sex  family history  and risk factor of smoking  was strongly suggestive of an AAA.  Management:  An interventional radiologist was consulted for an elective endovascular aortic aneurysm repair. In the interim  monitoring of the AAA was arranged every three months to keep track of potential growth. Mr. Smith was counseled regarding the importance of good control of his hypertension and hyperlipidemia  as well as encouraged to undertake a moderate exercise regimen for weight control.  This case highlights the importance of identifying patients most at risk for AAAs and implementing both preventive and monitoring measures to avert potentially fatal complications such as aortic rupture.   Mr. Smith's former history of smoking  hyperlipidemia  hypertension  and sedentary lifestyle are general risk factors for cardiovascular diseases but are most significantly associated with AAA. Therefore the management plan should be aimed at improving his lifestyle and control of his chronic diseases  while simultaneously monitoring the size and growth of the aneurysm  to prevent future complications.

Patient's Profile: The patient  Mr. John Doe  is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who has been recently diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He's had a history of hypertension for the past 20 years and is a current smoker with a 50 pack-year history. He had been following up regularly for his hypertension in the primary care clinic.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe has a history of other vascular-related problems like peripheral artery disease (PAD) and suffered from a minor stroke five years ago from which he recovered significantly. He has no known history of diabetes  hyperlipidemia  or any collagen vascular diseases. He reported a history of chronic back pain for which he takes non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) intermittently.  Presenting Symptom: Mr. Doe visited the emergency department (ED) with a new onset  intense  tearing abdominal pain that started suddenly few hours before. He complained of feeling a pulsating mass in his abdomen and occasional lightheadedness.  Family History: There is a significant family history of cardiovascular disease  specifically his father suffered a ruptured AAA at the age of 70 and his older brother  aged 72  has a known small AAA under surveillance.  Physical Examination:  Upon examination in the ED  Mr. Doe was found to be hypertensive (blood pressure 160/90)  tachycardic (pulse rate 110 bpm)  and had a palpable pulsatile abdominal mass.  Imaging and Diagnosis:  A bedside ultrasound confirmed the suspicious of AAA. It revealed an AAA with the maximal diameter of 6.5 cm. Due to his symptoms and signs  there was a concern for impending rupture  and a computed tomography angiogram (CTA) was promptly performed; this revealed an AAA with signs of early rupture  hence prompt surgical consultation was sought.  Therapeutic Intervention: Mr. Doe was taken up for urgent endovascular aortic repair (EVAR) by the vascular team. He tolerated the procedure well with no immediate complications.  Postoperative Course: He was closely monitored in the ICU post-procedure  maintained on antihypertensive medication  and showed gradual recovery. His post-operative course was complicated by a slight increase in creatinine level indicating possible acute kidney injury  but this was managed conservatively and function improved by the time of discharge.  Conclusion: This case illustrates the need for a high level of vigilance in patients with a significant family and personal history of vascular disease. An accurate history and examination  timely investigation  and prompt surgical intervention saved the life of Mr. Doe. While smoking cessation  hypertension control  and regular follow-up are significant for him  it's equally important to screen his immediate family members due to the family history of AAA.

Patient Presentation - Case Study  Demographics: The patient is a 65-year-old African American male  living in a semi-urban region in the US. He is retired from his job as a heavy equipment operator and is a veteran.  Chief Complaint: Patient reports experiencing severe abdominal and lower back pain intermittently for the past few weeks.   History of Present Illness:  The patient was managing well until six weeks ago when he encountered the first episode of pain. The severe pain intermittently presents itself and does not only confine to the abdominal area but radiates to the back as well. The pain lasts for several hours  standing moderate to high on the pain scale  and then disappears. No alleviating or aggravating factors were reported. The patient also complained of hard constipated stools  bloating  and occasional nausea but denied having fever  weight loss  or change in appetite.  Past Medical History:   The patient has a known history of hypertension for the past 10 years. The patient also had a myocardial infarction five years ago  after which he underwent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). He was diagnosed as a Type II diabetic three years ago and has been on regular medications since then. He also has a 40 pack-year history of smoking  having quit 5 years ago  post-CABG. He consumes alcohol occasionally.   Family History:   The patient's father died due to myocardial infarction in his early sixties. The patient's mother had hypertension and passed away in her seventies due to a stroke.  Review of Systems:   Aside from the pain  the patient has no report of other abnormal findings.  Physical Examination:   The patient appeared anxious and was moderately built. On examination  there was tenderness in the abdominal area. A pulsatile mass was palpable in the middle and upper abdomen region. There were no visible signs of external bleeding. The blood pressure was consistent with his hypertensive state and pulse was rhythmic but fast. Examination of other organ systems revealed no abnormality.   Based on the physical assessment and patient's medical history  an abdominal ultrasound was ordered. The ultrasound revealed the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The AAA was approximately 5.5 cm in diameter. The patient was explained about the AAA and the high risk of rupture associated with the size of his aneurysm. Following appropriate investigations  he underwent successful open surgical repair for the same. Currently  he is on regular follow-ups and his vital signs have been under control.   This case underscores the link between past medical history  lifestyle choices like smoking  a family history of vascular diseases  and the onset of AAA. It also emphasizes the relevance of early diagnosis and management for preventing life-threatening complications related to AAA  like rupture.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. P  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  was admitted to our hospital following a complaint of moderate and steady abdominal pain for the past week  coupled with a notable loss of appetite and an unintentional weight loss of about 10 pounds over the last month. He reports that the pain is more distressing after eating and tends to worsen throughout the day.  Past Medical History: Mr. P had a medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which were being managed with antihypertensives and statins  respectively. He quit smoking 10 years ago but had a 35 pack-year history prior to cessation. Lately  he’s been noting some shortness of breath upon exertion.  Family History: His father died of heart disease in his early 70s  and his mother lived into her 90s without any significant health concerns. His only sibling  a brother  had suffered a stroke in his 60s but had recovered with minimal deficits.  Physical Examination: Upon examination  a pulsating mass was found in the epigastric region. No other significant findings were noted.  Diagnostic Test: On suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  an abdominal ultrasound was ordered  which confirmed the presence of a 5.5 cm AAA.   Treatment: Upon the confirmation of the diagnosis  Mr. P was referred to vascular surgery  and an elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) was scheduled considering his age and the size of the aneurysm.  This case illustrates the importance of considering a diagnosis of AAA in elderly patients  particularly Caucasians  presenting with unexplained abdominal pain  a history of smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a family history of cardiovascular disease. In such cases  abdominal palpation and timely imaging can be a lifesaver.    Epidemiology Information: Abdominal aortic aneurysm predominantly affects the elderly and is relatively more common in the Caucasian population. It is also significantly more common in men than in women. Smoking  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia are major risk factors  and the disease may be asymptomatic until rupture  making screening and early detection critically important. Most small AAAs (3.0-5.4 cm in diameter) are monitored with ultrasound  while large AAAs (≥5.5 cm) typically warrant surgical repair.

Patient Profile:  Mr. X  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presented with discomfort in his abdomen and lower back persisting for several months. He had a 40 years’ history of smoking two packs per day  was a mild drinker  is a retired firefighter  and leads a sedentary life since retirement. He has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol  which he manages with prescribed medications. His Body Mass Index (BMI) registers as overweight  at 27. He has no previous history of surgeries or allergies.  Family History:  Mr. X's father died at the age of 50 from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). His mother died of breast cancer at age 68. He has one brother who was diagnosed with AAA at age 65 and was successfully operated on.  Presenting Symptoms:  Mr. X complained of persistent tenderness around his navel  episodic back pain  and occasional bouts of constipation or diarrhea. He also mentioned discomfort while urinating. These conditions troubled him during other periods of his life  but these episodes started to become more frequent  prompting him to seek medical attention.  Diagnostic Findings:  On physical examination  he showed an abdominal mass that pulsed with his heartbeat. imaging tests (Ultrasound and CT scan) confirmed the presence of an AAA measuring 5.5 cm in diameter. An electrocardiogram (EKG) demonstrated normal sinus rhythm  while blood tests showed slightly elevated white cell count (11 500 cells/µL) and an increased level of high-sensitivity C-reactive protein.  Treatment:  Based on the patient's clinical presentation and family history  considering the size of the aneurysm  the decision was made for surgical repair of the aneurysm. The patient was informed about the risk and benefits of the procedure  and he provided informed consent for the surgery.  Discussion and Conclusion:  AAA has a high rate of mortality if it ruptures. In Mr. X's case  his age  sex  smoking history  family history of AAA  and persistent hypertension are risk factors that contributed to his AAA diagnosis. No signs of AAA rupture were found in the investigations  but the aneurysm was large enough that it warranted surgical correction to prevent its rupture and avoid life-threatening consequences. It is equally important to manage his risk factors  such as helping him quit smoking  managing his blood pressure  and following a heart-healthy diet.  This case demonstrates the importance of family history and risk factor recognition in diagnosing and managing an AAA. It is crucial for health providers to engage in education and preventive strategies  particularly in high-risk patients  to ensure early detection and intervention.

Title: A Case of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 68-year-old Caucasian Male  Patient Profile: The patient  Mr. X  is a 68-year-old Caucasian male with a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  regularly controlled with medication. He is a retired engineer  residing in the northern United States. The patient is a former 40-pack-year smoker but quit smoking ten years ago upon the diagnosis of Stage I lung cancer. He reports occasional alcohol use and does not use recreational drugs. Mr. X lives with his spouse  and they have two adult daughters.  Past Medical History: Mr. X has had a past medical history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Stage I lung cancer. He has had his hypertension and hyperlipidemia controlled by medication  but underwent chemotherapy and radiation therapy for his lung cancer. There was no indication of metastasis and he has been in remission for the last ten years.  Family History: Mr. X's paternal grandfather had a history of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) and died at the age of 73 due to its rupture. His father had a history of ischemic heart disease. His mother is still alive and is known to have hypertension and diabetes. His sister underwent repair for AAA at the age of 70. None of his daughters have presented with any significant health issues to date.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. X presented to the hospital with a complaint of gradually increasing discomfort in his lower abdomen over the past couple of weeks. The pain was dull  non-radiating  and persistent but tolerable. There was no associated nausea  vomiting  fever  or change in bowel habits. He has no record of any recent trauma or injury.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpable. His vital signs were stable except for slightly elevated blood pressure. His cardiovascular  respiratory  and central nervous system examinations were all within normal limits.  Investigations: An abdominal ultrasound showed a 5.6 cm infrarenal AAA  with no signs of rupture. A complete blood count  renal function test  electrolytes  liver function tests  and coagulation profile were all within normal limits except for elevated cholesterol levels.  Diagnosis: Based on the medical history  family history  physical examination  and imaging studies  we confirmed the diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Treatment: Given the large size of the aneurysm and his increasing discomfort  surgical intervention was recommended for Mr. X. A vascular surgery team was consulted for the same. Given the patient’s cardiovascular risk factors  a cardiovascular risk assessment was done preoperatively. Post-surgery  long-term surveillance is planned to monitor aneurysm growth and development of new aneurysms.  While this case represents an individual patient  it correlates well with demographic data showing that AAA most often occurs in Caucasian males aged 65 or older with specific risk factors such as smoking  hypertension  and a family history.

Title: A Case Presentation of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male retiree living in a suburban setting. He has a history of heavy smoking with approximately 50 pack years and has a BMI of 28  indicating he is overweight. The patient is happily married and is a father to three adult children. He has a sedentary lifestyle and a diet high in saturated fats.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia with suboptimal control despite medication. He also has documented coronary artery disease with a history of myocardial infarction 10 years prior  treated with percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). The patient gave up drinking 15 years ago but still managed to smoke a few cigarettes daily. He has no history of any other significant medical or surgical conditions including diabetes  stroke or cancer.   Family History: There is a striking history of cardiovascular disease in his family. His father died at 72 due to myocardial infarction and mother at 78 due to stroke; one of the patient’s brothers has peripheral artery disease.  Presentation: The patient presented with intermittent lower back pain for the past one month. The pain was dull in nature and predominantly at the midline. Physical examination revealed a pulsating mass in the abdomen. No other significant findings were noted during the physical examination.  Investigation: CT scan confirmed the diagnosis of infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm  measuring 5.5 cm in diameter. ECG report showed ST depressions in the inferior leads. Lab results reveal patient’s LDL cholesterol level is slightly elevated  indicating hyperlipidemia. Blood pressure was recorded to be 145/95 mmHg  suggesting an uncontrolled hypertension.   Plan: Considering his age  symptoms  size of the aneurysm  and existence of multiple risk factors for rupture (such as prolonged history of smoking and uncontrolled hypertension)  the patient was referred for an elective open surgical repair. The patient and family were educated about the potential risks and complications associated with both the disease and surgical intervention. The patient was also advised to quit smoking and was referred to a dietitian for advice on a healthier diet.  Follow Up: The patient is scheduled for routine postoperative reviews and monitoring of his cardiovascular risk factors. Long-term success will largely depend on lifestyle modifications.  *Note: This is a fictitious case meant to illustrate a presentation of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. It should not be used as medical advice or diagnostic material. Always refer to the input of a certified healthcare provider for medical guidance.*

Patient Presentation  Patient Information:  Mr. Ahmed  a 65-year-old Middle-Eastern male  presented with lower abdominal and back pain persisting over several days. He has a history of hypertension (uncontrolled) and hyperlipidemia  conditions which haven't been monitored for the past year due to personal neglect. He has a 35-pack-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago.  Family History:  His father died of myocardial infarction in his sixties  and his mother had a stroke in her seventies. Two elder brothers  aged 68 and 71  are alive with one having been diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm three years back and another sister who suffered from a stroke at her early fifties.  Examination and Investigation:  On physical examination  a pulsating mass was palpable in the middle and upper part of the abdomen. No significant change in bowel or bladder habits was recorded. An ultrasound scan confirmed the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  measuring approximately 5 centimeters in diameter. Subsequent computed tomography angiography affirmed the diagnosis and offered a more precise aneurysm size and location. His blood pressure at presentation was 170/100 mmHg  and he had a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 27.9  indicating overweight status.  Clinical Course:  Mr. Ahmed was hospitalized immediately due to the large size of an aneurysm and high risk of rupture. He underwent an open repair surgery where a graft was implanted to reinforce the weakened section of the aorta.   Post Surgery: His postoperative period was uneventful  and after a satisfactory convalescent period  Mr. Ahmed was discharged with prescribed antihypertensive (Amlodipine  5mg) and lipid-lowering medications (Statins)  and smoking cessation advice for sustained recovery. A follow-up appointment was scheduled one month postoperative  with subsequent regular checkups to monitor both his aneurysm and his hypertension.   Conclusion: For a good outcome in this case  it would be crucial to assure regular patient follow-up and appropriate medication use to control his cardiovascular risk factors. This will require a holistic approach involving physicians  nurses  and the active involvement of the patient to prevent rupture of the aneurysm and management of his overall health. Lifestyle modification advice focusing on maintaining a healthy diet and weight  along with consistent monitoring of his hypertension and cholesterol levels  is absolutely essential.   In the context of his family history  genetic counseling and screening for vascular diseases in family members are advisable. Aggressive management of risk factors in this patient will potentially reduce the morbidity and mortality associated with this severe condition.

Patient Profile: Mr. Alfred Reynolds is a 74-year-old Caucasian male who resides in an urban area in Dallas  Texas. He is a retired banker  has been a smoker for over 50 years  and lives alone. He was married  but his wife passed away 10 years ago. Mr. Reynolds has two children who live out-of-state and don’t visit regularly because of their work commitments.  Past Medical History: Mr. Reynolds has a known history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He had a myocardial infarction eight years ago and had bypass surgery six years ago for severe ischemic heart disease. He also has moderate chronic kidney disease and peripheral arterial disease.  Presentation: Mr. Reynolds presented to the ER with a sudden  severe  and sharp lower back pain with a feeling of pulsation in the abdomen. The pain was radiating to his left thigh and was associated with nausea  vomiting  and feeling faint.   Family History: There is positive family history for abdominal aortic aneurysm in his father  who died suddenly at age 65 from aneurysm rupture. There is no relevant family history related to other cardiovascular diseases.   Physical Examination: On examination  he had an abdominal mass with a pulsing sensation and was experiencing hypotensive episodes. He showed signs of distress and his skin was palpably cold  pale  and moist.  Diagnostic Tests: Abdominal ultrasound confirmed the presence of a 7cm abdominal aortic aneurysm. Blood tests revealed elevated WBC count denoting possible ongoing infection or inflammation. Creatinine levels were also high showing impaired renal function.  Therapy and Plan: Mr. Reynolds was immediately admitted to the surgical ICU and a vascular surgeon was consulted. His blood pressure was stabilized with IV fluids. Given his age and high risk  an Endovascular Aneurysm Repair (EVAR) was suggested in order to decrease the risk of rupture.  This case represents the common demographic for abdominal aortic aneurysms  as they are most common in older  Caucasian men  particularly those with a history of smoking and cardiovascular disease. Family history is also a predisposing factor. The presentation of sudden  severe abdominal or back pain  often with radiation to the groin or thigh  reflects a large aneurysm at risk of rupture. Diagnosis is often made with ultrasound and prompt surgical consult is crucial in management.

Patient Information   The patient is a 70-year-old African American male  named John Doe  who lives in the suburbs of Brooklyn  New York. He is a retired construction worker  is married  and has three grown children. He is a former smoker who quit 15 years ago  an occasional alcohol drinker and lives a sedentary lifestyle.  Medical History  Mr. Doe has a past medical history notable for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type 2 diabetes. His medications include metformin  lisinopril  and simvastatin. Previously strict about his medications  he states he’s been slack lately due to lack of routine caused by the pandemic. He has been non-compliant with taking his medicines regularly for the same reason. Additionally  he has been required to make significant dietary adjustments due to his type 2 diabetes. However  he admits to finding this change challenging to maintain.  Presenting History  The patient was brought to the hospital through ER  complaining of sudden onset abdominal pain that started a night ago. He reported that this pain was unlike any other pain he’d experienced before  describing it as intense  sharp  and radiating to his lower back. He also reported experiencing nausea.  Physical Examination  On examination  Mr. Doe's BP was 170/100  HR 95  and he was afebrile. There was tenderness in his abdomen upon deep palpitation in the midline and lower areas coupled with a pulsating mass. His BMI was found to be 31  indicative of obesity.  Clinical Impressions  Owing to the physical examination and the aforementioned medical history  the clinical impression was that of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). An urgent CT scan was performed  which confirmed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with impending rupture.   Family History  Mr. Doe's father died at the age of 62 from 'heart complications'  though the specific complication is not known to Mr. Doe. One older brother  age 73  is still alive and has been diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD). There is no family history of AAA.  Conclusion  Considering the demographic correlation  AAA is common in patients over 65  particularly men  and African American individuals have been found to be at a higher risk compared to other ethnicities. The risk is exacerbated by the history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  obesity  smoking  and a family history of vascular disease. Emergency treatment was initiated  and vascular surgery consulted for immediate corrective repair of the AAA. It's also suggested to begin a family screening process as the family history poses potential predictive implications.   References: Khosla  S.  Morris  D. R.  Moxon  J. V.  Walker  P. J.  Gasser  T. C.  & Golledge  J. (2014). Meta-analysis of peak wall stress in ruptured  symptomatic and intact abdominal aortic aneurysms. British Journal of Surgery  101(11)  1350–1357. https://doi.org/10.1002/bjs.9608 Preacher  K. J.  & Hayes  A. F. (2008). Asymptotic and resampling strategies for assessing and comparing indirect effects in multiple mediator models. Behavior Research Methods  40(3)  879–891. https://doi.org/10.3758/BRM.40.3.879 Reimerink  J. J.  van der Laan  M. J.  Koelemay  M. J.  Balm  R.  & Legemate  D. A. (2013). Systematic review and meta-analysis of population-based mortality from ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. British Journal of Surgery  100(11)  1405–1413. https://doi.org/10.1002/bjs.9227

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a Geriatric Patient: A Brief Case Study  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 75-year-old Caucasian male who was born and raised in the Midwestern United States. His marital status is widowed  and he has two grown children. The patient is a retired mechanical engineer and comfortably-Iiving on his pension. He identifies as a non-practicing Protestant and enjoys golfing and reading as hobbies.  Presenting Complaint: The patient came presenting with a two-week history of intermittent and non-specific abdominal pain along with some episodes of back discomfort. Symptoms are more pronounced after meals but are not associated with fever  vomiting  weight loss  any change in bowel habits  jaundice  or urinary symptoms.  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which have been well-managed with medications for the past 10 years. The patient denies any history of diabetes or pulmonary diseases. He had undergone a cholecystectomy fifteen years ago due to gallstones.  Family History: The family history is significant as the patient's father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) and died of a rupture in his early 70s. The patient’s mother  currently 98 years old  is alive and lives with dementia. His elder brother succumbed to a heart attack three years back  while the younger sister is diagnosed with Brugada syndrome.  Social History: The patient was a regular smoker but quit 10 years ago around the same time he was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He drinks alcohol moderately  typically indulging in a glass or two of wine per night with his meals. The patient lives alone and for his daily exercising walks about two miles to the local library and back.  Clinical Findings: Upon physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was detected. The laboratory work-up was largely unremarkable. However  an Abdominal Ultrasound revealed an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm measuring 5.5 centimeters in the maximum diameter.  The case represents a stereotypical elderly  white male patient who mostly gets affected by abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  as shown in many epidemiologic studies. His lifestyle  family history of vascular diseases  and smoking habit have put him at risk for development of AAA.  Management strategy: Given the size of the aneurysm and the patient's advanced age  a consultation with a vascular surgeon was booked for further assessment. Given the elevated risk of rupture associated with aneurysms >5cm  the patient was recommended for elective repair.

Patient Presentation:  The patient  Mr. S  is a 67-year-old African American male from urban California  retired as an engineer. He presents to the emergency department with acute lower back pain and reoccurring abdominal discomfort over the past two weeks. He has a history of hypertension controlled with medication (lisinopril) and High-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol within the normal range. His body mass index (BMI) is within the normal range.  Past Medical History: In regards to past medical history  the patient has been managing his hypertension for about ten years. He had a transient ischemic attack (TIA) five years ago but has been stable since then. Mr. S also has a history of smoking one pack per day for nearly 40 years but quit ten years ago. He doesn't have diabetes and his regular blood panels have been within normal limits.  Family History: The patient's father passed away due to heart disease at the age of 75  and his mother died of breast cancer at 80. He has a younger brother living with type 2 diabetes. His two adult children are both in good health.  Clinical Examination & Diagnosis: Clinical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass. His blood pressure at presentation is 145/90 mmHg  and his pulse is regular at 85 beats per minute. Focused abdominal sonography in trauma (FAST) supported with CT scan confirmed the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) with a diameter of approximately 5.5 cm.  Management Plan:  Given the size of the aneurysm and his symptoms  surgical intervention was determined to be the most appropriate treatment. After discussing with the patient  he has given his consent for the procedure. It is planned to carry out the elective operation in the form of endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). Meanwhile  anti-hypertensive medication was increased to achieve better BP control.  Discussion: This case demonstrates typical AAA presentation in an older  male  former smoker with hypertension. Risk factors and demographics align with literature indicating higher prevalence of AAA in male patients  smokers or former smokers  those with a family history of cardiovascular disease  and in 65+ age group.  Being black  the patient falls into a group seen to have lower risk  yet his condition underscores the importance of considering AAA in any patient with appropriate risk factors and symptoms irrespective of race or ethnic origin. Hypertension control and smoking cessation has been shown to mitigate the progression of AAA. Monitoring of symptoms and elective surgical interventions upon reaching the threshold size can reduce the risk of rupture and associated high mortality.

Case Presentation  Patient Demographics:  John Doe  an 82-year-old Caucasian male  presented with complaints of lower back pain that progressed over the past six weeks. He is a retired civil engineer  married  and has two adult children. He has had a long-term smoking habit  averaging one pack a day for the past 60 years. Mr. Doe led a relatively sedentary lifestyle with no current or past substance abuse. He abstains from alcohol and has no travel history. He gained 12 pounds over the past two years.    Medical History:  Mr. Doe’s past medical history includes controlled hypertension and peripheral artery disease (PAD). He has been treated for PAD for the last seven years. He also has a history of COPD  most likely due to his long-term smoking. He has no history of diabetes  no psychiatric diagnosis  and no previous surgeries.   Family History:  His paternal grandfather died from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at the age of 75. His father was diagnosed with AAA at the age of 71 but passed away due to unrelated reasons. His mother is 81 and suffers from hypertension. Both his siblings  aged 75 and 77  are alive and well.   Symptoms:  Mr. Doe described his pain as a sharp  persistent ache in his back  concentrated near his navel. He reported feeling unusually fatigued  had decreased appetite but no weight loss. He denies any fever  correction  diarrhea  nausea  or vomiting. On physical examination  a pulsating mass was detected in his abdomen.   Diagnosis:  Being a male  smoker  over 65 years  and having a family history of AAA  Mr. Doe had a high-risk profile for an abdominal aortic aneurysm. An ultrasound revealed an infrarenal AAA measuring 5.5 cm in diameter  thus confirming the diagnosis. An ECG was suggestive of left ventricular hypertrophy but no other significant abnormalities. His blood work showed Hb 12.0gms  WBC 7800/cmm  platelets 2.5 lakhs/cmm with normal kidney and liver function tests.  Treatment Plan:  Given the size of the aneurysm and the patient's symptomatology  surgical intervention was immediately recommended. The patient and family opted for an endovascular approach (EVAR) due to its minimally invasive nature and quicker recovery. Mr. Doe was referred for the procedure next week. Concurrently  his smoking habit was addressed  and he was referred to a smoking cessation program. His hypertension was managed with control medication adjustments.  With ongoing surveillance  the multi-disciplinary team is hopeful Mr. Doe will recover without any complications. The family and patient were educated about the importance of lifestyle changes  the need for ongoing surveillance  and immediate medical attention in case of severe or sudden abdominal/back pain.

Case Presentation:  Patient Profile: The patient is Mr. Ross  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  residing in New York. He is a widower living with his daughter and her family. He is a former smoker and reports moderate alcohol consumption during his active years.  Initial Presentation: Mr. Ross presented to the ER complaining of severe  unrelenting lower back pain that radiated to his lower abdomen. He also reported loss of appetite and general malaise over a week.  Past Medical History: Mr. Ross has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and peripheral artery disease for which he is on regular medication. He quit smoking 10 years ago  but had a 40-pack-year history prior to quitting. A review of the system was found to be non-contributory.  Family History: There is a significant family history of cardiovascular diseases. Mr. Ross's father passed away at age 52 due to a myocardial infarction and his elder brother at age 65 due to a ruptured AAA.  Physical Examination: On physical examination  his vitals were: BP 150/90mmHg  HR 80bpm  RR 18breaths/min and temperature 37.1C. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass. No abnormal sounds were heard over the mass. The rest of the physical examination was unremarkable.  Investigations: Lab investigations showed a slightly increased WBC count. All other parameters were within normal range. An emergency ultrasound revealed an infrarenal AAA measuring 5.6cm. Subsequent CT scan confirmed the AAA.     Diagnosis and management: Based on his symptoms  physical examination and radiologic evidence  a diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm was made. The patient was admitted and a vascular surgery consult was sought. Considering the size  symptoms  his history  and family history of AAA rupture - it was decided to plan for an urgent endovascular aortic repair.  This case demonstrates an instance of abdominal aortic aneurysm  an often silent but potentially life-threatening condition  especially in older male patients with a history of hypertension  smoking  and familial predisposition to aneurysms. The case also stresses the importance of physical examination and thorough investigation in establishing a precise diagnosis and appropriate intervention.

Patient Identification: Mr. X  68-year-old Caucasian male  Presenting Issue: Complaining of intermittent and unexplained abdominal pain for the past month.  Past Medical History: Diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago  controlled with medication. Former smoker  with a 40-pack-year history. No known allergies. Diagnosed with Hyperlipidemia  well-controlled.  Family History: Father passed away due to myocardial infarction at age 72. Mother had cerebrovascular accident at 79 and died at the age of 81. No siblings.  Social History: Retired military  married  lives with wife. No alcohol or illicit drug use. Used to smoke one pack per day but quit 12 years ago. Minimal physical activity.  Physical Examination: - General: Alert  no acute distress - Cardiovascular: Regular heart rate and rhythm  no murmurs  gallops or rubs. - Pulmonary: Clear to auscultation bilaterally. - Abdomen: Slight tenderness in the mid-abdominal region with a palpable pulsating mass  non-tender  firm.  Diagnostic Information: An ultrasound performed earlier today revealing abdominal aortic aneurysm with a size of 5.5cm.  Plan: Referral to Vascular Surgeon for consult on possibility of surgical intervention or endovascular repair considering his age  the size of the aneurysm  and overall health status.
