Continued monitoring and control of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Patient is recommended to increase physical activity and maintain a heart-healthy diet to prevent progression of atherosclerosis.  In this hypothetical case  Mr. X's overall health status  coupled with his strong family history of cardiovascular disease  consistent hypertension  previous smoking habit  and hyperlipidemia without an adequate lifestyle modification predispose him to the development of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The brief presentational information provides enough data in order to assess and make a medical decision on the best course of action for the patient in collaboration with specialized departments. The prevalence rate of abdominal aortic aneurysm in males above 65 years of age is highest among Caucasians.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Initials: R.S.  Sex: Male  Age: 62 years old  Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Civil Engineer   Presenting Issue:   R.S. presented to the hospital with acute lower back pain and an episode of syncope. He reported feeling a pulsation in his abdomen  together with occasional back pain for the past several months  but thought it was indigestion or muscle strain.   Past Medical History:  R.S. had been diagnosed with hypertension 8 years ago  for which he is currently taking Lisinopril. He has been a chronic smoker for over 40 years  averaging at around 20 cigarettes a day. He has a history of high cholesterol but non-compliant with statin medications.  Family History:  Father died at the age of 68 from myocardial infarction. Mother is 88 years old  with type 2 diabetes and osteoporosis. His younger brother also has a history of hypertension  and his elder sister has rheumatoid arthritis. There is no known hereditary genetic disorder in the family.  Clinical Examination:  Physical examination revealed a pulsatile  palpable mass in the patient's mid-abdominal region. He exhibited signs of hypovolemic shock  including tachycardia and pallor. However  the patient was responsive and oriented.  Diagnostic Findings:  Ultrasound imaging confirmed abdominal aortic aneurysm  measuring approximately 5.3 cm. Unenhanced CT scan depicted a large infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with no signs of rupture.  Plan:  Due to the size of the aneurysm and the patient's advanced age  surgical intervention was deemed essential to reduce the risk of rupture. Elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) has been planned. The patient was counselled extensively about lifestyle modifications  specifically smoking cessation. The importance of being compliant with medication to manage hypertension and cholesterol levels was emphasized.   Final Comments:  R.S. presents a typical case of abdominal aortic aneurysm in line with the literature  with his pronounced risk factors being his sex  age  smoking history and hypertension. Following treatment  he will require regular check-ups to monitor the success of the procedure  his blood pressure  and any appearance/signs of further aneurysm development.

Patient Information:  Mr. Smith  a 67-year-old male of non-Hispanic white descent  residing in Sacramento  California. He is married with 3 adult children and retired. Overall  he has a relatively sedentary lifestyle since retiring from his construction job.  Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a long history of hypertensive disease  controlled on medications (Lisinopril 20mg). He has also been diagnosed with dyslipidemia and mild obesity with a BMI of 30.3. He underwent a successful total knee replacement six years ago and has an allergy to Cefuroxime. Mr. Smith has been a 25-pack-year smoker but quit smoking approximately 10 years ago. He reports moderate alcohol use. Regular follow-ups with his internist are documented.  Presenting Issue:  Mr. Smith presented to the Emergency Department with acute  severe lower back and abdominal pain  which began early in the morning. The pain did not radiate and was not associated with food intake  bowel movements  or urination. There was no record of fever  loss of consciousness  chest pain  or dyspnea.  Family History:  Mr. Smith's father passed away due to a 'heart condition' in his 70s. His mother lived up to 82 and died of cancer-related complications. He has one older brother with coronary artery disease and a younger sister with well-controlled diabetes mellitus. No known history of any vascular diseases in the immediate family.  Physical Examination and Diagnostic Findings:  Upon physical examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpable. A tentative diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm was made. A CT scan of the abdomen confirmed a 7cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm with no evidence of leak or rupture.  Plan of Action:  Currently  Mr. Smith has been admitted under the vascular team for further management. Owing to the large size of the aneurysm  a consultation with the vascular surgeon has been planned to evaluate him for an emergency endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). His family has been informed about his condition and the risks associated with the surgical procedure.  Conclusion:  This case study exemplifies the significance of thorough physical examinations and the need for timely intervention in managing potential life-threatening conditions such as an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. John Doe  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  was admitted to the outpatient department with complaints of intermittent abdominal pain that has been ongoing for the past two months. He expressed a sense of discomfort  describing the pain as a deep  throbbing sensation  located on and off around his navel area. He had no history of nausea  vomiting  or change in bowel habits.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Doe is a known case of hypertension for the last 10 years and has been on medication (metoprolol and hydrochlorothiazide). He also has a history of heavy cigarette smoking for about 35 years  having quit about 5 years ago. His other past medical history includes high cholesterol levels treated with statin. No known allergies are present.   Family History:  His family history is significant  with his father having died of a ruptured aortic aneurysm at age 75  and his older brother was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at 70.  Clinical Examination & Investigations:  On physical examination  he was comfortably placed with a BMI of 29 (height 175 cm  weight 88 kg). Pulse rate was 78/min  blood pressure was noted to be 140/80 mmHg. On abdominal examination  a pulsatile mass was felt just above the navel. His cardiovascular system revealed no abnormalities  and there is no evidence of peripheral vascular disease in the lower extremities. Basic investigations  including complete blood count  kidney function test  lipid profile  and liver function test  were within normal limits.  Abdominal ultrasound showed an infrarenal aortic aneurysm with a maximal diameter of 5.5 cm. Chest x-ray and EKG were generally unremarkable.  This presentation is typical for an asymptomatic AAA  with the risk factors being age > 65 years  male gender  Caucasian race  smoking history  and family history.  Treatment & Management:  A discussion was held with Mr. Doe about his diagnosis and the surgical repair of AAA  considering his aneurysm size and familial history. A detailed record of his case was made and planned for elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  after obtaining written informed consent. He was advised to follow a low-fat diet  and his antihypertensive medications were revised. Smoking cessation (although he already quit) and regular exercise were emphasized. His close relatives were advised about screening for AAA due to family history.  Follow-up:  Mr. Doe will be followed up in the clinic to monitor his status  watch for complications  and ensure proper post-operative care.  In conclusion  this case illustrates the importance of recognising risk factors for abdominal aortic aneurysm and the role of family history. The clinical management for AAA includes considerations about surgical treatments based on factors such as the patient's age  gender  history of smoking etc. Patients who fit these demographics  such as Mr. Doe  should report any sudden onset of abdominal or lower back pain to healthcare providers promptly.

Patient Presentation:  Patient Information: Mr. Manuel Alvarez  a 72-year-old Hispanic male  was admitted to the hospital complaining of severe  constant pain in his lower abdomen and back which began in the last 12 hours. He reports that the pain is not influenced by food intake or physical activity. His primary language is Spanish  which adds a possible language barrier to obtaining a complete medical history and ensuring informed patient decisions.  Past Medical History: Mr. Alvarez has been diagnosed with hypertension (managed with lisinopril)  hyperlipidemia (managed with atorvastatin) and had 15-year history of heavy smoking (20 cigarettes/day) but quit 5 years ago. He has been otherwise healthy and has no known drug allergies.  Demographics: Mr. Alvarez is retired  widowed and lives alone in a flat. He relocated from Mexico to Texas 10 years ago. His diet is primarily traditional Mexican cuisine  which is heavy in sodium and fats. He remains relatively sedentary  except for routine visits to a local senior center.  Family History: His father and older brother both died suddenly in their early 60s from heart disease. His mother reportedly died from a ""ruptured artery"" in her abdomen  although the patient lacks a full understanding of the specifics due to the language barrier.  Physical Examination: Mr. Alvarez appeared to be in extreme pain  exacerbated when touched in the left-lower quadrant of the abdomen. The auscultation of heart sounds showed no irregularities  but a bruit was heard over his abdominal area. His blood pressure was 150/95 mmHg  pulse rate was 110 beats/min  respiratory rate was 20 breaths/min  and the body temperature was at 98.6 °F.  Laboratory Tests / Imaging: Abdominal ultrasound confirmed the presence of a possible aneurysm. A follow-up CT scan confirmed the diagnosis  revealing a 6 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Lab tests found his cholesterol and triglyceride levels elevated  consistent with hyperlipidemia. His complete blood count  kidney function tests  and liver function tests were within normal limits.   Impression and Plan: A diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm was made based on the patient's symptoms  physical examination  and confirmatory imaging tests. Given the size of the aneurysm  the patient was immediately referred to vascular surgery for emergency repair as the pain could indicate a pending rupture. The patient was also referred to a Spanish-speaking case manager to ensure accurate communication and understanding of the medical condition and the surgical procedure. His hypertension and hyperlipidemic treatment plans will require adjustments with new guidelines for patients with AAA. The patient was also advised to inform his children about the AAA diagnosis due to the possible genetic component of the disease. After surgery  Mr. Alvarez will be closely followed up in the outpatient setting.

Patient Presentation  Mr. Albert Johnson  a 70-year-old African American male  presented at the emergency department complaining of persistent and severe abdominal and back pain for the past few days. Mr. Johnson says the pain is not episodic  and it seems to radiate to his back and lower limbs. He reported a loss of appetite but denied any bowel or bladder changes or weight loss.   Past Medical History  Mr. Johnson is a retired factory worker with significant occupational exposure to lead. He has a history of hypertension  which is controlled by regular medications  and a 40-pack-year smoking history before quitting 5 years ago  along with occasional alcohol use. There’s no history of any surgeries. He has a long history of neglecting routine health check-ups and recent weight gain of about 10 lbs. He occasionally takes over-the-counter antacid for heartburn.  Family History  Mr. Johnson’s father died in his sixties of a stroke. His mother  who is in her nineties  suffers from age-related macular degeneration. His younger brother  aged 66  was recently diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He has one son and one daughter  both believe to be healthy. There’s no history of lung or kidney disease in the family.  Clinical Examination  On examination  Mr. Johnson has a pulsatile abdominal mass  and his Body Mass Index (BMI) 28 falls in the overweight category. His Blood pressure was elevated in the clinic with a reading of 155/95 mmHg.  Investigations  Ultrasound and Computed Tomography Angiography (CTA) were performed  following clinical examination  confirming the presence of a large infra-renal Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) of around 6.5cm  which requires intervention.  Discussion  Risk factors for AAA include age over 65  male gender  smoking history  hypertension  family history of AAA  and Caucasian race. Interestingly  African Americans have a lower prevalence of AAA compared to Whites. But in our case  Mr. Johnson has major risk factors like advanced age  male gender  smoking history  and hypertension  including a family history of AAA  and hence confirms AAA diagnosis even being an African American male.   The patient's hypertension  history of smoking  occupational exposure to toxins  and poor health maintenance could have led to his current condition. Weight gain and associated heartburn might indicate lifestyle-related issues. It is important to consider his age and neglect of routine health check-ups in managing his condition moving forward.  This case presentation highlights the need for AAA screening in individuals with risk factors  regardless of race or ethnic background  to prevent fatal outcomes.

Case Presentation:  Patient Profile: Patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. J.T  retired accountant who resides in Northern California. He has lived in the region for the last four decades. He is a smoker with a history of smoking 1 pack per day for the last 50 years. The patient is married and has three grown-up daughters  but there's no history of cardiovascular disease in the family. The patient weighs around 90kg and is 175 cm tall  so his BMI is classified as overweight.  Presenting Concern: Mr. J.T. presents with midepigastric and lower back pain marked as a pulling sensation  unrelieved by rest or lying position for the past 2 weeks. No bowel or bladder dysfunction reported.  Past Medical History: Mr. J.T. has a past medical history exceptional for essential hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). His hypertension is controlled with Lisinopril and his hyperlipidemia with Simvastatin. He had been prescribed some medication for COPD but is noncompliant due to some financial issues.  Physical Exam: Upon examination  he appears weaker but is in no acute distress. His BP is 160/90 mmHg  heart rate regular. His abdomen is tender at the periumbilical region with a pulsatile mass.  Diagnostic Tests: A CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis was ordered  which showed an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.4 cm in diameter. Other structures appeared normal.  Discussion: The patient Tobacco consumption  uncontrolled hypertension and COPD  along with his age puts him at increased risk for the development and rupture of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. His description of unremitting abdominal pain and back pain  along with the finding of a pulsatile abdominal mass on physical exam  raised suspicion for abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Management Plan: Urgent surgical evaluation is warranted for Mr. J.T. given the size of his aneurysm and his presenting symptoms  suggestive of impending rupture. Meanwhile  strict control of his blood pressure is necessary to prevent further enlargement of the abdominal aneurysm.  Conclusion:  This case exemplifies proper identification and prompt management of abdominal aortic aneurysm  a potentially life-threatening condition if left unnoticed. Early diagnosis and medical intervention are key elements in the successful of this patient's treatment. It's also important that Mr. J.T. quit smoking and maintain his overall health to help mitigate further health risks.

Patient Presentation:  Mr. Johnson  a 70-year-old African American male  has been having intermittent  dull abdominal pain for a couple of weeks. He is a retired military sergeant and currently lives alone in his house.  Demographics: Mr. Johnson embodies a typical case witnessed in healthcare literature: he falls within the highest-risk demographic group for the development of abdominal aortic aneurysms—male  over 65  and African American.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a significant history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia that he controls with medication. He was a smoker but quit approximately 10 years ago after four decades of substantial pack/year history. He does not consume alcohol due to a past diagnosis of mild liver cirrhosis. Apart from these pathologies  Mr. Johnson has led a relatively healthy life with no other significant co-morbidities.  Family History:  He reports a family history of cardiovascular disease. His father died at the age of 74 due to myocardial infarction  and his elder brother has been diagnosed with peripheral artery disease. There is no family history of abdominal aortic aneurysms.  As part of his annual health check-up  Mr. Johnson underwent an elective ultrasound which revealed a 5-cm infra-renal abdominal aortic aneurysm. Given the size of the aneurysm and his relative good health otherwise  his vascular surgeon advised him to consider an elective endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  following pre-operative health optimization and risk stratification.  Behavioural and lifestyle modifications were also discussed with Mr. Johnson  including a healthy diet to manage his blood lipid levels and hypertension and regular exercise within limits of his physical comfort and abilities. He was also referred to a cardiac rehabilitation team for facilitating necessary lifestyle changes and continued cessation of smoking.  This case highlights the importance of routine health screening  especially in high-risk demographic groups. Early identification can lead to timely interventions  helping to alter disease progression or improve outcomes  particularly in potentially life-threating pathologies like an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  References used from literature: 1. ""Open versus endovascular repair of abdominal aortic aneurysm."" N Engl J Med 2019; 380:2126. 2. ""Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm: Practice Essentials  Background  Pathophysiology and Etiology."" Medscape. 2020-09-10. 3. ""Background and Prevalence of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm."" UpToDate. 2020-10-29.

Patient Profile: Name: John Doe Age: 66 Race: Caucasian Gender: Sex Residential Status: Urban Occupation: Retired Mechanical Engineer Past Medical History: Hypertension  High cholesterol levels Family History: Father died due to heart attack  Mother with high blood pressure   Presentation: Mr. John Doe  a 66-year-old Caucasian male  presented to our emergency department complaining of sudden severe abdominal pain radiating to his lower back. The patient was previously diagnosed and treated for hypertension and high cholesterol. His adherence to medications and routine check-ups has been consistent. His smoking habits (one pack a day for the past 35 years) can be identified as a significant risk factor leading to his present condition.   Family history reveals that his father died of a heart attack at the age of 70  while his mother suffers from hypertension. As per literature  male gender  age over 60  smoking history  high blood pressure  and family history of the disease are key risk factors of abdominal aortic aneurysm which justifies the potential risk in this case.   On examination  his vital signs were within normal limits  but a pulsatile mass was palpable in the mid-abdominal area. The pain scale recorded an 8 out of 10 describing the pain as 'tearing'. A discussion about his medical history and recent symptoms indicated a possible Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA).  An urgent ultrasound confirmed an AAA approximately 5.5cm in size. Due to its size and his symptomatology  the decision was made to operate. Pathology reports later confirmed the AAA.  Post-recovery  Mr. Doe was counseled to quit smoking and was enrolled in a cardiovascular rehabilitation program. He was also educated about the nature of AAA and the need for regular monitoring to prevent future occurrences. This case emphasizes the need for AAA screening programs  especially in risk groups i.e.  males over 60 years with a family history of AAA and a smoking history.  (Note: The demographic details for AAA  such as gender  age  race  and the risk increased due to personal and family medical history  are consistent with typical AAA patient profiles as found in research literature.)

Patient Presentation  Patient Identification: Mr. Ahmad Zubair  Male  68 years old  of Middle-Eastern descent  married  retired engineer.  Main Complaint: Presented to the emergency department with severe  constant  and overwhelming lower back and abdominal pain for two days.  Medical History: The patient has been diagnosed with Hypertension for the past 12 years  managed by medication. He is also a former smoker  having quit 6 years ago but had a significant pack-year history prior. There is no history of any known drug allergies. He has had no prior surgeries.  Family History: Patient's father died in his early-70s because of stroke. His mother suffered from hypertension and diabetes but died from pneumonia at the age of 80. His older brother  currently 72  has been diagnosed with Ischemic Heart Disease. The patient has 2 sons  both healthy.  Clinical Examination and Investigations: Physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass. A Computed Tomography (CT) scan confirmed the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring 7cm. Lab results showed a slightly elevated white blood cell count but other parameters within normal limits.  Clinical Impression: Large abdominal aortic aneurysm in a 68-year-old male with a history of hypertension.  Management Plan: Given the size of the AAA and symptomology  surgical intervention was unavoidable. The patient was informed about the risks of rupture and subsequent complications. The option of endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) was discussed  as was open repair. After providing informed consent  the patient elected to proceed with EVAR.  Post-Op Follow Up: Post-operative recovery was uneventful and symptoms relieved. He was discharged with a plan for regular follow-ups and imaging to monitor the site of the repair.  Discussion: This case underlines the importance of regular screening  particularly in patients over the age of 60 with a history of hypertension  smoking  or a family history of AAA. Mr. Ahmad had no notion of having AAA  despite being in a high-risk group  until the symptoms became severe. Earlier detection might have resulted in less invasive management options.  References: - Sampson UK  et al. Global and regional burden of aortic dissection and aneurysms: mortality trends in 21 world regions  1990 to 2010. Global Heart 2014; 9(1): 171-80 e10. - Kent KC. Clinical practice. Abdominal aortic aneurysms. The New England Journal of Medicine 2014; 371(22): 2101-8.

Patient Case Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Demographics: The patient is an 83-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. Smith. He is a retired civil engineer  is married with no children. He lives in suburban New York with his wife. He is a non-smoker and drinks alcohol occasionally.   Presenting Issue:  Mr. Smith presents with a sudden  severe and constant abdominal pain that has persisted for several hours. He rates his pain as an '8' on a 1-10 scale. He also complains of dizziness  nausea and back pain.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and chronic kidney disease  for which he is receiving regular treatment. He had a myocardial infarction 10 years ago and a bypass surgery following this. He is not diabetic. He has no known allergies.  Family History:  His father had a heart condition and died of an unknown cause in his late 70s. His mother lived into her 90s with no significant health issues. He has one younger brother in good health  and one older sister who was diagnosed with breast cancer in her early 60s.  Examination and Diagnosis: On physical examination  Mr. Smith appeared to be in severe pain with a distended abdomen. His heart rate was elevated at 110 beats per minute  blood pressure was 140/90 and respiratory rate was 20 breaths per minute. An abdominal examination revealed a pulsating mass in the midline.   A subsequent ultrasound of the abdomen confirmed the presence of a large abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) approximately 7.5 cm in diameter. Judging by the size and symptom severity  immediate intervention was deemed necessary due to the high risk of rupture.  Summary: Considering Mr. Smith’s sudden severe abdominal pain  his risk factors of advanced age  male sex  and cardiovascular disease history  as well as the discovery of a large and symptomatic AAA  immediate medical intervention is highly warranted. He was counseled regarding the need for urgent surgery and referred to a vascular surgeon for further management.  This case displays the critical importance for healthcare providers to consider an abdominal aortic aneurysm in the differential diagnosis generally but specifically for elderly male patients presenting with sudden  severe and persistent abdominal or back pain.

Subject: Case Presentation: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Patient Information: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male named Mr. M  who resides in a suburban neighborhood. He is a retired engineer  weighing 82kg (BMI: 28.5)  and stands at 5’9” (175cm). He is married with three adult children and six grandchildren. He is a former smoker  having quit 20 years ago  but admits to consuming alcohol occasionally. His social history is notable for jogs twice a week. He has a history of hypertension  which has been managed with a low dose of Hydrochlorothiazide for the past ten years. Mr. M has no known allergies.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. M presented with incessant lower abdominal pain  accompanied by discomfort radiating to his back. The pain  which he describes as 7/10  has been constant over the last 24 hours. He denied any associated symptoms such as palpitations  shortness of breath  nausea  or vomiting.   Family History: His father died at the age of 72 of a myocardial infarction. His mother is currently 88 years old and has been diagnosed with type 2 diabetes. He also has one brother who is living and healthy but a late sister who died following complications during childbirth.  Clinical Examination Findings: Upon palpation  an abdominal mass was detected  consistent with AAA. Mr. M's blood pressure was measured at 140/85 mmHg  and his pulse rate was 82 bpm. Other vitals including respiratory rate and body temperature were within normal ranges. His cardiovascular examination was unremarkable barring a slight bruit over the palpated abdominal mass.  Investigations: A subsequent ultrasound confirmed AAA with a maximal diameter of 5.8cm. Laboratory data  including complete blood counts  renal function  and electrolytes  were mostly within normal limits apart added mild anemia (Hb: 11.2 g/dL). An ECG displayed normal sinus rhythm.  Management: Mr. M was hospitalized immediately considering the risk of AAA rupture. He will be scheduled for an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  which is the preferred method in patients with suitable anatomy and multiple comorbidities. He is also started on blood pressure control and treatment for his anemia.  This case demonstrates a common condition affecting individuals over the age of 60  particularly males  with past smoking history and hypertension as key risk factors. Prompt recognition through physical examination and definitive management via invasive intervention is vital to prevent fatal rupture.

Patient Presentation: The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired  a lifetime non-smoker who presents with intermittent  dull abdominal pain for the past few weeks. He reports no changes in bowel habits  anorexia  or weight loss. He drinks alcohol moderately.   Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension  diagnosed at age 50 and is well-managed with medication. He also has hyperlipidemia and a remote history of myocardial infarction at age 65. He receives regular follow-ups for his cardiac condition and takes aspirin and a statin.   Family History: There is no known family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). However  his older brother experienced a myocardial infarction in his early 70s  suggesting a hereditary predisposition to cardiovascular disease.  Physical Examination: Physical examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass. His blood pressure is 140/90 mmHg in both arms  and heart rate 76 bpm. There is no lower limb edema. Peripheral pulses are intact. Hematological and biochemical blood investigations  including full blood count  renal function  liver function  and serum electrolytes  are all within normal limits.   Investigations and Diagnosis: An ultrasound examination of the abdomen confirms the presence of an AAA with a maximum diameter of 5.5 cm. The patient is referred for a CT angiogram for further assessment and planning for possible intervention.   Discussion: The patient's age  sex  hypertension  and history of cardiovascular disease significantly increase his risk for an AAA. The American Heart Association recommends one-time screening for AAA with abdominal ultrasound in men aged 65-75 who have ever smoked. Despite being a non-smoker  the patient's other risk factors warrant consideration for the AAA screening.   In line with the guideline  any AAA 5.5 cm or larger should be considered for repair to prevent rupture. Given the patient's cardiovascular history  both open surgical repair and endovascular aneurysm repair should be discussed with the patient alongside their potential risks and benefits.   Patient Care Plan: The patient should be counseled regarding the nature of his illness  need for surgical intervention  and potential risks associated. Involvement of a cardiothoracic surgeon is necessary for further management. The patient's hypertension should be optimally controlled preoperatively.   It's imperative to monitor the patient's lipid profile and cardiac condition continually and manage these in coordination with a cardiologist. Lifestyle modification measures including a healthy diet  regular exercise  limiting alcohol intake should all be emphasized. Regardless of surgery  the patient should have regular follow-up imaging of his aneurysm every six months.   Ethnicity and geographical considerations: While the above case represents a typical patient with AAA  it's worth noting that the epidemiology of AAA varies worldwide. The overall prevalence in men over 65 is about 1.5% and is additionally common in Caucasians. Though less common in non-Caucasian populations  awareness and management strategies need to be similarly rigorous.

Case Presentation:   The patient  Mr. Gallagher  is a 71-year-old Caucasian man living in San Francisco  California  USA. He is retired and used to work as a construction engineer. He currently lives with his wife and three adult children in a suburban neighborhood.   He has been previously diagnosed with hypertension and has been on medication for the same. Mr. Gallagher has no history of diabetes mellitus or any heart diseases but has a history of hypercholesterolemia. He was also a heavy smoker  averaging one pack a day for about 35 years before he quit smoking 5 years ago.   Mr. Gallagher first presented in the emergency room complaining about persistent  unmitigated abdominal and lower back pain  which he described as 'sharp and crippling'  rating it 8 on a scale of 10. He also reported episodes of nausea and feelings of general fatigue over the past two weeks.   On examination  his blood pressure was consistently borderline high (140/85 mmHg)  with a pulse rate of about 80 bpm. He has a high BMI (28.3 kg/m2)  indicating that he is overweight. Upon physical examination  a pulsatile mass was noticed in his abdomen  which raised suspicion of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA).  This suspicion was further confirmed with an abdominal ultrasound which showed a 5.5cm dilatation in the aorta. A CT scan was also performed to aid in the preoperative planning of intervention due to the patient's chronic symptoms and the size of the aneurysm.  His past medical history includes hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  smoking  and being overweight  which are all risk factors known to be associated with abdominal aortic aneurysms. His father died of a stroke at 78 years of age and he has a brother diagnosed with an AAA at 66 years old.   The patient has been recommended for an immediate surgical intervention to manage the AAA. He has been informed about the risks involved and the postoperative care that will be necessary following the surgery. The need for lifestyle changes such as regular exercise  a controlled diet  and maintaining a healthy body weight have also been discussed to manage his hypertension and hypercholesterolemia  and thus reduce the risk of cardiovascular and aneurysmal complications in the future.

Patient Profile:  Mr. John Doe  a 69-year-old Caucasian male  retired civil engineer from New York  presents with a complaint of lower abdominal and back pain that have been persistent over the past week. The patient has been relatively healthy  with only an existing diagnosis of hypertension for the last seven years  managed with medication (Hydrochlorothiazide). The patient reports compliance with his medication. He also underwent an appendectomy at age 25. His body mass index (BMI) is 26.1  indicating mild obesity.  Personal History:  Mr. Doe has been a smoker for the past 40 years  consuming about a pack a day. He enjoys a glass or two of red wine almost every day post-retirement. His diet consists mainly of home-cooked meals where his salt and cholesterol intake have been consciously monitored  considering his hypertension. He likes to walk his Labrador in the park daily for exercise. There's no history of drug abuse or any known allergies to food and medication.  Family History:  Mr. Doe's father passed away at the age of 72 due to a myocardial infarction  and his mother died at age 79 due to natural causes. His older brother  aged 72  was recently diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. His children  a 40-year-old son and a 37-year-old daughter  are both in good health.  Clinical Examination:  On examination  his blood pressure was noted to be 145/90 mmHg  slightly above his usual readings. Other vital signs (heart rate  respiratory rate  temperature) were within normal limits. On abdominal examination  a pulsatile mass was palpated in the periumbilical area. Bowel sounds were noted to be normal.  Radiology:  Given the familial history of abdominal aortic aneurysm and the clinical findings  a CT scan was ordered which indeed confirmed a 6.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Management:  Mr. Doe was counseled about his condition and the need for urgent surgical intervention  given the size of his aneurysm. He was scheduled for an open surgical repair. Lifestyle modifications were stressed  especially smoking cessation and control of hypertension.  Follow-up:  Outpatient follow-up appointments every month post-surgery have been scheduled for the first six months to monitor the repair site and control his blood pressure. It would also include counseling for lifestyle and dietary changes. His family members are suggested to undergo screening for abdominal aortic aneurysm due to its evident familial occurrence.  This case highlights the relevance of thorough physical examinations and detailed family histories in diametrically influencing patient care  given the potential fatal consequences of asymptomatic pathologies such as abdominal aortic aneurysms.

Patient Profile: The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male named John  who was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He retired 4 years ago from his occupation as a manager in a construction firm. John is married  has three children  and lives with his wife. He is an ex-smoker with a 30 pack-year history but quit when he turned 60. He consumes alcohol moderately.   Past Medical History: John has a medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has been on antihypertensive medication for the past 10 years and statins for his hyperlipidemia. There is no history of diabetes  vascular disease or renal disease. He had a hip replacement surgery five years ago due to osteoarthritis.  Family History: John's father died from a ruptured AAA at the age of 75. His mother passed away from stroke-related complications at 82. His older brother  who is 70 years old  recently had an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) for AAA. There is no family history of coronary artery disease  stroke  Peripheral Arterial Disease (PAD)  diabetes or cancer.   Presenting Complaints: John reported discomfort in his lower back and a feeling of fullness in his abdomen that has persisted over few weeks. He described the pain as dull aching and is not radiating. No associated symptoms like fever  altered bowel habits  bloating or weight loss were reported.  Clinical Finding and Diagnosis: On physical exam  John had a palpable abdominal mass which was pulsatile indicative of an AAA. In order to confirm the diagnosis  an abdominal ultrasound was performed which revealed a 5.4 cm infrarenal AAA.  Treatment Plan: The plan is to discuss potential treatment options with John including watchful waiting  endovascular repair or open surgical repair depending on his overall health status  risks  and the size and rate of growth of the aneurysm.  AAA is a condition common among the older population  predominantly in Caucasian males  with risk factors such as a family history and smoking being highly associated with the disease. It is highly important for clinicians to have high suspicion among patients who are older  male  smokers with a family history of AAA presenting with abdominal or back pain to ensure early referral for surgical intervention and optimal management.

Case Presentation:  Patient Information: The patient is a 72-year-old African American male  a retired construction worker  who was diagnosed with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA). The patient resides in a Midwest suburb. He currently lives alone  having been widowed six years earlier. He is a father of 3 and grandfather to 5.  Medical History: The patient has a significant history of hypertension  high cholesterol and type 2 diabetes  which are all controlled with medication. The patient was a heavy smoker who quit 15 years ago  but consumed alcohol socially. He does not exercise regularly but maintains a balanced diet. His BMI is 29  within the range of obesity.   Presenting Problems: The patient experienced occasional episodes of mild abdominal pain radiating to his lower back over the last couple of weeks. Initially  he attributed this to indigestion and did not seek medical attention until the pain became severe and was associated with a sense of his heartbeat in his abdomen. He had no other symptoms like fever  nausea  or hematuria.   Examination and Diagnosis: An abdominal examination has confirmed a pulsating mass predominantly centrally located and abdominal ultrasound subsequently showed an AAA of 6cm. Given his severe abdominal and back pain emergency surgical consult was sought. CT angiography confirmed the size and revealed a partially thrombosed AAA with no signs of rupture.  Family History: His father had a history of AAA and died in his late sixties from a cardiac event. His mother died from breast cancer. His older brother also has hypertension and type II diabetes.  Discussion: AAA is prevalent in males over 65 years  particularly those with a history of smoking  hypertension  or a family history of AAA (Brady  et al.  2016). African American men have a significant risk  especially if they have a comorbidity like diabetes and hyperlipidemia as our patient (Sampson  et al.  2014). It's noteworthy that he embodies multiple risk factors  such as being over 65  male  a former smoker  and diabetic. It's also reported that African Americans are less likely to undergo screening for AAA (Sampson  et al.  2014)  which makes early detection difficult.  References: 1. Brady  A. R.  Thompson  S. G.  Fowkes  F. G.  Greenhalgh  R. M.  & Powell  J. T. (2016). Abdominal aortic aneurysm expansion: risk factors and time intervals for surveillance. Circulation. 2. Sampson  U. K.  Norman  P. E.  Fowkes  F. G.  Aboyans  V.  Song  Y.  Harrell  F. E.  ... & Criqui  M. H. (2014). Estimation of global and regional incidence and prevalence of abdominal aortic aneurysms 1990 to 2010. Global heart.

Patient Presentation  Demographics: Mr. X is a 72-year-old African American man who resides in an urban setting. Literature suggests that an abdominal aortic aneurysm is prevalent in this demographic  particularly in men over the age of 65.  Presenting Complaint: The patient reports a history of vague and intermittent abdominal discomfort for the past 3 months. On his recent visit  he mentioned that the pain has escalated  radiating to his lower back.  Medical History: Mr. X has been hypertensive for 15 years  for which he takes amlodipine 10 mg daily. He has also been a smoker for 50 years and has continued to smoke a pack/day. He reports no known allergies.  Family History: His father died from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at age 65  and his mother has a history of hypertension. He has a younger brother who was recently diagnosed with a small abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Examination Findings: On physical examination  a pulsatile mass in the abdomen was palpable. His blood pressure was 170/90 mmHg  and heart rate was regular at 80 beats per minute. Casting further concern  his four extremities' pulses were regular but weak.  Investigations: An abdominal ultrasound confirmed an abdominal aortic aneurysm with a diameter of 5.5cm  qualifying him for surgical evaluation. Lab tests including blood counts  liver and kidney function  and coagulation profile were within normal limits. Chest X-ray was unremarkable  but an EKG showed left ventricular hypertrophy  likely due to longstanding hypertension.  Impression: Mr. X has a significant risk of aneurysm rupture due to his history of smoking  hypertension  advancing age  and family history. His symptoms suggest risk for rupture  necessitating timely intervention.  Management: Mr. X was educated about the urgency and need for surgical intervention  due to the risk of rupture. The patient was referred to a vascular surgeon to discuss the most appropriate surgical intervention  such as open surgical repair or endovascular aneurysm repair. For risk reduction  he was advised to cease smoking and ensure control of his hypertension. The healthcare team will also closely monitor and manage his pain to prevent any further complications.    Follow Up: Patient is scheduled for a follow-up visit after one week to evaluate the progress of his hypertension and overall health status. He will also undergo pre-operative evaluation for surgery  including a cardiac stress test due to the EKG findings.

Case Presentation  Patient's Profile: Mr. Johnson is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  from the upper-middle socio-economic status  presently residing in Tampa  Florida. He is recently retired after spending most of his life working in the banking sector. He is a chronic smoker and has a history of hypertension  both risk factors for abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA). He also indulges in moderate alcohol consumption.   Family History:  There is a family history of AAA  with his father having experienced a ruptured AAA at the age of 75.   Presenting Complaint: Mr. Johnson consulted with his primary care doctor due to an episodic abdominal discomfort he felt while engaging in mild physical activities. He also reported back pain  tenderness in the abdomen  and unexplained weight loss for a couple of months.  Investigations and Diagnosis: Following his complaint  an abdominal ultrasound was performed which revealed a 5cm dilatation in the lower part of the aorta  consistent with an AAA. A subsequent CT scan confirmed the size  location  and extent of the AAA. Blood tests were normal except for slightly increased cholesterol levels.  Past Medical History: Mr. Johnson is a known hypertensive for the past 10 years. He is on regular medication (Lisinopril and Amlodipine) and has relatively controlled blood pressure. He was also diagnosed with Type II diabetes mellitus five years ago  which is being managed by oral hypoglycemic agents (Metformin). He had an elective coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG) done seven years ago. He does not have any history of pulmonary diseases or kidney diseases.  Physical Examination: Mr. Johnson has a BMI of 27.1  indicating he is overweight. He appeared in good health with no signs of distress and was well-oriented. Cardiovascular examination was within normal limits with no murmurs  gallops  or rubs heard. His abdomen was slightly distended and a pulsatile mass was palpable in the mid and upper abdomen.   Management and Prognosis: Given the size of the AAA  its rapid increase  and his risk factors  Mr. Johnson was referred to a vascular surgeon for a possible endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). A detailed discussion of the benefits and risks of the procedure was carried out with the patient. His medication was adjusted  with increased focus on controlling hypertension and cholesterol levels  and he has been advised to quit smoking and control his diabetes effectively. If left untreated  the AAA could rupture  leading to a life-threatening situation.   In conclusion  Mr. Johnson's AAA is a consequence of his genetic predisposition  lifestyle choices  advanced age  and chronic hypertension. His prognosis would largely depend on his response to intervention  continued medical management of risk factors  and lifestyle modifications.

Patient Presentation:  The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  Mr. J  who presents to the emergency department with a chief complaint of sudden onset severe abdominal pain radiating to his back that started 6 hours ago. Mr. J identifies his discomfort as “tearing” in nature  rating it as a ten out of ten in severity  not relieved by any at-home measures. He denied having any heat intolerance  visible weight loss  nor symptoms related to thyroid disease.  Demographics:   Mr. J reports living alone since his wife’s passing five years ago. He is a retired postal worker and does not engage in any form of regular physical exercise. He has a 40-pack-year history of smoking but quit ten years ago. His diet consists of mostly fast and processed foods. His BMI is 30  putting him in the obese category. He does not consume alcohol and denies any illicit drug use.   Medical History:   He has a past medical history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and Type 2 diabetes. Medications include metformin  hydrochlorothiazide  and Lipitor. He had an appendectomy at 30 and has no known drug allergies. Mr. J is not under the care of a cardiologist  and his last health check was three years ago.   Family History:   Both of Mr. J’s parents passed away in their early 80s. His father had a history of stroke and coronary artery disease  whereas his mother had breast cancer and arthritis. He has two older brothers; both have diabetes and hypertension. His only sister had ovarian cancer.  Diagnosis:  Based on the severing back pain  Mr. J's obesity  and his age  in combination with symptoms of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  the physician ordered an abdominal aortic ultrasound. The ultrasound confirmed the presence of a large (5.8 cm in diameter) abdominal aortic aneurysm.   Discussion:  Abdominal aortic aneurysms are more common in Caucasian males  over 65  with a history of smoking and family history of AAAs. Hypertension and high cholesterol  both found in Mr. J’s history  are significant risks. As Mr. J is 70 years old  obese  with a history of smoking  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia  he was at a very high risk of an AAA. The sudden  severe  and persistent abdominal and back pain was indicative of a potentially rupturing AAA  requiring immediate surgical intervention.  Emergency surgery was scheduled  and the patient was provided with counseling regarding the benefits and risks. The patient agreed to proceed.   This case demonstrates the importance of considering life-threatening conditions like AAA In patients who present with acute abdominal pain  particularly in those with relevant risk factors. Regular healthcare checks  especially in individuals with multiple comorbidities  are crucial in early diagnosis and treatment of conditions such as AAA.

Case Presentation:  Subject specifications: A 62-year-old African American male  Mr. J.  Presenting complaints: Mr. J was initially brought into the emergency department complaining about a sudden  sharp pain in his lower back and abdomen  particularly severe on left.  Past medical history: Records indicate he's a diabetic  with a history of uncontrolled hypertension.  Smoking history: He reports being a regular smoker for the last 40 years.  Family history: His father had passed due to complications from aortic aneurysm in his 60s. He has no siblings. His eldest son  in his early 40s  has no known cardiovascular diseases.  Examination: On presentation  he appeared anxious and in distress. His blood pressure was high at 170/90mmHg  other vital signs were within normal ranges. On examination  a pulsatile mass was palpated in his abdomen. Initial investigations (ECG  chest-X-ray  lab tests) showed normal heart function  but high blood glucose levels and moderate anaemia.  Diagnosis: A CT angiogram was performed  which confirmed the presence of a 5.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Management: Considering the high risk of rupture due to the size of the aneurysm (>5cm)  emergency surgery was planned. Considering his uncontrolled hypertension and diabetes  these were managed preoperatively. He underwent an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  post which his vital signs and general condition improved significantly. He received counselling for smoking cessation  dietary modifications and regular exercise.  Follow-up: He was discharged and scheduled for outpatient follow-up with vascular surgery  endocrinology (for diabetes management)  and cardiology for his hypertension. His physiological as well as emotional well-being was assessed during follow-ups.  This case presents a common scenario involving an African American older adult male with an AAA and several risk factors such as smoking  hypertension  diabetes and significant family history. Attention to these factors during assessment may lead to earlier identification and intervention for AAAs  which can prevent rupture and significantly improve the quality of life in these individuals.

Introduction:  Patient Profile: The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  hailing from middle-class socioeconomic status and who lives in Florida. He claims to have quit smoking 10 years ago but has a smoking history of 30 years. He drinks alcohol socially and has no history of illicit drug use.  Presenting Problem: He presented to the emergency department with sudden onset  severe abdominal and lower back pain radiating towards his buttock. He denies associated chest pain  shortness of breath  palpitations  or lower limb weakness.  Past Medical and Family History: Patient has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed with medication. He is compliant with his regular medication - Atenolol and Atorvastatin. There is no known history of diabetes  stroke  or any other chronic illnesses. The patient has a family history of cardiovascular diseases  as his father had a myocardial infarction at 68.  Clinical Examination and Diagnosis: On examination  there is a palpable pulsatile mass in the abdomen. Blood pressure is slightly elevated at 160/90 mmHg. Lab results demonstrate no leukocytosis or increased renal markers. CT angiography confirms the diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring 7 cm in diameter.  Discussion: AAA is often asymptomatic until rupture  where it presents as severe abdominal or back pain  typically in males above 65. Risk factors include older age  male sex  smoking history  hypertension  and family history of AAA. The patient’s age  sex  smoking history  hypertension  and family history of cardiovascular disease put him at high risk. The patient’s aneurysm  at 7cm  exceeds the 5.5 cm threshold for elective surgical intervention in men.  Management Plan: Immediate surgical consultation was obtained for an emergency endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR)  considering the size of the aneurysm and the risk of rupture. Patient was also started on intravenous antihypertensive therapy to control his blood pressure until surgery was performed.  Conclusion: Awareness of the presentation  risk factors  and appropriate management can facilitate early recognition and treatment of AAA  leading to improved patient outcomes.  (Note: The details about the patient are invented for the purpose of creating this case study and may not be true)

Patient Overview:  Patient: Mr. John Smith Age: 72 Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired school teacher Residence: Urban setting  Mr. John Smith  a 72-year-old Caucasian man  came to the hospital complaining of severe  constant pain in his abdominal region and back that started about one week ago. He reports feeling unsteady while walking  and has experienced a significant lack of appetite.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has been hypertensive for the past 20 years. He has been sporadic with his blood pressure medication due to financial constraints. He is a former smoker  having quit 30 years ago but had puffed up to one pack daily for 20 years prior to cessation. He doesn't consume alcohol. He had a heart attack around 10 years ago but he made a complete recovery after a percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI). He is also prediabetic but has not yet started any medication for it.  Family History:  His father died at the age of 65 due to myocardial infarction and his mother died at the age of 70 because of stroke. One of his two brothers had an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) that was successfully repaired. This indicates a potential genetic predisposition to aneurysms in the family.   Examination:  Upon examination  his blood pressure was 160/110 mm Hg and pulse rate was 90 beats per minute. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsating abdominal mass. An ultrasound confirmed the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.6 cm.  Discussion:  Given the above information  the patient’s recognised risk factors for the development of abdominal aortic aneurysm include advanced age  male gender  history of smoking  hypertension  and potentially a genetic predisposition. The reported severe abdominal and back pain coupled with the physical exam findings raised suspicion of AAA  making the finding of the pulsating abdominal mass an important clue in the diagnosis.   In literature  males over 60 years  smokers  Caucasians  and individuals with a family history of AAA have a higher risk of developing the disease (US Preventive Services Task Force  2019). These factors align with Mr Smith's profile thereby placing him at greater risk.   Given the size of the aneurysm and the severity of his pain  there is a significant risk of rupture. Urgent surgical evaluation is recommended for Mr. Smith because of the large size of his AAA  his pain symptoms  and the risk of rupture associated with these factors.  Management:  After discussing with Mr. Smith the pros and cons of open surgery versus endovascular repair  he agreed to undergo endovascular aneurysm repair  which is less invasive and has a quicker recovery time. His blood pressure and prediabetic state must be monitored and managed accordingly to prevent postoperative complications.  Further steps would include lifestyle changes to control his blood pressure levels and strict glucose monitoring  assisting him to get access to affordable medications  regular monitoring for post repair complications  and screening his immediate family due to the high risk of AAA heredity.

Patient Presentation:   Mr. Jose Alvarez is a 69-year-old Hispanic male with a diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). This patient has a history of hypertension and 20-year history of smoking  although he quit 10 years ago. His past medical history shows periods of chest pain  occasional syncope  and kidney stones for which he did not pursue aggressive treatment but managed symptomatically. He also has moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and intermittent claudication on exertion  likely secondary to peripheral artery disease.  Family History:  He has a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died at 56 due to myocardial infarction and his older brother at 65 due to stroke. His mother is 90 years old and healthy. Two of Mr. Alvarez's four adult children have been diagnosed with hypertension and one is a smoker. His youngest brother  who is currently 55  was recently diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Social History:  Residing in a rural area  Mr. Alvarez is a retired carpenter with an annual income below the federal poverty level. His wife of 45 years provides home care; they have four children and seven grandchildren. He does not drink alcohol and quit smoking a decade ago.  Current Situation:  Five months ago  during a routine examination for renal stones  an ultrasound incidentally noted an infra-renal AAA measuring 4 cm in diameter. Repeat imaging two months later suggested that the size had increased to 5.5 cm. After consultation with vascular surgery  plans were made for an elective endovascular repair.   Assessment:  Mr. Alvarez falls into the category of patients most likely to develop an AAA - male  over 65  history of smoking  hypertension  and a family history of AAA. The growth rate of his AAA is concerning  as it is now approaching the 5.5 cm diameter threshold for surgical intervention considering his symptomatic situation.   Plan:  A plan has been established for endovascular repair with continued monitoring post-operatively. Lifestyle modifications emphasizing blood pressure control  smoking cessation for his son  a healthy diet  and regular exercise have been recommended. We also stressed on the importance of regular follow-ups and screenings for his siblings and children considering the familial link in AAA.

Case Presentation:  Patient Bio:   The patient is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  residing in a suburban community near a metropolitan city in the United States. He is a retired construction worker and is currently living with his wife. The patient has a history of smoking approximately one pack a day for 40 years  but he quit about 15 years ago. He drinks alcohol occasionally. His diet is high in fat and low in fiber. He also leads a sedentary lifestyle with minimal exercise.   Past Medical History:   The patient's medical history includes an ongoing treatment for chronic hypertension. He also had undergone a coronary stent placement seven years ago for managing his ischemic heart disease. The patient is diabetic and has been prescribed metformin and insulin therapy. He has a BMI of 29  placing him in the overweight range. He has been taking statins for his hyperlipidemia.  Family History:  His father died from a suspected myocardial infarction at 76  and his mother passed away from stroke at the age of 80. His older brother had surgery for an abdominal aortic aneurysm five years ago.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient came to the Emergency Department with complaints of unrelenting  sharp abdominal and lower back pain for the past few hours. The pain was not associated with food intake or posture. There were no accompanying symptoms of nausea  vomiting  shortness of breath  or chest pain.  On examination  a pulsatile abdominal mass was palpated  and an abdominal bruit was heard on auscultation. The rest of the examination was unremarkable.  Diagnostic Evaluation:  Based on the history  clinical examination  and familial history  a high suspicion for an abdominal aortic aneurysm was put forward. Immediate CT angiography confirmed an infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm measuring 6.5 cm.  Management Plan:  Given the size of the aneurysm and the associated symptoms  urgent surgical intervention was decided upon discussion with the vascular surgeon. He was scheduled for an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR). The patient was also referred for a genetic counselling because of his family history of aortic aneurysms.  In the long term  emphasis will be given to managing his risk factors which include his hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and diabetes. A dietitian will provide nutritional guidance to help achieve a healthier weight and reduce his cardiovascular risk. Pneumococcal and annual influenza vaccinations are also recommended due to his smoking history.  This case is an example of how numerous lifestyle factors  previous medical conditions  and genetic predisposition can contribute to the development of serious cardiovascular diseases like abdominal aortic aneurysms. Comprehensive case management  addressing both the acute surgical need and the chronic health issues  becomes crucial in such patients.

Patient Presentation  Name: Mr. D Williams Age: 72 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Marital Status: Married Profession: Retired Engineer  Chief Complaint: Mr. Williams was referred for a routine check-up following a mildly concerning finding of a backache during his annual physical examination. The backache was felt in the abdominal region and lower back.  Past Medical History: He is a known case of Hypertension (HTN) and hyperlipidemia  both controlled with medication. Previously  he had an occurrence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) five years ago. Regular smoker for the past 40 years  consuming 15 cigarettes/day but quit two years ago. Limited alcohol consumption to social events only. No history of drug abuse. No known allergies.  Family History: His father had a history of coronary artery disease (CAD) and passed away at the age of 78 due to myocardial infarction. His elder brother has been recently diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Presenting Complaints: Unexplained lower back pain and mild abdominal discomfort for the past couple of weeks. No associated complaint of chest pain  shortness of breath  or loss of consciousness. Bowels and urination were normal.  Physical Examination: Vital signs stable. Aneurysm detected at abdominal aorta  through physical examination via palpation but no visible signs or pulsation.  Investigations: Abdominal Ultrasound revealed an enlarged abdominal aorta  with a diameter of 5.5 cm indicative of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). ECG and chest X-ray were normal.   Management: Mr. Williams was immediately referred to a vascular surgeon and a multi-disciplinary team (MDT) for further management. Following a detailed discussion  the team recommended high-intensity statin therapy to control his lipid levels and continued control of his blood pressure. Surgical intervention is contemplated as the aneurysm size is above the threshold of intervention (5.5 cm).   Follow-up: Mr. Williams is scheduled for a periodic follow-up every three months to monitor the size of the aneurysm  along with regular blood pressure and lipid profile checks.   This case demonstrates an instance of an abdominal aortic aneurysm in a patient with a history of HTN  hyperlipidemia  and a familial predisposition towards aneurysms and cardiovascular disease. Timely detection and intervention are crucial in such cases to avoid catastrophic outcomes such as rupture and death. Regular monitoring and maintenance of cardiovascular health are advised.

Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in a 72-Year-Old Hispanic Male  Patient Profile The patient  Mr. Alvarez  is a 72-year-old Hispanic male retired engineer  currently living with his spouse. He has been experiencing lower back pain and a pulsating feeling in his abdomen for the past few months. He is a non-smoker and moderate drinker  and he reported physical exercise of 150 minutes a week. He has a family history of coronary heart diseases (father died from heart attack) and cancer.  Past Medical History In terms of past medical history  Mr. Alvarez was diagnosed with hypertension five years ago and is currently being well managed with medication (lisinopril  20 mg daily). In the past  he has had benign prostate hyperplasia treated with terazosin. Furthermore  he suffered a mild stroke at the age of 65 with no significant residual effects. He also underwent a colonoscopy at 60 that found no abnormalities.  Presenting Condition Recently  Mr. Alvarez has been complaining of abdominal pain and discomfort  often describing this as a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. During a routine check-up  palpation of the abdominal region led to suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  which was later confirmed by a CT abdominal angiogram. The aneurysm was measured to be 5.5 cm in diameter. A high-resolution ultrasound further confirmed the diagnosis.  Family History There is a significant family history of cardiovascular diseases. Mr. Alvarez's father died from a heart attack at the age of 73 and his older brother had a myocardial infarction at 67. His mother had a long history of hypertension but lived to the age of 90. His sister has type II diabetes  and his maternal grandfather was reported to have died from an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Lifestyle Factors Mr. Alvarez has a moderately active lifestyle for his age. He walks for 30 minutes daily and practices yoga twice a week. His diet is largely Mediterranean  with a moderate intake of alcohol. Previously  he worked as a civil engineer  but since his retirement  he has been involved in volunteer work.  Indicated Diagnostic Tests Due to the size of the aneurysm and given the patient’s age and comorbidities  surgical intervention has been considered. After conferring with a consultant vascular surgeon  the patient was counseled for elective open surgery  considering his overall good health and active lifestyle.  Conclusion This report illustrates that abdominal aortic aneurysms  while typically asymptomatic until rupture  can at times present with non-specific symptoms such as lower back pain and a pulsating sensation in the abdomen. If a patient has a family history of AAA  this could potentially clue the clinician to the correct diagnosis. Moreover  the management of AAA depends on a variety of factors  including patient qualities and aneurysm characteristics  suggesting a personalized care approach.

Patient Information: Mr. Jacob Henderson is a 72-year-old African-American male residing in the Washington  D.C. area. He has been diagnosed with abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) after a routine physical examination.  Medical History: Mr. Henderson's past medical history includes hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and type II diabetes mellitus  all of which he has been managing diligently. He has been a smoker for the past 40 years but has quit smoking since the last five years. He has no known allergies. His other histories include cholecystectomy approximately 20 years ago and periodic bouts of bronchitis. Mr. Henderson has been on Metformin for diabetes  Lisinopril for hypertension  and Atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia. There are no records of previous surgeries or blood transfusions.  Family History: Mr. Henderson's father passed away due to AAA complications at the age of 76  and his older brother was known to have AAA but passed away in a car accident. He has two sons in their 40s with no known cardiovascular disease. His wife of 48 years passed away lately from ovarian cancer. Cancer's prevalence has been high in his family with his mother dying of breast cancer  and his younger sister is currently battling with colon cancer.  Clinical Presentation and Diagnosis: He presented to the clinic with complaints of vague  intermittent abdominal discomfort and lower back pain for the past two months. No symptoms of syncope  chest pain  or shortness of breath were noted. Physical examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the abdomen. Further radiological assessments through an abdominal ultrasound confirmed the diagnosis of AAA with a diameter of 5.4cm.  Management & Follow-Up Plan: Given the size of the aneurysm and the associated risk factors  vascular surgical consultation recommended for considering possible surgical intervention. Smoking cessation  strict glycemic control  lipid control  and blood pressure management are critical. A follow-up appointment has been scheduled within four weeks to discuss the option of endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) or traditional open repair  with consideration to Mr. Henderson's comorbid conditions and personal preference.  Demographics: The prevalence of AAA in the general population is 4-8%  primarily affecting men over 65 who have a history of smoking. African American ethnicity is  on average  less frequently associated with AAA compared to the Caucasian population but in this case  genetic predisposition can be inferred from the familial history of the disease.  Discussion: Management of AAA requires a comprehensive approach that includes careful consideration of risk factors  symptoms  aneurysm size  and patient preference. Early detection and timely therapeutic interventions are key to prevent catastrophic outcomes such as aneurysm rupture. Furthermore  lifestyle modification measures  including smoking cessation  management of diabetes  and hypertension  are also crucial.

Patient Presentation  Demographics: Mr. A. B. C.  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  has presented to the clinic with discomfort in his lower back and abdomen. Driven by his profession as a truck driver  the patient has a history of sedentary lifestyle and has been a habitual smoker for 45 years  further augmented by a poor diet leading to obesity (BMI: 31.5)  Past Medical History: The patient has a known history of hypertension and high cholesterol  for which he has been on treatment for the last 10 years. He also has a history of coronary artery disease  and underwent angioplasty 3 years ago. Mr. A. has never been diagnosed with any form of aneurysm previously. There are no known allergies  and he doesn't consume alcohol.  Family History: The patient’s father passed away at the age of 69 due to heart failure  and his mother had a stroke at 72 but is currently alive. His only sibling  an elder brother  was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at age 70 but was managed successfully.   Present Complaint: The patient expresses symptoms of non-radiating pain in his lower back and the middle and lower region of his abdomen  worsening over the last week. He mentions that the pain is not associated with food intake. He further reported the feeling of a pulsatile mass in his abdomen.   Physical Examination: Patient vitals at rest were in the normal range; BP: 131/87 mmHg  HR: 78/minute  RR: 16/minute  and Temp: 37.1°C. Physical examination revealed a pulsatile abdominal mass  and there was visible abdomen distension.   Investigations: In light of the patient’s symptoms  a diagnostic CT angiogram was ordered  which confirmed the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm of approximately 5.2 cm with no sign of rupture.  Conclusion: Given the size of the aneurysm (more than 5 cm)  the patient’s current symptoms  and the potential risk of rupture  surgical intervention was deemed appropriate to treat this patient's AAA. The patient has been referred to a vascular surgeon for further course of action. He has also been advised to quit smoking  to follow a balanced diet  and to exercise regularly to maintain a healthy body weight  as these lifestyle changes will also contribute to the overall management of his AAA and other comorbidities.

Patient Profile:  Name: John Smith Age: 70 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Location: Texas  USA  Presenting Issue:  Mr. Smith has been referred for assessment to investigate a non-specific  pulsating abdominal pain that he has been experiencing intermittently for six months. The pain can last for several hours and seems to be unrelated to meals or activity levels. He is also suffering from unintentional weight loss and decreased appetite.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia and he is a former smoker. He was diagnosed with COPD 10 years ago. He controlled his hypertension and hypercholesterolemia through oral medication and a healthy diet. He quit smoking after his diagnosis of COPD.  Current Medications:   Antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering drugs  with an inhaler for the management of his COPD.  Family History:  The patient's father died from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at 72. Further  his maternal uncle also had an AAA.  Investigations:  Ultrasound scan confirmed a 5.5cm diameter AAA with no evidence of rupture.  Diagnosis:  Based on the ultrasound results  his medical history  family history and presenting symptoms  Mr. Smith has been diagnosed with an asymptomatic abdominal aortic aneurysm which is at a high risk of rupture.  Management Plan:  Being a high-risk case  Mr. Smith is referred to vascular surgery for AAA repair. Preoperative assessment will be initiated including detailed cardiovascular evaluation given his hypertension and hypercholesterolemia history.  Patient Education:  The patient has been educated regarding his condition  the risk of rupture  and the benefits and potential complications of surgery. He has also been advised to notify immediately if he experiences sudden onset severe abdominal or back pain  which could be indicative of an aneurysm rupture.  Follow-up:  Postoperative follow-up plan includes monitoring for complications  managing cardiovascular risk factors  promoting a healthy lifestyle  and regular surveillance imaging to monitor for AAA recurrence or other vascular disease.  This case has been anonymized and does not reflect any specific individual's history.

Patient Information: Mr. Johnson  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presented to the hospital reporting severe abdominal pain that intermittently radiates to his lower back. Mr. Johnson is a retired firefighter and lives with his wife in an urban city in the U.S. He has a history of heavy smoking but quit five years ago. The patient's body mass index is stable at 26  and he maintains a relatively active lifestyle. Apart from his hypertension diagnosis five years ago  he has been generally in good health.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Johnson was initially seen at an urgent care clinic four days ago  complaining of persistent abdominal discomfort. The pain  which he described as 'ripping' in character  has become progressively worse. He denies any associated symptoms such as vomiting  fever  or changes in bowel or bladder habits.  Past Medical History: He has a known history of hypertension  has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years  and drinks alcohol occasionally. No known allergies have been recorded. Regarding medical history  Mr. Johnson has been hospitalized once in the past for a minor heart attack at age 68.  Family History: His father died at the age of 64 due to a myocardial infarction  and his mother died at 69 from complications related to diabetes. There is no known family history of aneurysms.  Physical Examination: On examination  he appeared anxious and his abdominal pain seemed to intensify when lying flat on his back. His vitals were: Blood pressure - 146/90 mmHg  Pulse - 98 beats/min  Respiratory rate - 20 breaths/min  Oxygen saturation - 97% on room air  and Temperature - 37.2°C. Abdominal examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the periumbilical area.  Investigations: Lab tests showed a mild leukocytosis. His chest x-ray and electrocardiogram were normal. An abdominal ultrasound  followed by a CT angiogram  confirmed the presence of a 5.5 cm infrarenal abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Management Plan: The patient was urgently referred to the vascular surgery team due to the size of the aneurysm. After detailed discussion with the surgeon  open repair of the aneurysm was planned. His family was involved in the decision-making process to ensure patient-centric care  understanding the risks and benefits associated with surgery.  Outcome: The surgery was successful without any complications. He was monitored in the surgical intensive care unit (ICU) for close observation. After the surgery  the patient underwent a smoking cessation and rehabilitation program as well. Mr. Johnson was discharged in a stable condition after 11 days.  Follow-up: Regular follow-up appointments and ultrasound monitoring have been organized to monitor for possible complications  such as aneurysm expansion or leak. Medications for his hypertension were adjusted  and he was advised on a low sodium and cholesterol diet  along with regular exercise  to maintain a healthy lifestyle and to prevent further vascular issues.   Patient Education: Outlined the importance of lifestyle changes including smoking cessation  diet modifications  and regular exercise. Reviewed signs and symptoms to be vigilant for  such as sudden severe pain in the abdomen or back  or changes in urination habits.

Patient Presentation  Patient Description:   The patient is a 72-year-old White male  retired  who lives with his wife. He has two adult children with families of their own.   Presenting Complaint:   He complains of persistent abdominal pain  sporadic lower back discomfort  and fatigue.  History of Present Illness:   The patient mentions that the onset of abdominal pain occurred about three weeks ago  starting as a dull ache in the lower abdomen which gradually became more intense. The discomfort to his lower back is mainly only felt when standing for prolonged periods. He also reports feeling fatigue and shortness of breath during the last few days. However  There's no palpable abdominal mass. There is no history of trauma. No associated fever  chills  chest pain  or weight loss.  Past Medical History:   His past medical history is significant for hypertension and high cholesterol levels for which he has been on medication for many years. The patient also has a history of smoking  with a 50 pack-year  but he quit about 10 years ago. The patient doesn't have any known allergies.  Family History:  He reveals that his father suffered an abdominal aortic aneurysm at age 75 and he has a brother suffering from peripheral vascular disease. The patient doesn't have any family history of kidney disease or any other major systemic diseases.  Investigations:  Physical examination showed regular heart rate and rhythm with no evidence of acute distress. Abdominal examination revealed a mild tenderness in the lower abdomen with no palpable pulsatile mass but with good femoral pulses bilaterally.
