Laboratory tests were within normal limits except for elevated cholesterol levels.   Upon further assessment using ultrasound imaging  an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) of about 5.6 cm was detected. The patient was then referred to a vascular surgeon for further evaluation and surgical intervention considering his age and the size of the aneurysm.  Discussion:   In this case  the patient's history of smoking  hypertension  high blood cholesterol  and family history of AAA and peripheral vascular disease places him at high risk for developing an AAA. Early detection  surgical intervention  and the control of risk factors are crucial in preventing fatal ruptures. Patient education on the importance of regular follow-up  monitoring of aneurysm size  and control of hypertension and cholesterol is also key in managing this condition.   In light of the patient's history and the current prognosis  the vascular surgeon has recommended an endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) considering its low perioperative risk and recovery period. His family has been supportive and compliant with the medical advice given so far and the patient has agreed to move forward with the treatment plan.

Subject: An 70-year-old Male Diagnosed with an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  1. Demographics:  The patient is an unmarried 70-year-old male of Hispanic ethnicity. He retired from his job as a construction worker five years ago. He is a long-time smoker with a 50-pack-year history  has chronic hypertension and high cholesterol  but does not have a personal or family history of heart disease. He is currently living with his sister.  2. Past and Present History: The patient has a history of two significant health issues: hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He has been taking Losartan 50 mg and Atorvastatin 20 mg for the last seven years  and his blood pressure and cholesterol levels have been controlled within acceptable limits. He was also diagnosed with COPD  attributed to his long history of smoking  five years ago  for which he uses inhaled corticosteroids.  3. Current Presentation: The patient presented with a complaint of gradual onset  unrelenting sharp abdominal and back pain which he rates as an 8 on a scale of 1-10. He stated that the pain began two days prior and has been steadily worsening. He doesn't recall any precipitating event or injury. The patient reported feeling a ""pulsating"" sensation in his abdomen  and states that the pain seems unassociated with food or position.  4. Family History: There's no reported family history of heart diseases or aneurysms. The patient's father lived until 82 and died of a stroke; his mother lived until 78 and passed away due to lung cancer. He has two siblings  a younger brother with diabetes and an elder sister with rheumatoid arthritis.   5. Professional Considerations: The patient's age  ethnicity (Hispanic)  gender (male)  smoking history  and hypertension are all common risk factors associated with abdominal aortic aneurysm. Older age  male sex  and history of smoking are reported as significant risk factors for AAA as found in various pieces of literature.  6. Diagnostic Procedures & Results: Upon physical examination  the doctor identified a pulsatile abdominal mass. The occurrence of intense abdominal pain along with the presence of this mass raised the suspicion of a rupturing AAA  which was then confirmed through a computed tomography angiogram (CTA). The CTA also revealed that the AAA's diameter is 7.5cm.  In alignment with the demographics found in the literature  this case shows that men  particularly those who have smoked  have hypertension  and are of an advanced age  are more likely to suffer from an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The lack of family history does not rule out the risk factor  as primarily  AAA involves the interplay between genetic predisposition and environmental exposure. In any patient with this demographic profile and these symptoms  AAA should be a consideration in differential diagnosis.

Patient Information: Mr. James A.  a 70-year-old Caucasian male.  Chief Complaint: “Rapid and intense pain in my lower back and abdomen.”  History of Present Illness: The patient has been experiencing intermittent abdominal pain for the past month  which has suddenly escalated today. Accompanying symptoms include fainting  rapid pulse  excessive sweatiness  and pallor. Unknown history of past similar instances.  Medical History: Diagnosed with hypertension 10 years ago  managed by medications. Has a five-year history of high cholesterol  treated by diet modification and statin medications. Smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 35 years  stopped smoking 5 years ago. Had a minor heart attack at the age of 65  treated by stenting. No known drug allergies.  Medications: Lisinopril 10 mg daily  Lipitor 20 mg daily  aspirin 81 mg daily  Metoprolol 25 mg twice daily.  Family History: Father died from a heart attack at 68  mother passed away due to complications from diabetes at 72. One older brother with a history of hypertension and another older brother  who had a stroke at age 73.   Physical Exam: Pale  anxious older man. He is tender in the middle and lower abdomen  no scars were noticed. BP 90/60 mmHg  pulse 120  respirations 24  temperature 37.3°C.  Investigations: CT angiography of the abdomen was performed showing a large abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) measuring 5.5 cm.  Assessment & Plan: The patient was diagnosed with a potentially ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm apparent from his history  physical examination  and CT findings. Considering patient's age  co-morbidities; history of smoking  hypertension  high cholesterol  and family history of cardiovascular diseases increased his risk for AAA. Plans are in place for an immediate referral to a vascular surgeon for emergent repair. IV fluid resuscitation was initiated in the ER along with strict monitoring of blood pressure and heart rate.   Follow-up/Prognosis: Management of AAA generally includes surgery  with regular follow-ups. Controlling blood pressure will be important in this patient's post-operative stage to reduce the risk of complications. His prognosis depends on his surgical outcome  control of his chronic conditions and lifestyle changes  including maintaining a heart-healthy diet  appropriate physical activity  and continued abstinence from smoking.   This case demonstrates the classic presentation of an abdominal aortic aneurysm that could be complicated by rupture in a patient with significant risk factors as supported by literature. Urgent intervention is crucial in these cases given the high mortality risk. Regular follow-up and strict control of his medical conditions can improve his prognosis.

Case Subject: Mr. George Johnson  Demographics:  Mr. Johnson is a 69-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired construction worker  married  with three grown children. He is a lifelong resident of a rural area where he enjoys outdoor activities like fishing and gardening. He’s had a history of heavy smoking (30 pack years  quit 15 years ago) and has been diagnosed with hypertension for the last 20 years  controlled by medication.  Presenting Symptoms: Mr. Johnson visited his primary health care provider reporting a persistent lower back pain  occasional abdominal pain  and unexplained fatigue for the past month. He described the pain as a dull ache  more noticeable when he’s been motioning or after heavy meals. He also mentioned recent unexplained weight loss.  Past Medical History: - Hypertension (Diagnosed 20 years ago)  managed with a calcium channel blocker - Former heavy smoker ((30 pack years  quit 15 years ago) - No history of diabetes or high cholesterol - No known family history of cardiovascular disease or abdominal aortic aneurysm - A clearance of colorectal cancer through colonoscopy five years prior - Last annual check-up showed normal results  Physical Findings: On general examination  Mr. Johnson had a blood pressure of 145/85 mm Hg and resting pulse rate of 68 bpm. A palpable pulsatile mass in the central abdomen was felt on physical examination. No peripheral edema or clubbing noted. The rest of the systemic examination was unremarkable.   Given the demographic background  past medical history  and presenting complaints  an abdominal aortic aneurysm stands as a potential diagnosis for this case. Further diagnostic tests  including ultrasound or CT scan  would be recommended to confirm the presence of the aneurysm and assess its size and risk of rupture.   This case is designed with a patient profile that matches the typical risk factors for an abdominal aortic aneurysm as found in medical literature—being over the age of 65  male  a former smoker  and having hypertension. This case presentation is built to enhance disease understanding and management for medical students  underlining the importance of a thorough evaluation for patients presenting with non-specific symptoms like unexplained back or abdominal pain.

Patient Information: Name: X  Gender: Male Age: 72 years  Background:  Mr. X is a 72-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired dockyard worker and a former smoker having quit 10 years ago. He has been moderately alcohol dependent for the past 30 years and consumes a diet rich in fast foods and red meat.  Past Medical History: The primary complaints from Mr. X include a long-standing history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He was diagnosed with type-2 diabetes mellitus 5 years ago. Also  he was diagnosed and treated for peripheral artery disease around 3 years back. His father suffered from an abdominal aortic aneurysm at 69 years old but survived after emergency surgery.  Presenting Complaints: In recent weeks  Mr. X has been experiencing an increasing frequency of dull  vague abdominal pain typically in the midabdominal region. The pain can get severe and radiate towards the lower back. He has been feeling full sooner than usual while eating and has unexplained weight loss. This is accompanied by pulses that feel more prominent than usual in the abdominal area. Also  he complains of general lethargy and anxiety.   Note - The abdominal aortic aneurysm prevalence is highest in elderly Caucasian males. Risk factors include a history of smoking  alcohol use  a diet high in fat  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and a family history of aortic aneurysms. Quick identification and treatment of the condition can prevent serious complications. This case is designed to train students to recognize these risk factors and symptoms leading to early diagnosis.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  Mr. John Doe  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  presented in the health facility accompanied by his son.  Past Medical History:  The patient has been previously treated for hypertension and high cholesterol. He was a smoker but he managed to quit 10 years ago. His father died of an aortic aneurysm rupture at the age of 75.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Doe has been experiencing a strange sensation of pain in his lower back that radiates to his abdomen and groin  which has been increasing in intensity over the last few weeks. Associated symptoms include a constant feeling of fullness in the abdomen  occasional abdominal pain  and bouts of nausea. He denies bowel or urinary changes  chest pain  or any recent illness or injury. He also reported feeling lightheaded at times and was recommended to visit the hospital by his general practitioner after palpating a mass during a routine health checkup.  Importance:  Abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is a condition seen more frequently in the elderly  predominantly amongst males and smokers. Risk factors for Mr. Doe include advanced age  male sex  previous smoking habits  a history of high blood pressure and cholesterol  and his father's history of AAA. His back pain and other symptoms align with the clinical features of AAA  typically caused by the aneurysm pressing on surrounding structures. In some studies  the demographic pattern in the occurrence of the disease has been linked to age  race  and family history of the disease  thus it would be important to address the potential genetic susceptibility  lifestyle  and co-morbidity influences. AAA rupture is a significant cause of mortality  which makes early diagnosis and management essential. This case should form part of a comprehensive training material for medical students providing relevant insights into demographics  history taking  symptom presentation  and the importance of physical examination.   This report has sought to align with literature-based evidence to present an accurate representation of a typical patient case with abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Profile Name: Robert D. Age: 65 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired mechanic Location: San Francisco  California  Previous Medical History Robert has a history of high blood pressure managed with medication  hyperlipidemia and a 30 pack-year tobacco use history. The patient quit smoking ten years ago. His mother suffered from cardiovascular disease and died of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Presenting Complaints Robert presented to his general practitioner complaining of intermittent  non-radiating abdominal pain  which has progressively worsened over the past few weeks. He describes the pain as a deep  gnawing feeling in his stomach that seems to intensify after consuming a meal or when laying flat. It sometimes wakes him up at night. He has also noticed an increase in the frequency of urination.   He reported a noticeable weight loss  decreased appetite  and feeling fatigued in the past month. There aren't any associated symptoms like vomiting  changes in bowel movements  fever  or bloating.  Physical examination revealed a pulsatile mass in the abdomen.   This case report is representative of the typical presentation of abdominal aortic aneurysm  as most patients are asymptomatic until rupture occurs. When symptoms do occur  they often involve abdominal or back pain and/or a palpable pulsatile abdominal mass  as in this case.   The demographics represented here  including age (greater than 60)  sex (male)  race (Caucasian)  and history of smoking  are all significant risk factors for development of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Additionally familial history of AAA also increases the risk. This makes the case extremely educational in displaying the typical AAA patient profile.   It will be important for students to take away the critical nature of early detection and management of these aneurysms to prevent rupture  which carries a high mortality rate.

Case Report for Medical Students:  Patient Demographics:   -  The patient is an 82-year-old Caucasian male with a body mass index (BMI) of 25 kg/m2. - He is a retired engineer  a widower  living alone with regular visits from his two grown-up children. - He is a 40 pack year smoker  consuming one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years  but quit smoking 15 years ago.  Past Medical History:  - The patient has a history of moderate hypertension controlled with beta-blockers for the last 15 years.  - He also has hyperlipidemia managed with statin medications. - He had an episode of a transient ischemic attack (TIA) without significant consequences six years back. - He had minimal alcohol intake and no noteworthy allergies.  Key Complaints:  - The patient reports a vague constant lower abdominal pain over the last two days  increasing steadily in severity. - He feels a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. - He denies any associated nausea  vomiting  changes in bowel movements  urological symptoms  chest pain  or fever. - He tells a concerning story of feeling slightly light-headed while walking from his bedroom to the kitchen this morning. - He also reports unintentional weight loss and decreased appetite in the past few months  but no night sweats.  Reason for this Demographic:  Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm primarily affects men over 65 years  often related to smoking and atherosclerosis. It is more common in Caucasian ethnicity and individuals with a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Consequently  an octogenarian with a significant smoking history and vascular comorbidities is a relatively typical representation. The symptomatology illustrated in the case is suggestive though nonspecific; this aims at inciting students to reason diagnostic possibilities and not take symptoms at face value  emphasizing the importance of a complete physical examination for accurate diagnosis.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Details: - Name: Mr. Edward White - Age: 70 years old - Sex: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian  - Occupation: Retired Engineer - Marital Status: Married   Past Medical History: - Continuous smoker for 40 years  recently quit two years back. - Hypertension controlled with medication for the past 10 years. - Type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 8 years ago. - No known allergies. - Family history of cardiovascular disease; father had a myocardial infarction in his mid-sixties.  Key Complaints:  Mr. White presents to the emergency department with lower back pain and abdominal pain that he rates as 8/10 on the pain scale. He describes the pain as severe and steady  having been present for the past 2 days  and not relieved with over-the-counter pain medication.  Note: Abdominal aortic aneurysm is a dilatation of the aorta  most commonly found in the elderly Caucasian males and is highly correlated with a history of smoking and hypertension. It tends to be asymptomatic until rupture  which can lead to a life-threatening situation. In this case  this elderly Caucasian male with a smoking history who presents with severe back and abdominal pain could potentially have an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further assessment must be carried out to confirm this and provide urgent treatment as needed.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Patient Name: Mr. James Smith Age: 68 Years Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Engineer Residential Location: Urban Area  Past Medical History: - Hypertension for the past 15 years  on antihypertensives - Ex-smoker  quit smoking 10 years ago after approximately 30 packs per year history - No history of Cardiovascular Diseases  although a family history of AAA in father - No known diabetes or hyperlipidemia  Chief Complaints: - Intermittent  dull pain in the lower back and abdomen for the last 3 months - The pain is non-radiating and does not change with movement or position - Episodes of pain lasting from minutes to hours  with period of respite in-between - Recent unexplained weight loss - No other changes in bowel or bladder habits  Note: The patient profile represents a typical AAA patient. Majority of people diagnosed are males above 65 years with history of smoking and hypertension. Literature suggests that white populations have a higher AAA prevalence compared to other racial and ethnic groups. While most AAA cases are asymptomatic and might be found incidentally  some patients might present with nonspecific symptoms like abdominal or back pain mimicking other common conditions in older adults.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Demographics: Robert is a 69-year-old Caucasian male  a retired truck driver living with his wife in a small rural town. He has moderate socioeconomic status  is a former heavy smoker who quit 15 years ago  and has a history of mild alcohol use.  Past Medical History: Robert has a medical history significant for hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and Type 2 diabetes mellitus - all moderately controlled with medications. He also has a family history of cardiovascular disease  with his father dying of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) rupture at the age of 72.  Key Complaints: Robert attended his annual check-up with his primary care physician  reporting no specific complaints. However  he expressed concerns about his familial history of AAA. On direct questioning  he reported occasional lower back pain and some vague  mild discomfort in his abdomen  which he attributed to his age and occasional gastritis. Despite downplaying his symptoms  the chronicity and characteristics of the pain roused suspicion.  Narrative: In alignment with the USPSTF (U.S. Preventive Services Task Force) recommendation considering his age  male gender  and history of smoking  Robert underwent an abdominal ultrasound as a preventative screening for AAA. The ultrasound revealed an infrarenal aortic aneurysm measuring 5.6 cm.  Clinical Significance: AAAs are most commonly found in Caucasian males  over the age of 65 with a history of smoking. Often asymptomatic  they are usually detected incidentally or during screening for high-risk individuals. Symptoms can vary from abdominal and lower back pain to signs of rupture  which include severe pain and hypotension. The significant risk is aneurysm rupture  which can be life-threatening  hence early detection and appropriate management is vital. This case emphasizes the importance of a sobering clinical history and proactive healthcare in high-risk individuals.    Objective: The purpose of this case is to educate medical students and trainees on the risk factors  symptomatology  screening guidelines  and management of abdominal aortic aneurysms. This training case also illustrates the importance of preventative healthcare  especially in high-risk patients with a significant family history.

Case Summary:  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 69-year-old Caucasian male  who is retired and used to work as a firefighter. He is a former smoker with a 40-pack year history  though he quit smoking about 15 years ago. He is a social drinker and denies any substance abuse. He is overweight (BMI 28) but does not follow any regular physical activity.  Past Medical History: Primary hypertension well-controlled on medications. He has a 15-year history of hyperlipidemia and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He also underwent an appendectomy in his early 30s and was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease two years ago.  Patient Presentation and Key Complaints: The patient came to the emergency department with a chief complaint of severe abdominal pain that began suddenly earlier in the day. The pain is not related to meals  no radiation  and has not been changed by any means (e.g.  position change  food intake  etc.). He also reports feeling a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. On further questioning  he also has been feeling mild chronic back pain for a few months but attributed it to his old age.  The patient needs to be evaluated carefully since his age  sex  smoking history  and personal history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  and peripheral artery disease put him at a higher risk for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). According to the literature  Caucasian males over 65 years old who have ever smoked are at a higher risk  with the risk also increasing with age. Plus  the presence of an unspecified abdominal or back pain accompanied by a pulsating sensation could be indicative of AAA  needing a thorough clinical and imaging investigations to rule out a ruptured or impending rupture AAA situation.

Case Report: John Doe  a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a history of heavy smoking (30-pack years)  longstanding hypertension  and hyperlipidemia  presents to the general physician's office with complaints of vague constant abdominal and lower back pain that has increased in intensity over the past week. The pain is described as a dull ache with intermittent but brief episodes of sudden sharp pains. The patient also complains of moderate unexplained weight loss and decreased appetite over the past couple of months.   John's past medical records reveal poor compliance with his antihypertensive and cholesterol-lowering medications. While not diagnosed  John reports symptoms suggestive of claudication with pain in his legs and thighs  especially after walking  indicating possible peripheral artery disease  which he has largely ignored. His family history is significant for cardiovascular diseases  including an elder brother who underwent an operation for abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 70 years. There is no history of any allergies. John is a retired truck driver  widowed  living alone with his pet dog; he reports occasional consumption of alcohol.  The above scenario is representative of the typical risk factors for abdominal aortic aneurysms  primarily older age  being male  being of Caucasian ethnicity  smoking  hypertension  and a family history of the condition. Suboptimal compliance to medication and potential co-morbidity of peripheral artery disease add additional context and complexity to the case.  The symptoms presented in this case  including unexplained abdominal/back pain  weight loss and decreased appetite  are not directly indicative but are seen in some patients with an advanced abdominal aortic aneurysm. Remember  most abdominal aortic aneurysms are asymptomatic  and often discovered coincidentally during imaging for other conditions. However  it is also important for medical students to recognize this rare presentation.

Patient Case Report:  Name: Mr. John Hamish Age: 66 years old Sex: Male Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired military officer  Past Medical History: Mr. Hamish has a history of hypertension for the past 10 years  controlled with antihypertensive medication. He is also a former smoker  having quit about 15 years ago but with a 30 pack-year history. He was diagnosed with high cholesterol levels ten years ago  and he has been on statin therapy since. He has a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysms as his father died suddenly due to a ruptured aortic aneurysm at age 72.  Present Complaint: Mr. Hamish visited the Emergency Department complaining of sudden onset severe abdominal pain for the past 4-5 hours. He described the pain as being in the middle of his abdomen extending towards his back  and rated it as 8 out of 10 on the pain scale. He also reported of light-headedness and a sense of 'passing out'.   These findings are indicative of a possible abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). He is at a high risk considering his age  male sex  and family history of AAA. This is also aligned with the demographic data which indicates AAA is most commonly seen in Caucasian men aged over 65 years  who have a history of hypertension  smoking  high cholesterol  and a familial history of the disease.   Additional details: Physical examination  Radiologic investigations (like Ultrasound  CT Scan)  and other diagnostic tests should be carried out to reach a definitive diagnosis.

Case Study: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile: - Name: Mr. Harrison - Age: 71 years - Gender: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired former truck driver - Insurance: Medicare  Chief Complaint: Mr. Harrison presents complaints of intermittent  persistent abdominal pain radiating to his lower back  with a slight feeling of fullness. He describes the pain as a deep  boring pain that doesn't change with positioning. Initially dismissed the discomfort as potential indigestion or age-related issues  but it has progressively worsened over the last month.  Past Medical History: Mr. Harrison has been previously diagnosed with hypertension  which he manages with a calcium channel blocker (Norvasc). He has also been diagnosed with hyperlipidemia for which he takes statins. He smoked heavily for 30 years but quit 10 years ago.   Family History: His father died of a heart attack at 67 years and his brother had a stroke at the age of 72. Neither parent nor siblings had a history of aneurysm.  He lives by himself since his wife passed away 2 years ago. They have 2 adult children residing in different cities. Limited physical activity; walks his dog daily for exercise.  Review of Systems: - General: Febrile  but denies recent weight loss - Cardiovascular: Occasional tachycardia  no murmurs - Respiratory: No cough  wheeze  or shortness of breath - Gastrointestinal: No nausea  vomiting  or change in bowel habits - Genitourinary: No change in urinary habits - Musculoskeletal: Lower back pain along with abdominal pain - Neurological: No weakness or numbness in extremities  no difficulty with balance  Conclusion:  Given the history of smoking  hypertension  age and the symptoms - the differential should include abdominal aortic aneurysm. This case is designed to reflect the demographic (older  male  Caucasian) which is most commonly affected by AAA (abdominal aortic aneurysm)  as well as common risk factors such as history of smoking and hypertension.  Next steps involve further investigation to confirm or rule out the diagnosis and  if confirmed  evaluate the size and risk of rupture. This case provides an opportunity to discuss the management of the condition  the role of patient lifestyle modification  and potential surgical treatments.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: Mr. John Smith is a 67-year-old Caucasian male with a height of 5'11"" and a weight of 210 pounds. He is a retired truck driver and lives with his wife in a rural area. He has been a two-pack a day smoker for the past 45 years.   Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a known history of high blood pressure and hyperlipidemia  for which he has been prescribed antihypertensive medication (lisinopril) and a statin (atorvastatin) respectively. He struggles with compliance and regularly forgets to take his medication. He reports minimal physical activity and a diet high in fat and low in vegetables. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died of a heart attack at age 62.  Key Complaints: Mr. Smith presented to the emergency department with sudden onset  severe pain in the lower abdomen and lower back that began while having dinner. He described the pain as ""tearing"" and feels it radiating down to his groin. Along with this  he reported feelings of light-headedness  a rapid heart rate  and clammy skin. He denied any nausea  vomiting  diarrhea  urinary symptoms or trauma to the area. His wife noted that he looked pale and seemed more fatigued than usual.  Assessment: Mr. Smith vital signs were as follows: blood pressure 155/92 mm Hg  heart rate 112 beats per minute  respiratory rate 21 breaths per minute  temperature 37.5'C  and oxygen saturation 96%.  Notes for Education: This case was chosen due to the high incidence of abdominal aortic aneurysms in Caucasian males above 65 years of age  notably those with a smoking history and hypertension. Clinical manifestations of an abdominal aortic aneurysm often include sudden onset severe pain  hypovolemic shock due to rupture  or incidental findings in an imaging study. Immediate surgical intervention becomes necessary when an AAA ruptures. Signs of free rupture include severe back or abdominal pain that radiates to the groin  signs of shock  and a pulsatile abdominal mass. Symptoms of contained rupture are similar but can also include a vague or throbbing abdominal or flank pain. Therefore  in the presence of high clinical suspicion  patients such as Mr. Smith should be immediately evaluated via ultrasound or CT.

Case Study: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Patient Information:   Mr. Johnson  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  married with three children  presented to the clinic. He is a former smoker (stopped 10 years ago after a 30 pack-year history) and drinks alcohol socially.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a history of mild hypertension  for which he is currently taking amlodipine. He regularly visits the clinic for check-ups  the last one being six months ago. Also  there is a family history of cardiovascular disease - his father died of an AAA rupture at age 72.  Key Complaints:  Over the past few weeks  he has been experiencing recurrent episodes of dull  radiating pain in the lower back and abdominal area. Additionally  he has felt an unusual pulsating sensation in his abdomen  which prompted his visit. He denies any changes in eating habits  bowel movements  traumatic injury  or urinary complaints. His wife has noticed that he has been more fatigued than usual.  Review of this case is critical as AAA often remains asymptomatic until rupture. Prevalence of AAA is highest in older Caucasian male individuals  especially those with a history of smoking  hypertension  and family history of the disease. This case is designed to give students an update on the potentially fatal vascular condition  highlighting the necessity for early recognition and management  particularly in high-risk demographics as noted in literature.

Patient Information: Mr. John Doe  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retiree  residing in an urban setting. The patient's primary language is English. He is a former smoker  having quit 10 years ago but had a 30-year history of smoking two packs a day.  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a history of hypertension diagnosed 15 years ago  moderately managed with medication. He has hyperlipidemia treated with statins. He also suffers from mild obesity (BMI=30.5). His father died of an aortic aneurysm at 75 years old.  Chief complaints: Mr. Doe presents with intermittent abdominal pain over the last week  describing it as a deep  gnawing pain that does not radiate elsewhere. He also reports occasional lower back pain and a sensation of fullness in his abdomen. He denies any recent changes in bowel habits  weight loss  or changes in appetite. He mentions feeling slightly lightheaded on a couple of occasions but hasn't faced any fainting episode.  These demographics and history are consistent with literature stating abdominal aortic aneurysm predominantly affects older males and is associated with factors such as smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and family history of aortic aneurysms. Being a former smoker and having hypertension and hyperlipidemia put Mr. Doe in a high-risk category. He also has a significant family history with his father's sudden death due to an aortic aneurysm.  This vignette offers medical trainees the opportunity to explore potential differential diagnoses  including  but not limited to  abdominal aortic aneurysm - which requires immediate attention considering his clinical history and presentation.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient initials: J.M. Age: 72 years Sex: Male Race: Caucasian/White  Occupation: Retired Past medical history: Smoker  uncontrolled hypertension  hyperlipidemia  history of peripheral arterial disease Family history: Father died due to ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm  Chief complaints: J.M.  an elderly Caucasian male  presents with vague abdominal pain that he has been noticing for the past 3 months. The pain is episodic  located in the lower back region  and often radiates to his groin. He also reports an occasional sensation of fullness in the lower abdomen. J.M. further complaints that he has lost about 10lbs in the last 2 months without attempting to. He remarks that he is a long-term smoker and that he experiences persistent uncontrolled hypertension despite regular medication. J.M. gives a history of peripheral arterial disease and has a familial history of abdominal aortic aneurysm which led to his father's death.   This case represents a classic presentation of abdominal aortic aneurysm. Predominantly  it affects the elderly male population  particularly those with risk factors such as smoking and uncontrolled hypertension. Asserting the importance of this fact  abdominal aortic aneurysm is the 13th leading cause of death in the U.S. among men aged 55 and older. The patient's familial history of abdominal aortic aneurysm increases his risk  emphasizing the need for regular screening and evaluation in such cases.   Objective: The trainee should be able to identify the symptoms and risk factors associated with abdominal aortic aneurysm  suggest relevant investigations  and plan an appropriate course of treatment in consultation with a vascular surgeon.   Critical thinking and problem-solving skills should be employed to evaluate the aggravated risk factor due to his familial history  and the role of smoking cessation  blood pressure control  and statin therapy in the management of abdominal aortic aneurysm should be emphasized.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Information Name: John Doe Age: 70 years  Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired military officer Source of referral: Self-referred  History Past Medical History: Hypertension for which he has been taking antihypertensive medications for the past 10 years. Noninsulin-dependent diabetes mellitus diagnosed 5 years ago  under control with oral antidiabetic medication. History of tobacco use  although he quit smoking 15 years ago.  Family History: Father died of myocardial infarction in his 60s.   Presenting Complaint John Doe presents with a history of intermittent  dull abdominal pain for the past few weeks  which he initially thought to be due to gastritis. Moreover  he experienced sudden  sharp lower back pain going into his groin today  prompting him to visit the hospital.   Reasons for Representation Data shows that Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  while it can occur in both genders  are most commonly found in males  particularly those of Caucasian ethnicity  like John Doe. Older age is also a risk factor  making a 70-year-old a fitting demographic. John's past medical history factors such as hypertension and a history of smoking are notable risk factors for AAA. His complaint of a dull abdominal pain progressing into severe back pain is indicative of a potentially rupturing AAA  a surgical emergency.   Take Home Message for the Students Abdominal aortic aneurysm may exhibit no symptoms until it's nearly ruptured. Therefore  it's important to consider it in the differential diagnoses in elderly male patients  particularly Caucasians  presenting with abdominal or back pain. Risk factors such as age  male sex  hypertension  smoking history  and atherosclerosis can predispose patients to AAA. It's crucial to promptly evaluate and manage these patients to prevent life-threatening complications.   *This case is designed for educational purposes and does not represent a specific real-life patient.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Mr. Martin Harper  a 70-year-old Caucasoid male (since AAAs are more common among white males)  retired construction worker  is a lifelong smoker with a pack-a-day habit. Mr. Harper lives with his wife in the suburbs. He has two sons who live in different cities and doesn't have any access to genetic records noting the health of his paternal side ancestors.  Past Medical History: Mr. Harper has a history of untreated hypertension. He was diagnosed with high blood pressure 9 years ago and initially used to take medications  but discontinued them after a few years when he felt ""perfectly fine."" He is also a long-term smoker  with 35 pack-years of tobacco use. He has a history of high cholesterol and a familial history of vascular diseases (a brother had an AAA repair). However  there is no known family history of genetic connective tissue disorders  such as Marfan's or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.  Key Complaints: Mr. Harper visits the family physician complaining of a dull  constant pain in the middle or lower part of his abdomen for the past two weeks. Occasionally  he feels the pain radiating to his back as well causing discomfort along with a sensation of fullness. He denies any symptoms of chest pain  severe low back pain  syncopal episodes  testicular pain  or urinary symptoms. He also mentions that he has been feeling slightly fatigued lately but attributes it to his age and less active lifestyle.  Summary Narrative: Our patient  Mr. Harper  a 70-year-old lifelong smoker with untreated hypertension  represents a demographic that is at an increased risk for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). These typical risk factors combined with the fact that he has a brother who had an AAA repair and his presentation of persistent abdominal pain warrants screening for AAA.   From this case  students should learn to question patients about change in bowel habits  weight loss  ureteric colic or any history indicating rupture such as sudden sharp pain  signs of shock  etc. Urgency should be recognized to either order imaging right away or fast-track a referral to vascular surgery if there's clinical suspicion of AAA. These steps could potentially save the patient from catastrophic outcomes related to AAA rupture. Lesson learned: Early detection and intervention are crucial for improving AAA-related mortality.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. J. Brown is a 72-year-old Caucasian male presented to the emergency department.  Past Medical History: Patient has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has been a chain smoker for the past 40 years. Patient underwent an appendectomy at the age of 32 and was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes at 55. He does not exercise regularly. He is currently on antihypertensive and lipid lowering drugs  along with regular insulin.  Chief Complaints: Patient reports a sudden unrelenting sharp pain in his lower back and abdomen  which started about 6 hours ago. He also reports feeling weak and dizzy with associated nausea and vomiting. Patient mentions a rapid beating sensation in his abdomen  with associated shortness of breath.  Note: Evidence-based data shows that abdominal aortic aneurysms overwhelmingly occur in males over the age of 65  particularly among those with risk factors such as hypertension  hyperlipidemia  smoking  lack of physical activity  and family history of aortic aneurysm. The abrupt onset of pain in the back or abdomen along with symptoms of shock  may indicate a leaking or ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm  a condition requiring immediate medical intervention.  Having Mr. Brown as a patient would aid medical students in recognizing the risk factors for an abdominal aortic aneurysm and understanding the dire consequences of a rupture. The students can also learn to recognize the symptoms and understand the urgency of the situation  which can often mean the difference between life and death. They will learn to effectively communicate with the patient  providing reassurance while realizing the need for immediate intervention.

Case Report:  Patient: Mr. Robert Campbell  Demographics: 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired schoolteacher  living with his wife.  Past Medical History: Mr. Campbell has a history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and is a former smoker (stopped 25 years ago). His father died from an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture at the age of 63.   Presenting Complaint: Mr. Campbell visits the clinic with complaints of a constant  severe lower abdominal pain for the last two days. It's not associated with meals  bowel movements or physical activities. Additionally  he reports a perceptible pulsating feeling in the abdomen. His wife noticed a slight change in his gait and reported that he seems a bit slower and weaker than usual.  Possible reason to suspect Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm:  Mr. Campbell’s presenting complaints  advanced age  history of smoking  hypertension  high cholesterol  and a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm place him at high risk for developing an abdominal aortic aneurysm. His current complaints of severe abdominal pain and a pulsating feeling could indicate a rapidly growing or rupturing aneurysm  which is a medical emergency.  Learning Objectives:   Through this case  students should learn and be able to discuss: - The typical demographic and risk factors associated with abdominal aortic aneurysms. - How to identify the signs and symptoms of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  including a possible rupture. - The significance of early detection and treatment strategies for patients with abdominal aortic aneurysms given the high fatality rate of ruptured aneurysms. - The importance of asking about family history with regard to cardiovascular disease  specifically aortic aneurysms. - How to initiate a prompt diagnostic workup for suspected cases (ultrasound  abdominal CT). - The potential complications  surgical management  and postoperative care of patients who have abdominal aortic aneurysms.   This case is oriented towards being simple yet instructive  and to help students highlight the connection between epidemiologic factors  clinical history  and abdominal aortic aneurysm diagnosis. The importance of multidisciplinary patient care  including anesthesia and surgical teams  should also be highlighted.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Information:  Edward Schultz is a 69-year-old Caucasian male from a suburban community. He has been a smoker for the past 50 years  consuming approximately one pack per day. He is a retired construction worker and now leads a mostly sedentary lifestyle. He lives with his wife and has three adult children. He consumes alcohol moderately  up to seven drinks per week.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Schultz has a history of hypertension which has been fairly well-controlled with lisinopril. His last recorded BP was 135/85 mmHg about a month ago. He has been diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia and prescribed statin therapy 5 years ago  although he is inconsistent in compliance. He is also known to have peripheral artery disease. Due to his prolonged smoking history  he has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and uses an albuterol inhaler as needed.  Reason for Visit/Key Complaints:  Mr. Schultz presents with complaints of a visible and palpable pulsating mass in his abdomen coupled with occasional  dull lower back pain which he first noticed a week back. He denies any severe or recent trauma  fever  weight loss or changes in bowel and urinary habits. On further inquiry  he admits intermittent claudication that he attributes to his age and COPD. His family history reveals his father died suddenly at age 73 due to what was suspected to be an ""abdominal artery rupture.""  Physical exam:  A pulsatile mass is palpated in Mr. Schultz's abdomen. Peripheral pulses are reduced  and he has cool extremities with signs of peripheral neuropathy.  Preliminary Assessment:  Given the patient's age  strong smoking history  the presence of concurrent vascular diseases  and recent complaints  this case points towards an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The next clinical step would involve sonography or computed tomography for diagnostic confirmation. Further management would depend on aneurysm size and rate of growth. This case is to guide students into a deeper understanding of the AAA risk factors  diagnostic procedures  management options  and possible complications.

Patient Information:  - Name: Mr. Smith - Age: 72 years old - Gender: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian   Past Medical History:  - Former smoker  quit 20 years ago with a total pack-year history of 20 - Hypertension maintained with antihypertensive medication - Moderate alcohol consumption  Chief Complaint:   - Episodic abdominal pain for the past two weeks. Initially dull but intensified over the past 72 hours - Pain has a duration of a few hours each day  and gets relieved by bending forward  - Associated lower back discomfort - No apparent triggers  no relieving factors identified - Occasional dizziness and nausea  but no vomiting or change in bowel movement.  Clinical Case Summary:  Mr. Smith  a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a past medical history significant for hypertension and smoking  presents for the evaluation of recent onset episodic abdominal pain that has been occurring for two weeks. The pain is moderate to severe and is somewhat alleviated with bending forward but is otherwise unrelieved. The pain has been on and off but has increased in severity over the past 72 hours. He also complains of occasional dizziness and nausea but denies vomiting  or any changes in bowel or bladder function.  Considering his medical history and age  the clinical suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) is decently high. Current smoking and being a male over the age of 65 increases his risk. His hypertension could have facilitated the development and enlargement of an aneurysm. Thus  a thorough diagnosis that includes an abdominal examination and confirmatory imaging tests should be carried out to establish the presence of an AAA and to determine the necessary treatment protocol.  Note: This is a brief case outline and the learner's guide should delve into the dedicated discussion about AAA  its pathophysiology  epidemiology  diagnosis  management  including when to opt for surgery  and postoperative care. Prompt recognition and management of AAA are crucial considering the high mortality associated with ruptured AAA.   Educational Objectives:  1. Identify the risk factors and clinical presentations of AAA. 2. Understand the importance of a timely diagnosis and the role of imaging studies in AAA. 3. Discuss the management and follow-up protocol for patients with AAA.  4. Highlight the potential complications of untreated  large or ruptured AAA.

Case Study: Mr. Edward  66-year-old Caucasian Male with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Background: Mr. James Edward is a 66-year-old Caucasian male from a suburban background. He is married with three grown-up children. He has a 35-year history of smoking  though he has managed to cut down to 5 cigarettes a day from a pack a day over the course of 15 years. He has been diagnosed with hypertension for 10 years  for which he takes Lisinopril. He also has a family history of cardiac diseases  with his father passing away due to myocardial infarction at the age of 71. He has shown mild hyperlipidemia  which is managed through diet control. The patient denies any alcohol or illicit drug use. 	 Presenting Complaints: Mr. Edward presented at the clinic complaining of a persistent  mild abdominal pain for the past few weeks. He described it as a ‘gurgling sensation’ located near his navel that sometimes extends to his back. Furthermore  he has also experienced an unintentional weight loss of nearly 10 pounds in the past two months even though his appetite has remained relatively unchanged.   According to epidemiological data  Mr. Edward's demographic (age  sex  race) together with his past medical history – particularly his history of hypertension and smoking – make him a high-risk candidate for an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Patient Profile: Name: Mr. Vito Russo Age: 73 years old Gender: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired- Army Veteran Marital Status: Divorced Living Situation: Lives alone in a two-bedroom apartment Insurance Status: Medicare  Past Medical History: 1. Hypertension for 12 years  well-controlled using Amlodipine  2. Hyperlipidaemia controlled with Atorvastatin. 3. 50-pack year smoking history  currently reduced to 5 cigarettes a day 4. Type 2 diabetes mellitus diagnosed 8 years ago  managed with Metformin 5. Mild Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)  not on oxygen therapy 6. Preventive AAA screening 3 years ago reveals 3.2 cm aortic diameter.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Russo presents to his primary care physician's office during a routine visit. He does not have any complaint of any symptoms but was feeling a bit tired. On detailed interrogation  he does recount some intermittent  non-radiating low back pain over the past few months which he had attributed to his age and physical exertion during workout. He reports feeling of a pulsating sensation in his abdomen occasionally but no issues with eating or any change in bowel habits. Recently  during an at-home blood pressure monitoring  he observed a dip in his systolic blood pressure readings without any alterations in his regular medication schedule.  Physical Examination Findings: On examination  a pulsatile mass of about 6cm was palpated in his abdomen and a bruit was auscultated over it. No lower extremity edemas were noted. The rest of his physical examination was unremarkable with no abnormal cardiac sounds or lung sounds. His blood pressure reading in the office was 135/80 mm Hg and heart rate of 72 beats per minute.  The demographics  past medical history  and patient profile are chosen as per pertinent literature which state that high-risk individuals for AAA include older age group  males  smokers  people with hypertension or history of cardiovascular diseases and Caucasian race. Furthermore  AAAs are often asymptomatic and are discovered incidentally or during routine screening of high-risk individuals  similar to the scenario painted in Mr. Russo's case.   This interactive case would help inform medical students about risk factors of AAA  how its presentation might be silent or disguised as low back pain  the importance of physical examination and reflective on the need for appropriate screening measures within high-risk populations. After interactive discussion  the students can be guided to discuss further diagnostic work-up and management strategies for Mr. Russo.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 70-year-old African American male with a history of military service. He is a former smoker who quit 20 years ago and continues to consume alcohol moderately. He works as a retired engineer and leads a mostly sedentary lifestyle. The patient is overweight with a BMI of 28  and lives in urban surroundings.   Past Medical History: The patient has a documented history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and intermittent claudication indicative of peripheral arterial disease (PAD). He has had no surgical interventions in the past. His father succumbed to an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at the age of 75  indicating a family history.  Presenting Complaints: The patient reports a recent onset of intermittent  mild-to-moderate abdominal pain that he describes as a deep  gnawing sensation  localized to the lower back. He has also reported unintentional weight loss over the past few months. Further  he reports episodes of feeling faint and dizziness after brief periods of physical exertion  which are recent phenomena.  This case targets several key risk factors including old age  male gender  African American race  former smoker  hypertension  high cholesterol  family history of AAA  peripheral arterial disease  and symptoms such as abdominal pain or back pain that labor on AAA. As literature suggests that AAAs are most common in older white men with a smoking history  introducing an African American patient adds an additional layer for discussion regarding potential race-related diagnostic disparities and biases.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Demographics:  The patient  Mr. Alvarez  is a 72-year-old Caucasian male with a history of heavy smoking. He is a retired construction worker  residing in a suburban setting  married with three adult children  and weighs 215 pounds. He is of average height for his age and reports occasional alcohol use.  Past medical history: Mr. Alvarez has been known to hypertension for over 10 years  poorly controlled with amlodipine and lisinopril. He was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes five years ago and is taking metformin  but his glycemic control has been suboptimal with his most recent HbA1c at 8.2%. He has an extensive history of tobacco use  smoking 1.5 packs a day for 40 years though he ceased smoking 10 years back. Additionally  he has been treated for hypercholesterolemia and peripheral vascular disease. He has no known drug allergies. In his surgical history  he underwent a right hip replacement two years ago.  Chief Complaints: Mr. Alvarez visited the clinic with complaints of intermittent  dull abdominal pain that worsens after meals. The pain has been ongoing over a week and radiated to his lower back. Upon further questioning  Mr. Alvarez also noted unintentional weight loss of around 10 pounds over the last two months  low appetite  and fatigue. He also acknowledged that he felt a pulsating sensation in his abdomen  which prompted him to seek medical attention.  Note: This case has taken into consideration the common risk factors associated with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  including age (most commonly affects people aged 65-75)  gender (more common in men)  race (more common in white people)  smoking  hypertension  and atherosclerosis. Unexplained weight loss  though not a common symptom of AAA  may suggest secondary complications or other underlying pathologies. As per the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPSTF) recommendations  patients like Mr. Alvarez with a history of smoking should be screened for AAA.

Patient Profile:   Name: John Doe Age: 70 years old  Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired military officer Location: Urban  Past Medical History:  - John has a 40-year history of smoking  though he quit 10 years ago.  - He has controlled hypertension and a known history of peripheral vascular disease.  - His father passed away in his 80s due to ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm.   Key Complaints:   - John presents to the Emergency Department with sudden  severe pain in his lower back and abdomen  that started couple hours ago.  - He describes it as a tearing sensation  that is worsening with time.  - He is simultaneously experiencing nausea and mild shortness of breath.  - His vital signs are stable; however  a noticeable pulsating mass is felt upon physical examination of his abdomen.   The above case represents a classic presentation of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The patient's demographics like age  gender and race  his past medical history including smoking  hypertension and family history of AAA  and his clinical presentation with sudden abdominal and lower back pain  make it highly suggestive of AAA. It is also consistent with literature  where the AAA mostly affects Caucasian males aged 65-75 years  who are smokers or have a history of smoking  with medical comorbidities like hypertension and family history of AAA. The condition is also more prevalent in urban populations. The case is also designed to emphasize the emergency nature of a possible ruptured AAA  hence the setting of an Emergency Department.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Demographics: Mr. James Rooney is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  a retired truck driver residing in a suburban area. He is a widower with two adult children. He smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for about 45 years but has quit smoking for the past 5 years or so. He maintains a moderate alcohol intake and admits to a diet rich in red meat and high in fats.  Past Medical History: Mr. Rooney has a well-documented past medical history which includes Hypertension  Hyperlipidemia  and Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD). His family history reveals his late father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm. His medications include amlodipine for hypertension  atorvastatin for hyperlipidemia  and salmeterol for COPD.  Key Complaints: Over several weeks  Mr. Rooney has been experiencing vague  intermittent abdominal and lower back pain that tends to get worse after meals. He also mentions a feeling of pulsation in his stomach  which made him lose his appetite gradually. He initially attributed these symptoms to age and indigestion but decided to seek medical attention when the pain intensified  and he noticed unintentional weight loss  which has left him feeling worried.  This case was designed to represent a typical patient demographic predisposed to Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  a condition most often found in males over 65 years old  smokers  Caucasian  those with a family history of AAA  hypertensive  hyperlipidemia  and COPD patients. The chief complaints are also consistent with early-stage AAA  and allow room for educators to explain appropriate responses and diagnostic approaches.

Case Study: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information:  Mr. Jones  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  comes in for a routine physical. He is a widower and a retired auto mechanic. He now occupies his time with gardening and occasional golf.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Jones has been a smoker for the past 50 years  consuming approximately a pack a day. Although currently doesn’t report any signs of respiratory distress  he’s been diagnosed with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He also has a history of hypertension adequately controlled with ACE inhibitors and beta-blockers.  Key Complaints:  During the visit  Mr. Jones mentions that he has been experiencing intermittent abdominal discomfort for the last few weeks. The pain is not severe but is notable by its unfamiliarity. He notes that the pain happens mostly after a meal and seems to be unrelated to particular foods. He adds there's also discomfort at his lower back that he attributes to overexertion from his gardening activities.  Additional Information:  Mr. Jones is slightly overweight  with a Body Mass Index (BMI) of 28 but denies any changes in appetite  bowel habit  weight loss  dysuria  or hematuria. His pulse rate is regular but there's a noticeable pulsatile mass near the umbilical area.  This case presentation should stimulate your students to think about the possibility of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Mr. Jones's age  male sex  history of smoking  and hypertension are all risk factors. His complaint of vague abdominal and lower back pain  coupled with the physical finding of a pulsatile abdominal mass  should raise suspicions for AAA. However  his symptoms could also result from other conditions  such as peptic ulcer disease or musculoskeletal back strain  requiring a differential diagnosis approach. Importantly  his COPD also poses additional risks during monitoring and possible operative interventions  signifying the importance of multidisciplinary cooperation in managing patients with AAA.   Reference: Chaikof EL  Dalman RL  Eskandari MK  et al. The Society for Vascular Surgery practice guidelines on the care of patients with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Journal of Vascular Surgery. 2018;67(1):2-77.e2. doi:10.1016/j.jvs.2017.10.044.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information:  John Smith  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department. He is a retired Marine Engineer  a non-smoker but drinks alcohol moderately. His BMI falls within the overweight range. He lives with his wife in a suburban community.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a history of hypertension  for which he is taking Lisinopril. He was diagnosed with high cholesterol 5 years ago  and is on Lipitor (Atorvastatin) therapy. The patient reports regular compliance with the prescribed medications. There is no history of diabetes or kidney ailments. He had appendectomy at age 20  no other surgeries are reported. Family history includes a brother who died at age 63 from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Smith reports a sudden onset of severe  tearing abdominal pain that started a couple of hours ago  accompanied by back pain. He is experiencing mild dizziness  but denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  or loss of consciousness. Moreover  he mentions of having reduced appetite and unintended weight loss over the past few months.   The age  gender  and medical history of the patient aligns with demographic groups at increased risk for abdominal aortic aneurysms  as suggested by multiple studies. Males aged over 60 with history of smoking  high blood pressure  high cholesterol levels and family history of AAA are proven to be at higher risk.   The acute  severe abdominal and back pain reported  coupled with recent symptoms like reduced appetite and weight loss might point to an abdominal aortic aneurysm. However  further diagnosis is required to confirm this hypothesis. Following the clinical presentation  you should order an abdominal examination  blood work and an abdominal ultrasound. The subsequent steps towards management should be pursued based on the results obtained. Be sure to take time to talk with the patient and his partner  explaining clearly the situation and the planned diagnostic steps.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  Mr. Thomas Banks  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired mechanical engineer  long-term resident of Boston  Massachusetts.  Past Medical History:  The patient is a known hypertensive for the last 12 years  controlled with regular medications (amlodipine 5mg once daily). He is a former 30-pack year smoker but quit 10 years ago. He has no known allergies. Family history includes a father who died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at age 73 along with a younger brother who also had a non-ruptured AAA discovered incidentally during an imaging test for kidney stones.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Banks  who generally enjoys good health  came for a routine follow-up appointment. He mentioned intermittent episodes of vague abdominal pain that he had been experiencing in the past couple of months. He described the pain as non-radiating  without any associated symptoms like nausea or vomiting. However  he noticed the pain becomes more noticeable after his daily evening meals. The pain is not severe  but it is unfamiliar to him  which induced the concern. More recently  he noticed a pulsatile mass in his abdomen which he described as a “heartbeat in my belly”. Further  he mentioned unintentional weight loss of about 10 pounds (4.5 kgs) during the last three months  suggesting possible anorexia. He denied any changes in his bowel movements or urine output.   Note:  The demographic representation in this case aligns with literature  targeting a person who is male  over 65  a former smoker  hypertensive  and having a familial predisposition - all of which are primary risk factors associated with the development of abdominal aortic aneurysms. Further  the presented symptoms  especially the pulsatile mass in the abdomen and unexplained abdominal pain  push the suspicion towards an AAA. This case emphasizes the importance of taking a proper familial history and correlating the non-specific symptoms to the risk profile of the patients.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information:  Mr. James Thompson  a 70-year-old Caucasian male retired construction worker. He lives alone and has been a lifetime smoker  consuming approximately one pack per day. He also admits frequent intake of alcohol but denies any illegal substance use. He has a significant family history  with his father passing away from an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) rupture at the age of 65.  Past Medical History: Mr. Thompson was diagnosed with hypertension 20 years ago and Type II diabetes mellitus 15 years ago. Other medical conditions include high cholesterol and mild COPD. His surgical history includes an appendectomy in his early 20s and bilateral knee replacements five years ago. He is currently on amlodipine  lisinopril  metformin  and simvastatin.  Chief Complaints:  The patient presents with a sudden onset  severe abdominal pain which started around 3 hours prior to arrival. The pain radiates to the lower back  and he describes it as a tearing sensation. He denies any nausea  vomiting  or loss of consciousness. He also notes recent unexplained weight loss but doesn't have any noticeable decrease in appetite.  Upon initial evaluation  the patient is hypertensive with a blood pressure of 170/85 mmHg  heart rate 100 bpm  oxygen saturation 95% on room air  and respirations 16 per minute. The clinician feels a pulsatile mass in the mid to lower abdomen. Lab tests and further imaging will need to be done to confirm the diagnosis of an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm.  This case is representative of typical AAA patients  as literature shows a higher incidence in males over 65  especially those of Caucasian ethnicity. It is associated with a history of smoking  hypertension  high cholesterol  and family history of AAA. Type II diabetes has a unique inverse correlation  shown to decrease the risk of AAA  but in this case  Mr. Thompson still developed one due to other prominent risk factors. His complaint of severe abdominal pain radiating to his back is classic for AAA rupture. A pulsatile abdominal mass is also a key physical finding.

Patient Case: Mr. John Gray   Demographics: Mr. John Gray is a 65-year-old Caucasian male  a recently retired civil engineer who lives with his wife in Miami  Florida. He is a former smoker  having quit 20 years ago  but he reports a 30-pack year history of smoking. He does not consume alcohol or use illicit substances. He has a BMI of 29 indicating overweight.  Past Medical History: Mr. Gray has a known history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Both conditions are reasonably well-controlled with medications; he currently takes a diuretic for his hypertension and a statin for his hyperlipidemia respectively. Mr. Gray also has a family history of cardiovascular diseases; his father died from a myocardial infarction at the age of 73.  Chief Complaints: Over the past two weeks  Mr. Gray has been experiencing intermittent and vague abdominal discomfort. The pain is not sharp or severe but consistent enough to cause him to seek medical attention. He notes the discomfort seems to concentrate in his abdominal region  more in the center around his navel and sometimes radiates to his back. The pain does not increase with food intake or defecation. He denied any changes in his bowel habits  nausea  vomiting  fevers  or any other associated symptoms.  This case is designed to provide a classic presentation of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The age  gender  smoking history  and hypertension are all particularly significant as they play into the risks associated with the development of AAA. Abdominal discomfort and back pain are clinical manifestations  though it should be noted that many cases of AAA are asymptomatic until rupture. After presentation of this case  students should be able to recognize the potential signs and risks of AAA and consider it in their differential diagnoses.

Case Report   Patient Demographics:  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  a retired engineer. He reports a smoking history of 30 years but quit 10 years ago. He lives in a suburban environment with his wife. He occasionally consumes alcohol.   Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He suffers from chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) due to his smoking history. His father died due to an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture at the age of 75 years.   Present Complaint:  The patient reported intermittent and moderate to severe abdominal pain that also spreads to his lower back. The pain is not associated with food intake and was described as a deep  gnawing sensation  which occasionally exacerbates to a sharp sensation. He has had three episodes of such pain in the last week  each lasting for a few hours. The pain subsides when he lies down and worsens upon activity. He also expresses mild shortness of breath on mild exertion  loss of appetite  and unintentional weight loss over recent weeks.   Note: We have designed this case keeping in mind that abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) are most commonly found in males over the age of 65 with a history of smoking and hypertension. The Caucasian race  COPD and family history of AAA are also risk factors.

Patient Case:   Patient Profile: - Name: Mr. John Smith - Age: 72 Years Old - Gender: Male - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired Construction Worker - Marital Status: Married  with three grown children  Medical History: - Hypertension (well-controlled with Lisinopril) - Smoking: 40 pack-years  quit 10 years ago - High Cholesterol: Statin-controlled - Previous history of peripheral artery disease   Key Complaints: - Recurrent mild abdominal pain for the past three weeks - Mild lower back discomfort - Occasional episodes of feeling light-headed - Reported one instance of fainting a week ago - No report of drastic weight loss or weight gain  The above demographics and medical history are consistent with the most common risk factors for abdominal aortic aneurysm  as per the literature. These include advanced age  male gender  smoking history  hypertension  high cholesterol  and previous history of peripheral artery disease--all of which our example patient  Mr. Smith  has. Caucasian men over the age of 65 with a history of smoking and hypertension form a significant proportion of patients with abdominal aortic aneurysm. The key complaints also align with frequent symptoms of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  including recurrent mild to moderate abdominal or lower back pain  feeling light-headed  and occasional fainting. However  these symptoms might not always be present in all individuals  as significant proportion of abdominal aortic aneurysm cases are found incidentally when imaging is done for unrelated reasons.   This case study can be utilized to teach medical students about the aspects of risk stratification  early recognition  assessment  and management of abdominal aortic aneurysm. It may further prompt discussions about the importance of routine screening in high-risk individuals  especially considering the potentially severe complications of an unattended abdominal aortic aneurysm  such as rupture leading to life-threatening hemorrhage.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Demographics: Mr. Wilson  a 70-year-old Caucasian male who currently resides in the urban area. He is a former manual laborer but now retired. He is a heavy smoker with a 50-pack year history and drinks alcohol occasionally.   Past Medical History: Mr. Wilson has a known medical history of high blood pressure  high cholesterol  and peripheral artery disease  all of which he takes medications for. Despite being advised to quit smoking  the patient has not changed his smoking habits. He has been diagnosed with Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD)  which is managed with a combination of medications including inhaled corticosteroids  bronchodilators and occasional courses of oral steroids during exacerbations.   Key Complaints: The patient presented to the emergency department with severe and sudden onset epigastric pain  which he describes as a ripping or tearing sensation that radiates through to his back. He also complained about feeling faint and having a ""fast  faint pulse.” Over the last few months  he has experienced unexplained weight loss  occasional shortness of breath and intermittent claudication.   Background Information: The demographics and clinical history point towards a potential abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). AAA tends to affect older males and is particularly prevalent in smokers and those with a history of cardiovascular disease. Caucasians are the most affected demographic group as compared to other ethnicities. The sudden onset of severe pain is a classic symptom of ruptured AAA  which is a medical emergency due to significant risk of death from hemorrhage.  Further investigation such as a physical examination (palpating an abdominal mass)  imaging like ultrasound or CT  and hemodynamic management will be the next decisive steps.   The provided case can be used to impart knowledge regarding clinical presentation  risk factors  appropriate investigations  and management of AAA. The case can pave the foundation for a detailed discussion about the pathophysiology behind AAA  the reasoning behind various diagnostic tools  and possible surgical or conservative treatment options that provide best patient care.

Patient Profile - Name: John Doe Age: 72 years Gender: Male Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired Army official  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Doe comes into the ER complaining of severe and constant pain in the lower back and abdominal area which he has described as a pulsating sensation  deep within his abdomen. He also reports bouts of nausea and feelings of lightheadedness.   Medical History: Mr. Doe has been a smoker for approximately 40 years and has a history of high blood pressure (hypertension) which is controlled by medication. He's had episodes of increased cholesterol levels in the past and was on lipid-lowering drugs till two years back. There is no apparent history of diabetes. His father had suffered from an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 76.  Physical Examination: On examination  a pulsatile mass is felt in the abdomen while his vital signs are within normal limits. However  he looks distressed due to immense pain.  Considerations for Case Discussion:   This patient case has been designed to reflect the typical high-risk demographic for abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA). Studies indicate that the incidence rates of AAA are higher in males  and the risk increases with age  particularly in those over 65. Smoking is also a known significant risk factor for AAA. Furthermore  individuals with a family history of AAA are also at increased risk  hence this history has been added to our patient's profile.   This case is prepared to engage student discussion around the identification  differential diagnoses  risk factors  immediate management  and treatment options for abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA). Clinical reasoning and decision-making skills in an urgent vascular emergency as this should be a focus during training.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. Miguel Fernandez  an 68-year-old Hispanic male  Past Medical History: He has a history of diagnosed hypertension and hypercholesterolemia for the past 15 years. He's a former smoker with a 30 pack-year history and quit smoking 10 years ago. He has no history of surgeries or major illnesses. He reports moderate alcohol consumption but denies illicit drug use.  Key Complaints: Over the past week  Mr. Fernandez reports experiencing an unusual consistent pain in his middle and lower abdomen which he describes as a deep ache. He begins to worry as this pain felt different from his usual indigestion. Some episodes of sharp pain are superimposed on this dull ache especially when he is active. The pain is not related to food intake  and there have been no accompanying symptoms like nausea  vomiting  or change in bowel habits. He reports an unintentional weight loss of about 10 pounds over the last 3 months. He also mentions the recent onset of lower back pain  without radiating aspects. He has not noticed any pulsatile abdominal mass.  This case design is constructed to reflect the common risk factors and presentation of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). According to literature  AAA often occurs in older adults  especially males over 65 years of age. It also often occurs more frequently in the Hispanic population. Hypertension  high cholesterol level  smoking  and age are considerable risk factors. The gradual onset of abdominal and back pain imply the slow expansion of the aortic aneurysm. Furthermore  AAA is often asymptomatic until it is on the verge of rupturing  thus  it's crucial for medical students to understand the subtle presentation like loss of weight.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Profile  James is a 68-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired construction worker and current smoker with a 45-pack-year smoking history. He reports moderate alcohol use. He is 6'0"" tall  weighs 200 pounds  and has a relatively sedentary lifestyle.   Past Medical History  James has a medical history of systemic hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed by regular medication. His familial history reveals his father died of a rupture of an aortic aneurysm at age 70.  Presenting Complaints   James presented to the emergency department complaining of severe  acute onset abdominal and back pain that had been escalating over the past couple of hours.
