The pain was persistent and James described it as a tearing sensation extending to the groin. He also reported feeling dizzy and experiencing a rapid heartbeat.  Emergency Examination   On initial examination  James appeared anxious and pale. Vital signs demonstrated tachycardia but blood pressure was within normal margins. On physical examination  a pulsatile mass was palpated in the abdominal area. Further examination results are pending an ultrasound and/or CT scan.  Demographics Considerations   This case aligns with typical demographic reports from literature that shows abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) occur more commonly in men  particularly Caucasian men  over the age of 65 (Guirguis-Blake et al.  2014). Other risk factors often associated with AAA include hypertension  hyperlipidemia  smoking  and a family history of the condition. In fact  smoking is considered the strongest risk factor  especially with a history of over 35-40 pack-years (Kent et al.  2010).   References:  Guirguis-Blake  J. M.  Beil  T. L.  Sun  X.  Senger  C. A.  & Whitlock  E. P. (2014). Primary Care Screening for Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm: A Systematic Evidence Review for the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force [Internet]. Rockville  MD.  Kent  K. C.  Zwolak  R. M.  Egorova  N. N.  Riles  T. S.  Manganaro  A.  Moskowitz  A. J.  ... & Gelijns  A. C. (2010). Analysis of risk factors for abdominal aortic aneurysm in a cohort of more than 3 million individuals. Journal of vascular surgery  52(3)  539-548.

Case study: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information:   John is a 65-year-old Caucasian male who resides in a rural part of North Carolina. He is married and has three adult children. John is a retired miner and veteran.   Past medical history:  He has a history of 30 years of cigarette smoking but quit seven years ago  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia. His father died due to a ruptured aortic aneurysm while his mother has a history of hypertension and diabetes. John has a sedentary lifestyle and an average American diet. Despite these  he has never been hospitalized before.  Presenting complaint:  John arrived in the clinic complaining of a constant abdominal pain that he has been experiencing for the last two weeks. The pain is felt mainly in the central and upper part of his abdomen  which seems to extend to his back. He also mentions experiencing more fatigue than usual during his daily activities and has lost approximately 10 lbs. unintentionally in the past month. He states he has been feeling full quickly when eating and has mild nausea.  This case depicts a common presentation of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). The risk factors seen in this case are congruent with the epidemiological evidence  which underscores that AAAs are more prevalent in Caucasian men over 60 years of age with a history of smoking  hypertension  family history of AAA  and cardiovascular disease. Symptoms such as the presence of a pulsating abdominal mass or unexplained weight loss might indicate the presence of an AAA.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile: Mr. Richard Thompson  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department. He is retired and lives with his wife. He is a former smoker with a 30 pack-year history  but reports that he quit smoking around 15 years ago  after his initial diagnosis of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He is not currently on oxygen therapy for COPD. He also has a history of hypertension which is controlled with medication (lisinopril). He denies any alcohol or illicit drug use.  Past Medical History: - Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease - Hypertension - Hyperlipidemia - No history of diabetes  - He is not on any anticoagulant therapy  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Thompson reports a 2-day history of gradual onset  dull  constant abdominal and back pain that is unrelieved with over-the-counter pain medication. The pain is located in the lower abdomen and back. He also mentions a feeling of fullness in his abdomen which is a new symptom for him. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  lower extremity weakness/numbness or recent changes in bowel or urinary habits.  This case specimen is a typical representation of the demography that abdominal aortic aneurysm would generally affect. Literature suggests that AAAs are most commonly found in older patients with a mean age of 70  more frequently in males than in females  among Caucasians and in smokers or former smokers. Moreover  hypertension and COPD are also risk factors for AAA development. Thus  the patient  Mr. Richard Thompson  realistically represents the typical patient profile for an AAA case. His presenting complaints and past medical history are in line with what would generally raise suspicion for an abdominal aortic aneurysm in a clinical setting.

Patient Information:   This case involves Mr. Rodriguez  a 70-year-old Hispanic male living in rural New Mexico. He is a retired construction worker with an annual income below the national average.  Demographics: Ethnicity: Hispanic Age: 70 yrs Sex: Male Location: Rural New Mexico  Past Medical History: Mr. Rodriguez has led an active life with a history of hypertension and moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)  likely due to a 30-year pack history of smoking. He quit smoking 5 years ago after the COPD diagnosis. He has no history of diabetes mellitus  coronary artery disease or cerebrovascular accident. Over the past year  he has noticed progressive shortness of breath when walking up the hill to his home. His medications include a low-dose thiazide diuretic and inhaled bronchodilator.  Key Complaints: He came into the primary care clinic complaining of abdominal and lower back pain that he rated as about 6 on a scale from 1 to 10  10 being severe pain. He described it as a throbbing discomfort in his lower abdomen  radiating to his lower back  the severity of which tends to increase after eating meals. There has been no fever  hematuria  recent trauma or lifting heavy objects. He has noticed a bulge in his belly but assumed it was simply related to aging. No changes in appetite  but he has experienced recent weight loss due to reduced food intake because of his fear that eating exacerbates the pain.  Rationale: This case of Mr. Rodriguez is designed around the typical patient demographics for abdominal aortic aneurysm. The condition is most common in males over the age of 60 who have a history of smoking  hypertension  and atherosclerotic disease. The abdominal and back pain described by the patient suggests the possibility of an aneurysm and illustrates the need for a high degree of suspicion in clinical practice among the susceptible population. According to data from the CDC  Hispanic Americans are more at risk for an abdominal aortic aneurysm than non-Hispanic whites  providing an important consideration for the practice of culturally competent care. The inclusion of low socioeconomic background and rural living area highlights the importance of understanding barriers to healthcare access in certain demographics.

Case Report: Multisystem Involvement with Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 72-year-old male of Hispanic descent. He is a retired schoolteacher  married  with three children and six grandchildren. He has lived in the same urban area for the last 48 years and has a 40-pack/year history of smoking  but quit 5 years ago. He partakes in moderate alcohol consumption  drinking an average of 1-2 glasses of red wine daily. He's currently on an aspirin regimen for his heart condition and a statin for high cholesterol.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of cardiovascular disease  specifically previous myocardial infarction (about 5 years ago)  well-controlled hypertension  and hyperlipidemia. He also had Type 2 diabetes  controlled with oral hypoglycemics. There's a family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm with his father having it at around the same age.  Key Complaints: The patient initially presented to his primary care physician with a non-specific complaint of abdominal and lower back discomfort that had been progressively worsening over the past few months. Accompanying these complaints was a feeling of fullness in his stomach even when he hadn't eaten much. He also states that his trouser belt  which normally is quite comfortable  has been causing him discomfort. Unexplained weight loss of around 4.5 kg over 6 months has been noted too. Recent bouts of severe stabbing abdominal pain had alarmed him enough to seek advice.  Upon initial examination  a pulsatile mass in the abdomen raised concerns for an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA). The patient was immediately referred for further investigations.  These demographics  past medical history  and key complaints are consistent with the higher risk of AAA found in older males  those with a family history of the condition  and lifestyle factors like a history of smoking. The Hispanic community is currently underrepresented in most cardiovascular health studies but recent data suggest that they may have a risk profile similar to Caucasians. This case hopes to highlight the importance of considering all patient populations when assessing for conditions like AAA.   Furthermore  medical students should take note of the non-specificity of symptoms  which may explain why AAAs are often diagnosed late or missed altogether  emphasizing the importance of clinical suspicion and examination.

Case Presentation:  Initial Information:  Patient: Mr. Smith  a 70-year-old Caucasian male.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a history of high blood pressure  hyperlipidemia  and a 40-pack-year smoking history. His father reportedly died from 'a massive stroke' in his early 70s. He is currently on a regimen of antihypertensive medications and statin for his cholesterol. He has no history of surgeries or any known drug allergies.   Key Complaints: Mr. Smith presents to the clinic with complaints of an uncharacteristic  gradual onset  dull pain in the lower back and abdominal region over the past two weeks that isn't alleviated with routine over-the-counter analgesics. He also reports general fatigue and unexplained episodes of lightheadedness. No complaints of nausea  vomiting  change in bowel habits  urinary issues  or recent weight loss.   On Physical Examination: Mr. Smith appears mildly distressed. Vital signs are stable; however  his blood pressure is on the higher end. Abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile epigastric mass with bruit.  Reason Why this Case is Being Used:  This case was chosen to instruct medical students on the clinical presentation  risk factors  physical examination findings  diagnosis  and management strategies associated with an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). Due to the strong correlation with aging  smoking  and male gender reported in literature  the patient has been designed to be a 70-year-old man with a significant history of smoking  hypertension  and a family history indicative of vascular issues.  Objectives for Students:  1. Recognize the importance of carefully deciphering past medical histories. 2. Identify risk factors of AAA. 3. Understand the clinical symptoms and physical findings suggestive of AAA. 4. Understand the potential tests used for diagnosing AAA. 5. Become acquainted with the management strategies for AAA  both in emergency and non-emergency settings. 6. Learn about the potential complications of untreated AAA.   (Note: This case is designed for educational purposes and is not about a real patient.)

Case Report   Patient Information: Mr. Jack Arnold  a 68-year-old Caucasian male.   Occupation: Retired teacher.  Past Medical History: Former smoker for 30 years (quit smoking 10 years ago). Patient has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol. No history of diabetes mellitus  coronary artery disease  or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Not known with any allergies.   Key Complaint: Mr. Arnold presents to the emergency department with severe  sudden back pain described as tearing  which started a couple of hours ago. He rate it 9/10 on a pain scale. He does not have any other associated symptoms such as chest pain  shortness of breath  nausea  vomiting or loss of consciousness. He also reports intermittent abdominal discomfort over the past six months  which he had previously dismissed as digestive problems.  Physical Appraisal: Mr. Arnold's vitals on admission are as follows; blood pressure: 160/90 mmHg  pulse: 110 bpm  temperature: 37.1°C  respiratory rate: 18 bpm and oxygen saturation: 97% on room air. On physical examination  the patient appears to be anxious and in acute distress. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. An abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass in the midline  which is tender on palpation.  Based on real life statistics  an older male with a history of smoking is a typical demographic for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). In addition  hypertension  high cholesterol and Caucasian ethnicity are established risk factors for AAA. This case is designed to provide an accurate representation of a potential AAA patient  and assist students in identifying and managing AAA in its early stages to prevent rupturing.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Demographics: Mr. Andrew O'Sullivan  is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  a resident of rural Ireland. He is a heavy smoker with 40 pack-year history and a moderate daily alcohol consumer.  Past Medical History: Mr. O'Sullivan has a documented history of hypertension and hyperlipidaemia for the past 15 years  both being managed through medication (ACE inhibitor and Statins accordingly). He refused taking medications for smoking cessation offered repeatedly in the past. There is a familial history of cardiovascular disease: his father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 68. His older brother underwent surgical repair of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) 5 years ago.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. O'Sullivan visits his GP complaining of a strange pulsating feeling in his stomach  which has been persistent for a couple of weeks. He also mentions intermittent  dull lower back pain and unexplained weight loss over the past few months. He denies any bowel  urinary  or lower limb complaints. No associated fever  night sweats  loss of consciousness or traumatic events. No recent changes in medication or over-the-counter drugs have been reported.   Notes: The patient's age  gender  smoking habits  long-standing hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and family history  as well as his symptoms  make him a representative case for AAA according to available epidemiologic data. AAA is most commonly diagnosed in older adults  particularly Caucasian males  and is often associated with genetic predisposition  smoking  and other cardiovascular conditions.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Patient Demographics: Patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a history of smoking. He comes from a middle-class socioeconomic background. The patient is a retired veteran from the military  now leading a sedentary lifestyle.  Past medical history: The patient has been diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia  for which he is currently receiving treatment with antihypertensives and statins  respectively. He has been smoking a pack of cigarettes daily for the past 50 years. He quit alcohol 10 years ago and has limited physical activity due to arthritis. The patient is obese (BMI: 32.5) with no special diet or exercise regimen. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases; his father died due to myocardial infarction  and his elder brother was diagnosed with AAA.  Key Complaints: The patient presented with intermittent abdominal pain which lasted for several hours  following which it subsided on its own. Pain was described as a sharp  tearing sensation radiating to his lower back. No associated symptoms like nausea  vomiting  weight loss  loss of appetite  or any change in bowel habits were reported. The patient also indicated occasional palpitations and shortness of breath during exertion  indicating a potential cardiovascular complication.  Among AAAs  75% occur in males  and 90% happen in those aged 65 and above. Risk factors like smoking  hyperlipidemia  hypertension  age  male sex  sedentary lifestyle  and family history of AAA are consistent with epidemiological data. Although pain in AAAs is typically absent until rupture or dissection  in some cases  abdominal pain can occur  making every case unique and unpredictable. The case is designed in line with accurate demographic representation as found in literature.   [Disclaimer: This Case report is for training purposes only and does not represent actual events or individuals.]

Patient Case:  Demographics: Mr. Thomas Miller  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  widower  retired factory worker  residing in Wisconsin. He is a former smoker with a 50-pack history and quit smoking about 10 years ago. He consumes alcohol socially.   Past Medical History: Mr. Miller suffers from moderate hypertension and high cholesterol. He was diagnosed with peripheral artery disease (PAD) two years ago but never had any coronary artery disease. He has a family history of cardiovascular diseases with his father dying from a myocardial infarction and his older brother from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. He lives alone and has been managing his daily requirements independently. He has been on antihypertensive and lipid-lowering drugs.   Presenting Complaints: Mr. Miller presented at the emergency department with a sudden onset severe 'ripping' pain in his lower back that started a few hours ago along with persistent abdominal pain. He also complained of symptoms like lightheadedness and nausea. He denies further symptoms like chest pain  loss of consciousness  or recent infections.   Note: This case represents the typical characteristics of a patient with abdominal aortic aneurysm. The risk factors associated with AAA include age > 65 years  male sex  Caucasian race  history of cigarette smoking  hypertension  high cholesterol  PAD  and a family history of AAA.   The learning objectives in this case should encompass proper history taking  identification of risk factors  recognizing early symptoms  physical examination for suspected AAA  indication for imaging and labs  understanding the size guide for treatment intervention  and knowledge of possible complications if left untreated.   (Source: Mayo Clinic  MedScape  American Heart Association)

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:  Mr. George Bryant is a 70-year-old Caucasian male; retired construction worker living alone. His wife passed away 5 years ago and he has two adult children living out of state. He is a smoker with 40 pack-years history and drinks alcohol occasionally.   Past Medical History: The patient has a past medical history significant for hypertension  for which he takes lisinopril 10mg daily  and moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) treated with inhalers. He has no history of cardiovascular disease  no surgical history; particularly  he denies any history of abdominal surgery or trauma and has a negative family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Chief Complaint: The patient presented to the general practitioner clinic for a routine check-up. He describes intermittent  dull abdominal pain  and lower back discomfort that has been present for several weeks now. The pain does not get worse with meals. He also notes some unintentional weight loss over the past month but no fever  chills  night sweats  chest pain  shortness of breath  or leg pain.    This case represents a patient demographic with a high risk for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). According to the literature  individuals over the age of 65 who have a history of smoking and hypertension are at a higher risk. Caucasians are more likely to develop AAA than African Americans  and men are more likely to develop AAA than women. Additionally  having a first-degree relative with an AAA increases a person's risk.   It also reflects a common presenting symptom of AAA – pain in the abdomen or back. Pain related to AAA tends to be chronic  steady  and severe—rather than acute and sharp—due to the relatively slow growth rate of the aneurysm which allows the surrounding tissue to gradually adapt to its presence. The nonspecific nature of the symptoms warrant further investigation especially considering the patient’s risk factors.

Case Subject: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information:  Mr. John Smith  a white male  aged 72 years  retired construction worker  who is a lifetime smoker with a pack per day habit (30 pack years).   Past Medical History: He has a history of hypertension for which he takes a low-dose thiazide diuretic and a beta-blocker. His hypertension is usually under moderate control. There is also a history of elevated cholesterol treated with atorvastatin 20mg. No history of surgeries or major illnesses. Family medical history includes heart disease in his father  who experienced a myocardial infarction at 65.   Key Complaints: Over the past few months  he has noticed a dull aching abdominal pain that seems to come and go  as well as moderate low back pain. He reports a recent episode of feeling faint after climbing a flight of stairs. He reports that his appetite is poor and he lost weight over the past few weeks. Moreover  he has experienced several episodes of unexplained fatigue. He visited a primary physician who referred him to the hospital for further workup following the finding of a pulsatile abdominal mass during a routine exam.  This simulated case scenario is representative of the demographic most at risk for abdominal aortic aneurysms: older Caucasian males with a history of smoking and cardiovascular pathology  particularly hypertension. Symptoms like abdominal pain  back pain  unexplained weight loss  episodes of syncope  and an abdominal bruit could potentially indicate the presence of an abdominal aortic aneurysm in such a high-risk individual. The hands-on experience allows medical students to gain a better understanding of the clinical presentations and risks associated with abdominal aortic aneurysms  promoting better patient outcomes in the future.

Chief Complaint: ""Severe abdominal and back pain.""  Patient Information: H.M.  a 68-year-old Caucasian male currently residing in an urban location  was admitted to the emergency department. He is a retired mechanic and has a 40-year history of smoking two packs of cigarettes a day until 5 years ago when he quit. H.M. lives with his wife who is his primary caregiver and is socially active in the community.   Past Medical History: H.M. suffers from hypertension and high cholesterol levels for the past 20 years  managed mostly by medications including Lisinopril and Atorvastatin. He has also been diagnosed with early-stage COPD due to his extended history of smoking. There is no relevant family history of genetic disorders but his father died of myocardial infarction at the age of 72.  Key Complaints:  H.M. was brought to the emergency on the complaint of sudden  severe pain in the lower back and abdominal region. The pain was not relieved by any over-the-counter pain medications. He also reported feeling a pulsating sensation in his abdomen. Neither fever nor trauma history was reported. He also described experiencing episodes of light-headedness and shortness of breath in recent days.  Note: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm predominantly affects the elderly population (65 years and above) and is more common in males. Smoking  hypertension  high cholesterol levels  and diseases causing arterial damage such as atherosclerosis or COPD are major risk factors.

Patient Case Study: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Demographics: Name: John Williams Age: 72 years old Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired carpenter Marital Status: Married Living situation: Lives with his wife in a suburban house   Medical History: Mr Williams has a well-documented medical history of hypertension  which has been managed for the last 15 years with Lisinopril. He is also a former smoker  having quit smoking cigarettes around 10 years ago but reportedly smoked a pack a day for 30 years before quitting. His family history is significant for his father  who died of a stroke at the age of 67. Furthermore  his cholesterol levels are on the higher side  and he has borderline diabetes which is managed through diet and exercise. He does not have any known drug allergies. His only surgery was an appendectomy at the age of 25.  Presenting Complaints: Mr. Williams came to the clinic complaining about a consistent dull pain in his lower back and flanks experienced over the last few weeks. He also reported recent episodes of unexplained weight loss and decreased appetite. On specific questioning  he denied any chest pain  shortness of breath  or syncope. He also denied any changes in bowel or bladder function  or any lower limb pain or weakness.   This case study focusses on abdominal aortic aneurysm  and the patient represents the demographic most commonly affected - older Caucasian males  with a history of smoking and hypertension. The symptoms though non-specific  can be indicative of a slowly expanding abdominal aortic aneurysm. Clinicians should have a high index of suspicion in such cases  considering the risk factors presented.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Demographics: • Patient Initials: J.D. • Age: 72 Years Old • Sex: Male • Race: Caucasian • Occupation: Retired firefighter • Socioeconomic Status: Middle Income • Location: Urban  Northeast United States  Past Medical History: • Hypertension (10 years). • Tobacco use: Heavy smoker for 35 years  quit 8 years ago. • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) - Moderate (7 years). • No known allergies.  Presenting Complaints: • J.D. presented to the clinic with a 4-day history of episodic dull aching abdominal pain. • The pain described as ‘gnawing’ in nature and located in the central and lower part of his abdomen. It feels worse when he's lying flat. • He also reported a sensation of ‘pulsating’ in his abdomen  which he noticed in the last month. • Additional complaints included unintentional weight loss and reduced appetite in the previous 3 months. • He denies any changes in his bowel habits  chest pain  or palpitations.  The selected case focuses on the most vulnerable demographic for abdominal aortic aneurysm according to the literature: older  Caucasian males with a history of smoking and hypertension. Although AAA is sometimes asymptomatic  this scenario presents a case where the patient experiences some of the key complaints associated with the condition – such as abdominal pain and a pulsating sensation in the abdomen  allowing for proper education and training.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired accountant and working part-time as a consultant in the financial sector. He is married and has three grown-up children. He is an ex-smoker who quit around ten years ago and reports moderate alcohol consumption. His BMI is 29  effectively placing him in the overweight category.   Past Medical History: He has a history of hypertension and has been managing it with prescribed antihypertensive medications over the past 15 years. He was diagnosed with hyperlipidemia eight years ago  but it is under control through combination therapy with diet and statins. His father died of a stroke at the age of 73  and his older brother had a myocardial infarction when he was 68. Additionally  he has bilateral osteoarthritis  for which he takes over-the-counter NSAIDs as needed. He had a prostatectomy for benign prostatic hyperplasia five years ago  and since then  reports no significant issues with his urinary system.  Key Complaints: The patient came to the clinic complaining of persistent lower back pain that did not improve with the use of over-the-counter pain medications. He described the pain as a deep  dull ache that isn’t associated with movement  sometimes associated with a pulsating sensation in the mid-abdominal region. Past week  he had episodes of mild nausea and loss of appetite. He denies having any bowel irregularities or any urinary complaints. He also mentioned feeling fatigued more than usual over the past few days. There is no reported trauma or sudden exertive activity that might have caused this back pain.  Note - It's important when teaching this case to elucidate that abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) are common in older individuals  especially in those with a history of smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  or a family history of aneurysms. They are also more common in males and Caucasians. Importantly  an AAA might not present with symptoms until it becomes large or ruptures  at which point it can be life-threatening. Thus  a high index of suspicion is warranted for this patient due to his risk factors and symptoms. A medical history of persistent  unexplained lower back pain or a pulsating sensation in the abdomen should raise suspicion of an AAA. The remaining course should detail how this case is diagnosed and managed.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: Mr. Zachary Smith  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a diagnosis of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia. He has a 40-pack year smoking history but quit five years ago. He has no history of cardiovascular surgery but has a family history of vascular disease; his father died from an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) rupture.  Chief Complaint: Mr. Smith has been attending regular follow-ups at the hypertension clinic. During his most recent visit  he complained of a new  vague  gnawing abdominal pain  mostly after meals and associated with mild back pain. No hemorrhagic signs  syncope  or changes in bowel habits were reported.  Noteworthy  Mr. Smith is a retired attorney and his past medical history is significant for type II diabetes  hypertension  and hypercholesterolemia  managed by Metformin 500 mg bid  Lisinopril 10 mg qd  and Simvastatin 20 mg qd respectively.  Notes: The prevalence of AAA increases with age and it is more common in men than women. Up to 80% of AAA cases are attributable to smoking. Notice that usually  AAAs are asymptomatic until they rupture  then they become a medical emergency with a high mortality rate. However  some patients may report nonspecific abdominal or back pain. This case  therefore  reflects the common demographic of an AAA patient in terms of age  sex  smoking history  and relative symptoms. Additionally  key indicators such as hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and a family history of vascular disease have been considered  as these are recognized risk factors for AAA.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Presentation: Mr. Joseph Martin is a 67-year-old Caucasian male with complaints of intermittent abdominal pain  especially after meals  which has been getting progressively worse over the past two weeks. He describes the pain as a deep  gnawing ache in the middle of his abdomen. Occasionally  he also feels the pain radiating to his back. He has noticed an unusual pulsating sensation in his abdomen  which he describes as a 'heartbeat'. He denies any changes in bowel habits  nausea  vomiting  weight loss  or appetite loss. He denies any history of trauma or injury.  Past Medical History: Mr. Martin has a significant history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and 40 pack-years of smoking. He does not have any known food or drug allergies. He has been on medication for his hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He takes a daily dose of Lisinopril (10 mg)  Amlodipine (5 mg)  and Atorvastatin (20 mg). He is not receiving any anticoagulant therapy. He had a myocardial infarction (heart attack) seven years ago and was stented. He does not have any surgical history.  Family History: Joseph's father died from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 75. His mother lived until her mid-80s  passing away due to complications of Alzheimer's disease. He has one brother who had a stroke at the age of 59.  Social History:  Mr. Martin worked at a shipyard until his retirement five years ago. He is widowed and lives alone but in close proximity to his daughter. He stopped smoking two years ago but reports a significant history of heavy smoking prior to that (2 packs per day for about 40 years). He drinks alcohol socially and denies any illicit drug use.   Reason for visit: Joseph scheduled his visit due to the progressive worsening of his intermittent abdominal and back pain. He expresses worry about his father's history of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He has been managing his discomfort with over-the-counter pain medications with little relief.  This case illustrates a typical presentation of abdominal aortic aneurysm in a high-risk patient given his age  male gender  significant smoking history  and a personal history of atherosclerotic disease. The genetic predisposition should also be taken into account considering his father's history of aneurysm rupture. The vascular examination in this patient should involve palpation of the abdominal aorta and auscultation for possible abdominal bruits.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: Mr. John Baker  a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  presents to his primary care provider with complaints of abdominal pain and lower back discomfort.  Past Medical History: Mr. Baker has been treated for hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past 15 years. He has a 40-pack year smoking history  but quit about 5 years ago. He has no history of diabetes  cancer  or any previous surgeries. He drinks alcohol socially  has no known allergies  and his family history reveals his father died of a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 75.  Presenting Complaints: The patient has been experiencing intermittent  unexplained abdominal pain that seems to resolve spontaneously  only to return after a few weeks. The pain is generally located in the middle and slightly to the left of his abdomen. In recent weeks  he sometimes has a similar discomfort in his lower back.  Mr. Baker reports that the character of the pain is dull and throbbing  not colicky or burning. The pain doesn't seem to get better or worse with meals  different body posture or use of over-the-counter pain relievers. He rates it as 5 on a scale of 0-10 and reports a feeling of fullness in his stomach. He’s noted unintentional weight loss and decreased appetite over the past few months.  Physical Checkup: Vital signs are blood pressure 150/90 mmHg  pulse 85/min  respiratory rate 16/min  and body temperature 37.2°C (99°F). On physical examination  the doctor notes a pulsatile mass in the abdomen and bruit over the area.  This case lends itself to discussing risk factors (age  male gender  smoking  and family history)  symptomatology  and physical findings suggestive of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further  it provides an excellent platform to talk about the importance of regular monitoring and management of blood pressure and cholesterol levels  especially in patients with increased risk for cardiovascular diseases.

Patient Profile: Name: John Doe Age: 73 years old Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Occupation: Retired automobile mechanic  Patient Medical History: Smoker for 50 years  no prior known history of cardiovascular disease  hypertension for long standing (since age 60)  dyslipidemia  and no family history of aneurysms or peripheral vascular disease. Patient is annulled  lives alone  and depends on Social Security for healthcare. He has limited mobility due to osteoarthritis of the knees. No known drug allergies.  Chief Complaint: John came to the Emergency Department due to sudden onset  severe pain in the lower back that started roughly two hours ago. He described it as a tearing  sharp pain  non-radiating  10/10 in intensity  and nothing seems to relieve the pain. He denies any chest pain  shortness of breath  palpitations  or syncope. He also denies any lower extremity weakness  numbness  or loss of bowel or bladder control. He has no recent history of trauma. He also mentioned a slight feeling of fullness in the abdomen and his family noted that he looked pale.  Reason for Training Case: The patient's depiction of severe  sudden pain with a history of smoking and hypertension serve as classical presentations of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). In addition  statistics indicate that Caucasian males over the age of 65  who have smoked  have the highest incidence of AAA. This training case would thereby aim to teach students appropriate management of a potential case of AAA  including the importance of immediate imaging  possibly leading to emergency surgical intervention.

Title: Suspected Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male Patient  Patient Information: John Smith is a 72-year-old Caucasian male living in the city with his wife. Retired from a desk job  he leads a slightly sedentary lifestyle.  Past Medical History: Mr. Smith has a known history of hypertension and high cholesterol levels which have been managed with medication for the past 10 years. He smoked a pack of cigarettes a day for 30 years  but quit ten years ago. He does not consume alcohol. His father passed away at the age of 70 due to an abdominal aortic aneurysm.  Presenting Complaint: Mr. Smith came to the emergency department complaining of sudden  severe pain in his lower back and abdomen  which he described as ""tearing"" or ""ripping"". The pain had started two hours prior to his arrival  and it seemed unrelated to any physical activity. He additionally reported feeling faint and also showed symptoms of nausea.  He stated that unlike his usual hypertension related discomfort  this time the pain began suddenly and it was severe in intensity. He also mentioned he had felt a pulsating sensation in his abdomen for last couple weeks but considered it to be a simple gastric problem.  Given Mr. Smith's age  medical history  family history  and specific symptoms presented  the emergent medical concern for his serious condition is an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Further diagnostic studies  such as an urgent abdominal ultrasound or CT scan  would be needed to confirm this diagnosis.

Patient Case:   Demographics:  Patient is a 73-year-old White male named Joseph  a retired construction worker with a smoking history of 40 pack-years who lives with his wife.  Past Medical History:  He has a history of hypertension controlled on Lisinopril  high cholesterol  and atherosclerosis. No previous surgeries or allergies. Denies alcohol or drug use but has a substantial history of heavy smoking. Family history of cardiovascular disease  his father died of a myocardial infarction at 75.  Key Complaints:  Joseph presents with an intermittent throbbing pain in his lower back and abdomen. The pain started off as dull and mild about a week ago but has been increasing steadily and is now severe. He mentions there were times that the pain radiated towards his groin area. He also complaints about constipation for the last 3 days. He denies any fever  nausea  vomiting  changes in urine or bowel habits. He shares his concern regarding his father's history of heart disease and fears this pain could be heart-related. No recent changes in weight.   These complaints and medical history suggests the suspicion of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). As per the literature  abdominal aortic aneurysm primarily affects older population with a predilection towards males and smokers. It is also associated with cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension and atherosclerosis. In line with these epidemiological aspects  our patient falls within the typical demographic and risk profile for AAA.   The next step will be to perform a physical examination  with an emphasis on the abdominal region. If the suspicion of AAA remains high  confirmatory imaging tests such as an ultrasound  CT  or MRI scan will be ordered.  Learning Objectives for the Medical Student:  1. Understand the risk factors (age  male gender  smoking  hypertension  atherosclerosis) and typical demographic profile for AAA. 2. Recognize the classic presentation with intermittent lower back and abdominal pain. 3. Realize the importance of considering AAA even if the patient does not complain of any symptoms as most AAAs are asymptomatic and found incidentally. 4. Recognize the life-threatening complications of AAA  such as aneurysm rupture. 5. Familiarize with the various diagnostic modalities for AAA. 6. Understand the management options  including behavioral  pharmacological  and surgical interventions.  Reference: 1. Chaikof EL  Brewster DC. The care of patients with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. New England Journal of Medicine. 2003;349(3):210-21.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Demographics:  The patient is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired construction worker  residing in the urban setting of Boston  Massachusetts. He is a long-time smoker with approximately 50 pack-years of exposure to tobacco. He lives with his wife and his alcohol consumption is moderate.  Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of Hypertension  Dyslipidemia  and Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) for which he is on medication including ACE inhibitors  statins  and bronchodilators. He has a known allergy to penicillin. His family history includes his father dying from a myocardial infarction at the age of 75.   Presenting Complaints:  The patient was referred by his primary care physician to the Emergency Department after his routine physical examination showed an abdominal mass that was palpable  pulsatile and tender on the mid to lower abdomen. He reports unintentional weight loss but denies any common symptoms such as abdominal pain  back pain  or leg pain; however  he occasionally experiences dizziness and shortness of breath.  This case is consistent with data suggesting that risk for an abdominal aortic aneurysm increases with age  predominantly affects males  and is more common in the Caucasian population. Other key risk factors include smoking and history of cardiovascular diseases. As per literature  a significant number of cases of abdominal aortic aneurysms are asymptomatic and are often discovered during routine physical examinations.   Note for educator:  Following this brief case presentation  engage students in a discussion inquiring on the necessary further investigations needed such as diagnostic imaging  possible complications  management options (conservative  endovascular repair  open surgery)  and preventive measures for people at risk of abdominal aortic aneurysms.

Case Study: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Patient Information: Mr. John Hall is a 68-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer living with his wife in a suburban setting.  Past Medical History: Mr. Hall has been hypertensive for the last 20 years and has been taking Angiotensin-Converting Enzyme inhibitors prescribed by his primary care physician. He was diagnosed with hypercholesterolemia 5 years ago and has been taking statins since then. He also has a 40 pack-year history of smoking but has quit smoking for the past 2 years. There is a family history of cardiovascular diseases – both his father and grandfather died due to heart attacks in their early 70s.  Chief Complaints: He visited the emergency department with complaints of severe  sudden-onset abdominal pain that radiates to his lower back for the past 6 hours. The intensity of the pain has grown progressively worse. He rates the pain as 8/10 on the pain scale. He denies any nausea  vomiting  chest pain  shortness of breath  or changes in bowel and bladder habits.  Current Medications: 1. Lisinopril 10mg once daily (hypertension) 2. Atorvastatin 20mg once daily (hypercholesterolemia)  Given Mr. Hall’s advanced age  male gender  history of hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  smoking  and familial predisposition  he has significant risk factors for abdominal aortic aneurysm. The sudden severe and increasing abdominal pain  complemented by the back pain  could possibly point towards a rapidly enlarging or rupturing aneurysm.  This case study should help students identify the classic signs and symptoms of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  familiarize them with the risk factors  and help to manage the emergent and challenging nature of the case. The focus should be on an immediate diagnostic evaluation  which usually includes ultrasound or CT scan  and immediate surgical intervention if AAA is confirmed. This is a critical learning case for students to understand the importance of early recognition  urgent diagnosis  and appropriate management for life-threatening conditions like AAA.

Case Report - Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Demographics:  The patient is Mr. James Clark  a 72-year-old Caucasian male living in rural East Texas. He is a retired farmer and a veteran of the Vietnam War. His lifestyle history indicates he has been a habitual smoker with a 50-pack year smoking history and also known to consume alcohol moderately. The patient has been widowed for ten years and currently lives alone.   Past Medical History:  Patient has been diagnosed with Hypertension and hypercholesterolemia that has been managed with medications for the past 15 years. Mr. Clark has a history of peripheral artery disease diagnosed 10 years ago. The patient gave a positive family history of cardiovascular diseases  with his father having died following a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) and his mother from a stroke.   Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Clark walked into the Emergency Department himself with a chief complaint of sudden  severe pain in the lower back and abdomen that started approximately 4 hours before presentation. The pain  according to Mr. Clark  is “tearing” in nature  and he rates the severity as 10/10. Aside from the pain  he reports feeling faint  sweaty  and with increased heartbeats.  This case report is designed to represent the demography commonly diagnosed with AAA  mainly being older  Caucasian males with a history of smoking and cardiovascular disease. When looking at literature  there is a consensus that male gender  age above 65 years  Caucasian race  smoking history  and atherosclerosis ( manifested here as peripheral artery disease  hypertension  high cholesterol) are seen as risk factors for the disease with many also having a familial predisposition.   The symptoms presented by Mr. Clark align with the acute presentation of a potentially rupturing AAA. Sudden onset of severe abdominal pain  commonly described as ""tearing "" is highly suggestive in the proper demographic with predisposing factors. The associated symptoms of faintness and increased heartbeats reflect significant blood loss  a complication of a ruptured aneurysm. This case will help students understand the urgency and the risk involved in dealing with such a clinical scenario. Medical and surgical options should be discussed considering the age  overall health status  and the patient's preference.

Case Report - Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm:  Patient Demographics: Patient's Name: Joseph White  Age: 72 Years Sex: Male  Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired engineer  Past Medical History: - Hypertension diagnosed 15 years ago  on medication  - 40 pack-years history of smoking  quit 5 years ago - Moderate alcohol consumption - No history of diabetes or cardiac diseases - Father died following a ‘ruptured aortic aneurysm’ at age 76  Key Complaints: - Occasional episodes of abdominal pain  described as a deep and gnawing discomfort  felt beneath the chest  not linked to meals  exertion  or posture - Lower back pain radiating to the back of the legs  intermittent  especially prominent after prolonged standing - Unexplained weight loss (around 5 kilos in the past six months) - No signs of chest discomfort or shortness of breath  NOTE:  The demographics  medical history  and symptoms are designed to reflect known epidemiological data about the abdominal aortic aneurysm. Men over 65  particularly those of Caucasian descent  smokers or former smokers  and those with a family history of the condition are at higher risk. Symptoms stated above  especially the pulsating feeling in the abdomen  are common. Although  it's essential to remember that many abdominal aortic aneurysms don't cause symptoms until they rupture.

Patient Information:   Mr. Robert Brown  Caucasian male  72 years old  retired civil engineer  living in the suburban areas with his wife. He has three adult children who live within 1-2 hours' travel distance.  Past Medical History:   Mr. Brown has a documented history of hypertension and hypercholesterolemia for the past 15 years. He is currently being managed on Amlodipine 5mg and Atorvastatin 20mg  respectively. He has a 30-pack year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. His father died following a stroke  and his sister has heart disease. His BMI is 28. He does not engage in regular exercise and reports moderate alcohol consumption. He is not on any anticoagulant or antiplatelet therapy.  Key Complaints:   Mr. Brown visits his general practitioner  complaining of intermittent abdominal pain and a feeling of 'fullness'  specifically after meals  that has been on and off for the last 3 weeks. He complains about occasional lower back discomfort. He denies any nausea  vomiting  changes in bowel movements  or any other gastrointestinal disturbances. He has not experienced any alarming weight change  loss of appetite  or overt mature.  Note:   This case is designed to demonstrate abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). AAA is responsible for 2% of all deaths in men over 65  and the demographic features of the patient (age > 65  male  Caucasian  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  history of smoking  and family history) are consistent with high-risk patients as indicated in the literature.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient information:  Mr. J.  a 68-year-old Caucasian male  presents to the emergency department. He is a retired industrial worker and lives with his wife. He reports being a former smoker of 50 pack-years but quit smoking 10 years ago. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed with medications including atenolol and simvastatin. He does not drink alcohol. He reports no allergies. His family history is suggestive of cardiovascular disease and stroke in his father.  Key complaints:  Mr. J complains chiefly of sudden onset severe pain in the abdominal and back region occurring over the past few hours. He describes the pain as a tearing sensation  constant and not colicky. The pain radiates to his lower back and is not related to posture or movement. He rates his pain as 9/10. He also reports feeling mildly dizzy and sweaty but denies chest discomfort  shortness of breath  difficulty in urinating  or bowel movements.  On Physical Examination:  He is moderately built and well-nourished  appears anxious and slightly pale. His pulse is regular but fast (98 bpm) and blood pressure is high (165/95 mmHg). Examination of his abdomen reveals a pulsating mass in the middle and upper part of the abdomen that's tender on palpation. There is no evidence of peripheral edema.  In this case  the race of the patient is chosen as Caucasian male patient  as Caucasian men over the age of 65 are most often affected by abdominal aortic aneurysms. The history of smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and family history of cardiovascular diseases are significant risk factors in the development of aortic aneurysms. The presented symptoms like sudden severe abdominal and back pain  together with a pulsating abdominal mass  are particularly indicative of abdominal aortic aneurysm as per literature. The case is designed in such a way to train the medical students to make a comprehensive risk assessment  and the potential necessity for surgical interventions based on the symptoms of an abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Case Study: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Profile: • Name: John Anderson • Age: 68 years • Gender: Male • Occupation: Retired postal worker • Race: Caucasian  • Socioeconomic Status: Middle class • Geographical Location: Rural Midwest  Past Medical History: • Hypertension  managed with Lisinopril  • 30-pack-year history of smoking  quit 10 years ago • Family history of cardiovascular disease (Father died of a myocardial infarction at age 57) • Moderate alcohol consumption • No known drug allergies  • No history of pulmonary disease  diabetes  or hyperlipidemia   Present Complaints: • John has been experiencing episodic abdominal pain for the past month. The pain is typically localized in the middle and lower abdomen with occasional radiation to his lower back. • Pain scale is reported as a 6 out of 10  described as a dull and continuous ache exacerbated by eating. • He reports occasional feelings of fullness and discomfort after eating small amounts. • Denies any associated symptoms such as changes in bowel habits  chest pain or dyspnea. No history of urinary complaints. No history of neurological complaints. He also reports unintentional weight loss of approximately 10 lbs over the past two months. • John's primary healthcare provider has noted a pulsatile mass in his abdomen at his most recent annual checkup. • Vital signs: Blood pressure 145/90 mmHg; Pulse rate: 88 beats per minute; Respiratory rate: 16 breaths per minute; Temperature: 98.6°F (37°C); Oxygen saturation: 98% on room air.  Note Regarding Demographics: Abdominal Aortic Aneuryms are more common among males  individuals over the age of 65  those with a history of smoking  and in individuals with a family history of the disease.

Case Report:  Patient Profile:  Name: Robert Williams Age: 75 Sex: Male Race: Caucasian Occupation: Retired military officer   Past Medical History:  Mr. Williams is a former smoker  who quit 20 years ago but had smoked a pack a day for 30 years. He has had a history of high blood pressure which is well controlled with a calcium channel blocker  amlodipine. He also has a history of hyperlipidemia  managed with a statin. He has a family history notable for his father dying at the age of 60 due to a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Williams has not had any symptoms related to AAA. His current complaints were occasional lower back pain  which he had attributed to age and his old army injuries. He sought care from his physician for a regular checkup.  On examination  the physician felt a pulsatile mass in the abdomen. Considering his medical and family history  the physician characterized it as highly suspicious for AAA. The timing of his presentation matched the literature  as AAA tends to occur in the elderly population  more common in males and smokers  and those with a familial history are at increased risk.   This case can be used to educate medical students on the importance of family history and appropriate screening in high-risk population  also detailing how AAA may be asymptomatic until rupture  which often results in death if not treated immediately.

Subject: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) Training Case   Case Patient: Mr. John Lawson  Patient Demographics: - Age: 70 years - Race: Caucasian - Gender: Male - Occupation: Retired  former heavy-duty mechanic - Lifestyle: Non-smoker  drinks alcohol occasionally - Home: Lives alone  active social life with peers  Past Medical History: - Hypertension diagnosed at 50 - Coronary artery disease  underwent Coronary artery bypass graft surgery (CABG) 5 years ago. - Controls blood pressure with lifestyle interventions and antihypertensive medications - Lipid profile: LDL slightly elevated; HDL borderline low - Family history: Father died at 72 due to AAA rupture  mother has hypertension  Presenting Complaints: - Mild to moderate abdominal pain  described as a deep  gnawing pain  positioned centrally and slightly to the right  felt for last 1 month. - Occasionally the pain radiates to the lower back. - Episodic bouts of extreme fatigue. - Loss of appetite  resulting in unintentional weight loss.   Investigation: Further imaging and diagnostic tests will need to be carried out to confirm suspected AAA  discuss required lifestyle changes  potential endovascular surgery  or open repair depending on the size and growth rate of the aneurysm.   Discussion Points: - Link between patient's age  gender  family history  and likelihood of AAA. - Importance of recognizing typical and atypical symptoms of AAA. - Connection between hypertension  coronary artery disease  and the risk of developing AAA. - Effects of race and ethnicity on the risk of developing AAA. - Role of primary care in diagnosing AAA  initiating early management strategies  including lifestyle changes and  if necessary  referring for specialist care. - Appropriate management strategies in AAA including the risks and benefits of different surgical interventions. - Regular follow-ups for patients who have or are at risk of developing AAA.  The key to this teaching case is how Mr. Lawson's case demonstrates typical risk factors and signs of AAA  thus providing a deeper understanding of the condition and the comprehensive care needed to manage it.

Case Study - Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Patient Demographics: Mr. Robert is an 80-year-old Caucasian male. He is retired  married  and is an ex-smoker with a 60 pack-year history. He has no significant alcohol history but reported a sedentary lifestyle. He is a retired truck driver and lives with his wife in a suburban area.  Past Medical History: Mr. Robert has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidaemia. He was diagnosed with these conditions in his late 50s and has been on medication since. His hypertension is relatively well controlled but has occasional spikes. He also has a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) secondary to his smoking history  for which he requires inhaler therapy. He has no history of diabetes  stroke  or heart conditions  but there is a familial history of cardiovascular misadventures  including his father passing away from a heart attack at a similar age.  Key Complaints: Mr. Robert came to his doctor's office complaining of intermittent  yet persistent lower back and abdominal pain for the last couple of months. The pain has been non-radiating  dull and vague  often described as a gnawing feeling that is unrelated to meals or physical activities. More recently  the patient admits to feeling a pulsing sensation in his abdomen. He has had no changes in bowel habit  no weight loss  and no other urinary or bowel symptoms.  The complaints suggested by Mr. Robert are typical for asymptomatic AAA  constituting abdominal pain and a pulsatile abdominal mass. According to the literature  risk factors for AAA correlate with Mr. Robert's profile  notably  being over 65  a male  Caucasian  having a history of smoking  family history of AAA  and hypertension (Upchurch & Schaub  2006). Therefore  this case study  centered on such a patient  will help medical students understand the risk factors  presentation  and management of AAA more effectively.   Reference: Upchurch  G. R.  & Schaub  T. A. (2006). Abdominal aortic aneurysm. American Family Physician  73(7)  1198-1204.

Patient Profile:  Mr. John Cook  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  retired military veteran. He is a lifetime non-smoker  but has a history of moderate alcohol consumption.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Cook has a medical history of hypertension for 20 years  which is well-managed by Lisinopril. He was diagnosed with borderline hyperlipidemia a decade ago. His father passed away at 77 due to complications following an aortic aneurysm rupture. John does not have a history of Marfan or Ehlers-Danlos syndrome  trauma  or syphilis - conditions known to have an association with aortic aneurysms. Routine physical examinations and blood work have been consistent and within normal limits over the years  given his age and medical conditions.  Presenting Complaints:  John visited the clinic with a 2-week history of persistent abdominal and lower back pain  which he described as a dull ache. These symptoms were not associated with food intake or physical activity. Also  he complained about a feeling of ""fullness"" in his stomach even when he hadn't eaten. He also mentioned unintentional weight loss over the last few months.  Family History:  John's father had abdominal aortic aneurysm. His mother  who is 88 years old  has been diagnosed with osteoporosis and hypertension. He has two siblings; a brother aged 70 with a medical history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and a sister  68 years old  healthy with no known diseases.  Reason for Focus:  The case focuses on abdominal aortic aneurysm  which are most commonly seen in males over the age of 60. At this age group  the incidence is higher in Caucasians  smokers  hypertensive individuals  and those with family history of AAA. This case provides a typical presentation of an unruptured AAA with symptoms including persistent abdominal and lower back pain. Understanding and recognizing these symptoms are crucial for early diagnosis and management of this potentially fatal condition.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Patient Information:  - Patient Initials: M.B. - Age: 72 years old. - Sex: Male. - Race: white - Occupation: Retired teacher.  Medical history:  M.B. has a medical history tracking back decades ago  which includes hypertension  high cholesterol  and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He used to be a heavy smoker but quit 6 years ago due to COPD. He had no previous surgeries  keeps up-to-date on health screenings  and has never had a personal or familial history of AAA.   Present Complaints:  M.B. came into the doctor’s office complaining of persistent  unusual lower back pain that he originally pegged as something related to pulled muscles from gardening. However  this pain persisted and he has also noticed an occasional pulsating sensation in his abdomen around the navel. He regularly checks his BP at home and notes that it has been consistently higher than usual in the last few weeks. He denies any drastic weight loss  loss of appetite  or recent change in bowel habits.   This case reflects the general demographic that is commonly affected by abdominal aortic aneurysms – mostly older adults  particularly men  and those with a history of cardiovascular conditions or smoking. M.B.’s troubling symptom  the pulsating sensation in his abdomen  commonly points towards an AAA  matching perfectly with his demographic and patient history for high-risk factors of AAA. Through this case study  medical students can understand the typical presentation of an AAA in a patient and predict the probable next steps for diagnosing and managing AAA in such patients.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Presentation:  Mr. J.A  is a 66-year-old Caucasian male. He is a retired electrician  referred to the outpatient surgery clinic by his primary care physician.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a 44-pack year smoking history  having smoked one pack per day for 44 years  which he quit approximately two years ago. However  he does not have any history of other cardiovascular disease and diabetes mellitus. He also has no any familial history of aneurysmal disease.  Chief Complaint: The patient presents with intermittent lower back pain for the last four months  which he primarily attributes to age and his prior physically strenuous occupation. The pain does not radiate and is not associated with activity. Recently  he noticed an increase in the intensity of the pain and experienced an episode of light-headedness which prompted a visit to his primary care doctor.  Considerations:  Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) incidence is higher in males  Caucasians  and individuals over 60 years of age. Risk factors include smoking history  hypertension  and familial history of the disease. Hypertension and smoking are particularly important factors for AAA and must be explored in patient's past medical history. For demographic representations  Caucasians are selected which should educate learners regarding the higher incidence of AAA in this population.   Next Steps: Teaching should focus on ordering appropriate investigations  interpreting the results  and discussing a management plan with the patient. This should include an ultrasound or a computed tomography (CT) scan to confirm the diagnosis and determine the size of the aneurysm  monitoring or surgical intervention depending on the size and rate of growth of the aneurysm  and risk factor management including smoking cessation  hypertension  and hyperlipidemia control.

Patient Information:   Mr. Eugene Johnson  an 82-year-old white male  is currently living with his daughter and son-in-law after his wife passed away last year. His occupation was a coal miner before his retirement  indicating potential occupational exposure. He has a record of moderate smoking and had been a regular alcohol consumer until his late 50s. He is relatively sedentary and does not engage in any regular exercises.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has a history of hypertension  which is reasonably well controlled on amlodipine and atenolol. He has a high cholesterol level but no diagnosed history of cardiovascular disease. He does not have diabetes  but he has COPD likely secondary to his past smoking and work exposure. He's been on inhaled corticosteroids and bronchodilators to manage his COPD.  Presenting Complaint:  He visits the clinic with a complaint of ""unusual"" pulsating sensation in his abdomen for past few weeks  associated with intermittent  vague  mild lower abdominal pain. The pulsations get sometimes more noticeable when lying flat. He denies any radiation of pain towards back  chest pain  syncopal episodes  or significant weight loss. No bowel or bladder disturbances have been noticed  and he has not felt feverish or overly tired. He also mentions that he cannot recall any significant changes to his diet or bowel movements.  The clinical vignette as mentioned above is purposefully designed to include demographics & risk factors typically associated with abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) - age over 60  male gender  history of smoking  hypertension  and presence of COPD. The incidence of AAA tends to be higher in white populations.  Clinical suspicion should be raised with his unusual complaint of abdominal pulsations  which is not common in the general population but is noticed in >80% of AAA. His intermittent lower abdominal pain  although nonspecific  may potentially indicate early symptoms of AAA expansion or imminent rupture.   However  due to the often asymptomatic presentation of AAA until critical stages  heightened clinical suspicion based on associated risk factors and certain nonspecific symptoms is key in making an early diagnosis and managing this condition effectively and promptly.

Case Study: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Patient Information:  Mr. Hernandez is a 65-year-old Caucasian male of Hispanic ethnicity living in a suburban setting. This particular demographic has been chosen as the incidence of AAA is often reported highest in Caucasian males above 65 years and people of Hispanic ethnicity also have a significant predisposition to AAA.   Past Medical History:  The patient has a known history of long-term smoking of about 30 pack years and moderate alcohol use until 5 years ago. He was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia 10 years back and is on antihypertensive medications - Amlodipine (5mg/day) and Atorvastatin (20mg/day) respectively. He was found to have type 2 diabetes mellitus 7 years ago and is under Metformin (500mg twice a day). He had an inferior wall myocardial infarction 3 years back and underwent stenting. No known history of AAA in the family.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Hernandez visited his primary care physician complaining of a persistent dull and vague pain in his lower back and lower abdomen for the past 3 weeks. He also mentioned occasional constipation and slight difficulty in urination. In addition  he reported feeling a pulsatile mass in his stomach.   However  he doesn’t have any symptoms of leg pain  claudication  or rapid increase in the abdominal girth. He denied any chest pain  palpitations  or shortness of breath. There is no history of fever  chills  or nausea/vomiting.  Assessment:  Further investigations are warranted given the risk factors and the symptoms Mr. Hernandez has reported. An initial physical exam and subsequent abdominal ultrasound or CT angiography could be considered to check for the presence of an AAA. A team-based approach involving the primary care physician  radiologist  and vascular surgeon would be appropriate for comprehensive care and decision-making.  The prime objective of this case study would be to demonstrate the early detection of AAA  the significance of clinical acumen in reaching diagnosis  and the long-term management of AAA.  References:  1. Sampson UK et al; Global and regional burden of aortic dissection and aneurysms: mortality trends in 21 world regions  1990 to 2010. Global Heart. 2014; 9(1):171-80.   2. Reimerink JJ et al; Systematic review and meta-analysis of population-based mortality from ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. Br J Surg. 2013; 100(11):1405-13.   3. United States Census Bureau data.  4. Dua A et al; Epidemiology of aortic aneurysm repair in the United States from 2000 to 2010. J Vasc Surg. 2014; 59(6):1512-7.

Patient Information:   - Name: John Smith - Age: 72 - Gender: Male  - Occupation: Retired teacher - Ethnicity: Caucasian - Marital Status: Married - Number of children: 2  Medical History:  - Hypertension for the past 10 years  on treatment - Moderate smoker for 40 years  20 cigarettes/day on average  quit 10 years ago  Key Complaints:  - Presents with a sudden intense pain in the lower back and abdomen which started around two hours ago. - The pain is described as a pulsating feeling in his stomach area  around the navel. - Light-headedness and signs of shock (pallor  increased heart rate). - Additionally  patient mentions noticeable weight loss over the past few months.  Summary:  This training case involves a 72-year old Caucasian male retiree with a history of hypertension and long-term tobacco use. He presents with sudden onset of severe lower back and abdominal pain described as pulsating around his navel  along with signs of shock and recent weight loss. This case should prompt medical students to consider a diagnosis of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA)  especially taking into account his demographic profile (age  male  Caucasian) and risk factors (hypertension and history of smoking). The case encourages students to outline the proper diagnostic steps  including physical examination and imaging studies  as well as to discuss the treatment options appropriate for the patient's condition.

Case Study: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Description:  Mr. Alfredo Rodriguez is a 70-year-old Hispanic male presenting at your clinic for his annual medical checkup. He has an occupational history as a long-term heavy-duty truck driver  which significantly involves sedentary lifestyle. He has been a chain smoker for the last 50 years  but he claims he is trying to quit. He lives with his wife in a rural area with minimal access to quality health care.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Rodriguez was diagnosed with both hypertension and high cholesterol 10 years ago. Despite his condition  he has not been adherent to his treatments or routinely monitored his health status. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease; his father died of a heart attack at age 76  and his older sister suffers from peripheral arterial disease.  Presenting Complaints:  During the last two weeks  he has been experiencing intermittent  nagging abdominal pain and occasional lower back ache since a month. Initially  he associated it with his longstanding chronic gastritis and ignored it. However  recently the pain progressively increased in intensity  along with feelings of fullness in his abdomen  which pushed him to come for this appointment.   Key Note:  This case report is representative of the key demographic most likely to experience an Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA). According to research  men  especially those over the age of 65  are at a higher risk of developing AAA. AAA are more common in white populations  but that does not exclude it from other races. Other risk factors which are represented in this case include long-term smoking  hypertension  high cholesterol  a family history of AAA  and a history of heart disease.     The case study doesn't not just focus on diagnosis and treatment  but also emphasizes the importance of routine health checks  managing risk factors (such as smoking cessation)  and the potential risks of inaccessible or inadequate healthcare  particularly in rural areas. The character in this case also fits into the higher risk scenario due to his old age  Hispanic origin  and male gender  making the case more realistic and inclusive.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics:   Name: Mr. John Peterson   Age: 72 years   Sex: Male   Race: Caucasian   Occupation: Retired Military Staff   Geographic location: Rural Midwest  Past Medical History: - Hypertension for the past 15 years  managed by beta-blockers - Moderate smoker for 45 years (30 pack years) - Treated for high cholesterol for a decade - Family history of aortic aneurysm (deceased brother)  Key Complaints: Patient came to the hospital complaining of: - Lower back pain  described as a deep  throbbing constant ache  scoring 7/10 on the pain scale  with a duration of two weeks. - The related discomfort is causing him to have distal radiating pain toward the groin area. - He also expresses episodes of alarming lightheadedness  particularly upon sudden standing. - Recently noticed unexplained weight loss - No complaints of fever  nausea  vomiting or changes in bowels or urine. - Denies any form of chest pain or shortness of breath.  Note: The patient’s signs and symptoms along with the demographic profile characterized by his age  gender  smoking history  and family history are highly suggestive of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA). AAA has been found to occur more frequently in older males  particularly those with family history  hypertension  and history of smoking. AAA most frequently occurs in the white population and its prevalence is noted to increase with age. More than 80% of individuals affected by this condition are over 65 years old. All these should guide students toward the suspicion of AAA as they encounter such cases.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: Mr. Wilson  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  was admitted to the emergency room.  Past Medical History: He has been known to have hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past 10 years  controlling both conditions with medications. He quit smoking 5 years ago but had a 45-year history of tobacco use. No history of diabetes. Family history reveals that his father died of a ruptured aortic aneurysm in his late 70s.  Presenting Complaints: The patient arrived at the ER as an urgent admittance  complaining of severe  sudden onset abdominal pain radiating to his back. He described his pain as ""tearing."" He has been feeling faint and has had profuse sweating. He also reported episodes of claudication (leg pain/cramping triggered by activity) in recent months. No palpable mass was initially felt upon physical examination  potentially due to the patient’s large body habitus. Assessment of the patient's heart revealed a regular rhythm with no murmurs  rubs  or gallops.  Given the demographic propensity  the high-risk factors such as the history of nicotine use  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  family history indicative of AAA  and the classic symptoms described by the patient  an abdominal aortic aneurysm was immediately suspected.   NOTE: Literature often cites Caucasian males over the age of 65  especially those with a history of smoking  as having a higher risk of developing abdominal aortic aneurysms. A family history of AAA also increases the risk. The patient’s symptoms of sudden  severe abdominal pain  back pain  dizziness  and claudication further facilitate a swift diagnosis. It's recommended that the role play includes accurate representation of these facts and necessary investigations to confirm the diagnosis (i.e.  abdominal ultrasonography  CT scan) followed by management (i.e.  possible surgical repair if the aneurysm is large or symptomatic).

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information: Mr. John S.  a 70-year old Caucasian male  Past Medical History: Mr. S is a former smoker  having smoked for 20 years before quitting at the age of 50. He has a significant past medical history including hypertension managed by thiazide diuretics  hyperlipidemia managed with statins  and a family history of cardiovascular health issues. His father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm. He leads a sedentary lifestyle and has a BMI falling in the obese category. He doesn't consume alcohol  has no known allergies and is compliant with his medications.  Chief Complaint:  Mr. S presented to the ER with the chief complaint of severe abdominal pain radiating to his back that started several hours ago. He articulates that the pain is a strong  ripping feeling that started suddenly. He also describes feeling light-headed and faint.  Upon initial assessment  vital signs are as follows: BP is reading low at 90/60 mmHg  heart rate is slightly elevated at 85 bpm  respiratory rate sits at 20/min  temperature is normal at 37.1C  and O2 saturation at 95% on room air. No previous record of blood pressure measurements is found. Patient appears anxious and slightly diaphoretic  but otherwise has no external signs of injuries or distress.  Considering the patient's age  past personal and medical histories  as well as the primary symptoms  an abdominal aortic aneurysm is a top diagnostic differential.   This case is based on demographic and clinical characteristics found in literature for patients with abdominal aortic aneurysms. The incidence of abdominal aortic aneurysms is higher among males  typically individuals older than 65 years. Main risk factors include smoking  hypertension  and a family history of the condition. The classic triad of an aneurysm rupture  which occurs in about half of the cases  includes abdominal pain  hypotension  and a palpable abdominal mass. However  this triad is not always complete in every patient  as noticeable in this case. The aim will be to stabilize the patient and arrange for urgent confirmatory tests and imaging.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Profile: - Name: Mr. White - Gender: Male - Age: 68 years  - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired military officer  Past Medical History: Mr. White is a former smoker who quit 15 years ago but has a long history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia; both conditions have been managed with life-style modifications and medications. He has a previous history of 40-pack years smoking. He has no known drug allergies. There is a family history of cardiovascular disease  with both his father and older brother succumbing to myocardial infarction in their mid to late 60s.
