He is currently on antihypertensive medication (Lisinopril) and a statin (Atorvastatin) for cholesterol control.   Presenting Complaints: Mr. White presents to the clinic with an asymptomatically noticed pulsatile mass in his abdomen. He also mentions feeling a pulse in his stomach and lower back pain that comes and goes but dismisses it as age-related. Occasionally  the pain radiates to his groin and hip. On further probing  he reveals experiencing unintentional weight loss and decreased appetite over the past few months.   Demographic Consideration: The choice of a Caucasian male aged above 65 aligns with known demographic representation in literature. Older age  male gender  history of smoking  hypertension  and family history of cardiovascular disease are significant risk factors for the development of abdominal aortic aneurysm (Kumar et al.  2018).   Reference: Kumar  Y.  Hooda  K.  Li  S.  Goyal  P.  Gupta  N.  & Adegboyega  P. (2018). Abdominal aortic aneurysm: Pictorial review of common appearances and complications. Annals of translational medicine  6(12)  256.

Case report:  Patient Demographics: The patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male. The patient is a retired construction manager and lives with his wife. He has a 45 pack-year smoking history and has a BMI of 29. He reports moderate alcohol use. He's got a limited activity level due to chronic lower back pain.   Past Medical History: His medical history includes hypertension  which he has been struggling with for the past 12 years; hyperlipidemia  for which he is on statin and omega-3 treatment; type 2 diabetes  controlled by Metformin; and osteoarthritis. He has had a prior myocardial infarction 5 years ago for which he underwent percutaneous coronary intervention and is on Aspirin and Clopidogrel. The patient's father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at the age of 68.   Key Complaints: The patient came to the emergency department reporting an acute onset of severe abdominal pain  which he rated as 8/10. The pain is central and radiates to his lower back  which he described as different from his chronic lower back pain. He also mentions lightheadedness and feelings of faintness. He has not experienced any vomiting  fever  or changes in bowel movements.   This case was designed to represent typical presentations of abdominal aortic aneurysms  keeping in line with usual demographics: older age  male sex  prior history of smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  diabetes  and a family history of AAA. Persistent or severe abdominal and lower back pain in older patients with these risk factors should prompt consideration of an AAA. Early diagnosis and intervention are crucial to reduce mortality.

Patient Profile: Gender: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian Age: 70 Occupation: Retired banker Low-income background  Medical History:  Smoker for 50 years  quit smoking 5 years ago. History of hypertension managed with antihypertensives. Has a family history of cardiovascular diseases.  Presenting Complaint:  The patient approaches the emergency room complaining about severe  sudden onset abdominal pain that radiates to his lower back  lasting for a few hours. He also reports feeling faint  accompanied by cold  sweaty skin. He denies bowel or bladder dysfunction  fever  cough  or chest pain.   The above case represents a typical demographic profile for abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) – elderly  smoking history  hypertension  and male gender  as these are significant risk factors. AAA is more common in Caucasian males  while its prevalence among females is lower and women generally present at an older age. Smoking history  hypertension  and family history of cardiovascular disease fill threaten to increase the risk of AAA. Although the patient quit smoking  the extended length of previous smoking history is still a significant risk factor. The sudden onset of severe abdominal pain radiating to the lower back is classic for a rupturing AAA  though it should be noted many AAAs are asymptomatic until rupture.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Patient Demographics: Mr. Grant is a 71-year-old Caucasian male presented to the clinic by himself. He is a retired engineer and a widower living with his daughter’s family in the same city. He has a history of smoking (30 pack years)  but quit 10 years ago. Mr. Grant is also a veteran with exposure to Agent Orange during the Vietnam War. Having Medicare coverage  he has an inconsistent follow-up history due to frequent travels after retirement.   Past Medical History: Mr. Grant was previously diagnosed and treated for Hypertension and Hyperlipidemia 20 years ago and has been managing the conditions with a combination of dietary adjustments and medication (Lisinopril 10mg daily and Atorvastatin 20mg daily). He also has a history of Moderate Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD) secondary to smoking  managed with inhaled corticosteroids. There is a familial history of heart disease; his father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 78.  Key Complaints: Mr. Grant presented with the chief complaint of intermittent  dull  and non-radiating abdominal pain for the past week. The pain seems to be located around the navel area. He previously attributed it to indigestion but became concerned because it has been persistent. He has been experiencing mild lower back pain as well. Furthermore  he reports a feeling of ""fullness"" in his stomach after eating just a small amount of food  decreased appetite  but no weight loss  nausea  or vomiting. He denies any change in bowel habits  visible blood in stool  urinary symptoms  or fever. On questioning  he reports some dizziness and fatigue  but no chest pain or shortness of breath. Apart from these  he presented no other symptoms.  (Note: This case was designed to be representative of the usual demographic of patients who get AAA  which is more common in men  particularly those over the age of 65 with a history of smoking. Additional risk factors which are taken into account include hypertension  hyperlipidemia  family history of heart disease  veterans with exposure to Agent Orange  and Caucasian descent.)

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Patient Demographics: The patient is an 80-year-old Caucasian man  retired and living independently. He has a 50-year history of smoking two packs of cigarettes per day and consumes moderate amounts of alcohol. His BMI is 28  which is on the higher side of the normal range.   Past Medical History: His medical history includes hypertension and hyperlipidemia  both of which are controlled with medications for the past 10 years. He has prior history of occasional bouts of abdominal and lower back pain as well as frequent heartburn  for which he takes over-the-counter antacids. He had colonoscopy 5 years ago with no significant findings. He has no known allergies  no previous hospitalizations or surgeries. His family history is significant for cardiovascular disease; his father died from myocardial infarction at age of 72. He is a widower and lives with his daughter.  Chief Complaint: The patient presented to the Emergency Department with complaints of a sudden onset of severe abdominal pain  radiating to his lower back. The pain was described as a tearing sensation  8/10 in severity. It started while he was gardening and has been constant since then  not relieved by rest.  Given the patient's demographics  smoking history  co-existing vascular risk factors and clinical complaints  an abdominal aortic aneurysm is quite likely. Studies suggest that AAA are more common in older men  especially above 65 years  and incidence is higher amongst Caucasians  smokers  and those with a family history.  Note: This case represents a classical presentation of an abdominal aortic aneurysm  which is essentially a silent condition in most cases. It is designed for medical education purposes and is not intended to cover all possible clinical presentations of AAA.

Case Report  Patient Details: Mr. John Little  a Caucasian male  aged 72  from a middle-class background. He is a retired construction worker and has a history of heavy smoking of about 30 years but quit 10 years ago. He moderately consumes alcohol  averaging 2-3 drinks per day. His family history reveals that his father died at the age of 80 from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA).   Past Medical History: Mr. Little has been previously diagnosed with essential hypertension and mild chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). He is on drugs for his hypertension and uses bronchodilators for his COPD. There was a transient ischemic attack (TIA) 5 years ago  but he has not had a repeat episode. He has a body mass index (BMI) of 27 Kg/m2 and his medical records indicate occasional elevated cholesterol levels.  Key Complaints: The patient came to the outpatient department complaining about intermittent abdominal and low-back pain persisting for a couple of weeks. His pain is manifested as a dull ache and he occasionally experiences a pulsating sensation in his stomach. He reports no fever  trauma  nausea  or vomiting. Moreover  he has reported no blood in his stool or violent coughing but admits to feeling fatigued lately.  Context: Current data suggests that Caucasians  particularly males over 65 years old who have a smoking history  are at a higher risk group for abdominal aortic aneurysm. A positive family history also increases the risk. It is found that hypertension  COPD  and older age can increase the likelihood of AAA diagnosis and rupture. Mostly  AAAs are asymptomatic  but patients may present with vaguely defined abdominal or back pain. Therefore  Mr. Little’s presentation is quite characteristic of a possible AAA. This case can be used to discuss screening options  diagnosis  potential complications  and management of AAA considering the patient's profile  risks  and symptoms.

Case Report:  Patient Demographics: Mr. John Hamilton is a 70-year-old Caucasian male who resides in a suburban region. He is a retired mechanic  married with three grown-up children. Mr. Hamilton is a smoker and has been smoking one pack a day for the past 45 years. He stands at 5'8"" and weighs around 185 lbs  indicating a BMI of 28.1  which is in the overweight range.   Past Medical History: Mr. Hamilton has hypertension  managed by Metoprolol 50 mg once daily for the past ten years. His blood pressure has been reasonably controlled  generally staying within the 130/80-140/90 mmHg range. Additionally  he has hyperlipidemia for which he is on Atorvastatin 20 mg daily over the last six years. Other than these  he has no history of any other notable condition like diabetes  renal disease or cardiac issues. He has no known drug allergies. His father died at the age of 75 due to a ruptured AAA.  Key Complaints: Mr. Hamilton visited the clinic today complaining of consistent but tolerable abdominal pain that has persisted for the last two weeks. The pain is described as a deep  steady pain located in the central abdominal area  radiating to the back at times.  According to a study by Kent KC  abdominal aortic aneurysms occur predominantly in the elderly population  primarily Caucasians  with a significant history of smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a family history of AAA (Kent KC  2014)  similar to Mr. Hamilton's demographics and past medical history. The presentation of radiating abdominal pain is also a common symptom of AAA.  This case has been designed to serve as an educational tool  focusing on the identification  assessment  and management of abdominal aortic aneurysm in elderly patients  emphasizing the importance of early detection and intervention to prevent complications such as rupture.  Reference: Kent KC. (2014). Abdominal aortic aneurysms. The New England journal of medicine  371(22)  2101–2108. https://doi.org/10.1056/NEJMra1401541

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Information  - Name: John Doe - Age: 73 years old - Sex: Male - Race: Caucasian - Occupation: Retired truck driver  Past Medical History: Mr. Doe has a history of high blood pressure and high cholesterol levels well-managed on medication. He is also a current smoker with a 40-pack year smoking history and has a history of moderate alcohol consumption. There is no family history of cardiovascular disease. He is not physically active and has been overweight for much of his adult life.  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Doe presented to his primary care physician with complaints of intermittent and unpredictable abdominal pain for the past few weeks. The pain is localized to the middle and lowers part of the abdomen and sometimes radiates to the back. The pain is dull  not severe  and lasts for several minutes before subsiding. There are no aggravating or relieving factors. He has also been feeling light-headed at times but has not fainted. He denies any chest pain  cough  or shortness of breath.  Physical Examination:  Mr. Doe is alert and oriented. His blood pressure measured in the office was 154/92 mmHg on two separate occasions. His pulse is regular at 85 beats per minute. Abdominal examination reveals a pulsatile mass in the mid-abdominal area  which corresponds to the location of his pain. There is no bruit heard over the abdominal mass. The remainder of his physical exam is unremarkable.  This case is designed to represent the most common demographic and risk factors associated with abdominal aortic aneurysm including male sex  Caucasian race  age over 65 years  a history of smoking  high blood pressure  and high cholesterol. The key presenting symptoms of unpredictable abdominal pain  the feeling of light-headedness  and pulsatile abdominal mass should point the medical students towards AAA as a working diagnosis.  References:  ""Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia"". Medlineplus.Gov  2021  https://medlineplus.gov/ency/article/000162.htm.  ""Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm - Symptoms and Causes"". Mayo Clinic  2021 https://www.mayoclinic.org/diseases-conditions/abdominal-aortic-aneurysm/symptoms-causes/syc-20350688.

Patient Information: Mr. Williams  a 72-year-old African-American man  retired professional.  Chief Complaint: “I have been having a nagging mild pain in my lower back and abdomen for the last few weeks. Recently  the pain has grown more intense intermittently.”  Past Medical History: Mr. Williams is a former smoker (80 pack/year history)  quit 10 years ago. He has been living with well-managed hypertension and hyperlipidemia for the past 15 years and is currently under medication. He suffers from mild COPD due to his past history of smoking. He does not have any history of major surgical past. He lives by himself and enjoys a continually active social life. His diet is of concern  which is primarily composed of processed food with high-sodium content.  Family History: His father passed away at the age of 77 due to an 'abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture.' His mother died at 84 due to stroke complications. He has an elder brother who was diagnosed with an abdominal aortic aneurysm at the age of 75.  Physical Examination: Vital signs show slightly elevated BP at 145/90  heart rate at 78 bpm  respiratory rate at 16 breaths per minute  and oxygen saturation of 97% on room air. Examination reveals a pulsatile abdominal mass on palpation.  Considering the the patient's demographic profile  age  and significant risk factors such as a positive family history of abdominal aortic aneurysm  history of smoking  hypertension and hyperlipidemia  a preliminary diagnosis of abdominal aortic aneurysm is made pending further diagnostic investigations.  This case gives an opportunity to discuss the risk factors  clinical presentation and the role of family history in diseases like abdominal aortic aneurysm. It also allows the learner to correlate the chief complaints with the possible diagnosis while acknowledging the role and importance of taking a detailed family history in diagnosis. This also gives the chance to discuss steps for further diagnosis and management plan in such cases.

Case Report:  Patient Information: Mr. Edward Mitchell  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  Presenting Concerns: Mr. Mitchell came to the clinic complaining of sudden  severe abdominal and lower back pain. The pain is described as a constant  sharp sensation  not easing in any position or during rest. It's accompanied by a faint pulsating feeling in his abdomen.  Past Medical History: He has a history of hypertension  managed with beta-blockers and angiotensin converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors for the past ten years. He smokes a pack of cigarettes daily for about 50 years. He had a surgical history of an appendectomy about 20 years ago. There is also a family history of aneurysms  with his father dying from a ruptured abdominal aorta. Mitchell is about 20 pounds overweight  and his diet is high in sodium and low in fruits and vegetables.  Socioeconomic Details & Lifestyle: Mr. Mitchell is a retired locksmith and lives with his wife in a suburban area. His alcohol consumption is limited to social occasions.  Epidemiology: According to studies  abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) are predominantly seen in older adults  particularly men aged 65-75  and are more common in Caucasians compared to other races. Risk factors include hypertension  smoking  male gender  genetic predisposition  and a history of vascular disease. The case of Mr. Mitchell is representative of these epidemiological findings.   Points for discussion: - Importance of considering AAA in older  male patients presenting with abdominal or back pain. - Roles of smoking and hypertension in the development of AAA. - Relevance of family history in AAA. - Potential management and treatment strategies for AAA.

Patient Case: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Patient Information:   Mr. John Smith is a 72-year-old Caucasian male  widower and retired construction worker.   Past Medical History:   Mr. Smith has a 30-year history of hypertension  and type II diabetes mellitus for 15 years. He is obese with a body mass index of 32. He is a former smoker but ceased smoking 10 years ago after a 40-pack-year history. He has a family history of cardiovascular disease  his father died from myocardial infarction in his 60s  and his older brother was diagnosed with AAA and had repair surgery a few years ago.   Chief Complaint:   Mr. Smith presents to the clinic with a complaint of intermittent  vague abdominal discomfort mostly in the lower abdomen over the past two weeks. He says it feels like a dull ache and has been happening mostly after meals  which he initially presumed to be indigestion. He denies any sharp or darting pain  fever  nausea or vomiting  loss of appetite  or change in bowel habits. However  he has noticed a pulsating sensation in his abdomen  along with occasional lightheadedness.   Rationale:   The patient's advanced age  male sex  history of hypertension  smoking  family history of AAA  and Caucasian ethnicity are risk factors for abdominal aortic aneurysm as represented in the literature. This clinical presentation draws a large differential diagnosis  but given his intrinsic risk  a high suspicion for AAA is warranted.

Patient Case: Mr. John Caldwell  Demographics:   John Caldwell is a 70-year-old Caucasian male presenting at the emergency department. He is a retired mechanical engineer  who lives independently with his wife in an urban setting. He is a former smoker  with a smoking history of 30 pack-years but quit the habit 8 years ago. He has an occasional alcohol intake and is not active physically due to his health condition.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Caldwell has a history of hypertension and high cholesterol  for which he has been on medication (Lisinopril 10mg/day and Simvastatin 20mg/day respectively) for 20 years. His mother had a history of abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) and died in her late eighties due to its rupture. He has no known allergies to any particular drug.  Key Complaints:  Mr. Caldwell's main concern is the sudden  severe pain in the middle and lower abdomen that began 3 hours ago  a sensation that he describes as “ripping” and “shooting towards his back”. Additionally  he has felt light-headed and had near syncope episodes today. Probing reveals that he has been experiencing intermittent and mild abdominal discomfort and back pain for the past week  but he did not give it much importance.  Note:  Abdominal aortic aneurysm is prevalent in the demographic of older  white males  with smoking history and positive family history  which is represented here. Uncontrollable hypertension  hyperlipidemia  a sedentary lifestyle  and a history of cardiovascular disease can also contribute to the development of AAA. Sudden  severe abdominal or back pain and symptoms of hypotension can signify an impending AAA rupture  a life-threatening situation.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Patient Profile:  Name: Mr. Robert Smith Age: 73 years Sex: Male Race/Ethnicity: Caucasian  Occupation: Retired Military Officer Residence: Urban  Past Medical History:  Mr. Smith has a 40-year history of smoking two packs of cigarettes a day  has hypertension for which he’s been taking medication for the past ten years  and a family history of AAA (his older brother had ruptured AAA). He also has moderate obesity  with a history of high cholesterol. He is currently under medication for his blood pressure and cholesterol levels. There’s no known history of diabetes or heart diseases.  Primary Complaints:  Mr. Smith attended his routine check-up and complained about a persistent dull ache in his lower back and abdomen that has been present for the last two weeks. He claims the discomfort is constant but not severe  likening it to a ‘gut feeling.' Along with this  he mentions experiencing episodes of mild nausea and unexplained fatigue despite maintaining a little physical activity.  Rationale for Design:  Most patients with AAA present asymptomatically; often it’s an incidental finding or diagnosed when complications occur. But in this case  we have a symptomatic patient. The demographics were chosen based on the literature: AAA is more common in men  typically presents after the age of 65  and is twice as common in smokers. Hypertension is another important risk factor. A family history of AAA also increases the risk. Therefore  this scenario offers a realistic case to teach key points about aneurysm  patient presentation  potential risk factors  and the importance of a thorough medical history to guide the diagnosis.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm   Patient Information:  Mr. Johnson is a 70-year-old Caucasian male with a history of hypertension  high cholesterol  and type 2 diabetes mellitus  and a 45-year smoking habit (1 pack per day). Mr. Johnson is a retired mechanic  lives with his wife  and is socially active.   Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson was diagnosed with hypertension and high cholesterol two decades ago and type 2 diabetes mellitus ten years ago. He has been inconsistently controlling his medical problems with prescribed medications including anti-hypertensives  statins  and oral hypoglycemics due to his concern over side effects. There was no history of any heart disease or strokes  but his father had an abdominal aortic aneurysm rupture at the age of 73.  Because of his long-term smoking habit  he has a moderate chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) but has not considered cessation so far.   Key Complaints: Mr. Johnson visited the clinic with a complaint of mild  intermittent lower back pain for the last two weeks  radiating to his flanks and abdomen  not associated with any bowel or urinary symptoms. He also mentioned a weird sensation of fullness or pulsating mass in the abdomen he noticed a week ago. He denied any recent trauma or heavy lifting.   The prevalence of abdominal aortic aneurysms increases with age and is more commonly found in the male population  particularly Caucasian ethnicity. The major risk factors include smoking  hypertension  hyperlipidemia  and a family history of AAA. History of other vascular diseases and diabetes have also been associated with an increased risk of abdominal aortic aneurysm.   [Patients with an abdominal aortic aneurysm often have no symptoms until the condition reaches an advanced stage or the aneurysm ruptures  leading to a medical emergency. In some cases  patients may experience lower back pain  a pulsating sensation in the abdomen  or abdominal pain.]   In the next part of training  we will illustrate how to perform a clinical examination for abdominal aortic aneurysm and the relevant investigations needed for its diagnosis and management. We will also discuss common pitfalls in diagnosing this condition and how to avoid them.   NOTE: [Text in square brackets] are additional information that could be used for the continuation of the case presentation learning activity.

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  Patient Information: Mr. Paul Jackson  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  comes to the emergency department. Mr. Jackson is a retired steel worker and served in the U.S. army during his younger years. He currently resides in an urban area with his wife.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Jackson was diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia approximately 10 years ago but admits to inconsistent medication use. There's a significant history of cigarette smoking (40 pack-years) although he quit five years ago. He also has a relevant family history of AAA with his elder brother experiencing a ruptured AAA at age 75.  Presenting Complaint:  Mr. Jackson presents with a complaint of sudden-onset lower back pain that started two hours ago. He characterizes his pain as sharp and severe  not radiating  and constant. He denies trauma. He states that he has never experienced pain like this before. He also admits to feeling light-headed and has vomited once at home. He denies chest pain  dyspnea  or lower extremity weakness. He appears to be in considerable discomfort.  Rationale:  The demographic and social details included in this case are representative of key risk factors associated with AAA  including age  male gender  smoking history  family history  and Caucasian ethnicity. Furthermore  the symptoms discussed (abdominal or back pain  light-headedness  and vomiting) are often associated with rapid expansion or impending rupture of an AAA. This case would then lead into a discussion about the differential diagnoses  appropriate clinical and imaging evaluation  emergency management  and surgical intervention. The scenario is designed to emphasize that in an elderly man with risk factors for AAA and a complaint of abdominal or lower back pain  AAA should be at the top of the differential until proven otherwise.

Case Report:  Patient Information:  Mr. Robert Anderson is a 68-year-old Caucasian male who lives alone in an urban region. He is a retired engineer  and widower with two adult children living out-of-state. Mr. Anderson is a former smoker with a 25-pack-year history but quit 15 years ago. He is relatively sedentary and has a diet high in fat and low in fruits and vegetables.  Past Medical History: The patient has a history of hypertension  while managed on lisinopril 20 mg daily  he is often non-compliant with his medication. His other known conditions include hypercholesterolemia and peripheral artery disease. His BMI is classified as overweight  and he has a moderately high alcohol consumption. His father died of an abdominal aortic aneurysm (AAA) at the age of 60.  Chief Complaints: Mr. Anderson visited the clinic today with complaints of intermittent  pulsating abdominal pain for the past week that seems to be gradually worsening. He also reports feeling a pulsating mass in his abdomen. More recently  he started experiencing lower back pain but doesn't recall any injury or strenuous activity.  Case Summary: Abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAA) are most common in men  particularly those of Caucasian descent  over 65 years of age. Risk factors often include a history of smoking  hypertension  hypercholesterolemia  and family history of AAA. They are also likely in individuals who are obese  have a high-fat diet  or a high alcohol usage.  In this case  Mr. Anderson's risk factors including age  gender  medical history  and lifestyle choices puts him at a high risk for AAA. His current complaints of a pulsating abdominal pain and the sensation of an abdominal mass could indicate an undiagnosed AAA. Given his family history  these symptoms cannot be ignored and must be promptly evaluated.  The goal of this case is to help medical students understand the risk factors  complaints  and possible physical findings associated with AAA. They should also consider the importance of compliance with chronic disease management and lifestyle modifications in preventing these types of conditions. Prompt diagnostic measures such as abdominal ultrasound or CT scan should be ordered to confirm the presence of an AAA.

Case Title: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm in an Elderly Male Patient  Patient Information:  Name: Mr. Johnson Age: 73 Sex: Male Ethnicity: Caucasian (Data shows that AAA tends to be most common in Caucasian individuals) Occupation: Retired  Presenting Complaints:  Mr. Johnson presented to the emergency department with sudden  severe pain in his lower back and abdomen. The patient comments that the pain is sharp and persistent  claiming it is unlike anything he has felt before. Furthermore  he is feeling lightheaded and has vomited twice at home before coming to the hospital.  Past Medical History:  Mr. Johnson has been previously diagnosed with hypertension and hyperlipidemia  managed with antihypertensives (Lisinopril) and lipid-lowering medications (Atorvastatin). He has a 40-pack-year smoking history and quit smoking 15 years ago. He has no history of surgeries and is not allergic to any medications. His father died from an 'abdominal explosion'  though Mr. Johnson is unsure of the specifics.   Physical Examination:  Mr. Johnson is noted to be in physical discomfort  holding his abdomen often during the assessment. His abdomen is visibly pulsating. During palpation  an abdominal mass is felt which is tender and pulsating. His blood pressure on presentation was 166/90  and his heart rate at 98 bpm.  This detailed case study accurately represents the risk factors  demographics  and complaints related to Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm. This case serves as a tool to verses the students about diagnostic tests such as ultrasound or CT scan  preventive measures  and potential treatments like endovascular surgery or open abdominal surgery for AAA  as well as emphasize on the importance of Smoking Cessation. It will assist the students in understanding and identifying an emergency situation that calls for prompt recognition  accurate diagnosis  and immediate intervention.

Case Report - Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA)  I. Patient Demographics: Patient is a 70-year-old Caucasian male  retired engineer  lives with his wife and is a former smoker who quit 10 years ago.  II. Past Medical History: The patient has a documented history of hypertension for about 15 years  which is well managed through medication. He has hyperlipidemia  a BMI of 28  and a familial history of cardiovascular disease. His father died of a myocardial infarction at the age of 72 and his elder brother underwent a surgical repair for AAA at the age of 65. The patient had smoked 1 pack per day for 30 years before quitting. He consumes alcohol moderately and does not have a history of illicit drug use.  III. Presenting Complaints: The patient arrived at his primary care doctor  complaining of intermittent  dull abdominal pain that has been ongoing for the past six weeks. The pain had recently intensified in the last 3 days  prompting the visit. He also reported feeling a pulsating sensation in his stomach  general fatigue  occasional low back pain  but denied any instances of syncope  rapid weight loss  or changes in bowel movements. He has not noticed any blood in his stool or urine.  (Note: This complies with demographic data suggesting that AAAs are most common in males  age of 65 or older  with a history of smoking  cardiovascular disease and hypertension. AAA is usually asymptomatic until it is close to rupture  at which point severe abdominal or back pain might occur. However  some patients  like the one in this scenario  may report minor  vague symptoms long before rupture.)

Case Report: Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Demographics:  Mr. T  a 72-year-old Caucasian male  reports he is a former smoker with a 30-pack-year history  having quit 10 years ago. He works retired from a stressful managerial job five years ago. He resides with his wife in a suburban area and admits to moderate daily alcohol consumption. His diet is often high in fats and red meats. His physical activity consists of daily walking for around 30 minutes.  Past Medical History:  Mr. T's medical history consists of hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He has been on treatment for these conditions for the past six years. He has no known allergies. Family history is significant for a brother who died from a ruptured abdominal aortic aneurysm. A general health check 2 years ago was unremarkable and he has not had any recent surgical procedures.   Key Complaints:  Mr. T came to the doctor's office complaining of intermittent mild abdominal and lower back pain for the past month. He has also been feeling a pulsating sensation in his stomach. He has noticed that the pain seems to intensify after meals and when bending over or straining. He denies having any bowel or urinary complaints and weight loss. He has not had any known exposures to infectious diseases.  Remarks:  This training case focuses on abdominal aortic aneurysm  a condition that affects primarily older individuals  particularly males. Risk factors taken into account while designing this training case are age  gender  race  smoking history  family history of AAA  and presence of associated cardiovascular risk factors such as hypertension and hyperlipidemia. With these parameters in place  medical students are able to work on a realistic patient profile while learning the key aspects of diagnosing and treating abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Case Report - Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm  Patient Demographics Gender: Male Age: 73 years old Race: Caucasian Marital status: Married Occupation: Retired  Patient  Mr. James Bowman  is a 73-year-old Caucasian married male  who is a retired construction worker. He has two adult children and three grandchildren. He is a smoker with a 40 pack-year history. He is 5 feet 7 inches and weighs 180 pounds. Patient lives with his wife and enjoys gardening and playing golf during his spare time.  Past Medical History Known hypertensive for the last 15 years  controlled with medical therapy  and is also diagnosed with hyperlipidemia and peripheral artery disease. He has a past surgical history of a cholecystectomy. An identified risk factor includes a positive familial history of aneurysm (his father had a known aneurysm). The patient does not have any known allergies.  Key Complaints Mr. Bowman presented to the clinic with mild intermittent abdominal pain for the past two weeks  which he initially attributed to gastroenteritis. The pain is vaguely localized  and described as ""deep-seated "" of a pulsating nature. In addition  he has noticed a pulsating ""mass"" like structure in his abdomen.   In training discussions  students should note that most abdominal aortic aneurysms are asymptomatic  but approximately half can present with abdominal  lower back  or flank pain. Older males with cardiovascular risk factors (smoking  hypertension) and a family history are at higher risk  which is evident here. Further diagnostics are necessary to confirm  including a physical examination and imaging (e.g.  ultrasound  CT). If an aneurysm is confirmed  discussion about ongoing surveillance or surgical repair options would be dependent on size  rate of growth  and the patient's overall health profile.   Please note that an abdominal aortic aneurysm is a potentially life-threatening condition that can lead to sudden death due to massive hemorrhage and prompt identification can greatly influence the prognosis.
